RATING: 4
Played once.  I enjoyed it, but didn't find it that exciting.  More plays needed.
Update: Played again. More exciting but less enjoyable. I've read that a lot of people just like the aspect of building their own farm.  I don't feel like that myself, but maybe that is me being competitive.  I find the victory points have to be considered, which puts a lot of pressure on in terms of: food, fences, family members, animals, vegetables, house construction.
Theres a lot to the game and I find it pretty overwhelming.  Hopefully it will get easier.
Update: Played for the 3rd time, this time with cards.  I've got to say I just don't enjoy this game. I came 2nd on a 5 player game so I've mostly 'got it' now, but I think I find having too much choice a bit too stressful and I'm too competitive to just enjoy building my own farm. Downgraded to a 5.

Update: I think I just don't enjoy heavy euros. Where is the fun? Downgraded to a 4.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'm going to mark it down one though because I really am terrible at it and, as a consequence don't enjoy it quite as much as I could do.

RATING: 9

I am glad my husband is slowly beginning to like this game better (after he won a couple of games).  Introducing the complex cards was a good idea.  Even my 6 y.o. didn't feel that the easy deck really added to the game, but the complex deck does begin to make things interesting.

RATING: 9
This game instantly became one of my favourite boardgames of all time the first time I played it - and has continued to get better and better.

I found the instructions extremely complicated, considering the game is actually very easy to play. It is very challenging and has great depth, whilst remaining fairly simple.

Definately recommended.

RATING: 9

But after a few plays it really grew on me. This is one of my very favorite games, and by far my favorite "Euro" worker placement.

UPDATE 8-15-14: Bumped down a bit to an 8.5. It is still one of my favorites, but it just does not hit the table as much as it used to as we have so many other games that we would rather play.

UPDATED 10-10-14: Played it again recently and bumped it up to a 9. What can I say, I still really like it.

RATING: 7
Might have been the first worker placement I played, and still one of the best. For me the threat of the wrong decisions potentially making you crash and burn rather than merely 'do less well' makes the game far more tense and exciting than you'd expect. Not to everyone's tastes, but it sure appeals to mine.

update 22/06/2016: as I've played more and more fresh takes on Euro mechanics my desire to play this has dropped somewhat. Still a classic, but no longer in my personal upper echelons.

RATING: 10
I've been holding out for a year and a half before allowing anything to be as good as chess despite playing excellent game after excellent game thanks to recommendations on the geek but Agricola has cracked my resolve. Simply superb. Fast but filled with tough decisions. Only played with two and it has a perfect level of player interaction. No two games are the same. Complex where it needs to be and simple where it needs to be. It may take a while but it is destined to be number one. Congratulations to all concerned. It's a masterpiece.

RATING: 8.8
I have only recently discovered my love for Agricola. I have played Caverna before Agricola, so I had never strived to try the older brother, but when I tried it, I have realized that cards really do make all the difference. I love games in which you do not have enough time to do everything you want, so optimising and careful planning are the key. The theme is freaking gorgeous - I really do feel like I am a poor farmer fighting for his life :D

A true classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very thematic worker placement game, with excellent scalability and good variability, about building the best farm.

It's hard to believe that such a strategic "gamer's game" could be so accessible to the average non-gamer, and that it's designed by Uwe Rosenberg of all people (of Bohnanza fame).  This is a game that once played, people want to immediately play it again.  Despite the fact that the main mechanism is worker placement, which is getting overly tired these days, the game still feels fresh, as it has a very unique and strong theme.  Plus the huge amount of cards (occupation, which add special abilities/skills, and minor improvements, which again add special abilities) adds variability.  It should be noted that the cards are not nearly as crucial to gameplay as one would think.  I have bitched and moaned practically every game I've played about my terrible starting hand, and won most of those games without the need to play hardly any cards (although I would hope that having and playing a lot of strong cards is a viable strategy- edit: it is, as I've even won by playing a lot of crap cards).

The components are very good (particularly if you have the animeeples, which I do), the scalability is excellent, and the game, while lasting 14 rounds, goes by very quickly and gives you a lot to think about during and after the completion of the game.  It's all about balance, balance, balance, as points are awarded (or deducted) for essentially every possible category in the game (3 different animal types, vegetables, grain, pastures, fields, stables, family members, filled/empty spaces, buildings, cards, etc.).

If ever a "gamer's game" is to become mainstream, and break through to the masses, this is that game.  I've recently noticed this for sale at Indigo/Chapters, which is a real positive sign (they've expanded their zone beyond Settlers and Carcassonne).  Edit: Agricola is long gone from those shelves, looks like the herd weren't up to the challenge after all, too bad.  Anyways, this game is definitely deserving of it's overall #1 ranking here on BGG!

Own complete [boardgame=37235]Z[/boardgame], [boardgame=39256]O[/boardgame], [boardgame=59158]CZ[/boardgame], [boardgame=85704]G[/boardgame], [boardgame=38733]X[/boardgame], [boardgame=83697]F[/boardgame], [boardgame=103182]NL[/boardgame], [boardgame=103183]WC[/boardgame], [boardgame=131403]FL/WA[/boardgame], [boardgame=130847]Pi[/boardgame], [boardgame=150732]Bielefeld[/boardgame], [boardgame=166463]France[/boardgame], [boardgame=39090]L[/boardgame]  and [boardgame=234218]Artifex[/boardgame] expansion decks, along with [boardgame=38641]Through the Seasons postcard[/boardgame], the [boardgame=43018]Moor expansion[/boardgame], [boardgame=73833]Goodies[/boardgame], a homemade copy of the [boardgame=113413]Ereigniskarten (events)[/boardgame] cards, the [boardgame=111165]Biogas Plant[/boardgame] promo card, [boardgame=210625]5-6 Player expansion[/boardgame],  animeeples, vegimeeples, resourceeples.

RATING: 8
After a long break, I finally decided to give this one another go-around.  Apparently, my tastes have changed as I had an enjoyable experience.  The main draw of the game appears to be the stress of not being able to complete everything by the end of the game.  If that doesn't sound fun to you, probably pass on Agricola.

---

(2012-10-01) Additional plays continue to produce enjoyable play experiences.  Like wine, this one seems to get better with age.

RATING: 10
After a few plays at BGG.con '07 I can safely say that the hype is totally justified! I haven't felt this way about a game since I discovered Settlers oh so long ago... my German copy is on it's way, and the Z-Man edition has been pre-ordered. I am officially obsessed!The game itself is wonderful... so many paths emerge from the card variance and the actions picked that it would be hard to see two games go the same way. I can't wait to immerse myself in this one! UPDATE: I have played solo, two-player, three-player, four-player and five-player. I have loved it all! Each iteration is a little different, which adds yet another great level to the game (resource availability, timing issues, etc). This game will end up being a 10 for me, I am sure. UPDATE: After 25 plays and still wanting to only play this game above all others, I am going to upgrade to a 10. This game is not perfect, but for me, it doesn't get much better.

RATING: 6
Welcome to action-paralysis hell.

Great game if you have players who can plan contingencies for their contingent contingencies knowing exactly what they're going to do on their turn no matter how other players before them act. Otherwise just pop a bag of popcorn and watch some paint dry because that would be a more enjoyable and efficient use of your time. . .

Also, the rulebook for this edition could likely fall under the category of "crime against humanity", do yourself a favor and download the headless hollow summary and print one for all of your players.

Update: up from a 7 to an 8. Ok, the game does have depth. Like a friend of mine pointed out, this is as close as we get to multi-player chess. He has a point. However, the other games referred to here are still more 'fun', imo.

RATING: 7
Habe meine Meinung revidiert. Zuerst fand ich das Spiel nur schlecht, aber nun nach 3 weiteren Spielen, finde ich es immerhin so gut, dass ich behalten werde. Ich bin zwar immer noch der Meinung, das ich es schade finde, das am Ende die Runden zur Ernte immer kürzer werden (ich sehe auch keinen Sinn drin, wenn man schon etwas aufbaut, was der Realität entsprechen soll!), aber es hat mir nun trotzdem Spaß gemacht. Aber am besten spielt man es mit Karten, damit man am Ende wenigstens noch etwas machen kann, anosnsten ist es meist nur ein gegurke ums aufrüsten. Deshalb auch im Moment nur eine 7, aber auch das könnte höher werden. Großer Vorteil. Durch die Karten wird man nie immer und die gleiche Strategie fahren! Deshalb sollte der Langzeitspielspaß ungebremst sein.

RATING: 10
Agricola is not a game for everyone, but it consistently offers up the most rewarding board-game experience I have encountered. It is a great couple's game, endlessly customisable, with plenty of variety to keep things interesting, and surprisingly accessible. Few other games offer up the same 3D, tactile experience of Agricola, and those that do, don't provide the same depth of gameplay. Agricola is a masterpiece of board-game design.

RATING: 7.5
I'm pleased with the results. To be sure, there are negatives. The rulebook is poor given the relative simplicity of play, the components sprawl all over the place when playing and makes for an intimidating experience, the number of cards feels completely over the top - like a movie with a large budget but no editor - and in general, there's nothing terribly novel about the mechanics.

On the up side, it has good pace (but plays long), flowed well and made sense. It does have a worthy depth to explore and I'd like to know it better. This game somehow "fits" well and plays smooth - great construction, not just in components, but in mechanics. The theme is cute and well integrated. My wife says she'd try it one more time and my daughter says she prefers Stone Age. Friends find it "alright" so far, but overly complicated (over powering by the number of components and cards) for what it is. As for me, I remain ready to play again. Something keeps drawing me back.

RATING: 9
2017-11-28
Agricola is close to the ultimate worker placement. Competition over the best spots is fierce and you never quite get to accomplish everything you want in a game. The need to feed your family after each harvest puts pressure on you and creates a natural limit for growth. When the game first came out back in 2008, the theme was refreshing since there were not too many games about farming. To be honest, I was not too excited about the theme at first, and the initiation game was a sore multi hour experience of down time. But it did not take long before I embraced the game, and as of this writing (2017) I think the theme is pure gold.

The absolutely best part of the game are the occupation cards, since without them Agricola would be just another soulless worker placement game. The cards allow for a myriad of strategies and no two games play the same and I actually find the initial analysis of the cards the most fun part of the game. Your analysis gives you a long term plan to follow and helps with tactical choices. This is something I am always seeking after in all games, i.e., a balance between tactics and strategy. Agricola offers both. 

2015-11-04
To my big surprise I sold this in an auction. Might be that I'll regret it later, but at this point of my life I just felt like getting rid of games that haven't seen any or very little play in the past 3-4 years. It seems that nowadays the games hitting the table are action packed sub 90 minute games instead of longer ones like Agricola.  If I only had more space to store my games...

2010-03-15
Truly a great game. There are so many ways to win and so many things to do. The different difficulty levels make this one of the most versatile titles out there. However, not worth a 10... maybe a little deeper story is required.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After a couple more plays, this is a solid 9. Great game, endless replayability, feels different every time (so far), interesting choices. I'm really liking this one.

=====================================================
Played for the first time, it felt like Roads and Boats done better. R&B had too much accounting for me  (and I'm pretty decent with math) and was too fiddly. Agricola is too, but to a lesser degree, and is also shorter making the fun/hour ratio much better in my opinion.
Rating is bound to go up with more playings.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Hmmm...scratches head...I enjoyed this game and can see why so many on the Geek rave about it.  It certainly a Gamer's Game par excellence.  In many ways it reminded me of an expanded Caylus.  It certainly seems less linear and more variable than Caylus, but the downside to that is that it's also longer and more difficult to get your head around at first.

But there are problems that mean I just can't rate this higher than a 7:  

1. It's one of those games where there is likely to be quite lot of downtime between your turns - and that's never a good thing.  
2.There is player interaction, but not quite enough for me.  
3.It's also maybe just a little bit too much of a calculation game.  That can also bog-down the game even more, and after a while, all that calculating numbers gets a bit dull.  I find myself desperate for something exciting to happen...instead one just keeps building the puzzle.
4. And this brings me on my main gripe - it's just not got as a high a "fun factor" as many other euros.  Yes, it's brain-burning, and brain-burning can be a major part of fun.  However, the other part of fun (excitement, unexpected interaction and edginess), is not there for me.
5. The rules are both poorly written and hard to grasp.

Having said all of that:
  
I like the heaviness of it and the theme is fine considering it's actually pretty abstract at base. 
It's also deep and variable and the artwork is great, though I think cubes for animals is irritating.

Overall, I really don't think it's worth all the hype it gets but it's certainly a solid 7.  To get more it needs magic and excitement.

And that's not to say that deep games can't have magic or excitement: to give one example off the top of my head -  El Grande is just as deep, but is also less mathematical and ultimately more fun and edgy.  

This may all come down to taste in the end and I guess I find this game good, but not compulsive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.45
Solid game sure to be appreciated by people who like heavier strategy games.  Less likely to be appreciated by people who feel that heavy thinking games feel more like homework than a game (particularly where suboptimal decisions can severely handicap a player for the entire game).  Several people who I regularly game with find this game to be too stressful (what?  My family is running out of food again??).  Excellent game for teaching the importance of engine-building.

Early mistakes can be brutal which, over time, tends to lead to fairly predictable early and mid-game play.  Fortunately there is a fair amount of variety with the minor improvements and occupation decks (with lots of unnecessary expansion decks in case you get bored with all the ones that come with the base game).  The luck element of drawing a better starting set of improvements and occupations can be mitigated through card drafting or other methods so that players are still more or less similarly situated at the beginning of play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
So I am getting this game, the highest-rated of them all. And it has a theme of farming, which is appealing to my whole family. So I was all excited when I bought this game, for the steep price of seventy bucks. 
My disappointment started when I unpacked this game. No nicely designed landscape and pieces, as I would expect from an upscale game. But just boring game plans for placing the action cards. It wasn't even obvious which side was the front or the back. One of the plans has even to be turned around during the game, totally unnecessary. The farms: just boring green rectangles. And the resources are just round and square color coded wooden blocks. And then hundreds of game cards, nicely designed, but when you start up you only play with a few of them. And it turns out that their design isn't so great after all, as important information is so small printed that they are hard to read even for people who do not wear glasses.
Well, I shrugged this off and started studying the rules. Oh what a mess these are! Confusing and full of errors. Example drawings are rare and not aligned with the text. So now you start looking for the drawings and assign them to the rule text. 
The rules of this game are very complex. I have no problem with that, if the rule book help you mastering these. But where is the rule "My first game"? Agricola has such a rule, called the "family game". But in order to play this game you have to work yourself through the whole complexity of rules only to learn what you can leave away. Why not explain the base game first and then add all the rest as advanced options? This would makes way more sense.
Summary: I got extremely frustrated when studying the rules (for 2 hours). And my coplayers got VERY bored when I explained the rules to them.
But then the surprise for everyone: The game itself wasn't bad at all, and this is the reason why it gets an ok rating. The game mechanics are really good and allow the application of strategies. It was actually fun to build up the farm. But without studying the scoring rules, it is easy to apply wrong tactics that make your farm look good, but still make you loose the game. 

Is this the best boardgame of all times, as the rating implies? No! By far not! Not even close! I don't think it is even worth the 70 bucks that I payed for it. But it is ok fun, and I will play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.1
How bad is Agricola?  Well, it's not as bad as [thing=483][/thing], which is why this is not a "1" rating.  You may say, "Hey, this game isn't broken."  Yes it is, and I'll tell you why.

When I got back into gaming around 2009, I was exposed to Eurogames.  I was an old school wargamer, but with 25+ years of no wargaming, my senses were dull and I fell for the trap of Eurogames and was trapped in a cold & dull prison of my own making.  I heard grumblings about a "lack of theme" and "multi-player solitaire" but what the heck did that mean?  Can't you see that Ticket to Ride is about trains, Pandemic is about saving the world, Power Grid is about creating electricity and San Juan is about -- um -- buildings?  Yeah... buildings.

I had yet to play any of the revered "top 10" on BGG, and then a well-intentioned soul invited me to play Agricola.  Oh goodie, the #2 ranked game.  This is going to be awesome sauce.

So what happened?  I woke up.  I had been under the spell of Wormtongue who was telling me Euros are elegant, beautiful, and deep.  But while playing Agricola, I suddenly understood what "themeless abomination" meant.  This game has as much to do with farming as Nexus Ops does with ballet.  It was a 2+ hour exercise in boredom and I was trying to build my "farm" better than everybody else, and build it myself.  Come on, the Amish help each other raise barns!  They even know multi-player solitaire sucks!  

As I was "playing" ("suffering" is more accurate, because "play" infers I was having fun), I was actually thinking, "You know, if the Rapture happened now, I wouldn't have to finish this horrible game and nobody would hate me for cutting out on it."  I frequently pinched myself hoping to wake up.  The words "Calgon: take me away!" were uttered under my breath.  I even subtly pulled out my wallet, flipped it open, leaned over discreetly and said, "Scotty, beam me up" hoping against all hope that it would actually work!  

Since none of that worked, I was at least hoping that one of the event thingies that come up would have unleashed a dinosaur across someone's farm.  THAT would have been really cool and might have saved this bore-fest.

This game actually has the unique ability to move your entire gaming table at near-light speed, because time slows to a crawl as you suffer through it.  It may have only been 2 hours, but it felt like 2 centuries.  Poke an icepick through my head and put me out of my misery!

When it was over, I was happy.  They summed up the victory points and I won -- not because I had the most (I promise you, I did not), but because I was spared the continuing torture of this game, and unlike the poor saps at the table, I would never have to play this again.  This game tried everything to break me, but I overcame!

"Yeah, but it's not broken!" you're saying.  Well, remember all of those Euros that I liked?  After that, I hopped in my car, drove home, got on BGG, and lowered the rating of [u]every single one of them[/u]!  Like sunlight through a magnifying glass, I suddenly understood what [i]multi-player solitaire[/i] and [i]themeless[/i] meant, and I saw Euros for what they are.  This game is so broken that it broke an entire genre for me!  How's [b]that[/b] for broken?  

Now that Wormtongue's spell was broken, I rose and embraced the glorious wargames of my youth and their distant cousin, Ameritrash.   So if not for Agricola, I would still be one of those poor unfortunate souls pushing a wooden rectangle (pretending it's a train) across Neverland and moving cubes from hither and yon ... or as my buddy says, try to be the grand poo-bah of latrine inspection, or whatever lame-brained "theme" these Euros come up with.  I would be one of those unfortunate souls pretending boredom is "elegant" and BGG rankings actually mean something.  So in a sense, those 2 hours of boredom and torture served a greater purpose of personal emancipation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

-------------------------------------------------
Think on "Sim City" on a farm...
A good sucessor to Puerto Rico. Great components, both basic and advanced play modes, great replayability with all the available decks and expansions, and even the theme seems to be not so pasted as in other euros (you really will suffer for your farmers family, when it has been a bad harvest and you have to kill your only little cow to feed them..). Also, it plays well with 2 and 1 players (it has a solo mode).
Absolutely addictive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Monopoly -> Catán -> Agrícola
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game!  Worker placement for food, resources (including animeeples, cubic or non-geometrical) and actions, a small construction aspect (rooms & stables, fences, major and minor improvements), and card-playing for enhanced abilities (professions and minor improvements).

The game is driven by food.  Food, food, food.  You must feed your family or else the coyotes will get them and you will lose.  Food is so important that it's everyone's primary concern.  Resources are most useful in the ways they enable you to purchase things and/or play cards that enhance your food production efficiency.  Plus, more family members equals more food consumption but more actions.  Tricky balance.

I don't have (non-geometrical) animeeples yet, wooden or plastic.  I am sad.  My cubic sheep do not frolic.

Rated an 8 (vs. a 9 or 10) because while food drives the players, the cards drive the game.  The cards a player draws will determine the best direction, as well as strongly influencing the player's success.  Some cards are clearly better than others, and this disparity is glaringly obvious at times.

On the plus side, there are so many cards (E, I, K, Z decks) that replay value is very high.

On the minus side, scales poorly to 5.  More players means a *much* longer game and a *much* rougher game (more contention for worker placement).  With 4 or 5 players, going 4th or 5th really bites.  (In one 4 player game, I went 4th for 4 rounds out of the first 5!  Very not good.)

My recommendation is 3 players max, 4 if at least three of them are familiar with the game.  I do not recommend playing a 5 player game (though I suppose sometimes we must).

Similarly, there's a lot for a new player to absorb.  The sheer number of choices is overwhelming at first, particularly since there are so many different strategies that require such different directions and planning.  In addition, the initial hand of 14 cards can be difficult to grasp and/or use.  If you're playing a teaching game, plan on it going much longer than you'd hope.

Do not, I repeat, DO NOT play this game with the AP-prone.  You will regret it.  You have been warned.

You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.  You must play Agricola.

Really, just give in, give it a shot and determine for yourself whether it lives up to the hype.  In my opinion, it does and it's worth every dollar, euro, swiss franc or currency-of-choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
Very good game, but I'm not getting the fandom it receives here.  I don't think I've ever turned down a game of it, but occasionally it feels like work (mostly when you can see who's winning but have to wait a couple of hours for it to happen).

Update: years after the first few goes, I've had another game.  I enjoyed it, but I dunno whether it'll ever beat 8 on my scale unless we switch to variant rules that allow for hand management.  In the recent game, the bloke who drew the best hand at the start won, and looked like he would from the get go.  Throughout the game he seemed to have the luxury of making second-best moves quite regularly (certainly the guy who seemed savviest over the board never had a chance; he came in a distant second, and no I am neither of these people).  I can understand the point of, and thoroughly appreciate, a shorter luck based game in which, over multiple plays, this all washes out, and I can also understand the point of etc a longish luck based game where a lot of fancy and skilful tap dancing is needed across the game to make the most of your luck, but a long game skewed by a card deal at the start is not so great.  (Drafting's the obvious fix, which I haven't tried yet.)  Doubtless some of Agricola's compensating virtues are still invisible to me, but I'm not that interested in bludgeoning my way to an appreciation of them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's hard to say whether any game TRULY captures the choices of a 17th Century, European, subsistence lifestyle but I imagine a scarcity of resources and a general disdain for the differences between green and brown were closer to fact than fiction. The playing area is fiddly and messy. Animeeples are a must, and their absence from standard versions of the game smack of an unfinished product. 

Mechanically, worker placement, like deck-building, is one of those artificial gaming genres that is much less interesting than it seems. Resource conversion games are a dime-a-dozen, yet Agricola seems to find a nice blend of manageable quantities with variable qualities. Occupation cards and Improvements keep things interesting, but also add a degree of variance unusual for a game requiring this much mathematical analysis. 

There is something of a masochistic dynamic to Agricola. It definitely feels like work, but sometimes in a rewarding way. I wouldn't say I look at my farm with pride so much when I'm finished - I always feel like there was more I could have done differently - but I do think, for a game, Agricola does a remarkable job of making you feel that the struggles to build and feed a household from scratch. I'm still bothered by player order issues, and don't think the in-game option to change order solves the Eurogame problem of the experienced player leeching from the inexperienced player upstream. 

Overall, I don't mind Agricola, and it's a game I might return to when my kids are teenagers. It's a game I'm happy to play if you need a third or fourth (won't play two or five), but it's not a game I think has much impact beyond the board. In other words, it's a fun and immersive puzzle, but lacks the narrative punch of a truly great game. 
.
I'D RATHER WE PLAY: A strange comparison, but at this stage I'd rather play [thing=13][/thing]. Agricola is one of the more engaging modern Euros I've played, but I find the reliance on competent play from opponents a dealbreaker for the effort required. This is a problem I have with the genre overall. If I was going to own one of this type of game, this would be it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Impressions after one play (Family version):[/b]
Agricola was no.1 on BGG when I first came here. Since then, I wanted to try it, to see what makes it so special.
It's a game where you try to build your farm, raise animals, plow and harvest fields, and feed your family.
What I like:
- it runs very smoothly and it doesn't take too long to explain
- you are really connected to what you are doing
What I didn't like:
- it feels that it's over too soon (you don't have enough time to do everything you want)

[b]After second game (Normal version)[/b]
+ Minor improvements and Occupations add to the complexity of the game
- becomes AP-prone and lasts too much

RATING: 4
Mechanically, this is an ok Eurogame. However, both the theme and the fact that it's a Eurogame do not really appeal to me (although the fences and the animals look cool!). The cards in your hand can and willnmake the game unbalanced, and make you feel treated unfairly. That one time you can pull off a really cool combo with those cards doesn't make up for the fact that the cards in other cases play themselves... Paradoxically, the "family version" is more balanced and less luck-depended (since you have no hand cards).
But I think if you like Eurogames and don't hate the theme, this could be one of the better games for you. 
Only keep in mind that with a lot of players, the duration of the game (and also downtime in between turns) lengthens drastically. It's playable solo too, which takes about only 20 minutes.

Theme (artwork/story/...)
1/2
Gameplay (smooth play/player interaction/strategy&tactics/depth)
2.5/5
Fun factor (can you afford a smile during play?)
0.5/3

RATING: 5
[With the Z-Deck & Farmers of the Moor, for whatever that's worth]

Huh, it really is as good as they say, perhaps.  Addicting as heck, Caylus-you-can-play-three-times-in-a-row good.  I have yet to win, of course, but that's to be expected.

REVISED:  After 7 plays (in short order), I'm downgrading "the 'gric" from a 10.  It's a very good game, yes.  It's not as amazing as it looks at first; there is a certain _sameness_ even with the cards, once you learn how to optimize fairly effectively, not the endless variety the cards seem to promise, but don't really deliver.  Jambo and Race for the Galaxy aren't the same kind of thing, obviously, but they may deliver more variety in the end than Agricola does, and that's a good thing.

REVISED:  Haven't played in a while, downgrading -- the issues with Le Havre show me some of what makes this not as good as it should be, and the "build THIS farm" bugs me more in retrospect.  Still a solid game, of course, but over-rated.

REVISED AGAIN:  Ok, played more, added Through the Seasons, etc.  You build the same farm and wish for more resources, and find the cards unexciting.  At least I do.  Meh.

REVISED AGAIN:  Farmers of the Moor I like in some ways but I still don't like Agricola that much, alas.

RATING: 7
It's one of those worker placement and maximize your victory points type of game. 

The whole game evolves on what cards you begin with and max out what's on the table. 

It's boring because it so dependent on whats left on board to do on your turn. The game felt that the player on the right tells you what you can do and the flow goes round the table. An entertainment of restrictive play. 

It's interesting because, from the above chaos, you can still manage to assemble some form of cohesion to get victory points. 

Not the best game but it does entertain your inner frustration. A game that truly plays the player.

RATING: 7.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Playing the game is similar to playing the boardgame version of harvest moon.  

Players control 2 - 5 pieces/workers to plow fields, sow seeds, upgrade house, reproduce offsprings (for more pieces), fence up stables, collect animals, collect food, make a minor or major improvements for the player.

At every harvest phase of the game, enough food must be supplied to every piece players controlled in the game or players have to beg to food to feed them.  In the harvest phase, seeds that are sowed will be harvested, animals could be breed and multiply.  At the 14th (last) round, victory points are counted and the one with the most victory points wins.

Good points: Every action move taken first will result in delaying of taking other actions.  All actions seemed to be equally tempting. Actions could be snatched by other players which makes the game more interesting.

Bad points: The worst user manual I have ever read so far.  It took me a long time before I can understand the game.  For those who doesn't like luck factor in the game, a good set of occupation & minor improvement cards will really make a difference in the game.  If playing on single player, it is tiring to refill all the resources alone and may forget to refill at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nothing new.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A future classic. Three games in one box.

You are a farmer with a basic farm - over the course of the game you are trying to make the best farm by assigning workers to actions.

By taking an action you block it for all other players.

You start with just two workers but they can reproduce giving you more actions per turn, but any offspring must be fed every harvest season and failure to do so is disatrous.

A solitaire version for loners.
A family version that cuts some of the complexities out yet remains exciting and fresh.
The full version adds a dizzying array of cards (minor improvements to your farm and "occupations" for your workers)that make for a different game every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
+Farmers of the Moor
+Bielefeld Deck
+Gamers' Deck
+Through the Seasons
+WC Deck 2011
+Glonnacker (printed)
+NL Deck (in Dutch)
+Belgium Deck (in Dutch)

A challenging game that feels quite cut-throat with two players. There's a nice blend of long-term strategy mixed with tactical decisions along the way. Often times, your strategy going into round one will change drastically by later rounds, as you missed a chance to play the improvement or occupation you planned to play, got blocked out of a critical action, needed to deny your opponent of a critical action, or found a different path to victory based on the resources and actions available. The cards give this game the depth and variability to keep it engaging for years to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Solid game, in my top 5 worker placement games so far. 

However, in one game, we found game-end scoring cards to be extremely powerful with one player getting 11 points and little diversification beyond one of each item and no empty spaces. Since the player had the minor improvements and occupations that supported house expansion and upgrade, this was a natural route for him.

So, we did a quick look at our game sheets and noticed that the winner was always someone who had a combination of the most: stone houses, family members, and points from cards. And at least one other past game was won by a player that had house expansion and upgrade support cards. Maybe there is a pattern here?

*** Update 1: I never really want to play this game, but when we do play it, I enjoy it - very attractive game, nice cards, lots of choices, interesting mechanic, decent end-game scoring. I just can't explain why I'm not ever really enthused to play it. ***

*** Update 2: Now I can articulate why I don't care for Agricola. It is too long for what it's worth. My patience for lengthy worker placement games has worn thin, mostly because you do the same actions over and over again until you can hit a certain mass to trigger the game end condition, or until the final round is reached. I think it boils down to... I don't like "solitaire" style games with low interaction that are big time sinks. If it's under 2 hours from rules review to game end, then I can really appreciate it. Otherwise, it too much time to spend on a game. So, when is Agricola the card game or abridged version coming out? (Just cause it seems to be a trend with board game "suites".) ***

Rule clarifications: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/332022

RATING: 8
Gran juego de gestión de recursos con el objetivo de administrar la vida en una granja:construir la casa, aumentar la familia, cuidar de los animales... Mediante el método de elección de roles vamos posicionando a los miembros de la familia en las diferentes acciones que van saliendo a lo largo de la partida. Mantiene la tensión durante toda la partida.Importante uso de cartas, cosa que a mí personalmente no me agrada del todo. Gran rejugabilidad., para muchos el mejor juego de mesa de la historia. RATING: 9
one of the best!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My opinion of this game has changed since I first bought it. At first I thought it was great. Now I think it's amazing.

The problem with owning so many games is that you really want to play all of them. You want to make sure you're justifying every purchase, but I don't know if I can do that with Agricola. Every time I've played the game has been a unique and satisfying experience. I've not played a game of this where I felt that I went into it a set strategy.

I've heard a lot of complaints that people do not like "building the same farm over and over", but I think they're missing the point a little bit. It's not about the product at the end, it's about the journey to get there. We all know what it takes to make the most points; it's written right on every player aid card. The problem is that getting there is not easy for everyone, especially with the time limit set on the game.

It's a great experience. With so many decks, variations, and now expansions coming out I can see myself owning and playing Agricola for a long time.

RATING: 8.5
Along with Le Havre it is my favorite strategy game (Puerto Rico is less engaging but funnier somehow). Agricola is a masterpiece in every respect. Everything works perfectly. The only home rule I made for two players is to start the game with three farmers instead of two in order to have more actions to perform. In two the game can be incredibly short sometimes. Lot has been said and written on this game, I can't but stress how this work really put your mind at work! At the end, whether you win or lose, you always have a very gratifying experience.

RATING: 8
A surprisingly well-themed engine-building game; and not all that different from most engine-building games, apart from an unending supply of options. Nevertheless, it IS a very good game!
It's only real negatives are two:
1) There is not a great deal of player interaction, apart from, "Hey! I wanted that action, and now you've taken it!", and
2) It is waaaay too long for what it offers. If I want an engine-building game (which I don't, very often), I (and you!) can get the same challenge from shorter games....Carson City, anyone?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A worker placement game with (unfortunately) "points salad" scoring that forces diversity.  The best part of the game is the tension/stress that comes from having to feed your family.  There are a lot of different occupation and improvement cards that change the feel and strategy of each game, so you can't just optimize your play once and repeat.  I've heard Caverna allows you to win without having to diversify, but to me that's part of the challenge of Agricola and what makes it so tense at times.

RATING: 10
I was sceptical when I read that this is a game that you're a farmer. Seriously? Well I decided to give it a shot and I was instantly drawn into what is one of the best worker placement/crisis management games out there! A fantastic game and among my favourites! It scales very good with any number (haven't played it with 5...) and with such a huge variety with the different decks (even in only the base game there are 3 decks!) every play is different and you have to carefully plan what you'll do while you keep an eye to your opponents and try to see what cards they're playing and try to take the resources and actions you can before they do! The solo experience is also very good with it's puzzly feeling!

RATING: 10
1-5(3,4)

Stressful, but in a good way.  It's rewarding to see your farm at the end, and I feel that the variety is enough here to create different plays each time through.

With additional players (I often play two) this becomes completely different and almost as if you have to relearn how to play. Of course I know how to play, but the different strategies and resource balances and actions, etc. can make a winning 2p strategy near useless 4p. Makes it all the more brilliant, and challenging.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Resource
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A worker-placement/resource management game. It's easy to teach (though we had some problems learning our first time, as it was the group's first worker-placement game). It has built-in scaling to make it enjoyable for any number of players.  The many decks of Improvements and Occupations (and the sheer number of cards and combinations in each) guarantee a lot of replay value for it.

There are a lot of fiddly bits representing the resources available to your farming village, which must be fiddled with constantly, which can get time-consuming, especially later in the game or with more players. Second, there are some definite balance issues between some of the cards available, with some being all-around useful, some being useful if you have set your family on a certain path to prosperity, and some just sitting in your hand forever.

(Update) Tried a "drafting" mechanic for assigning occupations and minor improvements after seeing somebody recommend it here.  It's a fairly solid variant: it prevents the issue of getting dealt a crap hand, but it's still frustrating to see somebody (other than me, of course) playing a Wet Nurse.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Agricola is one of that rapidly expanding family of action selection and economic engine building games.  The sheer and growing choice of available actions is reminiscent of Caylus, as is the competition to grab them before an opponent.  Thematically, I think this doesn't quite work in Agricola; why can't I bake bread because a neighbour fired up her oven before me?  However, the rest of the game gives a decent sense of building up a farm.  I have only played the full game, which introduces a huge variety of occupations and minor improvements to increase the strategic options.  The scoring system rewards diversification of crops and livestock and there's a real sense of time pressure to get it all done in just 14 turns.  Agricola plays quickly and doesn't outstay its welcome.  The quality of the components and the artwork is good, though something other than cubes to represent the livestock would have been nice.

This may be the best Euro efficiency game that I've played.  And yet the issues I have with this genre remain.  Player interaction is limited to thwarting another player by taking an action ahead of them; there is no trade, no cooperation, no burning of barns.  Agricola feels to me like a multi-player puzzle, albeit a highly variable one.  This isn't how I like to spend my gaming time.

RATING: 8.5
UPDATED: (7 -> 8) More games with improved start techniques like keep 7 of 10 Occupations and Minor Improvements or card drafting makes the game *much* richer strategically.
-------------------------------------
UPDATED: (5.5 -> 7) I played again and I have to admit that there are fun things about Agricola.
-------------------------------------
INITIAL: Agricola is another moderately boring, lack-of-interaction, everyone has their own mini-board resource efficiency game (see Puerto Rico, San Juan, Princes of Florence, etc.).  That said, for the style, it has been interesting enough to bother learning what makes it tick.

NOTE: The rule variants (back of instructions) for varying the initial card distribution mechanism resolves the glaring weakness with the game -- luck with initial cards is much more important than strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Includes:
[thing=43018][/thing]

:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
Once the #1 listing on BGG overall, and I'd say that's accurate. Worker placement, tons of variable cards, initial strategic draft, lovely Klemens Franz art, deep thematic integration, devious player interaction, (some) engine building, great build-your-own-player-board, and external pressure with thematic scoring.

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
The pressure of the game is excellent. I absolutely disagree with people who say this game is "punishing" or should be called "misery farm." In 30+ games, I've seen someone take a begging card... ONCE. And then they played Mendicant to get rid of it. Honestly, no one should be taking begging cards. This is a not a "you suck at this game" comment, but more according to the spirit of the design--if your post-Black Death family is going to make it in the long haul, you need to diversify your farm so one singular blight doesn't wipe it all out. That's the scoring scheme in a nutshell, and the feed-your-family harvest mechanic keeps you on that track. It's not truly constraining, it just captures the theme of the game both in each harvest and each part of the scoring rubric. As a result, the challenge and fun comes from seeing how much you can exploit the game state (and other players) to excel in spite of the constraints.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
Playing with the huge number of cards is both a strength and weakness, though I still say it's playtested/balanced far in favor of strength. That said, even with drafting, some games simply feature cards with little synergy and oomph, leading to more generic play. I've never found these sessions lacking, but I have noticed exceptional games with especially fun gameplay as a result of excellent, complimentary card play.

:arrowE: [size=13][url=https://play.spotify.com/user/jwilliamparkin/playlist/62RTRACmFatxy9s7EHLqod][b]PLAYLIST[/b][/url][/size]

RATING: 9
Raised to a 9 after getting my own copy in a trade and playing more games, including a few solo sessions and the family version, and thoroughly enjoying each play.

After one play. It is a great looking game with a fantastic range of components. I enjoyed it and look forward to playing again, however I'm becoming slightly wary of this type of game. Even in its basic form there is a bewildering array of options; so many that my instinct is this somehow negates genuinely skilled or strategic play. I feel that even with a number of games under my belt I'll still just be doing the few obviously important tasks (enlarging family, ensuring they are fed), then trying to find a path in the forest and hoping it doesn't lead off the edge of a cliff. 

Maybe that's a disservice, and more games will prove me wrong. Or maybe that's how the game was designed.

A lot of other raters seem to be placing a fair amount of importance on the cards in hand. I didn't get that impression in my (basic) game. The timing of actions seemed to be a much bigger factor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Previously I wrote why I didn't like this game that much (too complicated, too fiddly, too whatever). But after teaching this to more and more people with different gaming backgrounds (new gamers, experienced gamers, etc.) the game's merits have started to come out.

Agricola is a wonderfully strategic game that comes with multiple ways to play (family, standard - with whichever decks you choose). The family game is perfect for a medium weight game akin to Stone Age, while the standard game introduces many different nuances, tactics and paths for people to take.

Overall Agricola is a lot of fun to play no matter how you play it and can work for a number of different situations and people. Oh and for those who are wondering I greatly prefer this to Le Havre (still haven't tried any of Uwe's newer stuff however).

RATING: 9
Muchas partidas no registradas.

Para mi uno de los mejores eurogames que existen. Desde que vi su idea, estando aún en desarrollo, me pareció simplemente genial. Lo tuve incluso en Alemán, cuando no había edición en Castellano.

Una rejugabilidad brutal debido a la enorme cantidad de cartas. Suelo jugar, eso si, con la opción draft para preparar un poco los combos y la estrategia de partida debido al amplio abanico de posibilidades (evidentemente no se llega a todo).

Diseño bonito, componentes chulísimos (tengo todos los meeples y componentes asociados al juego en castellano... hasta la postal). Se hace fácil para cualquiera, sea veterano o jugador exporádico. Eso sí, este juego tiene una profundidad estratégica muy grande, como pocos eurogames. No es ninguna perita en dulce.

En su parte negativa poco puedo decir. Tal vez poca interacción directa (pisar acciones de otro y en algunas cartas del mazo I... poco más). Hay veces que como tomes varias malas decisiones o quieras ir a todo te puedes ver con una granja patética a mitad de la partida y sin posibilidad de remontada.

En definitiva un juego magnífico.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Enthalten sind folgende Produkte:

Agricola Grundspiel (3. deutsche Auflage von 2009)
Agricola Die Moorbauern (1. deutsche Auflage von 2009)
 
Z-Deck
X-Deck
Gamers Deck
Ö-Deck
World Championship Deck - 2011
Das legendäre Tannenbäumchen-Deck 
L-Deck (ziemlich unvollständig und auch nicht zum spielen ausbalanciert)
Im Wandel der Jahreszeiten (Postkartenerweiterung)

5 Hofpläne mit alternativen Motiven (3 Jahreszeiten, Alien, Cowboy)
Rohstoff-, Gemüse- und Tierspielsteine
Ein Rohstoffsäckchen
Aufkleber für die Arbeiter (schon beklebt)
Spielsteine in türkis

Sortierung:
Alles oben erwähnte befindet sich sinnvoll sortiert in der Grundbox und in der Box von Moorbauern (siehe Fotos). Beide Schachteln sind sehr voll, die Deckel schließen aber vollständig. Bis auf ein paar Karten im L-Deck ist sämtliches Material in deutscher Sprache.

Zustand:
Das Spiel wurde nur 2 mal gespielt, die meisten Erweiterungen sind gänzlich ungespielt. Ö-Deck und Teile des World Championship Decks sind sogar noch in Folie. Sämtliches Material ist vollständig vorhanden und sofern nötig in Zip-Beuteln sortiert. Die Schachtel von Agricola hat an ein paar Ecken weiße Stellen (wirklich nur minimal zu erkennen, siehe Foto).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
I wanted to like Agricola, but the more I play it, the more I hate it. I don't mind getting cut off from a resource. What I do mind is that once I get cut off from said resource, I have no alternatives that actually lead somewhere.

There's really only one strategy to win. The farming theme/premise is attractive to me, and I very much enjoy worker placement games; yet in Agricola, there's only one way to play. If you don't get a leg up on your opponent early on, you end up just chasing them for the rest of the game.

Basically it's like chess: the more practiced player will almost always win, and there's nothing but frustration for the other player(s) as they watch that process play out. At the end of every single game I've played, I was left with a feeling of "If only I had..." or "But I almost..." -- when what I want to feel is "That was fun!" This just doesn't cut it, sorry. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

RATING: 9
Great game which my family are really enjoying, my 8 year old is a livestock Baron already
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A serious, solid game, but alas, a boring one. The cards are all "special" cards, and in a 5-player game each player has 14 of his own plus the major improvements! The combinations are hard to evaluate and I don't see how they all could possibly have been playtested. Naturally, some combos are clearly a lot better than others, so the luck of the draw can be a big factor. 

The only interaction is in choosing roles, and if someone picks the one you wanted you'll have to completely re-think your selection. The whole thing is clunky, with a zero excitement level, and after your turn you can go read a book for a few minutes. Oh, yeah -- the game drags on far too long, and I pondered quitting after the first two hours. 

My second and third plays found me constantly thinking "When will it end, already!?" Expansions just make things worse. While I like the concept, the whole affair feels more like work than anything else. I hope I never have to play again.

RATING: 7

RATING: 10
Initial turn order issues?  Perhaps.  Uneven card strength issues?  Definitely.  I prefer a front-to-back actions variant, a la Settlers, on the first turn: 1-2-3-4-4-3-2-1 in a 4P game, for example.  I massively prefer drafting cards, but with less experienced players I think drawing 10 and discarding 3 is also fine.  I never thought I would award a 10 rating other than Magic: The Gathering, but Agricola has earned it.  My play is usually only limited by the interest and schedules of my gaming group, but luckily for me they love the game almost as much as I do.  It's very safe for me to say that this is the best board game I have ever played, and my favorite one of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A charming worker placement game with a surprising amount of tension (5 players), and with a very gratifying sense of accomplishment, since it actually feels like you built something.  Makes for a brain-burner that is actually fun as well!

Edit:  Occupation and minor improvement cards are starting to wear on me.  Randomly getting cards can screw you before the game starts if you get a weaker draw.  Drafting takes too long.  At least with dice, you roll enough and your luck balances out usually.  But a little bad luck (or very good luck for someone else) at the beginning of Agricola offers no more chances to balance out the luck factor.  This has hurt the enjoyment of some of the sessions, and damped my enthusiasm for the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great game, I learned it while teaching friends (famly game style) in a few minutes. There are some complex strategies, but the limited actions make the game engaging and keep the pace of it. Only issue I have is it is really a multiple play game, the first time you may make some poor decisions and that can cost you big time.

RATING: 9
Suppose I'm just jumping on the bandwagon, but I love this game. It's elegant, simple, and has a lot of variety owing to the initial draws. Still, it always leaves me feeling rushed. While I seem to do well enough at the game, it feels ... stressful to play, which is not entirely pleasant. It has what a lot of this genre lacks in the form of variable turn order (really disappointed that Uwe dropped this with Le Havre), a great deal of variety due to the card draws (though this randomness provides the game's only real weakness), and high production value. Having played Le Havre, I think the begging cards may be too punitive, but I find it hard to criticize the game otherwise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Lives up to the hype. Plays a lot like Caylus, only more variability with the card stages. Very analytical/mathematical--a highly complex game. Its only weakness is that there is no negotiation and very little direct player interaction. You have to pay close attention to your opponent's strategies, and try to do something opposite to that, so you aren't fighting for the same resources as your opponent throughout the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I am in the definite minority on this game.  While people see it as a deep strategy game, I am left cold and often frustrated after playing it.  The randomness of the initial card draws and subsequent card draws can have a huge impact on a game's outcome but the game is often touted as luck-less.  The game has a tight feel - so tight that each turn you are playing to minimize the efficiency losses that are bound to trip you up.  And those obstacles are thrown down in front of you by your fellow players, not as challenges to you but with cold indifference - as if you are merely someone else playing a game on the same field.  Is the game well designed?  Perhaps.  Is it the best game on the market? Hardly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.9
Many have found the 'Feed Your Family' component to this unforgiving, but I rather enjoy this Rosenberg design, and can see why it has made such an impact on the Euro gaming community as a whole. It embraces its theme fully, where Caverna rather tiptoes around the subterranean/fantasy thing and just sort of transforms this into a more light, sand box style of game. Enjoy Agricola more. The pressure, the choices, a game that lives up to its hype for the most part, though I have others in this style I prefer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is essentially a puzzle solving game.  The more you play the better you get at solving the puzzle or optimizing your moves.  After 39 plays the shine still hasn't come off.  I think that getting the right draw of cards is significant in determining whether or not you're the winner, but more important is getting your food engine up and running.  This is a game which can appear daunting to people who have just played lighter games, but is fairly intuitive.

One of the nice things about this game is that it is a very strong 2 player game.  I play with my wife a lot, and she enjoys it as the flow seems to make sense and relate to how a farm would work.

After 13 plays I'm willing to concede that I may bump it up.  But I hate to bump it up, burn out, and then move it back down.

11/25/08 Bumped it up to a 9 as I'm playing this game a lot.

03/28/09 I think that I enjoy 5 players less than a fewer number of players. Seems as if card draws can weigh more heavily than skill in determining the winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excellent game. Don't know if it will stay in heavy rotation as my collection grows but for now: Always want to play it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.85
This used to be my favorite worker placement game, but it has dropped off as I have played it more (and played other games). The basic mechanics are pretty straightforward, but I love finding synergies in the occupations and improvements. I also like the pressure that the game puts on you to make efficient decisions (I enjoy feeling like there isn't enough time to do everything I would like in a game). I know some people find this game too punishing and unforgiving. I don't find the punishing nature of feeding your people an annoyance. In fact, when I first played the game that was one of the things I liked best about it. However, after more plays I am finding that, while the pressure to feed your people doesn't bother me per se, I don't love that the game doesn't let me explore the space in the way I choose. Feeding your people is on target thematically, but I wish I had more choice in what I did each game rather than knowing that many decisions are forced upon me by that mechanic. I still really enjoy this game, but I'm finding that there are now other worker placement games I would rather get to the table.

RATING: 10
My rating is for the family game. So far at least the "gamer" version with the mass of cards rates a little lower.

2010-04 Even playing 2-player with someone that I taught I've failed to score well in almost any game. The intricacies seem to be beyond me.

2010-07 Now I've played (a lot) more I'm probably just as willing to play either version of the game. As long as the others have played the "Family" game at least once before.

2011-07 After teaching a few people to play the "full" version I'd still rather teach the "Family" game but if the new people are wanting everything I'll teach that way.

2017-7
This has now been my favourite game for about 5 years. I prefer to teach the family version so new players have the base understanding of how things work.

2017-12 I've been gifted the revised edition. My plays will likely be more often that version now.

RATING: 7.5

The game itself is a lot of fun. The game play changes a bit each time and you have so many different options.  I would like to get a few more game plays in but so far, it's one that we look forward to playing.

RATING: 4
I've only played the family version, and just a couple o times online. Hence, mine might not be the best opinion about a game that is so beloved around here, but the bottom line is simple. I was intrigued by the scarcity of resources, which usually makes a very good game for me, but in the end, the sheer amount of possible routes reduced tension, and made me felt like I was solving a complex puzzle instead of playing a game.

I'd love to give this one a few tries more, but for now, it's no game I'd love to play again and again, much less actually commit to buying it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Unplayed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Agricola is a great Euro style victory point collection game. It is a worker placement game with sturdy components and wooden pieces.

Players tend farms and raise their families scoring points along the way and facing challenges (feeding your family!).

Agricola is a bit complicated compared to other worker placement games and initially players may feel lost as to how well they are doing, so for beginners I recommend something more streamlined like Stone Age.

Pros: great strategy game with tough choices and competition for key spots on the board. Players struggle to both score points and maintain their family with food offering some really tough decisions and down to the wire game play
Component: Great quality
Solid mechanics

Cons: Design/theme is simple, farming isn't going to grab anyone attentions.
Colours are kinda bland
Rule book can be confusing and game play takes a while to master
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

SOLD

The theme is integrated beautifully and I love the whole feel of the game.  I really want animeeples though...

I think I may be burnt out on the game currently, but I think that is just over the hype.  Need to let more people learn the game then get back into it without the slow movement of people trying to figure out what they are supposed to do on a turn.  A slow game of this is not a fun as it should be.

Rating Edit: Yep.  I have lowered the rating on this game.  The play is still great, it is more the players playing and their absolute blind obsession with the game.  It just makes it not fun to play.  Still a great game though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I very much enjoyed getting to know the 'basic' game.  After a few initial plays it was a 10.  However after playing again after a few months gap against some 'experts', the game has lost its magic.  The starting card imbalance means that players are not equal.  It's not great fun playing with people who, like with Puerto Rico, have majored in the game and against whom I am only ever playing to avoid the wooden spoon.  I still enjoy the game.  But not as much as many others - including Le Havre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
So far this game is the real deal.  A lot has been said about the theme.  Personally I find it interesting.  I also like how the game really "feels like farming" -- which obviously sounds silly coming from someone who's never farmed before.

Still, the game mechanics manage to capture my imagination in a way that makes sense given the theme of the game.  There is some sorta strange drama in living on the precipice of starvation and trying to grow ones modest holdings in order to get beyond mere survival and into prosperity.

This is primarily a game of worker placement.  The majority of player interaction comes as a result of the scarcity of actions (since only one person can take advantage of each action every turn).

On the other hand, this is a game that rewards diversity over specialization.  A player with a diverse farm will be able to capitalize on a number of different actions shielding him from missing out on that one crucial move.

One thing I especially like about Agricola is the sheer number of options.  With over 300 cards there is a ton of diversity built into the game.  Maximizing your points given your available actions and cards dealt to you promises to be a different challenge each time you play.

RATING: 9
Agricola... oh how I love to play you, oh how brain burning you can be. Agricola is a magnificent game, with a complexity that is hidden under a rather casual looking exterior. People with analysis paralysis will literally be stuck in Agricola, with the sheer amount of actions, all of which need to be done and are equally useful. But overall, Agricola is one of the prides of my collection for being a completely strategic game with little to no luck involved. I actually prefer Le Havre, but both are great! My only major criticism of both Agricola and Le Havre is that they take a good while to set up with the different boards, the card shuffling, and all the wooden pieces.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The game has the same mechanical feel of a cross between Puerto Rico and Caylus.  The actions don't seem compelling and the penalties are quite harsh.

A very interesting concept that is relatively simple in concept, but terribly difficult to understand good strategies.

Absolutely requires player aids to play adequately, I'd strongly recommend printing score charts and major improvement summaries for each player to reference during the game.

The game can feel a little bit like multiplayer solitaire despite having ruthless interaction in worker placement.  I was a little disappointed that the game didn't spark discussion except to clarify rules and get strategic advice.

so far through 10/25 all games I've played received a score of 30...at least I'm consistent :)

11/2 scored 43 in two player game.

(Includes Through the Seasons, Z-Deck and Target Animeeples)
I will include the "agricolumn" storage solution with it as well.

RATING: 8
Talán a legéletszagúbb játék (leszámítva a "Pecunia non olet"-et:)), a legjobbak közt mindenképp. Az állatok szaporodására, és a vetés mechanizmusára gondolok. Még egy városi ember is elhiszi, hogy ez nagyjából így megy a valóságban is:) Nagyon igényes a kivitel. Pozitivum az is a játéknak, hogy a már megszokott akciókiosztásos mechanizmust felfrissítették a kártyákkal. Ezzel azonban ki is merült az eredetisége. Épp ezért nem adok rá több pontot, mert összevetve más, kevésbé favorizált játékokkal, nem érzem annyira újszerűnek az egésznek a mechanizmusát. Döntően csak korábban kitalált panelek lettek egymásra pakolva. Ráadásul a szerencsefaktor is túl nagy, ha a kezdő kártyakiosztást alkalmazzuk. Épp ezért a haladó kiosztást javaslom! Összességében nagy élményt ad, és kellően komplex ahhoz, hogy sokféle győzelmi taktikát kínáljon.
---
2 év szünet után újra előkerült a játék, és végre a családi változatot is kipróbáltam. Ez alapján azt mondom, hogy szívem szerint soha többet nem is használnék kártyát, az csak a "hogyan bonyolítsunk feleslegesen túl egy amúgy kártya nélkül is tök jól működő játékot" jegyében lett szerintem hozzá legyártva, meg azért, hogy ráírhassák, hogy 120 perc a játékidő. Kártyák nélkül 3 fővel 1 óra alatt lement az egész! A kártyás változat helyett inkább Caylusozok.

RATING: 7.5
Excellent design as it is accessible to occasional gamers while demanding to seasoned ones. The individual farm-board permits to make calculation easy even when you're not mathematically inclined - while familiarising new gamers to acute planning. 

Yet, it's not challenging enough for my group (too little interactions), and too massive (large box, many chits, many rules) for improvised games with non-gamers (even if it's simple to understand and perfectly rendered, it demand too much goodwill). Also, the game is expensive and not radically different from other euros.

RATING: 7.5
An enjoyable resource management game that really needs its rules rewritten in an understandable format as soon as possible. Youtube videos should not be needed to work out how the heck to play a boardgame. 

Still, once the rules became clear, the game is very easy to pick up, and plays well. You never have quite enough resources todo everything you want, which is great as it forces you to make difficult choices with a  tangible result. 

The game lacks a little bit in theme, and each game plays quite similarly, so I don't often get the urge to play it. It's good for the occasional play, so I'm glad I have access to it without having to buy it.

RATING: 9
Played 2 x solo and 1 x a training 2 player family variant. The game is really nice (aesthetically just perfect actually), but now it is too early to give it more than 7.

Note 2008-11-17. Yesterday we managed to play a 4 player standard game with the E deck. Everyone enjoyed it, to the extent that one of girls mentioned "you know I play those games because I know my husband loves them and this one is the first one I really like". Definitely the game is very interesting, has a big sense of urgency and you can even be a little nasty to other. Thus I give them game 8 now, but quite honestly this game did not thrill me to an extend as Puerto Rico and Brass did.

Note 2009-12-07. This game plays very nice with 2 - its scalability was well thought over. And it is nice and tense. Therefore, its price per play is now much lower than majority of other games I own.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Aug-08-2008
First four games.  Wow!  Just wow!  This game is so much fun.  The game is so enthralling I don't notice the time go by.  The game has so many hard decisions to make as you try to do/get everything to have the most well rounded farm.  The game is a great combination of so many mechanics found in great games, yet this one provides a very different experience.  It really is hard to put into words.  This is the only action placement game that I actually like.  Games like Leonardo Da Vinci, Caylus, Age of Empires III are abysmal compared to this game.  It is really cool how the game changes so much between the family game and between each regular game.  It is a cool feeling of finding your niche among other farmers and seeing your desolated land develop to a prosperous farm.  How a few rounds ago your land is half empty and by the end of the game it is "complete."  Agricola is a great combination of theme and mechanics that fall in the meaty category.  Mind kind of game.
Initial Rating: 9

Aug-31-2008
After 45 games I think it is time reward the game a 10.  Even though I have played the game 45 times, I still want to play it back to back to back to back... You get the idea.  This game embodies the 10 rating.  I love playing this game with new players and experienced players a like.  I like the feeling of playing against other people and playing against the game at the same time since you have so little time to do so many things.  Kind of like the same feeling you get from playing Antiquity.  The cards are what make this game so great.  They provide the avenue for the game to become strategic as they give you incentives to follow specific strategic paths.  The cards prevent the game from being a tit-for-tat game and from being a purely tactical game.  Actually, I think the underlying skill needed to play Agricola well is to gauge how much use you can get from the occupations and improvements.  You will find that a lot of the cards are awesome to play but you have to focus on only a few of them or you'll find yourself doing too many things at the same time and thus not getting much use from your awesome cards.  The person that can do this best will win the game.  Additionally, I am happy to report that I haven't played a game where my hand of minor improvements and occupations made me feel like I was doomed.  The game actually moves in a pretty quick pace.  Obviously if you play with AP people then it would take longer.  I typically play 4 player games in under 90 minutes.  Additional to the cards, the game has so much replayability because the game changes character when playing the game with different numbers of players.  For example in 4 player games it is easy to get ovens because there is an action that gives you reed, stone and food.  It is easy to setup a grain food engine.  In contrast with a 2 player game, there is no reed, stone & food action so it takes a bit longer to get the stone for the ovens.  Also, occupations are slower to play in 2 player games compared to 4 player games because in 2 player games there is only 1 occupation action versus 2 in 4 player games.  You really have to reorient yourself when playing the game with different numbers of players.  It is liken to hitting a wall.  
Update: 9 -> 10


Top Scores:

2p - 55
3p - 44
4p - 59
5p -

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like this game, but after a few plays, I find I don't seem to play it much. I like that the game rewards shrewd, balanced play; you need a bit of everything by game's end lest you lose points - livestock, crops, fences, improved cottage, barn etc. But maybe it funnels/prescribes play a bit too much?! By game's end, everyone's board can look a bit same-y ... kinda like a farm, I guess. 
Where the game shines is in creating great tension in competition for food, resources and action spaces. Each turn, players are faced with some agonising decisions; whether to "grab now" or hold off to reap bigger rewards next turn. 
Playing pieces and boards are lovely, with but one exception: for a game which oozes theme, those ice-hockey puck "people" leave me cold. Meeple people or farmer stickers would have been a nice inclusion. At least those sterile cubes have been replaced my animeeples in more recent versions.
Oh yes, and I can't subscribe to the rule that allows you to house one animal in your cottage. I mean, who wants to live with a sheep?!! Baaaaaa.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

edit: having had the opportunity to play this on ios quite a bit now, it is quite brilliant!

RATING: 9
I've got 1 4-player, 2 2-player, and a handful of solo games under my belt to this point.  Only the 4-player game has involved anything other than the E-deck.

The base tech-tree engine is great.  The cards, however, put this game over the top.  The endless variety and differing focus generated by the cards gives infinite replay ability and keeps the game from being over analyzed a-la Caylus and Puerto Rico. 

I'm giving this an initial 9, but it may increase.  There's an incredible amount of game in that box.

RATING: 9
This is the game that got me into tabletop gaming.  Before playing this I hadn't played anything since Dominion years ago.

Even though I didn't fully grasp a viable strategy until round 4 or 5 my first game, and the theme is super dry (unless you're just really into building farms), I lovvve this game.  I love how much thought and strategy goes into everything you do, I love how you can have little on your board but with a few well-timed moves you can come back from behind and build an awesome farm in the later rounds. 

My only complaint is the randomized card mechanism.  I hate randomness, and I don't like getting a crappy hand that's difficult to string together purely based on bad luck.  I haven't played it yet but I imagine I will enjoy the Caverna tile system more.

But that's just me and it's a small concession.  Agricola is awesome!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Agricola wouldn't need any comment: BGG is so full of words about its awesomeness that mine are surely superfluous.
What is so amazig about it is its tightness, the pressure it puts on players, the constant need of one more action like grasping for air.
The only (perceived) imperfection, card imbalance, vanishes using the drafting variant.

Update february 25, 2009: My GF loves it, so it gets +0.5!
Update july 12, 2009: The more we play, the more we like it with any number of players! It's definitely a 10.
Update july 16, 2010: The GF's love for the game is definitely declining, so it loses 1 point...
Update september 17, 2011: still playing it on a constant basis, why should't it be a 10?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
First impression is that it is a very tight game that focuses quite a bit on the ability to provide for the family. Everyone was so obsessed with getting enough food to feed the people that rarely anyone had spare capacity for anything else.

Finally played the game with the occupations and the minor improvements and I must say they improved the gameplay so that there are more options to GET MORE FOOD!

I enjoy the tight game where you have to do a lot of trade offs. Same as this world, there are tons of opportunity costs, when you do one thing you cannot do another.

Will be incorporating the other decks and the expansions next.

[b][url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1238280/part-2014-challenge-play-10-games-case-agricola-10]Agricola Session Report for 2014 10x10 Challenge[/url][/b]
