RATING: N/A
Aug 30 2013  
 During my first play through, I noticed that 24 of the game cards have manufacturing defects. It is an obvious score line right across the top 9mm of the affected cards. I have contacted the publisher (Z-man Games) to replace these cards or to find another suitable solution. I've removed my initial rating of the game until this matter is resolved.

Update Oct 02 2013
 I received the replacement cards today and 18 of the 24 replacement cards have the SAME score line manufacturing error in them! In some cases it's even worse! I have contacted Z-man customer service again through email regarding this on going issue.

Update Oct 03 2013
 I received a very prompt response from Z-man. They have apologised for their errors and are sending undamaged replacement cards immediately. It would seem that there have been some significant manufacturing and worker
 related issues at Z-man in the last while. I was not the only one who was affected by poor quality parts and service.

Update Oct 08 2013
  I received my undamaged replacement cards and 3 "bonus" cards. I have a proper Agricola set now :)

RATING: 8
I'm a little late to the Agricola party.  Experienced reviewers made me hesitant to pick up a copy and the general consensus in my gaming group is unfavorable.


I played a "family version" with my wife this afternoon and I LOVE this game. The worker placement was tight and the number of strategies were multi-varied and interesting. Our final score was 32-33 so it was really we'll balanced. For 2 first time players with the same amount of gaming experience we really should be scoring nearly the same and we did.

UPDATE: I included this game in my 10x10 - 2015 gaming challenge and I'm really glad I did. There is still so much to this game I haven't discovered and yet I never would have guessed that from my first plays. The cards are ESSENTIAL to really getting the most out of play. Really, they are everything. I love this game.

RATING: 9
Currently my #1 favorite game.  I enjoy all aspects of it.  I play a lot solo, and love the puzzle-like aspect of Solo Agricola.  I've even found myself with a pen and paper planning out several rounds beforehand for many solo series.

Multiplayer feels like a completely different game, trying to time resource/action space grabs perfectly, oftentimes blocking or being thwarted by an opponent.

The hundreds of occupations and minor improvements keep the advanced game fresh every time, and I love the tactile addition of lots of wooden bits!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Agricola is similar to Caylus, but with random player cards that are kept secret until played.  The positive thing about the random distribution of Occupation and Minor Improvement cards is that it almost forces you to try out new approaches and tactics for each session.  There are balance issues in which players may potentially get better card combinations than others.  However, the draft variant allows for a more balanced, customizable game.  I prefer playing Agricola with a draft, but I'd only do this with experienced players. I also am a little concerned about how much study time is necessary for new players to become familiar with all of the cards.   Another concern is that the start player mechanic is better handled in Caylus.      

[b]Farmers of the Moor expansion[/b]
The special actions are awesome.  They make it easier for players with less family members to stay competitive.  Timing your actions is crucial, especially since each special action may be selected twice per round.  Overall, I find the action phase to be more dynamic than standard Agricola.  Each new feature provides so many alternative ways to combo and score points that you don't even need to play with Occupations.

RATING: 7
LIKES - Analyzing occupation and minor improvement cards for combos that will help your worker placement efficiency.  Oddly enough - the theme (I have tons of sheep; You have none - (diabolic laugher)).

DISLIKES - Winning feels anticlimactic.  (What, I just won a game of Agricola.  I should feel more excited).

WHY A 7.5 RATING BASED ON THE BGG DEFINITIONS? - This is a "very good" game (9), but I would be apt to "probably suggest" it depending on the make up of the game group (8), however I don't think I would "never" turn down a game (8).  There are other games out there I would rather play therefore Agricola gets a 7.5.

RATING: 9
I've gotten into a bit of a rut in strategy always going for a 2 room extension from the start.  Of course this is a good way to go, but I've been completely screwed over by people that mix it up a bit (especially if someone focuses on taking animals early).  Despite this, the cards always add interesting choices from the beginning.  I like this game the most with 3 players -- more than that simply takes too long.  I also like to play at least a couple of games at a time to make the set-up and tear-down times more worth while.

RATING: N/A
IMO: Agricola feels like Bohnanza filtered through Martin Wallace.  This is after 1 play with just minor improvements and occupations.  We played a 3 player game and I really didn't find it fun.  It just felt like a simulation that forgot it was a simulation and glossed over bits that weren't interesting.  Case in point: I have a child on a stage.  Each stage representing 1 year as far as I can tell.  Now in the next stage I can send that child to work for me?  But he or she is only 1 year old or less.  How the heck is a 1 year old going to go fishing or collect cattle or build a room on to the house?  Seriously, if you're going to simulate life on the farm simulate the whole thing.

RATING: 10
Played 5 times in one weekend when I first got it. What an amazing game. I was fascinated by the interactions of the cards, the new opportunities that presented themselves in each game, and the way the whole game played. A gaming masterpiece that any fan of meaty games will enjoy. 

[q]- What do you like the most about Agricola?[/q]
The game combines a strategic plan with tactical choices very well. It offers immense replayability and you must react to your opponents plays, and their perceived strategy at all times to do well. It rewards good planning and deep involvement. All this while having a fun, different theme, and cute little animeeples.

[q]- Do you think you'll be playing much more of it in the future?[/q]
I expect to be playing this for some time, though my plays of it have recently tapered off. I hope they pick up again soon as i devote less of my gaming time to playtesting Dominion.

[q]- Why do you think this game is so replayable?  In other words, what keeps you from getting bored with it after so many plays?[/q]
The sheer variety of possible hands, and the adjustment to your overall strategy that each hand will require makes each play slightly different.

RATING: 7.5
(3-5 Players, 30 min/player, CLASSIC) As a subsistence farmer in the Middle Ages, hunger is your adversary. With only so many resources and opportunities in your village to go around, every member of your household must spend their time wisely. Plow your fields, plant crops, raise livestock, and improve your home (with a family) to become the best farmer in town.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have trouble [i]enjoying[/i] this game as much as other games, but I still have some desire to play more in order to try new cards, new strategies, etc. However, I have to say that most of my desire to play comes from wanting to see new cards and try to make them work rather than from a genuine enjoyment of the game – more curiosity than pleasure.

I find the scoring at the end to be a bit of a downer. Needing to use a spreadsheet to add up scores takes a bit away from the fun of the game (counting up points is one thing; tallying them in a dedicated spreadsheet feels like I'm back in the office).  In addition, the need for balance combined with the limited number of rounds really makes the game feel too short and too constrained.  Due to the way the scoring works, it's almost always more profitable to spend a fair number of my limited actions getting one or two of everything, no matter what specialization (if any) I may (want to) have. I end most games feeling like I didn't have time to really accomplish anything (especially when attempting to harvest crops) and feeling like too many of my actions were scripted, which is more than a bit frustrating. 

While the game provides a good 'feel' for the difficulty of surviving as a Middle Ages farmer, I find the fact that the mechanics force me into being a sheep/cow/boar/wheat/vegetable farmer with a family and upgraded house slightly off-putting. There is (seemingly) no opportunity to specialize, which cuts back on the realism and makes for a less enjoyable experience than, e.g., Puerto Rico, where I feel that I really have a choice in how I play the game. Additionally, at the end of Puerto Rico, I feel like I accomplished something, even if I lost. Perhaps I tried a shipping strategy, so I focused on a couple crops and tried to buy a wharf. Or perhaps I tried a building strategy and focused on cash and construction over shipping. But at least I can say "I tried to do X/Y/Z and succeeded/failed". In Agricola, every game feels the same: "I tried to do some of everything".

Overall, I quite like Agricola's theme and think it does a great job of depicting the struggle of surviving as a subsistence farmer in the Middle Ages. However, I find the gameplay lacking in a few areas, and while I will not refuse to play, I'd almost always rather play something else.

Perhaps an interesting addition could be a 'Market' mechanism: you place a worker on the Market and can sell or buy goods at market (i.e., trading with the local townsfolk). Each good would have a different purchase/sale price (e.g., a sheep would sell for less than a boar, but would require less money to purchase as well). It wouldn't fix everything I dislike about the game, but it could perhaps add a bit of flexibility and interest. I also wonder if some balance would be added by changing the family growth action (at least the first one) from an action one must take in order to have a child to a different action space (e.g., 3 clay) with a disclaimer that when that action space comes into play, each player immediately has a child that can be used that round (or the next). Perhaps it would have to be at the start of a round in order to facilitate 'family planning' but it might remove some of the (illogical – the Smiths had a baby, so I can't) competition for obtaining more actions. (2012-01)

Traded for Settlers of Catan (3e), as Settlers has a better chance of getting played with my group of friends, and there are a number of games I'd prefer to Agricola at any rate. I'd still be willing to play now and then, but don't need to own a copy. (2012-03)

Some additional musings: 

Regarding the mandatory 'diversity' in scoring, the timing of actions that allow more flexibility in growing one's farm, the replenishment rates of wood/animals/etc. vs. grain/vegetables, etc., I strongly agree with [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/3351125#3351125]this comment[/url]: [i][Agricola] seems to be built of artificial balancing, rather than having a few bits of artificial balancing bolted to tweak the power of various actions or reign in the leader.[/i] The end-game scoring seems to be a product of this same approach: instead of working the game out in such a way that collecting a single kind of VP is balanced (e.g., in Puerto Rico, players collect a single [i]kind[/i] of VP though through different means), Agricola seemingly takes the approach of correcting a potentially overpowered strategy X by forcing [i]all[/i] players to play strategies X, Y, and Z in every game. 

Another aspect of Agricola that doesn't sit well with me is the fact that the game itself is an opponent -- in some ways, perhaps the [i]main[/i] opponent. The game sets fairly strict requirements that each player has to meet (or else risk losing not because another player beat you, but because you failed to meet the game's requirements -- which, naturally, the other players get some degree of credit for, but it's not quite the same), which diverts the primary focus from competing with other players to meeting the requirements of the game system. More on this idea [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/3350325#3350325]here[/url]. The fact that one can play Agricola [i]alone[/i] is indicative of this problem in my mind: if the game is enough of a challenge on one's own, why add other players? So all can fight against the game simultaneously, while also trying to make it more difficult for each other to do so? This reminds me of racing canoes [i]upstream[/i], where the other racers try to sabotage your efforts to simply move forward. It certainly is competitive, but is [i]so[/i] cut-throat (and demanding enough on its own) that it doesn't allow for the same type of competition as, say, Tigris and Euphrates, Puerto Rico, Chess, and so forth. 
(2014-01-07)

RATING: 9
Rating improved to a 9.0: So much going on and so much to consider with your own hand let alone keeping up with what others are doing. The deal of the cards absolutely steers where you drive your strategy and ensures no two games are the same. The first game is a learning experience both for the rules and approach. Always more to do than you can achieve, what a frustratingly beautiful game.

Now played with 2,4 and 5 players, the game seems to scale perfectly. Relatively straight forward to explain to new comers and always an extremely positive reaction. This game has staying power and has now been lodged in my top ten.

RATING: 7.5
The comment that I seem to make most while playing this game is 'This game is hard!' There's too much stuff I want to do, not enough family members to do them with, and the other players always seem to put their guys on the spaces that I need.

But that's what makes it so fun! Our games tend to take a long time (2-2.5 hours for 3 players). But we understand when someone is taking an especially long time in this game. Some of the choices can be pretty hard!

It's also kind of fun to look at your nice little farm after the game is over.

Something that I don't like about this game is that it takes up a ton of room and takes a while to set up and take down. It's not that big of a deal, but it's something you have to take into account if you only have a certain amount of time to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros - Great replayability, especially with the advanced rules.  Lots of interactivity with other players through competition for actions.  Great mechanics that follow the theme well.

Cons - Games can take upwards from 2 hours depending on the number of players and how quickly you can setup.  Complex rules.  Casual gamers can learn it, but will take them long to master the rules.  Not recommended for beginners.

RATING: 7.8

I get it’s a way to balance between the players though. Overall, I really like the game, but it’s probably not my top 10. I look forward to play more once in a while.

RATING: 6
There is a lot to like about this game.  It has a ton of strategy and decision making.  I like the theme with the development of early modern life and all of its complexities.  Best of all, the game can be scaled by complexity.  This makes it possible for very nuanced games with lots of cards and interactivity or the simple core game with farm building.  In that sense, it is wonderful because it scales easily all the way from a kid's game to a gamer's game.  Few games can make this claim.
UPDATE:  Reduced score.  Maybe I'm just getting tired of these optimal resource games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fortunately, I was not expecting much after all the hype from BGG, so I was pleasantly surprised by this. It doesn't deserve to be #1 in my opinion, but I like it better than Puerto Rico (which also did not deserver to be #1, in my opinion). 

My main complaint, which is a frequent complaint with Euros, is that it felt like there just were not enough turns (actions) to do everything I wanted to do. I just started getting my animals going in the pasture, and then it was over. 

I did like having to diversify.  I suppose that could "limit" strategy choices as I play a few more games, but I felt it made the game more challenging by forcing all players to compete for all goods.  The cards seem to be what makes the game "different" each time, and I've yet to play enough to see if any are truly overpowered as some claim.  However, I doubt I'd enjoy the "family" version of the game.  Without the cards, it seems this game would get very dull very quick.

After 3 games:  It seems that the cards are not well balanced in this at all.  Now that I know the cards better, the winner can almost be pre-determined just by looking at what cards each person was dealt.  I probably would rate this a 7 or maybe an 8 but for this defect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
You know how good this game is. Hell, it's number 1 in the charts.
I love it for it's diversity of choice for where to place your family members and the various strategies to victory. 
However, the cards are not balanced and players can definitely get a leg up on the competition if dealt good cards. Also analysis paralysis tends to stall this game to hideous lengths with 5 players.

RATING: 8
1 play with the family deck:  

It was everything they say it is.  So many good decisions, so many better ones.  

I really liked my experience with it, however, it's a heckuva game to play.  ..and you don't step-up to the 'gric without being ready to play...  So it doesn't make my "never turn down a game", but I think it rightfully deserves the place it's at on boardgamegeek at #1, as it is a very excellent game.

What's nice about this, is that it wasn't dry because there was so much you could do on any given turn...


Some comments sometime later:

I got a new job, and I can't really muster-up what it takes to want to play this game.  It's the weirdest thing.  

The one thing I solidly have against this game, is that while it's kind of fun, it's brain-burny fun...  and when I say 'fun' I mean "not 110% strategic".  There's just so so so so very much going on with this game that I have a hard time believing there are many folks that know what they want to do and what they are doing, even after like the 10th game they've played.  Almost boils it down to being a fun exercise.  The problem is, it's really really hard to explain to people.  There's a lot of tacit knowledge here...  like that you have to plow a field to use it to grow veggies, and what converts to food and what doesn't...  and...  I don't know.  I have to opt for le havre as my economic game of choice out of the rosenburg series.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Agricola is a very good Euro game with a strong focus on "getting everything done before the end". What I mean by this phrase is that a player has to have various elements, such as animals and crops, in his/her farm by the end of the game. Failure to have certain elements will remove points from the player's score.

This is not necessarily a bad thing as the game stays away from being too linear. There are multiple avenues to get what you need, and, for me, the fun lies in developing a particular timing strategy with the 7 minor improvement cards and 7 occupations cards one gets in the beginning.

Overall, Agricola is a fun and rewarding, but also stressful game at times. Getting enough food to feed your family at the harvest while at the same time developing your farm is challenging and is the key to victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love this game.  It's a theme-heavy worker placement and resource management Euro where to goal is to see who can get their family the best quality of life.  Yes, some people find a game based on medieval farming inherently dull, but I prefer to think of the theme as "Not Starving To Death."

The occupations and minor improvements add a ton of replay value, but their sometimes poor balance adds an element of luck that's a bit too strong.  And after a few playthroughs, your best choices for optimizing your farm space become pretty obvious (though the excellent "Farmers on the Moor" expansion does a lot to mitigate that).

Still.  I love the tension that comes from hustling to keep my family fed, or from the rat bastard next to me stealing that big pile of wood RIGHT before I was going to nab it.  This is a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolutely fantastic game.  I really don't think I've played anything better.  There are a couple that are as good, but nothing better.  After a couple more plays, I'm finding the game less impressive.  Still great, but not the best.  Especially after playing Race for the Galaxy and also finding that Dominion has held up so well to multiple plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
To be fair I've only played one game and that was simply the "family" version.  However, I really don't think this game is for me.  I just don't understand where the fun in the game comes from.  The most frustrating part for me is probably the feel that I'm always trying to dig myself out of a hole, in an effort to get enough food to feed my people.  I never could get over the hump and had no idea how it was possible.  I'm sure with multiple plays that would become obvious, but for a first timer it's just irritating.  It feels too much like the financial struggles I deal with in real life, and the boring farmer theme doesn't help in that matter.

Another thing that I didn't like is the forced diversity.  The fact that the game basically demands that you focus on every area, trying unique strategies seems difficult.  And, finally, I don't like the fact that they just plop 25+ options in front of you and expect you to have some clue what is worthwhile.  I'm OK with games that have a learning curve, but when it's so steep that experiences players can triple the score of a new player it's just not fun for me.  I wouldn't refuse a game in the future, but I'm certainly not going to seek it out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favorite game.

RATING: 7
8-17-08.  After 11 plays, this is becoming more solidified in its 10-ness for me.  I used to be worried more about the cards, but learning how they are interacting is qualming some of my fears.  May still change in the future.

9-15-08.  I just really enjoy this game.

9-29-08.  The game has started to lose some of its charm after 22 games.  Still solid, but I can see this being harder and harder to want to pull out, particularly with the Essen season coming.

11-06-08.  I've gotten my enjoyment out of it, but the game is simply not that strong in the end.  There are some varying levels of complex mechanisms, but ultimately I think the randomness of the card hands take away too much for me.  4 players is probably the max I'll play this with again, and sit out of a five-player.  3 players is the sweet spot.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Why is Agricola as popular as it is? Well it has got:

- Variable setup due to the cards ensures endless replayability.
- Competition for spaces (typical for worker placement games).
- Tension from having to feed your workers (a tension which is sometimes lacking from other euros).

On top of that, it is just really tightly designed. To me, it didn't need a fix at all and I refuse to regard Caverna as a fix, rather it is a more casual alternative, despite arguably being more complex.

I think this is one of those games that gets better the more you play it and I certainly haven't played it enough yet to fully grasp it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I have played it with two, three, four and five players.  I like it, especially because it plays so well no matter the number of players.  2, 3, 4 player games are best as 5 can get a bit long.  I feel like the cards do provide advantages to certain players depending on how they are dealt out.  It's just hard to know how much, or if, the cards determine the players' final standings.

While I like the game, I am not infatuated with it and many of the people I game with are infatuated with it.  I'd prefer to play this once in a while and play a bit more variety.  I've noticed that my family members are especially hooked on this game.

UPDATE: After 27 plays, I've decided that this is just a "good game that I am usually willing to play."  Now, when people ask to play it I will, but I'll suggest something else first.  I've traded it away because I rarely play it and, when I do, I am always playing somebody else's copy.

RATING: 8
Great game. At first an intimidating amount of cards and pieces, there are 10 different resources in the game, wood, clay, reed, stone, grain, vegetables, sheep, boar, cattle and food. Despite the complexity, it plays quite nice and our group has become quite obsessed with it.
You will need a ping pong table for five players. 
Not very casual, it will reward the player who carefully optimizes their moves.

RATING: 9
At the start of each game I figure I'm just going to concentrate on the basics of feeding and developing my farm and not get distracted, but then I get a hand of cards with amazing possibilities, and suddenly I'm diverting resources into complex card combos which will then be used 10 turns later to get me enough materials to do something else... and before I know it I'm scrambling to make it to the end of the game, all the while competing with my opponents for scarce resources. This game is involving, frustrating and always leaves me wanting to play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.8
Goes down like a mouthful of runny sheep droppings.  No wonder Hanno once effectively said "It's shit eating good!!"  Without a doubt, the worst Cola EVER!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Finally got the chance to play it (on a friend's paste-up version), and kept an open mind considering all the hype, all he hubbub, and all of the backlash.  I'm glad I did.  An absolute stunner of a game.  Played twice in two days, 5 player full games, and each time left me wanting to play again.  Engaging, and leaves you wanting to revisit the game and see what else you could have done.  Lots of competition, and you always have to adjust based on what the other players are doing, so you never feel like you're playing in a void.  Even better, the extra occupatios and minor improvements merely added to the strategy and nudged you along, rather than provided game-breaking powerplays.  At no time did I look at somebody else's cards and say "oh, I would've won if I had that", but I always looked at somebody else's cards and said "Oh cool!  I wonder what I would've done if I'd had that!?"  Admittedly I scored fairly well in both games, but even the low-scorers were engaged and happy to have played, and merely want to better their score next time.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Provisional rating based on one 5-p game with the E-deck.

Pretty good worker-placement game.  I think the starting card deal introduces a bit more randomness than I'd like in a game with such a long play-time.  Perhaps one of the variants which reduces the variance of the initial deal will be more to my liking, though I will certainly play multiple times with each of the included decks to become much more familiar with the game before making a final decision.

Edit:  Still have only played this once but wanted to also mention that it's certainly possible that the cards might be balanced well enough that the random card draw just isn't as important to the outcome as I suspect it might be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a hit for me! 

Honestly, I really had trouble caring much for the theme...But once I finally started a game I fell in love with it, and now have this intense craving for new Euro games

There's an ever present threat of starvation happening to your family which is great for me because I love games in which it feels like an ongoing struggle to survive (ghost stories for example). And then on top of that, this game has a TON of variation when playing with the hands of occupation and improvement cards that forces you to change your strategy.

Sometimes you may realize you've messed up and end up crashing and burning, but never have I felt like a particular game was hopeless due to my hand - I just didn't play cards or gather resources at the right time

But in other times you excel at feeding everyone ever, build yourself a stone house and have loads of farm land. It's a REAL joy to see your engine working so well

** After 5+ more multiplayer sessions**

Bumping it up to a 9 - everyone that's tried it in my experience has loved it and working around the other player's resource gathering adds another depth of complexity I really enjoy. It's also a really nice breather from games that allow you to directly crush your enemies - so this game gets worked into our rotation regularly
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.2
So many choices, yet so little in the way of resources (and so many types of resources) to play with. Nothing but difficult decisions. You really need to think through a strategy based on your cards and yet also be opportunistic when you can and be prepared to rethink when somebody else takes an item or an action you want. Masses of replayability and very deep.

Now into double figures played and still not tired of it, still look forward to pulling the game out, would still play this in preference to most other games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
To my taste, all the eurogames look (and feel) the same: even Agricola does, despite it being so highly ranked and rated by many. Like any other eurogame, it’s a multiplayer solitaire whose focus is on resource management: the theme itself is just a wrapping stuck onto their precious rulesystem and not a jointly-developed part of it. Therefore, all you can do all the time is to meditate on your next move, worry because the player before you just took the same action you wanted to, find an alternative move quickly and be content with what little it gives you, before falling into the realm of boredom again until your next turn is up.

«Be content» could be the eurogames’ motto: it fits Agricola even better, because you will never be fully satisfied by your playing it. I know eurogames take pride from their cold and uninspiring wooden bits, so when playing Agricola I can accept the big discs standing for people. I can also accept the smaller and differently colored discs standing for resources. I could even accept the usual refrain about «strategy» being an eurogame’s core, as though any other category were strategy-free: I can’t stand a game though that punishes its players for playing like Agricola does.
But it’s just a matter of being content.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Para mí el mejor juego que he jugado, mi favorito.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Don't believe the hype.  The game itself is a solid effort, but ultimately it's a fatally flawed design.  The final scoring makes it so that every player must diversify and do a little bit of everything.  This leads to scripted play and a false sense of competition over the same few resources.  There are better worker placement games.  Agricola is too tightly designed for it's own good.  Figuring out it's puzzle isn't worth the time investment.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a very good game.  Fun theme, moves at a decent pace, and the mechanics work nicely.  I don't have a problem with the card play that some people seem to have - I've won by playing barely any cards, and I've won playing lots of cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
[with Z-man deck, from Tanga]
I love this game. I've played with 1, 2, 3, and 5 players so far. All work great. I love Caylus but hate it with 5, but Agricola works great with more. The addition of more action cards with more players really keeps the play balanced and keeps the feel the same. The only difference is that the First Player action becomes more and more important as the number of players grows.

The solo game is great, too. It's different in that it's more like puzzle, because you know that no one's going to take the actions that you need. However, trying to time everything just right--especially when you don't know what actions are coming up (I keep the action cards randomized, like normal, and I took random minor improvements and occupations, too). So, it's different, but it's still a great option if you need an Agricola fix but there's no one else around to play with.

I do think that I prefer the Family Game with more players, though. I found the cards to be interesting and challenging in the solo game, but I find them to be distracting and too slow in the multi-player game (only played with them with 5 players so far, though). I love the tension of the game when no one has an advantage in certain areas based on the cards' customization of their abilities. Read the play notes on my logged play of 8/27/2008 for my initial thoughts on the cards.

UPDATE: Have played with cards two more times, both with 3 players. The second time I didn't like it, either, because the deal was really unbalanced. The third time, we did a draft and it was better. I'll play with them again, but I can't say that I love them.

UPDATE 2: Fine, I like the cards. Having played 20 times now, it's nice to mix it up with the cards. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I really like how the cards you receive alter your grand strategy, but that can get thrown out the window if there are 12 wood sitting on the woodcutter! So tight, in that there are never enough actions to do what you want. Anyone who claims multi-player solitaire has not had the one action they have to have to feed their family taken just before them. Tons of replay.

Deserving of its rank, I think. Not a 10 for me, cause of the imperfect balance of the cards, but it it so fun, and you get dealt so many cards, that I can overlook that.

RATING: 7
Rating based on the solo game and 2-player family games, plus 1.5 games with five players.  The card thing doesn't do much for me; it always seems I get a weird mix of cards that do not compliment each other in any way, so I'd rather just ignore them.  I do enjoy the family game so far.

The main thing I like about the game is its scope.  I'm not some architect assigning workers to build different parts of a castle or cathedral, with the hope of pleasing some faceless king.  That means absolutely nothing to me.  The scope of this game is narrower and more believable, and so is easier to insert myself into.

Of course the game is good too.  Could be frustrating with many players though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love it! My favourite game to date. Must have played in excess of 100 games with my wife and it still feels fresh with loads of possible options. Also when playing with 3, 4 or 5, while the core mechanic remains, the game is totally different, although just as much fun. Everyone I've introduced this game to has loved it and a copy has even been taken out to Dubai (from the UK) with one of my friends after a 2 game session.

Can't recommend it enough.

Dom
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.75
This is a very beautiful game with high-quality components but I just can't understand why it's as highly-rated as it is. My feeling is that people are rating it a 10 because they LOOOOOVE IT OMG rather than because it's actually an exceptional game. I almost gave it a 1 just to try and drag the rating down a bit. [EDIT: I'm glad I didn't, given how that sort of ridiculous behaviour has affected the PR/Agricola/TS battle over the last week - stupidity!]

It is a very good game - It's got some great features - I really like the way it rewards diversification and I love the way everything clicks into place in the last few turns if you've played it right. On the other hand, you ALWAYS wind up clicking into place in exactly the same way. I would be better disposed towards this game if I could choose my own strategy, prefereably based around some sort of specialisation.

I'm not entirely sure the decks of cards add a whole lot, either, as some are game-breaking and some are only good in the right context of other cards. I will say that I don't get the criticism that it's multiplayer solitaire. People who argue that have just missed the point.

My biggest problem with the game is the hyper-scarcity of resources in the first few turns. I also strongly dislike the tension as you wait for your friend to finish so you can finally plan your turn out with whatever spaces are reamining. This game is one of the most prone to Analysis Paralysis and it becomes unbearable with two AP'ed players. The lockout by worker placement mechanic induces the wrong sort of tension in me - anxiety. The game is also just dreadful with two players, as it ratchets up the hyper-scarcity problem, especially for wood.

Ultimately, everything this game does, other games do better.  Race for the Galaxy also feels like it ends just as your engine starts ticking over, but you can specialise. Twilight Struggle also has cards that can only be played once, but you'll see them all and the combos are somewhat reliable, given enough plays. Overall, I'll almost always pass up Agricola for four or five plays of something shorter, or a play of something more rewarding.

NOTE: I have played five or six times, with from 2-5 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Squeezes a complex depth of tactical decision into a self-limiting game design.  I love the game's complexity, richness, and ability to customize the experience through various decks or professions and minor improvements.  This game sets the bar as far as I am concerned.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's a pretty good game solo, for that I would give it a 7. With two, I'd give it an 8.  It took a little bit of effort and some back and forth in the instructions to get going, but by the end of my solo game, it was moving along nicely. 

It becomes tense as you build your farm and work to keep your family fed.  When you work it correctly, it's not difficult to keep the family fed, but to do that, you are using your points for the end of the game.  I do enjoy the wide variety of cards, as they force you into looking at starting each game differently.  

Update:  Played with four, moved it up a point to 8.5 (from 7.5).  More action availabilty, but I think it becomes more tense with more.  The clock starts winding down and you are scrambling to get your farm up to snuff.  

Update: Down to a 7 as it's a good game, but I don't see myself wanting to play it as much anymore.

Update:  6 - Been replaced by Caverna for myself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Agricola manages to almost single-handedly rescue worker placement games for me. In addition to being wonderfully thematic (even if the theme is farming), it provides multiple paths and has player interaction without being subject (as much) to a one true strategy or a run-away leader problem. Having some of the resource piles grow steadily larger means that the value of certain choices can change, and not in a way you can predict. Occupation and minor improvement cards are what make the game truly shine, however, by introducing a level of personal strategy while still providing room to work within a chosen playstyle. The fact that you can even customize the occupation cards used in a game for a more or less interactive experience is just gravy. It's a brilliant design and the best of Rosenberg's impressive work.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still, the theme is attractive and you can justifiably control your progression.

RATING: 9
What other game lets you bake bread, beg for sustenance, slaughter the family pet, and answers the question of where babies come from (out in the fields)? As far as I know, none. 
That all these things are integrated into an extremely gratifying strategy game that has been streamlined to perfection is just gravy.
I don't think it's as tight a design as Puerto Rico, but it's usually more fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun game, but there is one thing that really irks me about the game.  The occupation and minor improvement cards.  Was there no objection during playtesting that the vast majority of the cards are not worth playing?  This is actually a far worse predicament than the presence of a few overpowered cards.  

The complete mishandling of the cards are what separates this from a really great game.  Ideally they would have informed your strategic decisions and the challenge would be implementing it through the very tight tactical gameplay of the worker placement.  This would also add some variability to the game that it currently lacks, which was probably the original intent of the cards.

As it is, the game starts to feel very similar between plays.  Combine this with a brutal beginning that winnows down the contenders for victory far too early and we have a game that needed just one more layer of polish.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games for both complexity, difficulty, and replayability. Runs 30 minutes per person

This is a worker placement game where you build up a farm by building structures, growing your family, planting crops, and raising animals. It's one of those games where you want to do everything but can't and it stresses you out. 

A simpler, more beginner friendly version of this game is Caverna (most of the mechanics are exactly the same), which is a better game to start with. Agricola has mechanics that are more challenging, create more competition, and add more replayability, but are harder to learn. 

Long tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TIkxqjuQuOE
Shorter less in depth tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNjVR46Np5Y
Example turn (recommended): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b20sq4VM3Rg

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Only one play and solo with family rules.

This is a challanging game, and the struggle with not suit everyones tastes.

Short version though, I had lots of fun with the game and even solo it had me counting on my fingers and looking at alterate routes to place my workers.

With all the expansions and decks, and with the full rules set yet to explore there is a lot of game here and I recommend it!

I can't wait to get a game in with live people!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As good as everyone says. Strong theme, tense gameplay where you never have enough time to accomplish everything. Scales well with most numbers of players. Solo play isnt too bad. Cards add some spice/replayability to the mix, but also introduce some imbalance to the gameplay. 

Who doesn't have a little part of themselves that longs to be a quaint farmer? 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We purchased Agricola very early in our introduction to the hobby and were overwhelmed. We didn't have great first experiences and put it on the shelf for a long time. We revisited it after becoming much more experienced gamers and could immediately see the genius. Very tight worker placement and a need to do more than you can give this game a great feeling. Uwe has removed this tension from many of his more recent games and those have paled in comparison. This is a classic game that is a perfect representation of why the worker placement mechanic is so wonderful. The Farmer's of the Moor expansion adds some nice twists to make this game even better.

RATING: N/A
After one play. This seems to have everything I ever enjoyed about heavier Euros like Puerto Rico, Caylus, and Princes of Florence. Like those, it's attractively produced, gets the brain-box working, and let's me play the role of a "planner/manager" for awhile.  However, it's still a baroque "cube-collecting" and point scoring exercise in cardboard and wood. 

The big difference from my experience with a nearly all other euros that I've played before is that I can tell a bit of a "story" about the family whose fortunes and failings I just raised after the game is over. That's a positive change in my book and is more in line with the games with strong narratives that I enjoy so much. However, I'll withhold a rating till I've played a few more times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the game that started the hobby for me. Great sense of accomplishment after building up your "engine". Base game still feels very fresh even after 6 years and ~50 plays, due to the infinite combos that advance your farm. 2-3-4-5 player games give vastly different experiences, with 2 and 5 very cutthroat while 3-4 are maybe a little friendlier and less resource scarce. Can take a while for beginners to play through, but experienced players would have no problem playing a 5-player game in 3 hours.

RATING: 8
1st game was rough.  Learning curve is very large since there are ~200 different cards in the game, and it's hard to figure out how things are inter-connected.  It's a game of resource management and hand management.  Lots of luck in the occupation and minor improvment cards that you are dealt at the beginning... but these are the only cards that you get for the entire game so you must use them wisely (so there's a good bit of strategy).  It's neat to know the full potential of your "clan" instead of drawing cards during the game.  I want to play again soon to fix some 1st game strategy mistakes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
I bought the English edition on preorder and this is one of my most played games. There's immense replayability here due to the number of occupation and minor improvement cards (you only have 7 of each at the start of a game). There's also a number of different decks. The Basic deck and the Interactive decks are very different. The interactive deck makes this a very different game as occupations can affect others as well as your own gameplay. Agricola is a fasciniating game with a lot of options (more than you can possibly pick from) and a variety of strategies that you can use to win, like all the best Eurogames. 

The game gets spoiled in my opinion if the decks get mixed together.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant worker placement game with astounding replay value. I quietly snub anyone who loudly snubs the stressful nature of the feeding and farm-building demands.

It takes several plays to get the hang of how to time your opening moves, how to leave back-up plans for yourself, how to jump-start your food reserves, and how to leap from engine to engine. 

I read about a lot of gamers who try it once, find it too hard, and they run off to Caverna. I'm glad Agricola doesn't just hand itself to you right away. It's a game you can get better at and you WILL get better at it with each passing game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Arg. Arg. Arg.

So, I've only played this a handful of times, and almost every time, it's been as part of a group that includes people who've played it dozens and dozens and dozens of times.

I really like the family version, possibly because I did really well at it the first time, almost by accident. It can be frustrating, never managing to get quite what you need in each turn, and finding that every action takes one extra action because you just can't get that 1 stone/1 wood/1 animal extra you need to be efficient, while others do. On the other hand, when you do manage to get what you want, success seems to build on success, and the game zips along. The flavour boards and animal meeples I picked up from the Goodies deck go really well with that, and it's fun, if sometimes frustrating.

Throw in the decks with the professions and lots of cards that interact in different ways I don't really understand, and which you have to build an engine out of that I can't work out how to put together, and it just becomes ninety minutes of losing painfully.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The rating may go up. For a native AT gamer such as myself it's clear that enjoying most of what this game has to offer entails a certain discipline of learning the game's rhythms and pathways. It's very cool to see such a robust engine in the game and one that makes good sense with the theme, too. I've only played one two player game, though, with the other sessions being solo. I'm glad I own this modern classic and look forward to exploring it more in the future (the iPad app will help, no doubt).

Update: The iPad has helped me get a grip on this game. Very tight, very oppressive and tense - but in a good, thematic way. I've not heard it compared with Ghost Stories but the feeling is similar, though with an aim towards desperate construction rather than defense. The rating is up to an eight. The only reason so far that it is not higher is because I personally prefer a little bit more slack to try out new strategies; if have a wasted action or two in this game you're toast. I look forward to more sessions, though, and finding new combos; the design is amazing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What I Like:
The theme, crazy enough. The Homesteading idea of living off the land is an extremely appealing thought to me. I think it comes through nicely with the professions and minor improvements. I like the variability of the cards, forcing a new strategy each play. And the scalability between 2-4 players makes it fill a game night hole nicely with a managable playtime of around 2 hours.

What I Don't Like:
The end result seems samey. Though the path to victory may be varied, the game doesn not allow for much deviation from the "optimal farm" design. I wish there was more of an opportunity to see a variety of winning farm designs. I undertand the fun comes from the earning and rewards forward planning, but I don't feel like the games tells much of a stary once you look at your completed mat. All the varience between players seems to disappear in the final 2-3 moves. 

Why I Still Own It:
It's currently the only worker placement game I own. It playes like more of a puzzle than a game, and I enjoy that. Coupled with the theme, I forsee this one sticking around for a while.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I found the starting cards added far too much randomness, predetermining the victor in many of our games. Also, the starting hands elongate the first turn as each player goes through their fourteen options to determine their whole game strategy, making the experience uneven.

Maybe if the cards were distributed slowly throughout the game, the play would feel better paced.

If the game were shorter, the randomness of these cards would be more tolerable.

The art, concept, basic mechanic and card variety are all good, but I cannot see Agricola becoming a longstanding default game for a group.

RATING: 6
Well designed game that feels a bit overwhelming the first time you play it. It's a lot cleaner than it seems at first sight, however. The reason I don't rate it higher for such a quality title, is the frustrating notion you're always falling short. Sure, there are many games that challenge you with tough choices and scarce resources, and I like that, but in Agricola it's haunting. I guess that captures the theme of farming back in the day, but that doesn't mean I like to feel it in a game.

It's typical of Uwe Rosenberg games, but the art style doesn't do it for me. Should be a minor quibble, but I like a game better when I appreciate its looks. I'm shallow.

LIked the game better with the expansion cards. That said, it's a pity that the extra cards make it somewhat more luck driven.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A classic game with a worker placement mechanic. 

Don't judge the game by its theme. Farming is not that exciting, but it works just fine here.

Envolving, challenging and kind of... "cute". It can be tough for inexperienced players, 'cause when we take a spot, it means you can't take it, so it feels like a race for the best spots to get the right resources to build the right buildings, to get the right actions.

Note that you'll feel that you wanted to do so much more at the end of the game, but that is how it works. You'll never do everything.

A very clever game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
jestem dumny, że jestem z europy wschodniej

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I didn't think a game with a farming theme would be fun, but I was pleasantly surprised with Agricola.  So many different ways to go in the game, and you have to be prepared to change strategies or take advantage of situations that come up.  It will certainly be hitting the table again!  Now to decide if I buy this or Le Havre, or both...

This is a solid game, I'm quite happy with it.  I need to spend some time working on my strategy, but I'm sure I'll have many, many games to do that with!

I've been playing this more, and now I'm starting to see the beauty of the game.  Tons of decisions.  So many, in fact, that I can usually see multiple paths I could follow in the course of a single game.  Naturally you want to follow the most powerful course plotted by your occupations and minor improvements, but trying to stick too closely to that path when other players are blocking you can cost you the game.  My ex-wife often commented that this game (while fun) is more like real life than any other game: so many things you want to do, so little time and actions that you'll never get to do it all.  Just like life you learn to manage the game better and better with practice and get some of those things done in the end!

100 plays and I still rate this as a 10!  Most of these plays were two players, and including the Farmers of the Moor expansion.  Do I have enough in me to get to 200 plays?  Just maybe....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
It's tense and rewards clear planning and analyzing. You get some help, because your starting hand points you in a certain direction, but after that you're quite free in what you do. The best moves usually depend on what the other players do, so there's some great excitement to be had there.

너무 기대가 컸던.. 그리고 너무 기대가 컸기 때문에 약간의 실망을 안긴 게임.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I finally figured out what sucks the fun out of this game for me.  It's the decisions!  Sure, at a glance this game seems to have a lot of tough decisions, but after a while, I came to realize that no matter which path I chose, I always ended up at the same endpoint.

In reality, a botched worker placement usually doesn't matter much.  Most of the time, the next best move was worth almost as many points in the long run, so it's just a matter of how you want it to look.  I could take a veggie for a point, a cow for a point, or a few sheep for a point, or maybe just another development for a point.  Sure, it looks different, but they're all really the same when you truly boil it down.

And that's what frustrates me.  My decisions seem meaningless.  I really blame the scoring system for this.  Since you can't be tops on everything, you have to make sacrifices.  But everytime you do, you typically bump up a different track. So it's zero sum, you still end up the same.  I want a method for this game to let you go completely linear in your strategy, instead of always forcing you to half-ass everything.

These is something to be said for the "challenge" of feeding your family while still striving towards your goal.  However, I don't think it's tough enough to be judged on that basis.  If I want that sort of experience, I'll play Antiquity and have a game that truly hates me as a player. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

An interesting game which to some degree simulates the difficulties of managing a farm. Elegant design and replayability combined with the good solitare option make this a sure winner.

RATING: 9
Still a very good game, as a recent return to the game has reminded me, but not as good a Caverna which now occupies my #1 spot for worker placement games.

Maybe a hiatus in the playing of this game has re-vitalized it for me but on returning to it recently I've concluded that this could well be the definitive worker placement game complete with a fully integrated theme that has survived despite any number of expansions. The release of a very well done IOS version has also helped to renew my enthusiasm. Bound to be an enduring classic
******
Yet more play and I've notched the rating back down again. I must admit I was surprised at how fast this game rocketed to dominate the Geek Meter and even more surprised at its staying power (for now), but there was a lot going for the game in my first outings. The endless card combos salvage the game from circling into boredom (which the "family version" would have arrived at much sooner), but despite that our games are beginning to feel a bit like getting on a treadmill. Similar to "Le Havre" in that respect but with a livelier theme.
******
After more play I've notched up the rating on this game. It has become one of my favourites. There is more to this game than meets the eye and achieving a good score bestows a sense of accomplishment usually reserved for "heavier" titles. The different deck combinations make for extensive replayability.
******
Initial impression after first play is quite positive. The array of decisions and options is very broad indeed, but "Puerto Rico" looked quite intimidating at first also. RATING: 10
Wide and deep game that I've probably only scratched the surface of. The drawbacks to the game, such as they are, is that it is fiddly to set up, annoying to repopulate every turn and it can easily swamp some new players with all the detail.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Feels similar to Race for the Galaxy on the interaction side - seems only interaction is picking an an action before others, but really it's all about working out your opponents strategy and predicting what they'll be doing next. However unlike Race for the galaxy it's hard to do that because of all the cards - each one is unique and does something and it's too hard to keep track of what everyone has and what they all do, so in the end you don't bother and it becomes a puzzle game. All in all not the '10' perfect game I was hoping given all the hype. Sitting 5th in a 5 player isn't much fun either, especially if you have lame improvements or ones needing lots of occupations to play, as you in effect burn an action getting the start player back, to watch it get changed again next turn with someone doing it mainly to play an improvement ...

**Update, now have my copy, and with repeated plays a number of my concerns become less. Still not sure about 5 player though. Definitely a learning curve, with newbies I'd only stick to the E deck, and I still have reservations about the power of the cards.In some ways it's like a CCG, with some good cards and some average and some that need others to work at all. Not sure that's a good thing for a game of this length. I think I like this best with some sort of draft mechanism to limit the variation in power of the cards. 

** 2nd update - definitely flavour of the month with most of my gaming friends - and my concerns about tracking others' cards diminishes as you learn the game and the decks. Once you're progressing on the learning curve this game is great - but I still prefer to draft the cards to help balance out differences in power, rating has increased from 6, to 7 and now up to 9.

** 3rd Update - played quite a bit and rating has dropped to an 8. Might dip lower depends how much more I play it.

** 4th Update - cult of the new has taken most people on to other things, so this isn't getting as much play. I quite like it - but have no burning desire to play, rating dropped to a 7.

** 5th Update - now have the expansion, and that has helped. Base game is a 7 for me, but with the Farmers on the Moor expansion it's either an 8 or a 9 :)

RATING: 5

This is not so much a comment on the game play itself (which can also be quite slow depending on who you play with). The development of your farm is so slow.  These have to be the most inefficient farmers of all time.  The "children" in the game are full-fledged workers in one round, but it takes forever and a day to plow and sow or build a fireplace?  My highest ranked game that I really don't care if I play again.

RATING: 9
I liked it on my first play.  For me, it's a lighter game than games like Power Grid or Steam, but it provides about as much depth in play.  The cards allow for incredible variety each game.  It ends at just the right time too, meaning it ends with you BEGGING for at least five more turns.

I put off trying this one for so long because I thought it was too heavy and the theme too dry.  I was wrong.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played at BGG.Con.  This game has a lot of potential replay value because of all the cards and how they change your situation in the game.  I had fun figuring out how to make a go of it with just the tools on hand.  At the end of the game there's a sense of accomplishment when you've created a successfull farm.

I am concerned however that Agricola may not have enough player interaction to aviod the multiplayer-solitare pitfall.  More playing are needed to see if Agricola lives up to the hype.

I'm dropping the rating to a 6.  Once the newness of the game wore off I began to see Agricola for what it is.  A mediocre worker placement game that has a real lack of player interaction, soul and fun.  Sure the cards add a nice element of the unknown, but once you seen them all the game become nothing more than a near-solitare logistics puzzle.  Even the vaunted "I" or interactive deck dosen't change that assessment as most of the iteraction is very indirect or parasitic in nature.  In fact I call it the "P" deck.

This is another case of hype overselling a game beyond its actual merits.  It's not a bad game it's just *meh*.

RATING: 8

I think because they can relate to it. Works well for 2 and 4 players (haven't tried 1,3 or 5 yet). I have played the game about 10 times now.Family version 6 or 7 times and normal only with 2 players.

Okay, I have explained this game to about 10 people now and most people seem to enjoy it quite a bit, but I have had some complaints that there are too many actions with too little workers. The replayability is tremendous. So far I have only used the E-deck and I am not even close to trying the I, K and Z deck. This is a top game and I am curious to see how Le Havre will do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Well, after my first play of this legendary game I'm giving it an 8. After further plays I can see it going up to 9. Will it get a 10 from me? I don't think so...

My problem with this game is that there are too many difficult decisions. Don't get me wrong... I love Puerto Rico and Caylus... two heavy games with a lot of tough decisions. But with those two, I feel that with a reasonable amount of time and a reasonable amount of effort, I can hit upon my optimal move and confidently make my decision. But with Agricola... not a chance. I've never been one prone to AP issues... but this game left me struggling to make a decision. It seemd like every move I made left me full of regret.

It's a strange criticism for a game, I know.

***

After a few more games, I'm sticking Agricola with an 9. THe downtime can be tough, especially with 5 players, which for me disqualifies it from a coveted "10" rating. Another point against it is that it isn't a very visually-appealing game; our tabletop during games of Agricola are a complete mess.

It's still a good game... not just the PUerto Rico-killer some are making it out to be.

***

After some more playing and much contemplation on the matter, I've decided to raise Agricola to a 10. Once you become more familiar with it the game speeds up and the decisions become a little bit easier. But what really convinces me is the game's cards, which encourage different approaches to victory.

UPDATE (Jan. 2010): I'm lowering this to an 8.5 because I now prefer Le Havre over Agericola. There's a a good g ame in there, but I find the fiddlieness and messiness of the gaming exsperience to be distracting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

It was challenging, and made me think, and had a lot of strategy and meaningful decisions.  But it wasn't very fun.  I'm still trying to figure out why.  I feel like I should have liked it, but my response is just Meh.  I have put this one on hold for the wishlist for now, and will borrow a friend's copy to play a few more times.

RATING: 9
Initial Rating: 7 (8/7/2008)

A worker placement game where there's never enough of what you need to do what you want.

Two player family game was fun, and competition got fierce for key spaces (such as wood and reeds). Though I anticipate suggesting this be brought to the table in the foreseeable future, it is more fiddly than Puerto Rico, and that detracts a bit from the play.

Played 4 player and there's a vast difference in resource allocation and distribution with that number. I still think this is very fiddly with all the wooden bits moving around.  Competition was again fierce, only this time over different key spaces.

RATING: 3
5x 2 [0-5] [80']

(5 plays) Initial Rating: 6 After five 2 player games and one solitaire I think that this is a decent game, but nothing more than that.

It has got nice components, the theme fits very well and it plays reasonably fast. It doesn't have much interaction (no direct one, some indirect interaction) and in fact it is a multiplayer solitaire.

It doesn't live up to the hype though and in my oppinion it doesn't earn its No. 1 spot in the game ranking here on BGG.

Updated after 5 games: 
the more I play it the more I hate it. 

The mechanics work but they are no fun at all.The game involves a preposterous amount of bookkeeping (e.g filling the board with new resources at the beginning of a turn), the harvest phases are really clumsy, the symbols on the cards (cost, points etc.) are hard to distinguish, ... I am still willing to try it with more than 2 players, but if 3 or 4 player games don't convince me, this one goes to the trading pile! Lowered rating to 5.

Updated after 6 games:

RATING: 10
I absolutely love Agricola. Though some consider the theme to be rather bland, there is something about building something out of nothing that is rather appealing. The game is usually pretty tense in the last few turns as everyone is competing to complete their planned out strategy, which really gives the game momentum in the end. This usually leaves everyone wishing there was one more turn. I've heard both "If I only would've had ONE more action!" and "We need to play this again... like right now" numerous times when playing this game. It's always left me anticipating the next game rather than wishing it was a turn longer so I could make the perfect farm. One of my favorites for sure.

RATING: 10

Warning:  not only is this game addictive, it will show up in your dreams!  Rating based on about a dozen plays (1-5 player), all with E deck.  Must paste up I and K decks!  UPDATE:  After a couple of plays with a mixed E and I deck, rating goes up to a 9.5, because I really would rather be playing Agricola at pretty much any given minute of the day.  I'm holding off upping this to a 10 until the initial infatuation has worn off -- we'll see where things stand in February or so.  UPDATE:  Okay, after 40  plays over three months, it's a 10.  Even as I type this I'm having a hard time resisting the urge to invite some gamers over for a game or three!

At its heart, this is a civ-building game.  There is luck in the initial hand composition, but I'm not convinced that it plays a conclusive role.  I've seen a player come in a very close second despite playing no occupations and only 1 or 2 minor improvements.  Instead, he focused on starting his fields and pastures and scooping major improvements while the rest of us were bickering over occupation and start player spaces.

RATING: 9
[b]Sheepies:[/b] What phrase could adequately sum up Agricola? I love this game, in all of its fiddly, stressful, and multiplayer-solitaire awesomeness. In fact, I think the last quality actually makes it really excellent for groups in which some people might get offended by too much "interaction." The only thing that could make this game better for me would be more of a spatial component - which has made me really curious about Farmers of the Moor, or the [filepage=46343]"rocky ground" variant [/filepage] by GameRulesforOne. 

+ [thing=43018]Farmers of the Moor[/thing]
+ [thing=85704]Gamer's Deck[/thing]
+ [thing=103183]World Championship Deck—2011[/thing]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I enjoy Agricola. The farming theme is very well done, and I get a kick out of growing grain and raising pigs to feed my family. I think the designers did a brilliant job of turning a humble subject into a rich game. It's surprisingly tense--feeding your family quite difficult, and the game punishes you harshly if you can't come up with enough food at harvest time. You're constantly battling against the feeling that you're running out of time and not getting enough done. This is both a good and a bad thing.

While I think Agricola is undeniably a good game, I have enough quibbles that it falls a bit short of excellence, in my eyes. First, it is not very interactive. You are competing with the other players for the same resources, so there's some interaction there, but there's pretty much nothing you can do to affect anything that's on your opponent's board. So the game can feel a little static. It can also get boring as you wait between turns for your opponents to make their decisions. Two-player Agricola plays pretty fast, but with three or four players expect to do a lot of waiting around.

My second complaint is that actually farming tends to be a losing strategy, which is totally nuts for a game called "farmer." I would love to start plowing fields and planting crops in the early game--but that is so action-intensive and inefficient that it is a sure loser (unless you have the right special improvement or occupation support.) Ranching is typically a vastly superior way of feeding your family. You'll do a bit of farming towards the end of the game to grab some points, but that's usually about it. Why does a farming game make farming so unattractive? The balance just doesn't feel right.

Finally, I don't love Agricola's scoring system. Players receive a fixed amount of points for having certain quantities of most of the products in the game: pigs, sheep, cows, etc. The problem is that the game harshly punishes the player for not having at least 1 of everything. This forces everyone to diversify in pretty much the same way, and means that everyone's farm looks similar at game's end. Furthermore, the actually point totals are arbitrary. You get -1/1/2/3/4 points for 0/1/3/5/7+ Wild Boar... and -1/1/2/3/4 points for 0/1/2/4/6+ Cattle. It's clunky and unintuitive. I also don't like that amassing huge quantities of one animal is not rewarded. It's a big accomplishment to get 15 wild boar, so why does the game not reward that at all? I think Caverna is a vast improvement on Agricola in this respect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
The game has an impressive number of cards in the several decks that come with it. This seems to be the essence of its appeal, lending a great deal of variety. However, some cards are better than others. Even with this imbalance issue, they don't dominate play. The decisions made in taking the finite number of actions is very crucial, and to me makes this game shine as a superb development game with every action counting. The key is combining the right cards into one's playing field with proper action selection both before and after these cards are played down. The actions are few (2-3 per turn), which keep the game going. UPDATE: Bumped down to a 9 as it has not been requested near as much lately. Perhaps the demanding attention required for the regular game play (not family game) has reduced requests. UPDATE: Liked the card drafting variant at the beginning to avoid some bland card hands. Upgraded again to a 10.

Solid worker placement game with varied yet predictable set-up, tons of replayability with the cards, and lots of tension. The tension is what makes the theme of clawing your way to survival come alive. Surprisingly easy to teach because of the theme, but hard to do well on your first couple games

If you are looking for a relaxing game this is definitely not the game for you!

RATING: 9
1-5 | (3-4) | 120 min | 12+ | Uwe Rosenberg 
Mixed feelings about Agricola. My rating varies between a 6 and an 8 depending on the day. What annoys me is that every game feels the same due to the final scoring conditions. You can finish your farm in many different ways, but you are basically trying to build the same farm, with a bit of everything. I like Le Havre much better because you can specialize.
--------------------------------
Update 1: Yesterday I played my first 5 player game. It was a wonderful experience, way better than 2 player games.
--------------------------------
(June 2010) All right, I bow to the evidence: this is a 9 if you draft the cards at the beginning of the game. After some more plays, Agricola tops Le Havre, though admittedly not by much. The fact that goals are shared in Agricola means there is more competition and interaction.
--------------------------------
(April 2017) Final verdict: still the best worker placement game out there and my favorite Uwe design by a mile. All-time Top 10 in my collection.

RATING: 7
When I play this game, I feel very hungry and oppressed. In that aspect, the theme is very successful. It does feel too much like work, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Based on one 5 player game.

Its basic platform is on a fairly standard worker placement mechanism (similar to Caylus, Pillars of the Earth, Stone Age).

Where it shines and frustrates (at the same time) is the myriad of occupation and minor improvement cards. We randomly dealt the 7 cards from both decks and some players had lousy hands while some had awesome combos; thus unbalancing the game. We will try the draft mechanism next time.

The actions were very tight, constantly making you feel like you don't have enough actions and time to do all the things you want to do. Slightly reminiscent of In the Year of the Dragon's tension of disaster aversion, since you are constantly fighting to get food and acquiring every category to avoid negative VPs.

Look forward to future games. It may go up after more plays.

Update: Played a second game. This time a 3 player game. VERY tight actions. Definitely need a good food engine. We played with the card drafting variant. It very much balances out the hands.

Update: 
Rating 8.5 -> 9.0
Played a 5-player game with the Interactive Deck and card drafting. It was very intense! Everyone became very involved. The card drafting took 50 minutes but it was worth it because it balanced out the game. Some players had many awesome cards while others had really lousy hands. The card drafting fixed all that. The interactive deck made it less multi-player solitaire. Agricola is a winner. Much more 'fun' than Puerto Rico.

Update:
Rating 9.0 -> 9.5
It scales well to 3 to 5 players. Got the drafting down to 10 - 20 minutes (depending whether there are AP players present). Lots and lots of tension. So much to do in so little time. It's a game worthy of the anticipation and hype. We can all celebrate it being the new #1!!! (though it's not a top 5 for me, it is more worthy of #1 than P.R.)

I own the animeeples, vegemeeples, resourceeples, Z-deck, X-deck, Ö deck, signed L deck, Through the Seasons, 5 new player boards, new player colours. Yes, mine is all pimped up.

WARNING: Through the Seasons breaks the game. The expansion rates a "2". AVOID!!!!

Update Aug 2013 dropped to 8.5. Worker placement is wearing thin, though the 'gric stands its ground against other WPs.

RATING: 3
The emperor has No Clothes!
 Despite all the hype, Agricola does not have elegantly simple mechanics for its abstract parts and almost enough details to be a simulation (not its aim)
Great graphics, components (animeeples are neat) and ideas but too many special conditions and fine print. Other problems: too many rule-breakers; need apriori knowledge of card order; clay should be red and stone – white (maybe straw, twigs, bricks a la 3 pigs?); hand size too big and varied. In need of a major editing; maybe I will try the no-card family version. Can see how it could be addicting as you learn a little more each time and want a “replay” (like a video game) to try and “beat the system” (which is randomized by the huge number of cards.)

RATING: 10
Enjoyed the basic game.  Good fun.  An optimisation game, something I don't usually like.  I imagine I will enjoy this one on repeat plays.  My only concern is that this game could last a little long for what it is.  And there is no way on Earth I would ever select this as a gateway game - some have claimed it can be, I just do not see it!

This is an excellent game to be sure, but certainly not friendly to people who have not played before, let alone to people who have not really played games before.  It is satisfying building up the farm, but the game can be cruel, the rules complex (a lot of little exceptions and modifications), and the play length too long for what I would consider foisting upon an unsuspecting gamer-to-be...

That aside, it is a very good game that I think I will enjoy playing a lot.  I don't think I will ever get obssessed with this game, but I will certainly enjoy it, and am glad to have pre-ordered it.

My copy has arrived - looks very nice!!  I am impressed with the feel and look of the game - posts that write about the heavy weight of the game are not exaggerating!

Update: The wife and I really enjoy building our own little farms.  The cards provide quite wild swings (ie: good cards can make a huge difference), but for all that, it is a great game that is relatively simple to play and enjoyable to experience.  Well worth a 9 Rating in my book, and well worth the price and shelf space.  Top game.

Update:  My wife and I have played this over 25 times - for a game that requires this much set up Agricola is still a lot of fun and we love getting it out to play.  I've bumped the rating to 10.

That's one of the things that I love about Agricola.
