=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Impossible to ignore the quality of design here, but not a game I enjoy playing - despite very much enjoying other eurogames. I just find the "indirect" player interaction in many worker placement games irritating rather than tense or enjoyable. 

I found it was just too easy for players to spoil other player's plans in this game, with little punishment for deviating from their own strategy. Furthermore, this spoiling can completely stop you dead in your tracks - meaning you can finish the game without even completing your plans. In some games this type of agony in defeat is the source of enjoyment in a game and what keeps you returning for more - or the risk of this type of defeat is the engine behind a tense battle of wits. However in both games of Agricola I have played, my plans being foiled felt more like I was tripped before the finish line as opposed to being out-run by my opponent in first place. 

I have rated the game a 7 because I think I can see some of the game's appeal, and do I think I would play it again if suggested. However, this isn't a game I enjoyed at all during my first two plays. Although there are parts of the game that intrigued me, I think my curiosity to play it again has much more to do with wanting to see what so many others see in this game - rather than for enjoyment's sake - but also because the game has me entirely confused as to whether I think it's "good" or "bad". One I will be surprised if I never play again, but not one that I will be actively looking to get to the table for a long time.

RATING: 10
Sheep (Ovis aries) are quadrupedal, ruminant mammals typically kept as livestock. Like all ruminants, sheep are members of the order Artiodactyla, the even-toed ungulates. Although the name "sheep" applies to many species in the genus Ovis, in everyday usage it almost always refers to Ovis aries. Numbering a little over one billion, domestic sheep are also the most numerous species of sheep.

Shut up about the sheep.

Fine.

Tell me about the game.

Whatever.  

No, seriously.

This game gets a 9 because it is well themed, reasonably well paced with little downtime, and the expansions are fantastic.  For once, a game that has a ton of variability and replayability due to the cards.  I wish other game makers (ex: Phoenecia) would learn from Agricola and add a ton more variation.  Sure, it's a lot more work in game balance, but it's well worth it.   Only complaint is that a few occupation/upgrades do seem to be considerably under or overpowered.  I suspect more tweaking should be done in this regard, and would be welcome in a 2nd edition (with even more expansion cards of course!)  The expansions ensure that the seeds for an entertaining game are sown.

2015:  upped to a 10.  Simply one of the few games that I'd be willing to play anytime.   I do like that we are now so familiar with this game that we can knock it out in about 40 minutes.

RATING: 8
How come I'm enjoying being one step from starvation AND losing horribly to all comers?  This game is brutal, but I really love it (including the family version.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
This game is great, I won't blabber on about it and review it, instead I'll give some pointers and impressions after more than 10 games. 

It's very complex! When you are a beginner you want to imitate you opponents strategies to keep up, or worse you'll want to focus on only one thing the entire game, like creating lots of fields and plowing an sowing like mad. 

After a couple of games you learn that imitating an opponent is near impossible because of limited resources and you are better of trying to start one of the other possible strategies (1. building a room for future family, 2. upgrading house, 3. fields, 4. animals), it's usually not as simple as this because some strategies might be blocked by others.

You have to be very flexible and focused. Don't abuse one strategy and forget about the others. Don't waste actions on taking food, instead produce it while you do other actions (see major improvements). 

When you want a minor improvement it's a good idea to take the starting player as well (if you don't have it) but don't obsess about the starting player it's not worth wasting action on that one unless you have an improvement in mind.

This might help you win against your spouse/girlfriend, because I used to take a serious beating from mine before I started focusing on a flexible strategy.

This game is really fun, even with two players. I recommend using the cards as well, don't get stuck on the family version for too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game, love how the board changes everytime. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Deep, multi-layered farm building sim. One of a small subset of Euros that greatly encourages deep, long-term strategizing.

When I read the rules, I thought it might be too fiddly, but I was pleasantly surprised by the game's pacing and fun factor. Everyone that I've played it with has been enthusiastic about trying it again.

Note: my group still enjoys this game after 20+ plays. However, I must caution that we always play the drafting variant (draw 7 occupations and minor improvements, pass 6 to your left, etc.). Without this modification, I think the inherent randomness of the card draws would have soured the experience for us. Feeling that you lost a game due to someone else's lucky (read: synergistic) draws isn't fun.

RATING: 7
The game is fun. But I find the opening strategies a bit limited. It seems to me that you want to grow your family as quick as possible, but if you don't get enough wood early on, this becomes very difficult to accomplish. The middle part of the game is the best, if you have your four or five member family, there are many options to grow your farm. The end game is mostly a scramble to diversify your farm to avoid negative point penalties.

The occupation and minor improvement cards are interesting, but you can be dealt a lot of duds if you do not get the right combination of cards. It can be frustrating to see your opponents lay down great combinations of cards while you are having trouble getting the resources you need.

RATING: 9
It's not the next Puerto Rico, and saying it's the next Caylus will sell it short.  Agricola is something else altogether, and it's quite special. The fun factor is huge!  While the game is a lot of fun and the system is pretty cool, the game rises or falls based on the cards. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
As you can likely tell from the sheer number of games of it I've played, Agricola is an old favorite. Sure, these days it seems a little less thrilling than it did back in the day (the day being the days right after we got it, when we could play 2 or 3 games of it in one sitting!), but mostly that's because so many other games have cribbed off of it, and worker placement is less hot than it once was. And I must admit, some of the shine has come off the game - at the same time, surviving 40+ plays without reaching sick and tired status is pretty good.

My main gripe with the game is that the scoring is a little humdrum. The game rewards balanced, large farms, and the chances for "specialty" scoring are pretty low, usually a few extra points based around an improvement. So the play tends to start fitting a pattern and it becomes easy, depending on the player count, to predict who will go for what when. Since it is hard to specialize, the game can feel samey after a while. The variety of cards help ward this off, but it's not quite enough. If you're getting into this now, rather than 3 years ago, I'd highly recommend getting the Farmers of the Moor expansion too - it adds a lot.

Note: Having played Caverna, I'd rank Agricola higher. Caverna is too close to Ora & Labora - lots of possible ways to go. (A lot of his recent designs seem to trend this way). There is more tension in Agricola as feeding is tougher. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
A very good game. There are lots of choices to make, and with all the occupations and minor improvements you get a different experience every time you play. I also like that there are abundant opportunities to increase the challenge as you get more experienced. 

The game can be very punishing, though, especially if you get pushed out of a crucial spot, so it sometimes feels as if the game itself is an additional opponent for you to defeat. The drab cubes and discs included with the base game are awful, and almost make it unplayable IMHO. Getting the meeples is a must. 

My new preferred way of playing is the amazing iOS app, which might just replace the cardboard version for me once they include more decks. Hopefully they'll add Farmers of the Moor down the line.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like the way the game develops, the aspect of competing for choices from the limited number of actions each turn, and the scoring system which rewards several different paths to victory.  The weakness in the game, which is also the attraction for many, is the randomness of the cards.  One player getting a lucky combination of cards that work well together will dominate over the rest who do not get that lucky.  I also think the cards that score bonus points at the end of the game for things that players will want to do anyway because those actions are worth points (like building a home out of stone) are unbalancing because some players may get them while others do not.  For the game to really work for me there needs to be a method for controlling that variability or balancing it out.  Something like having separate decks for bonus point cards, resource amplification cards, rule-breaking cards, etc. and then dealing an equal number of cards from each deck out.  Won't fix the problem of unbalanced individual cards, or of lucking into cards that work well with each other, but at least it would give everyone an equal spread among the different card types (e.g., everyone would get 1 or 2 bonus point cards).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fiddly, complex, euro-style fun.

RATING: 8.5
Strangely I wasn't that anxious to play this despite, or rather because of, the hype.  First impressions are of volume - of pieces - of options - and of rules.  Once you get into it the rules become a little clearer but, in a similar way to Caylus, extra options are added regularly - though here that is driven by the game rather than the players' actions and, unlike Caylus, most of them open up radical new possibilities rather than more of the same, albeit a slightly different variety.  The end result is lots of options to distract you if you're not careful and end game scoring which rewards those who aren't distracted.  On first sight it looks like scoring is balaced between all the aspects of the game but I suspect that isn't quite the case, though it will take some more games to work out the sweet spots.  Looking forward to playing again.  Further play has increased my score, with perhaps more increases to come - there's certainly a lot here to like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent game. Lots of thinking and planning required.
Been playing with 3 players which is a good number. 5 players may slow down the game considerably.
Requires players to be at the same level of expertise.
UPDATE:
After having played several games I have found that the game is one of worker efficiency. You want to be able to complete as many actions as possible. Whenever you have the option to perform two actions you should do so, The seven occupation and minor improvement cards act as a focus for your game strategy and the right combination can give you the winning advantage.
Whilst some planning ahead for future rounds is worthwhile you don't want to do too much of one thing between any one harvest.
As a result the game is about balance as scoring penalizes you for specializing too much and ignoring facets of your farm (though some cards can work around this, of course!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The daddy of worker placement games. Another game about reacting to what's infront of you and (like all worker placement) maximising your opportunity. The beauty of this game is that you will have 100* things you want to do and you'll have to pick 2 or 3! *OK - slight hyperbole!

Without the minor improvement and occupation cards the strategy to win is perhaps too similar each play, but these cards really add a flavour to the game, allowing you to try a different route to victory each time of play. And frankly there are enough cards even in the basic game to mean that you will never see exactly the same combos come around again.

I really like the fact that the board is different depending on the number of players which keeps it fresh, but most importantly perfectly balanced.

RATING: 7
OK, I think the 7 rating is about where this settles. It's a fun game, and I usually enjoy it, but I'm starting to weary of it as I find the cards to be frustrating as often as they are fun. Also, I think the pressure on wood in the early game is a bit too high, putting a heavy premium on cards that can bootstrap wood (or reeds). Not sure. But the balance doesn't seem right. Usually you know if you have a shot by the second harvest, and usually I know if I've won by that point; the early game is just really tight, and people who get ahead early will win. Also, as I mention, the huge variety implied by the vast number of cards seems deceptive; too many cards are too weak or specialized to be useful very often, and the I and K decks do not seem to stand alone well, so you need at least some E cards to make the game work, which seems to result in seeing the same core cards being played over and over again since they are the most versatile and useful.
---
UPDATE: Well, I've docked my rating a point. I still like Agricola, but I think the initial appearance of variety is deceptive. I think the card mix is too large, too inconsistent, and too surprisingly similar. It's not so much that there are strong cards, but that there are too many weak, useless, or too-highly-specialized cards, and that overall the cards are not helping the theme as much as I thought. I've found myself looking at my cards and seeing only a few legitimate plays and too few really interesting cards. I think the decks needed a round of culling to bring the card count down but the consistency up. It seems that not many games are going to be spoiled for everyone by one player getting great cards and dominating, but having your own game spoiled by a lousy draw occurs with somewhat disappointing frequency.

Also, the early game (Phase I & II) are dominated by getting a food engine going. This is almost entirely contingent on getting cards that enable you to do so in some way. Getting cards that accelerate getting that food engine going seems a huge advantage. Likewise, if you *don't* get that engine going by then, you're done and hardly need to play the rest of the game.
---
After playing some more, this may finally be a game the hypemeisters and I can agree on, more or less. First time through I enjoyed it but it didn't quite suck me in, but more play has improved my opinion. It's thematic enough, and balanced enough to be interesting (unlike similar games, there is almost always something productive to do, instead of having two or three good choices and "the rest"). I think the cards do a good job of allowing the game to have a pretty clean core system, with theme, depth and interest then introduced through the huge variety of cards.

It's still not perfect - the endgame scoring is a little awkward, and the rewards for doing things are not quite lined up with in-game activities, so you end up building worthless fences from time to time just to get a few VPs. There also can be a little lock-up at the end because almost every activity scores points for something, but it's not a smooth curve, there are peaks and plateaus, so towards the end you have to do a little more theme-breaking math than you'd ideally like. It's a little gamey, it would nice if it were better, but it's not a major problem, I think; it's close enough, and for the most part the game lets you play reasonably intuitively.

Definitely keep the player-count to 4 or fewer. 5 is too many, in my opinion - the game becomes too slow.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The coolest thing about this game to me is that your "scoreboard" isn't just a victory point track, but the actual engine you are building throughout the game. Impressively well balanced (not to say perfectly) across 2-5 players, particularly given how many cards there are.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Update 11/6/10.

Before you read on, I need to make my bias perfectly clear: Agricola was the first "complex" Euro that I ever played.  It came immediately on the heels of Puerto Rico, and I found it so much richer, more challenging, and intuitive, that I immediately fell in love.  Consequently, however, Agricola also stands as a measuring stick--a Platonic form of Eurogame, against which others are measured.  Because of its central role in shaping my perspective, I strongly doubt that anything I have to say about the game can be considered "balanced" or "objective."


Agricola will always remain among my top-rated games, and, to me, it is characterized by two features that I think it does better than nearly any game.

First, it is archetypal of one style of Eurogame that I enjoy immensely: that in which players struggle within the confines of a highly restrictive game system, creating tension simply from the panic that players experience trying to keep their heads above water.  Agricola is the only game that has made me literally sweat at I'm performing my last action or two.  It's not that the decisions are all that hard, but optimal play requires careful sequencing that is easily thrown off by the choices of others.  Working flexibility and a backup plan into the game is the true source of challenge.  Particularly with three players (which is my preferred number of players for games), the tension toward the endgame is unbearably delicious  

Second, Agricola does the single-best job of any game in my collection integrating theme with gameplay (especially impressive when you consider just how many occupation and improvement cards there are).  If I plow a field in Agricola, my thought process is: well I ought to plant something to put this thing to use. And if I plant some grain, I can bake bread later, which will require an oven, so maybe I'll get some clay now while it's cheap. None of this is explicitly in terms of victory points, or action/opportunity costs (although those do help guide and shape more tactical decisions). At this stage, I'm just trying to build a cool farm in a game about farming.  And building a cool farm is a winning strategy, so there's no thematic disconnect.  The farming feels like farming; the snozberries taste like snozberries.   

If forced to list Agricola's weaknesses, I would point out that I find the game lacking with only two players.  The gameplay isn't dramatically different, but your opponent's choices are more obvious, and there are fewer game-altering events between each of your moves, so the need for flexibility (what I cited above as "the true source of challenge") is meaningfully reduced.  This weakness is drastically improved by the addition of Farmers of the Moor.  I would also point out that some people are bothered by the impact that the initial card draw has on the game, and also by the lack of variety -- you're building the same farm every time.  I am not bothered by these criticisms, but they exist and I would be remiss not to mention them. 

So, basically, I love the game.

[b]My #7 Favorite Game[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I might rate this game higher if I played it fairly regularly. As it is, it has a hell of a steep learning curve and since I play so infrequently, I have to re-learn every time, and this dampens the experience a lot.

This is a longer game than I typically go for, but this is really an excellent system. The resource game is taut and exciting, and there's a massive amount of variety thanks to the fantastic occupation cards with very little in-game luck.

It is just... well, a bit fiddly. The rules have a slew of gotchas, and it's just very hard for me to process everything that's going on in this game. Specifically, the scoring system feels much more convoluted than it needs to be. Perhaps some of these things are just an issue of presentation, but either way, it's just plain difficult for me to get an idea of how well I'm doing sometimes.

It's also only fun if all players are roughly the same skill level. It's very easy to fall behind, and when a game is this long you really don't want to be the one in last.

Though the idea of farming is boring, the colorful board makes the theme feel quite charming (and relevant). I just wish that the base set included all the special animeeple/resourceeple bits that came later, instead of cubes. It seems small, but they improve the experience tenfold.

All in all, this is a design I hugely respect, but my personal tastes skew a bit cleaner and shorter.

RATING: 8
This fun game tells a great story in an abstract way.  I feel like I'm part of an important, yet simple slice-of-life adventure.  You are participating in a short story in which you are the main character.  It places high demands on reading comprehension

The 300+ cards create an infinite number of replayable scenarios.  It takes 10-15 minutes at the beginning to set-up and read all the cards that you get.  You need to be in the right mood to enjoy this, it is a time commitment and requires a lot of mental energy.

There is a lot of down time with 5 players.  Expect 30 minutes per player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Agricola is the archetypal worker placement Euro and one of the best games not only of that genre, but of Eurogaming in general.  The basic mechanics of the game are incredibly simple - place workers and carry out actions; retrieve workers; harvest crops, feed workers, and breed animals, if required - but the freedom of choice that one has with regards to how to develop one's farm, grow crops, keep animals, build Improvements, and use Occupations is amazing.  Also, the variety of Improvements and Occupations provided and the different ways in which they interact make for infinite replayability.  Who thought a game about farming could be so much fun?  Truly, one of Uwe Rosenberg's masterpieces and a pinnacle of gaming!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
The number of strategic options in this game are mind-boggling.  A beautifully produced game that is fun, because it feels like you are actually producing something.  This game does suffer from the worker placement problem that I have noticed in Caylus and Pillars of the Earth.  Due to its tactical nature, the indirect competition can be rather frustrating.  I also like Caylus more because it is not just a point grab as Agricola is, but rather a game where you manufacture points abstractly.  In Agricola, many turns boil down to weighing how many points each option immediately gets you.  Again, small criticisms of an otherwise amazing game.  It's number one for good reason.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For me, Agricola lies on the very edge of complexity in terms of what I am able to enjoy. 

Where Ora et Labora and Glass Road took the concept of special power combos to an absurd, bewildering degree with dozens of interlocking buildings and goods, the fact that it is limited here to 14 individual cards that you can examine before the game, and then a manageable amount of major improvements is limiting enough that I feel I can drive through a coherent strategy. 

There is also just enough interaction in competition for spaces and buildings that I feel like I am playing a game against other players. And the theme is excellent and ties everything together nicely. 

That said, this is never going to be the style of game that I can love - individual player boards and everyone trying to maximize efficiencies somewhat independently. But my favorite of this type. 

And the fact that I have probably played 50 times and don't cringe when it comes out is probably enough to warrant a 7. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
[u]October 09:[/u] After 4 2p games with 2 different people. We all lied the game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First of all, I think every review should contain positive as well as negative aspects of a game. So let's start with my problems with Agricola: ...

Good, now that I have mentioned all of the flaws in Agricola (just kidding; there are two issues, and I will get back to them later), let's continue with why Agricola is actually my favorite game of all time! There is so much to do each turn yet you can't do all of them which is quite frustrating but, to me, strangely satisfying as you really have to balance the value of the different spots on the board. Also, you can block opponents by taking an important spot, so it can be played with just the right, small amount of nastiness/aggressiveness which I like. The tension in the harvest phases is great; you're always worried about whether you've collected enough food and you're almost always barely paying the food limit. Get a begging card and you will have a hard time winning...

I like that there is no optimal move in the start of the game like there is in Puerto Rico where you "should" pick Settler and grab a quarry... However, in Agricola, there are a lot of good options throughout the game and no dominant strategy (not that there is one in PR either, not at all). Still, it's almost always a good idea to try and grow your family as soon as possible as more actions usually transfer to more victory points - just be sure that you are able to feed your offspring!

You might have a couple of occupations/minor improvements which suggest that you should perhaps plow a couple of fields and sow grain, or that you should grab some clay and build a fireplace etc., and even though the cards definitely do not push you in any direction and determine your strategy, they ensure that you can't use the same strategy every time - and that's a huge plus as each game will play out differently! There are different paths to victory but you always need to get a little bit of everything which I think is a cool feature compared to other games where it's good to focus on specific stuff. 

Here, you need to get a big family, upgrade your house, get all kind of different animals, build fences, plow fields etc. and it can be pretty hard to do so when you also need to get food... Which leads me to saying that I really like the two main strategies for getting food! It does seem that I'm personally better at being a rancher than a baker and I prefer this strategy, but again it kind of depends on the cards and what the other players do; again, it shows that Agricola does have interaction between the players and that you need to improvise in order to win! Sure, you can lay down a big strategy, but when the people block you off from the spots you want to go to, you need to adapt and make some tactical changes...

There is luck in the game and some cards are better than others, but I have never felt I have won or lost due to lucky draws (and my opponents haven't complained about that being the case either). 
Many of the cards are good if played correctly, and after all it's not like you're going to play 10 occupations/minor improvements during the game... I think the cards add a great variety; so far I've almost only played with the E-deck, but I'm going to play much more with the I, K, CZ, Ö etc. decks going forward - and I can't wait to try the crazy X and L decks, although those seem to be somewhat silly, so they are definitely not decks I'm going to play a lot, and after 50 games I still haven't used them...

Now, let's talk about the few issues I have with Agricola. Because, yes, I do have something negative to say even though I've rated it a perfect 10. First of all, there is the luck of the draw - I've played a couple of games where I basically just knew right when I was dealt the cards that I would lose... And that kind of sucks! Still, it hasn't happened too often, and if you're drafting it shouldn't be a problem, and if you play with 10-7 like I do it's also not too likely. Just be aware that sometimes you can be screwed by the cards...
The other thing I don't really like is the fact that family growth is a strong move - more actions in a worker placement game is almost always a good idea! This means that the first half of the game is a frantic pace of collecting resources in order to build a new room (well, it's not exactly this bad, but you get the gist). It's very hard (well, almost impossible) to win if you only have two actions each round while your opponent has four... But everybody knows this, so everybody usually gets their third action soon after the first player does. However, and this is what bothers me a little, you never know when the family growth action is going to show up - meaning that you have to hope that it turns up the round after you just took starting player, otherwise you almost have to take it again just to prevent the other players with empty rooms in doing so, and this can be a wasted action.

Despite these flaws, I love to play Agricola! It's my favorite game, followed by Terra Mystica with Hansa Teutonica and Castles of Burgundy in a combined third place.

Oh, finally I guess I have to compare it to Le Havre (which is a great game as well) like many do... However, to me, Le Havre honestly didn't remind me of Agricola at all except for the facts that ressources accumulate until somebody grabs them and that you need to have enough food at the end of a round - and that is where the (lovely) frustrations and your planning come into play! 

Overall Agricola is an extremely balanced game with no superior strategy and it works very well with 1-5 players - yes, I have even tried it solo - the only game IIRC that I've played solo, that's how much I like it, and it works well. I haven't played it much with the full 5 players, and I think I prefer it with 4. It only takes around 1-1½ with 3, at least for our group, so it's a game which will definitely be hitting the table a lot in the future!

So all in all: it's a brainburner, has huge replayability, scales incredibly well, the components are great, it's tense - the gameplay is just awesome!

I'm pretty sure that I won't grow tired of it and I always want to play it, so I have to give this wonderful game a perfect 10 - it's my favorite!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Can be hard to plan ahead when it's not your turn. Also some of the occupations (particularly in combination with others) seem overly powerful making the game unbalanced from the start. Has downtime issues with more than three. The end of game scoring system rewards those who have a very rounded farm and punishes players who have tried to specialise so we are all forced to build the same 'average' farm. Revgiblet's excellent and amusing geeklist (#51357) summarizes why I don't really enjoy this game.

RATING: 10
WOW. Really took over our gaming group for an extended run. People even got into the solo play challenges. I find it completely engaging while playing and a little stressful in the good way.

As a design it is absolutely stunning. The work that must have gone into this is staggering. That so many paths can be taken and yet so many games are so close is such a joy as we near the end of each game. I knew I was truly enamored with the game when I heard that you had to heat your home in Farmers of the Moor and I got excited about it. Really? Excited about feeding your family and upgrading your house, and whether the pigs can breed? "Oh yeah! I can't wait to heat my house and clear the land?" Really? Really! 

UPDATE: 07/2011 Really prefer to play with Farmers of the Moor. Closer games, less of a formula to follow.

UPDATE: 05/2015 Not coming out due to extensive set-up and commitment involved with making it happen. Have to drop it a point because I'm reaching for easier quick games instead. 

11/2015 - Finally got it to the table with my mother, my nephew, and brother-in-law. This goes back up to a 10.  What is it about this game that's just so good? It was all their first game and still the session was filled with wild laughter and jokes and people eager to play it again. 2 hours and the time flew by.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I played Agricola a few times and was consistently underwhelmed by it.  For a game as popular as it is on BGG I just don't get it.

For starters, there's a massive stack of cards, but each player only ever gets 14 of them.  And the winner invariably seems to be whoever manages to randomly get dealt cards that happen to work well together.  Might as well just play Snakes and Ladders for all that strategy seems to matter in this game.

The game has some nice features.  The theme is consistent and well-implemented, and the idea of building up your farm as you go is good.  But gameplay itself is simply underwhelming.

I wouldn't recommend buying this game.  Play something like Puerto Rico instead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This will probably be a 10 for me.  You gain victory points for building up your farm the best.  The more children you have the more actions you can take in a game turn but the more food you will need to feed all the hungry family members.  Actions are selected like they are in caylus so this game will be compared to that one a lot, but I more see the game as likened to Princes of Florence.  You are dealt a starting hand of farm improvements and occupations and the way to win is to best utilize these cards to fit your engine, much like in PoF you have to make the most victory points out of how your cards fit together.  The crazy thing about this game is that there are so many cards that no two games should feel the same.  This may be its only drawback as well, as certain card combinations will most likely lead to certain victory - but time shall tell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

You can't do every action you want, but enough good actions are usually available that you're not wasting your turn.  I definitely prefer a restricted set of decks, with a card draft.

RATING: 8
"The" eurogame. Easy to learn, wonderful materials (even more if you pimp it with meeples they sell separately) virtually unrepeatable thanks to the hundreds of cards (which actually increase the degree of luck, otherwise quite absent). If you have a group of light gamers, this is your choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Out of obligation, I traded my copy of Ys for Agricola. After all it is (or was) the #1 rated game on the ‘geek. So, I felt like I owed it to myself to have a copy.

I’m not sure Agricola will ever be a top 10 game for me, but I do like my worker placement games, and Agricola does it well (and did it before the big explosion of these sorts of games). There’s plenty of tension in the choices for resources. Unfortunately, I still haven’t played this game with any regularity. I owe it to myself to get more 3-5 player games in. Agricola forces you to fight against a harsh game system, and I like games that provide that sort of tough alternatives, as it helps to focus my game decision making.

Some random observations -- The rulebook is really bad, but the game itself is fairly intuitive. Scoring is not immediately apparent, and it does force you to “homogenize” your strategy as the game goes on, ultimately shooting for many of the same things each game. It does not allow true specialization. Also, I understand why folks “pimp” their games. The standard cubes and discs are a bit bland given the diversity of resources. And lastly, I'm still surprised though that some consider this a family game, and I find the array of choices to be pretty difficult for a casual gamer. I doubt I'd get my Mom to play this.

Update: I ultimately traded away this well regarded game. It never clicked with me. Part of that might be that I was late to the party. Too many cards, too much frustration. If I want this again I can always trade for it. But I don't see my wife playing this game. So, off it went.

RATING: 10
There is no betteer game than Agricola. The amount of strategy and mind power that goes in to playing this game is one of a kind. The solo version of this game is incredibly addictive and it never gets old. I find that playing solo versions of games help to teach you strategies while you play and you get an idea of how the various cards help you and the various actions help you. This can prepare you to be more agressive in a multi-player game. I find this game is also very balanced with a full number of people playing. You just have to start out with one particular strategy and stick with it. You can't change your strategy throughout the game. You have to be agressive, and if being agressive means you maintain control of the first player token to insure you get your resources or can take the actions you need to when you need to. The game is never the same because the occupations and minor improvements change every game. There is no guarantee on what you're dealt. :0)

Great game. Love playing it.

After 6 plays

A good game, but not excellent.  The limited choices each turn lead to scripted play regardless of the variability of the cards.  I personally find that it's too long for what it is and that games like Caylus Magna Carta fill the same niche much more elegantly.

More comments at:

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/235129

What has surprised me about this title is that in all respects it is the antithesis of Rosenburg's gem "Bohnanza". It is inelegant, weighs a ton, costs and arm and a leg, is filled with exceptions (from the cards), and has near zero player interaction.

RATING: 7.23
Main Positives: It's one of those games that got me hooked to the worker placement mechanic. The variety of ways to succeed in the game really hooked me in the game. Not very slow AP-wise.

Fun Factor: High to medium
Complexity: A bit high especially with the reading of cards at the beginning of the game.
Replayability: Play more of this game if you want to get better at it. For me, I like the variety of things you can do which can make it a different game each time.

Main Frustrations and Caveats:
Can't put all your eggs on one basket (my weakness is that I do). This usually costs me the game. Also, reading a lot slows down the preparation for the game especially if you or someone is a first timer.

RATING: 10
I have played well over 500 games of Agricola, and I find that the strategies are still deep and challenging and that even with my experience I still have games where I am barely keeping my head above water especially if the other players are playing cut-throat or have similar feeding engines to what I am trying to employ.

I cannot see another game knocking this one off for interesting player interaction and building in my book.  It packs an incredible amount of depth into 40 minutes-90 minutes.

This is a must have game.

RATING: 5
I enjoyed it more than I thought I would. Part of that probably had to do with playing with people I like and hadn't played much with in recent months. Besides that, I found it to be a totally functional implementation of the worker placement/action selection mechanism in the context of efficiency engine. That is to say: pretty bland. Lots of little decisions. Zero drama. The push away from specialization in the scoring seems necessary to create the tension of the action selection. While reduces the 'paths to victory' that so many people beg for, it emphasizes the interaction - a plus from my perspective. It changes the game from an engine building game to a blocking/anticipating game. I imagine that my appreciation would grow over several games as engine-building moved to autonomous brain function and blocking became the focus of my thinking/planning. However, after that, I imagine my interest would quickly wane because, frankly, the blocking doesn't seem particularly interesting. Moreover, the single-path issue would eventually lead to indistinguishable plays. Zero drama, untineresting little blocking decisions. Not my thing.

RATING: 7
Having played with all the player numbers from two through five, the game does seem to scale well.  Throwing all the cards into the mix seems like it could create some very good, or very poor, combinations.  The games seem to flow from the cards you get, and analyzing and thinking about the initial hand of cards dealt is probably much of the strategic part of the game.

In the end, it's a solid game, but I'm finding my tastes slipping a little away from the passive-aggressive nature of worker placement eurogames.  But, this could turn out to be the best of the bunch, I'm not sure.  I do like that the cards vary the game tremendously between playings - but I could see others being turned off by the chaos of the whole affair.

Update: This has proven popular with the kids, so has seen many more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
:sugar: :) :D :D :D :D On top of the plays recorded, I have played the hell out of the iOS version of the game (I don't record games vs. an AI because REASONS), and I am slightly upticking my love for this title again. Agricola is a game that fundamentally [i]works[/i]. It's a classic engine-building economic-snowball game playable by any number between 2 and 5 (though playing time compounds with each additional person at the table), and the game is subtly but significantly different at every player count. It is playable (and actually pretty good) in the form of the introductory "family" game but really takes to the air once you play the full game with the cards.

Like Dominion, the basic challenge lies in finding the best combination of goodies (in the form of occupations and improvements) to maximize the number of useful actions you can take. Like Struggle of Empires, you would ideally like to add a new ability every round but must balance that against the need to actually do the actions that give you victory points, so knowing when to push forward and when to hold back is critical.

Agricola is a game of significant complexity and subtlety (maybe a bit less complex than, say, Dominant Species, but only a bit) but the genius of the design is the way it uses the gentle pastoral theme to file the edges off the complexity and reduce the intimidation factor for newcomers. It's obviously not a [i]simulation[/i] of Mitteleuropan peasant life, but mechanics do reflect reality in nice ways -- it does a great job of impressing upon you why Not Eating The Seed Corn became the truism it is.

I am consistently taken aback by the number of people who quickly and intelligently grasp the mechanics of the game; people who would hit brainlock in five minutes when confronted with Caylus or Dominant Species just love building up their farms. Another nice feature is that your score is more or less a direct reflection of how well you played, so as skills are gained, you get gratifyingly rewarded with better scores.

The downsides? It's not short, it can definitely be more of an exercise in multi-player solitare than some folks want, and the luck of the initial deal will sometimes enrich you and sometimes leave you high and dry (try the "draw ten, keep seven" or "draft" variants to keep this from being too decisive), and unlike Le Havre (for example), the scoring is such that you find yourself straightjacketed into a generalist approach, which can cramp your style a bit. But, if I can be real about this for a minute, the winning conditions for a game are what they are, innit? Complaining that you lose points because you didn't grow vegetables is akin to complaining you lost Brass because you got the most money but the fewest VP.

These are nits, though. Agricola is a fantastic game, with tons of variety and replayability in a single box, appropriate for most ages and skill levels, that will more than pay for itself in the amount of fun you have. Not my favorite game, but without question the one game I would choose to appeal to the maximum number of people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Although many seem to like it a lot, I find this game very repetitive: option cards pop up at more or less fixed moments, resources are very predictable and the components are very abstract, with fences being bigger than stables and houses being as big as a weed field, while each family member eats the entire produce of two vegetable harvests per year and newborns grow up in one year's time. The extensive use of boards for examples, resource storage and even card display makes the game components a bit confusing.

The cards that give small advantages give such small advantages that they add very little to the game at all.

The components are good quality and the game can be played solo as well as with quite a few players, which saves it from being a total waste of cupboard space.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a very solid game. There are so many things to do and very little time to do, well, ANYTHING. I really like the feeling of building up my "engine" but just as it gets running the game is over. It plays fast as long as you have a plan, AP can grip players who are not prepared or have their desired action taken. The pressure to make optimal moves can be a little daunting, especially when you have to factor in the other players.

I love the variety the occupation and minor improvements add to the game. Sometimes a great combo will pop up and sometimes you will be stuck with junk. There are plenty of variants, including drafting, that can create a more "balanced" experience.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Lookout Games have been thoughtful enough to hire a wonderful artist to produce lovely illustrations for the components. Unfortunately, this seems to have left no room in the budget for competent interface design. The decision to employ cards instead of tiles for the action spaces is mind-boggling. At least 90% of the text could have been done away with by smart use of icons. Agricola is a huge, cluttered mess on the table, and it's not easy to get a good overview of the game.

The game itself is Supermarket Sweep for nerds. Very, very good if you like that kind of thing. Scales from 2 to 4 perfectly but becomes practically unplayable with 5.

RATING: 8.7
This is the buzz game of the moment, I've tried it a few times now and I can't say any time it has particularly wowed me.  Yes it's a solid game, and the design is fine, the gameplay works, and the cards give the game a nice flavour, but I have two main gripes.

1) The game is all about the cards, but it's usually only in your interest if you're trying to win to build a few of them out.  If I get loads of cards which sound interesting, I want to build them all out.  Knowing that doing so will mean I won't win just makes me frustrated.

2) The cards are quite swingy.  Sure you can say that in general they average out, and over a long time you could probably say they would do.  But there are cards there that are worth loads of VPs for no effort, and cards that are basically useless.  What you get is random.


Edit: Played it yet more times now, my comment on swingy ness of cards is only really applicable in the K deck, I think this game plays much better with the E or I deck

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
All the fun of basic accounting classes wrapped up in a time/space conundrum. How can a game be simultaneously too long and not long enough? This type of game should be done in an hour and a half (seems to be a sweet spot), but instead manages to drag our over the space of about 2 and a half hours. On the other hand, you never have enough time to do what you need/want to. You get a random hand of cards that either win the game or screw you from the get-go, scads of little boards to consume table space and turn after turn you get to watch as the one action you really need (the only one that will actually do you any good at all, in fact) is taken by someone else.

I would rather re-watch Soul Plane than play this again.

RATING: 6
I would like to rate this game higher, but I can't.

I appreciate how much work must have gone into making this huge game.  There was obviously a great amount of play testing and planning that went into it.  It is very well created and has a lot of replay value.  However, it just doesn't hit the spot of me.  I have only played a half dozen or so games - which leaves me wondering if the lights will flash with more plays.  

The choices are near overwhelming.  The paths to victory almost too many to count.  And that is where the game falls apart for me.  There is so much to think about that there seems no way to correctly determine the best choice during my turn.  There seems no way to discern who is in the lead and what choices I need to make to thwart the leader.  I am just 'guessing' the whole way through what the best option for my turn or what I need to choose just to keep it from another player. And, yes, I have even won...without any idea how I did it.  Lucky me.

It would seem the solution to this would be to play it more.  But how many times must I play before it seems less like guesswork?  I enjoy playing to a measure. I can see why it is highly rated.  It is a clever well designed game.  But for me I want a gaming experience where I feel like I know why I'm am making the decisions I am making and, if necessary, what I can do to undermine another player.  But with Agricola I just can't seem to see through the myriad of choices to understand why I should choose one thing over another.  It becomes "I'll take this and see what happens"...through the whole game.

I'm just not a fan.

RATING: 9
Rating after 1 game just so I can get my intiial thoughts down.  Good game and well worth the wait.  I am not sure if it is the game to take down Puerto Rico or my personal number 1's, but it is a fun game.

There was a lot to think about and I took the shotgun approach.  I only took negative points for not having my fields filled.  It was a bit overwhelming to realize all the potential positive and negative points but I am sure with more time, it will become 2nd nature and more-crafted plans will develop.  I want to get a few more family games in before delving into the Minor Improvements and Occupations.  I think these items will help you focus a bit more on strategy.

I expect my rating to go up with more plays but I am comfortable with an honest 8.5 at this time.

Subsequent plays settles it at a 9.  The full version puts the family game to shame!

RATING: 10
With more plays, this could rival Yomi as my favorite game. Every decision is interesting and critical, and the card play gives this game great variety. This game is so unforgiving, but it gets better and better with each game. I can see myself playing this game with old crotchety gamers when I myself am an old crotchety gamer. It has an unending supply of depth which I can see myself investigating for years to come. I just can't help but supply heaps of praise upon this game.

Agricola is a fine double stout in a world of lagers, and as such, requires proper preparation in order for you to enjoy its depth. While I love this game, it certainly is not for everyone. I was introduced to it after playing tons of Stone Age and some Manhattan Project and the 2-player Agricola. If you haven't played Stone Age, STOP READING THIS AND GET IT. If you like Stone Age or 2-player Agricola and want a deeper and more challenging experience, you will like Caverna for sure, and you will probably like Agricola also. If you like games that are difficult to be good at, then you might like Agricola.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This rating is after my initial play. It could change in the future depending on whether or not my initial fears and concerns turn out to be founded or not. For example:

There are lots of cards and lots of text in very small font on each one of those cards. Because there are so many cards, strong card familiarity is something that would take A LOT of plays to acquire. I see why all of the wooden bits are there but the number of cards in the game seems excessive. It feels like having five boards worth of Puerto Rico buildings - all different and all having a paragraph of text instead of a summary of their use. Yes that many cards would contribute to variety from game to game but when each card requires a paragraph's worth of text to explain its use, the game can very quickly bog down with players reading each card to see what it does. Puerto Rico doesn't suffer from this problem as, after a few plays, you learn what the buildings are and what they do because the same set of buildings is available in each game and you get reminded more frequently how each building works. Race for the Galaxy also doesn't suffer from this problem as it uses a symbol system to explain each card. Thus, once a player is familiar with the symbols, they can quickly tell what a card does. 

Also, at it's heart, Agricola seems like a path carving game where, after a few initial turns, you are almost "locked" in to a specific style of play for your cards and resources to interact in the most efficient manner possible and yield the best results. This quasi "locked" feeling kept me from really paying that much attention to the other players when selecting actions. The only thing I cared about was whether or not the action that most benefited me was available when it was my turn. This created the "multi-player solitaire" feeling that many people harp on Euro's about but which I had not truly felt in a Euro before until this game (that's including the usual targets that get indicted by many for being "multi-player solitaire" like Princes of Florence and Race for the Galaxy).

Further, the theme does nothing for me. (I've noticed that farming games in general don't work for me. Hacienda, for example, just isn't exciting to play.)

I'll see after a few more plays what changes and what doesn't and update my rating accordingly. Until then, my rating is a "5" with the strong possibility that it may drop unless my concerns are resolved by future plays. 

Update: The more I think about it, the fun I had while playing Agricola had a lot more to do with the conversations with the people I played the game with. The actual game was pretty boring to me and I don't find myself really wanting to play it again. So, I've updated my rating to a "4" as that better reflects how I feel about the game.

RATING: 6
Its a fun game, and I applaud the effort to create an asymmetric game with high replay value. Here, the variability of the cards dealt is the main mechanism for that. The problem is that this also introduces a fair bit of luck. As much as some people want to insist that "all the cards are balanced" they really aren't. There are some cards or card combinations which, if you're fortunate to draw them in your hand...you'll have an advantage in the game.

But the game is long enough and there are enough places to incrementally overcome someone else's advantage that it doesn't bother me. I guess you'd say I can acknowledge the luck factor, but still enjoy the journey.

The theme seems to really hold up, surprisingly.  I guess my biggest quibble is that the scoring seems a bit clunky at the end of the game, and is hard to line up with the theme. It seems a little arbitrary, the things that give points, but the game itself works well enough with that system.

Update:  Played with card drafting and all the decks mixed together.  I didn't choose this method, but went along. Yuck, painful and not fun. I'm enjoying each play of Agricola less than the last one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(Played with the card decks only, I would refuse to play the game without them, and the rating would drop to something like 3, not because it would be utterly terrible as such, but because I would never want to play it without the interest and variability that the cards offer up and would feel like I was wasting my time sitting at the table playing a castrated version of the game)

I had almost no interest in this game for quite some time, and it wasn't even on my active radar going into Essen. The enthusiastic response that people have had to it made me take a closer look though, and I am pretty impressed with this game.

Agricola is another one of the endless worker placement games that have come out recently. In this case, the twists are very good though. In short, each player has an individual mat which shows a farm yard. Over the course of the game, they will try to fill that mat with fields, fenced in animal areas, and a house. The worker placement scheme, in this case, expands each round, with another action becoming available at the start of each round. As the game passes, more valuable things and/or more powerful actions becomes available. At the end of the game, you score points for scads of different things: i.e.: having some/a lot of the 3 types of livestock, having spare grain or vegetables, filling up your board, having fields, having a nicer house for your family, having a larger family, &c. 

The big twist is the card decks. At the start of each game, the players are each dealt 7 occupation cards and 7 minor improvement cards. These all allow you to break the rules in some way, and require actions and often resources to build. There are hundreds of these cards, and the game plays very differently based on what cards you have and how you combine them.

In game terms, this has almost everything I like about Caylus, but adds a significant amount of player differentiation into the mix, which to me adds interest. The cards are a touch on the random side in that they don't seem to be at all balanced, and having certain combinations can be powerful, which means that I need to play it more to see how much they swing the game one way or the other, but I think the negatives are worth the much more abundant positives in this case. 

This game initially makes one feel like there isn't nearly enough time. 14 rounds, and only a couple of actions each round until you can grow your family. Harvests, which require you to feed you family (which can be a minor or a major undertaking depending on your cards, current board, &c.) happen more and more rapidly as the game goes, and it seems like you can never do enough, at least initially. The more I have played the game, the less stress these sorts of things cause though, and I have gotten to the point now where I'm pretty comfortable with the system and can easily prioritize actions efficiently and I've also gotten much more effective at using my cards. This takes a bit away from the game for me, because part of the initial allure was the sheer brutality of the system.

On an aside: this is one of the better worker placement games out there, but I am a touch tired of that style of game in general. I can understand the fervent fan base this game has generated, but it's one of those titles that I don't think I need to own, mainly because everyone and their brother is going to have a copy. My opinion might eventually rise, but I remember being just as enamored with Caylus when it first came out, and that quickly faded off the local tables as well. Presently, I think Le Havre does this type of game a touch better because it doesn't have the personalized randomness of the card decks and the unknown factor of the available actions. The latter would easily be fixable if the group just opted to play with that information open, the former is much harder to tackle, and I think it can be quite significant in the end game results because of the amount of points a synergistic hand can generate vs. a non-synergistic one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Plan ahead or else!  This is a great game that keeps you on your toes.  A lapse in concentration could lead to begging for food (feeding your family is very important).  While I really like the game mechanic (reminds me of Caylus) I have a problem with the balance of the minor improvement and occupation cards.  Some of the cards are useless while others are very powerful.  Add the ability to combine cards into insanely powerful combos and you end up with a game that can be very unbalanced.  That being said, part of the fun is making the best out of the hand you are dealt. If you enjoy a challenge then Agricola is a good game for you.  If you have problems with balance issues and need to win to have fun then you may want want to look elsewhere. As far as the Puerto Rico vs. Agricola issue.....I like both games but feel PR is more balanced (BOTH GAMES ARE GREAT though).

RATING: 10
Agricola is an absolutely amazing game about building and developing a farm. Without repeating others earlier commenting the game, I just would like to take emphasis on my own unique experience with Agricola: the game can be played both by hard core geeks and casual gamers, too. You can take it deadly serious or just play it for fun. And that is what I like the most about Uwe Rosenberg's game.
The artwork always amuses me and the variability and replayability of the game is extraordinary.

You'll never have the same game twice and you'll always have new strategies to play out based on your cards. Also reminded me of the Race For The Galaxy card game in that aspect. The components, wooden cubes and disks, were a little too utilitarian though, but definitely a game I'd consider buying.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
In Agricola, you're a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you'll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood, or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Some say having to feed your family is a broken mechanic, but it's what makes this game fun for me.  There are many routes to getting good scores, but you still have to have a plan on how you're going to feed your family in the end.  Some say that encroaches on their desire to be able to do whatever they want and that's why they pick Le Havre or some other worker placement game, but for me, it's that extra complexity that makes this game the best.  The massive card decks are the cherry on top which make each game a very new experience.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Our first play of this game was the family version. I hated it. After some time and more experience playing harder games, we pulled it back out and played the regular version. It was better. It still is not one of my favorite games, but I don't hate it anymore. The animeeples help a lot. (I think the publisher was kind of cheap to not include them in the first version of the game.) One thing that really holds this game back for me is having to diversify to avoid negative points. It feels restricting and gives the game a negative mood. Final opinion: not a bad game, but not a great game either.

RATING: 9.8
The best worker placement game. It keeps amusing me how fun this game is, how flavorful it feels, and unlike some other people I do not play without Occupations or Minor Improvements. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cons:
- Frontloaded information overload. You start off with 7 occupations and 7 minor improvements. Trying to figure out how to use those cards is a lot to process right at the beginning of the game. Especially for a beginner. 
- Accidental hate. Sometimes you will pick an action just to spite another player, but more often than not, taking the 6 wood was just the best move for you; nevermind that the next player can't feed his family now.
- I suck. Probably the biggest con.

Pros:
- Good introduction to some action economy. 
- Good amount of variety with occupations/improvements. Just wish they could be introduced in a more piecemeal way rather than all at once.
- Despite what I said about the accidental hate, you do have to account for it and think strategically about what your opponents might do.
- Good sense of power and progression. You start off wondering how you're going to get all the food you need to pulling off some powerful turns and filling your empty board with farms and cows.

Note: only ever played with 3 or 4 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
Well designed euro-game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
Agile, and very well balanced.
The best of this game is that it is intrinsically fun.
My major complain is that getting a decent crop is soo hard and slow for a game named "agricola".
The second complain is that your farm is in fact a "micro-farm" and you are unable to develop anything while trying to develop everything at the same time. The need for food sets partial goals that doesn't match at all with the end-of-game goals. In this sense, I prefer the worker placement of Caylus as it has much more synergic and elegant development.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

2/11/13 - Ok so I played it again, and have rerated it. This game is ok and will play sporadically again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Interesting efficiency game with nice theme. I like the look of the game, the components and the theme (rating +1). The game is a bit complex, especially with occupation and improvement cards, which makes the game  difficult to teach and easily leads to analysis-paralysis (rating -1). The strongest and weakest aspect of the game are the cards. They add replayability and force players to use different strategies (rating +2). On the other hand, there are obviously much better and much worse card draws, which is a real issue in an efficiency game (rating -2). I would not like to play the game without the optional card discarding rules, which add extra setup time but mitigate the randomness of the card draws somewhat. The game is surprisingly good for solitary play (rating +1) although the experience is very different from multiplayer games.. 

I have animeeples and and I am not afraid to use them, moo ! :)

RATING: 10
Rating +Farmers of The Moor.

Generally I don't think there are a lot of games that deserve a 10, because every game shall have its (minor) flaws and Agricola is not an exception. But after 6 years of play, endless hours of thinking about strategies and still discovering new cards resulting in long after-game discussions if it was really the card itself or the support for another card in a never-made combo, it strikes me how much this game still stirs us. 

Looking at the definition that BGG gives for a 10 I do think Agricola deserve it greatly. I’m pretty sure that it will take a long time before I find a game that keeps us moving as long as Agricola.

RATING: 10
Remek játék, nem kell ezt fokozni. Ami jó az jó. Egy dolgot azonban nagyon hiányolok belőle: a nagyobb fokú konfrontációt a játékosok között. Egy kis kereskedéssel nagyon fel lehetett volna dobni. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
 Agricola is an okay game.  It has similar aspects to games like Caylus, combined with the CCG elements of games like Race for the Galaxy or even Through the Ages.

Problem is I'd much rather play any of those games.  Agricola just didn't interest me that much.  I never felt any of the tension that I get from Caylus or TtA, or the sense of vision and wonder I get from TtA or Race for the Galaxy.

Also, the scoring seems incredibly arbitrary (Grain is more useful than vegetables, but vegetables are worth more vp?  Really?).  It SEEMS like there's a lot of ways to earn vp, but ultimately you pretty much need the cookie-cutter equally diversified farm to win.  

And I think the card play detracts from the game rather than adding to it.  I don't have this "I miss MtG" itch that needs to be scratched and having a poor starting hand really sets you up for two and a half hours of non-competitiveness.

At that length there are so many other games I'd rather play.

And you know what ... I'll just go and say it.  It's frickin' ugly.  I can't stand the look of it.  And I hate to say it but that's a factor too.  Color me human.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

As I get to play it more, I'd bet my rating will improve.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my first BGG-informed purchases.  I love the tight decisions and shorter play time of this excellent game.  It always leaves me feeling like I could have used just one more turn!  I do not love the amount of put away time and have been thinking of possibilities to ease this process.

The more I play this the less I like using the cards.  They add too much luck and randomness and can result in a very unbalanced game.  Play is much tighter and rewarding of strategy with no cards.

I'm using 2 larger sized daily pill containers to store animals and other small resource bits.  We've found these make the bits much easier to deal with during all phases of the game.

RATING: 9
My wife has made me play this game with her about 40X in the past 6 weeks!  If not for this, I would have probably given this game a higher rating, as I am getting a little bit sick of playing it all the time (thankfully her obsession has shifted to Puerto Rico, which I consider to be a superior game).  I have won every single Agricola game except for one against her, but there have been times that I groaned and cursed through the experience anyway.
The problem with Agricola is that the desperate need to constantly feed your people takes some of the fun away from the game.  I know that difficult games should be more enjoyable, but Agricola has a way of becoming frustrating as you try to balance running the farm "as required" and experimenting with Occupations and Minor Improvements.  
This game is brilliantly designed though and very pretty.  It has led me to Le Havre by the same designer which I enjoy quite a bit more.  We are planning on collecting most of Rosenberg's games now as a result of being exposed to these two.  

Changed rating from 8 to 9, 8 months later after playing Caverna,  which I found to be a bloated mess.  Oddly enough,  the things I disliked about Agricola, which Caverna tried to "fix" (the stress and sense of urgency, the limited available choices, occupation and minor improvement cards) suddenly became valuable to me in their absence.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Update:
I've now played a bunch of times, and the rating stays. I actually thought it would go down, but the sheer vastness of the cards keeps it virtually endlessly interesting (well, I'm not one of those people who play it 100+ times). More surprisingly, it went over really well with my family. After watching a couple games, even my 7 year daughter started playing (with a handicap of starting resources). And although my wife fell asleep during rules explanation, she said she loved it, and requested it later, which is rare. But dang it's a PITA to put away.
---
Finally played. Yeah, great. So far I've only played with people who have played a lot. I think my rating might go up more if I get a chance to play with people that are still exploring the game, like I am. One of the more interesting aspects to me is that although there are like 10 different ways to get points, all of them are linear, and you are penalized for not having at least some of everything, so it's a bit unusual in that it strongly encourages breadth over depth, keeping everything valuable to everyone.

RATING: 9.8
I'm so loving this game. The theme is very nice implemented, and it really feels like you're building your own farm.

It has great components (although I'm very disappointed with the quality of the Dutch gameboards (999-games).Despite of the great wooden animeeple, I like my customized fimo even better. 

There are so many options/strategies to play this game, that I think it won't bore me for some time. The cards just add more variation/strategies. But can add luck to the game. You can take a bit of the luck away by using a drafting variant.

I have played it with 2 and 3 people, and both are very good. Besides that it is also fun to do solo.

Some minor points about the game are the fact that you need to have a bit of all, and that one wants to do more than one can do in a game. But that's just really me being a perfectionist and wanting a perfect/complete farm :P

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Agricola is at heart a surprisingly simple and 'shallow' resource engine game, with the ways to obtain the various goods and products you need surprisingly simple to obtain. Agricola employs a different way of creating a semblance of depth: giving the players a godawfully big choice of cards which have the potential to change their little games to a major extent. It is then obvious and easily understood that you don't really [i]want[/i] complexity: the game would be a logistic nightmare, and much better suited to computers than humans. Agricola is many, [i]many[/i] different simple games rolled into one. Take for example the harvest phases. These are basically a simple and crude drain on your economy, and force you to spend quite a number of resources on cards and improvements you don't actually [i]need[/i] save to avoid getting a rather hefty penalty which will most likely cripple you in the end. The large number of Knizian ways to score and lose points? A consequence of the flexbility in setting up your economy. But at the same time it becomes rather hard for players to intuitively decide that someone is ahead or no. The relatively very high price of expansion of your family? Simple: extra actions are worth a lot, so the game introduces a major barrier to see you profiting from extra actions only in the long run. All in all, despite a cute exterior—especially if one is artistic enough to replace all game parts with models made from polymer clay—a slightly deeper glance reveals a very 'gamey' side which in my opinion could have been hidden a little better. I'd much rather see a small selection of truly interesting cards than a large selection of variation on a theme.

I cannot say what effect the randomisation of the cards will have on the game of individuals. It is by no means a given that a good combination will actually appear as the action choices leading up to their playing-out are limited too. It might not be the best course of action to focus on those cards, or rather, it might not yield the largest amount of points. But this can only be established by playing the game with the same cards again. I have no idea how that will affect everything, but the answer may actually be quite surprising. I can see certain individuals analyse this game to death in order to figure out optimum card configurations, which would be complete and utter waste of time if you ask me, but hey, it's their time, not mine. As for myself, I will probably play this game once every while; therefore the variety is completely wasted on me. This is a game for people who want to play the same game over and over and over and over again, making it simply not my game.

[b]Update[/b] Two years after writing the above I still stand by it, to within 95% or so. In the meantime I've become acquainted with other resource engine games like At the Gates of Loyang, Glen More, and Endeavor. These captivate me more for a number of reasons which can be objectively established:
— simpler rulesets, 
— clearer scoring,
— normal quantities of game material, and
— sufficient [i]interesting[/i] variety for what I consider a normal lifespan of a game (< 100 games).
Agricola only wins out in terms of interactions, as the actions become blocked over the course of a round, meaning that timing your needs is an integral element of the game. I'm not even sure the variety is there after 100 games or so: of course there are truly humongous amounts of card combinations lurking in the box, but whether these are [i]interesting[/i] is another matter: the action cards are not altered, after all, in fact remain quite scripted. I realise that's a pretty cheeky statement to make, and shouldn't be confused with the existence of 'cookie cutter strategies' and such. It has more to do with the fact that family growth isn't available in the first quarter of the game, pigs not until the second half, cattle not until the final quarter, and so forth. It forces the game into several similar patterns, with cards allowing the players to bypass these to a certain extent. In essence, the cards force a non-neglegible puzzle element into the game not unlike that found in for example Shipyard or Die Burgen von Burgund.

It isn't that Agricola is a bad game; it's just that other games do away with a lot of the material and condense things into shorter, streamlined packages.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
August 2008.  Yes I pre-ordered sight unseen and fell for the hype.  My favorite type of game is worker placement which this one is superb.  The theme is very enjoyable and works well with the game play.  This game has instantly shot to the top of my favorites to play.  Since I'd play again right now given the chance, the rating is correct.

November 2008.  Now that I've had a few plays under my belt I can give it some critical judgment:

1) Don't enjoy playing more than 4 player.  Having too many people or too many new players really slows down this game.
2) Wife won't play game with cards so it loses a lot with the limited way the family plays with it.
3) Theme is great and works well with my young family.
4) Decreased my rating from 9 to 8 since the possibilities of varied game play is very low which gives it less appeal.  As ranking of all worker placement games, I think the theme helps this one, but Caylus is more strategic and interesting to me.
5) Still think Power Grid should be the top of BGG.

2009-May - Moving this one down a bit in my worker placement rankings.  Still a very fun game, but the feature I dislike the most is that you have to be balanced in your scoring.

2009-June - Decreased rating again.  7.5  Not a bad game, but since my wife doesn't like it much and I like other worker placement games more, this one gets neglected.  I think I'd sell/trade the game now if it wasn't the theme the kids like.  I think the biggest issue I have with the game is that you have to do a little bit of everything so each game seems samey.

2010 - February - Wife despises whole world after playing this game.  Maybe some day.
