=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of those games that is "inherently" fun. By that I mean that there is something intrinsically fun about performing the actions in this game--growing grain, breeding farm animals, plowing fields, building houses--it all gives you that certain sense of "accomplishment" (kind of like delivering goods in Railroad Tycoon, or checking an item off your "todo" list) and makes the game fun. The game is very tactical, and it's tough to look at your options in any given round and formulate a solid plan to move forward, but despite uncertainties of card draws and your opponents' actions, success in Agricola is firmly rooted in skill and experience. It's the first game since BattleLore that my wife and I have played 6 times in a single day.

Edit: At the 10-play mark, I've decided that the game is far more tactical than strategic. There is a somewhat fuzzy strategic element (e.g. "breed lots of animals" or "sow lots of fields"), but it's mostly tactical. And once you start getting used to the game, analysis paralysis is reduced even with occupations and minor improvements present.

Either way it's an extremely fun game.

RATING: 9
This game is a perfect integration of theme with mechanics. What you are doing makes sense and you can see your board position growing. However winning is hard and requires you to evaluate whether you want short or long gains, the hallmark of a great game. 5 is too crunchy and usually one player gets left in the dust, 2 is a bit too harsh as zero sum play becomes more pronounced, 3-4 players is just beautiful. The family game is good, but the minor improvements and occupations take it to a whole new level. The only gripe I have is that the family game tends to be the one I play most, as there are almost always new players and it is solvable without the variation provided by the minor improvements and occupations.

RATING: 10
I love playing with a variety of people and Agricola caters to a large audience of people. The different decks keep the game fresh and allow for extra chalenge for more experienced players or pull out the E deck for the people just learning.

How many games come with the variety of game options that this does? How many games allow you to scale from playing solo up-to 5 people?  

My wife doesn't like playing many board games but she looks forward to playing Agricola and that is sufficient for me to give it at 10!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Agricola is my favorite Euro game of all time - especially when played with The Farmers of the Moor expansion.  Amazing replayability!!!  Fantastic game with 2,3,4 or 5 players as the games scales very well!!!  This heavy thinker Euro style game is the type of game that is an addiction as once you play the game 5 to 10 times. Agricola grows on you until you wish to play it more and more and more! My extended gaming group almost always plays the "deal 10 cards - keep 7" variant option for play balance to give all players a reasonable chance of a good group of cards each game.  For variety there are other expansion decks which I own, but I feel they tend to introduce rules conflicts and are best played on their own.  Lastly, Agricola creates the dynamic of "if only I had one more move or turn".  Each player is forever clawing at getting what they need - usually barely in time - making for tense play while desiring to push the limit every round of play.

-The theme.  It's very soothing and appealing to me.
-The multitude of paths to victory.
-Variations in each game caused by a ton of cards that are packed in with the base game, with the option to buy more decks for even greater variety.
-Love the wooden components and crisp card quality, though some of the art is a little cartoony for my taste.
-Pretty much everything - this is my favorite game.

Don't Like:

-The frustrating final rounds where players (including myself) tend to wrap themselves up in a blanket of AP and simply glare at their farms.

RATING: 8.25
A very good one resource management game, and the first hit  of Uwe Rosenberg, his creator. A mix between worker placement alla Caylus, and personal board management alla Puerto Rico with thousands of cards in order to build up the most beautiful and functional farm and feed your family/worker team. I like the way you have to search to play the cards but sometimes your score depends too much on the cards you recieve at the begining of the game. It isn´t my favourite game but I enjoy every time I play. Maybe my favourite in the "multiplayer solitaire" category.
Thematic.................8.5
Components............7.9
Mecanic...................9
Replayable value......8
Complexity level......Medium/High (easy to play, hard to master).
Luck factor..............Low/Medium (a game depends on a hand of cards)
Interaction...............Very Low
Total.......................8.25

RATING: 8
After about half a dozen plays, I can say that I enjoy Agricola quite a bit, and that it looks like it'll have a huge amount of replayability. That being said, I don't think it'll become one of my all-time favorites, though I've certainly been wrong before about that sort of thing.

The only (minor) gripe I have is with the logistics of adding to the various accumulated resources every turn; later in the game, there's a lot of stuff to add, and it's easy to miss/forget something.

[12/08: There's even more varied dynamics than I'd thought; the different actions available in 2/3/4/5-player games have a palpable effect on play. Neat.] 

[10/09: ...and earlier this year, my interest in the game kind of fell off a cliff, moreso than usual for "the shiny has worn off". Leaving rating in the 7-8 range due to earlier enjoyment.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Agricola is fun - there is no doubt about that. But after a few plays, with the novelty of the CCG mechanics gone and a better sense of its internal dynamics, it’s also shown a number of problems that prevent it from reaching hallowed status. 

Firstly, around the time you begin to become competent at it, the game also begins to feel highly repetitive. Part of this is the relative lack of viable paths to victory - that is, the game in large part is driven by the overwhelming need to grow your family as soon as possible. The increase in actions a family member gives you is simply so powerful that it trumps any other priority. That makes the early part of the game all about planning around the first family growth, which means building rooms, which means obtaining a large stockpile of wood and a smaller store of reed. And that means it plays out similarly and is ultimately determined by a combination of minutely superior choices about the tightly constrained key resources and some luck in positioning on the critical (unknown) round when family growth appears. The intense race for this space amidst the tight early game effectively eliminate players from contention earlier the game warrants, especially as later rounds become longer (due to more available actions and family members).

These above problems, I think, are magnified by the shoehorned scoring structure. The need for a balanced farm mean players are all gunning for similar ultimate goals. So once the early rounds are over, the game doesn’t open up into multiple victory paths. It becomes a race for ticking off scoring checkmarks, though the order for each player may differ. I also particularly dislike the large percentage of points given for family members. They ALREADY give you actions. By giving them such a large point value, it further reduces any tension as to whether to choose the family growth option if available (the small increased food cost nonwithstanding). At least with animals and plants, you do have some decisions to make, as their value as food conflicts with their value as points. So I wonder if removing these points might serve to open up the game a little, although I have my doubts. 

As for the cards. Oh, the cards. I loved the idea of them the first several times through. But again, around the time you become competent at the game, you begin to realize that they fail to live up to their promise of instilling infinite variety into the game. For starters, many of them are so weak or conditional as to be effectively useless. Others are simply far too good, especially those that simplify the race for family growth - for instance, those easing the early food burden, those increasing the amount of food or reed you collect, or those making early food engine growth more efficient. Again, the problems are those of variety and choice. Since most cards are uninteresting or have marginal effects, they do little to muck up the repetitive nature of the crucial early rounds; the more powerful ones are simply so good that they offer no hard decisions about whether to play them out. (I also wish the designers would have taken a page from the better card game designers and been far more precise in their wordings on cards; there are too many ambiguities in resolution).

The game also bogs down in the end rounds, as play devolves into point optimization calculations among competing available actions. This is unfortunate given that the game’s most meaty decisions have already been made and the winner largely determined, though I think unavoidable.  As a bonus, though, except for this point, the game actually feels highly thematic, which is quite an achievement given both the seemingly dull topic and the worker placement mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Components: Nice artwork all around. The cards are too flimsy. There are too many wooden bits for them to be just cubes; upgrading to unique shapes is a must.

Experience: So many choices! The number of options available for my actions grows each round, though often not having enough of a certain resource (e.g. wood) will close off several types of choices for the time being.

It's fun, but it's also hard work; it's almost not worth it to expand my family because it's so difficult to feed everyone. Very challenging. There are always interesting things to do, but never enough time to do them. By the end of each game I feel I've been dragged through the coals.

The occupation and minor improvement cards are essential for making each game different, and for providing me with direction at the beginning.

I play as a vegan (never cooking my animals; pretending the fishing hole is for water cress, etc.). And this makes getting food very difficult. If my starting hand doesn't contain a food engine, I'm screwed.

First Played: 2009-09-03
Last Played: 2013-12-10
Plays (18):
2 players: 9
3 players: 7
4 players: 2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Initial impression.  A tremendous array of combinations and possibilities provided by the card decks.  Tight, focused objective set enhances balance and approachability.  However, depth of strategy is largely tied to what cards are available to you on any playing, rather than any attributes of the game in general.  This "situational" strategy is not necessarily a negative, but the reason I reserve assigning a higher rating to the game.

Subsequent impression.  The game is a increasing constriction of options, as if you're being thrown down a funnel.  What becomes challenging with 2 becomes increasingly frustrating, as the number of players grows, until the game relies too heavily on simple opportunism, and planning becomes largely a matter of not sticking to any, one plan.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I was sure this game was overhyped, but after playing it, I realized it's just amazingly good. Lots of different ways to win, and more player interaction than it gets credit for since only one person can perform each action each turn. It is almost a bait game when you play by the family rules (no occupations or minor improvements). I actually like the family rules better because it takes out the chance of the cards and it plays quicker. Of course, with the cards I can always blame my loss on the other guys great occupations instead of my ineptitude.

RATING: 6.5
0902: After my first (family) game, hard to see what the fuss is about. The game does nothing original, but seems to be just a more involved version of any number of Euros. Removed from wishlist.
0908: Played a second time, two-player with occupation and minor improvement cards. Got whipped as I completely failed to develop in a sensible manner. I like the variability that having cards to shape a strategy will bring. I've borrowed the game to see if a few solo plays will make it click.
1011: This time a four-player game with occupations and minor improvements. More to consider = more engaging, and have raised my rating by 0.5 to 6.5, but still far from my first port of call.

RATING: 6
I love the *idea* of Agricola, but when it comes down to actually playing it, I just...  meh.  I find the harvest mechanics to be too punishing, and I dislike the scoring that basically forces you to do a little bit of everything instead of being able to specialize, particularly since everyone is competing for the same action spaces to try and build essentially the same farm that you are.  And the cards, which I know everyone raves about as far as adding replayability, just seem to be too *much* randomness for my taste.  I've not gotten rid of this post-Caverna; nor do I plan to.  It's still a good game, I just don't think it's a *great* one.

RATING: 1
I dedicate this rating to everyone who hasn't yet played this game and gave it a 10 based on hype. I wanted to like it; I really did. Heck, I even bought this game after I thought that maybe I was missing all the fun because I didn't play it often enough.

Someone recently asked me if my opinion has changed about Agricola. It hasn't. In fact, it's gotten worse. A one indicates my personal reaction to a game is that I have no desire to play it. Ever. I've played it eight times now, with different groups of players, and each time is worse than the last.

It's way too fiddly and illogical to be entertaining, and the theme of French Medieval farming is, shall we say, uninspiring. What next, a game about simultaneously building wooden, iron, *and* steel ships in a French port while avoiding starvation, Mr. Rosenberg?

Yes, the mechanics of Agricola are interesting, but ultimately, the game as a whole is a dismal failure as fun, which is the primary reason for this rating.

RATING: 8
One play so far of this ultra-popular euro.  This was a fascinating experience - a game I felt was a bit similar in structure to Puerto Rico, but a 100% more satisfying experience due to the TEACHER that taught me the game.  The person who showed me how to play TOOK HIS TIME and really took care to teach me the aspects of the turns, etc. in great detail - AND WENT SLOWLY!  This improved my enjoyment of the tricky first play entirely better than my first Puerto Rico game.  I felt if this individual has taught me Puerto Rico, I'd be much more enthusiastic about THAT game, too.  As it is, Agricola is a fantastic game that I became hooked on and can't wait to play again.  Using the Animeeples (which I was lucky enough to use) is really essential to play, I find, as using bland discs would make the game feel like balancing a budget or something.  But the use of Sheeples, Wild Boars, Carrots, etc. really makes it feel like you are growing your own whimsical little world - it really brings the latent theme of the game out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
One sentence summary: Agricola is the [b]least favourite game I've ever had the misfortune to play in more than 45 years of gaming[/b] (and I have played some seriously awful games). But don't take my word for it, here are some other enlightened and honest opinions about Agricola ... 

[q]I'd rather watch paint dry or grass grow. -- gittes[/q]
[q]My memory of playing this game makes me want to barf. -- sbconstant[/q]
[q]Misery Farm. -- Unknown BGG member[/q]
[q]The Coldplay of modern boardgaming. Fucking boring and inexplicably successful. -- Abiezer Coppe[/q]
[q]I've never been waterboarded but I imagine the experience is comparable to Agricola. -- SamuraiBudgie[/q]
[q]I would rather trade an eye than play this game. -- WhimsicalOne[/q]
[q]All the excitement of 16th century farming. -- cooler king[/q]
[q]Goes down like a mouthful of runny sheep droppings. -- bob_the_goon[/q]
I'm a gamer's gamer. Been boardgaming as a hobby more than four decades. I love Euros and wargames. I [i]should[/i] like this one. Nope. Never again. Awful. Brutal, nasty, passive-aggressive, stressful, un-fun.

I'd rather undergo root canal work ... without freezing. I'd rather spend three hours in a quiet, dark corner poking myself in the eye with a dull pencil or rusty spoon while listening to Donny and Marie music. I would not play this game again even if you offered me US$1,000 (really). I'd rather play Candyland.

Technically, I should rate it a "1.1" since my opinion of the game somewhat matches BGG rating system definition for a "2" ... Extremely annoying game, [i]won't ever play this again[/i]. It's much closer to the definition of a "1" rating though, however it's not fully "broken" as a "1" rating requires (though the uneven luck-of-the-draw cards and absolute blocking mechanic [especially when this is done purely for spiteful reasons] pretty much do make it broken in my opinion, since there is no way to recover from these two things). But both of the other two requirements for a 1 rating certainly hold true ... Defies description of a game. You won't catch me dead playing this. Since I agree with two of the three criteria a 1 requires, a 1 is what it rates.

Agricola is the only boardgame I've ever quit half-way through a game (my fourth game, so three-and-a-half plays suffered through) because I was so crazy bored and stupidly frustrated with the absolute choice denial blocking mechanic and the ungodly slow pace and length this game takes. It's also a much meaner game than most of it's fans will acknowledge despite it's friendly little veneer, and it's a game that railroads you to having to do something with little variation in your choice of what to do. Any game that encourages the sort of behaviour where players yell out "I shall build fences just so you can't!" is nothing but a spiteful mind-fuck of a game, and a lot meaner than I want to play. 

Boring as hell. Never again, I can't even stand the sight of the game, honestly. 

I [i]have[/i] turned down money to play this game again. I hate Agricola that much. I absolutely refuse to ever play this "game" again.

Does it deserve it's high rating? I guess, and I do acknowledge that it is a very good game for many people, but I have no real idea why, since it's the complete opposite of fun in my opinion. Can I honestly and without malice rate it a "1" based on BGG's definition of a what constitutes a 1 or 2 for how I define/rate games? Absolutely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The good thing about Agricola is that it is adaptable depending on the group. You can play the family game with beginners, just use the minor improvements if you want a faster game with a bit less luck, play with both minor improvements and occupations for maximum options (and chance to concentrate too much on cards and go horribly wrong!). Drafting the cards and/or allowing card exchanges are other, more advanced ways to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating as of Jan '15 - 6. Owned since Dec '13 and only 4 plays as of the time of this rating. My main gaming group doesn't seem initially impressed with the family rules. They would rather be playing Carson City or Dominant Species if we're looking for a Worker Placement game. It is a very tight optimization game, meaning that it feels like there are no good moves throughout the whole game. I think I need to play more with the Occupation cards to fully enjoy Agricola.

Things I like about Agricola: How neatly the components fit into the Plano box and within the original box. The animeeples are kinda cool.

Things I don't like about Agricola: Takes up a lot of table space. The fiddliness of setting up components between each round. The game takes a long time to explain. I feel like I'm always losing, and that nobody's ever winning.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think Agricola is a very well designed game, but it's just not for me.  To cut to the chase: I don't like how the tension (from feeding and from scoring) limits my ability to use my cards to make a cool combo.  I want more freedom, but not as much as is offered by Caverna, or Fields of Arle.

What makes Agricola shine is the cards: the occs, and the minor improvements.  Together, you can put together a cohesive and powerful strategy, but it generally requires some focus (e.g. focusing on clay and pottery, or on fields and grain).  If that focus is not on food production, you will lose.  If that focus doesn't get you a bit of everything, you will lose.

If, like me, you accidentally forget to get food for a round and you get three begging cards, you will lose.

I know how to play the game reasonably well.  Get a combo that gets you food more efficiently than just using the board actions, and use your leftover freedom to get everything else.  But that is not how I want to play it.

Conversely, I don't want to be able to do anything I want, like in Caverna.

What I want is to have the constraints and the suggested strategy from the cards, but without having to worry about aspects of the game that do not relate to my chosen strategy.

Plus, my wife hates farming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
June 5, 2010: Just played this for the first time last night--a 2-player game with my wife. I'm not ready to rate it yet, but I really, really liked it--as did she!

June 7, 2010: Played this the other night as a 4-player with my wife, my brother, and my brother-in-law. My brother and brother-in-law didn't seem to like it that much, and they had some difficulty catching on to the differences between grain and vegetables. I'd recommend teaching this game as a 2- or 3-player game. Anyway, my wife and I still really enjoy this game. I've even been having dreams about it, and we took a drive out in the country and all I could think about was Agricola. We still haven't played other than the family variant, but I'm gonna give this game a 10--and I'm the type of person that always wants to counter popular opinion and trend. I just love all of the options and planning and variability. Great game! I have to get Le Havre soon.

RATING: 9
This is a very heavy strategic board game.  Fun to play with the right people.  Lots of strategies limited by what other people's strategies are and the worker placement board.  Downside is feeding your family.  It felt like I was always behind and trying to come up with the necessary food instead of building my farm up.  Other downside is negative points if you don't build/grow one of the items on the board.  this makes you have to do everything.  This is the mother of all board games for me.  Interaction with others can be almost zero to a lot depending on what cards are incorporated.  Components are very good and solid.  Great game with great mechanics but not for the casual gamer.  Games can last 1-2 hours.
Strategy: 4/5
Rules: 4/5 
Ease of learning: 3/5
Luck:1/5
Interaction: 2/5
Difficulty:4/5
Replayability: 5/5
Components:5/5
Gamer Type: Avid or in depth gamer.  Not for casual.
Analysis Paralysis:3-4/5
Overall:4.5/5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I struggle with this one, I really do. Sometimes I think it's a smart, sharp game, and that it's a classic for a reason. Sometimes I get excited at the prospect of playing it. Sometimes I think trying to figure out what action is best to take when considering my long-term strategy versus what action is particularly delicious right now versus what I can reasonably expect other players to do is board gaming at its best.

But sometimes, when I really think about it, I feel like this game has a lot of problems. Maybe too many problems. Your starting hand of cards, regardless of what system you use to obtain them, can vary widely in quality from player to player and, player skill being relatively equal, the person with the best hand will win. However, somewhat paradoxically, a good card-based engine that requires more than a couple-three cards will take half the game to build, thereby wasting so much of your time that you lose. Family members are massively over-valued during game-end scoring; because they allow you to take extra actions and because they live in rooms that (usually) also get you points, they basically do triple work with respect to scoring. Getting to a point where you feel like you're not totally wasting every turn collecting paltry amounts of resources in order to spend them on paltry farm improvements can take way too long--sometimes three-quarters of the game--and I'm not sure I can praise a game that doesn't feel good for so much of its length. And some of the game systems (especially baking bread) are just plain overcomplicated.

So I don't know. Given all that, I guess, on average, this game is just fine. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Agricola is an amazing game, no question.   While I recognize everything amazing about it, the cards make me not want to play. Card drafting is the only way to go to reduce randomness in the initial card draws, yet it adds 30 minutes to an already long game.  

Why do you need to reduce card randomness? Because some card combos are completely broken. Moreover, some cards are so broken that our group simply leaves them in the box.  To top it all off, the cards are subject to pages of errata and clarifications, e.g., "Does card A combo with card Z?". 

But the biggest issue is that knowledge of the cards and their relative power is absolutely necessary to do well.  Maybe I'm just bummed because my group keeps getting new card decks and I never had a chance to acclimate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Plays: 2-5
So, finally played the current #1 game. I can see why people tend to be euphoric about Agricola. Gameplay is a bit overwhelming at first, but smoothens out during your first play. Game mechanics are interesting, components top notch and the cards create a lot of variety. I expected a Puerto Rico-clone - to some extent it is, but Agricola is probably better.

But... Rich in theme my $ss. 
- animal populations tend to grow exponentionally if given enough space. Not in Agricola. 
- why can't I plow my fields, because some other farmer has done so this round?
- why can't I have children because my neighbour's wife is pregnant. And why does the kid need his own room?
- tell me how to make food out of wood, reed or clay? it would solve some of the major problems in the world.
- I can't slaughter a pig when I'm hungry, unless I have some improvement? Did prehistoric man need these improvements to eat a mammoth? No... 

But my biggest problem: no direct player interaction... Agricola would be so much more fun if you could burn down your neighbour's house, steal his cattle (or wife) or spoil his food supplies. Okay, maybe that's too violent. But how about trading cattle and other resources, renting out your ovens, fields or family members ('son, enough lingering around, go work at our neighbour's farm'). It would make the game so much more lively and exiting. 

The game is all about maximizing your cards and the options available. And that's it. Games are supposed to be social events. Exciting and lively. Agricola is not. It's a puzzle. A smart one, but puzzles can be solved alone. When people are around I want to interact with people. Agricola just isn't a social game.

Edit: I've given it a second change. My opinion hasn't changed much. Clever mechanics: Yes. Exiting: no. Interaction: very limited.

Bottom line: with 3-4 players and about 2 hours of playtime, I know lots of different deep games. Exiting games. Interactive games. Games that make more sense theme-wise. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Animeeples, recursos y miembros de la familia personalizados
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Agricola is one of my favourite worker placement game. I especially enjoy seeing my farm grow slowly, piece by piece. In Agricola you have your own little farm that you build and nurture. Not only is building it great fun, but the game makes sure that there are plenty of tough choices every turn. It all comes together brilliantly as the players are trying to gather enough food to feed their little wooden families. Agricola is a surprisingly thematic game for a heavy euro. The game can take a while with more players and there is a certain tedium involved in the board upkeep that happens between rounds, but other than that Agricola is all-around a really good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Box lacks a decent sorting tray, and setting things up and clean-up is hampered as a result. I use lots of little plastic cups and bowls to store the pieces.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While Agricola is undeniably a classic from Uwe Rosenberg, I feel that Caverna is an improvement on it in almost all aspects that I care about. First the superficial: the art is more vibrant and pleasing to the eyes; the components are far superior with every resource and animal having uniquely shaped wooden pieces. In terms of game play, Caverna offers more choices and more freedom while removing the annoying food shortage in Agricola, so the game becomes more about building a thriving household than struggling to survive. To those who criticize Caverna for the lack of a random setup, I have to say that (1) the symmetric setup with no hidden information give the game more strategic depth and removes any luck factor (2) the huge number of rooms available ensures that the game never plays out the same way (3) one can always choose to draft rooms in the beginning rather than laying all of them out. In all, unless you are a stubborn, die-hard Agricola fan, you will find Caverna a deeper and more enjoyable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A fantastically well-designed game with great replayability. Gameplay feels a bit 'tight' for me because of the need to feed your people and the fixed, limited number of rounds. Cute theme, scales well from 2 to 4. Have played a lot of solo games on the iPad.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
With Farmers of the Moor

Played base game 3x

Comes with a crazy amount of cards for tons of replayability. The cards are often very powerful and will aid your strategies in the game, although it can be intimidating since you get 14 cards at the beginning of the game and you probably don't want to use them all. 

Also the cards are unbalanced. The card draft variant adds more skill than random draw but not very beginner friendly.

As for playing the game itself... I like the "difficulty" of feeding your family and keeping your farm afloat. It makes each decision seem more important and blocking your opponents feels more dire. I also like how you will want to shoot for a well-rounded farm for the most part, but due to the swingy nature of the occupations and improvements, no two games are the same.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1-5 players, 90-120 minutes, medium heavy, farming/worker placement

I've played several games with 1-4 players, all of which were quite entertaining. The theme is nice, the components look nice and there is a lot to choose from (even with the family game). 

Once you've mastered the game mechanism and add the various crafts and investments (we haven't yet), the game becomes even more exciting. As there are several decks to choose from (beginner, advanced, expert), replayability is very high.

The solo game is quite good as well and even has a campaign where you need to improve your score every game. Definitely a keep in my collection.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I didn't like it at first, feeling that the cards were ultimately unbalancing, but it has become one of my favorites. In particular, playing with the iOS version has shown me just how good the game is.  It's very thematic, and during play you feel invested in the farm you are building and even the well-being of your family. Caverna is very similar, but robs the game of its intensity since you can always get what you need in Caverna.  Not so in Agricola! Going later in a turn can be devastating. I recommend playing with some sort of draft or dealing extra cards and discarding down to help eliminate the possible imbalance of the cards.

Traded my set, now have the revised edition--hoping that the new set balances the cards better.

RATING: 8.5
The thing about Agricola is that you never feel like you had enough time to do everything you wanted, so you always want to play it again to try and hone your strategy. It's like a giant toy box and you're trying to get the toys you want out of it before someone else takes them. 

A lot of fun--but it also takes a long time to set up, a long time to play, and it's complicated to explain the rules to others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
What a hard and demanding challenge this game is!

Players might take quite a while to make any decision in this game because there are so many options and so much is demanded (otherwise, the final score will be severely affected if a series of requirements aren´t fullfilled), however, the game´s progression develops at high pace and, with very little resources, one finds very hard to accomplish all that was supposed to and priorities must be set.
The game mechanics can be somewhat heavy, especially for those who aren´t aquainted with similar games, and the experience can get somewhat stressing because, at the moment it feels like you are really acomplishing something, the game ends and the final score dictates it´s cruel law.
All in all, Agricola is very demanding about brain effort but is an experience and a challenge few gamers dislike.

RATING: 9
Includes 3rd party animeeples. Still my favorite game, Ill admit partly due to nostalgia since this was our first *real* weighty euro. I love the decision space Agricola provides as well as tactile feel of building the "farm". I have played this so many times that the "feeding" phase no longer feels like a burden unless I'm trying some wacky tactic. Most people I have taught this to do not like it and I believe that is because it takes at least 3-4 plays to get a handle on the strategy. It is a great game and will forever be at the top of my best list.

RATING: 10
My favorite theme!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really like Agricola, the cards make this game really interesting and unique.  Drafting the cards is absolutely essential though, otherwise the element of luck is too high.  

Game is excellent with two and three players, but I feel that the family growth action becomes too essential once you reach four players.  If you're the last person to take family growth (and someone has to be the last person every game) you're at a severe disadvantage, that makes the first few turns of the game feel like it's all about planning to be the first to take family growth.

It's possible that expert players can take advantage of this and pursue a strategy that doesn't rely as heavily on family growth, but it has seemed too important with my limited experience with the game.

RATING: 9
I wasn't sure about this game the first time I played. But a few more kicks at the can and I was hooked. Every attempt offers something different; a new twist on a strategy, a whole new approach, and it's very family friendly.

It does, however, take a while to play, especially with newcomers. One game for 4 players clocked in at 5 hours.

I do agree with some people's assessment that there's limited player interaction, but that (in part) depends on the deck of cards you're using and what you consider interaction. Some inter-farm trading might spice things up, but as is, it's a wonderful setup and well thought out.

Update: after finally playing Puerto Rico (and liking it very much) I've decided to level the playing field and give both these games a well-deserved 9. I'm taking Agricola down a step for lack of inter-play between gamers (which Puerto Rico offers more off), but Agricola has a much longer strategic path. 

Both are great.

Update 2: No, Agricola rocks so much I put it back up to 10. There's something very special about a game I keep coming back to even though I've rarely won. I love building a working farm. Seems boring; it's not.

Update 3: We picked up farmers of the moor and the G-Deck; the game becomes much more rounded. I lowered the score because the game is so long and heavy that few are interested. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
No, no, no, no and no again. As much as I love Caverna, I trully, passionately I hate Agricola. Feeding my people is not my main concern, it's the fact that I have to do everything in order not to lose points. If I want to specilize in carrots, let me do it. Uwe Rosenberg is a smart designer, realized it and made a better game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
    - Important note: this review is based on 12 2-player and 3 3-player games; I've never played with more yet.
    
    - Gameplay: 4/4. Agricola is a fun game to play, similar to Caylus. It is highly competitive and there is a lot of player interaction. You'll need a good strategy to win, but still be flexible enough to adapt to the circumstances. Thanks to the occupation and minor improvement cards it really feels like the game is different with each play, as the viability of certain strategies depend on them, really allowing multiple paths to victory. Because of the engine building aspect combined with the strong theme, you really feel like a farmer struggling for survival. At the end of the game you feel you have achieved something and it is hard to resist the urge to examine and discuss why your family members were/weren't able to build a prosperous farm. One downside is that just like Caylus, Agricola lets you build an engine for which you don't get enough turns to really reap its benefits. I have read that Le Havre fixes this issue.

    - Absence of luck: 3/4. Although there is luck in the draw of the occupation and minor improvement cards, I have the impression that they level out nicely (partly depending on the deck you use). Even when are dealt a stellar hand, you still need the ability to use them well. Also, by focussing on the strategy supported by your cards, you give way for your opponents to follow their strategy. To avoid the few cases where you really feel like your cards are absolutely worthless, there are a few good variants provided to mitigate this last source of bad luck. As I feel it, there is much more randomness caused by the other players' actions than by the dealing of the cards. This second kind of luck factor doesn't bother me at all, because it makes the game even more fun by trying to guess what actions the other players need to do an trying to block them.

    - Duration: 3/4. Agricola takes a bit more than an hour with 2 players and a bit more than 1.5h with 3 players. Compared with the games I know this is quite short. It is rare to find a short game that is both this thematic and this strategic. It considerably lowers the threshold of bringing the game on the table. 
    
    - Player range: 4/4. Note that I've only played with 2 and 3 players. The game is really nice with both player numbers. The downtime increases with the player count, but with 3 there is still not much downtime. What is especially nice is that you'll need a different strategy for different numbers of players (and this without rule modifications!), adding even more variation to the game.

    - Theme and looks: 4/4. If there is one aspect where Agricola really shines it is in the theme. I doubt a game theme can get stronger than this. The artwork and components are nice also. Make sure you get a version that includes animeeples and maybe vegimeeples and resource meeples. I'm always surprised how big the difference is between placing a cube on the board or a sheep meeple. It really increases the game's fun factor. 

    - Set up/clean up time: 2/4. Agricola takes some 10 minutes to set up and some 10 minutes for cleanup. This is long, but it still feels considerably less hassle than setting up Puerto Rico. Considering the length of the game I can live with it.

    - Learning curve and documentation: 2/4. You simply cannot explain all relevant rules to a newcomer at once. He'll need at least one full game to grasp even the basics. Thankfully, the in-game documentation is great and the strong theme makes the rules easy to remember. So I don't consider Agricola hard to learn, but it does take a few games before you can actually start playing it.
    
    - Other notable aspects: one think that is worth mentioning is that this game requires quite some table space.    
    
    - Like: unbeatable theme, relatively short, highly competitive, lots of player interaction, lots of variation, also great with 2 players
    
    - Dislike: too few turns to benefit from the engine you've built    

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
With a dozen plays in 2 weeks, Agricola has clearly captivated me with its replayability.  The basic game is OK, but it's the cards that really kick this up to a must play.  The cards force you to try new lines of strategy.  There's no resting on your laurels here.

That said, the farming theme isn't terribly exciting to me.  Also, while the theme isn't as tacked on as it is in most Euros it isn't exactly dripping with theme either.  This game could be re-themed without much trouble.  It reminds me a bit of Puerto Rico: the mechanics work with the theme, but they could easily have supported other themes w/o changing any rules.  What would make Agricola a 10 in my book is if it were re-themed as a war profiteer game where players compete to become the best arms dealer.

On second thought, maybe this game will make it to 10 anyway.  Only time, more plays, and cracking into the other decks some more will tell.

Update: I'm already feeling some resistance from my group on this one.  If this trend continues, I won't get a chance to fully explore this wonderful game.

Update: Now I'm the one who's feeling resistant.  I really like Ag, but my passion has moved on to other games.  It is now a solid game in my collection, rather than a must play.  As I predicted, I prefer Puerto Rico at the end of the day.

Update: I've officially burned out on Ag.  Too many 2 hour plus games of it have killed it for me.  I just can't help squirming in my seat as my opponents agonize over the simplest of choices.  I've stopped even trying to win...I just don't care anymore.  

Post Script: totally Jones-Theoried by Caverna.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is a decent variant of the resource management/competition game that so many Euro's follow. Unlike some folks, I actually enjoy trying to figure out the best uses of my Occupation and Improvement cards.

Complaints about playing time have reached absurd new levels with regards to this game. If you can't handle 30-40 minutes per player, it's time for you to find a new hobby.

Complaints about lack of interaction strike me as bizarre. First, it's just not what the game is designed to be. BGG is riddled with resource management games that aren't interactive, e.g. Puerto Rico, so I'm not sure why people are targeting this game for that particular criticism. Second, there's an interactive deck, if you prefer a more interactive game.

My _own_ complaint is that not all Occupations and Improvements are created equal, and the right combination can give players an incredible advantage in the long run, even if it doesn't seem obvious to the other players at first.

Still, I think this game is relatively fun, and will probably be good for about a dozen plays.

Update: I'm now convinced that your initial hand of Occupations and Improvements is too crucial. Also, the theme just isn't interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have only played once, and I enjoyed the experience.  I am not a huge Euro fan, but I would play this again if the mood struck right.  The mechanics are interesting, and the gameplay is much better than Caylus.

RATING: 4
For me there are a lot positives and negatives that stand out about this game that make it really difficult to rate.

Positives:
* Great theme worked in very well
* Lots of strategic decisions and paths to take

Negatives
* New Player's have no chance at all with lots of brainburn
* Long for what it is
* Felt heavy and really dull, game only gets interesting towards the end when you have three workers to place.
* A couple of bad decisions early on and you will be behind for the rest of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is truly one of the best gamer's games that I own and I predict that it will still be popular years from now; a modern classic. Great decision-making, great replay value, great design; a must-own title.

It scales well, both in difficulty and in player count (including single-player!). Each game is very different, thanks to the inclusion of [gameid=463]-like card combos which provide nearly unlimited paths to victory. The gameplay suits the theme, as in games like [gameid=2651] and [gameid=30869]. It has the gameplay depth of games like [gameid=13122] and [gameid=875], but it's more accessible. I think this game is perfect for gamers that love [gameid=3076], and have played it death, but want some added variety (although the it isn't limited to just that audience, by any means). It's beautifully produced and it's loaded with 300+ cards (the animeeples are a must).

If you are worried about hype, get over it. If you are worried about complexity, play the family variant first. If you are worried about random factors, play the official card-draft variant. If you are worried about the monetary cost, sell your child on eBay. Just get this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Bought in November 2007, played one single player game. Can not say too much about the game yet.

[2012-01-06 Rating: n.a. -> 9]
It took me quite some time to come up with a rating for Agricola. Sadly, this fine worker placement game doesn't hit the table as often as I'd like. I guess, one of the reasons that it doesn't do so is also the reason why I like this game so much: Agricola is tense! While playing Agricola, I'm constantly stressed. How can I feed my family? How do I upgrade my farm so that I won't come in last place again? How can I combine these two things? Agricola rewards me for all this stress like no other game: In the end, there is the farm that I've built, giving me this great feeling of accomplishment. But I get that the stress level in this game is not everyone's cup of tea.

Furthermore, Agricola implements the farming theme very well. I never had any problems explaining this game to new players since every action just makes sense. Sure, you'll have to remember the exact number of grains to put on a grain after planting it, but the gameplay itself is surprisingly intuitive for such a 
heavy game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Still one of my favorites, especially after a lot of practice with the app. I find the art adorable, the variability high, and the choices always just hard enough. I don't get to play often enough on the table, but I don't envision this leaving my collection any time soon.

RATING: 7
Going back and re-rating this one after some recent plays. I've knocked it down quite a bit. It's a good game with an interesting theme and lots of variety through the many cards and decks. But what gives me pause is the intense competition for action spaces. The game can be extremely frustrating and tough to execute a strategy because resources are so tight. An admirable design, but I prefer games with a bit more openness. It almost feels like Rosenberg reached the same conclusion as his later worker placement designs are far more open and forgiving.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game starts with reading 18 cards and goes downhill from there. Draw all endgame cards while your opponents play cards that give them resources throughout? You lose. And you knew it from turn 1. Fascinating. Nudge me when it's over...

edit: Played the revised edition. The reduced card pool seems to have addressed the problems of the opening hand. No doubt it's better than the draft solution - which was a non-starter for new players. Rating upped to 6 accordingly.

However, in LeHavre, a small set of initial possibilities expands every turn. In Agricola a vast set of initial possibilities is narrowed every turn. My strong preference is for the former.

RATING: 6
This was very enjoyable to play.  Even so, there are too many exceptions and there are too many things going on for my tastes.  I would NEVER try to get my fiancee to play (or even my business partner) to play this game.  I played the first game without looking at the cards in my hand.  This was a great move on my part because it took the whole game just to figure out what was going on in regards to the options on the board.  Things started to become clear half way through the game.  

I decided to play it again immediately afterwards (which is a good sign) and everything made more sense. This time, I used many of the cards in my hand and consequently did a lot better (well, I won by a HUGE margin, but that was because most of the players were new and they did not value wood even though I told them it was really important).  Even so, there were several areas of confusion that no one could answer authoritatively, which is VERY annoying when it causes a conflict (which it almost did).  

So while the game does not seem very tight, there is something about it that is very enjoyable to play.  And with all of the variation from the cards, I'm sure that I will end up playing quite a few more times.

--- Edit ---
I think I only ended up playing it one more time.  I guess its not my cup of tea.

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
I think it is safe to believe the hype on this game.  An excellent worker placement game similar to Caylus.  Agricola however includes hundreds of cards that can make each game quite a bit different from a strategic point of view.  Out of the 100s of cards included in the game, you get 14 at the start to make up your hand.  These are played to enhance a particular strategy you have chosen.

I'm not sure whether the cards sacrifice balance for variability.  So I'm starting it out at a 9, but could see it going up to 10 if future playings show this not to be a problem.

After many plays, this game has indeed gone up to a 10.  It has rapidly become one of my favorite games.  Just an overall excellen design.  Great mesh of strategy and theme for a euro.

Update:  9 years since i wrote the above.  Nothing has changed.  This game is simply amazing.  My favorite euro.

アグリコラ
１～５人
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Is good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
At the beginning of time, simple hunters and gatherers spread from their homelands looking for resources. In the neighboring areas are numerous other tribes who are competing for the same, limited resources. As time goes, on the tribes get larger, building bigger towns, developing new technologies, and eventually domesticating animals or planting crops in sufficient numbers that the tribe is able to sustain itself, and is able to focus its attention on building a great city, and monuments to its power. In the end the largest tribe, with the greatest monuments, and the widest variety of nutritional sources, in other words the tribe best positioned for the future will win.

Agricola is, in other words, a civilization game and a damn good one at that. With immense amount of variety, and an engaging theme. The tension in establishing the greatest civilization/farm is fun, and I think that thinking of it as a civilization game even makes the end game scoring more intuitive. The score represents a sum of both the civilization/farm's current progress as well as its future opportunities with its technologies (improvements), specialized workers (occupations), its nutritional sources (crops and livestock), its ability to sustain itself (fields and pastures), and its overall population (family members). 

When I first got onto BoardGameGeek and began to hear about Agricola, my initial response was disdain. My reaction against the hype surrounding it was so strong, that I became dismissive about the potential quality of the game. As time went on, however, my suspicion began to shift towards enthusiasm, and I eventually caved and pre-ordered the game. After my pre-order the enthusiasm grew to epic levels, and when Agricola finally arrived I was in no, way, or shape disappointed. 

When I brought the game with me to Gen Con most everyone I taught it to shared my enthusiasm. Five different people I taught the game to, bought it at the convention for $70, and I played the game seventeen times there. 

I could go into great detail about why I love Agricola, but this game is so omnipresent on BoardGameGeek that there is no point. I will state that I think this is the ultimate resource management game, and may be the best civilization game out there. I have not yet played the classic Civilization, so I am not yet sure. 

Session Reports:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/341597
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/336705

Best with 4>5>Anything Else

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My first 10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players represent medieval farmers, working their own 15 spaces of land.  The game is played over 14 turns, interrupted every now and again by harvest time.  The beginning of each turn sees areas of the boards seeded with stuff to make them increasingly attractive (wood, clay, animals, etc).  Players then take actions with their farmers (start with two, but can increase to five) to do stuff - build, renovate, plough, reap, breed, bake, etc.  It's all about growth and expansion, with the ultimate goal to have your 15 spaces brimming with food and animals.  Nicely executed game, great theme.  A couple of astonishing things - the innocuous looking box is jam packed full of stuff - wood, boards, playing cards.  In addition, the game comes with hundreds of cards, roughly divided into "jobs" and "items" that grant players additional abilities if they can get them into play.  This turns a rather dry game into something you can play for years and still discover things you hadn't seen before.  The designer, developer, artist and playtesters must have gone bonkers balancing all this out into a nice, playable game.  Another plus is the game feels very different, based on the number of players, from solitaire up to five.  Two years and about 50 games later, the rating has settled on a 6 - okay, but have to be in the mood.  Too much anguish to be fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great game. I'm terrible at it, but I enjoy the challenge. Downsides are that it's a very long game and can be taxing. Agricola usually leaves me in the mood for nothing more complicated than UNO or watching Netflix.

RATING: 8
The fact that all of the replayability comes from the cards dealt bothers me - I almost feel like I have to play a small game of Magic on the side in order to do well in Agricola, and in Agricola itself it's obvious what I should be proceeding toward.  This may because I've only played 2 player.  In all of my games both players have been able to accomplish very good layouts.  Maybe with more players there'd be more sacrifice.  Or maybe we need to play more aggressively.

Ultimately I still feel like the real challenge is in making the best use of your cards, and that doesn't seem right.  It's not a card game.

I do like the race for the exclusive action spaces you need and the press your luck element (surprisingly).  And I'm still very happy to get the game to the table.

RATING: 4
I definately see the attraction to this game, but I don't think this deserves the widespread gushing it receives. 

This game uses the same "limited menu" of choices that Peuerto Rico pioneered and Wallace games have been using ever since. However, this game features a wide wide menu of actions, such that there is less cut-throat positioning and ruthless grabbing away from your opponents. If something you sought is gone, odds are you can do something else productive. In fact it seems that seeking the path of least resistance is a key strategy. 

A bit convoluted the first time through, I expect a second playing will be much faster and coherent.

RATING: 8
[b]Tipo:[/b] Competitivo // [b]Interacción:[/b] Media // [b]Azar:[/b] Bajo // [b]Rejugabilidad:[/b] Alta
[b]Cartas:[/b] 360 de 59x91 mm
[b]Fundas recomendadas:[/b] Ultimate Guard "Supreme" (tamaño "Standard european") [b][X][/b]



[b]OPINIÓN PERSONAL:[/b]
Aparte de ser un clásico de la colocación de trabajadores, el Agrícola es uno de los juegos más "redondos" que he tenido la suerte de probar: es de estos que cuanto más lo juegas más te vas dando cuenta de lo bien pensado que está, y aun sin ser el mejor juego de la historia gustará a casi todo el mundo.

Además, hay un par de "mitos" con respecto a este juego que me gustaría desmentir:

 -> Agrícola NO es un juego extremadamente difícil. Su versión familiar resulta bastante fácil de entender, sobre todo si (¡regla casera!) la primera vez que juegas no utilizas todas las adquisiciones mayores (recomiendo usar solo la Alfarería, la Cestería y la Ebanistería, pues son muy sencillas de explicar). Puede que no sea adecuado para iniciar en el mundo de los juegos de mesa a alguien que nunca ha probado uno, pero tampoco le falta mucho (en cuanto haya probado 2 ó 3 juegos de iniciación, ya podrás sacarle el Agrícola).

 -> Agrícola SÍ que tiene interacción entre los jugadores. Aunque es un poco difícil de percibir en la primera partida, según vayas cogiéndole el truco te darás cuenta de que ocupar ciertas acciones claves en determinados momentos del juego puede hacer que otro jugador se quede sin posibilidades de ganar... o al menos ponérselo francamente difícil.

Aparte de lo ya mencionado, hay que decir que es uno de los juegos que mejor escalan a cualquier número de jugadores: aunque resulte difícil de creer, puede resultar igual de entretenido a 2 que a 4 jugadores (aunque la experiencia de juego sea distinta... a más jugadores, más choques habrá entre ellos).

Como único punto negativo me gustaría mencionar sus ilustraciones. Los colores están bien elegidos, pero es que el estilo de los dibujos se me hace demasiado infantil para un juego tan profundo, y la verdad es que puede echar para atrás a más de uno (una pena, porque merece mucho la pena).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think I will never like this game as more than a good friend.  Despite the card decks, this game is Euro like Tom Willis is white (which means very very, not matter what crazy cards are mixed in or who he's married to).  It does do a good job of evoking the appropriate angst of being a 17th century farmer, but actions are just so limited it feels like trying to swim in handcuffs.  On one level I enjoy it, and on another I find it laborious.  I think I'll play this one every once in a while, but I doubt it will become a favorite.  After my latest game, my overriding thought was that I think that, for a heavy worker placement game, I prefer Caylus.

UPDATE: My love/hate relationship with this game continues.  I still am not very good at it, but am enjoying it more.  My problem is that I get distracted from my goals too easily, and there just aren't enough spare actions to do that.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although being a peasant and farmer (is there a difference in the English language?) isn't too exciting to me, this game has certainly something to it. The process of building your farm and amassing all those beautiful wooden vegetables and cute wooden animals seems to resonate in my brainstem. The cards add the urgently needed amount of variety to the game - without them it would be quite repetitive after a few games. I also like the mechanism, that resources start to accumulate on one action field, and form a nice little pile of wood, until one finally shows mercy and takes it all.
One thing I dislike, however, is the fact that this game is so tense. I mean, it's too tense. There are always not enough rounds left, not enough resources to achieve what you desire. The whole tension is just a little over the top, for me personally. Also, the hunger mechanism is turning me off.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

I also really enjoy the theme, it really feels like you are growing a farming family.  One sign of how good this game is, is that I'm not that good at it, but still really enjoy it.  I always seem to get caught up chasing some complex string of occupations and improvements that would have won me the game had I only been able to (insert card/action/resource here).  Seems to happen every time, but I always come back to chase another impossible string of cards.  One of these days I'll wise up and play more conservative. :-)

RATING: 8.5
I have played this a lot, and I like the "Family Game" very much. You basically play without the Occupation and Improvement cards which makes for a less random and more chess like game.

I like the full game as well, but the cards are obviously of varying usefulness and a large part of being good at the game revolves around knowledge about what cards are good and in which combinations. There's nothing wrong with that, and it certainly adds replayability, but it also adds an element of luck.

RATING: 9
I came.
I saw.
I ate some sheep.
I love the way that the action pool progressively rolls out and the many fun and sometimes difficult choices it presents.   The scoring system is a bit odd, and makes it hard to tell who is winning.  But the game looks great, the animeeples are a real nice touch, and the occupation and minor improvement cards should give a massive amount of replayability.  The game doesn't take itself seriously and the sense of humor really comes through. Best of the worker placement games that I have played, despite not really innovating in any way.   It somehow just works.

Group
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating based on a single, four-player game. The game seemed to start slow and then slowly cascaded. The random Minor Improvements and Occupation cards had really good combos for some players, not so much for others. How much does that affect the outcome? I don't know yet. No one got anything going until well past mid-game and then before we knew it, the game was over. I'm not sure if this "snowball" effect seen in so many of the highly ranked Eurogames is a plus or not for Agricola. I don't seem to mind it in (for example) Puerto Rico, but that may be because each player in PR gets the same number of moves and the same opportunities to perform an action. In Agricola, this isn't necessarily the case.

UPDATE: Ratings upgrade (7 -> 8). Another 4-player game. Very close ending (tied, actually). While it does appear that random occupation/improvement cards may help some players over others, part of the replayability of the game is dependent on this randomness. Want to play more.

RATING: 7.5
Gazdálkodj okosan :D. Mielőtt bármit is írnék a játékról el kell mondjam, hogy nem szeretem azokat a játékokat, ahol valamilyen negatív hatás ellen kell küzdeni. Jelen esetben, minden betakarításkor meg kell etetni a jómunkás embereket, különben keményen megbüntet a játék. Régebben már játszottam a játék családi változatával, hát nem lett a kedvenc játékom. Túl hosszú, a szabálymagyarázat is, ki- és bepakolás, mindig valaki elveszi azt a lépést, amit épp kinéztél.... Most kipróbáltuk négyen, kissé gondolkodós társaság vagyunk, simán eltartott 3 órát a játék. Arra gondoltam, hogy most ne a családi változattal játszunk, hátha a kártyák némi izgalmat adnak a játéknak. Azért nem az összes lapot vetettük be, csak az egyszerűbbeket. Most már értem, miért fanyalognak sokan azon, hogy a kártyák szerencsét visznek a játékba. A sógorom a kapott lapjaival behozhatatlan előnyre tett szert. A halászatból simán megvolt a betevője. Ráadásul, mivel a halászat alapban csak egy ételt ad, így senki nem pazarolta el a szűkös és ezért rendkívül értékes akcióját arra, hogy blokkolja. Persze neki volt olyan kártyája, amivel tudott mindannyiunkat blokkolni kétszer is, méghozzá úgy, hogy a 2 létszám fölötti családtagok akcióit blokkolta, fájdalmas volt :). Tehát úgy gondolom a családi változat letisztultabb, de a kártyák több színt visznek a játékba. Ettől még nem ez lesz a kedvenc játékom :). (2015.08.19.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The original “farming game” of 2007 spewed forth a slew of similar games; it was a great game for its time but has now been completely superseded by its superior sequel “Caverna.”  

I played this a few times and then played Caverna a few times.  I immediately felt Caverna to be much more balanced and streamlined.  I recently played the original Agricola again and that play-through really hammered in my feelings toward the original game.  I strongly dislike the Occupation and Minor Improvement Cards handed out at the beginning of the game as I find them random and unbalanced; they also strongly favor experienced players.  I didn’t even focus on them and just ignored them.   

The best parts of Agricola (the resource management, the seeding and growing of your family, farm and livestock) are all in Caverna (along with enjoyable new options such as adventuring and mining).  However, in Caverna everyone equally has access to the same options and ALL options are there on the table for everyone to see and players don’t have to worry about random and unpredictable factors showing up via Occupation and Minor Improvement Cards.  

While Caverna is more accommodating toward new players while at the same time keeping experienced gamers engaged, Agricola players really can only be challenged in a game if they are playing against other seasoned-players as was evidenced by the wide-range of scores resulting from our recent game: the player who brought and promoted the game scored 44 points, the two middle-players that had some experience (myself included) scored 25 and 23 points, and the new player scored negative-two (-2) points (and he is an experienced gamer too!).  I would not call Agricola a broken game by any means, but by 2016 standards, its not quite up to speed with Caverna out there running around.  

I’ve read that some players promoting Agricola will add new expansion cards and cull certain other ‘broken’ cards, etc… why bother when you can just pull out Caverna and play it out-of-the-box as is.  

I guess back in 2007, I would have given this game a “8”, but now in 2016 I would give it a “6”; so I’ll compromise and give it a mellow “7”.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have officially taken this off my wishlist. The random elements of the copious cards, mixed with the annoying tedium of the setup, mixed with the fiddly constant replenishment of resources on the board, mixed with it's utter lack of player interaction, mixed with the fact that it takes forever to play... have led me to the conclusion that this game is not for me.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So, is farming in the middle ages fun?  I wouldn't think so, but Agricola manages to make a decent game of it.  Standard worker placement fare: grab the spots that are most valuable or needed, hope the others make it back to you.  The only twist is the struggle to build your food engine in the beginning, when you have nothing, and get it running fast enough to hit all the benchmarks the game imposes on you.  

The family game is really not all that interesting, and not something I'd play repeatedly.  You really need the cards to make it good, and I've already started to get tired of the 'E' deck ones.  For more spice, add the draft variant.  

The game as a whole is just a little too much 'chore' and too little 'leisure' for my tastes, so I won't want to play that often.  I've only a couple criticisms apart from that.  
Start player is extremely critical, since you have a lot of knowledge as to what actions will be available on what turns.  Sitting to the right of the person who's always camping on it can ruin your game.
A minor complaint, but it always feels to me like the animal and baking builds are way different from each other in terms of ease.  For baking, you just have to take grain 2-3 times early, grab some clay or stone, and build the oven to make your first batch.  Somewhere in there, get a field, then plant one of the grain, and hopefully bake another.  After that, it's all downhill.  The only difficulty is in the uniqueness of the spots you have to grab.  (There isn't any substitute for the sow/bake spot).  Whereas, for animals, you have to compete with everyone else for the piles of lumber, get enough for at least a small pasture, then take the fence spot to build it.  Then, of course, you need the animals to fill it, which means waiting for sheep to accumulate on the sheep space and being the one to snag them.  Finally, you'll need a fireplace to cook them.  The main problem with this is that you really want to be spending that lumber expanding your house, and fences compete with that.
Card power level is also quite varied.  Some look cool, but won't actually do much; others you can build your whole strategy around.
I hate the fact that the lumber and clay are both wooden discs, a slightly different shade of brown from each other.  
If someone gets a lot of wood and reed early, they'll be well on their way to building the next room first.  This means they'll probably be first to grow their 3rd person, giving them a leg up on everyone else.  It's by no means a runaway leader, nor a guarantee of success, but it can be a predictor.
Farms tend to converge on similar appearances due to the scoring system.  It becomes a question of how many categories you excelled in, and it's entirely possible that people will be close to the same point total, even if they're doing well in entirely different areas.  At that point, it comes down to the bonus points on cards, which I've seen swing games.

Anyway, I still like the game.  It's probably my favorite of the whole Uwe series.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Player order:

RATING: 9

Many more plays online than recorded here.

Edit: after playing Le Havre I much prefer Agricola. Not that Le Havre was a bad game, I still enjoyed it...but the stress of working out an efficient point scoring machine all while meeting the periodic goals of feeding your people is what puts this game over the top. Le Havre felt more like a pure exercise in efficiency, whereas Agricola feels more like that and a dollop of additional tension which gives the game the thematic feel and keeps players growth balanced. I kind of don't want to touch Caverna...

RATING: 8.85
My all time favorite euro game. It so perfectly balanced and diverse and it's fairly complex. 
It will never finish in the same way nor will strategy be repetitive, and the winner is often concluded after the final point counting in the photo finish.
The theme (building a farming household and raising a family) is really light and common and I love the fact that it attracts regular people of all ages and it repels hard core uncompromising geeks. 
Drafting occupations and minor improvements in the beginning of the game is greatly recommendable as it eliminates overpowered combos.

:star::star::nostar:

[b]Edit:[/b] Few unrecorded plays.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Endless variety of Vocation and Minor Improvement cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As with most euros this failed to inspire me. The theme isn't really grabbing and whilst superficially the game is about farming most of the decisions you make seem to have little to do with farming but more about squeezing victory points from the system. So for example you might plough all your remaining land to avoid taking points penalties at the end of the game, but from a thematic point of view, why would a farmer ever do this?

It does give you plenty of options and routes to points, and i quite like the idea of the occupation and improvement cards (drafting them will probably lead to a more balanced and interesting game). However ultimately i found this to be a bit of a dull solitaire points grind. Not really what im into gaming for.

RATING: 8.5
Having played this a few times through now, I'm a little more comfortable making comments.

Agricola took a little getting used to; a warm up period was necessary for sure.  But I have to say that each time I play it, I like it a little more than the time before.  The game boards and pieces will certainly *not* blow you away with their artistic flair but the game mechanics just might.  The competition for resources is pretty intense at times as is deciding when is the best time to go for that big pile of wood.  And the BIGGEST challenge of all is keeping the family fed especially toward the end of the game as harvest times come faster and faster.

The game can feel a smidgen repetitive at times if you play with the same people and they keep their same strategies, but with new people and new strategies I could see this game having immense replay value.  We like it enough and will probably play it a few times a month for now.  It may eventually get shuffled to the back of the closet ... but not any time real soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Overall, this game is really good. You can really feel that you build something, and the struggle to feed your family is (to me) not a nuissance, but an essential part of the game that makes it harsher, but also way more interesting.

RATING: 9.8
You either love it or you hate it.  What I love about this game is that you have your own farm (board) in front of you; you make it the best farm you can and nobody can screw it up but you. RATING: 8
Enjoyed this game for quite some time, but got thoroughly sick of it.  Game can get quite redundant--new action spaces are revealed as the game progresses, but relatively little shuffling so few surprises.  Blocking by other players can be a significant problem.  It is difficult or impossible to recover once a player falls behind.  Strikes me that this game is close to being excellent, but there is a mismatch between the high level of strategy required and the relatively short number of rounds. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably the first thing that jumps out at you when you play Agricola is the very unique theme and mechanic. There aren't many farming games, and I don't think I've ever played a game that uses this mechanic (except maybe Lords of Waterdeep, but Agricola came out way before that game). Because of the randomization of cards, including the round cards, there is a lot of diversity between each play through. Depending on who you are playing with and what they are trying to accomplish effects the game drastically. This is the one game I can truly say that has no set stragedy or path to victory. Every game is different. My only gripe about this game has nothing to do with the game, but with the design of the box. The makers of this game obviously put 100% of their effort into designing the GAME ONLY, and put 0% of time thinking about storage of the multitude of pieces that come with it. Now, Agricola is not the only great game on the market that makes this mistake, but I think this game is THE WORST. The box is relatively small, and has NOTHING on the inside for storage. After punching out all the pieces you are left with a totally empty box. This is my only game that REQUIRES its own separate storage box for pieces. If the point of the small box was to give it a small footprint on your gaming shelf, then epic fail, because this game with its TWO boxes takes up more than any other. However, to now reiterate, this game rocks!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played my first game. It was a 2 player game. It gave me an idea of the game's mechanics.

No interaction between players.

Reason for my rating is because there seems that you can do lots of things. What you do and how you do them(order which you do your actions), was a real puzzle for me in my first game. 

Especially towards the mid game when you got less turns to get enough food to feed your people. One time, I had not enough food and it cost me two grains. I was saving them for something else. It was very frustrating.

Seems like if you want to do something, you need to do stuff in a certain order, if you don't, you can easily shoot yourself in the foot and ruin your game.

So, for a first game,  it was a crash and burn experience. I would want to play Agricola again, but before I do I need to do some reading about the game.

Seems like there are combos you can do in this game. To spot them after only one play is difficult. There are lots of cards in this game. I didn't see most of them.

Now, since I know the game mechanics and how the game works, next step for me is looking to see if there are some actions that are more important than orders. See exactly what resources you need to do certain things.

Also, the cards you got in hand influences what kind of game you can have. If you got bad cards, it can hurt your game overall or at least you'll need more actions than other players who has good cards which gives them bonuses.

Overall, a good game, not excellent. This game is overly-hyped in my opinion. Rating can change with more plays. Not something I would buy myself due to its price tag. I don't find it interesting enough for my taste for getting my own copy.

I would play it with someone's else copy, but not mine. Paying that much for a game, it would have to be for a game I enjoy more than Agricola.
