=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
Based on several plays. 

I just don't get it. I feel as though bad (read: inexperienced) plays early in the game are compounded, and continue to punish in later rounds. The leader gets ahead and stays there (in his five-room six-worker stone mansion, while you have two starving guys in a two-room clay hut). 

Example: If you're last to place a worker, the only way to get the Start Player marker back is to waste one of your precious worker placements, and then be first player in the next round. But then you run out of food and starve at harvest time. There's no compensation for being last to pick. 

In a five-player game (which I obviously can't recommend) you run out of Kitchen-type Major Improvements, and (again) the odd-man out gets left behind.

There is no player interaction (other than competing for worker placement). Caylus has similar mechanics but a lot more player interaction.

It feels weird to give the #1 game on BGG a 3.5 rating, but honestly if Agricola what's being played, I'll go elsewhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Long, heavy, and random! Not my thing. Long/heavy is fine and good, and so is random (occasionally), but never together.

UPDATE: Actually played now. Interesting game. I still think that the randomness of the minor improvements and the occupations are unbalancing. Getting good ones - synergistic or just overpowered - is make or break.

I enjoyed it the first time. I question whether I'll enjoy it long-term due to this issue, though. Maybe with an added drafting step - but that requires significant experience to be done at all quickly.

Pretty good with 2 players. Exacerbates skill differences, of course. Possibly exacerbates luck of the draw issues too, but my case was skill.

RATING: 10

We never get sick of this game after well over 100 plays and don't think we ever will.

Best with 3-4 players in my opinion. 5 is great too but some people find it to drag on a bit.

This is definitely the most stressful game (feeding your family is a pressure that never relents... And if it does it's probably a sign that you're losing because you're not growing your family).

Great game. Good for advanced gamers. Good for rookies.

RATING: 10
I never tire of this game.  I only yearn for more.  Whenever I get around to playing it, I'm reminded that it's my favorite.  

I downloaded the app after having sold the game awhile back as I rarely got to play it.  Now I feel foolish.  This game is awesome!  It's a tense battle for the limited action spaces that comes right down to the wire, and at the end of the game you can look at the farm you built and feel proud of the family you raised up through the hard knocks of agrarian life.  

I usually end up preferring the app more than the physical game.  With Agricola; however, I prefer the physical game as I like having everything out in front me when I figuring out what to do.  The app compartmentalizes all the boards and cards in a way that makes it difficult for me to make timely decisions.

RATING: 9
I really like that the rules are in themselves quite simple - but you have a LOT of choices. Also since only one player can take each action, your strategy keeps taking deroutes all the time. Up to the point where you have to change it - and you really don't have time for that.

There are many different paths to victory.

I'm not surprised if I bump this to 9 after playing the full version.

RATING: 10
After one play of the basic (family) game with 5 players I found this quite intriguing, with seemingly many things to do, though we were all (4 newbies at it) a bit lost to start with, and rated it a 7. However, we fairly quickly picked it up, and if we played a second time would certainly see more deliberate strategies played. 

Having played my newly arrived English language version, complete with Animeeples, a couple of times my rating has increased to 8. Still only played the family version which so far I've found quite complicated enough but also satisfying. Though I'm still struggling to play efficiently and am flailing around desperately trying different things. Hopefully more plays will rectify this!

A couple of plays now with the E-deck cards; not really any more complicated and in some respects more forgiving as they tend to make it easier to get enough resources and food. There are more opportunities for distraction though......now rates a 9.

A couple more games and this is a 10: I'm always happy to play it, and we've played it a couple of nights in a row by popular demand, a sign of a good game. Hasn't lost it's lustre yet!


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I want to rate this higher because it's highly a strategic euro with an approachable theme, but I just can't.  The first reason is that I find it to be too fiddly.  The second is that I feel the cards introduce a catch 22: The cards seem to be a little on the unbalanced side.  To rectify this people can play the 'Family' version which has no occupations/minor improvements.  In doing so, players can't accomplish as much in the game which takes away some of the fun and more importantly there will be a LOT less variety from game to game. Drafting is another method that addresses the problem with card balance. The benefit of drafting, other than a balancing mechanism, is that you can try to draft cards to match a specific strategy you want to try rather than virtually being forced to use the strategy that you've been dealt. An example of this is having to play an early plowing strategy due to being dealt the Field Watchman. The issue with this is that drafting does add a fair chunk of time to a game already of medium to high length depending on the number of players.  After further plays I dislike the end game scoring because you're always trying to get at least some of everything, instead of doing what you want.

After further plays, I feel that the player that's able to grow their family the earliest has a huge advantage and will likely win the game.  Due to this mechanism, I don't feel that Agricola is as strong a worker placement game as Uwe's Ora et Labora, All Creatures Big and Small, and Fields of Arle.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Tentative rating... Still tentative after several plays. Just not sure how I feel about this one. Sometimes it frustrates me to no end how hosed you can get by the cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The 17th Century Was Not an Easy Time to be a Farmer.  A game for 1-4 players ages 12 and up; play time is 30 minutes per player. Amazing replay value. The Agricola base game is a revised edition of Uwe Rosenberg’s celebrated classic. The game is designed for 1-4 players, features improved all-wood components and a card selection from the base game as well as its expansions, revised and updated for this edition. Players begin the game with two family members and can grow their families over the course of the game. This allows them more actions but remember you have to grow more food to feed your family as it grows! Feeding your family is a special kind of challenge and players will plant grain and vegetables while supplementing their food supply with sheep, wild boar and cattle. Guide your family to wealth, health and prosperity and you will win the game.

I prefer Caverna: The Cave Farmers over Agricola.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
It's in the top 5 for a reason.  A solid game beginning to end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
This is a really great game, close to Puerto Rico and Power Grid caliber. What's nice about this game is that it is playable for 2 players (it's better with more than 2, but still fun with only 2) and it has a solitaire option which I have not yet tried. The other nice thing is the family rules, which makes this game playable for children. My 10 year-old son really likes this game. There is something very satisfying about watching your farm grow with all of the different components. There is good dramatic tension due to the different decisions to be made and risks that you are forced to take throughout the game. The price is a bit lofty however I think this game really delivers some serious fun.

Fisrt Impression: Ugh, who wrote this? The rule book is a jumbled mess, not to mention being full of grammatical errors! I'm sorry. but the game doesn't seem THAT complicated to warrant such convoluted rules.

RATING: 4
I have issue with the identical scoring which forces you to do everything (because if you don't - negative points!)  I think a lot of the intial game moves at the start are too obvious (and repetitive) and the feed-your-people phase is just an onerous chore.  Even the designer seems to agree as a lot of these concepts have been reworked or removed in his much better successors (Le Havre, Ora et Lab, Glass Road, Caverna, Odin).  If those never existed I would have a high rating here, but as they do, old Agricola no longer merits more than a 5.  I think a lot of the reviews on BGG also reflect this and I suspect were probably posted prior to Caverna or Le Havre being released.  Great components, but so many are a pain to sort out and store, so no grade impact for them.

RATING: 9
Started this off at nine rather than the typical 8 or 7. RATING: 5.75
First play rating of 7.25 a composite of my rating (7.5) and my sister's rating (7).  Played 2 player game.  Rating may improve a half point if, as I suspect, the game has more tension and tough decisions with more players.

Update: on a second play with 3 players, rating slipped down to 5.75, a composite of my rating (5.5) and my sister's rating (6).  Wife's rating of 4 not factored in, as she was exhausted and somewhat sick.  In that condition, she found the game too busy and confusing.

While the use of Occupation, Minor Improvement and Action cards creates many permutations, ultimately I found the game a bit boring.  Precisely because of the randomness introduced by all of the cards, it becomes difficult to formulate long-term strategy, and play becomes more tactical, as players react to changes in circumstances which can sometimes be hard to predict.

Victory conditions requiring a balanced farmyard seem to sap the game of interest, homogenizing strategies and making the game feel like a rather dry exercise in resource optimization.  The very appealing animeeples and veggimeeples were not enough to generate much excitement.  Playing the game is fun, but fiddly bits and numerous options make for work as well, and the latter almost overshadows the former.

At least for us, the claim on the box that it takes 1/2 hour per player is ridiculously inaccurate.  We find that about 1 hour per player is more accurate.

In all, a mildly interesting game with fabulous production value, but not worthy of the lovefest it has engendered here on BGG.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The quintessential worker placement, with an array of winning strategies to analyze. The Occupation and Minor Improvement cards offer interesting combinations to explore, but are difficult to fully utilize, which as the main source of game-to-game variety is unfortunate. The scarcity of food and resources is oppressive, especially for new players, but as an experienced gamer I cherish this. You'd never expect farming, and the ever-looming harvest, to invoke such intense stress and worry, but these emotions work to quickly immerse players into Agricola's bleak world. While many will point to agriculture as the theme, I would argue that Agricola is a story of scarcity. There will never be enough resources, or workers, or time, to complete all of your goals, but you have to do the best with what you have. It may be simple life but it's hard as hell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A little too coarse for my tastes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Based on app play. Taking excerpts from other negative comments and reviews...

"A game should, even in the lightest of ways, feel adventurous driven by player autonomy. Agricola is, for lack of a better term, deterministic in that players lose points if they don't do everything, and so a player cannot choose to do something. And that which a player so happens to do is never surprising, determined by that which grants bonus points. This, and not even necessarily the punishing points system, is my biggest problem with Agricola."

"Very mechanical, very fiddly, and a little overwhelming in the number of actions. Its very hard to see a clear path to victory because this game penalizes specialization and rewards doing poorly in different fields. It never feels like you get to enjoy advancing your farm (or managing it the way you want to) as you do rushing to take actions before someone takes them from you."

"In Puerto Rico, one builds, so even in last place, I feel like the least *successful* player. Agricola is about fighting the game and often destroying what you've built before (crops, herds), so even if I were to win, I think I'd feel like the least *failing* player."

Just very punishing and unintuitive without a satisfying payoff.

1 - 5 players, 2 - 4 hours

RATING: 7
I don't know how cool I am with the incredible randomness the hands give this game. I'd consider drafting cards into your hand, but I don't know how that investment of additional time would equal an increase in return. Also, thought the interactive deck was pretty nasty though. 

Don't get me wrong, I still think this game is pretty, pretty, pretty good. 

My biggest qualm with this game is the AP the optimization element of the game brings. If your move was taken by the player before you, you're going to have to think of a new move that scores the most points/does the most for you, and this can take a little longer than I'd like. 

9 to 7: I've got my play out of it after 12 plays. I just don't think it's as fun as it used to be. For every big decision, I feel there's a fair amount of forced decisions and waiting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I've played this 30+ of times, mostly 2 player, and changed my rating more than once.  I really have mixed feelings about it.  The game has a lot going for it - a lot of resource management and optimization that is a lot of fun.  And yet I tend to get frustrated with it, in a way that I don't with better games like Caylus and Puerto Rico.  

I think that essentially my complaint is the lack of player interaction.  Sure, it has some player interaction, mostly of the blocking kind, but I think it must fall below some sort of critical threshold for me.  When I play Agricola I don't really feel as if I am playing against the other players as I do with Caylus or Puerto Rico - instead I feel like I am playing against the game, aiming for a new high score, and the other players are just distractions.  Except that they are darn annoying distractions, who every so often really mess you up.  And so instead of the thrill of competition (I really do enjoy tight, competitive games), I just get frustrated.  

Also, I'm not a big fan of the randomness in the cards - I almost prefer the family game.  

In general, I find this game very interesting, and if I am in the right mood and can manage to take it lightly (not easy for a game that does require a certain amount of tactical thought), I do enjoy it.  But many other times I have been left feeling frustrated or disappointed, and so I am afraid the best I can give it is a 6.5  

Update 1/5/2012 - sold the game, and downgraded it to a 6.

Have played about 10 more times.  Still agree with my initial rating.

RATING: 10
I just absolutely adore this game for so many reasons:
- really, really solid game. Not much luck involved
- you can't go for the same strategy every game. The cards give you new directions every time, which adds to the replayability (and it still doesn't bore me after 100s of I plays!)
- I like the player interaction. No direct aggression and almost all information is available to all players. However, since there is some tense competition for the action spaces you do have to watch other players very carefully.
- The tension in this game is great. I know many people who find it exhausting to provide food every harvest. They complain that the game is over before they really 'get going'. But I like it that you can't do everything every game, which makes every game different and interesting for me.

RATING: 5.5
Having played three times now, I just don't get the hype around this game.  It's clever and complex, but it's just not much fun.  I do like the way there are many possible strategies; I'm less keen on how long it takes to play out, so trying different strategies to see what might work is a very time consuming process.

On my first play, it felt like there was a certain amount of imbalance in getting resources depending on how close one sat to the starting player and which occupation cards were dealt.  (Yes, I know there's an action to take start player marker, but if the person on your right does this often, you're in a better position than if the person on your left does so.) I imagine that with experience one learns the best way to play with one is dealt, and I'm told by friends who have played a lot that it is a game that gets better when players are experienced.  I suppose that climbing this learning curve could be satisfying in a group where the same people played together often and learned together.  But I remain to be convinced that the time investment is worth it (for me), compared to spending those hours playing (for me) more enjoyable games.

That said, I'd be willing to try it again if someone else really wants to play.  But not very often. (Jul 13)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]Rating based on - 10 plays, 2 player[/b]
A worker placement game where you are each controlling a farmer and his wife on your personal farm board in order to make the most points. The box comes chock full of components, artwork is lovely and components are well done – sturdy cardboard, wooden animals etc., rulebook takes a bit of time to wade through but it's all well organised and we could find what we needed no problem, well designed I guess...I mean it won awards so it must be OK. 

However, the setup is too long for the lack of fun generated, a vast amount of table space is required, cards lack variety but give the illusion of many options with its hundreds of cards but many cards are in fact duplicated, game is very prescribed – diversification is rewarded and specialisation is not, so you must follow a certain formula to win and as a result you both end up with practically identical farms at the end *yawn*. I also don't like games that leave out tons of components when playing with different player counts – I've never had a chance, and never will, to try any of the cards from 3-5 players which is about half of each of the decks (many of which look much more interesting) and along with Alhambra and Keyflower this game made us realise we don't like games where players are focused on their own village play area. We'd rather all the action take place on a central board.

It feels like a 3+ player game and was just a very MEH experience for us from the first play to play 10. I got this one in because we loved Loyang so much, and many comments I read here state outright that Agricola is the better game. We, however, didn't find that to be the case. We found it same-y after a handful of plays, I find it incredibly dull and my gaming partner finds it frustrating because he doesn't have the time to bring all his plans to fruition. We will stick to At the Gates of Loyang in the future.
[b]Status: TRADED for Summoner Wars Master Set & Summoner War Phoenix Elves vs Tundra Orcs[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Borrowed from Tim O'Connell for 7 Wonders 4/3/17. Yet to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's a bit convoluted for my taste. It seems like everything you try to accomplish takes several workers - and you only start out with two.

Feeding your people is a central part of the game and a real nuisance. There's always a feeling of dread because you don't have time for everything - and because of the way scoring works, you have to do a bit of everything.

Having 14 different cards at the beginning of the game is pretty neat, but it can lead to some serious analysis paralysis and most of the cards you don't get to use anyway. The way the cards work isn't very streamlined and the return on investment is very slim. In the end, it just doesn't feel that satisfying to me.

I love the wooden animal meeples, but really dislike the art on the cards. I've also upgraded some of the discs to MeepleSource farmers.

I will have to play it with 3 or 4 players to see if that changes my mind.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Balanced so well that almost every game you will be one resource away from accomplishing your final plan unless you have planned perfectly. Just enough player interaction to not feel like multiplayer solitaire and only passive aggressive actions.

RATING: 8
Comes with a version to play with families, as well as being a good game in its own right.  As a worker placement game, it has similar mechanics to games like Stone Age and Pillars of the Earth, but the cards give this more replayability. Don't miss the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/340902]Wine-label review: A Wine-taster's Guide to Agricola[/url].
This game seems to be as good as they say - quick play time, lots of options with different cards every game, nice components, solid theme, not too complex, all round goodness!  
The English edition does seem to have [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/326815]a fair amount of errors[/url], hopefully these will be corrected in a future edition soon (most recently, recommended changes to [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/612645/official-changes-on-2-cards]two cards[/url]).  Great game, but it can fry your brain, very tense gameplay in a short amount of time.  I like the fact that it's not very confrontational, and to some extent each game is a challenge against yourself.

Areas that are downsides for me personally:
1. too tense and too short, doesn't allow you time to do everything you want
2. makes diversity mandatory, arguably taking away from focusing on multiple paths to victory (at least in the Family game)
3. cards can advantage players depending on what they draw
More of my thoughts: [thread=730206]here[/thread].

For an alternative viewpoint along similar lines, see [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/461632]UndeadViking[/url]: "[i]When I play Agricola I have a two hour session of minimal player interaction coupled with me putting a puzzle together that always ends up looking the same when I am finished. Sometimes the pieces I have to use are a little different, but it always looks the same in the end ... For what it is, it is as close to perfect as I have found, and for the right people, it is gaming nirvana. However, for me, it is a tired, ponderous time of pushing and placing wood tokens at a table with a few friends doing the same thing, in which all of us are stuck on our farming treadmills until we reach a conclusion that is neither a surprise, nor as fitting a reward for the efforts we just went through.[/i]"

See some of my thoughts in this article: [thread=730206][/thread].  

Agricola vs Caverna: Agricola is quite restrictive and punishes you if you go wrong; in contrast Caverna is more flexible/open.  Agricola forces you to meet specific objectives and feels your family, and feel more like a struggle for survival than positively building a farm, while Caverna lets you build what you like more.  However Agricola has more player interaction and more replayability due to variable cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Agricola sits in the pantheon of worker placement games, and is one I still enjoy very much. The cards are frequently mentioned as a gamebreaker for some people. For me, they’re specifically why I like this game. The cards break rules or give you bonus powers such that the w-p decision space is different every time. 

Here, you get 14 secret powers at the start of the game which adds another dimension of figuring out how to play them in concert with each other as well as classically tight board actions. In fact, I've always thought Agricola is a game about which cards you do not play, i.e., which ones you decide aren't worth the benefit they confer relative to good old, boring board actions. I've seen players plop down an occupation a turn and have all these cool benefits only to see the game end before they could make use of them. Smarter players will play just enough at just the right times and not be seduced into more. While you'll do some of the same things each game, you'll do a lot differently based on which cards you play. The power of those cards generates a feeling of promise and an excitement unique to Agricola. 

So what I'm saying is while the worker placement in Agricola would probably be an interesting enough game, it's the cards that make the game transcend to a level of constant fascination and give it some oomph. To be adept at this game, you need great worker placement skills along with card discernment. I do think drafting is a necessity lest someone end up with the better cards, but I find a draft of some sort solves this potential problem. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Great game. I think that in terms of strategy games go, Agricola paves the way. Even though I consistently find flaws in the game play, every game continues to surprise me as well as make me want to play more.

Have played most often with two players and it definitely gets boring without expansions. Love 3+ game, really gives a different experience every time you play. Strategy is demanding. 

Winner is usually person with least strategical flaws although usually can make a couple of mistakes and still win. Aggressive play can be a good strategy if you play aggressively with the right actions.

Not a good game to play against recent learners if you have a decent amount of plays under your belt.  

This game is a ten until I find something I enjoy more (may never happen).

RATING: 7

But in Agricola, players are constantly being forced to feed their workers instead of working toward interesting goals and card combos. So I totally understand the 'Misery Farm' nickname this game has earned.

RATING: 8
What else can be said about Uwe's masterpiece that hasn't already said.  I personally think this game far surpasses Caverna and Le Havre.  This game is tight from start to finish with every round involving a tough decision.  I love the 'feed the people' mechanic and the scoring where you have to do good in all areas or the game punishes you.  

Since my wife and I have a large game collection, it only comes to the table sporadically, and so by the time we get it back out we want a rules refresher again.  So we play the 'family' variant most times.  Even then, this game is fantastic and I even think it's got some good replayability in this form.  

I really like that the full version gives you some direction to focus on for strategy with your opening hand.

I own the farmers of the moor expansion - like this as well, but play it even less often.

RATING: 9.5
Played at BGG.con.If at all possible, play with someone who has played before and really knows the rules. Also, don't plan on winning your first game out. There are simply too many options available to make a novice happy. I predict multiple plays will result in a greater love for this one.We had a guy mess up early and by mid-game he got up and walked away from the table never to return. He used some awesome swear words too. Anyway, the game is not exactly forgiving of early mistakes and for the first couple plays, you should expect to make some early mistakes.In the end, I enjoyed the game, but I kept asking myself if having twenty million different paths to victory really makes for a better experience than five paths to victory.

UPDATE: A few years later and I finally broke down and purchased the game. Mostly because I made a new friend who doesn't mind playing brain-burner type games. Well, I've played again (one time Solo and once with Kim) and my experience has been much better. I've raised my rating from a 7 to an 8.5 and actually look forward to seeing this hit the table in the near future. I'm going to say that Le Havre is responsible for my turn around. It was good enough that I decided to give Uwe Rosenberg's first game another chance. One thing I've learned about this game is if you have a jerk playing with you (as I did the first time) you won't enjoy it much.

RATING: 9
Agricola is a great game, a near platonic ideal of what a tense euro-game should be.  There is real tension between all you WANT to do and all you CAN and MUST do; time is always against you.

The lack of direct player confrontation is not a problem.  Like many classic euro games, there is plenty of indirect manipulation of resources and actions that make this an interactive experience.  Consequently, no one strategy seems to always work and flexible game play and tactical changes are needed to do well.

The myriad of minor improvement and occupation cards continue to provide new tricks and strategies that keep this game fresh. What drops this to a nine for me however is that some of these card combinations are clearly better than others.  This at times seems to unbalance the game depending on your starting hand, though it can be mitigated somewhat with better play. 

Agricola is well deserving of all of the praise, and will likely have staying power as (one of) the best. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
I really wanted to like this game, but I was underwhelmed by the actual play. I don't mind the dry farmer theme. I don't even mind the multiplayer solitaire feel. The part about the game that frustrated me so much was the feeling that I never really *finished* it; it just ended. There is so much to do and the times I played I could not finish even half of the things that scored points and thus got a very low score. The other frustrating part was the actual role selection; if someone took the action you really needed you had to rethink your entire strategy and there were usually no good options. I don't feel this way about other two top ten games I've played, Power Grid and Puerto Rico. Neither of those get me feeling so frustrated and incomplete.

After I played "At the Gates of Loyang" I realized how much I really loathe this one, and I dropped the rating from 5 to 3.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[2014 September 15; 5 plays; 9/10]
This is one of my favorite games, and I suspect it may always stay in my top ten, and as of right now, I can only imagine its rating growing from a 9 to a 10.

The things I love about Agricola are not highly unique, and are probably better stated by a better writer than I:

[user=chally][/user]

[q="chally"]Agricola will always remain among my top-rated games, and, to me, it is characterized by two features that I think it does better than nearly any game.

First, it is archetypal of one style of Eurogame that I enjoy immensely: that in which players struggle within the confines of a highly restrictive game system, creating tension simply from the panic that players experience trying to keep their heads above water. Agricola is the only game that has made me literally sweat at I'm performing my last action or two. It's not that the decisions are all that hard, but optimal play requires careful sequencing that is easily thrown off by the choices of others. Working flexibility and a backup plan into the game is the true source of challenge. Particularly with three players (which is my preferred number of players for games), the tension toward the endgame is unbearably delicious 

Second, Agricola does the single-best job of any game in my collection integrating theme with gameplay (especially impressive when you consider just how many occupation and improvement cards there are). If I plow a field in Agricola, my thought process is: well I ought to plant something to put this thing to use. And if I plant some grain, I can bake bread later, which will require an oven, so maybe I'll get some clay now while it's cheap. None of this is explicitly in terms of victory points, or action/opportunity costs (although those do help guide and shape more tactical decisions). At this stage, I'm just trying to build a cool farm in a game about farming. And building a cool farm is a winning strategy, so there's no thematic disconnect. The farming feels like farming; the snozberries taste like snozberries.[/q]

I've played 5 times now, and that is the only thing keeping it from a higher rating, but each of those plays it has blown me away!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A masterclass of visual design, deep-game design, player-scale design and presentation design (no one can forget the animeeples). 
Arguably one of the most thematic games of the last decade, Agricola does not treat you with satin gloves. You feel the grind with every move, every round, every encroaching harvest, winter coming closer and closer.
The game, without occupations, is tough to muscle through the first few times, and once everyone is on the same playing level the start-game drafting catapults the game to near-perfection levels.
Probably the most notable Worker Placement game on the market, it arrived only two short years after the creator of the genre, Caylus, to make farming one of the most exciting, and terrifying, experience you can have with your friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Czekam na pierwszą rozgrywkę...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A typical game where you want to do much more than you are able to. The action selection mechanisms are one of the best in the world. Though, the game tends to last a little longer than I like.
I must admit that I like games where the most experienced players win (at least for this type of game). What I dislike about this game is that the strategies seem given. You must have enough family members. Otherwise you are lost. And when you have many family members, you need enough food to feed them. Therefore, it is given to go for the major improvements that convert animals or vegetables into food (there is no point in acquiring family members if you only use them for gaining food). The other given thing is that you must do everything. Otherwise you will lose too many points (since you get minus points for each missing object).
But all in all a very good game where the fight between the different actions makes the game really tense and interesting.

RATING: 10
I've played around 15 games of Agricola and I can say that this is about as close as you can get to a perfect game.  The only issue that I have with the game is that each additional player in the game dramatically adds to the required time for a game.  To the point where a 5 player game will take around 3-4 hours unless all of the participants are seasoned Agricola players.

Edit:  I've played 50-60 games of this now and I still consider it the best board game I've ever played.

RATING: 3
Since this is a top rated game I thought I should probably play it before criticizing it. I asked a friend to bring it along and we dutifully gave it a game.

One of the other players dislikes it, and so was a little negative the whole play through and I admit I slipped into it too.

The theme is sooo boring and like Puerto Rico everybody has to be at the same level or newbies get schooled!
Being stuck as last player repeatedly, I found I had very little options for my turn and to be honest halfway through the game I couldn't care less. I could see no way to catch up and was just falling further and further behind.
That said this is a beautifully made game. The components are top quality and you get plenty of resource tokens. It is a  bit weird that only two of the player boards have spaces to store everything and the others just have woodlands... but this doesn't affect game play.

Overall I think I was as miserable playing this game as my two little people in their small drafty wooden hut!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Awesome game.  The replayability is super high with the amount of cards included!  You can literally play several hundred games with a completely different flavor each time.  I've only played a couple games so far, but I do have a few minor squibbles:

1) My biggest concern is that the game (with equally competent players) may actually be decided by luck favoring the player who receives the best Occupation & Minor Improvement cards.  Perhaps a card draft or using the Interactive Deck will counter this.  I have only played with the basic "E" deck at this time.

2)  For a $70 MSRP game it would have been nice to include a quality usable insert and better artwork.  The green & tan color scheme is fairly dull; but I guess it doesn't matter too much since there is so much else going on for it.

3)  The board that displays the Major Improvement cards is completely unnecessary.  A better design would be to create a spot for the stack + have spots for other goods and/or features.  A slightly bigger & better designed 2-sided player aid may also be worthwhile.  

My rating can easily go up to a 10 (or down to an 8-9) depending on the revelation of the balance of the cards.  Otherwise, it could possibly be a waste of 3 hours - but still a very fun one at that (1st game was 4.25 hrs, 2nd game was 2.75 hrs - both w/5 players).  Grade: A-
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rating is 10 with Farmers of the Moor, 9.5 without.

Agricola is an extremely tight game, where almost each move involves tense and difficult decisions. I enjoy the mix of both short-term tactics and long-term strategy, and the intricate dance of ensuring you get what you need while denying your opponent what he or she needs. The occupations and minor improvements keep the game fresh and varied each time. The theme may be about farming, but the graphic design is functional, and some of the art is genuinely funny.

The Farmers of the Moor expansion is a worthy addition to the game, by adding a more puzzle-like spatial element to one's farm layout, introducing new scoring elements such as horses, and also rebalancing some aspects of the base game such as making early renovation more important. One disadvantage of the expansion is that it adds a bit more leeway to the game, such as by adding more (but admittedly not efficient) ways to get food, and granting extra actions. This makes the game slightly less tight in my opinion, but I find the added variety to be (you guessed it) a major improvement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played one game — so far. The game seemed okay at the beginning, but the player's positions were so horribly influenced by the bloated carcass that was the card deck, that any hope of strategy quickly went out the window. The game feels fat and lazy; lolling around on its rather ponderous backside, calling for the players to fetch it another round of treats. 

I'd play this again, probably a few times, but so far I'm just not seeing the attraction. Lassies and laddies, before you go off about the wonderous card decks, let me state that this feature is the primary problem with the game. This victim of scope creep, feels and plays like a Frankenstein's monster, that people couldn't stop adding bits to. Look — this monstrosity already has two heads and four arms, why can't we just apply the juice and call it a day?

While some games suffer from too short of a development time, this one seems to have the opposite problem. Culling the cards by 75% might make a quicker, leaner game, but we're a bit too far down the road for that. 

Will I play this game again? Yes, certainly. May I learn to enjoy it? Maybe. My rating may go up in the future, but let's wait and see regarding that proposition. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]This highly variable farming game is, in my opinion, the greatest game of all time.[/b]

My rating history: 10...9...8...9.10.......................

2016: Still my favourite game of all time. It helps to have a few expansion decks to keep things fresh for 2p, as the card pool for 2p is not all that large for someone who plays as often as I do. I am very curious to see what 2017's Collectors Edition brings. The Revised edition is nice, but has such a small card pool. :/

2014: Back up to a 10. I now LOVE the competitiveness of this game, watching resource stacks and predicting needs and ways to beneficially interfere.

40th play: 10. Still going strong. The cards and the pressure are what make this better than Caverna for me.

50th play: 10. 4p. No animals and -6 space pts, but 5 family members, 5 stone rooms, and 14 pts in cards for the win.
52th play: 10. (2p) My first 2p draft led to me playing down 9 cards...which took too many actions, and left me too unfocused, and got one of my opponents a first tie (34-34). Note to self: FOCUS! =)

60+ plays, still rate a 10. Just so good.



2011: The more I play it the less I care about "competing" with the other players, and the more I care about building a perfect farm. Something about the game doesn't seem that competitive (which is why this game gets the "multi-player solitaire" label from a lot of people) but the challenge present in the game, and the race to certain spots on the board give it a sense of challenge to all. I have knocked this from a 10 to a 9, but I honestly don't think I'll ever get sick of Agricola. The extra decks included with the game give you a new challange every time. A real delight, and the "family game" rules are simple enough, I think even young gamers could play with a little help.


2009: I wouldn't want to play this with 5 players again, but -- wow! What a game! Wonderfully themed (you can pretty much explain the game in theme, which is fun), and a rewarding game experience.

RATING: 8.2
I play it with my selfmaid (pimped) version !! GREAT GAME ! thanks Uwe !!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
Family version takes about 1/2 hr. per person to play.  The interactive version we enjoy more, but takes more time--not the actual play, but the preparation prior to play when deciding which combination of occupations and minor improvements is best.  There is such a hugh possibility of combinations & it takes time to consider them all, so I don't see planning time being cut much.  Actual play (the rounds) can be very fast.  Don't like the expert deck.  When someone gets the card that allows them to get an extra family member in the first two rounds, gives them the game.

Never enough turns and lots of hard choices which increase as the game progresses.  Important to get extra people (for extra turns) as early as possible without struggling for food, or eating all your points up.  Early on building resources most important--especially for the extra room for the extra turns & oven for more efficient food production.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After several plays I've lost my enthusiasm for this one.  It's quite fun designing your farm but processes are very slow and I've never managed to plant a vegetable.  To collect enough wood to build a decent fence takes most of the game. The later phases with the necessity to provide food almost every round means that the same processes have to be carried out several times.  
Also there is quite a lot of replacing of bits and turning cards over and usually one bit or card gets forgotten.

RATING: 3.62

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&gameid=31260&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze]Ratings[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have a much better idea of how to play this game, and the limited actions and feeding requirements no longer make me feel claustrophobic. I know how to line up synergistic actions, play for flexibility, watch for others' priorities, and score points as I play rather than just at the end.

The variance of the cards peeves me a bit, but the variety and interaction of many of them is good.

The game still takes longer than I like, and does inspire AP in others. Fortunately placements are interleaved.

The theme is depicted very well, despite a couple of anti-thematic elements (the worker placement, family growth) that are critical to it functioning as a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Update: after probably 40 plays, I don't really get excited about the cards anymore.  Initially I felt like each hand of cards was like getting a completely new set of possible strategies.  Now I feel like there are only a few strategies and the cards give you some options for pursuing those strategies.  Without the excitement of trying new things, the core game is a little bit not my style.  

It's also funny to note that when I first started playing this game, I felt like I was building something.  Now, I feel like I see what is possible from the beginning, and the game is just tearing it down.  It's seems like the game is too opaque in some areas and too clear in others.  Still, I can't really recommend the game enough.  I certainly got a ton of value out of it and I'll continue to play it here and there down the line.


(original rating)Just a fantastic game altogether.  It hangs with any of the other top tier games, but there's two things that elevate this above the rest for me:

1) It's like if Puerto Rico/Caylus/etc. had new buildings every time you played.  With 300 some cards and the cards being so integral to how you approach each game, it's like you get that new game excitement of trying to figure out a strategy every time you play.  Fantastic.

2) Bits do a lot for me, and it's not the look of these that are so great (I mean, it's farming, not an army of ninjas) it's the way you get to actually construct your stables, sow your crops, and see things actually come to life in your farm.  It really immerses you in the game.  Having animeeples and vegimeeples just takes this a step further.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Note: We love Le Havre and played it before Agricola. 

This is much better for less serious gamers. Very thematic - who doesn't love play farming - and it's much more manageable scope and length. The limitations make it such that nobody can pull too much ahead, which can keep it semi-competitive for less experienced gamers. 

Still,the scoring cap is very frustrating and limiting. It really doesn't allow a whole lot of room for specialization because you need at least a little of everything, but having a lot of something only gets you so far. 

My complaint is that the game feels a little too short/incomplete - it doesn't feel like it's quite ready to be over when it ends. I would say it's very dissatisfying. 

Still, I'm looking forward to teaching the family game to some lighter gaming friends and see their response to this game. I have a good feeling about this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[floatright][size=5]2012-12-05[/size][/floatright][b]Solitaire[/b]
The no-cards ([i]family game[/i]) single player is a good environment to learn the mechanics and provides an interesting puzzle; if you like playing solo, the variable phase bonuses allow you to learn a lot without the solitaire feeling too repetitive. Even when you have figured out some of the best scoring strategies and the opening has become monotonous, the variable phases will often throw you a curveball and force you to adapt and change your strategy accordingly, making the last 3 harvests more interesting and challenging. Another challenging aspect of playing solo is the increased upkeep of the farmers, who need 3 food each harvest instead of 2, putting a lot of pressure on the player especially during the late, shorter harvests.

When you feel like you're done with this version, you can move on and introduce the cards, which should give the solo variant a much longer life. The first game will probably take more than an hour, but after making yourself more comfortable with the game you'll be able to consistently play in less than 60 minutes (setup time might not be included, depends on your tendency to go into analysis paralysis).

[floatright][size=5]2015-01-14[/size][/floatright]What I like most about Agricola is probably the struggling, the increasing pressure given by the shorter and shorter intervals between harvests, the fact that, even though you are creating an engine, you'll still have to overcome the same problems. Often, in this kind of games, your growing curve transforms the huge hurdles you face at the beginning in little bumps you barely notice. Not so in Agricola.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
[b]Design:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]Interleaved action, economic engine.[/i]
[b]Execution:- [/b]:star::star::star::star::nostar:  [i]Fixed structure given variety through random set-up.[/i] 
[b]Experience:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]Not bad; feels a little like the game is doing the driving (for example, the diversity "requirement"), but definite presence of angst.[/i]
[b]Presentation:- [/b]:star::star::star::star::nostar:  [i]Excellent components let down by a handful of rules errors and slight confusion.[/i]

This is a good game, but I am a little uncertain whether it will have lasting appeal.  There are so many games that already have a broadly similar play structure for me to get too excited over this one; action selection, resource management and building in the mix has been done so many times before and IMO in many better ways.  This game could grow on me a bit more; the replayability factor is great with the different decks of cards and it is beautiful to behold but I doubt it is ever going to fill the shoes of such greats as Keythedral or Caylus.  Good, but by no means great.

RATING: 10
My boardgame buddies say it's right up there with Caylus and Puerto Rico. I don't think THAT highly of it but it's for sure the best new game I played in 2007. ONE thing is definetely better than in Caylus and PR: due to the huge variety of cards each player receives at the beginning of each game (14 out of several 100s!!!) the strategic choices are MUCH more diverse than the ones you can possibly use with the other 2 games. 

July 2008: after about 100 games (mostly 2 or 3, some 4 player games) I herewith declare that it has officially climbed to No.1 on my Top 10 List. This is the game that brought my girlfriend into regular boardgame playing. FINALLY. THANK GOD :-) 

June 2009: I figure that I've played about 250 games so far. Still my favorite and still different almost every time.  Just WOW

June 2012: dunno how many 100s of games I've played by now. I cannot see that this will ever be kicked from it's 1st rank in my personal All-time-favorite game list. Never before has a game intreaged me over such a long time period  (and it still does!) and I guess i can even say that this is the only game that actually affected my personal life as it finally brought my girl friend into boardgaming.

RATING: N/A
60E
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game really intrigues me.  I think the idea that it is customizable based on number of players and their experience level is great.  The components are of a good quality, though I would have liked to see something a little less abstract than tokens and blocks for the resources.  I suppose that would have driven the price from high to ridiculous though, so I am content to slowly make Sculpey bits.

The gameplay itself is intuitive thanks to the theme (well, sort of) and rewarding in a zen sort of way.  It is great fun to build your little farm and watch it prosper.  It lasts a good while without being too long, but so far just about every time we've played it, people have said "I would play again, but it is too late now."  That is probably more a commentary on my poor choice of starting times than anything else.

My only complaints would be the set-up and the constant shortage of Wood tokens, but I can't see how you would speed things up too much.  The game is enjoyable enough that the setup headaches aren't too bad.  I imagine if you played with an experienced group who could help with setup, things would go much more smoothly, but I haven't had that luxury yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Un peu plat à deux..

L'aspect stratégique (un plan de nouriture / un entassement sans logique des ressources) prévaut plutot sur les cartes et l'oportunisme.

RATING: 2
Almost everything that I don't like about Eurogames or worker placemen games, can be found in this. Huge downtime, having to do everything ultimately, or else... Random cards in the start that you have to plan whole game around of lose... If i want dull misery farming, I want the game done by Phil Eklund, he probably could make it at least properly impactfull and competitive, instead of passive agressive "I pick carrot so you lose one point" "I shall then build fences so you can't!"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Agricola is a good game, a great one, actually. The problem is it becomes very predictable after having played a few times. I can almost say that it is possible to find a-recipe-for-winning the most games, and if not for the huge variety of cards that the game brings, this game would be somewhat mediocre. The problem is that even with the large number of cards, this "winning key" continues to function. In other words: you can win by following this "recipe" even without using none of this cards.
However, I must admit that I like Agricola. Why? I suppose a mixture of reasons among which are: subject matter, visual design, its basic mechanics, the fact that this is a dynamic and interactive (though not much) and not too long game...
In conclusion: I like Agricola and I realy enjoy playing it, but If I'd have to choose between Agricola and his younger brother (or big brother? I don't know), Le Havre, I'd certainly choose the second one!

2011/06 -EDIT-
Having played it many times since my first rating, I don't see that "winning key" anymore! Agricola is great, deep, very replayable, absolutely nice & fun!

RATING: 8
Feels alot like Caylus with a much larger array of actions and some ccg-type elements to it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In the first game Agricola is pretty overwhelming. There's so many things to do and it isn't at all clear how some actions will influence the outcome when compared to other actions. The perception of "OMG, I have no idea what to do" is then slowly replaced by "OMG, I don't have enough manpower/room/food/resources for what I need to do" during that first game. That pretty much sets the tone for the game: You are constantly under pressure.

The improvements and occupations are simply needed for interplay variability, and some of them just allow you to do the usual stuff a little more efficiently while others open up entirely new avenues of play. It is true, however, that depending on the initial card distribution the playing field can sometimes tilt to one side or another, and while prevailing against overwhelming odds can be a fun endeavour in its own right it is not usually what I am looking for in a boardgame. Then again, in the grand scheme of things this is only a tiny cloud in the great blue sky.

RATING: 8.5
A well balanced and rewarding empire builder, where 'empire' is actually just your little medieval farmstead. This game is fun, but I tend not to agree it is the greatest ever, as the BGG game ranking seems to suggest. 

I think it suffers from too little interaction between players. The only thing players can do to each other is use an action first, but that still usually doesn't effect another player in any serious way. I strongly believe there needs to be some system of player trading, or auctioning, or some other form of interaction between the folks you're playing against.

Even in a 5 player game, it often feels like the players are competing against the scorecard and not the other people sitting around the table.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolutely fantastic. Keep coming back for more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
PRO - Easy to pick up after the first game.  For a Euro, the theme works very well.  Each action you take really does seem to contribute to the success of your farmstead.  The game is engaging, approachable, and fun to play.  Play time is good too.

CON - Only fault I find is the amount of cards dealt to each player at the start of the game (14) is a bit much.  There's a little too much to mull over when combined with the other choices presented by the board, the pressure of feeding your family each harvest and the limited set of rounds.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my wife's favorite games, but it's a bit too long for my tastes. The game is based off of three mechanics:
1. Worker placement
2. Resource gathering
3. Building/upgrading

There are other worker placement games I'd rather play, and better resource gathering games as well. However Agricola does the building/upgrading well.

In all, I probably wouldn't turn down a game, but the set up time and the long play time means it doesn't hit the table very often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Agricola is a game we play often, each time with a different outcome.

Basically you play a farmer. You start of with a couple of acres of land and a house. You job is to use your land to provide for your family and in the meanwhile both expand your family and house.

The luck factor does play a (small) role with this game. In the beginning of the game you're dealt cards at random. Your strategy will have to be based upon these cards. In my opinion this feature is what keeps the game 'fresh'. Every game is different.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I love the struggle to feed people at the end of the round.
Either with cubes or ani/veggy meeples, this game is one of the best.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
just some comments about usual complainments:

1) 'Agricola is multiplayer solitaire': yes the interaction-factor is not very high in this game. You can compare it with caylus - the whole interaction is in blocking the actions you use for others. But that is important you always should watch your opponents what they will do next and make sure you are startplayer in the right moment... (also there are some cards which give you some kind of interaction).

2) 'Agricola is to luckdriven, if you get the wrong cards you have no chance': yes there are cards which are stronger than others, and there are combos of cards which are extremley powerful. BUT: each card costs you an action ressources, the time you need to get out your three-card-combo I can use to get important ressources or build up my hut and get another child. I think in most cases it balances out well. If you don't believe in it you can decrease the luck by either the official variant (you can always discard 3 handcards to draw 1 new card) or some selfmade variant (instead of 7 cards you get 10 cards but you have to discard 3 of them before game starts)

3) 'You are played by your cards': yes your cards give you a direction where to go - but usual you still have at least 2 strategies which you can improve with cards. Also it is not everytime clear which is the best move in any situation - the cards give you some hints for the strategy but you still have to choose all the tactics.

4) 'Agricola is hyped': So what! It IS a good game and it would in no way different if no one had mentioned it anywhere - but now you have the chance to recognize it so give it a try!

If you love Caylus you must try Agricola - if you neither love nor hate Caylus still give agricola a chance - if you hate Caylus you should avoid agricola. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun, but overly complex and fiddly.

RATING: 6.25
2016
====

In an attempt to "retrograde" my collection I traded away Agricola. As a result I haven't played it for quite some time and have attempted to try other worker-placement games in the intervening time to see if I could find something that I liked better. I did not. Agricola is strong and tough to beat and one of these days I'll grab it again and enjoy it all over again (as I've likely forgotten the cards we've played).

[2014.10.10]
I could play this game many dozens of times and probably never see the same set of cards.  Of all of the thematic games I've played this is probably the closest to a lifetime game.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It takes too long to play, and there's not enough player interaction, but Uwe Rosenberg has created such a nice farming aesthetic in this game that it wins me over.  The occupation and minor improvement cards really add a lot of diversity to the game.  There is always one card that will dramatically alter your strategy, but the game is just perfectly timed so that you will never fully realize that strategy.  About the time your strategy is kicking in, the game ends.  This is a little frustrating, but on the other hand, I sort of like that the game is brutal in this way.  There's also so little player interaction that you can chat with other players when it's not your turn, get up to get a cup of coffee, watch TV, or any other sort of thing.  This gives the game a relaxed feeling; you want to set aside a Sunday afternoon for this one and just take it slow and enjoy it.  The other wonderful thing about this game is that there is a solitaire version, a 2 player version, and a multi-player version so it's like 3 games in one!  It probably does not deserve to be the #1 game on geek, but it's a good game, and certainly fun to play!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: N/A
I have only played it once, and I don't think I am familiar enough with the game to give it a rating.

I've actually enjoyed it. There is of course not much interaction and I felt that the game does not really allow too much creativity for the players. But I was still really engaged in it. Only after finishing it did I question, why it sucked me in. Then I've realized that for me this game was the board game equivalent of online farming games. It's super addictive, and it's actually enjoyable to watch your little empire grow, but in the end there is nothing cool about it. Also, the social part felt as if I were at a party where everyone is only playing with their phones.

This is just a very subjective opinion of a newcomer, but at this point I am not really motivated to ever play again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
The worker placement works fairly well early, limiting resources with players fighting and choking each other, but the pace of the game eventually overloads the board with spaces, resulting in that supposedly key blocking becoming impossible.

The way the game incentivizes collecting some of everything results in a samey experience each play. Hands of cards theoretically change the game, but their random nature results in sets that are sometimes synergistic and sometimes not which makes the game seem to favor players with good draws. Drafting or discarding can only help so much when the cards are so unbalanced.

(6 Plays)
First Impressions: 2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A very entertaining game, and fun for everyone who is introduced to it.  This game gets a ten because it is so versatile.  The family version is a great way to introduce new serious players to the game and also is great for literally just playing with the family, non-gamers who will find the animeeples cute but would not normally play a modern board game.

The full version however is where this game really shines!  The occupations and minor improvements ensure that no two plays are exactly the same.  This leads to a great deal of variability, but back to the versatility argument this game works great with one player and scales exceptionally well all the way up to five players.  I'd have to say that Agricola is my favorite solo game, and my favorite two player game.  Hence the high rating.

RATING: 8
No bandwagon - It's just one of the best in my collection. I waited until I played 9 games before rating it. I intended to wait until I played 10, but after the 9th I was positive. 

However, after 28 plays I have downgraded it a bit. I keep it as a 9 only because I know it is a good game, but  the cards ruin it for me (obviously, not for others). So, when I do play (not so often now) I play without the cards.

[The following is what I wrote after 9 plays: "Still think it is a good game, but not nearly as good as I thought it was when I wrote the below:
As for bandwagons, I was not taken with Puerto Rico or Caylus. I bought them both, couldn't wait to play after all the hype. Was sure they would be among my all-time favorites. While I recognize both as excellent games, deserving of top status, neither kept me fascinated past 3-4 games. At that point I lost interest in both. But Agricola is different. I am even MORE fascinated with it after the 9th playing than I was after the 1st, or 5th, or 8th. It has grown on me with each playing - and I have not begun to tap the depths of it due to the built in "expansions" that come with the game.. Solitaire, a Base game (family), expansions, and playable up to 5 people."]

RATING: 9
Fantastic game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Starting with Le Havre first, I really enjoy the game system that Rosenberg has developed.  Agricola is Uwe's classic game that feels very much like his signature design (i.e., collecting resources, using them to purchase abilities, feeding phases, harvests, etc.) The theme in Agric is more integrated to the mechanics than Le Havre. Le Havre, however, is still less to keep track of and a more fluid game experience. Regardless, Agric is a game that offers something different from Le Havre, and the balance and theme and sheer replayability keeps this one in high regard.  A seriously brilliant game that deserves its high praise. It has everything I love about Le Havre, but a stronger theme-to-mechanic integration and richer game immersion.  Solo has a very fluid feel to it - much more so than a 4-player games which feels tight and panicky!  However, I really enjoy both experiences for what they bring to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very funny game with topnotch longevity and scalability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The learning curve is steep. So steep. Takes a long time, ~2-3 hours with 4 players. The scoring system feels incredibly arbitrary.

Having played this 50+ times on iOS, I like it a lot more. The scoring system is still terrible though - play Caverna instead! Same awesome farm building mechanic, much better scoring system.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I'm enjoying Uwe's style of games less as time goes on, especially as his designs have become more expansive and less tight. Agricola represents the best of his design philosophy for my tastes. Taking an action is denying your opponent and, unlike many euros, there is unlikely to be a suitable substitute on the board. Though not a direct layer of interaction, this aspect still creates a tense experience where your opponents moves feel impactful. I will never trade in that feeling for the more open experience.

Tight, tense and fun, struggling to feed your family has never been so good. Still one of the greats.

RATING: 9
This deserves its high position in the rankings.  There are so many different directions that you can take your family, independent of the fact that, like everyone else, you're trying to ensure that everyone in your family gets fed and that you utilize every space in your farm.  One thing to always remember is that you need multiple strategies, especially as the number of players increases.  Much of the time you won't get the action you were most counting on, so you need to have Plans Two, Three, and sometimes Four in mind.  Make sure you know all the food-acquiring vectors; you have more options than just cooking, baking bread, and picking food up from actions on the board.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For me, Agricola is the definition of a Euro game. It is all about worker placement, efficiency and passive-aggressive player interaction. I like some of the game components like the animals, but I regret the family members, resource and vegs are just wooden discs - I would have liked meeples and smaller ones for babies. I am not a fan of the veg and resource tokens available outside the game, they are just not as cute as the animals.
Also, I regret that the only player interaction is by blocking access to resources. It is almost like you wished the other player wasn't there. I think there is a missed opportunity for negotiation or any elegant player interaction, like group investments, synergies between players'actions (i.e. Terra Mystica), etc
I really like that the game feels tense and I always get that impression that I could break the game and stay on top of things. But I always end up not being able to do all I wanted to do.
The game feels different each time thanks to the occupation and minor improvement cards. It is also very simple to teach and play but hard to master. But because chance barely plays a role, expect experienced players to beat newbies.
Certainly one of the games my wife and I play the most.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is just a great game. You truly feel like you are building a farm in medieval times. While the cards add lots of replayability and variety, I think that the family game holds its own.

DCCL :
A worker placement game with an agricultural theme. Players have to maintain a farm and feed their family. Different settings for 1,3,4 or 5 players is brilliant. Agricola totally deserves its ranking and in my opinion is simply the best game ever made.

RATING: 8
Great complexity and depth of play. Lots of decision points where you have to evaluate what you need tactically (immediately) and what you want strategically, as well as evaluating your opponents to attempt to determine what they need/want as well. 

Its theme is surprisingly appealing; I've seen even non-strategy-gamers enjoy playing (she ran an organic farm to reflect her vegetarian sensibilities). However in general, the length and complexity are a barrier to getting people to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My main complaint about the game is that all farms tend to look like each other.  Everyone has to get veggies, sheep, pigs, cows, and expand their house / family growth; the penalty for not doing so is too much.  Of course, this competing for the same resources and the worker placement mechanism is what drives the game.  That said, it's still a good game.

Also, as a solitaire gamer, I do like that it comes with a solitaire game in the same box.  The solitaire game is more of an optimization problem (compared to the regular game, which has a strongly antagonistic environment), so it is a different game.

RATING: 6
Sweet mother of God...there are a lot of options each round, and it only gets more and more complicated.  Much tougher to learn and play than Puerto Rico (making the comparison because both are highly ranked).  

Much better the second time around without using ALL of the cards.  

Good as a two-player game.  Better with more, but even with only two, choices are still tough but in a different way.  With more players, it's a question of, "What should I choose based on what others need too?", but with just two players, it's, "What should I choose even though there are so many things I need to do?"  Having less competition for choices doesn't make the game easier.

Sold my copy, as I much prefer Loyang.  I'm definitely in the minority there!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It lives up to the hype.  Lots of tough decisions to make, and a goodly amount of player interaction due to the worker placement mechanism. The random draw of Occupation and Minor Improvement cards will lead to a lot of replay value, as a player's strategies must shift to take full advantage of the set of cards available in each game.

Agricola shares a lot of mechanics with Caylus, but it offers an element of *fun* that Caylus seems to lack.  At this point I'm not sure whether that's a result of the lighthearted theme, or whether it is something else entirely.  I suspect that experienced players will run through a game of Agricola faster than a game of Caylus, which neatly addresses one of the biggest issues I have with the latter.

The five player game is incredibly resource-tight; I prefer four players or fewer.

The "family game" variant (no cards) is a bit boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Still enjoy after all this time.

RATING: 8.8

I have also felt like I was telling a story at times so there is, for me a sense of narative. 

Sure the cards add luck, I don't mind.  Often they are distracting, It adds to the replayability and narative.

RATING: 2
Played once, lacking a few turns to completion.  If complexity = depth then 'gricola's myriad of cards deliver a challenging, almost daunting game experience.  I would play again but have no desire to own it.  For me, Puerto Rico is still the gold standard of the Euros.  

After a 2nd, complete play in a five-player I've decided that I would rather watch paint dry.  The theme doesn't do anything for me, and while it is a game that has garnered huge support, I have no desire to invest the time necessary to play this game competitively.  It is too long for what it is. This is in the NO FUN ZONE for me.

Played this game a third (and final!) time.  I don't hate any game--hatred should never be wasted on something as ultimately insignificant as a game.  However, if I was capable of hating a game...

I picked up a copy cheap at a thrift store.  I traded it for a copy of Automobile.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First solo and 2 player plays last night.  I have to say, this is likely to become one of mine and my wife's all time favorites.  Having never played it before, learning it from scratch from the manual was a bit of a challenge, but once I had it down, teaching it to my wife was easy.  I think others will pick up on it quickly too.  Has to get a 10.

Update: 2/20/2012
With 5 games finished, I can confirm it as a 10. I think it accomplishes what it sets out to do which is to give the feel of actually being a farmer hundreds of years ago.  I doubt this would be a good "first euro" game for someone, but after they get some of the gateway games under their belts, this will likely become a favorite.  

Also, need to note that we've aslo put in 5 more games with Farmers of the Moor expansion and I think that's totally the way to go.  FotM takes a 10 and makes it an 11.  Get it.

Update: 8/14/2012
20+ games (with FotM) and still it's a 10--my favorite among 30 or so Euro games I've played.

Update: 1/26/2015
Close to 40 games (not all games are recorded here--didn't start recording until much later).  Never disappoints.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Only one play, but that's enough to convince me there's substance behind the hype. 

Update: Bumped up rating a half point. Even more enamored after a couple more plays. Delicious, farm-fresh turn angst with death constantly at your doorstep. The hardship of living paycheck to paycheck transformed into tense, harrowing, gaming fun.

Update: Not quite as enamored as I once was. Lowered half a point.

Update: Now the randomness of initial card draws is starting to bother me. If this played out as quickly as a straight card game, such variance wouldn't be an issue. But at 2-3 hours for a single hand of cards with four players, it can be vexing. Also vexing is the seating order dependence. Yes, one can always choose Start Player. But one cannot choose a motivated right-hand player who will occasionally choose Start Player. Or choose a left-hand player who is not hell bent on choosing Start Player at every opportunity.

Update: The tedious, plodding pace of this game makes me more and more reluctant to sit down and play it. In fact, this is another 2- or 3-player only game for me.

I can't imagine wanting to play this ever again. Perhaps decades from now, when nostalgia exceeds aversion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game - difficult to learn with the interacting paths to victory points, and the necessity of getting your food engine running.  Huge replayability with all the cards - overwhelming at first.  Most impressive, and the attention to detail in theming the cards is superb.  And the solo series works really well.

The more I play the better it gets - rating moved to 9. Not sure about 5p - bit slow and seemingly random interaction makes it difficult to plan.  More plays may address this.  3 or 4p my current sweet spot.  But plays well 2p, and solo works fine. playing a lot - but the way that option close down still irritates me a little - I prefer the opening up of Le Havre to the frustrations and tightness of the standard Agricola last 3 turns
