RATING: 3
I have an oven, and you have an oven, but you are on the Bake Bread "space", and that somehow prevents me from baking with MY oven?!

I so very much wanted to like this game.  Farming theme?  Terrific!  Limited resources?  Great!  But illogical constraints on when I can use those resources ruins it.

Also, the scoring is such that there are not really different strategies to pursue.  You need to be decent in almost every aspect and great in a couple. Specialization is not an option.

With some tweaks, I'd probably enjoy it, but I'll just play its superior sibling, Le Havre, instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent euro efficiency puzzle game - worker placement/action selection, get resouces, and build an engine and make it more efficient, in order to convert resources to VP - while trying to keep your family members fed. Great game.

Components are very good quality and there are some very good enhanced meeple sets (farmers, sheep, cows and vegies) that add colour.
  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Rated well for a reason, thus far this is the king of its particular worker placement genre.  It provides a big enough decision space without just overwhelming you with 10,000 options.  Requires some creativity to maximize the hand you have.  Still doesn't make me want to rush out and buy a whole bunch of other worker placement games.

But man, the turn to turn upkeep in this game annoys me.  It's excrutiating and makes you want to just play the iOS version.  Fields of Arle does it better in this respect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Not a game for everybody and yes the buzz has been deafening at times (along with the anti-buzz buzz).  Just the same, this is a solid games that has nice variety to it with the sheer amount of cards.  It's a balancing act to play this game well and you have to keep on your toes in regards to feeding your family while at the same time expanding and making improvements to your farm.  The theme isn't exciting for many since it lacks trolls, but I am perfectly ok with it.

I really groove on having to manage your cards for each game so I really see no point to the family version unless you really are playing with non-gamers.  The cards add variety and room for good play.

Animeeples rock and I am forever better than anyone who doesn't own them and only the original animeeples count towards one's coolness factor.  :)

I don't like the whole "farm" theme...but I like this game.

RATING: 5.5

However, such a rich idea is ruined (partially) by the cards, which are different for each player and randomly dealt, thus ruining the illusion of absolute balance (which I treasure in Euro games, otherwise I rather play my beloved AT) and most importantly forcing or influencing your strategy. 
Still a fun game, just not the absolute wonder it could have been (provided it was also themed decently).

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]Agricola[/b] [i]Uwe Rosemberg 2007[/i] 
Agricola includes more than 300 cards in its box and has a superb expansion ("Farmers of the Moore") that improves the core game turning it into an excellent gamers game. Using FIMO bits the game looks really beautiful on the table and reachable for non gamers when playing the family version. The game mechanics are also great and its scalability is excellent from one to five players. Agricola basic game is not the most replayable game in the market in terms of winning paths, but its expansion solves this problem adding many new ways to the victory as well as new problems to solve in order to build a nice (and winning) farm. The expansion is excellent and improves its rating from an eight to a very deserved nine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Such a heavy thinking game.  Brilliant.  Plays great solo.

RATING: 10
One of the best of Uwe! Great game!

Some say: 'this game is to hard... You don't have enough time, and it is over when it really starts to pop up'..
But hey, if you don't like that 'Making from noting a small farm' then go play Ora et Labora...
That one is huge! And takes way more time... 
The soul of this game is that feeling that every worker, every single sheep, every action counts..
You can't make a single mistake... And the smallest thing can depend if your going to win or lose..
And we love that!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
It's a very well made game and I can really see why people love it so much, but it's not for me. I would even say that it's aged surprisingly well, it was very innovative for its time, I just don't have that much fun when I'm playing it. The game is basically 16 rounds of doing incremental things that don't feel very rewarding. I guess it's thematically appropriate, but I don't enjoy barely scraping enough food together every round to keep my family from starving. In most games like this you can look down at what you've created after the game is finished and feel a sense of accomplishment. When I looked down after my 1 play of this I saw empty fields and pastures and a cow standing in my living room, pooping on my fancy stove. Sure, I had my very own outhouse and a clay deposit, but I didn't feel accomplished.

I also don't like the cards. I don't like that you're just handed 13 cards from decks of 100+ cards each and simply told to work with what you've got. You have no control over it and it means that certain players will have an advantage. Sure, it's not that bad if your cards don't have synergy because the game punishes you if you don't do EVERYTHING, but it's less fun to build a wide and shallow engine and some cards are just better than others.

I like the worker placement spots. I like that they come out in a slightly different order every game (though it can be frustrating) and that resources stay on some cards, incentivizing unused spots. I also like the balance that more family members give you more actions, but also need to be fed (though it's handled better in more modern games such as Tzolk'in, this was the game to invent the mechanism) but I don't like how they give you a LOT of points so you always want to grow your family even if you're struggling for food, it's always worth it. I like the interaction and how much competition there is for a lot of the spots on the board, it's rare to me that the first player market moves almost every round but it does so in this game. 

In summary, it's a great game but this rating is subjective and I would simply rather play other worker placement games most of the time.

RATING: 9
I like this game a lot, but what keeps me from loving it is how hard it seems for people to want to play it.  Of course this is going to get compared to Le Havre, which I love as well.  I struggle with this game a little because I've found it hard to find a crowd to play it.  Perhaps this would be different if I had other people that loved to play a 2 hour game where you feel like you are constantly behind the 8-ball, but it seems like a harder sell, and a little intimidating for my group most of the time.

I've enjoyed it every time I've played, but I really think it's a game you need to play a few times before you like it, and that can be a hard investment for a lot of people.

Still, I think it is flawless in terms of mechanics and execution.  I don't mind the struggle at all, and what most people seem to not like about it - the feeling that the game is beating you up, is actually a positive for me.  I like that it is hard, which this game definitely is.

RATING: 8
After several plays, this game quickly became one of our favorites.  My wife and I love the theme, the mechanics, the strategy, the depth, the variety, the replayability.  Excellent excellent game.  

UPDATE: We have played almost 20 games so far. At times it is a struggle and we end the game frustrated and exhausted.  Life on the farm ain't kinda laid back.  At other times it feels like everything is working well.  We're experimenting with the other decks now and trying to figure out the right balance between food engines and pacing family growth / renovations, etc.  There's never enough wood!

UPDATE: Most of the time my wife and I decide we're going to play nice in this game... so instead of taking a worker placement just to screw our opponent, we focus on doing the best we can in the game, against the game itself.  There's a little less negative energy at play because we actively help each other figure out a difficult plan and setup the correct timing.  We don't play 100% open handed, but we also don't go out of our way to screw each other over just to prevent the other person from gaining points.  We hadn't played this game in several months and just recently got it out.  

The first play after such a long hiatus was painful.  We wondered why we ever liked this game in the first place.  "But we've played it 20 times!  No one plays a game 20 times if they didn't enjoy it."  So we scaled it back to just the E and I decks and the 2nd play was better.  3rd play even better and after 4 plays we're back into the swing of things and have added E+I+K decks together for the first time.  

After a few more plays, I'll add FotM in and we'll be givin' 'er all she's got, Captain!

Highest 2P Score so far: 54 (I think... I may have broken 60 at one point but I threw out the score cards)

UPDATE: The threat of starvation in Agricola is a source of stress for us, and the game ends right when we finally get the puzzle solved so we never really get to see our engine running smoothly, which robs us of a little satisfaction.  I'd like to try Caverna before buying to see if the lack of card variety is a dealbreaker despite the removal of the starvation threat.  Rahdo thinks Glass Road is better than this, and it plays faster, so we're going to give that a shot first.

UPDATE: We gave it one last shot, but it gives us agita from the very beginning to the very end.  It feels like work.  Farmers of the Moor didn't fix it for us.  So I'm putting it up for sale.  She had a good run.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I used to rate this game higher, but now I find myself agreeing to teach it without wanting to stay at the table to play . . .

There is a lot of complexity, and it's all front-loaded. (If you don't teach the complete rules before starting, then players learning as they go are strongly disadvantaged) However, the game is complex enough that it is best taught in a "play-as-you-teach" method, but so long you can't really play a learning game as a prelude to a competitive one. I wouldn't call the game easy to master, but getting very good at it is not THAT much harder than just learning to play. 

I don't put a lot of weight on theme, but do find it ironic that the most important technique to master is producing just enough food to feed your family (not wasting effort producing excess of a commodity you don't score points for). Farms exist to export food, so the theme works against the mechanics instead of making a game more accessible.

After several plays and teaching several games I haven't played in, I still haven't seen a balanced deal from the occupation decks. Some combinations are extremely powerful, while a few cards are so weak they are effectively null cards (only worth playing if there aren't any other actions available). I don't mind randomness per-se, although I dislike the outcome of long, meaty games depending on a small number of important random events - in this case the initial deal. This problem affects the E, I, and K decks, but is worst when decks are mixed and amplified by the Z deck (found only in the Z-man games edition). Dealing 10+ cards and discarding down to seven mitigates the problem a little bit, but also increases the play time.

There is also far too much advantage to early players in the first round. The first player starts with one less food, but the people who really get hit are players four and five who have few options, especially for their second action, and they don't get any more food than player 2. Starting resources really need to scale for each player around the table, and one food may not be enough of a penalty for the first player. The first player mechanic in Agricola also introduces a substantial seating order dependence -- sitting to the right of a person fixated on being first or the left of someone who doesn't recognize its importance is a significant disadvantage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Man, I like this game (I'm a sucker for a farming game) but it is quite hard! Not a bad thing but won't be able to really judge it until it clicks. I would have to say that it feels stressful and like you have to hyper focus (some might classify that as 'feels like work') which I enjoy to most extents, but it's maybe too long for that much high-level stress. In particular, I found it hard in both plays to get my extra workers out (expanding the house) and have to work on this so I can actually have the game click before I say for sure if I like it or not. 

Edit: the more I play other gruel-fest games, I've been growing colder on this. Doesn't do well in comparison to A Feast For Odin for pure worker placement coolness, Trickerion for the competitiveness, or something like Age of Steam for crunchiness.

The stress of feeding in this game is a double edge sword where I really like the tension but feel like it's such a big focus that I can't enjoy the rest of the game's options.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best strategic games I have ever played. Like chess with theme, however unlike chess, this game has some slightly different starting positions (cards) and you have to think out your strategy each game, not just play in patterns at the beginning (like in chess). Theme is well involved in this game. This game is not only strategically deep, but also very thematic.

Pros:
+ Interesting and realistic theme,
+ Game is strategic, mentally challenging with very low random chance (minor improvement and occupation cards are dealt randomly),
+ Game mechanics works very well and they are well balanced,
+ Every move and every decision made in game just makes sense - they're all meaningful,
+ Aesthetics are very good, cards and board looks great.

Cons:
- 3-player game is probably too short in resources - very hard to get those, don't know about 5 player game.

P.S.
My solo game record is 61 points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yes, yes, YES!  The sadists weep because the masochists have all gone off to play Agricola, and who can blame them - being punched in the face never felt so good.  Simply freaking exhilarating.  You will know that your own special moment in history has arrived the first time you feed your family clay for dinner, because your Farm-Fu is so powerful.  Agricola is the bee's knees and the D's Bs (or perhaps the Wildschwein's Bs?).

Why does Agricola excite me while outwardly similar games like Caylus, The Pillars of the Earth and Leonardo da Vinci do not?  Two reasons.  First and most importantly, Agricola has drama. It hurls you into a burning house and locks the doors from the outside. You're doomed, but the prettiest corpse wins. There is simply not enough time to do what you need to do, so you merely do what you can. Through its sheer brutality, it creates the tension and urgency that I didn't find in other games from its genre. Agricola makes me feel like I'm walking a knife's edge, and what might be a small tactical decision in other games could lead to ruin here. How thematically appropriate, as well!

Secondly, Agricola manages to create a different game experience every time you play, on a level far beyond almost any other so-called Euro. Every game offers a unique set of challenges and opportunities because of your hand of 14 cards, chosen from a set of hundreds. The designer Uwe Rosenberg has taken a page from the Anglo-American school of game design here, adopting the variety, chaos, and rule-breaking powers of games like Cosmic Encounter and Magic: The Gathering. It's a welcome breath of fresh air in a German game market that has been growing a little stale in recent years.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have mostly played solo campaigns and really enjoy them. I need to play it more with a group and I suspect I will increase my rating then.

RATING: 10
Gifted from Myrriah and Jared on 9/26/08.

Upgraded to a 10 after 3 plays. It's as much fun as El Grande, which used to be my only other 10. For a long time, my family and friends all wanted to play this just as much as I did, so we played nearly every night. I think it's a combination of wanting to win, wanting to beat your personal best score, and wanting to find new ways to combine the cards that keeps us coming back for more. The basic person-placement mechanic reminds me of master builder placement in Pillars of the Earth. And you can never have too much wood.

K-Rated: 10

Keeper.

I still prefer the sandbox feel of those two games, but Agricola has grown on me. As expected, with more familiarity the stress level has dropped. RATING: 7
I don’t think Agricola is very innovative, but is more a feat of good craftsmanship. The mechanics have been seen in other games before and it doesn’t do anything flashy. But the game itself is good and there are many interesting decisions of whether you should go for a big stack or do what you really need to do in time. The game unfolds and strategies and options become clearer as you play. The game plays best with four players, but I also enjoy it with three or five. I prefer to draft occupations and minor improvements.

RATING: 8
Ten plays, five times with three, thrice with four and twice with five.

I enjoy the well-implemented theme of this one; I get a kick out of growing my crops and seeing my livestock multiply. The mental exercise of planning for the future and competing for resources is also very engaging. Overall, I think it's an excellent design. The only caveat is that I liked the game better with three than with four; the four-player game can be a lot rougher and if any of the players suffer from analysis paralysis it can bog down pretty badly.

It's also perhaps a hair too involved for my taste.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Own it and love it, nice to play for 1-5 people
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Holy smokes, this is an amazingly good game. Wonderful information displays, plenty of choices, layered gameplay, outstanding theming, and enough options to ensure lots of replayability (it's like a game and two expansions right out of the box). Interaction is indirect but this isn't a competitive game so much as a shared journey where you get a real sense of satisfaction when you can finally feed your family and set a little aside for the next year (this tipping point is the same kind of "high five" moment as when your railroad is finally in the black in Age of Steam). Maybe I'm caught up in the rush of a new game (in which case my rating will decline), but right now I am inclined to think this is the finest Euro I have ever played. Brilliant game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.1
Once again a game where you put your workers to do things and get ressources.Rating after two games, one with basic cards used and one with the complex card deck. Rating may go up (but not much) with further plays that include even those interactive cards. Yes there are a lot cards. Other publishers would have offered them as an expansion but here you get them right in the original box. But why is it not a straight 8 or more for me: The progress is pretty slow. Once you know the game it's all about getting get a third worker as quick as possible and so on. The cards you get on your starting hand may get you lucky as they are useful and intelligent to combine or you get a set where only one card makes sense, bad luck as the cards are important. Even the rest of the game is luck independent this bothers me a little, because if all gamers are of equal skill, it's that starting hand that decides which one will be ahead.Yes there are infinite options. But you also have to set up a strategy, making a plan. Once you took that decisicion, you follow over many rounds your plan only interrupted by rare occasions where you react about what others did. Therefore the flow of the game is peaceful and slow. Strange enough those 14 rounds to play seem too short (to fulfill all your plans, but that's intended by the author to increase replayability, to try next time another strategy).You don't get bored during about three hours (five players) but also I wished there was more tension. The only tension is if you can use a certain action before another players uses it (and therefore blocks it for you). You don't care if your neighbour goes for wheat or for sheep (as long you don't have the same plan to grow your ranch). Furthermore I am not that fond of the ergonomy to the action selection boards. So all in all a good game for gamers that like complex games but one could also say that it is a slow progressing multiplayer solitaire. Another downer is "repeated plays"; I very soon got bored from the theme and low player interaction. Another Geek said: "The limited choices each turn lead to scripted play regardless of the variability of the cards."  and I agree. I don't like to be the executor of a strategy initially dealt by the cards in the beginning of the game. After 3 hrs I must say: too long for what it is or where's the game, the interesting decisions?

RATING: 9
The more I play Agricola the more I love it!  Usually after several plays of a game a player can begin to figure out a winning strategy that they can use over and over again to achieve victory.  I have played close to 50 rounds of Agricola and have yet to find my winning strategy.  One of the other things I love about this game is it ends too soon.  Almost every time I play I find myself wishing I had just one more turn.  Rather than being frustrating, this element keeps me wanting to play again.  I really enjoy this game and hope to pick up some of the expansions in the future.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Truly, a very good game. I believe it is overrated at 8.13 by 38,065 voters at the time I post this, perhaps because it is one of the first games for relatively new board gamers offers:

* deep strategy
* a façade of immense replayability using the occupations cards**
* minimal player-player conflict

For a certain type of gamer, this is heaven because it allows him or her to strategize his next move out of very tough choices but not be bored from game to game because it is too easily solvable AND it allows the player not to be harmed too easily by other players' choices. Yes, placement of a farmer in a location does preclude another player's placement there, but it's usually not profitable to harm another player's chances by spite-placement. The game is just too tight to be playing vengefully, so the incentives are there for everyone to basically play the best game they can.

** Yes, the occupations cards make the game probabilistically replayable beacuse there are so many combinations of cards available. But they do not change the game so drastically to make Agricola too different from game to game. It's almost a game that is replayable by insensible degrees.

Agricola is a great game but slightly overrated.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great complex game! The 5-player game is the toughest and the most interesting game.

Provisional rating after one play of the 'family game'. I can really see myself enjoying this with the added variants from the additional decks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Yeah, this is after one play, but I don't think that I'll be back. There's a little *too* much information and too many lines of pursuit that *must* be juggled for me to enjoy. I also didn't enjoy the pressure that the food mechanic brought to bear. I'm okay with being less efficient than another player, but the unforgiving nature of running short on food just didn't appeal to me. This opinion is a little surprising to me, but there it is.

UPDATE: I've played this a couple times and my opinion has improved quite a bit. It was helpful to start with the family version of the rules, which are about the same complexity as (say) Puerto Rico.

UPDATE: having been a beta tester on the iOS app, I had more exposure to this game. And, it's grown on me over time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fully expected to like this more, based on all the hype and high ratings.  With too many players, there just aren't interesting enough choices unless you're one of the first couple in the round.  That's not to say there aren't MANY choices, there are, just that after the 1st couple players, they are about the same level of mediocre.  I was not interested most of the time. 

You spend the first several rounds just trying to survive, not getting what you really wanted, and hoping for better next time.  Long term planning is difficult as you cannot always get what you want.  In these ways, Agricola is just like real life!  :P

 I give the game kudos for being relatively easy to learn.  I also like the scalable difficulty to make it a little more a "family" game also.  I thought the production value to price ratio was on the poor side, with flimsier cardboard than the price warranted, generic cubes and disks, bland art, etc.  This was a game that really needed packed in animal and resource tokens to give the dry theme more personality, especially considering the retail on this.    

I've mostly played larger games.  I am reserving final judgement for 2 player, which I hope to try soon.  I have a sneaky feeling the game might be a bit more interesting, and faster paced, as there should be a good decision to make each turn.  

I hope my rating can increase with 2 player or just with more experience, as the larger games have just seemed to drag and leave fewer interesting options.  I'll update ratings and comments after further exploration of the system.  For the record, I do NOT consider 6 a bad rating.  It fits my "feeling" about how much I want to open and play. 

Update:  Had time for a solo play, finally.  I wasn't expecting to care for it, but I actually did.  It plays differently....in a sort.  You can let supplies build up without competition, so you can long term plan better which felt more satisfying actually.  This lets you grab a large amount when you need it, and build the same turn.  Reducing the wood payout and increasing the food needs went well toward keeping some feeling of pressure on the single player (if you assume that's a good thing), that is otherwise lacking without resource competition from other players.

Still think I prefer Stone Age and Kingsburg + expansion.  Stone Age is a much nicer product with bits, art, and quality of boards.  Yet, it is priced at what definitely feels like a value.  I also like the gambling aspect of SA, where you're "workers" determine dice you roll, not guarantee results.  You can choose to hedge your bets by padding your workforce on a resource or take a risk on variety by scattering your workers.  There always seems to be at least a worthy choice every turn, something that seems to lack from multi-player Agricola.  Overall it just feels less clunky than Agricola, looks much better, and after finishing a game, I'm ready to play again.  I've never wanted to reload another round of Agri after a play, unfortunately.  

With Kingsburg+Exp you place your workers/dice which vary every season.  You still compete with others for placement.  However, even with "bad" rolls, everyone can get something, and more likely than not it is something useful.  I also like the tech tree building up of your town.  It's very similar to the Real Time strategy tech trees.  I never cared much for those type PC games, but this is one aspect of them I DID like.  It's nice to see it thoughtfully implemented into a board game.      
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like that every game is different because of the tremendous variability of the cards.  Each time you sit down, you need to look for combinations that make the most of what you're dealt.  That's why my favorite method of drafting is the Rulebook Variant, where you deal 7 cards and get started.  If I draft, I prefer to have a 10-choose-7 draft, so that I can see my entire hand of occs and minors and look for synergies.  Whenever I do a "take one and pass the rest", my goal is to take the most powerful card, not necessarily to look for hidden synergies.

Another very important skill in Agricola is learning when to play cards and when to ignore them.  Sometimes you won't have a great combination, so you have to adjust your play.  It's great fun when I get to the end of the game and realized that I've only played 2-3 cards out of my hand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
2008-01-24 - ok, so I rode the hype wave and pre-ordered from zman.  well, now I can say screw the hype, I've caught the bug.  got to play at atlanta game fest.  managed to net zero points my first game after picking up a bunch of begging cards as a result of first not understanding a rule, and second simply forgetting to do the bake action.  let my starving agricola family be a sign post for others...FEED YOUR FAMILY!

design influenced by CCGs and caylus/pillars of the earth type mechanics.  the huge number of cards, and multiple levels of difficulty in play (with the E, K, and I decks) really make this a flexible game that should have broad appeal.  Someone had to have playtested the shit out of this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
The idea of this game was fantastic, it sounded so cool.  After playing several games, the chinks in the armor began to appear.  

- Can't be relevant without being part of the wood rush.  - Luck of the cards can massively influence the game.  
- Forced diversity limits play options
- Seating order relative to players fighting for first player
- Luck of which phase card comes out at which time

I'll probably still play if someone wants me to, I'll probably never request this game.  Maybe if I had been into solo gaming this would have been more fun?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A rules-heavy point salad with no compelling player interaction and frequent power imbalance due to the initial card draw. Deal me out.

RATING: 7
After a series of solo plays I am starting to see the charm and the popularity of this game. Some of the thematic flaws grate on me in the multiplayer game (why can't two people bake bread in a turn? Why can't we both have kids? etc....

I understand it makes for a more tight game experience, but it often leads to sub-optimal moves that do not reflect the reality of the theme. So now I'm forced to view it as a puzzle and not a farming in the middle ages...which makes all the artwork superfluous. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Agricola now feels quite dated, and its mechanic show a simplicity which remind us that this was released in 2007! A whole 7-8 years ago. A similar title today, would be more complicated, with more option: just like Caverna.

I love: The simplicity of it, and the analysis paralysis that come with your decisions.

I don't mind: the bland art. It makes it easier to play with non-gamers, but for me, I 'd prefer some chrome.

I hate: The 300 occupation and minor improvement cards. There is such a thing as too much of a good thing. Yet, I have no choice in the round cards. Yes, they show up at different time, but they are always the same cards. Why not include 8 different cards for the first round? and 6 for the second... Yes, that means you have to make chicken cards, maybe a church card, but that would give it real replayability.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you play with deck drafting or even pre-built hands then this game is the best. There's really almost no chance and I love how it takes a very simple economic principle "scarcity of resources" and imputs it simply and beautifully into board game format. You all start absolutely equal (barring cards dealt, but drafting deals with most of that randomness) and really it's down to who does what with their resources. Everyone is given the same opportunity and there's no lucky rolls that are going to save you. My favourite type of game.

[EN] Great worker placement and resource management game that keeps you planning your actions several rounds ahead to feed your family and score enough points in the process. The occupation and minor improvement cards give the game huge replay value and, even when you lose, your finished farm feels rewarding enough. My two complaints: 1. Getting a much worse hand than your opponents will kill your chances to win before you even start 2. The game puts too much emphasis on feeding your family leaving little room for what you really want to do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When I first played this game I really hated it.  There were so many options in the game, but resources were too tight to do anything other then feed your family (and that was often out of reach).  I played two more times and my opinion did not change.  I had no desire to ever play again. 

A couple years later my wife saw some people playing at a game day and got curious about the game.  I told her my opinion of the game, but she was stilled intrigued enough she wanted to know more.  Then we heard Rahdo raving about it on some of his top ten lists.  Doubt began to grow, it sounded almost like a different game.  From some of Rahdo's comments I begin to think I was taught the game wrong.

So, when Agricola showed up at Barnes & Noble my wife and I talked about it for a bit and we decided to get it.  I felt a little crazy for buying a game I hated but there were two points that made me take the plunge.  First, by this point my wife was really excited to try it out.  Second, if she didn't like it and my opinion didn't change I could always trade it, a popular game like this will usually generate interest quickly.

I setup while she made dinner.  And we gave it a shot after eating.  I had no memory of the occupation cards, I can't say if they were used in my first games or not.  But I know we were refilling the action spaces wrong.  In my first games the action spaces were only ever filled to their number of goods instead of adding that many goods and accumulating over time.  That made a HUGE difference in how the game played.  It was still challenging to do everything you wanted to do, but it was not impossible.  With that one difference in play the challenge went from infuriating to intriguing. 

By the end of my wife and I's game, we were both hooked.  I am happy I gave this one a chance to redeem itself.  Agricola will be staying in the collection.  My rating rose from a 5 to a 7 after that one play.  With more plays it may rise still more.

Update:  Dropped the rating to a 6  in the wake of a string of more interesting games that scratch a similar itch.  This still has a place in my collection, but it is beginning to fade some.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Played for the first time last night. Wow, there is a LOT going on.I am rather concerned that with the wrong players this game could melt down into an analysis paralysis nightmare.FWIW I won the game comfortabley without really knowing what I was doing.I have now played twice and won both games comfortably despite one other member of the group (a very good board games player) having played a lot more games than me. Both times I was in third place on round 1 and he was in 4th. I fear there may be a seating order problem in the 4 player game at least.Still worth trying a few more times but I won the last game with a score of 56 to 40, 31 and 21. I knew I was going to win from about turn 9, it was just a case of by how much.

A few more plays under the belt now and it is still just an OK game. Yes there is a lot of variability fron the cards but to be honest it just doesn't grab me. The end game is something I particularly disslike, the game starts well, builds nicely then goes flat. Agricola isn't alone in having this trait, I might be unusual in dissliking it so much.

Of the top 10 games I own all but two. Twighlight Struggle which just doesn't appeal and Agricola which I feel no desire to waste my gaming cash on. I will play the odd game at conventions and clubs with other people's copies but I just don't get the excitement :(

I finally buckled and bought a copy. I think my copy has been played at most twice. Perhaps I should not have bothered with the purchase.

RATING: 7
This is very good, if this is the type of thing you like.  I need to play it a couple more times to really figure out how I feel about it.  There is no interaction other than buying stuff before others and a handful of other very minor mechanisms.  Other than that, it is an interesting and surprisingly easy to play efficiency engine game with a lot going on.  Fantastic game if you want a game where you don't interact at all.

I want to play it again to re-evaluate 

Updated, played again- still not totally sure if I like it.  It reminds me a little of through the ages in that I recognize there isn't nearly enough interaction, but I like it so much I think I could play it solo, so I don't care like I would with a lot of other games.  There is something very satisfying about building your food engine which delights me in much the same way through the ages does, only on a shorter, smaller scale.  Although I generally really hate games where the only interaction is competing for shared resources, I think I like economic engine building enough to overlook it. Now, if only Agricola had a war phase, I could rate it an 8!

RATING: 9.5

But the fact is, it's really FUN; in fact, half of the excitement is looking at your hand and seeing what options you'll have this game.  And Agricola delivers better than any other game that delicious tension of having so many things you WANT to do, and yet never quite enough actions to do them all.

RATING: 5
I actually got the same impression I had when playing Pillows Of The Earth... yes - it is for me no imporvement when you take nice mechanics of a reacently published game - i.e. Caylus - and add some also well known mechanics.

The art of a good design is not adding useless things, it is realizing what is useless and can be dropped.

All those cards here are for the fake of variety.

And yes, like some BGG-fellow already wrote - it was also something what felt odd to me while playing: why the heck can the neighbour hinder me in doing actions on my farm, because he does them on his too?
Didn't bother me that much at Caylus: you give an order to the jeweler so he is busy now. But here we give no external orders, we distribute tasks to our family members.

Anyways: The game is not bad. It was interesting to play. It looks cool. You can see that the designers cared about it (for example different images for rooms, actions, and so on) so there is a lot of work in it someone can easily see. But it is no milestone in gaming history (something what enayone might think when looking at all those 10s here).

RATING: 4
Perhaps the game that solidified my long-term interest in the hobby. Played weekly for months with the same group of guys, which gave me an appreciation of the system that I have with few other games. Still, I'm more or less burnt out on the game, and will consider bringing it out only on request.

I'm not convinced that the key to the game is to draw the right cards at the start, though I have seen one or two glaring exceptions in mixed-deck play. The cards themselves add some flavor, but the real game is in properly timing your actions and doing what is needed just before the other players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
While I felt a bit lost at first, the learning curve to at least understand the game is not really that bad. I was having a lot of fun by the end. Two things this game does better than any other game I have played. First is multiple paths to victory. There are so many ways to score points that you can focus on almost any of them or some hybridization of all of them. The end of the game leaves you feeling like you just didn't have enough time to score all the points you wanted to, so you will have some tough decisions to make as you realize how few actions you really get in each game. The second thing is being a game that is both very strategic and very tactical. You can almost break it down by the components: the cards in your opening hand are your cards for the whole game. They dictate your strategic options. Look over them and develop how you want to proceed. Then, the selection of actions adds a whole tactical level, in which you try to implement your strategy while getting in the way of what other people want to do as they get in your way. You have to adapt to this, as well as adapting to which actions come up in which order. We only played with the basic intro cards and I was dazzled by how many choices there were. This seems like a game that could never get stale, and seems to include expansions right in the box. It is a bit inaccessible to non-gamers though, and can take a bit long for what there is to do. I like games that have tons of options that you WANT to do but can't do them all more than games that have options you HAVE to do but can't do them all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I find it astonishing the number of people who have committed $70 to a game they've neither played nor seen played.  Hype machine is in overdrive.  I'm watching this one with a healthy dose of skepticism.

Update (9/3/08): Played for the first time tonight.  I like it, but I'm not sure how much.  My main concern is being able to keep track of the cards in front of your opponents.  "Oh, you get 4 food whenever you get wood and you have 3 sheep in a pasture with an enclosed stable?  I'll be sure to remember that..."  With the number of cards in the deck, it's also going to take a long time before you can even get a handle on what the other players *could* have.  I think I prefer games that have more clearly defined bounds.  

Update (9/8/08) - From 7 to 8 - Played twice more with 2-players.  So far so good.  My biggest concerns about the game - keeping track of your opponents' cards and being able to develop a game to game strategy - have been largely assuaged.  Rating could go up if the game holds up under repeated plays with more players.

Update (9/16/08) - The cards seem extremely unbalanced -- and that's just in the Basic deck.  With that in mind, I'm not sure I'll be able to give this more than an 8.  More specifically, any starting hand has a theoretical maximum score.  The maximum score for any two starting hands could be significantly different.

Update (9/18/08) - Played four more times (2-player) with drafting variant, still with just the E deck.  Improves the game tremendously.  I'm raising this to a '9'.  Can't wait to see how this plays regularly with more players.

Update (9/24/08) - Played 16 times now, 12 of them 2 player.  My major complaint now with the game is that it's stressful.  Even when things go relatively well, it doesn't feel like it's going well.

Update (12/2/08) - Probably played over 30 times now.  Lately the majority of them have been 5-player.  The game now frustrates me to the point I'm not sure it's "fun."  I think I'm worse now at the game than I was a couple months ago.  Ironically, I think I might like it better if it were more of a multi-player solitaire game than it actually is.  Downgrading to an '8'.

Update (1/1/09) - Back to a 9 based on playing it 2-player again.  My rating for the 2-player game is near a 10, and my rating for the 5-player game is dropping toward a 7.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
On first play, I liked it, but was dismayed at how much the starting hand of 7 occupations and 7 small improvements changed the rules.  It's true that without those 14 cards, the game would be less interesting, but with them, it becomes easy to get lost in the analysis of "Hey, card A would be great to play, but maybe I should play card B first, but then I need to take a bunch of other actions first to get resources to get card B, so maybe I should play card C to help me get those resources faster" and so on.  Since the choice of actions is competitive, you even have to recalculate your plans when another player takes the action that you were counting on.

After playing it again, I felt less overwhelmed.  I realized that you probably won't be able to play all your 7 occupations or 7 small improvements, so don't plan on it!  It's important to pick a strategy at the beginning and go for it, without wasting too much time planning to play cards that are just too difficult to get out (or are worth very little in terms of resources or points).

I recently played a variant that helps reduce the luck somewhat -- everybody draws 10 occupations and 10 small improvements to start with, and discards down to 7 each before the game starts.  With this variant, it's even more important to pick a strategy at the beginning, rather than assuming you'll get all your occupations and improvements out.  Keep in mind that in a 5-player game, for example, the "small improvement" action will be very popular if everybody has a great selection of improvements to start with...

I also played the "Family Game" once (in combination with Farmers of the Moor, to keep down the complexity).  Even without the randomness of the Occupations and Minor Improvements, it seemed fun, but it would probably get boring if played too often, especially with the same group of players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this game is addictive for a few reasons. (1) The goal of building a nice and complete farm is always just beyond reach. Your family must eat a certain amount at certain intervals. The availability of actions is restricted. These contraints make playing Agricola a slightly frustrating (but never quite futile) experience. (2) The extreme and almost excessive variety of cards makes each game unique. (3) The game is multiplayer solitaire that also feels like a race. The interaction with others is indirect, but you cannot help but pay attention to what others are doing to gauge your own progress, watch to see if they interfere with your plans or if you can interfere with their plans.

Add these three features together and the result is that after each game, you are left slightly unsatisfied, but you are also left with the distinct feeling that the next game will be different -- that a satisfying gaming experience will happen next time. And so on.

RATING: 9
Now that I played it, I can believe all the hype surrounding this game. I like the infinite replayability offered by the cards. I like the very hard choices to be made each round as to what action to choose. I like that it can REALLY be played solo.

What I would like to see is more interaction between the players. I think that adding the possibility to trade goods during the harvest would elevate this game even more. Maybe it would raise some issues. I'll think about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Agricola - the family game is a decent worker placement game distinguished by it's unusual theme and nice bits, but somehow marred by a scoring system that greatly reduces the possible winning strategies; I rate it a 8.
Too bad the scoring system needlessly limits the winning strategies and leads to building the same farm over and again.

However, with the cards, the game is difficult to rate
-no effort was made to relate the working of the cards with their name or illustration: for example, a forester can plant a forest... in a firstly tilled field; wood is then harvested at the same rate cereals are...  with a little thought, a more true to the theme mechanic could have been implemented
-there are very nice combos, very nice single cards, but many feel pretty useless
-these uneven cards make the game extremely lucky; some cards are game breaking
-too many cards feel the same

In summary, I would have liked a smaller deck of better designed cards; Agricola cards are more about quantity that quality, and feel under-designed.
If more thought had been given to the cards, this could have been the perfect game.

RATING: 5.5
Talk about limited actions and the desire to do more.  Not for the faint of heart as the game will usually be a solid 2-3 hours.  Not to be played with folks who suffer from Analysis-Paralysis!

In this one you need to find the right combos which will yield you the best results.  The cards passed at the start of the game ensure good replay value, but I found they limited your options.  Then again, it forces everyone to adopt different strategies.

Played twice with 5-players and did not enjoy the experience.  The initial card handout will provide some players with an advantage.  Game is probably best with 4, as it is too tight with 5.  Was unable to get my strategy going due to the options being very limited.  Game ended with the leaders essentially doubling three of the five players!  36-34-21-20-20.

Play with 4 and it was much better.  Raised my rating, and am looking forward to trying it again, with 4.

RATING: 6
What can I say about Agricola that hasn't already been said before? I think it has earned its rank because it is such a solid game that is also accessible, deeply replayable, as well as gorgeous and it works incredibly well across all of its player counts. 

-------
Edit: yet, at the same time, Agricola has become emblematic of many of the things that I am having a more difficult time swallowing about the game market: baked-in strategies, individual player boards, spatiality excised, and variability for the sake of variability. It's not that I don't want to play Agricola, but rather that I don't want every game I play (when going to meetups or other) to be a shadow of Agricola: at once a poor reflection of a masterpiece and yet another Euro game that moves away from family-accessible interactive games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is an excellent game – one of my all-time favorites (right up there with Race for the Galaxy)!  This game is very stimulating to the brain.  It is a game that starts off simple enough, but takes off in complication in just a few rounds.  I find myself somewhat talkative and laid back during the first few rounds, but after, oh, say, round 3 (there’s 14 rounds in total), I am starting to really focus on strategy (actually, re-adjusting my strategy due to what others have claimed) and keeping my family fed while trying to build up my estate and family.  I think it is perfect in that regard (starting off relatively simple, but becoming complex in just a few rounds).

My son very much enjoys it, but I would have to say that my wife just “likes” it.  I think it would be rare for her to suggest it, but she is always open to playing it whenever my son or I suggest playing it.  I discovered that the very thing I find very interesting regarding the game is the thing that is a turn off for her:  the constant re-adjusting of strategy.  There has yet to be a game where my initial strategy has not been thwarted by one of my loved ones.  “I think I’ll try building fences early this game and get some sheep early on….What?  You just took the wood for my fences?  Oh, so we’re playing that way, eh? J  Okay, it looks like I’m going to plow some fields instead.”  I love that things are constantly changing (and needing to change), but my wife finds it irritating (at times, at least).  I will say this, though:  It is a heavier game and definitely takes concentration throughout the game (meaning, socialization becomes less and less as the game goes on).  And it can become somewhat tense (again, I think in a good way, my wife – not so much) towards the later part of the game when you are desperately needing to find ways to feed your family, but having trouble doing so, as others are in the same boat.

The final thing I’ll mention is that the cards (and extra decks you can buy) make every game slightly different.  I do wish that the items that always exist on the board and the “round” cards that are always used could be changed, but I understand that would be difficult to do and still keep the integrity of the game intact.

Overall, I highly recommend this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In some ways, I should probably drop this score down to like a 6 because I never will likely play it again.  Or at least not for several more years.  In fact I think I did lower the score at one point, then put it back up high just because of how important this game was to my development in the hobby.

Ag is the only game I have ever pre-ordered without having played first.  It just sounded so delightful and there was a chance it would never make it to the US so I bought through Z-man's pre-Kickstarter crowdfunding.

We played it something like 60 times in the first couple months after receiving it, absolutely devouring the depths of strategy and reveling in the horrifying tension of feeding your family.  Eventually, when we had figured out the strategy sufficient, I grew weary of the tension and have shelved it for the forseeable future.  But goddamn was that a fun ride for several weeks!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[Initial Impression: 7]
Clearly a game with serious depth, and the strategic variations through card play will be innumerable. The game will clearly reward experience and knowledge of the card powers and how they can interact. This is all for the good and makes it a game I will definitely explore much, much further. However, the fact that you get a limited hand of occupations and minor improvements and have no way to modify that hand could prove overly limiting and possibly lead to certain players having a built-in advantage, which (if true) would be a major drawback in a game of this depth and length.

One thing that is very important is to not be seduced by your cards - it takes an action (and often resources) to build each one, and the benefits aren't always as nice as you might originally envision. In many games, the player with the least cards in front of them is the winner.

After several games, I just don't see why so many consider this the pinnacle of gaming. It seems a fairly typical resource management engine without any truly novel mechanisms, the course of play is fairly slow and routinized, the strategies are highly constrained (unless you get certain cards, like the Yeoman Farmer, that allow you to ignore the diversity imperative), and the initial card draw can occasionally determine the course of your game.  It's still decent, but the fact that there are many other resource management and/or worker placement games that I would consider to be far, far superior (e.g., Antiquity, Caylus, Le Havre) means that I don't expect to ever find myself requesting a game of Agricola. (I'd still play it, but only if the group can't be convinced to tackle one of the other titles instead.)

RATING: 9.3
Somehow i like the game mechanics, but i absolutely hate the feeling of the game. Ohh my boy look how beautiful pet we have, i hope you love him so much. But now after we loved him hard time comes and we must kill it to have something to eat... Another thing is that i feel like the game finishes too early i haven't got enough time to finish the things that i want to.
-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 
Because a lot of player suggested so after the revised edition came out i tought why not give it another chance. The bad feeling i have had before completely gone and i started to enjoy the game quite much. The revised edition has fewer cards but they put into the box the most balanced ones so it is a welcome upgrade of course. They reworked the art which becomes more beautiful however i didn't have a problem with the old one. Unfortunatelly the production quality of the game board dropped quite a bit and with the attaching thing can be damaged very easily. There are not enough resource tokens we ran out of wood and brick in numerous occasions. Because of this im thinking about getting the old version instead. I believe this game has a very high replay value because every game is different by what actions you proceed and what cards you are dealt in the start. It seems that there are numerous strategies to pursue which all capable of winning the game in the end. A little bit bigger player interaction would be nice though. I think this was an outstanding game when it came out but there are simply better games nowadays.

RATING: 9

This is a worker placement game that simulates running a farm, complete with sheep, boar, cows, vegetables, grain, fields, fences, stables, and a harvest in which you have to feed your family.  I have the English edition without animeeples.  After 30+ plays, I'm still really enjoying this game.  Each game is different due to the Occupations and Minor Improvements.

RATING: 10
12-27-09
After getting more plays in with other people, this game is terrific.  Fun to play every time, many different paths to victory with the cards and a good amount of subtle player interaction.  Each game can feel very different depending on what tasks you're doing and what occupations/improvements you're benefiting from.

It is absolutely one of my favorites.  The solo experience alone is worth a 10 playing in less than an hour and being a fun, engaging, lighter fare than the multiplayer counterpart.  The solo version plays in 45-60 minutes, and playing with players who are familiar with the game doesn't take too much longer than that.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best, most intense strategy games I've played.  Hard to grow your family and build your farm when you're scraping for food.

RATING: 7
Good euro in which, against all odds, has some theme.Except for the darn plow. You mean that, for many years, only one person was allowed to plow per turn? Did they only have one Hoe in the village or something?

I didn't like how the game deals with player order though: Instead of having a rotating player order, or one dictated by each player's actions, like Year of the Dragon or Power Grid. We get the absolute worst of both worlds: A player can pay to be first, and then it goes around. This makes sitting arrangements important, and that's not a good thing. 

In a game I played, the player on my left would ALWAYS try to get the first player token with his last action, even if the current arrangements had him go second. Of course the player to his left won handily.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The grand daddy of Uwe Rosenburg games. The turns are fast. The rulebook is thick but the gameplay is very fluid. The cards add asymmetry between players. Many possible strategies.  On the downside, you spend 3/4 of your actions making sure your family is well fed and just as your farm starts looking good, the game ends.  Fired by Caverna.

RATING: 8

I, on the other hand, think it's an interesting little adventure in resource allocation. It's a game about farming and trying to support your family through your agrerian lifestyle, but it's the mechanics, not the theme, that keep me coming back.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is fun to play. Every turn you try to do everything you need to until you realize that you really can't do everything. Then you have to make the agonizing decision what you wanna do. But I really like that. You just try to do your best and at the end you have your little farm in front of you. Sometimes it looks good with pastures full of animals and fields with grain and vegetables. Other times... well it looks not so good. But still I find the game fun.

Family version works fine and it's fun to play. Actually I was suprised how interesting the game was, because I had read that the cards really make the game and thought that the family game wouldn't be that interesting. When you add minor improvements and occupations there's more choises for you and you can try to build your strategy based on those cards. I only have one game under my belt with the cards so I can't say much more about them other that they definitely make the game little more complicated.

It's a 9 now, but lets see when I get more plays with the cards if this have what it takes to climb to 10.

Oh and this game is a pain to keep organized. You have tons of wooden pieces and the box doesn't have any insert so you have to bag them all in plastic bags. I definitely need to work out some easier way to keep those pieces organized.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I like this, I can see it's more replayable than stone age but I see a couple of differences.

1) it's more complicated and I found the gains to be minor

2) it seems difficult to play your cards and so it's over before you're really into it

Would play again though

---

Edit: no I wouldn't. I've come to really dislike Uwe Rosenburgs games generally the more I've played them. Loads of card options and combos and never enough time to complete them

I get that it's meant to be a struggle but not all games should feel this unfulfilling all the time

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played it for the first time at a meetup.  The cards make for a different game for each player everytime. Worker placement a la Stone Age and Leonard Da Vinci. Adding major improvements like buildings in Puerto Rico. Resource management/growth like the plantations in PR. Sheep. Wild Boars. Cattle. Vegetables? Worry about baking bread so your kids don't starve and end up begging. It feels like a race to make the best farm, but there's never enough time... Initial rating: '8'.

Update-After playing it ten times, and having played Dominion most recently, I'm starting to get annoyed at the fidgety nature of the game--there are so many little bits and pieces, compared to only so many cards in Dominion. Yes, they are different games, so they each have a different feel. With five players the game has dragged to four hours, especially since we haven't played it in awhile.

Update-After teaching this game several times, it has become apparent that this is a complex game, even though the mechanics are simple. I am upping the weight to 'medium heavy'. There are so many things going on, as the number of options and paths to victory are numerous. There is substantial luck in the draw of the seven occupation and seven minor improvement cards. You're dead if you don't get a good hand, but it is also total dependent on your skill getting the hand out IF you are so blessed to have a good hand, and know how to maximize their effects.

Update-After playing it my 14th time, our group grumbles whenever this is suggested. I am beginning to dislike this game. It seems one in my group (not me) has managed to win 8 out of 9 times, with scores in the 40+ each time. I think I'm hitting a trough here, as I find it frustrating with setup and tear-down, along with the feeling of dread that I won't be able to do much with the hand I'm dealt, the resignation that comes with realizing within the first hour that I have already screwed up, and that I have to suffer through 2.5-3 hrs of torture for that mistake. And what is it with this "bake bread" action? It takes too many actions to set this up, while someone with the Baker or Brewer card is pretty much destined to win. The game is not forgiving, and amplifies any mistakes one makes early in the game. This can be said of Puerto Rico and Power Grid, as they are near-perfect information games also, but most of my group still struggles to really 'understand' this game. Rating dropped from '8' to '7'.

Update-Game 15: Okay, I had the baker and the "plow 3x fields twice a game" cards, but still did poorly. So, it's not just the cards but how you play them.

Update (09/17/09): This game hasn't seen the light of day since January. I simply don't want to play this game anymore--I don't want to "tread water" for 2.5 hrs and get crushed by someone else who had better cards. There are better, faster, more fun games out there. The "herd" has moved onto Le Havre, which has turned me off as well, as it is more of the same, just with a different theme. I  think this game has reached its apex, and now we are waiting for the next fresh face to arrive. I'm downgrading this to a '6' from a '7'.

Update (08/28/10) 16 plays: Downgrading from '6' to '4', because you're going to have to do a LOT of talking to convince me to play this sado-masochistic's wet-dream come true game again. I played it again after 11 months, and still don't like the game. Now, I need a stiff drink to buzz away the feeling of mediocrity and shame I get after coming up with only 13 lousy points. Why subject myself to this kind of pain?

Update (09/14/12): Haven't played it in two years, although my copy gets an infrequent play with others in my gaming group. After trying Le Havre a number of times, I've come to the conclusion that I don't like the designs of Uwe Rosenberg. So, I avoid his latest incarnations, such as the Gates of Loyang and Ora et Labora, which are just another rehash of "collecting and turning it into something else". That doesn't mean I don't respect Agricola or any of his other designs, as they are important, significant events in the chronology of board gaming evolution. I simply no longer wish to be a part of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[i][size=10][b]"VVouldst thou like to live deliciously?"[/b][/size][/i]

[b]tl;dr[/b] — It's time to get excited about farming!  Farming.  And man, did we ever get excited.  This thing hit like dynamite fishing and then we fought a massive war over it.  And when I finally got to plowin' with my doughty farm-wife the earth gave up its dead because they only moved the headstones.  50+ face-to-face plays.

[imageid=276736 small]
UPDATE:  Well, there's massive shrinkage in Hell—I picked up a copy and I'm actually looking forward to playing it!

[b][thread=393626][/thread][/b]

UP-UPDATE:  I can totally see how people can rate this a 10.  It's charming and mildly haunting, and there are actually opportunities to dump a turd in the downstream player's punchbowl.  "Yeah, I didn't need that food.  I went fishing just to watch your kids starve."

Ultimately, though, this gets stuck in the dreaded 7 ghetto—good enough, but missing that special something.  And that something is a theme that isn't farming.

[b]After 17 plays:[/b]  I'm bumping this up to an 8.  My wife [i]loves[/i] it, and I find her enthusiasm for the game infectious.  With two relatively experienced players—and wine—the game flies by; the struggle and decision-making is a pleasant diversion, and the tiny model farm you wind up with at the end is nifty.

FINAL ANALYSIS:  All things being equal, the cards make or break the game.  Either you get a fistful of synergy that showers you with freebies or you sit and watch someone else play that game.  I suppose this could be mitigated with some kind of card draft or other time-consuming setup step, but really, the game isn't that deep or robust to support such shenanigans.  This sensitivity to the vagaries of luck keeps the game firmly wedged in the "whipped dessert" category—very tasty, but ultimately nothing more than sugar and air.

[b]After 27 plays:[/b]  Revising down to a 7.  Familiarity is bleeding this one out, especially after a brutal string of games with poor card draws.  Also, the tension in the 5p game is unpleasant, or, more correctly, is out of whack with the payoff for suffering it.  There are only so many times you can circle the drain of reductive choice where it's pastry, pie, cookie, crumb, bowl of poop before losing your mind and fantasizing about rolling some dice and kicking in the door of the guy who wasted the sow space for baking and using the axe you invented on his family.

"You got Ceramics?  I got Clogs, bitches!  CLOOOGS!!!"

So far the 2p game is my favorite—it's over quickly enough that a bad hand is tolerable.  Two or 3p is definitely the sweet spot for this.

[b]After 38 plays:[/b]  Revising down to a 6.  Not timeless, not a classic, and it's about farming.  [i]Farming![/i]

[b]After 50 plays:[/b]  Bumping it back up to a 7.  My wife really, [i]really[/i] loves it, and that softens my hard heart.  Besides, our last game was really weird—I didn't try my usual min-maxing by following the script that always nets 40+ points—I went after a wheat baron's seven-room stone mansion with constant barbeques.  Meanwhile, my wife deviated from her script as well, with the game ending up 24-21 in my favor.  I like weird.

Also have:

[thing=43018]Farmers of the Moor[/thing]

[thing=85704]Gamers' Deck[/thing]
[thing=83697]Legen*dairy Forest-Deck[/thing]

(Up-rezzed with [thing=138404]Animeeples[/thing] and [thing=138403]Vegimeeples[/thing].  Got the Go 7 Gaming "official" insert, which saves about a billion man-years on setup and takedown; this simultaneously nukes the dreaded "archeology of baggies" and makes it much more likely this'll get pulled off the shelf and played.) 

[microbadge=14795]

The ugly history lesson:

[q]Spurious rating of 1.11 placed during

[b]BGG.CON-JOB 'O7:  OPERATION AGRIKERFUFFLE[/b] aka [b]The Great (?) Agricola Hoax[/b] aka [b]The 'Cola Wars[/b]

During which an [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1863174#1863174]offhand comment[/url] and a [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/241295/page/1]little demagoguery[/url] set the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/241289]house on fire.[/url]

If you made it through all that, you won't want to miss the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/241647]After Action Report.[/url]  And [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/241870]here.[/url]  And [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/242219]here.[/url]  And don't miss the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/26293]GeekList.[/url]  And [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/26274]this one.[/url]  And hopefully the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/26422]last bit.[/url]  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1875007]Not.[/url]  The saga is [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/242980]complete.[/url]

Original comment:

[i]Finally, a solution to the 400-year-old problem of four-player farming...  This "game" gets a well-deserved 1 for being the epitome of Euroslack; as a good gaming buddy always says when Euros hit the table (with a wet plop, I might add):  "What am I in this one, a farmer?"  It pulls a 1.11 for only being available in Ancient Atlantean (that crazy mouth-stumbling they call a "language")—note to the designer:  I hope you make a bajillion dollars selling this to all those multitudes of Atlantis who are obviously going to be going game-nuts over it.  Sheesh.  [BGG CON III got [i]played[/i]][/i]

Final analysis:

[i]By all accounts this game is the Second Coming of [gameid=18602] With Three Testicles.*  The tidal wave of hype surrounding this should be more than enough to obliterate the actions of 17 rogue BGGers.  But I am intrigued by the fact that it only took 17 people (out of how many tens of thousands who traffic this site?) to rock the boat...[/i][/q]
[size=7]*Once upon a time, [i]Caylus[/i] was the savage hotness, the blazing terminus that divided gamers into two camps—the lofty intelligentsia who breathed the Language of God and shat meaningful decisions and the drooling idiots who would mold dice out of poop and gamble with their own teeth on the outcome.  In the decade between then and now (2005-2015) the turd-rollers won.  [i]They won.[/i][/size]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
At first I really disliked this game because the number of options can be overwhelming and the game makes me feel like I'm constantly struggling. As I've played it more the number of options and setup combinations is what I like most about Agricola. Each game feels unique and every decision is difficult. While the game is still stressful, it has gotten a LOT more fun over time.

RATING: 8
Rating after 1 play (4 players): First of all, Agricola is undeniably a very good game, hence the 8. I will, in all likelihood buy a copy (my wife loved it), however I fail to grasp the intricacies of efficient production/consumption engine when playing  most economic games, often finding myself drifting through most part of the games and just hitting my stride when they are about to end. Definitely need to play more . I really liked the action selection and the fact that more people mean more actions (and more food consumption!) was quite revealing. Good game.

RATING: 8
I don't know what it is about this game.  It's fun, but yet I fear playing it.  If a boardgame could be an intense-edge-of-your-seat thriller, this would be it for me. RATING: 6
Note: I have played this a great deal before I created a BGG account.

This game, while very well-designed, is a bit too stressful for us at times.

Edit 9/16: After some reflection I think I realized what my main issue is with Agricola. Most of the game feels like a struggle to barely scrape by, which is quite thematic. However, the ending feels very abrupt. The game is over just as you finally start to get an engine going. While I think this is probably the correct design choice, it is a feature that decreases my  personal enjoyment of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Despite the hype, it's a really fun game.  Intuitive actions (Plow > sow > harvest... Fence > get animals > eat animals) lead to fun and easy to grasp strategies.  Occupations and minor improvement cards add a huge amount of variety and really changes up the potential strategies.  Luck plays a huge role especially if the person to your right is going after a similar strategy as you are (due to cards dealt) - you have to decide quickly and early to change your approach.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played once.

All components, box included, in excellent conditions – or "very good", I guess, according to BGG standards, since it seems that the moment you play something you can't say "like new", which in my mind is what describe the condition best.

Full disclosure: upon close inspection, I see the very faint indent of someone testing a ball pen on a sheet of paper, using the box cover as the hard surface. The game nazi in me is seething in anger, but trust me, this was not done on my watch. That's how I got the game from the store. This small detail only shows up at a particular angle of light. I'm very anal retentive and I only saw this years after I've acquired the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like the game but at the end of the day the small niggling complaints mount up and keep me from giving this a higher rating.

Has a lot of great concepts: variable turn order, random ordering of when actions become available, variety through the cards, easy-to-understand the goal (though the final scoring is a bit non-intuitive).

I can understand why people like it so much.

The tokens the game comes with are bland. There is a reason so many people pimp their games. The cards add variability but don't seem entirely balanced. You can fix this by drafting but that requires everyone know what does/doesn't constitute a good card.

Relatively low interaction with other players. Blocking someone by taking an action is about it. Way better than Race for the Galaxy or Dominion, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
German version fully converted with English pasted throughout. Excellent hand and resource management game

RATING: 6
If I were to praise this game then it would be for the time spent balancing all the different possibilities.  If I were to criticise it then I would point out that it is extremely boring!

I bought Agricola because I wanted to try to get into it.  It must be really good to have been at number one on BGG, surely?!  I just don't understand.  Each turn is a chore.  I do not like the feeling of wanting to do everything at once.  It must be a personal thing.  I do not really enjoy worker placement games at the best of times, and Agricola is worker placement at its most frustrating!

Just can't see why it is rated so highly. Not bad, but not that good either.

RATING: 8
It's too easy to make a couple of bad choices, or sometimes just have bad luck, and cause half the game to be a painful struggle just to feed your people, without any prospect of improving your situation.  When it's a 4 or 5 player game you can be in this unpleasant situation for an hour or more.

That said, this game has completely recaptivated me. During its first couple of years it got played every week at our game club, and often more than once, but I would not often join in. For the past few months I've been suggesting it almost every week at both of my weekly game nights. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A academic well-made example of the Euro genre. Orchestrates so multiple interweaving yet smooth flowing mechanics without feeling cumbersome. 

But this game isn't as much fun. The scoring system forces every player to attempt meeting every criteria with stiff penalties for any misses. The 'Feeding' mechanic just furthers the abuse.

It's like a well-organised swimming competition riddled with poisonous jellyfish, deadly undercurrents, stinging rays etc. If you held your head above water for that long, then you're doing pretty well already. Great example of an Euro but the game could do with less gruelling punishment for more fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Because James would like to try Caverna and Agricola seems to be the ideological predecessor of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
1.動物繁殖 每兩隻生一隻  只會產生一次
2.農田
農田需要經過三個階段耕種才可收成
a.犁田 (一次一個田，田與田之間也要相連)
b.拿種子 (一個種子，之後可由收成的作物中播種)
c.播種
(每次在播種階段，先放一顆種子在田上，然後麥子從外面拿兩個新的麥子疊在上面
蔬菜則放上種子後，從外面再拿額外一個蔬菜疊上，也就是田上只有兩個。
可一次播多個田，也可一次播兩種植物的種子)
3.行動格
a.注意的是有箭頭符號的代表會累計，當這回合沒人領取的時候下回合會增加
相反的沒有就是不會，像是臨時工這格的食物就不會累計
b.當人數在三人以上的時候，最左邊的行動格會增加綠色的行動卡(上面有標示使用人數)
家庭板和正式板須注意有無家庭的符號，行動卡上也有分家庭和正式兩面
c.藍色的回合卡依照回合所在季節直接放在對應的季節裡，總共6季14回合
每回合翻開一張新的回合卡，並將資源補上，一開始須先翻開第一張回合卡
d.注意有些格子有兩種以上功能，如果是(和/或)則可以直接執行第二段功能
但是如果是XXXXXX之後可以再OOOOOO，
則第一個動作"必"執行後才可以選擇執行第二階段動作
4.壁爐可用烤爐直接換不用加資源(耗兩回合)
5.收成階段
收成分三階段，順序很重要
a.農田上作物收割 (每個田都拿下一個作物)
b.餵養家庭成員 (每個人要兩份食物，這回合剛生的一份，未轉換的麥或蔬菜可當1食物)
c.動物繁殖 (兩隻以上可繁殖一隻，兩隻可生一隻，一百隻也只生一隻，動物不需餵養)
順序記住不可亂，也就是說剛收割的植物可以拿去餵養，蔬菜也用爐子轉換成食物
但是不能把新生的動物在這回合轉換成食物拿來餵養家庭成員，要也是下季的事了

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
