=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is amazing. Surprisingly easy to explain and understand given its complexity. Seems to scale well for all numbers of players though game length can increase unpleasantly with player count.

Unfortunately there is a barrier to cross between just surviving and maximizing your score. If some players are still in the "just surviving" stage of their play and other players are in the maximizing stage, the game is no longer fun for the struggling players since it's obvious they aren't going to win and the maximizing players' turns take much longer (Not just because of analyzing but sometimes we're talking about having a 5 person family vs a 2 person family)

Furthermore, Agricola has a large upfront information load in terms of your starting occupations and minor improvements. This can be overwhelming for new players.

RATING: 9.5
This is a punishing game, but it is fantastically designed and the theme is very strong. Extremely rewarding when things go your way, crushingly disappointing when they don't. But you've (usually) only yourself to blame, and a bad result makes you want to immediately redeem yourself by playing again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Firstly, I love card-driven games and this one comes with a completely irresistible theme that draws you in and keeps you engaged for the entire playing time. There are agonising decisions throughout, you want to do everything, but only get a few actions each turn. The game also has a very different feel in its 4 and 5 player incarnations with animals much more accessible when 5 play, but it's the quality and consistency of the card decks that's the most questionable aspect. The E, I and K decks don't vary the game as much as their names imply and very similar cards (e.g. ploughs) appear in all three. I also don't like the endgame scoring that awards negative points for any commodity that you don't have (I suspect this was dictated by the deck limitations, just in case your initial card draw gave you a runaway 'sheep engine' or something), making each game essentially the same. The major criticism is that even though this is a 2 hour game, far too much is decided by the initial cards that you're dealt. Card synergy and who is first to get an extra family member are the major success determinants. I quickly tired of the basic game, card variety and consistency is way behind that in Race for the Galaxy for instance, but once in a while the attractive theme is enough to see it through.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Like this, and the game solo's well-can be a little overwhelming and feeding can catch you out. Cards may seem a little OP, but does not detract from enjoyment.

RATING: 5
Played once using the "family game" rules. There are so many options for building up your farm, but someone else is likely to take them before you...and even if you get what you want you still have to constantly worry about feeding your growing family! Kinda liked it but it's too long, too Euro and the only "interaction" is of the annoying, blocking actions, variety. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yep, it's a game about doing things in the right order.  And it's lots and lots of fun.  I love putting together my farm and making things work together. I love the card combos and the way it feels like really building something and the free form nature of it--it really feels as if  you can put you farm together however you like, though it isn't obvious if you look at it at the end. Really satisfying and after over 20 plays, I think it's safe to say this will be a favorite for a long time.

EDIT: Frankly, if you don't think Agricola is awesome, you simply don't play games for the same reasons I do. If you want a satisfying building experience, this is it!  Must.. play...more... 

EDIT AGAIN: Yeah, for now I am pretty sure I'm madly in love with this. The more I play, the more I want to keep playing.

COOLER OBSERVATIONS: The issues with the game are as follows:  1) it is very much a giant fiddly mess.  The upkeep is pretty intense.  2) Turn order can matter, especially with a smaller number of players.  3) Yes, it is possible to get a very good hand and that does influence the outcome.  I have tried the drafting variant and like it quite a bit.

But except for #2, these are integral parts of what I love about the game too and I will happily forgive them.

RATING: 6
While this is a solidly designed game, it's quite a bit too "solitaire" for my tastes, especially considering the playing time.  So many other games elegantly (and in less time) cover the same sort of game with more interaction (Stone Age is the most recent game that comes to mind).  While I appreciate the cards bringing added flavor and variety, they also appear to sometimes unbalance things.  It's a good game, and I'll play it, but I can't agree with it's current rating and ranking.

RATING: 9
I bought this game because, at the time, it was the #1 rated game. No regrets about such a purchase, as it is indeed one of the best. Rather playing with the cards or not, there is a lot of stuff to do and a lot of strategy to think about. It's also fun playing with the pieces, and I have enough imagination to pretend disks are people and cubes are sheep. A lot of people complain about the farming theme, but I for one love it (then again, I'm descended from farmers). Also makes for a great solo game, for when one needs to play around with cardboard and wood chunks yet has nobody around to join them.

RATING: 9.8
Resulta dificil creer que un juego para jugones pueda ser accesible para quienes no lo son. Parece combinar lo mejor de Caylus (elección de acciones, construcción)con un cierto toque de los juegos de cartas coleccionables. Esfuerzo de la editorial Homoludicus que merecía que lo comprara. Buenos componentes (animeeples), no es largo, gran rejugabilidad y escala muy bien de 1 a 5 jugadores. Me encanta la sensación de competir contra los demás (“que no me quiten esa acción”) y a la vez competir contra el propio sistema de juego (mendicidad, cosechas…). No es un juego para pensar a largo plazo, sino que favorece a los jugadores que se adaptan al desarrollo de la partida. Estaba por encima de Le Havre en mi lista personal por el componente de iniciación que tiene. Ahora compruebo que LH es mejor juego.

Para jugar en linea: http://www.boiteajeux.net

[ENG]

It´s dificult to belive it, but Agricola is a gamer´s game that is very  accesible to the rookies. It combines the best of Caylus (action selection and building) with a bit of CCG. Homoludicus, the Spanish editor did a big effort and he deserved my buy. It has good componets (animeeples), it isn´t extremely long, has a lot of replayability. I love the felleing of being in competition against the rest of players and against the game itself (begging and harvests). It´s not a strategic game, so is easier to the player that doesn´t think in long term and addapts better when he´s playing. Agricola has higher score on my own ranking than Le Havre becouse of  his "gateway flavour", but Le Havre is a better game, IMHO.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I'm not sure I've ever played a game as delightfully maddening as Agricola.  The game play is brutally unforgiving - rare is the game of Agricola where every single player doesn't feel like the game is going terribly.  Fortunately, though, the pastoral theme goes a long way towards blunting the games' harshness. It hits the sweet spot between having many options on any given turn and not being completely overwhelming, and the food requirement adds a good amount of tension to the game and requires a sometimes painful balance between short term needs and long term strategy.  The occupation and improvement cards give the game immense replay value as you try to discover the best card combinations in your hand.  I'm knocking off a half point for the fiddliness of replenishing resources, but that's a very minor complaint.  Overall a very excellent game.

Updated to say that my original rating is for playing with the basic decks.  After limited experience with the complex and interactive decks I would rate the game lower when playing with either of those, as the cards are way too unbalanced (based on playing the iPad game, combining all the decks seems to be okay, the above comment refers to using the K and I decks in isolation).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First played October 2nd, 2008. Taught in 30min, played in 2hrs for 5 players. This game seems well balanced. If anything it has more strategy than luck in it. The game is filled with options. Each player starts out with a player area with 15 spots. A two rooms house fills two squares and two people fill each room (1 person per room). The start player gets two "food" and each subsequent player gets three food. There is a main play area with actions that can be taken. Your people you have act as your action points. So everyone starts out with two action points. Actions are: collect food, grain, vegetable, animal(sheep,pig,cow), wood, clay, stone, add room, upgrade house, plow land, sow crops(if you have any) build fence(cost 1 wood for each section), build stable(doubles fenced in compacity) add family member, play occupation(special actions), minor upgrade(special actions), major upgrade(better special actions). Many of the actions cost materials,etc. The game is played over 14 round and there are harvest / feedings along the way (rnd 4,7,9,11,13,14. You must have two food for each person you have at each harvest. If you have two animals they have a baby. Fun game that keeps your interest throughout. You won't realize it has taken two hours after you finish. I strongly recommend giving this a try especially if you know someone who has it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A snowstorm hit, and everything was shutting down early. We barely made it home... and then got noticed that our copy of Agricola had been delivered to the office. We suited back up, hoped the buses wouldn't stop running, and braved the storm, but it was worth it. We played twice, staying up 'til almost midnight. I was prepared to be overwhelmed by the rules and details, but we were up and running surprisingly quickly, and it is so well designed that we had very few checks back to the rule book.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
2/10/09
-------------------------

In this game about farming in late Medieval Europe, players take control of a couple on a farm, and must ensure their economic and social success by breeding animals, growing vegetables, growing their family, upgrading their house and many other actions. It can be played across the full common gaming spectrum of 1-6, and thus has a long shelf-life, especially with the Full Game and the Family Game options, and the three different decks of cards to use.

I must comment first about the atmosphere this game conjures; that of tension and suspense, unusual for a eurogame because of their dry nature, but in [i]Agricola[/i], the pressure of having to continually take care of your farm, animals, and family can be quite real. This is felt most during the early stages of the game, and seems to disappear towards the end, to be replaced by the fight with the other players to claim the powerful end-game action spaces. Definitely one of the things this game does well.

The game play revolves around the recently popular worker placement mechanism, brought into popular view by [i]Caylus[/i] in 2005. With only a handful of actions available in the beginning, expanding to a plethora in the end, [i]Agricola[/i] captures the feel of an expanding industry very well. The way in which all the parts of the game; crops, animals, and the cards, mesh also heightens this feeling of development. No part of the game feels like it has been pasted on, nor does anything feel ‘gamey’, at least nothing that I have found. The worker selection works very well in this game and brings the interaction into an otherwise solitaire game. The little luck is sufficiently restricted with limited foreknowledge, and can be mitigated entirely through forward planning. 

My only problem with this game is the lack of distinct paths to victory; there is only one way you can win, and that is by having a little of everything, the hand of cards that you get and the way the other players interact with you can affect this, but I still feel that this is a considerable drawback, as they do not affect the end state, only alter the means slightly, and it is this that stops it from attaining a 9. 

[b]Pros[/b]
- Great atmosphere
- High player interaction
- High replayability 
- Emphasis on planning
- Mechanisms interlinked

[b]Cons[/b]
- Limited path to victory
- Solitaire version lacks tension
- Full Game may be too heavy for casual gamers
- Many counters and cubes make it fiddly

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
King of worker placement.  Long play time with slightly dry topic means this doesn't get the love it deserves.  An excellent resource economy game that isn't too hard to understand, forces you to fight with players for control of resources (but when you lose, there are lots of other things you need so it isn't terrible), but offers variety to scoring.

2 player version of this (just like Caverna) may replace it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In Dec 07 I pre-ordered from Z-man and made my own paste up version with bits from other games.  I got my Z-Man pre-order Aug 4th 08 and have returned the bits to their own games.  

I have played solo, 2, 3, 4 and 5 player games and then more players you have the more exiting it gets.  It has been described as multi-player solitaire but in my experience there is interaction with the other players.  Choosing the actions you are going to do and when you choose them can be influenced by other players. There was lots of interaction in our 5 player game and using the "I" deck helps introduce more interaction.

The solo games I have played have been challenging and I want to see if I can do better. In multiplayer games, several new players in the groups I have taught it to are ready to play it play again. Even if you lose there is a "let's try it again and see if I can do better".

Replayability is GREAT!  None of the games that I have played have been the same and your strategy will change based on the cards you have and what actions and paths the other players follow. 

[2-23-2008] I have played like 14 games which have been a 2, 3 and 4 player games.  They have all been different and have required different strategies.  Used the Interactive deck in a 4 player game (4 E cards and 3 I cards) and WOW! My opinion of the games still stands - GREAT GAME!

[8-4-2008] Got the Z-Man pre-order and sleeved the cards.  They are thinner then the "old magic cards" I had sleeved with the paste-ups previously. Other then the cards being a little thin all of the other components are Great and the Animeeples are cool.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The classic Rosenberg game. I like the theme of building and developing a small farm. It's a tough game, with interesting choices and strategies. Resources are scarce which is ultimately why I don't enjoy it as much as its successor Caverna.

RATING: 10
Because only hard-core gamers play games about farming!  This game is so good, I actually had to go back and reduce the score on some of the other games in my collection to reflect the awesomeness of this one.  I never would have thought that a game about farming could be so good.  The game it's self is easy to learn and play despite seemingly complex rules, however deep levels of strategy and calculation will reward advanced players.
The box is absolutely packed with components (cards, game boards, various wooden tokens and markers).  So much so, it can be a little tricky to get everything back into the box nicely!
I am usually not a fan of euro-style games, but this is an absolute must for any game fan.

RATING: 7
Agricola is a challenging game!  Whether you win or lose, you rarely feel as if you have accomplished everything that you had originally planned.  There are a multitude of successful strategies to win and it is difficult to balance your efforts across the different scoring conditions.  Speaking of balancing your efforts, you are penalized if you do not try to do a little bit of everything.  However, it can be quite frustrating for a player who is looking for a lighter game.  Unfortunately, I have not tested all of the card play-sets.  I am sure they offer even more variety and bang for your buck in a game that is already mentally stimulating and feels fresh on most plays.

RATING: 7.7
Aug08: Oh yes, the hype-o-matic 3000. How was it? Not that bad really. I've only played the family game, but it was thematic and engaging. The play made sense and there were plenty of meaningful choices.

Now on to the bad:

I don't like worker placement, too passive aggressive. Way too many similar bits, I don't need 3 shades of brown in my game just for the sake of the theme. It takes a little too long for the payoff in my opinion.

There is tons of room for skillful play however. Experienced players just trounced all over the newbies.

So... good, not great.

I'll try it again with the cards. However, it seems to add an extra hour to the play time around here...

RATING: 7
Great worker placement game with a lot of flavor and variety - I particularly like it with the special meeples box I bought. There is much to like in the concept, art and flow, especially when you add the cards.

Key negatives are (1) length of time per game and, correspondingly, teaching it to others, (2) elements of randomness, (3) being forced into a box of strategy rather than enjoying totally open strategy, and (4) a level of Euroness that turns off many more casual players in my group. 

Also, it wears less well on me with more plays than some of my other games. As such, it hits the table less often.

Mechanics are old and it feels old. Tensed game and beautiful design but there are plenty better games in the same concept.

Description: Place your family members to gain resources and build your farm.

Pro: Perfect example of a euro-game. Able to increase or decrease complexity to suit the players. Balanced for any number of players. Lots of nice wooden bits. Many different ways to win.

Con: Sometimes your occupations and minor improvements work together better than others.

RATING: 9
While I will play this game anytime anyone else is willing, it does not get suggested as much around our house. Frankly, I'm not as excited about it as some other less highly ranked games. I have tried to figure out exactly why this game is not as popular here since it is so well-received among gamers. 

Refilling all the resources on the board each time (despite all the good advice I have read from people about how to do this) is distracting and never compensated for by the feeling I get when I am playing Brass or Puerto Rico of "wow, this game works so smoothly and elegantly to lay before you a number of interesting decisions." 

Update 8/12/11: Sat on shelf so traded for Hamburgum. Odd trade on face of it considering the rating differences, but I think Ham will get played and that's where the value is.

7/15/12

Strategy: 4.5
Luck factor: 2 - if you plan well, randomness wouldn't trouble you much.
Players interaction: Very High Passive. Your desired spaces get blocked very quickly.
Play/Wait Ratio: Medium-Low. Sometimes the game flows quicker than you can plan. 
Replayability: 4. Many card sets that changes your strategy.

all in all I must say I didn't enjoy the too-quick flow of the game.

RATING: 10
(1-5) - je Spieler 30 Min.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played 8 multi-player games and a solo series. I see Agricola as a core game that works well and is well-themed but that might became stale after several plays; and an expansion in the form of the many Occupation and Minor Improvement cards. While the cards add to the theme of the game and clearly provide a lot of variety, they also seem to cause a couple of problems even when restricting them to the Basic (E) Deck. The first problem is that they add substantially to the length of a game as players refer to them while also considering the many possible actions inherent in the core game. The second problem is that they are not balanced; some cards are better than others. It seems to me as if the cards in Agricola have not been fully tested and developed. I would have preferred that the game had a much smaller set of carefully balanced cards and/or a well-defined mechanism for balancing each player's hand of cards. Perhaps the different card decks and the variant rules enable such a game to be played, but the rulebook provides no clear guidance on this; indeed the rulebook could be better in many ways. No doubt Agricola blossoms as a game when all players have many plays under their belt; but until I reach that stage, I have to judge the game somewhat critically.

UPDATE: after a few plays, I still see a problem with the cards: a couple of good cards can really help win you the game, while a poor set of cards can make it difficult in the first few rounds (I've seen one or the other in my own hand in most of the games I've played). A fellow player pointed out that the rather untidy -1 scoring is entirely unnecessary: all scores could be increased by 1 point so that there are 0-5 points in each category. My opinion remains that Agricola is at heart a very good game, that would have benefited from more testing and development. 

FURTHER UPDATE: after several more plays, I am enjoying Agricola more than ever. The card system, while it has its problems, certainly ensures that each game is different. 

FINAL OPINION: with more than 20 games under my belt I can at last rate Agricola as a 10. I have recently found that the variants help to mitigate the above-mentioned problem with the cards, and I've also enjoyed some 2-player games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Jansy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

Hand Management

RATING: 9
It floored me how such a simple and fast paced game could contain such variety.  With the ridiculous amount of occupations and minor improvements, Agricola is a different game every play. Colorful art and pieces lend an attractive visual appeal that similar Euros lack.  The subject matter (farming in the 1500s, ho-hum) is dry but the gameplay and art most certainly are not.  Unlike other Euros I've played, the theme integrates perfectly into the mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Worker placement:Variable powers:Engine game

inital rating (8.5) 1 play 4 players (03/04/08)

Who knew farming could be fun? The hype IS most likely justified IMO. Maybe not the next coming or anything but pretty damn good already. 

A very strong themed game actually as people are farmers trying to max out their farm as much as possible. Indeed a game of efficiency at heart that has a very nice blend of strategic planning and tactical jostling. The tactical game is of course quite similiar to Caylus where you are placing your workers trying to grab the best things available, the similarity pretty much stops there though. 

Starting the game everyone gets 14 special power cards to help them in their quest, these of course will somewhat dictate your strategic path and because there are so many cards it is hard to imagine a dominant strategy emerging for some time. This also means huge replayability as you will need to adjust your play from game to game in order to max out your efficiency with the cards you get dealt. 

Very much an engine building game like RFTG actually where you try to get your improvements down asap in order to be able to do more with less. A ton of special powers here just like that game also through the cards and also a ton of ways to score points! (and lose points!) I was a little overwhelmed my first game which almost never happens and is a good sign (lots of scoring and lots going on all over the place), I got caught up in the tactical grab game and lost track of all the scoring and before I knew it the game was ending, pretty engaging and came in around 2 hours with 4. 

Looking forward to more plays, not sure about scaling down to 2 players, I hear it works well so there must be some changes in how different goods come out and action selection I guess. Of course another potential negative is the card balance and how someone's hand could be much better than yours right from the start, just draw 3 extra cards and discard 3 crappy ones. 

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 8.5 => 9  Five plays in, played the 2,3,4 and 5 player game and it scales very well (see below however).  Ranks 3, 4, 2 then 5. We have noticed big swings in card luck and while the cards may not be as important as they seem, it can be just too much to compete against someone with really good matching and useful cards. This means drafting now becomes a necessity (tried extra with dumping) which unfortunately adds considerable time to the game hence 5 is the weakest number just due to time, the game scales perfectly as far as mechanics and balance but just takes too long with 5, even without the draft (which we tried)

So this sounds kind of negative, why the raise in rating then?  The theme is simply outstanding, everything in the game just drips of theme and nothing in the game goes against it at all either, it seems every detail was considered thematically. The 360 cards are unbelievable as well, every card I think I seen so far has been named perfectly for the benefits they provide, Uwe and company must of spent many hours on these and it shows. Most of the cards seem [i] fairly [/i] balanced considering how many there are, there are some odd really good ones, especially when combined with the right card or cards hence the need for the draft. For a high strategy game, luck really needs to be reduced as much as possible and this looks to be the only way to an even distribution.  

What really pushes the game to greatness though is the absolute stress of trying to do everything while never being able to, similiar to a lot of good games and most recently "In the Year of the Dragon". The stress is high because actions really start running out and your farm will suffer negative points should you neglect any part of it, (in Dragon you suffer small disasters for any neglect) this price you are going to pay is ever present and agonizing. It also has the addictive quality of that game where you really want to improve your game and beat your score or the current high score (again RFTG anyone?) and also shares the great engine building aspect of both of those games as well. 

The only other [i]possible[/i] negative besides what I already mentioned is the way the game forces you to play a balanced game as everything is important, this is a strength to be sure but maybe a negative too. I'm not sure this will have any 'multiple paths' so to speak as the end goal of this game will not change, build the best farm possible with lots of everything for max points. Not diversifying or focusing on just some things versus everything I think will mean you won't win as someone who did will beat you the way the scoring is structured, more games to confirm.  This could mean we may not see any little side strategies show up, they might but at 5 games I don't see it, right now it looks like it is just a matter of picking the right cards, playing the right amount of cards, at the right time and especially in the right order. This card play along with having different cards every game to mesh together is fun and adds its own variance strategy-wise along with wicked replay. Of course the order of actions is also critical and what this all means is while maybe there isn't true mutiple strategies you can still execute a very satisfying game long plan, definitely a high strategy game no question and there is still some variance in how you will get to that end goal in both the order of how you excute your plan and with which cards you keep and play. Might be my final rating but if I'm still playing after 20 games and gameplay does not need improvement in any way it could just hit 10 (my criteria for "10" along with meeting my 9 criteria) 

Great game. 

[u]Tidbit[/u] - I think the suggestion of the least negative points breaks the tie was the best I seen so far but my opinion could change after many more games.

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 9 => 10 Only 8 plays, this is only the second time I have broken my 20 game rule (POF before at 11) and only my 4th "10" rating. I know I will be playing well after 20 games and it is already threatening the 3 games above it in my top 10.  The game is excruiating maybe more than any other game I know, its extremely challenging as the rounds speed by with so much to do and I love a great challenge. Imagine juggling while walking a tight-rope 50 feet in the air...that is Agricola with the right group, a constant juggling of actions and cards while trying to keep your head just above water and also trying to get or stay ahead of the others at the table. I don't think I care anymore about multiple paths, the entire game is about planning so its a high strategy game regardless and the cards really help alleviate any feeling of only one path. (edit - after 20 plays the game does feel somewhat formulaic but no more than POF) It can be pretty unforgiving if your playing with other good players, similiar to POF in both those ways and I do kinda get the same feeling out of it as you try to execute your game long plan but remain flexible along the way. Another POF trait, winning between a game of good gamers will often come down to 'the little things' [ie 1 grain :P ] and this will keep it VERY tense throughout. 

The draft is the only way to go now, at least for us. We have it down to 10-15 minutes and it removes almost all the luck out of the game. The draft is really a "sub-game" within the game itself and a pretty cool one, VERY tough decisions as you ALWAYS want to keep more than one card, great stuff. The game scales perfectly 2 to 5 and feels a little different at each number which also helps to keep it fresh. It is important to watch the other players in every game, especially for blocking actions and the "I" deck also provides some nice interaction as well.  The game is fun although there can be a lot of 'quiet' rounds while people calculate and plan, yet another POF trait. Though I have made many comparisons throughout to show certain strengths and Uwe has admitted borrowing things from other games, Agricola comes out feeling very different from pretty much any other game and is a unique playing experience unto itself. 

You simply can't ask much more from a game than what this offers. 

Thank you Uwe for such an awesome game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I don't like how you have to score in every area (grain, sheep, fence, etc.) to have a chance at winning. There is not enough specialization in my opinion, and too much solitaire-like play. Good if you love euro-spreadsheet style games, but not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I find that Agricola did not live up to the hype.  I was very excited about trying this game only to discover that it felt a lot like Caylus feels.  There is a lot going on and, as a beginner, it is extremely hard to tell if the actions you are taking will actually be beneficial to you or not.  Familiarity with the cards, building costs, and timing of harvests would help and would be gained through additional plays.

The problem for me here is that I'm not going to be able to find face to face opponents who will be willing to learn this game over the course of several plays.  I need a game that draws people in on the first play.

Also, I'm really starting to lean toward games with more player interaction.  The player interaction in Agricola is minimal and indirect at best.  A game of Agricola feels much more like playing against the system than playing against the other players.  I expected to buy this and didn't.  I've taken it off my wishlist.

UPDATE:  My brother ended up buying this and I've gotten several more plays in.  I'm enjoying this more and more =)  I've bumped my rating up to a 7.

UPDATE AGAIN:  Wow - I love this game!  This is now an 8 and is solidly on my top ten games list.  I prefer playing with the K deck.  Scales very well.  Enjoyable with anywhere from two to five players.  Player interaction picks up a bit in the two player game.

RATING: 7.6
In Agricola, players manage a family trying to survive off of the land during the Middle Ages.  Each turn, players assign their family members to certain life-on-the-farm tasks; provided that another player has not already selected their desired task during that turn.  The game advances almost too quickly, making the players feel as if there is insufficient time to complete their goals making, Agricola an engaging but stressful experience.  I generally end up worrying more about producing enough resources to feed family members and rethinking strategies when denied resources by another player's action sequence than spending time enjoying building up my farm.  Overall, this is a good game – but the stress tends to erode my enjoyment, making it a game that I am usually willing to play but not one that I yearn to play.

Rating: 7.6 (Fun 6; Gameplay 9; Components 9; Theme 7)
Formula:
[Weighted rating = (((Fun*4) + (Gameplay*3) + (Components *2) + (Theme *1))/10)]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Occassionally... why not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As a game, Agricola doesn't really excite me. It's essentially just a standard worker placement game and all of the actions are pretty generic. I'll agree that it's probably a very good implementation of worker placement. But at the end of the day that's all it is, and a straight up worker placement game is never really going to excite me as a game. It's true that the cards aren't all perfectly balanced, but they're close enough for most people to have a good game out of it. And getting extra workers is incredibly important, probably moreso than any other worker placement game I've played, but if everyone knows that going in and plans around fighting over reed, the build action, and family growth then it's probably fine and in fact might make for the kind of game I'd otherwise like. But the core of the game just coming down to straightforward worker placement just doesn't excite me.

Now, all of Uwe Rosenberg's other big box games are basically just worker placement games as well, and yet I've rated them higher. What's the key difference? All of his other games are more of sandboxes than Agricola, which is a much more directed experience. Firm direction and being required to do certain things and jump through specific hoops is probably better for a proper game, and so if you like worker placement as a core mechanic and like serious competitive games, this one will probably be your favorite of his. But for me, since I'm not too excited about them as games, I can enjoy his other big box titles almost as romps, just doing cool things and collecting whatever I want and seeing how many whatevers I can get and how effectively I can convert them in more valuable whatevers. I can just enjoy myself exploring and experiencing the games, since I don't really care about them as games. They're very similar to Mage Knight in that way. But you very much can't do that in Agricola, something that might be a bit of a shock if you're coming from Caverna.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

RATING: 8.5
Many plays now with all decks and numbers of players.

It's great fun building up and improving your farm, agonizing over actions, formulating an initial strategy with your cards, balancing short-term needs with long, and adjusting to what other players are doing.

I do wonder if this game will hold appeal after so many games. Not that the card combinations aren't nearly limitless, but the game's linear turn order is already feeling a little "same-y"--get your production engine going, ramp up the family, maximize VPs. But nearly every game is "same-y"--AT, Wargame, Euro, Card--there are rules and a framework. The beauty (or lack thereof) is in the details--which I think Agricola has in spades.

I've rated this a 9 for now. I would always want to play, even if I'm not certain of its longevity. -- 8/2/2009: Played two games yesterday--still fun, but not as fun as I remembered. The linearity bothered me a little. Re-rated to 8.5

Not a game for non-gamers.

I've played this out, solo. The practice was helpful, but it will only be enjoyable against others now--not being able to count on resources being there.

Great fun with more players, though. 3 or 4-players IS the sweet spot. 5 is fun only if everyone moves things along. -- 8/2/2009: I like the 5-player action cards -- stone, boar and cattle are available early.

RATING: 9
This is one of my Favorite Games.

PRO:
Solid Strategy & Worker Placement Game; Plays well with different range of players;

CON:
You are penalized by not creating a farm of everything, and victory points earned by each item has a limit. Though I understand the idea, that you want to create a successful farm all around (with animals, crops, family, nice houses and stable...) it limits your path to victory. You will have to do everything, you cannot attain victory through just farming, or through just breeding. I don't mind this, but I listing it as a con.

RATING: N/A


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Each player is a farmer which sounds boring but is a really fun game.  It's a worker placement game where each turn you take turns grabbing one of the locations with a worker.  There are resources to gather, pastures and fields to build, rooms to add and upgrade, and ultimately families to expand.  Every choice is agonizing and there is much player interaction as you seek to get what you need while blocking other players.  Some asymmetry and variety is added by cards that provide a benefit that are not available to the other players, helping to keep things from getting too scripted but not so much as to keep things from becoming luck-based.  A real brain burner!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The epitome of a eurogame.  Lots of nice looking components.  The game mechanics leave you spoiled with choices.  There's a little bit of backstabbing going on.  

But, it avoids some common Euro pitfalls: it scales exceptionally well.  (*gasp*  It even solos well!)  It moves along at a reasonable clip.  (The last third of the game feels like a runaway train.)  Not super-easy to teach, but intuitive after you walk someone through a couple of turns.

Love it.

I've had a surge of interest recently. Especially as a two-player game I find myself wanting to play more than I used to. My wife enjoys it, or at least tolerates it, and will play with me. I even taught my 5-year-old to play the family game. She's so proud of her farms, and grasps a lot more about the game than I expected. The fact that a good looking, well rounded farm usually has a decent score is probably the root of this. My daughter builds what looks good to her, and ends up doing just fine.

RATING: 10
Rating after 4 plays.  It's an excellent efficiency engine game, if that's your bag.  I enjoy this particular genre of games (not all the time), and think Agricola has the potential to be one of the best.  In some ways, there's even less player interaction than Puerto Rico (which is bad).  However, the multitude of ways you can get your engine working, and the replayability due to the sheer number of cards makes it really stand out.  If you don't like this kind of game, stay far away.  If you do, give it a try.  I'll be re-evaluating my rating after several more plays, to see if it has staying power.

Update 1: It's 4 years after Agricola's release and I still love this game.  It's infinitely replayable, plays in a good timeframe, has an interesting mix of decisions, etc.

Update 2013 July:  Moved to a 10.  I never tire of this game.  I only have about 20-30 plays, so I'm not nearly as burned out as some people may be.  I imagine enjoying this for years to come.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My rating of a 5 is misleading. If this game were handed in as an assignment, I'd give it an A+. However, that doesn't mean that I like to play it. Because I don't.

There is only one path to victory: (in this order) collect wood, expand house & family ASAP, diversify. There's no need to explore different strategies because they won't work against a player that chooses to follow the one path to victory. And once that player takes the lead, there is no catching up. The game is simply a fierce competition for wood, expansion, diversification. There are many tactics within the strategy, but only one strategy. With a game that has this much going on, this many cards, tokens, tiles, and board space, you'd think that there would be many ways to win. There aren't.

I want to like this game more than I do. I love having to develop and manage the farm, but the game is too much like the setting it models: an environment unforgiving of errors, with an excess of struggle and a lack of fun.

Also, even within the game world a lot of suspension of disbelief is required. If (for one example out of many) two players have ovens for baking bread, they can't both simultaneously bake bread. Yes, sure, it's a game and the rules are there to restrict and guide game play, but it still bothers me. Other players' contrived explanations to help with the suspension of disbelief are equally implausible. "Maybe there's only one oven and what you're gaining is not the oven itself, but permission to use the one oven." Well, cripe, if this actually happened in real life, wouldn't they just build a second oven? Ok, ok, suspension of disbelief.

Other than that, it's an extraordinarily well-designed game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Can Farming be fun?  It certainly can and my 11 yr old son and wife both agree!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I very much love Agricola. Despite the set number of rounds and the same decision tree, the numerous cards make every game a different decision path on how to get your farm-engine running. Even amongst a few "basic strategies", I have seen some unexpected outcomes and interesting strategies develop.

The down-side is teaching the game to new players: there is a lot going on and the setup is daunting to the inexperienced.

RATING: 6
This is an excellent game, as I'm sure you already know, but it can be a bit long for my taste with lots of players.  In my first game, I decided to give up on trying to figure out what everyone else was doing and play it as multi-player solitaire.  That seemed to work, as I won with 30 points (2nd place had 29; it was a 5-player Family game).  Update: After 2 games, I upgraded it from 6 to 7, but after 4 games, I put it back down to 6.  Finding a coherent strategy is proving to be much more work than I want to put into a game.  Later update: At some point, I pushed it back up to a 7.  I don't play very often, but as long as I don't worry too much about min/maxing and I just enjoy building my farm, it's a good time.  Another update: I haven't played this in almost 2 years, so I'm downgrading it again.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excellent worker-placement game from Uwe Rosenberg, and one which I have played a lot since I first got my German (and subsequently my English) copy of the game.

I do prefer the game with fewer rather than more players: 2-player is fun, and 3-player is probably my favorite. With 4 or 5 players, there is too much downtime (particularly with 5 where the total game length also becomes too long).

Also, and going against the current here, I am still undecided on whether I prefer the family version of the game, or the full version with cards. The cards do add a lot to the game, in particular variability and depth, and as a result an almost infinite replayability. On the other hand, they also introduce more downtime, and they add a significant amount of randomness to the game. Every single game I have played with the cards have seen one player triumphantly play strong (almost unbeatable) combos, and at least one player has been loudly cursing his bad luck.

I'd describe the family game as a regular, proper medium/heavyweight euro, if one that has a tendency to become a bit stale and dry with repeated playing. The full game, on the other hand, doesn't really feel much like a euro. The core game is the same, of course, but the cards takes the game clearly out of euro territory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
農家樂
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorite games - great theme and gameplay.  There is something even philosophical about the game and how it reflects the rat race of life.  The game isn't supposed to be easy - because the lives of farmers is not easy, and early game, you are just scratching by to make ends meet as you invest for the future.

Besides the thematic and philosophical angles, much of the fun in the game play comes from the delicious tension of trying to feed your family while both growing your family to get more actions and maximizing points for end-game scoring.  There are game theory elements and considerations of macro-level impact for any action taken or benefit gained.

Highly replayable due to so many cards and different combination of cards.  Drafting for the game is one of my favorite parts (that is when you get to dream).  Much, much better than Caverna.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

[hr]
2011-01-17 

I love the family version of Agricola, the advanced deck versions? I don´t like as much. In Agricola you have to really think to win a game, so I dislike the luck present in the game when you add the cards. They can easily (powerful occupations) tip the balance to the players who drew better cards. I liked it better when all players had exactly the same tools to compete. I have not played yet the draft mode so the jury is still out on this one, but right now I really prefer Caylus over Agricola. 

Current Rating: 8.0
[hr]
2011-07-07 

I finally tried the draft variant and I really liked it. I still think there are over and under powered occupations and minor improvements, but in a way the draft controls the annoying luck. If we are going to play with cards, I demand to play a draft. The downside of doing that is the extra time (around 45 min) needed to do it (with further aggravation from the analysis paralysis folk).

2013-08-26

Nowadays I still like Agricola a lot, and I plan to buy it in the future (I have not yet done so because so many friends already own it). I still think it is the best worker placement game out there, I´m downgrading its rating because I’m re rating most games so they match the BGG recommendation system with my feelings for each game, in that light Agricola is an 8.5 to me. A very good game that I want to play almost always.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2015-05-01

For me, Agricola continues to be the best worker placement out there. I love it and I think this will never change. My SO also loves it and request it often.

Last year Caverna was released and many bggeeks think it is better than Agricola but I have a different opinion. Caverna is less tense, has an static setup, it is more expensive and feels repetitive very soon. IMO, Agricola is miles better than Caverna, the main reason are the cards. I feel the cards are what makes Agricola special, highly replayable and easily expandable. Without them Agricola becomes a generic worker placement game (like Caverna). The secondary reason is the feeding of your family, in Agricola is much more harder (more tense) than in Caverna, a huge plus for me.

Another common criticism Agricola receive often is that it makes you take a predetermined path to win, but I have found this is not the case at all. With the cards you can pursue any strategy you want. For example I have this friend and he never kills animals for food (he is a vegetarian) but he does quite well in our games. I also have won games with wooden huts and without cows or grains or with many unused farm spaces etc. Agricola´s strategy is very flexible.

Great production values, furthermore with the later editions that came with the animeeples.

I finally broke down an bought the game, along with all the expansions I could find. I’m a bit worried support for this game is diminishing as Caverna took over but they recently released the France Deck so I hope this is not the case.

Nowadays, I vastly prefer to play it as a 2 player game but I won’t say no to a 3 or 4 player game, mainly because I get to see more cards that are unavailable in the two player game. As a 5 player game, I find the game has a lot of downtime so I almost never play this way (and I can’t imagine a 7 player Caverna game :shake:).

Bottom line, Agricola is the best Worker placement I have ever played. I have played it more than 50 times and I’m not tired of it. I love it.
 
One of 2007´s favorites.
Ex top Ten Game.

Current Rating: 8.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
iPad only

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Amazingly addictive Euro-hybrid.  Swinginess of the starting hands can be a problem.

Been doing some thinking about variability in the number of players and how resource scarcity affects the game, and am struck by how difficult the cards make this problem to attack.  The game will appeal to a lot of PR fans but I think it is much deeper strategically, if a little more limited tactically.  I see basic principles but I don't see truly dominant strategies akin to building/shipping in PR.  Agricola might be the best and most replayable Euro of this generation.

I'm close to 100 plays in now, probably.  Yet recently I saw a combo that I'd not only never seen before, but of a type I'd never seen before.  (Patron-Educator to get out all occupations before end of Round 4.)  That's what keeps me coming back to this game again and again.

RATING: 5
Played with five players. The only blemish I can see on this game is the importance of going first each turn. Last on the first turn guarantees that you get the fifth and tenth worst actions. Next to last is not much better. Combining the space for going first with the ability to perform a minor improvement assures that you will not be going first any time soon. In games of equals I wonder just how often the first two players on the first two turns win.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Still have mainly played this one by myself. I did get one play in with another person and overall I guess it's tough for me to comment on.  I actaully owned and played Le Havre before I purchased Agricola.  It's really hard not to compare it to Le Havre as there are many similarites between the two and overall the games have similar feels.  That said though my intial impression is that I like Le Havre a bit better.  For me Le Havre beats out Agricola as a single player game hands down.  Perhaps I felt it easier to update the offerings in Le Havre....a lame knock I know but it just seems like to often I forget or don't update one of the resources.  I've yet to play either of these games with my wife or core gaming group for that matter but I'm also thinking that I would have an easier time explaining and them accepting Le Havre.  Agricola when stripped to it's core is a very simple game.  There are however, a good number 
things to keep track of and a fairly complex scoring system leading to a steep learning curve for those who are not avid gamers.  

Having said all of this though Agricola is a great game!  After I get a few more game plays under my belt I'll revaulate it.

**A few more games in and gotta say it keeps me yearning for more.  It's surprisingly hard for me to find players for it.  I either get complaints about the time commitment or the lack of understanding.  My stance on those two complaints are as follows:  We can play three mediocore games in the time it takes to play Agricola or we can play one great game, and in terms of understanding it play as a two player or even on your own and by at least the second game you should have a real good idea of whats going on...it's really not that complex...maybe a lotta little things but if you can follow the print on Dominion cards and keep track of what's what I think you could play Agricola...perhaps not master it but at least have a general idea of what's going on.

Given the variances in occupation cards and minor improvements and number of expansions that have come out for this game I have a feeling that I'll be itching to play this game for years to come.  Really just so many possiblites that I doubt I'll see a clear path to victory for a number of games if at all.

On a final note I'm going to bump this game up.  No boardgame is perfect but this one is a masterpiece.**

RATING: 3
Z-Man is my least favorite publisher and this is my least favorite game from them. Can't understand what people like about this game as it isn't fun whatsoever. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow.  How did this game rocket to the top of the charts?!?  Agricola is a good game, yes... but greater than Puerto Rico or Power Grid or Caylus or El Grande?... I think not.

The game has some serious flaws.  Some items, when combined with the right occupations, make for unstoppable combinations, making the game almost broken.  The only redeeming factor is the sheer number of cards, which could easily have been trimmed back.

Take a game like Cosmic Encounter or Glory to Rome, multiply the ways to "adjust" the rules by 10, and you are only getting close to the game play in Agricola. Oh, NEVER play the game with someone who is prone to AP... by the final few rounds you'll be ready to shoot them.

A nice bonus is that Agricola includes rules for solo play, so I bumped my rating by a point.  But I'd still like to see a little more interaction... cattle rustling, anyone?  Gophers?  Random tornado?

And (because I like money games) I was disappointed that there was no economic system.  How do you pay for all those seeds to plant?  Where does the money come from to hire all those people and buy that equipment?  The use of resources is OK, but where's the cash?  "I work for food" just doesn't cut it for me.

Agricola is a game that I'll be willing to play anytime but it just doesn't give me that 'best of all time' feeling.

Still not deserving of anything higher than a '7'... and that's being generous.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We enjoy this one however it doesn't hit the table often. Great game that seems to stop when you are just getting going, still an enjoyable game though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have to admit that when I first heard about board game about 'farming,' my very first response was a sensible one: turn around and walk away. To clarify as not to appear condescending, when I play a game, 'farming simulation' is not exactly what I have in my mind nor I can attest to that not majority of people would be either.

But with so much appraise that this game has gotten, I cannot help but try it out for myself. Being a very meaty euro game, the depth of strategy found within allowed me to overcome the 'farming 'theme - and actually transformed me to keep an open-mind when approach games with obscure themes since it can turn out to be a real gem such as this one.

What truly helped me to get into the game was how tightly theme was interwoven with the mechanisms - during game play, I rarely had to question rules to make sense of them since the reasoning behind was very themetic. For example, of course, if you cannot feed your family, you will go out begging for food and this will hurt your reputation (VPs).

And this might be a silly reason to like this game but animeeples are very nice touch. This is such a simple change, but seeing small white sheep meeples in your own farm is very heart warming. If this game did not come with them, I would have liked it a bit less (drop the score from 0.5 to 1?)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rated after one play of the "advanced" version. 

Plusses: Very nicely interwoven mechanics and challenging gameplay; obviously a great deal of thought and playtesting went into this one. 
-The sheer number of cards to choose from assures continuing variability in individual strategy and tactics. 
-Rewards optimal planning and use of variable starting resources.

Minuses: Theme is tissue-thin. Not really an issue for quick and light games, but a longer and heavier game benefits immensely IMO from a well-matched and interesting theme.  
-Some concern about impact of starting hand. Certain card combinations were clearly more synergistic than others. May not be a major issue over the long run. 
-No real player interaction beyond the possibility of taking an action desired by an opponent. While the 1 person/action limit does introduce the need to take into account what other players might do, that dynamic typically plays out as securing an action you need and for which you believe you will be competing with an opponent. Actions are too precious to use them primarily to harm another player. 

Overall: An impressive effort that unfortunately just wasn't much fun to play. I felt as if I was solving a very complex but rather dry puzzle. Others in my group are agog over it, so I'll likely have additional opportunities to play and perhaps revise my rating. Maybe there's fun in there I haven't yet found.

UPDATE: After 3 plays the rating of 6 is pretty  well confirmed. After thinking about what aspect of the gameplay I found less than satisfying, I came to the conclusion that is was the fact that the heart of the game,  the many  different cards, all consist of exceptions to the rules. This strikes me as a rather inelegant way to achieve replayability and variety. I also think it contributes to the "multi-player solitaire" feel of the game. With 30 or more "special powers" in play, it becomes almost impossible to keep track of who gets what benefits in which situations, thus making it much harder to factor in opponents' possible strategies when making your own moves. I much prefer a game in which offers a greater scope for anticipating opponents' plays and countering them in ways that still benefit you. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2017 Plays: 1

RATING: N/A
[b][url=https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/BoardGameGeek_Golden_Geek#toc7]2008 Golden Geek Winner[/url][/b]

In Agricola, you're a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you'll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood, or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats?

Players:   1, 2, 3, 4, 5
Time:      30 − 150 minutes
Mechanics:  [property=2043][/property], [property=2041][/property], [property=2040][/property], [property=2082][/property]

RATING: 10
I absolutely love this game.  I've heard that some people dislike the struggle to get everything you need or want.  But the game is about farming in the 14th century, not about being a multimillionaire in the 21st.  Many choices in this worker placement game, along with the cards, create a deep game with much replayability.  Only reason it doesn't get out more is my wife isn't too fond of it.  

Purchased the Belgium Deck recently, albeit begrudgingly.  Agricola, I think, is a game that I'd rather enjoy purely in its original state.

The game is easily teachable to youngsters; my six-year-old boy is pretty good.

RATING: 7
This is a solid worker placement game.  It really is tight and cut-throat competition for worker placements, however multiple successful strategies leave it well balanced.  I actually find the farming theme rather fun because it's personalized and better than other traditional euro economic themes (gather resources, produce goods, ship goods, repeat).  

Gameplay can grow cumbersome, so it's best to encourage thinking ahead and keep it moving.

RATING: 7.5

PLUS: different cards at different levels means you will get lots of variety from just the base set
MINUS: no way to stop someone getting too far ahead, manual has text too small for some adults to read

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Nicely designed game of farm development. Take an action, acquire some resources or derive some other benefit, trade in resources for improvements. Several little mini-systems can get going and become self-supporting if you do it right (e.g., sowing fields to generate crops to feed your family). I was dealt only a couple minor improvements and occupations that I could really take advantage of, and a couple of others whose benefits I didn't understand until later in the game when it was too late. 

This game will have immense replayability for its fans because of the innumerable combinations of cards. I thought it was decent, but it didn't bowl me over. Nowhere close to matching the hype.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Reminds me of several other games, e.g. worker placement of Caylus and the unchosen actions getting more attractive by stuff being put on them as in Puerto Rico, but it still feels fresh. Like a good cube pusher Euro, it has that anxiety of 'so much to do, too little time' and 'will I get stitched up by someone else choosing the action I want if I don't choose it now?'. As for the language level, I would say that the family version is still playable for someone not knowing German if Melissa's excellent translations are used, but for the full game you really need a card translation if you don't know German (luckily I do know enough to get by ;)). My first impression is that the family version is still well worth playing though, and despite the language barrier it would probably be easier introducing the family version of Agricola than e.g. Caylus to other players. See my review for more details.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
UPDATE: 2.14.15 (cleaned up comments)

Agricola is a well-themed, engine building affair of balancing priorities and efficiency over a set number of rounds. There is variability in the cards, tension in feeding your family, and frustration when others inadvertently take actions you want. At it's best it is a challenging activity that I do not mind participating in once a year. However, I don't care for the random card draw, engine-building, indirect player interaction, and that the game funnels everyone down the same path via its negative point model. 

WIFE RATING - 5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
OK, I will violate my own rules and rate a game here after one play for the first time, given that first play was at EuroQuest over nine months ago and I have had no burning desire to play or purchase this game, that should give you some idea how I feel about this game.  It's way overrated, nowhere near as good as the "best of class" of Essen 2007, which in hindsight are Tribune, Kingsburg and Container -- three games that for some reason haven't hit the top 100.  By contrast to those very innovative designs, Agricola offers nothing new or innovative in the way of mechanisms (feels alot like Caylus), the components are surprisingly inferior (i.e., why not at least have a picture of a sheep on the item that's a sheep, a la Zooloreto?), and the 66 cards in the "basic" deck mean there's a steep learning curve and obviously a huge alot of luck in the initial card draw which kind of dictates your approach to the game.  Also, I was distressed at the lack of alternate strategies, seems to mean the main goal is to feed your people and then expand with stuff to fill all 15 spaces, again nothing new or exciting here.  Finally, there seemed to be little reason to have three types of food or three types of animals, it just made the endgame scoring go much longer than necessary.  So, in summary, why didn't I like this game more?  Three things:  1 - lack of innovative mechanisms  2 - apparent lack of alternate strategies (note this is something that may not be the case if I played it more or with some of the other decks, perhaps) 3 - lots of randomness in starting card draw that could skew the outcome, in addition, there was a 4 - steep learning curve and 5 - too long and fiddly and complicated for what it purports to be:  a simple farming game.  

Updating the comment but not changing the ratings after a couple of more plays (including my first "win") in late 2008, almost a year after the first very dissatisfying experience.  With the benefit of 20-20 hindsight, I wish my initial play had been with just the "Family Game" without the cards; scores would have been lower, but gameplay would have been much quicker.  I think taking the cards out of the equation makes the game alot less luck-dependent, maybe enough to push my rating one spot higher to a 6; but since most people are enamored with playing with all those cards (lucky or unlucky, depending on the draw), I have to stick with my initial rating of a 5.  

Bottom-line:  No way this game should be #1 or rated up there with the greatest Euros of all time, like PR, Die Macher, or Power Grid.  The collective viewpoints of the cogescenti on BGG have got this one all wrong, IMHO.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Micro-management, limited actions and worker placement.  I guess its fun to build your farm, but its just so tedious in doing it!   This really is a logistics game - long strings of actions are required to get anything done and if you mess up the planning then you are stuffed.  The scoring system means that there seems to be only way way to victory - the most 'balanced' farm (with a small amount of variation) - this is not a genuine 'multiple paths to victory' game.  Very unforgiving of mistakes.  Finally, the player interaction in Agricola is purely through the worker placement mechanism.  As such, the ONLY reason why players interact is to block other players from doing their optimal move.  That is, your turn is purely an optimisation exercise in finding the move which strikes the best balance between what benefits you the most and your opponents the least, and often that will mean simply messing up your opponent's plans rather than progressing with your own plans.  Compare (for example) Settlers Of Catan, where player interaction is largely through trading, where both players involved benefit from the deal.  Personally, I find blocking games to be far more annoying and downright nasty than games which involve direct combat (Small World, Mare Nostrum etc).  Stone Age is another worker placement game but its much more forgiving so blocking does not play such a large roll.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Who cares how you pronounce it, and yes it's about farming -- but [-]Agricola[/-] The 'Gric is actually pretty fun. I love the variability the cards offer and it scratches the CCG itch as well. I still think if you changed the theme from farming to spice harvesting on Arrakis, you might have an AT claasic. Best of all, it's the first time I've seen the Euro crowd complain that a wooden cube is not good enough. Animeeples...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fiddly with a huge initial learning curve, plenty of analysis paralysis, and a long setup/teardown time. My group will never play this. All that being said, it has plenty of depth and replayability.

Recently I have purchased a plastic organizer where I placed the common game components like the rooms, animals and resources. This simplifies the setup time greatly. Also, I sorted out the player components into bags. Now I simply give each player a bag. Without this method, the game would be far too fiddly to play very often.

After a number of games, I've come to the conclusion that there are two main factors that dictate strategy. What is everyone else doing, and what occupation and minor improvement cards you have.

Since everything but the cards are open, what everyone else chooses to do will strongly influence what you will do. In general, you do not want to be building your economic engine in the same fashion as another player at the table. If you are synchronized and follow the other player, you will likely be blocked from performing the same moves.

It is my strong impression that cards are not balanced. I sense that a skilled player with the right set of Occupation and Minor Improvement cards will rule a game. I think we'll have to move to card drafting variant in the future. But of course, this will make games even longer to setup.

Ultimately, I find that getting more workers as soon as possible is usually a very useful strategy. It is also the easiest way to score 3 points.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was the first game that I really played once I started getting into "modern boardgaming" and I loved playing this on the iPad. Can't wait to try  it out with real people!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Original + Farmers of the Moor + cards draft = Masterpiece
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I just played my 20th session of Agricola, after letting it sit for a few months. Here's my revised comment. 

[b]Quick Overview[/b]: You begin Agricola with a two-room house, an empty farmyard, and a husband and wife determined to develop the land and start a family. You play 14 turns. During these turns, each family member takes a single action. These actions include collecting resources from the commons (wood, clay, reed, fish, stone, grain, boar, cattle, sheep), building improvements on the farm (new rooms, renovating old rooms, fences for pasture, plowing fields, digging wells, constructing ovens, and fashioning lots of little improvements like spindles, axes, etc.) and lastly, learning new occupational skills / hiring help (becoming a stone-mason or a baker, hiring a wet-nurse, etc.). There are three full decks of cards for "minor improvements" and "occupations," and players are dealt a selection of 14 at the start of the game. Sounds incredibly rich and fun, right? Well, sort of. 

[b]The Upkeep[/b]: At intervals throughout the game, there are harvests when you accrue grain and veggies from the fields and breed more livestock in the pastures. During these harvests, you also have to feed your family. As your family grows, you can accomplish more on the farm, but you have to provide more food. The additional labor would quickly outpace the relatively small increases in the food requirement, allowing players to create a thriving, bustling farm too quickly, so the designer of the game decided to make the harvests come at irregular intervals. This makes no thematic sense, and is purely for game balance. The first harvest occurs after four turns, the second after three, the third, fourth, and fifth after two, and the sixth and final harvest after a single turn. The more productive your farm gets, the more pressure the game applies. 

Consequently, most of your efforts in Agricola are spent on subsistence farming. You save the occasional resource boon for a small step up. Progress is slow. The need for efficiency cannot be overstated. The name of the game is finding out how to accomplish more with fewer actions. There is little room for error. I find that my enjoyment of the game depends directly on whether or not my hand of cards enables a baking strategy. Grain is one of the only things you can begin working on early in the game, and a solid baking strategy means you've kicked the upkeep early and play around a bit more for the rest of the game. The most fun I've ever had with Agricola was incredibly card-dependent. I had the baker (occupation), the baker's oven (minor improvement) and the riding plow (minor improvement). Once the upkeep was history, I actually got to, you know, play.  

[b]Final Impression[/b]: And that's too bad. Agricola is a well-designed game. What sours me on it a bit is that it looks like there's a rich interplay of resources - lots to build and lots of cool stuff to do with it. Not really. Agricola is more like a grueling obstacle course. When I play it I feel less like I have creative options and more like I'm worried about stumbling. There's undeniable reserves of variation in the cards, but the end-game scoring conditions make every game feel much the same. It's a matter of getting a stone house "just in time." One of every animal "just in time." Covering your last empty fields "just in time." I'm frankly surprised that this has achieved the broad-based appeal that it has. Gameplay here is rigid, painstaking, and difficult. I don't get much of a rush from it. The only reason I've rated it a six is because I really enjoy a small subset of games if my opening cards allow me to do certain things. Balance isn't the problem - I realize players can usually do well with different hands. Ultimately I may trade this away, vegimeeples and all. 
[size=5]Rating updated 11/24/08.[/size] 

[size=5]2nd Update a year later - 11/22/09. Agricola was in some ways my first "fatal flaws" games. Lots to like. Lots to ruin it as well. [/size]

I Dislike:

RATING: 9
We bought this game for the farming theme and have not been disappointed.  One of the best things about it is the endless variety of play because of how many cards come in the base game.  The game does require some pretty heavy thinking though as the tension between expanding your farm while feeding your family is very tight.  You can relax a little bit when you have a good system going particularly if you have been lucky enough to find a good combo in your starting card selection.  Nevertheless, we always end up needing some scrap paper to jot down what we ideally want to do over the next round or two.  All this thinking time does add a lot to the overall game time.  Most games are very satisfying though as you transform your farm from empty land to fields and pastures and your farm house from wooden hut to stone mansion. (Or bigger hut - lol)

RATING: 10
Great game.  Tough worker placement game.  Probably the best I have played to date.  The fact that it's hard to get food at the start really keeps you on your toes.  Lots of strategy and competition.
If you don't like high pressured games, I would recommend Caverna instead.
I personally don't like to play with 5 players as it really slows down.  I think three players is great, but works well with two and four also.
We often card draft to take away the randomness.  Does add time on to the game length though.
To keep the game flowing it does really require players to think ahead whilst others are taking there turn.  Perhaps this is true for all games......
Modern classic game.  Perhaps it isn't as good as Go.

RATING: 8.6
After only one play of the solitaire game I need much more. There are so many things to do in this game, but they all creep up to you very slowly.  I think this is a game that will be easy to teach to newbies, but will satisfy the needs of the more experienced players in our group.  Can't wait to play this some more!

Edit 09/09/08
WOW!!  This game IS better than Puerto Rico.  So many elements of so many games all packaged into one seamless little system. It's beautiful.  Everyone I have played this with has wanted to play again; immediately!  And this is only the family version.  There's so much to do and think about, I can't wait to introduce the cards into the mix.  Just stunning.  A well deserved victor and certainly the best game I've ever played.  
  the only element that is missing is player interaction or combat.  But the way the actions are chosen, you feel like sometimes yo uare steeling from another player.  This will get many many more plays, and I fear that Puerto Rico will begin collecting dust.

Edit 01/10/08
Have now played nearly a dozen games ranging from 2 to 5 players.  This game is a corker!  It's only limitation, that I can see, is that when very experienced players play against each other, then everyones strategies will collide.  And the game will then come down to who is the luckiest when they take the starting player.  But I think that's pretty minor.  further, I have seen a good strategy beat a VERY strong hand.  So the cards do not necesarily swing the game.  they help, but they're not everything.  This game is AWESOME!

Edite 19/11/09
After nearly 4 months since my last play I have no choice but to drop my rating of this game.  It's too long to get any sort of regular play in and takes far too long to explain to people. Stone age is now my top choice.

RATING: 6
Our second ever purchase.

While I enjoyed this game,  my wife did not take to it. She found the game to be remarkably similar from play to play (always wanting for wood at the beginning, rushing to expand the family as soon as possible, etc., etc).  There's not really a  variety of strategies to be played here - even with the cards -  it's mainly only the order of events that change from game to game.

All of which taught me an important lesson about luck when it comes to games to play with my wife. It's not that she doesn't think strategically, it's that with games such as this where there is little to no interaction between players, there is no outside influence to interfere with your plans. Yes, you can put your family member into a space before I do - but that really isn't going to break the game for me. At least with games with dice or other luck-based mechanics, there's the possibility that I'll have some terrible rolls, or hers will be great, and she'll get the upper hand.

It all comes down to the fact that we're supposed to be relaxing together playing "games". There are ups and downs and excitement when things are unpredictable - and that makes games fun for us. Playing Agricola doesn't have the excitement; isn't the kind of game that leaves lasting memories. In the end, for us it feels less like a game and more like an "excercise".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
100+ plays.

+ Incredible depth.  Players continually get better after 5, 50, or 500 games
+ Excellent replay value, due to variety of occupations and improvements (+new cards), high variety of winning strategies
+ Excellent pacing (gets more intense as the game progresses)
+ Very high skill, little (but not zero) luck
+ Scales beautifully with 2-5 players
+ Quality and quantity of components 

- Unforgiving / not for casual gamers.
