RATING: 7.5
A really good game where you have to make a lot of interesting decisions. But it is intimidating and sometimes exhausting. There are so many options, starting with the 14 different cards for every player and every one of these can change the way you plan to develop your farm. When playing this game I often do not feel like I'm achieving or building something, but just struggle to survive the best possible way. And in every round I heard every player say at least once :"Mmh, I should have done this differently ...".
A lot of options, tough decisions, clever mechanics -> great game. I really like to play it, but would never play two rounds of it in a row.

RATING: 9
I've played mostly two player, but I really like how you can't always do everything you want on a turn. Very interesting choices to be made every turn.

RATING: 6
Played solo and 3-player. I see what the hype is about. I REALLY enjoyed it. I feel the cards do shake things up and make every game different, but at the same time COULD give one player an edge over another. That said, I think the card variants at the end of the rulebook are sufficient to get around this.

I think the beauty of the game is that it has those clean euro mechanics and yet is dripping with theme. Rarely done in the Euro world. Kudos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Even playable solo but I like it best with 4 players. It's not unusual to struggle through the whole game and ending up with the feeling that you didn't accomplish much. So much the better is the satisfaction when a strategy works out and a game ends with a well-developed farm.

The strength of Agricola for me is the multitude of available cards for professions and acquisitions which make every game unique. A bad starting hand can decide the game against a player when the opponents are of equal skill.

I would choose Agricola over Caverna due to the variable cards anytime. I guess, many others prefer a more balanced, less random and learnable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Otro juego económico. Tiene algunas mecánicas interesenantes como la asignación de trabajadores y la ocupación de las acciones disponibles, el incremento de familia (más acciones por ronda), la necesidad de dar de comer a la familia, la acumulación de recursos, etc. Se penaliza la sobre-especialización, tienes que conseguir puntos en todos los apartados. Las cartas de mejoras menores y profesiones hacen que las partidas sean distintas entre sí pero también más dependientes de la suerte. El número de rondas fijo y la necesidad de alimentar a la familia mantiene la tensión del juego. Es susceptible de analisis-paralisis y downtime (como la mayoría de juegos económicos).

UPDATE: cada vez me gusta más la versión familiar. Sin usar las cartas el juego es mucho más rápido y menos dependiente de la suerte.

FUNDAS: No enfundado. Harían falta 360 fundas Mayday Eurogame o TBG Size 4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wow. Just played a two player family version. There's a lot to soak in. It was fun but dear lord was it hard to get from the instructions. We watched 2 different youtube videos after reading the instructions and had to read the instructions again afterward. It took us like 1.5 hours from when we had everything out of the wrap and when we finally finished the first move. And there was 14 more to do after that! It was an enjoyable game, but I'm just not as impressed as I should be. It's theme is just so-so, though I really liked the Animeeples for the livestock (just purchased new). For the third rated game on BGG, I was expecting to be blown away, not confused slightly bored. Maybe this will change when I update after playing with the included decks.

Update:  The app made this one a home run for me. Takes care of all the maintanance and I can play the game in a decent amount of time. I think the game plays better online because the game is stressful in person. As of now: Agricola if we are all hardcore gamers that play very fast, but Caverna in any other appropriate circumstance.

Next (and maybe final) update: This game has everything. At first glance from the uninitiated it is complex and has obtuse scoring. With repeated play, it is a masterpiece. No other game offers the same permutations of long term strategies, formed through the in-depth analysis, and preferably drafting, of cards. Tactical decisions and improvisation take over from the initial draft, and the game is a home run. The interaction is perfect, the expansions add infinity to infinity, and the theme is represented as well as can be within the confines of a board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Trade version in German.

RATING: 5
4th April 2010
Absolutely fantastic.  Wasn't convinced on my first game, scoring only 15 points (how embarrassing). I failed to appreciate how important it is to feed your family and felt pressured all game.  However, it has grown on me very quickly.  I play Puerto Rico and Power Grid plus a plethora of other games and heartily rate this a 10.  Fabulous 2 player game.  Fantastic with more.  What my gaming club loves is that it plays within 60 - 90 minutes no matter what.  There are lots of things to do and you have to have 2 or 3 options up your sleeve. The cards for the different decks are great but you should limit yourself to playing only 2 or 3 as we've found that you tend to waste family member actions on getting them out while other players get ahead by plowing fields, sowing, building fences, etc. Fun.

21Dec10 - Still love this game. What a fantastic 2 player! I like multiplayer too. We have become quite wary of the cards. You really can fall behind if you focus on them too much. 2 or 3 out over the course of play seems adequate.

3 Jan 13 - Have downgraded from a '10' to '7.5'. Still great but not playing it as much. One problem is that it's not easy to get the cards out if you're playing decks. Trying to get professions out, etc, will mean that you fall behind elsewhere.

22 Oct 14 - Haven't seen this on the table for a long time. Lots of newer games that we prefer. Shipyard, Stone Age, even good ol' Puerto Rico is better. Rate a 5.

RATING: 10

This game is really growing on me, and I am working on convincing my fiancée that we need to play this more often. It has a good theme, lots of variety, and is a lot of fun. The only downside is the poor quality components, but there are plenty of third party alternatives available.

RATING: 6
I'm feeling a whole lot of meh out of the gate. Initial rating: 5 for a 3-player learning game.

Update: 2nd game bumps this up to a 6, even though it was a verrry long 5-player learning game (3 brand-new players). I felt I got junk for cards and had to scrounge for subsistence the whole game. Still, there were moments there where I started to see why people like it. I'm hoping for experienced players and/or fewer players next time for a "better" read.

Update 2: After playing a four-player at the advertised speed (30 min/player), I'm not convinced I'll ever like this. This probably says more about me, my tastes, and my admittedly low competence in that kind of thinking ahead and synergizing.

Update 3 (12/11/08): Traded away. There are plenty of copies around, anyway, if I want to play this again, which I doubt I will.

Update 4 (1/31/14): Bought it again, enjoyed it better now that I'm not taking it as seriously. Bumping up rating to 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was really surprised at how difficult the "family" version of the game was - it was a tough fight just to keep your family fed!  Agricola has a very fun theme which is well implemented.  As everyone says, the huge number of cards improves the long term replayability.  I guess the central mechanisms are not really anything new, but this seems to be my favorite "worker placement" game yet.  A hallmark of German-type games seems to be the situation of having so many things you want to do on your turn, yet so few opportunities to do it.  Agricola has this feeling more than any other game - I would imagine that the competition is very tight with experienced players.  I look forward to exploring this game further.

Update 2/08: This game has indeed proven its worth.  It has preoccupied my gaming group for months now, players often want to play again right after finishing to see what they can do differently the second time around.  I've also had success teaching it to casual gamers and even my mom and sister.

The cards definitely provide a lot of variety, but also the simple availability of resources/playing spaces.  Sometimes, due to turn order or other player's styles, you may be forced into a particular strategy that you did not anticipate.  

It is unusual to find a game this compelling - it's a definite winner and probably one of the strongest contenders of my 9's to become an eventual 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Very mechanical, very fiddly, and a little overwhelming in the number of actions. Its very hard to see a clear path to victory because this game penalizes specialization and rewards doing poorly in different fields. It never feels like you get to enjoy advancing your farm (or managing it the way you want to) as you do rushing to take actions before someone takes them from you.

Honestly, I do feel the game is overhyped. For this sort of Caylus-style game, I still think Pillars and AOEIII are better examples of games in the genre.

[2 years later]
I think the problem I have with the game is that every player's strategy (if you want to win) is to do the exact same thing. Early game: get some occupations, get a new family member. Mid game: feed the kids, collect resources. End game: Fill up your farm with whatever you can. There is no variety in game plan. The tension is in recovering from what the other players do to you (by blocking your actions). As such, I still consider it a far inferior game to others like Le Havre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Our group has at least 15 plays of this now, usually with 4 players.  We have yet to use anything but the basic deck and are just fine with that. The extra decks are like a prebuilt expansion.

Most games are decided with less than 3 points, sometimes only 1 point with a tie at second.  There's a lot going on here, and it keeps us coming back.

Edit: We only don't play this as much now due to the growing collections of myself and another player.  We don't dislike it overall it just doesn't see much time anymore
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
As I've mentioned in other game comments, I'm not a huge fan of overly complicated non-sequitor rules, or rules without a wholistic feel to them. Agricola reminds me a little of Endeavour in regards to it's placement and resource management, but feels more unified and less abstract - My game group explained Agricola to me, and though the rules SEEMED abstract and "more of the same," I was up and running with a limited but planned breeding strategy about 15 minutes into my first session.

The game is a blast. It takes awhile to play - we were pushing 3 hours with 5 players, but at no point was I ever bored. The game also seemes to have enough random variety per session to maintain good long term play value. Agricola can be played competetively (ie. attempting to screw over the other homesteads by squating on resources they might need), but if you're not into that style of play, you'll also do just fine concentrating on gathering your own nuts and building your nest.

Some of the rules are headscratchers - 

For example, if you have plenty of wood resource, why are you limited to building only as many fences as your piece-count allows? If I have the actual wood resource, why can't I keep building?

And why do i have to wait until much later in the game in order to bunk up family members in the same house? Realistically, shouldn't that happen first?

I'd also think this game could benefit from a lite trading component (a la Settlers), but it's hard to tell how well that would work without it changing the gameplay substantially.

Meh. Minor quibbles with an overall great game.

Agricola also has a "family mod" which removes some of the more complicated elements (occupations and homestead improvements), and if you have little ones in your play group, i'd reccommend keeping it with this limted version. Regardless, the game teaches the value of planning ahead, organization, and management, and if you're also a teacher looking for a completely non-violent, constructive game for your classroom, I'd strongly consider this (just mind the heaps of cards and parts). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 9
A farming game with an incredibly tight gameplay; this is one of those 'want-to-do-everything-but-don't-have-enough turns' sort of game. Some people might be turned off by the tightness that is prevailing throughout the whole game, but nevertheless I keep coming back for more, asking myself, "Can I score better than last time?". The variety of worker & minor improvement cards also helps elevate this game's longitivity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Raised the rating to 10 from 9 after about 30 games.

+Very thematic euro.
+Cards and the randomness of stage card order give great variance to strategies and replayability.
+Because of the previous point, there is a lot to learn. Gives MtG-feelings.
+The amount of options and strategies given by cards is immense.
+The game is tense, demanding and makes your brain physically hurt.

-Some cards are imbalancingly good, i recommend using the ban list used in play-agricola.com
-The game makes your brain physically hurt.

RATING: 8
I was pretty overwhelmed when I played my first two games, and they took a long time.  In the third game, I played the "family" version with my wife and son and things came together a bit more.  In the first couple of games, I pretty much ignored the major improvements because they were too far away from me and the translation was hard to read (or missing).  I finally understood those cards.  I would definitely recommend playing your first game using the family game rules with fewer number of people (3 is pretty good).  It is good to get down the first couple of games using the family rules before tackling the occupation cards and the minor improvements.

Definitely a buy when the English version comes out.

RATING: 5
Agricola was interesting the first few times I played it but I gradually got tired of the length and the overwhelming power of some cards relative to others. I would much prefer a deck of 30 reasonably balanced cards to hundreds of wildly unbalanced ones. I also think there is too much downtime. I now will only play if someone else insists. Among the Caylus style games I much prefer the original and Stone Age (a 9 and a 10 for me) because the decisions are quick, meaningful, and tactical whereas Agricola is slow and emphasizes long term strategy.

RATING: 4

However, discovering other WPs made me understand how terribly I hated this game, especially the feeling of despair that comes with it. It feels likes work, but not fulfilling work like I do at my 9-5 job, but terrible menial work, with pay so low I'm hoping to stay alive. Much, much too tight, and I hate playing for 2h before finally feeling like I'm ready to do something. This game should start on turn 10 and then end on turn 20: oh, that game already exists, and is named Caverna.

RATING: 9
Even interesting in solitaire mode IMO (despite sometimes you are at risk of the card draw).

The one mechanic I dislike is the Starting Player token and turn order based on where you sit at the table relative to other people greatly affects your chances with the game. Especially when the person to your left is more likely to take starting player than the ones on your right.

I have had a hard time introducing this game to people due to length.

It also plays horribly as a 3 player game, as two people will probably conflict more than the other one (who will run away with it). Usually decided mid-game who will end up winning.

However in the last few 3 man games we have played that might not have been the case. Maybe it is because one of the 3 is still learning?

Still one of my favorite games to play, even as a solitaire game.

RATING: 6
I must be one of the very few people who isn't completely gung-ho about this game. Here's why: 

First: I always feel like I am just about to get really started playing this game when it ends (I happen to have the same issue with Puerto Rico - don't hit me! :p ). 

Second: It is so hard to play any of the cards due to a constant lack of resources. There are so many cards in this game and I feel you never really get to play them. 

Third: I absolute hate the artwork :) I disagree with the folks out there who say that artwork is not important, to me it is vital. Maybe because I'm a photographer and aesthetics count a lot for me (occupational hazard I guess). 

Undoubtedly a good game, but I happen not to like it a lot. I have my eye on Caverna, since it's supposed to fix a lot of the issues I have with Agricola (not so hard to feed your family / dwarfs), better artwork etc.

RATING: 9.5
well, some of his mechanics opened the way for really great games and it's brillant even today (2013). the interaction between players is minimum, it's just a race for common actions (like most games with a board for each player). it's perfectly coherent with his setting and is a really astonishing one. the score sistem is very cool and balanced, forces you to do a little bit of everything. cards are A LOT and you will never play a similar game. on the other side the cards are really too many to be balanced and some good combo allow a match of experienced players to be won by the one with better cards. that's a pity for a game that, otherwise, it's totally luckless. you can play the game without cards, but hey, it gets really stripped. these are flaws that i really feel because the game has a really long setupping and playing time. other that that... you're seeding your fields and you can hold a sheep in your house... could you not love it?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fantastic game - Definitely Placement of Caylus meets the planning and stress of In the Year of the Dragon.

A game that deserves the hype. Perhaps a drafting system would work to strengthen the cards you are holding would work nicely.  Initial Rating a 8.5

Update: Reduced rating to an 8 - Is it good? Yes. Is it great? I don't think so. All and all I think it is a future classic that most who consider themselves boardgamers should get. I do believe there is an inherent flaw designed into the game. It's the cards. It's not that one is more over-powered than the other, it's that the cards are different. Thus inherently as a player you will receive bonuses individual to only you throughout the game. 

Now, you could go ahead and do whatever strategy you like, and hope for the best. Or you can play toward the bonuses you acquired. If you did this you have a greater chance at winning the game, and so does everyone else who does this. It balances the game out - you have your benefits, and I have mine. 

The defect comes into play here. The "leading" for strategy - or being overly scripted. You are free to construct a different strategy than what you have - you just will not win. This makes the game too simple strategically. 

Tactically it is full of goodies - but is that enough to bring it past a good game. I say no. It must have both to be in the realm of greatness. I will enjoy this one - but it is not the best of the best.

Update: Wow - to fall so far so fast! It's a real shame but with the Strategic Leading it really kills this game for me. Every player has this basic strategy: Get more people and enough food to feed them for each Harvest. The other strategy is practically based on the cards you get - if you get the best set and can implement them the most efficiently you win! That's it and it's kinda boring. Rerated to a 6

Update: Played again - Boring! Just slow and mechanical. No thank you! Rerated to a 5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Good worker placement game. One of the prime examples of worker placement games.
It spawned tropes/recurring themes like "always have to feed your people", "getting more workers is the dominant strategy", etc.

I like the cards, they give the game a lot of variety and replayability. I dislike the cards because there are some absolutely bonkers cards in there but also a lot of very boring ones.

I like the game. But prefer pretty much any other worker placement game over this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Update 3: Have played this solo a number of times now. Obviously, this is one of my favorites, and being that I'd have a hard time having to choose between a game of the 'Gric and anything else, even my precious Struggle of Empires, I'm going to have to give this a 10. I just can't think of anything I don't like about it.

[Update: While I was reluctant to admit it, because there's no map, no armies, and no mayhem, this game is fantastic. It always feels exceptionally tight, and there are many, many paths to victory, most of which are available regardless of the card pulls, though those can have a serious effect. There are some deadly combos in here, though, so beware; one of the most interesting things about the game is that those cards and combos aren't necessarily the ones you expect - the Mendicant can be as powerful as the Wet Nurse, and watch out if someone finds a good way to turn clay into food!

An extraordinarily nuanced game, one of my GeekBuddies says in his review that it's the hardest he's ever played - and I concur. Packed into a fairly straightforward engine is complexity the likes of which you just don't see everywhere. The action drafting can be really tough - it's really painful when you think you know exactly what your opponents are going to do, and then they surprise you.

Another interesting thing about Agricola is the level of cockteasing that goes on with the cards. You usually only get to play three or four in any given game, so you keep wanting to play over and over again, just so you can finally land that plow or that occupation on the table...]

Well, OK. Now that I own this (albeit in German), I need to play it while stone cold sober.

DO NOT, I repeat DO NOT make the same mistake I did, and try this any other way for the first time.

RATING: 8.5
With Farmers of Moor this is one of the best games out there.
Theme might be boring for some people, but mechanisms are brilliant.

Needs alternative rules for occupations and minor improvements as the game becomes a luck fest with normal rules.

I simply don't understand the people who complain about the point cap for every category in the game.
It's a brilliant rule that forces people to tackle all the problems and does not allow heavy exploitation of specific cards/mechanisms to enable a single winning strategy.
Also, it's the MAIN goal of the game; to have a DIVERSE farm. IMO It's quite silly to complain about that.

High replay value game. Worth every cent
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
What immediately stood out to me when I began through the rules the first night of owning the game was how well thought out it was.  The fact that there a few pages dealing with how each card operates specifically shows that lots of the kinks have been thoroughly worked through.  I really thought it was great how there is a family addition and the regular just by flipping one of the boards over.  This game is not something you play a few times and figure out.  It has more re-playability than any other board game I have come across so far while maintaining a great theme and engaging mechanics. 

I really feel like I got my money's worth with this game.  So much replayabilty!

RATING: 8
[b]Likes[/b]
Thematic 
Rules are easy to teach and pickup
Minor improvement and occupation cards are the flavour of the game
Cool bits with massive number of cards for replayability
Well balanced with just the right amount of tactics and strategy involved
Solo play, when noone wants to 

[b]Dislikes[/b]
5 player games can drag on for a really long time
Family game gets stale fast, so play with the minor improvement and occupation cards
Knowledge and synergy of cards important, newbies will be clueless
Overwhelming number of bits, requires big playing area

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A current favorite.  Huge replayability with all the occupation and minor improvement cards, and a tremendous depth of strategy.  You will have to plan ahead to do well, and it is very satisfying to pull off a move that has been many turns in the making.  Theme is not of particular importance to me, but I find the theme in this game to be aid in both its accessibility (enticing people to play the game in the first place), and as a mnemonic to help remember a lot of the intricate rules.

the main criticism i have read - that the scoring system does not encourage specialization and so everyone's farm looks alike at the end - i have not found to be true at all.  in my experience, typically you ARE specialized in something during the midgame (e.g. animal husbandry, baking), and then the endgame is a scramble to try and grab all those things you've been neglecting.  this creates and adds to the tension in the game since you're all competing over the same finite supply of resources.

approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  15
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players: 1-5
Time: 120 minutes
Players compete to create the best farm. there are limited resources and workers must be managed. The theme of this game seems to be rather shallow on the surface, but the game is extremely enjoyable. There are lots of important decisions to make throughout the game. There is also a random element in how resources become available and which occupations are available each game.

RATING: 10
Somehow I got sucked into the BGG hype and ordered Agricola through the Z-Man preorder. After a few months of attempting to read the rules I was pretty worried I wouldn't like the game and even considered selling off my preorder. Fortunately I was absolutely wrong...dead wrong. This is the best game I've ever played and I honestly don't expect that to change. The game is so different and unique every time. I love trying to find ways to make perfect card combinations only to find out that the game is about one or two rounds too short for my plan.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Lowered rating. There are a lot of things I like about Agricola: the sense of building something up from nothing, the gardening/surviving theme, and the intricacies of the card effects within that theme (like being able to keep bees or trim hedges and thereby produce more food or create more enclosures). But the sense that I get when playing it is one of pressure to perform rather than a self-directed sense of accomplishment. Instead of being able to sit back and contemplate with pleasure the many options available, forming ideas about how to build up my little plot, every turn I feel like I'm just trying not to drown. The begging chips are just looming over me. And the negative points at the end for not having the proper variety of animals/crops does not cause me to do better than I would have or increase my enjoyment of the game. A good game should allow you to have a chance at winning using a vast number of different strategies, some of which the designer may never even have thought up. It should just work so well that it accommodates new and creative paths. So a vegan farm, or an all-sheep farm, or a family that has very little land but succeeds through barter, or one that makes its living through its members being specialists who entertain or provide services in town--all these should have an equal shot at victory. But with the rules the way they are, there seems to be just one "right" way for your farm to be at the end, and if you deviate from it, then woe betide you. For that reason, I don't enjoy Agricola as much as I enjoy other building-up games like Stone Age or [thing=278][/thing] Game. If you want something of equivalent weight, [thing=102680][/thing] is within a tenth of a point of Agricola's using BGG's rating system, but Trajan rewards you for the positive things you do rather than punishing you for failing to toe the line.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Builder game centered around farming.

The Good: Fun heavy strategy game. Several different strategies to pursue. The special cards for occupations and minor improvements give you even more options each turn. I think with experienced players it would clock in around 2 hours. Reminds me a little of Caylus - but better and faster. 

The Bad: There is a chance for some degree of analysis paralysis - due to the large number of options available during your turn. However, early turns have fewer options. Potential for new players to be lost. However this can be dealt with by playing the family game first and make sure they understand early in each stage the importance of feeding their people. Final scoring is rather complicated - but there is a player aid. I like a game where completely different strategies can win, but so far I am wondering if that is true with this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Edit: My rating seems to go up and down with this game.  I think it's settled on a 4 or 5.  I just think it's a LOT of work to get a good food machine going and when you don't have the right card combos to help you do that, it can be way too frustrating.  Plus, whoever has the wet nurse will be at too much of an advantage. But the real problem is a feeling that I just can't shake and that's you have very little impact on anyone else and that bugs me.  However good or bad your opponent's score was had nothing to do with anything I did.  Another thing that kills this game for me is "drafting" of cards.  This takes way too long. Just pass out the cards randomly and let me try to figure out how to best use them. I really have no desire to play this game again and if it hits the table (which it ALWAYS does at game night) I'll take a pass and go see a movie instead.

Edit: raised my rating again, from 6 to 7.  Not sure what I missed the first times I played, but now I am truly enjoying it.  I also realize that an astute player can really screw with other players, making the game much less multiplayer solitaire than I initially thought.  

edit:  Raised my rating from 3 to 6.  Played with five and for the first time, I enjoyed it.  I never had trouble feeding my family and ended the game with a full farm and plenty of animals, scoring my best score ever.   Perhaps my low rating was because I always do poorly? Perhaps, but I strongly dislike the lack of player interaction. Still, I think this game could grow on me.

Played four times and liked it less with each play. Three seems harsh, but it's exactly how I feel (likely won't play again but could possibly be convinced...my game group loves it so unless I can negotiate for another game to hit the table I might be stuck playing). 

I can see why some people like this game.  Too me, it's just too much work.  Like actually farming.  With worker placement, you are in direct competition for spots on the board.  Yet for some reason, I really felt like I was just playing a game by myself.  I was struggling to build my own farm so much so that I couldn't be bothered even caring about anyone else's farm.  And you really get the sense that there is nothing you can do to stop other people from scoring points.

RATING: 10
So much has been written about Agricola. Perfect theme integration, tight gameplay, mild but present screwage factor, perfect mixture of predictable and non-predictable elements and replayability for ages.

If, and that's a big if, there's one thing that could have been better, it's the possibility of meta-gaming. Settlers is a little bit more "talkative".

Update: Played it again lately and schooled some friends that never played Agricola as competetive than I did. It's still all about the first kid in round 5 to 7 and good management with the minor improvements (to grab the starting player when you need it ;) ), but you know, with players that know this as well, Agricola is still only comparable to Terry Mystica (or Gaia Project, let's see..) when it comes to great competition against up to 4 opponents where your brain melts, your heart races and you just have great, great fun. Boardgaming at its best.

RATING: 8
It evokes the theme well, in that I feel like I'm suffering horrible crushing poverty when I play it. It's almost a bit too stressful, but I do want to play more. I like that the main engine doesn't suffer much positive feedback like many similar games, it simply produces points and food.

I'm not convinced by the cards, which make it very hard to keep track of other players' abilities and incentives unless you learn all of them by heart or keep pausing the game to read them. Neither of these options is much fun. Update: I'm even more convinced by this now. The cards detract from the actual game, unless you play it very regularly.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent, Age of Empires-type (the computer version) game of resource management and action-taking. Each player has an empty farm of 15-spaces, two people, and a 2-room hut. You have fourteen turns to completely build up your farm or lose VPs (-1VP per empty space). The house can be built bigger and the family can get up to 5-people in size. The rest of the space is taken up with stables, fields to be plowed, sown, and harvested, and fenced-in pastures. Animals can be obtained, occupations can be learned that give benefits, and improvements obtained that garner VPs and still more benefits. The beauty of this this game is that each player gets a hand of seven each unique Occupations and Improvements that they can purchase each game, so no two games are alike. Buy the right combination of Improvements and Occupations and you will get lots of Food and VPs. This is not the typical, abstract, brain-dead Euro. It is a very deep game with tons of strategy and even more difficult choices. Due to the large number of Occupations and Improvements available (there is a total of 360-cards of all types), no two games will ever play the same.  Players are in effect, relearning how to play the game each time they are dealt their card hand. Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Traded for Web of Power
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Downgraded from '9' having since acquired Fields of Arle.  The arbitrary timing constraints of the Agricola actions cards now seem quite irksome.

RATING: 5.5
One play was not enough to understand the hype. I mean, it seems okay-ish. A frustrating game, as you always want to do a lot more things than you actually can do. Seems to favor the guy that was dealt cards that complement each other. I like the aesthetics, but I don't understand why this knocked sliced bread off the top of the list.

Four plays is enough to know that this is a really annoying game, in which one can never even come close to getting the engine going before the game ends. It is like a girl flirting and teasing and suggesting, and then saying goodnight right when she knows you're so worked up that you aren't going to get any sleep at all.

A lot of cards seem to offer really helpful benefits that you'll never get to use because it takes the whole game just to get the card onto the table. It fascinates me that so many folks find this great rather than irritating, but hey, there you go.

RATING: 7.1

Even after many plays, I have still not dug very far into the "I" and "K" decks.  So my views are primarily based on the E deck.

The luck of the draw doen't particularly bother me, but it is clear some combos are much nicer than others.  

Now hard to wish to play when Caverna sits on the same shelf.

RATING: 7
I love the theme and how the mechanics supports it. Also the animeeples are a definite plus. While causal gamers tend to be intrigued by the design of this game they also tend to be overwhelmed by its complexity and length of gameplay. For the committed gamer it might be a little to random and therefore they tend to prefer Caylus instead. 

Farmers of the Moor adds to the overall appeal and mechanic of the game. But it also adds time and complexity to the game play. I would suggest you only get it if you play Agricola frequently and you look for even more variation in game play.

RATING: 7
An amazingly intricate worker-placement game with an exceedingly well-integrated farming theme.  Lots has been written about this game, and most of it is true.  The variety of having 14 individual cards adds incredible variety and replayability to the game, but it's still the core mechanics and actions that make it so fun and interesting.  The only "down side" of the game for me is that it wears me out to play, so I'll rarely play multiple games back-to-back (unlike many of my fellow gamers at my FLGS).

RATING: 8
This is a great game. The mechanics are tight and when playing with card drafting, there does not seem to be one specific path to victory. 

While I very much enjoy this game, beware, it's stressful. The feed your family mechanic can be very draining and you may spend the entire game trying to dig yourself out of a hole. (If you know anything about farming, this might be very thematic...).

Play with the cards, and draft the cards and this will be an awesome game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Overall a decent game.

Several times in the game players felt like they either had no good choice to make when placing workers or were slowed by analysis paralysis.  Neither of those is good in my opinion.

The scoring seems a bit convoluted and complicated - time consuming to track your own score let alone anyone else's score.

The first few turns seem to take forever and accomplish very little until the proper action cards are available.  The end of the game seems to come just as people are getting their farms going.

Right now I like Caylus and Stone Age better than Agricola for the "worker placement" games.

RATING: 5
When I play this game the base mechanics make me feel like I am playing through a simulation of an excel spreadsheet.  When I add in the cards, it makes the game a lot more interesting, but brutally random since some players will get a hand of highly synergistic cards that let them get much more out of every action than typical, while the other players will have a hand of mutually contradictory garbage that makes it impossible to compete.

Games like that are okay, if they are short, but when the game last 3+ hours, that sort of randomness is not interesting to me.  Some will love it, and clearly do.

RATING: 8
Great blend of different game designs. Other than the start player mechanics which have the potential to lead to some unbalance in 4-5 player games, a top placement/resource collection/path to victory planning game. I like playing with 4 or less. Forcing a somewhat balances approach with the many scoring parameters  seems to result in a close game (in most cases) at the end and also adds to some uncertainty as to where each person is in the standings. Card variety is a big part of its high rating but can also be the difference in a game with similarly skilled players.

RATING: 6.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Very little interaction, as the only way to influence other players is through the action drafting. The game is designed in such a way trying to block opponents is sub-optimal, as it's generally better to pursue your own goals.

Action drafting aside, the game is a pure optimization activity of snowball economies, where every player is on his own, giving life to its own farm, and lasts far too long for what it offers. Would rate higher if a game with newbies could be reliably finished in an hour or less.

I see the appeal it has, particularly for those who love low conflict games, but this is definitely not for me. Not a bad game though, and will play if asked.

RATING: 10
Intriguing complex strategy game in which you develop your near empty farmyard into a booming farm with pastures full of cattle and lots of crops on your fields. The farming theme fits remarkably well with the game mechanics. *** Recommended to start with the family game during a learning session. The full game adds sets of occupation and minor improvement cards which increases the complexity of the game, but also ensures a rich variability in possible game scenarios. *** Closest victory: 3 players tied with 30 points and me with 31 points (K-deck on 25/12/2013) *** Played: Family Game: 2-player (p2/w2), 3-player (p2/w2), 4-player (p5/w3) & 5-player (p3/w1) / Full game with E-deck: 3-player (p4/w2), 4-player (p6/w3) & 5-player (p7/w5) / Full game with I-deck: 3 player (p1/w0) & 4-player (p3/w3) / Full game with K-deck: 3-player (p6/w5) & 4-player (p6/w6).

RATING: 7
Its a good game but I think clearly over rated. 

Caylus did a better job at pretty much the same thing a couple of years ago. Caylus may take a little too long but Agricola offsets that by having much longer set up/pack up times and more general fiddliness during play.

Also Caylus feels at least somewhat interactive whereas Agricola feels largely solitaire with any actually screwage being completely incidental.

I prefer the family game to advanced one. I don't really see how the minor improvements and occupations add anything to the game other than AP and imbalance.

RATING: 8
n
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Agricola is an aggravating, yet interesting worker placement game. In it there are several rounds and during each round you place your worker(s) in certain spots to perform duties such as chop wood, gather animals, cook food, etc. much like a typical worker placement game. However, there are so many goals you have to accomplish that its nearly impossible to do them all, especially if you are playing with 3 or more people. You will get minus points if you don't get a certain amount of animals, buildings, food, etc. What makes the matters worse if the rounds fly by so fast that you have very little opportunity to complete needed tasks. Also, you are required to feed your people which requires you to get food - IMO one of the hardest aspects of the game. 

If you havent played it, give it a shot, but I wouldn't really recommend buying it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

If I wanted to play something where I was worried about my next meal came from I would go back to my college days, or those really bad times when my parents were too proud to go on welfare growing up. 

I wish it was more enabling like Le Havre or harvest moon.

RATING: 8
essen 2007. language level 2 (3). Lots of different cards with much text on them but the cards don't change when the game is started.

great 2 player game.

I believe this is a number one candidate.

Edit: first comment was typed pre-essen 07
today 2008-08-03 replayed someones solo game
to get a feel for the game.

I am a bit worried that the rules are a bit too much to interpret correctly. Certainly so if I want to explain the game to my friends.
There are a huge amount of things to do in your turn. So many infact that this game can turn into a real brainburner for the AP crowd. So my main concern is that you have to plan far ahead. In order to do so you have to have a couple of games under your belt. The friends I play with are not real gamers and I think this will not be fun for them as they don't know what they are doing.

I think it is a brilliant game. Don't get me wrong and I still think this will be the future number one. 
I have to get some more solo plays in before I can introduce this to my friends. Puerto Rico is much easier to explain I feel because there aren't as many options to do each turn.

Rating will go up in time. 

Edit 2017 rating rethink.
Downgrade from 8.99 to 8.
There are games that I like more and it hasn't hitthe table in 2016. 
Eager to play Caverna and a feast for Odin.

RATING: 9
After only one game played in which we were learning the game I can tell already this is an excellent game.  No luck involved, just a lot of strategy.  It comes with a ton of cards that you don't have to use all at once so each game will be different.  And while you are playing against the other players it doesn't feel so "cut-throat."  Sure there's opportunities to notice what the other players are doing and thwart them, but with so few, precious actions available each turn you won't spend much time doing that.  I'm already envisioning how I want to play next time.
Update: Bumped my rating up to 9 after another play.  I remember thinking after my first game, "how the heck are you supposed to fill up all those spaces" but with a good strategy I managed to do so my second game.  Its hard not to love this game with so much originality and so many options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Agricola is a pure worker placement game, one of the king of the Eurogame genre.

This could make it hard to play for beginners and a game only for hardcore players, but that's not the case. 2 things helps new players get into the game :
- The theme, which is very engaging
- The "Need to feed my family" mechanic. A new player will always know that they at least need to do that. This goal will guide and ease them into the game. They probably won't win against experienced players, but at least they will be active for the whole game.

Even the first play will be enjoyable, because contrary to many others game in the genre, you always have a goal and therefore knows what to do. This feeling that the game is pushing me to play is something unique to this game, that I like very much. It's the only economic game that I dare propose to players which aren't big fans of such games.

Of course, for fan of the genre, the game is also great, with a very interesting scoring mechanism (having to score in every category is hard), a card system which make each play different, and lot of possibilites and competition between the players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game is long, complicated, and at times stressful. However, that somehow works out extremely well in Agricola. Aside from the hand you're dealt at the start, there isn't much of a luck factor. The opportunity-cost factor, however, is prominent all game long.

Do you take the three wood now? Or do you take another job you need, and hope that nobody else takes the wood so you can nab it next round when it's 6? They could have called this game, "Tragedy of the Commons," although it probably wouldn't have sold well.

Plus the bits and pieces all neat, and there are literally hundreds of unique ability cards. Can't go wrong there!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.65
One of the few heavier euros that I have successfully played as a gateway game. It's amazing how a simple worker-placement mechanism tied with farming simulation can be so engaging! I love that there are so many different cards bringing variety to each game. 

On the negative side, it seems as if early family growth is needed to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my first worker placement games and one I still really like. There's a good amount of pressure on the player's in this one as each action is significant and you generally don't have time to do what you want/need to do. Efficiency is key here and not easy to come by.

The family version is great fun but in some ways I find it harder than the full version. It is less complex for sure, but the cards add different options for players to obtain the resources they want or to work around the barriers the game and other people present. Without the cards all you have to go with is the basic actions and it can be a much tighter game.

RATING: 8
What a fantastic game. When I went through my game designing phase back in the early nineties I so wanted to create a farming game, I just loved the idea of choosing which crops to grow, using crop rotation, whether to go dairy or beef or sheep etc, but it never got beyond a few jotted down ideas. This game knocked those thoughts for six, it has everything I ever wanted in a farming game. I have rated it 8 but really its almost but not quite a 9. This game works perfectly well as a solo game and multi-player, there are no faults with it except Wendy uses the midwife to devastating effect.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think the game is fun but can get pretty intense for some players.  Having more players seems to shift to more tactical play, since it's hard to predict every player's needs among the various options, but the game still seems enjoyable with different numbers of players.  It can take a while to play, especially with new players.

The game could use a mechanism to even out the effects of occupations and minor improvements.  Occasionally, the imbalance is reasonably severe.  It's generally difficult and/or unwise to deploy many cards, so each player only needs a couple of useful ones to stay competitive.  However, drafting can take pretty long for only a minor improvement to card balance, while also increasing the value of improvements and occupations overall.

The turn order mechanism can be a little annoying, especially in a large game, but it's hard to tell if the impact is truly significant in the midst of the more impactful differences among cards and strategies.  We've since mostly switched to Caylus-style shifting of turn order.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
[2014.Mar.01] :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

[2008.Aug.18] The Z-Man Games production is quite a good-looking game and the inclusion of the animeeples--instead of the cubes found in the standard game box--gives the game just a touch more flavor. In addition to the attractiveness of the visual design and quirky, but fun, artwork, [i]Agricola[/i] is a truly elegant game. Even without the minor improvements and occupation cards, the family game is fun and an excellent way to introduce the game's mechanics to new players and/or non-gamers. That said, the standard game, which does include the minor improvement and occupation cards, successfully takes the game to the next level. (My only concern/gripe/issue with the overall production is that the 300+ cards included in the game are not printed on slightly thicker card stock.) Playing [i]Agricola[/i] with its nearly infinite card combinations will remain a fun past-time for a long-time. Enjoy raising wild boar and harvesting vegetables, I know I will. See you on the farm!

:star::star::star::star::nostar:

However, it's a good game that keeps most people coming back for more.  It plays well from 1-5 players, which is rare.  Highly recommended.

RATING: 5
Played Agricola at BayCon 2009. Well laid out board, excellent bits (carved wooden animals), pity about the game. Agricola is very easy to get into and the mechanics seem to fit the game, but I didn’t find it that interesting. Once you have decided on how you are going to develop your farm (and players need to have different strategies as you can’t all do the same thing, because for example there is a severe shortage of buildings) I felt I was in a game of  multi player solitaire. My only interest in what other players were doing was to anticipate any action that might block/delay my progress. The player interaction seemed limited. Good game for introducing non-gamers but doesn’t strike me as having long term appeal. I’ll play it again but you won’t find me in the stampede. Not on my shopping list! I can't see what all the fss is about.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The theme is strong here, and the game mechanics work well. If I don't like this one more it's due to my theme preferences (I am biased to more epic themes) and because, in fact, you don't "use" your farm at any point of the game. True, you are building a farm, and you "feel" like doing so. But, well, "why" are you building it? You don't use what you have built at any point of the game, and due to this Agricola ends up feeling as a completely abstract game. For me, playing Agricola feels a bit like playing go, and if I want a game experience such this... Well, I prefer the later.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Deutscher Spiele Preis 2008
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
It took a while before I could learn what BGG ranking meant. When I finally found the list, I was trying to see which game was in first place. And it was Agricola. Since it's the number 1 BGG game, it should not be that bad. At last no, It's an horrible game.

The game could be summarized as "Too much": Too much cards, too much special abilities, too much actions, too much resource and not enough actions to use them all. Oh! damn, that breaks the "too much" chain.

You start with a bunch of special ability cards relatively complex to analyze, and you won't use even 3/4 of these cards. Why do you give me these cards If I am not likely to use them. Not only the powers they give are not the sun and the moon, but you need to spend resources and actions to activate them. By the way, Actions are pretty scarce.

It is very hard to do everything because of the limited amount of things you can do. But the game rewards you for doing everything, not for specializing. 

For some actions, there are multiple ways to achieve them. But there are some actions that you can only have 1 of them for the whole game. Which mean that it gets blocked very easily.

Finally, there is so much things to think about that it is very hard to know where you are going. Also, since you need to do everything and cannot focus on a specific thing, it gives the feeling of what-ever you do, everybody is going to score average in everywhere and get  a similar score to everybody else.

It other words, if you survive, your score will be not that much more or less than other players score. Which mean that there is actually now way to actually get ahead of your opponents or know if you are actually leading. It's do your routine stuff, we will declare a winner and you will not know why he won.





=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[update 2009]  I now prefer Le Havre more than Agricola but somewhat willing to play Agricola with five players.

An excellent deep, or should I say, "wide-angled" game with plenty of choices, options and strategies to pursue.  The first half of your game is based upon how efficient you are at combining the 14 cards that are randomnly distributed at game's start.  As of this writing (Nov. 2007), I can't but help think that there will be a more streamlined/shorter version of this later on down the road (i.e.- Power Grid).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I was doubtful that this game would live up to the hype. I bought it on the spur of the moment when Pozy had it on sale and I am very thankful that I did, as it has become one of our 5 favorite games.

Yes, the game really is awesome.  Multiple strategies and the cards provide virtually endless variation.  It has become my wife's favorite game, which makes it easy to get to the table. I disagree with the criticism that the game is multi-player solitaire.  Just because you can't attack the other players' farms does not mean you can't screw their plans.

My wife also loves the game, which is a huge bonus as it gets to the table much more often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I finally have played this game, and it wasn't what I expected. To be honest the game is solid for what it is. I can see the appeal for fans of Euros. I am not a fan of Euros for the most part. It seems to me that the designer played Puerto Rico and decided he wanted to make a heavier version of that game. He succeeded in that, but in the end that is all that it feels like, a Puerto Rico Heavy.  I also have to say that the mechanics, contrary to popular belief, Agricola's mechanics are not very thematic. The mechanics could be tied into all sorts of themes, and honestly they are mechanics that I generally despise in games. The game is also quite fiddly, with too many pieces, and too much going on.  

And to top it off, the theme of the game is the worst theme I have ever seen for a game. I have farmed before, I don't want to do it when I play games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A dreadful mess of a game whose clear progenitors are multiplayer solitaire puzzles such as Princes of Florence.  The hand of occupation and minor improvement cards that one is dealt at game start are a clear attempt to add "variety" to the game, but I see it as layers of ugly combinatoric complexity and a silly way of deciding the game before move one is played.  Do you have a hand of cards that work synergistically with one another?  Bully for you.  Have a hand of random crap?  Tough row to hoe.

It's depressing to see Mr. Rosenberg, an inventor of unusual card games that I admire (Klunker, Bohnanza, Mamma Mia) turn out such dreck.  But then, Agricola seems to be selling well amongst the obsessive-compulsive efficiency-mongers that populate BGG and who tweak games for solo play, probably the ideal player count for an exercise like this.

I don't care how many options and interlocking rulesets a game has; if I see no compelling reason to play it with other human beings present then the game is spiritually broken.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I was pretty much sucked into it because of the cute Animeeples and lovely artwork on the board.

Game strategy changes as different players sabotage yours.A great family game too

RATING: 7

It's a very good and deep game with a huge amount of variations! Also the theme is really immersive (I bought the wooden tokens from Mayday, I love them!). I think what I find most frustrating is that you only have two workers most of the game (that means only two actions!), and also that it takes A LOT to set up (even the easy familiar version).

RATING: 8


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game flow was perfect from my first game on!  The fact that players take a small action at a time helps, here.  It's one of these more meaty games that don't require you to re-read the rules each time you play.

The fact that harvests come faster and faster towards the end felt nice: it makes for a more climatic ending.

The playing time feels a little bit long, compared to a tense and relatively short game like Race for the Galaxy, but the thinking time was close to 100 % of the whole playing time.

Building something during the course of the game feels good: closer to the end, you can cook lamb in order to feed your family, should this become necessary, whereas this is not possible at the very beginning.  It feels like you accomplished something--enjoying some luxury doesn't hurt!

Interaction between players is of a special kind: there is no direct retribution and confrontation; what you can do is to have enough strategies so that you don't suffer from other players hindering one of them (by taking an action that you wanted).  There is more interaction than in Race for the Galaxy, though.

In my first 2-player Family Game, I regretted that interaction was so limited: we never wanted the same Action space as our opponent!  The interaction was even lower than in our Race for the Galaxy games.  I did not feel the same kind of competition as with Caylus Magna Carta.  Things improved with our 2nd game, since we had a better idea of what our opponent could be wanting to do.  I hope that more interaction will come from using the I deck.

I found it hard to really measure the cost/benefit ratio of any action in my first, rather quick Family game--much harder than in Caylus Magna Carta.  Thus, finding a good strategy is not easy.  However, since diversifying one's production is an obvious strategy, there is always enjoyment to be found in trying to implement it.

On a similar note, the fact that the consequences of your choices are not immediately quantifiable makes the game less tense and dense than in games with direct confrontations (e.g., Colossal Arena, or Lord of the Rings: the Confrontation).

Playing a 2-player Family game felt a little bit like Caylus Magna Carta, except that it was a richer experience: there are more resource types and available actions, and they are linked to each other in a deeper manner (for instance, you build fences, then have animals, then build an over and cook the meat).  Using Animeeples helps feeling more immersed in the game than abstractly building the castle in Caylus Magna Carta.

Playing with the E deck adds depth to the game.  It is nice to look for and find powerful combos.  It is also fulfilling to play cards that are adapted to the situation as it unfolds.

It seems relatively difficult to "outsmart" your opponents, as interaction is limited.  Instead, you always have to perform the best possible, but for your own little farm.

Overall, a well oiled economic/worker placement game, that apparently scales very well from 1 to 5 players.  Probably one of the best in its genre (I prefer it to Caylus Magna Carta).

The setup time is a tad long, but remains very reasonable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Has barely been played. I love the game but we just don't play it often.

RATING: 10
Ein sehr schönes Spiel. Man versucht im Arbeiter-Einsetz Manier seinen Bauernhof mit Äckern, Weiden mit Tieren und Ställen zu füllen und zusätzlich sein Haus auszubauen und neue Familienmitglieder zu produzieren. In regelmäßigen Abständen muss man diese noch ernähren und das alles wollen die anderen Spieler auch.
Jeder Spieler nimmt den anderen die Aktionsfelder weg, die Ressourcen sind knapp und man hat andauernd das Gefühl: Alles geht schief!
Zu viert spielt es sich total anders als zu dritt und ebenso anders als zu zweit. Ich liebe Agricola, spiele es aber mittlerweile nur noch auf dem iPad, da es massiven Mitspielermangel gibt. Hier haben wir es endlich mal wieder auf den Tisch bekommen.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I had heard many commendable words for my first meeting with "Agricola". As you know, at play prices almost everything was cleared up, which can be forgiven. Many equally good strategies should supposedly lead to the goal. My first game was a solo game and it was really fun. I did not see the game as a "good game" at first. I did not realize right away that "Agricola" would become one of my favorite top 3 games. There are different ways to get victory points, but you can only get four points per scoring area, and you actually have to build or harvest everything, which in turn means you have too few actions. Where were the different victory strategies? Was it not just to create as many things as possible?
However, after the following games it has become clear that long-term planning for a particular direction, such as Animal Breeding should be there, but one must constantly respond tactically. The other categories can also be reached on the basis of the main strategy and especially towards the end. A change of strategy is also possible, so that you can never get stuck. In my opinion Uwe Rosenberg succeeded with "Agricola" the "almost" perfect game. Only in advance, later more.
Now I would first like to refute the criticism of the difficult instructions, because now, at least from the seventh edition, there is a revision. However, I noticed an error here. On page two, action cards are spoken without describing what they are. The abundance of different cards I was not clear what it is. The explanation follows only on page five in the game instructions for the entire game. As "Agricola" is explained by an experienced player, but also otherwise quite complex games, dissatisfied participants quickly understood the mechanisms. Collecting resources and inserting is very intuitive. Rather, the abundance of possibilities is a problem for newcomers.
Very well came with me and others, that you create something and see the buildings that have been built for you. Slowly the farm grows around animals on meadows and in stables, fields are made, the house gets new rooms and the family increases. For Nintendo players Agricola could be the board game implementation of the released version on different platforms "Harvest Moon".
Because of the abundance of cards and the variable action fields with different numbers of players, each game develops differently. As a passionate strategist, I think it is important that the cards are each drawn up with an extra card before the start of the game according to the "7 Wonders" principle. This means that each receives eight small purchases and eight training sessions, one chooses and passes it on to the neighbor player, leaves a card at the end and puts it away. In the tutorial it is only suggested to make seven cards.
In the following I will explain why in my opinion the game has no clear 10 points, but "only" excellent 9:
There are three cards, even late on the "Family Gain" card, which have four cards that I think are too good. Once this was the "beloved", which seems too powerful in the early stages of the extra action per round. For this I recommend to increase the nutritional values ​​by one to three per harvest time for this family member. Furthermore, there are the "forward and cart team", each of which allows six free fields in fields to be changed when arable fields are used. Although you have to pay three or four wood here and have three training, but it is quite possible that you can use the training anyway.
Then, with these small purchases, each time within three actions, only six fields, each of which would give one downside, are covered. Five fields also offer four victory points. In addition, small purchases on certain action fields can be played practically occasionally. Finally, it should be noted that an early "wet nurse" can get up to three extra set pieces (150% increase!) For a teammate while the rest is still waiting for the "Family Growth" card and additional actions. A change of the rules was conveniently integrated into the Moorbauern extension. Cool game with building a farming family

RATING: 7

But after several plays (especially solo games) it feels like a puzzle that you need to solve every time and it's the same puzzle (because you need to do more or less the same things every game). Yes, there are random cards every game, but I feel that they are slightly unbalanced and don't bring as much as I would have wanted.
Don't think it's my "cup of tea".

RATING: 8
Solo Rating: 9

I've played it 4 times, but I have to play it a few times with more people for a definitive rating. 

Solo it is great but after a few times, the jobs (wich are only 10 in the solo play) become repetitive and boring . The game is quite breakable after a few times and the strategies are dictated mostly by the Minor Improvements. But still, the variety is mostly endless. For a Euro it's amazing. I still need a few more plays or with more people for a real rating. I don't want to mess with the system, hehe.

Edit: I found out that there were more cards for the solo game for the E deck, in the other decks, I've played more times but actually the solo gaming got a little bit old due to the total lack of any kind of interaction with anyone else. I'm getting sick of all kind of solo gaming, it's not a purely "Agricola" thing...

Edit: I finally played both the Basic game and the game with the E deck with my friends. They actually liked it but they got a hang of it until about half into the game. I decided to give this an 8 because it let me wanting for more but I have some problems with the whole game system and the basic mechanic (worker placement). OK it is an strategic game, and the cards somehow balance the game but I can't stand the part where the only interaction you have in the games is when you say: "Hey, that's a nice strategy you have there", or "I'm gonna take the first player token". I ned more interaction, and I know lots of people will say "just use the I deck" (and I will) but the game seems dry and heartless. I'll stick to my Cosmic Encounter for now, but I will continue to try to solve the mistery of why I like Agricola...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A rich worker placement game with more (and constantly changing) options than any I've seen. Great fun to play. The only negatives are 1) the rulebook is not well written (I recommend watching a tutorial video to learn how to play) and 2) there is no balancing mechanism when groups with different levels of experience play. The less experienced players will always get trounced by the more experienced ones. So it plays much better when all in a game are of equal Agricola experience.

Some people argue certain cards are too powerful. And that may be true for those with 50 plus games under their belt who know ideal strategies, but in my limited number of plays I've found that you can always adapt to someone else's seemingly "powerful" card by altering your strategy. The only risk is in ignoring someone's "powerful" card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
經典的工人放置型桌遊，以農家主題包裝建設、收成與稅收機制，同時搭配可愛的動物、農作物米寶，很有農家生活的氣氛。約90－120min一場。家庭版時間可以更短。遊戲過程十分好玩，但也很燒腦，是款硬派策略遊戲，因此每次玩完都很虛脫……

p.s.與Robinson Crusoe一起入手的第一款桌遊。老婆很愛。
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In addition to being our first "heavy" game, this is our first 10 rating.  This is one of the most addicting and fun games we own.  The theme is surprisingly strong and is well represented by the gameplay.  You get personally involved with building up a farm and trying to help your family survive, using multiple different strategies.  The components (animeeples included) are quite good.  The card interactions make each session take on a different flavor and keeps the game fresh and new.  Despite being heavy, the actual gameplay is quite intuitive and reasonable to grasp.  It's also a game that my girlfriend loves and requests.  

We've found the two player game to be very good and quite tense.  The game is tight, resources are short, magnifying the importance of each decision.  Even better, with more players, more actions become available, resulting in a different feeling of gameplay.  This keeps the game fresh and scaleable for any number of players (and we find that you're always involved since you need to watch what actions your opponents are taking).  As a next step game for a newbie gaming couple, [GAMEID=31260] is highly recommended.

Each of the E, I, and K decks give a different feel for the game, keeping it fresh.

Full review:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/342767]A Newbie Couple's Journey to Agricola[/url]

Session Reports:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/333805]Family Game is Brutal, Full Game Easier for 3 New Players[/url]

RATING: 7
When I was first taught it, I hated it and rated it a 2. I ended the game with no clue as to what was going on, and it dragged on for hours.
I was eventually roped into playing it again using the non-card "family" version - and liked it enough to raise my rating to "7". 
Thus I have come to believe that the cards are a mess, and they ruin the game; I won't play it with them. I suppose for experienced players they add some flavor and new options, but if you are trying to get into it, I highly suggest to avoid the cards for quite a while until you get a sense of the basics. And for heaven's sake, do not teach the game to new players with the cards.

RATING: 9.5
Great game - this has notched up 20 plays for me in around 3 months (which is a lot for me).  We all really enjoy it and not many other games are hitting the table at present.  Still exploring all the decks, and because most of the plays have been 2/3 players with cards, and a few family games, there are still a lot of occupations thta we haven't seen yet.  Even get the odd E deck minor improvement that we haven't seen before cropping up.

Love the variety of ways you can build your farm depending on the cards you have, and what your opponents do. Have upgraded to animeeples and vegemeeples - will make the game more attractive to introduce to new players, and encourage our kids to play this in a couple of years or so.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Plusses: High replayability, novel concept. For such a complex game it's scaleable enough to allow you to wade into it a bit at a time. Game flows pretty smoothly after the first play or two with a new group. Straightforward mechanics create a high-tension game.
Minuses: Not a very good game to introduce to casual gamers. Lots to learn and keep up with during the course of a play. Player interaction is limited mostly to competing for actions in a round, though the I-Deck includes many cards that increase player's effects on each other's farms. Trading/wheeling/dealing between players is not part of the basic rules (though trading as a free action would be pretty painless to implement in a house rule). Though players' game boards are a visual indicator of their standing, scoring at the end of the game can sometimes be a surprise.

RATING: 8.25
Players: 1-5 
Best: 3-4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is probably gamer heresy, but Agricola is only *barely* a good game, and certainly not the greatest thing since sliced bread.

First, the cards are completely out of hand. Even for someone that plays the game incessantly, half the profession and improvement cards would be plenty to last a year (until the first expansion deck was ready), and the decks could have been pared down to the best, most interesting and best balanced ideas, leaving the rest to cook a while longer.

Second, the "turn order mechanic" (a start player location where you can place a worker) is a joke. If start player is going to be self-selecting, there have to be tools for other players to move themselves up in the order of play as well. Failing that (and it can get fussy to operate), the number of top-tier choices, especially early in the game, needs to be larger.

The scoring is a bit fussy and precious, too, but not beyond the pale.

All of that said, I like Agricola miles better than I do Caylus and every other popular worker placement game, save Le Havre. The professions and improvements are a nod at strategic play, rather than pure tactical opportunism, and breadth of options (agriculture, animal husbandry, building your home and family, professions and improvements) is nice and chewy. Perhaps shaving one of these facets off, or reducing the types of animals, crops and resources by one each would make the game a bit tighter and less fussy, but it's still within the bounds of sanity. I'm happy to oblige my friends who enjoy this game, although I slightly prefer Le Havre and my Rosenberg game of choice, by a mile, is is classic, Bohnanza.

This is no game for casual gamers, either, let alone non-gamers. The learning curve is steep, the rules *and* the systems are complex, and it'll take most of an evening to play the first couple times if you have more than three players. I think I'd be more comfortable unleashing Die Macher on newbies than this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game simultaneously makes you feel like you need to do a little everything, but at the same time makes doing so very difficult. I wish there were fewer spaces so there would be more instances where you take the spot that your opponent wants, although that some spots get better over time seems to make the number of good spots significantly less than the number on the board, and you can easily starve an opponent of a resource they want. I don't see anything super outstanding in this game compared to other worker placements (I think the cool time mechanic of Tzolk'in makes it my favorite at the time of writing), but the sheer number of different starting hands that alter your strategy significantly means this game will probably be one of the games in my collection that survives the test of time. Rulebook is the worst I have ever read.

I wish that there weren't so many spaces to refill each round. Especially since until near end game you only have very few actions each round, making each round relatively short, this makes the game pretty fiddly.

I really like the stress of having to feed your family and making it restrict you from doing anything. The downside is if you don't get a good start it is hard to get off the ground, but it makes this game feel more than just a point salad and adds a little bit of theme to what could have been JASE.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.83
Comments entered on 07 Jul 2010:

Agricola is an interesting twist on a multiplayer puzzle. Each player is trying to build his puzzle to get the highest score, yet you can also take actions which will reduce an opponents' scores by blocking their actions.

I have played this game several times solo (which really emphasizes the puzzle aspect). I have also played this game several times with 4 and 5 people. A lot of the game can be determined by who best utilizes their occupation and improvement cards.

I have the base game and the Farmers of the Moor expansion.

RATING: 10
Think of it as Harvest Moon the board game with 3 levels of complexity, and a ridiculous of occupations (other than just being a farmer).

I say complexity, but the game does not get more complex with the I deck (and I doubt with the k either), and only serves to make it a deeper, richer experience. Also note that the change of deck type also does not lengthen the game.

It does play in about 30 minutes per player, and feels only a fraction of that. This game is simply brilliant.
