RATING: 5
First game out and I turned out to be the hog farmer. Next my dog died and the wife ran off with the farmer next valley over. His crops were bigger. Next game I'll move the hog pens away from the house. Yes the first time out and I was lost again. This game is very highly rated and the group is going to give it two more spins. So many things to do and I didn't get much done. On the bright side if it's still slow, I think I can trade it easily. Second game and the wife ran off again. The farmer next door picked up a wet nurse and a house goat, so she came back. Game was a little more fun this time. I have played this five times now and it's still only a 7 at best. A couple of more plays and it sinks. Save yourself some time. Deal out the cards and the person who gets the best cards wins. I play games with two groups. One group it did not go over well with - great! The other group likes it - crap. I have to play this stinker once in a while with the second group.I'm just not very good at this game and that's why I have it at a lower rating.
One question - How can the # 1 game have such a problem with cards?  There are all kind of suggestion on how to fix the card unbalance at the start of the game. I don't see any other game in the top 100 with a problem to fix.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Every decision is interesting, and the cards make every game vastly different. Building your farm is a fun creative endeavor.

Where Agricola and I part ways is I just find the volume of difficult choices and the unknown consequences quite daunting (although it certainly isn't as overwhelming as Caverna). Making a game plan out of a hand of seven cards before you even begin is quite a difficult task.

RATING: 9.5
簡單來說遊戲對一般玩家來說都不容易，很難找到一個好對手跟您坐上好半天的時間來研究這個以回合制的遊戲。

祇玩無卡版(家庭版本)的農莊樂絕對是個悶蛋遊戲，但不失為第一次遊戲的試玩介紹；當加入職業及小改進卡牌後，整個遊戲變成「做少錯少」的心機關算盡的遊戲。

介紹您們找一些有棋力的朋友作戰，要不是就是自己做自己事的「個人桌遊」

RATING: 10
I resisted making this a 10 game for a while.  I liked it immediately.  The theme and how it works within the game appealed. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wonderful brain-burner worker-placement, scales well for 2-5 players.  Tense.  Deep strategy and planning is rewarded, excellent re-playability, fun theme.  The multitude of occupation and minor improvement cards (and several expansion decks) allow for a plethora of combinations and multiple paths to victory, forcing the player to choose what cards are most important and most complementary.     This game may be considered a bit dry by those seeking a light-hearted luckfest, or more interaction.  A wonderful game about identifying synergies between your minor improvement and occupation cards, setting priorities, [i]following through[/i].

The pressure in this game can be heavy--there doesn't seem quite enough time to get done all you need to with your limited number of turns.  An optimization problem, but with the added unknown of what actions your opponents will choose, thereby making them unavailable to you.  One step further, Agricola becomes a tactical game, where opponents purposely aim to block each other from critical actions on the board that can completely foil their end-game strategy.  

Update:  still enjoying Agricola occasionally, but it is not hitting the table as often due to the laborious set-up and tear-down time [20 min setup, 20-min tear-down with Farmers of the Moor expansion].

Update #2:  Bought a simple compartmentalized bits-organizer for Agricola + FotM animals and resources for $3.  This will seriously enhance is playability, knocking down the setup/tear-down time from 20 min to under 5 min!!! TTFN
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wonderful game. Can't get enough of it. Have played about 80 times, with four or five players.

RATING: 9
Clearly a very deep game.  Have played mostly solo at this point, which means there's a whole lot left to discover, to say the least.  I have yet to have a multi-player game where I knew what I was doing, things felt evenly balanced, etc.  I look forward to digging in.

One thing worth mentioning: I only have the animeeples at this point, but it's amazing how much they add to the game.  And the one play I did with vegimeeples and resourceeples was even more immersive.  This is a game that it pays off to pimp, for sure.  -- March 2, 2011

It took me this long to bump this to a 9? Okay, have played plenty of games of this by now. Love it love it love it.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What makes this game so charming is that the competitive aspect is really just thinly overlaid on a lovely, gentle game of make-believe about gradually building up one's very own seventeenth-century farm. Even if you lose, a score of over about 22 is a  signal that you can feel like you managed your turns competently, and ended up with a nifty little tract of land. The game could probably be played cutthroat too, but I can't see what the attraction of that would be on the first few dozen plays. It's remarkably easy to teach and to learn on the fly, in spite of the deep complexity of the rules. The cards and gamepieces are fiddly and fussy to keep track of, but for me that actually added to the fun. My one minor quibble is that there's a failure of realism when it comes to trying to imagine how the different actions could possibly be getting performed simultaneously; a simpler game might not have appealed quite so much to Euro diehards, but might also possibly have done a better job of preserving this aspect of the illusion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
The best worker placement game out there.  It does have increasing levels of complexity where the "family game" is reasonably easy to learn.  But I would say this is very much a "gamer's game" and not a family game.  However, if you have kids who can play a game for 2 hrs, the family game variant will work.  

There are an incredible number of card expansions to this game making it very deep.  

Cards, and the combinations make it complex and highly replayable.

AP prone players should stay away.

RATING: 8
Looking forward to picking up the deluxe 2017 edition.  Sold our copy to replace with Caverna, and found Caverna just didn't have the same appeal to us.  Now anxiously await the opportunity to get it back on our shelves and on our gaming table.

Ken:
Great game, with depth, incredible replayability, adjustable difficulty and level of interaction, paired with a well-integrated (yet perhaps ho-hum) theme.  Fiddliness reduced with good custom storage.  Family game works well as an introduction, but the occupations and minor improvements of the regular game bring this to a whole extra level of incredible.  To some degree, I still prefer scoring systems wherein you get points for doing things instead of losing points for not doing things, but I still find this game very engaging and enjoyable.  Perhaps the stress of needing to do everything adds that extra kick to the game.

Kathleen:
I agree that this is about an 8.  This is my favorite of the many worker placement style games that we've played.  The scoring system forces you to do everything, which I like.  Has a very well-integrated theme with great artwork.  I prefer playing this with 2 players, although it does work well with 3+.

RATING: 7

RATING: 9.5
This is a really nice game- meaty without being too long, absorbing without being too fiddly.  Played it 6 times now plus a couple of solo games and still feel like I'm improving significantly each game.  Because of the "solitaire" and development aspects of the game I've found that first time players enjoy it too, even if their scores aren't high at the end-  people feel they are getting somewhere by the end of the game and are keen to have another go.

My only question is about the repeated replayability of the game- even with the cards I feel there are probably limited strategies.  But Roads and Boats only has one basic strategy and that's replayable so this might be a red herring.

German edition is fine with some work- the paste ups available on the Geek and lots and lots of card protectors are all you need.  And then the stuff doesn't fit in the box.  

I'm off to try out a solo strategy now.....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A heavy game - literally. It has so many parts and cards it must weigh ten pounds. 

At its heart Agricola is an game of economics.  A game of managing limited resources and production with a limited number of rounds to accomplish several balanced tasks.

The strategic fun is in the cards, and without the cards this game loses it's soul.  Building  power combo to move through this game with an asymmetrical advantage, and placing workers to block theirs is Agricola. 

This is why I have no use for Caverna.  These games are better with a bite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Vs. Le Harve as a solo game: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/470218/le-havre-or-agricola-better-solo-game

Vs. Le Harve in game length: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/508744/game-length-and-comparison-to-agricola-and-pr

NB: Agricola has a pressure element in that there's not enough time to do everything you want to do. This is not so in Le Harve. To some it could be a plus, to others a minus?!

Games seems to be able to be bought for $45, however, it's not worth getting until other games have been more played (Puerto Rico, Notre Damme etc)

Good score keeper: http://boardgamegeek.com/image/407450/agricola

As a 2 player game, this apparently still takes 1 hour. See: http://boardgames.stackexchange.com/questions/4193/evaluating-agricola-as-a-2-player-game-how-long-would-it-take-how-competitive

It would seem to make more sense sticking with all creatures big and small AND caverna (which seems to be a more enjoyable playing experience according to many).

Agricola does have "Family Rules": http://www.reddit.com/r/boardgames/comments/1bljcq/wsig_agricola_or_all_creatures_big_and_small/

In favor of All Creatures is the lengthy setup time of the original game. "Just getting it out and setting it up for the photo above, and then putting it all away, took nearly as long as it would to play an entire game of Agricola: All Creatures. And that’s for a two-player game." Quote is from: http://geekdad.com/2014/01/agricola-all-creatures/

Vs CAVERNA: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1179158/will-you-prefer-caverna-or-agricola-review

VS CAVERNA: http://www.clevermovegames.com/2014/10/22/rosenberg-review-should-you-play-caverna-or-agricola/

Solid review: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1332964/having-played-fair-bit-i-wanted-clarify-my-thought

In light of Caverna's popularity, Agricola should be held off getting unless it can be acqjuired for about $35 with all the animeeples.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
8/2008 Yet anohter resource harvesting game with way too many choices given the amount of time and resources at hand.  There are basically two tasks 1) get enough food for your workers, and 2) use your workers to do a bit of everything available.  Its the latter you're awarded points for in the end - or minus points for neglecting one area.

Agricola is a good game but not #1.  The major flaw lies in the initial 14 cards each player are dealt; secondly the specialized and limited actions available.  (The former can be somewhat lessend by using a variety of house rules, still...)  Granted, the cards gives more replayability but some are unbalanced and some card combinations are a sure victory.  

5/2009 Another game, this time with three players, and I cannot understand how Agricola has the #1 ranking.  We spent 2+ hours, with very little chit-chat, and really didn't accomplish that much.  Rating down 7 -> 5.  The rating explanation "slightly boring" seems fitting.

[COLOR=#0000FF]Großartiges Spielkonzept, das langanhaltenden Spielspaß verspricht. Besonders gut gefällt mir, dass die Wertigkeit/Knappheit der verschiedenen Güter und Ressourcen je nach Anzahl der Mitspieler sehr stark differiert. So sind z.B. Stein und Lehm speziell zu zweit knapp, Schilf zu dritt sehr rar und Äcker sind bei vier oder fünf Personen Mangelware... Es empfiehlt sich also, die eigene Strategie und Kartenwahl immer in direkte Abhängigkeit von den Rahmenbedingungen der aktuellen Partie zu stellen, womit bereits für ein enormes Ausmaß an Abwechslung gesorgt ist.
 
Zwar sind die Karten im direkten Vergleich relativ gut ausbalanciert, doch gibt es einige "mordsmäßig" starke Kartenkombinationen, die das Spiel ziemlich außer Gleichgewicht bringen können. Wie oben bereits erwähnt, ist die Stärke einer "Kombo" allerdings sehr relativ und immer mit Hinblick auf die Mitspielerzahl zu bewerten. Beispiele gefällig? 

Als sehr stark erwiesen sich in unseren Partien (und dies sind nur E-Karten!):
-> Akademiker, Steinbruch, Gartenarbeiter und/oder Saisonarbeiter
-> Holzfäller, Axt, Schilfsammler oder Schilfteich
-> Lehmmischer, Lehmstake , Dachdecker, ggf. Spachtel
-> Steinschlepper, Steinklaue, Restaurator, ggf. Pflughalter oder Fachwerkhaus

In den anderen Kartensätzen befinden sich wohlgemerkt noch weitaus mächtigere Karten wie etwa Amme, Bummelstudent oder Liebhaber![/COLOR]

[COLOR=#009900][b]Card-Drafting Variante[/b] 
Nachdem diese Idee in einem Kommentar zur Agricola-Rezension der Westpark-Gamers aufgetaucht ist, spielen wir das Spiel mit folgender Änderung der Kartenverteilung, die das Kartenglück stark reduziert: Jeder Spieler erhält zu Beginn des Spiels je sieben Ausbildungs- und Anschaffungskarten, von denen er sich jeweils eine aussucht. Die übrigen sechs Karten reicht er an seinen linken Nachbarn weiter, sucht sich wiederum je eine Karte aus und gibt die übrigen Karten weiter... Das Draften endet, sobald alle Spieler je sieben Karten ausgewählt haben (die letzte wählt der Vordermann). Das Hauptspiel bleibt unverändert.
Achtung: Natürlich verlängert das Auswahlverfahren die Spielzeit. Außerdem wächst die Gefahr, dass sich Spieler "ideale" Kartenkombinationen basteln können. Dafür ist diese Möglichkeit nun aber allen gegeben - das Spiel ist also "gerechter" geworden.[/COLOR]

RATING: 4
I felt very lonely in this game (like with so many of the Spiel 2007 releases). The game seems to lack direct interaction.

I can confirm this feeling after the second play, I felt totally uninterested in what the others did and still made shared first place. A game shouldn't be like this.

More disturbing things got clear to me recently:
Why can't I plough/build etc. if my neighbour already did? I mean I can understand this restriction for the resource gathering actions, but this is just gamey. Furthermore the minor improvements and occupation cards just have too big differences in quality. Some are completely useless, others are completely overpowered. This game just rubs me the wrong way...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Despite the family-friendly theme, this game teaches you one lesson - there is no such thing as cooperation in the land of Agricola, only brutal competition for survival. If you're last in the turn rotation, you get totally screwed. And the game has no mercy on poor decisions. The beginning of the game offers some flexibility to recover from mistakes, but the latter half feels like a rigid sequence of decisions that, if you haven't prepared for it, can each be a resounding blow against the foundation of your family's legacy. On numerous occasions my family survived the harvest phase only by ravenously eating raw grain with their bare hands because someone took the accursed Bake Bread action.

"A child skips his way to the Bakery, eager to prove himself by baking his family's grain into bread to last through the winter. He arrive only to see the father of the neighboring homestead enter first. 'Hello, good sir!' he says cheerfully, 'I see you're also here to ...' The door slams in the child's face emiting a lingering scent of warm dough. A cold wind blows across the child's neck. His stomach growls."

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Agricola is a worker placement Euro-game, wherein the players attempt to construct a flourishing farm, but in most cases the farm never gets that far. There is a constant balancing act between feeding ones family (workers) and developing the farm (including animals, produce, and home). This is a tense game, not due to epic events happening, but due to the struggle of surviving. 

There are a variety of actions to be chosen from, but true diversity in gameplay comes about due to the occupation and improvement cards dealt out at the beginning of the game. Sometimes the cards mesh nicely and a winning strategy falls from it, but other times they just seem somewhat helpful, but not worth the effort. 

It is satisfying when you are able to find an efficient way of feeding ones family, whether through crops or animals. 

The art style of the game is slightly cartoon-ish while not looking silly. The component quality is good, but not the reason this is a widely appreciated game. 

The first few play-throughs are really slow, but eventually players have a good idea of what should be done , even if their optimal actions are taken.

Overall, a good worker placement game if you're okay with the stress of food procurement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like this game, really.. BUT: Cards are not fair !
There are good working combos in my opponents hand... and I'm sitting there with always useless educations & stuff

RATING: 3
I just don't get why people love this game so much and I hate it so much!!!!

I love all the concepts and mechanics and when describing it it sounds like a game I would love, but here I am many plays later still hating it.  My siblings continue to hold it in their top 3.


two years later:
I think I know now, It lacks proper achievements/rewards.
I always feel I didn't do good enough, even when I won.  The rules feel like they just keep you down, I've never felt that great success for a turn like all other games.  Dominion:"yeah! just played a huge string of cards";  carcassonne:"yeah! just compleated a big city";  gin rummy:"yeah! got gin" and so forth. agricola:"dammit, why didn't I get that reed last turn, uggggghhhhhhh"
this game doesnt have the same fun or stratigies other similar games have.  Its like standing in line.  Everyone wants the same good choices.  And the cards make or break the game, its just hard to notice because everyone does poorly.

RATING: 9
Superior game. (This is the original version) 

+For us, tops out at 3 or 4 players.

+Many, many strategies.

+10/3 discard is best for occupations and improvements.

-Some players perceive the private cards creating unfair imbalances in play.  I disagree but it's hard to dispel this perception.

-The only flaw I can see is how hard it is to play a 5'er.  Everyone in my group wants to play Agricola but the battle for the turn order ends up scuttling much strategy in a 5er.  Geek wisdom on this is not to play with that many, sticking to 2-4er.

++Farmers of the Moor is not a must; there are many, many plays in the base game.  Adding the highest complexity of Farmers of the Moor makes this game exponentially better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Farming is not really my pick of choice theme and game itself is so-so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game burns my brain every time I play it.  My wife and I have never really graduated past the family game version.  There are so many variables in the family game version that the more advanced versions seem a bit overwhelming.  Nevertheless, great art, great pieces (animeeples!), clever theme.  It's a bit like two players at solitaire, except they compete for the best resource draws from the middle of the table.  It's fun to guess what resources the other player needs and then take it before s/he has a chance to pick it up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Agricola can be extremely tedious and nerve-wracking, and like any worker placement game, it causes annoying passive aggressive interactions among the players. Randomness in the minor improvements and occupations can also cause discord, as it always seems that one player has an amazing combo while everyone else struggles. That being said, the gameplay involves plenty of strategic maneuvering, planning, and anticipating, which does stimulate the mind as long as you don't get bogged down in the desperation of scrambling for food and resources. I'll play this occasionally if the player group seems up for a challenge.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really do love this game.  I love the bits (I got the animeeples, but beyond that, even the normal pieces and the boards and almost everything but the rather ugly food counters are a delight for the eyes).  I love the theme and, even though I can see how the game would be considered dry for some, I feel it fits very well.  On a farm, the main fight is to stay fed and keep one's head above water.  Once that is accomplished, it is time to make improvements.  I love the cards and the replayability they offer (I have not found them imbalanced.... some are just flashier than others)..

However, I do have two real gripes.  The lesser gripe is that I am not much of a fan of the scoring system (I dislike Die Macher for the same reason).  Having to sit down and add up everything is rather anticlimactic.  

My biggest problem, however, is that the game just does not feel paced right.  One of the pleasures of economic engine games is getting your system in working order and reaping the benefits.  I would love to be able to get my farm into working order and then actually watch it work.  Unfortunately, by the time that really happens, the game has come to an end.  I see why, with the mechanics the way they are (particularly the scoring) this must be, but it always leaves a bit of dissatisfaction in my mouth.  Now... this normally turns into saying "ah.. lets play one more game," so it certainly is not a deal-breaker, but it does bother me a bit.

Okay, I don't want to play this without a draft again.

My group won't play with the Wet Nurse from the Z deck because they feel it is overpowered.  I also don't like the broom/spring cleaning card for the randomness/windfall it can create and the mansion because it is a big double-dipping windfall.  I will probably try to have them removed in the future, or at least modified. 

I can't believe that every combination of cards was throughly playtested.  I think that's probably the biggest weakness of the game.

1 play, 2 players, family game
1 play, 2 players, E deck
3 plays, 3 players, E deck
1 play, 3 players, E+I deck
1 play, 4 players, E deck, draft
2 plays, 4 players, Z deck, draft
1 play, 5 players, I deck, draft
1 play, 5 players, I+K deck, draft
1 play, 5 players, E+I deck

RATING: 4
Update
Second play, and I still fail to find any fun in this game. Sure it all works... yes there are a few different things you can do to win, but it is very solitaire in nature, most of the blocking is accidental due to the limited nature of certain key actions (like family expansion and adding rooms etc.)  In addition the deal of the cards usually gives certain players a big advantage that I feel will get even bigger as we get better at playing. 

Update
I did finally play this game, and it is a well made set of mechanics that produce a rather boring exercise in min maxing a scoring system. The theme here is irrelevant, it could be anything the rest is just completing  set of goals to score points. 

It is like a bunch of people playing a overly complex version of Bazaar individually, hardly interacting and then comparing scores at the end. The hand of occupation cards you are dealt will either provide you usable advantages or it will not the rest of your play comes down to how well you know the game engines and the scoring requirements. 

Drafting the occupations may make this better, but not by that much. 


all in all i can not see why this thing is so popular.



--------------------------
I have not played this game. I normally do not rank games i have never played, and in fact don't have any opinion as to how good or bad this game is.  I do think that the response by this games publisher (hanno) to the joke rankings was beyond the pale. 
his quote:  
Do you also think it's a fun prank if all the folks who you played this prank on call your mom tomorrow and condole her while telling her you passed away eating your own shit at BGG.con?  IMHO this was uncalled for, unprofessional and unacceptable from a game publisher. 

As asinine as we bgg members tend to get, people who are here to make a living should stay out of the mess. There was never any attempt made at harming the game's rating yet the game publisher took the joke personally and began attack the very gamers who may have been a customer in the near future. 

the poor rating is my small way of protesting those actions. If I ever play this game I will give it a fair rating. 

-M

RATING: 5
Not a game to introduce to a friend you are trying to convince gaming is fun. It's an engaging game that gets you involved deeply, but for all your fret and strategem and focus and manuvering, at the end, no matter if you win or lose, there is no sense that anything has really happened. And it always ends just when you're really getting together and can start playing, which is the point, but after calculating and tabulating, it lacks that wonderful sense of triumph that other games give you, even those you lose. If I owned this game, I would definitely want to play it from time to time; not owning it, I won't miss it.

RATING: 4
I'm not a huge fan of worker placement games.  But this is by far my favorite of the bunch.  I like the farm building.  But I'm not a huge fan of the cards since there's no mechanism to change your hand.  I feel like I'm always watching someone else have a card that amasses them tons of good X, and I can do nothing about it.

Also, it seems that farming as such is almost tangential.  Family growth and house growth seem overpowered compared to actually running a farm.

I also wished that the scoring rewarded specialization.  You can't think "I'm going to build the best sheep farm ever this game".  Every game, you're going to built a more-or-less similar farm.  I don't like scoring mechanisms that force everyone to be pigeon-holed in such a way.

I used to rate this game higher, but lately I've been avoiding it.  For the amount of time it takes to play, there are just so many better things in my opinion.  Thus, I've lovered my rating 7->6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'll start with some bad comments. I don't like worker-placement games like Caylus or PoE(I think it's rather mediocre way to add some interaction). I don't like logical-efficiency games(I think it's rather like puzzle more than game). I don't like many-things-to-do-and-scarce-turns-to-do games(I think it's frustrating rather than fun).

That said, I like Agricola. because-
1) Cards provide almost infinite ways to play. Every dealt hands are different, making every game fresh and demanding new strategy every game.

2) It is highly thematic. Of course there are some gamey-elements(e.g. only one person per one action, years getting shorter). But atmosphere of farming is realized very well(resources, animals, occupations, buildings)

3) It is fun - which is great merit, for many Euros lack fun.

I think this is one of the best Euros, and will be a classic.

Update--------------------------------------------------
Luck of initial card draw can influence the game much more than I firstly thought.

Owning also "Z-Deck", "X-deck","Through The Seasons" and "Ubegeeks" promo card.

RATING: 2
Although I can appreciate the amount of work that has been put by the creators of the game, Agricola  is for me both boring and frustrating. The theme is not at all appealing and the whole "too much to do in so little time" concept is rather indifferent.

Having said that, the production value is over the top and the replayability is guranteed (tons of cards).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Well, I've now played this game 18 or so times and I can honestly say that this game truly deserves it's #1 ranking on BGG. There is so much going on at any one time that you always have a lot of options in how you want to go about building up your farm. I find that a 2 or 3 player game is the sweet spot for me - I've had some VERY close "edge-of-your-seat" games (especially 2 player) with this number of players.

The multiple decks in the game make this immensely replayable - we have only just started on the I (interactive) deck and haven't touched the K deck at all yet. I can see playing this eck for awhile too as all the games so far have only been 2 player so we've just barely touched on the card. 

The great thing about Agricola is that you are never really sure how well you are doing in relationship to the other players except in a very general way. Sure, you can take the time to count up each player's VP total at any given time, but it's not really accurate in telling you who will win, as many powerful cards don't come out until the later part of the game and by then you are really focusing on YOUR farm and how you can improve it verses how you can thwart another player.

We almost always use the "Through the Seasons" expansion and add in a Round "0" to slightly reduce that "Not enough rounds to do all that you want to do" feeling that comes into play with only 14 rounds. It makes the game much more satisfying as your farm is usually a bit more completed with the addition of 1 more round.

I'm really looking forward to getting a copy of "Farmers of the Moor" and have also been working on my own expansion - The Chicken or the Egg (see the post in the forum under variants).

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
An excellent example of European gaming. An intense introduction to farming and living off the land. 
I have not tried the family rules, but I understand that is a good way to start learning the game. Simply do not use Occupations or Minor Improvements.
The full game is incredibly complex, with many opportunities to make crucial decisions. While there is some player interaction (ie who gets what action for that round), the race is against the game. Feed your family, upgrade your farm, breed your animals. 
The few first games, consider it well played if
1) your family did not starve. 
2) each game end you have a little more then the last
Finally 3) you haven't thrown a tantrum! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Dans « Agricola », vous êtes un simple fermier vivant seul avec votre conjoint dans une petite chaumière de bois.
Durant votre tour, vous devez faire deux actions, une pour vous et l'autre pour le conjoint :
prendre de l'argile, du bois ou de la pierre pour construire des bâtiments.
Vous pourriez penser à avoir des enfants afin d'accomplir plus de travail, mais pensez d'abord à améliorer votre maison.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After 13 plays, the luck factor appears very clear.

Dawn suggestion (08/05/09): "Agricola is awesome. It's a long game, though (2 hours), and has a pretty big learning curve (or at least, it takes one full game to figure out what's going on--your first game will be the most confusing). But once you get past that, it's great fun."
Dawn suggestion (01/24/14): "Agricola's my favorite of all, but it's over 2 hours to play and expensive."

RATING: 10
Lots of fun, slow start and a quick finish, highly repayable - definitely worth the money. A complex game, includes a "family" version that I highly recommend is played for the first 4 or 5 games so you can pickup a good understanding of the game mechanics before adding in the occupations and minor improvements. This is one of the most replayable games I own, and I almost never turn down the chance to play. You often think "if only I had ONE MORE TURN" at the end. I love it!

RATING: N/A
I bought this based on its position in the BGG rankings (#1 at the time) and was turned on by the components but turned off by the rules and the play time-- I worried it would be too complex. Talking to the best player in my group, who'd tried it once and had no particular desire to ever try it again, sealed its fate. I kept it for a little while and then sold it unplayed.

These days I do more up-front research and tend to do a better job of avoiding mismatches. I do feel like a filthy sinner for selling off such an acclaimed game without even giving it a shot, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After waiting 8+ months for the English edition, I am very satisfied.  The game met my extraordinarily high expectations. This game is an instant classic.  My kids will probably want some of that farm bits people are trying to track down (have the animeeples already).

An incredible 2-player oriented review - http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/239620Rating after one play - German Ed. with translations.  I believe this has replaced Puerto Rico as the euro of choice in our family (with accompanied decline in the rating for PR).  This game more than lives up to the hype.  This old guy is really excited for this one (more than any new toy I've ever bought surprisingly enough.)

Two points in favor of the game for me:
First, no scoring until the end.  The play is the thing, not the scoring and the winning.  Very un-Euro.
Second, so many interactions nobody could ever 'solve' the game.  Part of the fun of a game is the discoveries found within the game itself.  I don't want to understand everything that is going on from the start to the end of the game.  That's a math problem, no thanks.  I expect this will see many, many plays for years to come.  Some solo, mostly 2-player, but occasionally more.

This game is for people who like variety, discovery and replayability.  If those aren't your thing, take a pass on it.

After 10+ plays all I want to do is keep playing.
Update after over 50 plays - nothing has changed, this game is unbelievable fun and addictive. I haven't been so hooked on a game since Magic first came out eons ago.

Nothing so far to indicate anything but the best eurogame created to date.  The replayability is far beyond any current euro.

Latest update 2014 - still a great, great game. Dropped rating one point as we simply haven't been as into euros in general.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
This is a great game, and enough people have given good descriptions as to why that is.

The game is so much about planning, but also about opportunity and considering you opponents plans.

My only problem with this game is that it is quite restrictive, and players with AP can make the gamelength extend significantly; this is because despite there being a limited number of options there is so much to consider.  In my experience AP is less prevalent in less tight games, and where  most options available significantly improve your score/position; I just feel that in my group anyway, those who like to consider every outcome are less likely to hold onto that mindset so tightly when choices have significantly positive outcomes.

RATING: 9
Originally I wasn't too exited about the theme, but bought it out of curiosity (to see what the fuss is all about). I'm glad I did! Great mechanics and design, lots of strategic depth and it keeps the tension of players high from start to finish.

It all made more sense when we started to play the 'draft' variant, that allowed players to 'build' their deck and card combinations. It should be part of the main game rules, IMO (e.g., after the family version and one or two introductory 'random card' plays).

RATING: 10
I really dig the wide variety of strategies you can pursue within the rather simple game system. The way your timing is forced to react to other players helps to keep things from being just a solo puzzle.

That said, this isn't the sort of game you get all fired up about yelling at dice and cursing the other players.

That combined with the sort of wonky scoring that generally pushes you towards diversity despite any possible awesomeness in a few facets, keeps it in simply "great" territory rather than "totally awesome".

RATING: 4

The only reason i'm rating it this high is because it incorporates theme into gameplay quite well. I'll play it, but barely.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The highest rated game I do not own.  I love every time i get to play this game, and they have done a great job with adding many occupations/improvements which can be added to the game to bring more variety and replay to it.

What I love about Agricola is that in order to win you have to have played smarter than your opponents.  After the first few times of just trying to survive to the end, the possibilities and strategies start to really open up.  However, the downfall can be that one bad turn can ruin the rest of the game for you, so you have to be careful.

My favorite 2+ hour game to play with 4 players.  The worker placement is beautifully simple, and the game makes intuitive sense.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
4 / 5 - Very Good

There's a lot - a hell of a lot - of min/maxing in this game. No hidden information (other than the cards of the other players) means you're constantly trying to add up various potential combinations to spot the best. It's the same problem as power grid, only with less interaction and interest. The plays I racked up on this were mainly solo, and I did enjoy the puzzle element of "solving" it to make a full run of seven campaign games. But once solved it ceased to have much interest. So the rating is a balance of what I'd give solo (6) and what I'd give multi-player (4).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A great game I've played many times. The family version is great for first timers and the many different cards allow for countless possibilities. We've shuffled all of the Minor Improvements into one huge pile.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.99
Rating:

Game quality: Rating is very tentative as it is just a feel rating after a play. I had heard about the stress and and tight gameplay numerous times. It still caught me off guard coming from Lords of Waterdeep and my lone real experience with worker placement games.

Turn order can be the very important here. If you lose out in it, you might be completely blocked from doing what you want to and looking at picking up the scraps. This can feel rather combative for a Euro style game because of it.

Not sure I like how the rounds get shorter as the game goes on. I was surprised how much the later versions of all of the meeples really added to the game. 8.

Would I buy this again if I was starting over: I think I'm past the idea that I would rate this a 10 by default, but this is a classic that I feel would need to be in my collection. 9.

Do I want to play this if asked: There's so much to still untap with the game and then adding in the expansion. 9

Overall: 8.99.

Rating Potential: High 8 to high 9. Variable set up helps push this past Puerto Rico in my mind, so that says something right there. This might be one of those games that I debate why it isn't a 10, and I simply can't answer it.

RATING: 8
Played 5-10 times. It´s a very good game, though I prefer games where you can specialize more. Here you need to have a bit of everything (almost). The game is almost thematic, except for some illogical restrictions that make the game harder to teach and learn: You can cook anytime but not bake bread. You can cook 8 sheep instantly but you cannot cook one lamb. All fences must be connected. And so on.

Uwe Rosenberg. 1-5, best with 3 or 4 says BGG poll.

RATING: 8.5
Possibly the only thing stopping this from being my favourite game is the amount of time and effort it takes to set up. Many of the cards have never been used because there are so many possibilities, and so few are used in each game.

RATING: 9
An excellent game, best game in my collection (though War of the Ring CE scores higher, cuz it's hotter!).  Very busy, very complicated and quite challenging if you get a bad hand of occupations/improvements at the start (draft variants can help with this).  I often prefer the family version, as it's just easier to play (not to mention quicker), and I frequently play with newbies and non-game-geeks.  There's just no way I could spring the whole thing on them!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Torn on this one. As a design it gets a 10 no question - almost infinite replayability combined with a system that puts a lot of pressure on the players and a satisfying theme. It's nice to watch your farm grow and expand. But a 4 rating would more accurately reflect how much fun I had on my first play. The game is basically Caylus, but here players have a hand of cards that give them unique bonuses when built/played and the scoring is more opaque. I think I'm just beginning to tire of games in which players are really playing the system rather than each other. There is screwage in this game (you can take actions someone else really needs) but most of that seems to be done inadvertantly; if you take actions you know someone else needs just for the heck of it you'll lose for sure. One question that remains to be answered is play balance: the cards one is dealt at the beginning of the game will nudge players to pursue particular paths to victory. But with so many paths and so many cards that help in this pursuit can the designer really have managed to balance ALL the cards/combos/paths? Given equal players is the game over from the first deal? So I guess (10+4)/2=7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

No. Just no.  Cant get my head around. Dont want to.  Maybe its just me.  But this really doesn't motivate me to engage further. Traded away.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The first euro game I bought, as well as the only euro game I owned for almost a year.  I've primarily played 1-3 players.

What I like about it:
- Replayability with all the occupations and minor improvements
- Satisfaction from seeing your engine (farm) grow throughout the game
- No direct conflict but plenty of tension from action/resource competition and races to buy limited improvements
- Available actions are slowly revealed every round and the ordering changes every game
- Scales well across all player counts
- Family version makes it easier to introduce to new players
- Solo version offers an interesting optimization puzzle

What I don't like:
- It's more difficult to get to the table with more players because of the longer play time and stress
- The ending farm configurations start to end up looking similar after a few plays (Farmers of the Moor fixes this)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
great game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As of 26 Aug 2008, I've played a few solo games and 2 2-player games with my boys (7 and 9).  It's a good game but can be a bit fiddly with the card interactions. The Appendix helps with this greatly as it spells out which cards can be used with which other cards and when.  As a kids game, I can see it getting on the table for a while as both boys like the theme and creation aspects and can't wait to play again.  As a homeschooling parent, I see some math, resource planning, turn taking, possibly history if you talk about the 17th century hardships of farmers, and possibly more educational benefits of the game.

I love to play the 2 player version with my wife.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
3rd best game of 2007 and my favorite heavy game.
Pretty heavy game. And I still remember when I had to learn it from rulebook, the rulebook is terrible. Those negatives aside Agricola is one of the best boardgames made, I rarely agree with BGG Rankings but here I do. Hardcore gamers can of course make it unfun with ridiculous amount of blocking, but just don't play with those kind of players and it can be fun. Very hard when you're learning it, but still fun. In some other designers hand it could've been point salad, but Uwe added story and concrete farm, making players care. And enough randomness -the cards really make the game, almost all the replayability comes from them. When I play 2p with my wife we play with 4 occupations&improvements, drafted - it's easy way to reduce option overload. Farmers of the Moor is nice alternative way to play with even more strategies but so heavy that we rarely use it. If you always play without cards it's a must though.

2-Player Comment:
* Agricola is great 2p game. Official fix: add the +1 all resources action card to 2p from 3p cards. It makes the game less unforgiving and opens new strategies. Drafting is recommended for experienced players.

Expansions:
+Agricola: Farmers of the Moor
+Agricola: The Goodies
+Gamers' Deck
+World Championship Deck 2011
+Z-Deck

RATING: 10
Fun game, satisfying to build your farm, but bloody hell, is it ever fiddly... boards bits cards bags rules everywhere, constant replenishing of the board, unusual scoring system that rewards the little-bit-of-everything farm, so winning farms generally look similar... but the paths to get there are myriad. I think I'm a sucker for the infinitely variable yet similar game, and it has this in common with Settlers and Scrabble, my other favourite games. It has a super 2-player game, too.
Caved and bought the iOS version. Not bad, but got bored with it fast; even the good AI is pretty weak and the game plays slowly with many bots. And playing against other people online I've always found painfully slow.

RATING: 8.5
Great game overall. Good art, production value, instructions. Plays tight, no real bash the leader problems, some randomness to keep things interesting, nice theme. 

Is it the best thing ever? I like it a lot, but it’s also long, suffers from AP, and the cards can be interesting or broken. Though it’s replayable due to randomness of cards (on board and/or if playing with in hand), it’s really the same every time. Stone Age and Caylus suffer from this as well. 

The biggest barrier to new folks is probably the timing of the fields - plant, sow, reap. Also, the feeding can be a problem. But after one play, maybe 2, people get it and then it’s back to normal Euro points optimization exercises. But I like cows, so there you are.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games.
The Pros: Amazing freedom of play (basically, you can pursue victory any way you want), high replay value, tension, indirect influence and/or interaction, tough decisions, no obvious path to victory... you could play this game and lose repeatedly and still enjoy it every time.
The Cons: not an easy one to teach to newcomers, long gameplay (though it doesn' feel like it), loads of tiny similar looking pieces, and this game is expensive (but worth it).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Tight game with limited number of turns where every turn counts.  AP-prone players beware (me included)!  Thinking ahead is a must.  Huge selection of starting cards means you'll never play the same game twice because you'll want to tailor your strategy to maximize your card benefits.  Having to feed your family every few rounds can get stressful, but that's part of the charm and challenge of the game, i.e. you can't just go off and do your own thing.  You do get points for everything so there's flexibility, but the scoring system that subtracts points for not achieving baseline goals in each category also drives your actions.

Great 2p game.  No need to get Agricola: All Creatures, because this plays 2p fantastically.  And it's a game to grow into as there's a family game variant with simple rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I much prefer the family version.  Some occupation/minor improvements are much better than others and a bad draw can ruin the game for you.

I love this game, I love any game with a ton of pieces and a huge rule book. But I think we will look into some variations to make our gameplay feel more varied.

RATING: 8.75
I suck at this game! I love it anyway. To worker placement what El Grande is to Area Control, and I like worker placement games. Lots of variety in the cards -- improvements and occupations -- but if you don't get a set that really meld into a strategy for you they aren't completely necessary. Agonizing decisions on what to do when to make the best farm possible. I would give it that coveted 10 if scoring didn't make my brain melt. Thank god there is an app for that. Still that is part of its charm. Rarely will you get a perfect farm that doesn't loose some points for not having everything. You are constrained to doing the best you can. So hey, maybe I don't suck so badly, I'm just wanting impossible farming perfection.

RATING: 8.5
I like this game. It is very tense; there are so many choices to make and not enough time or resources. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Place a circle on the board, grab some cubes. When you have enough cubes, turn them in for a scoring opportunity.

RATING: 8
Agricola is certainly a fine game.  It is intuitive and the mechanics mesh well.  The theme matches the game systems in an extremely satisfying way.  My grandparents are farmers/ranchers... and the game goals seem to coincide with their life work and goals.

Agricola isn't ground breaking, however, and I feel a game needs to be this way to justify a perfect score.  When Puerto Rico came out it broke new ground and the gaming community rejoiced.

I have played two games now - once with cards and once without.  I think I prefer without.  After I get tired of playing the basic system I am sure the card mix will offer enough to carry the game through many more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Three plays. It's one of these fashionable type of gamers' games: place your worker to choose and claim your action and build on your own board. It's about optimizing your economy, optimizing your points. Solid game and challenging. However, my favorite games are those that have more interaction: besides optimizing your own points, also minimizing other players' score. There is too little of that in this game. And given the length of play, I am more critical. So no higher than a 6.5, I don't follow hypes so easily...

RATING: 4
I like Agricola.  It's not the best game of all time, but it's a nice enough design to keep a gamer satisfied for the duration of a game.  

What I like best about this game is the cards that makes every game a little bit different.

Edit 15th july 2009 : After consensus from many gamer friends, we decided that Agricola should really be played only in the Family version (Without the cards).  It's a more strategic game that way and alleviate the "My hands sucks and yours is terrific" syndrom.  I would play Le Havre instead any day of the week though.

RATING: 9
A very good game with lots of variation and therefore lots of replayability. My few niggles are that it's a pain to set up, doesn't have much player interaction other than blocking someone else's action and, in common with other Rosenberg games, feels like it's coming to an end just as you start to develop something interesting. I also think some of the additional decks are a bit frustrating and unnecessary, and that hand drafting should be the standard way of playing (though it doesn't help novices up against experienced players).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As a late adopter, I probably missed the excitement about the originality of Agricola, and met it after playing a bunch of worker placement games which came after. Maybe because of this, during play there's always the unfavorable comparisons; this one is prettier, that one has way more options, the third is faster and more thematic, while Agricola is just ... solid. It works, does its job, enjoyable, but at this time it is just another worker placement game.

RATING: 9
The thing I love about this game compared to other worker placement/management games is the "downhill" pacing that makes the experience morph as you play the game.  The turns start out slow with little to do and little stress, but as the game continues responsibilities, options, and stresses all grow to a comparatively fevered pitch, that is quite exciting and different than others I have played.  Also, the single player "campaign" is very smart, surprisingly fun, and has really helped me enjoy the game experience more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really enjoy playing Agricola. I don't mind the farming theme and the game-play is tight, rewarding both planning and flexibility. I love euro games and I can see why this one is a classic.

As I play more and more euro games, I'm finding that my enjoyment of any particular game has a direct relationship to it's complexity. 
~ as long as it's well designed and I have the time (and group) to play it

In other words, when it comes to euro games, "Heavier is better!" There may be a peak at which this changes, but I'm definitely not there yet.

Agricola is the heaviest game in my collection at the moment and it is also the highest ranked. I don't think this is an accident.

* worker placement, resource management
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
El juego tiene un par de elementos que penalizan, el no alimentar a tus trabajadores en los turnos de cosecha, y que tu granja al final de la partida no tenga "un poco de todo". Obviamente puedes pasar de estos requisitos, pero penalizan fuertemente en comparación con los jugadores que los cumplan. Para mi gusto esto lo hace restrictivo a la hora de explorar posibles caminos a la victoria con diferentes modelos de granja, algo que cambia en su juego hermano [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/102794/caverna-cave-farmers]Caverna[/url]. Aún así, un punto a favor de Agricola con respecto a su hermano es la cantidad de cartas de sus diferentes mazos.

RATING: 7
Rating based on one play with three players and one play with four players using the Easy deck.  I enjoyed it.  It didn't feel too long.  I liked the variety of actions.  I like the theme and the way it all works together.  That said, it doesn't grab me immediately and make me want to buy it myself.  I would gladly play it more.  The variety of the cards made it seem almost too variable to me.  What gets to me is that often I don't really care what action I take because it's just so variable that it's hard to plan too much ahead, so I care less about it.  I'm sure I'll play it more, but I could see my rating going either way, up or down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This will probably go up to a 9.5 or 10. I've not seen hype over a game like this for years. What sets this apart from the crowd is how tightly the game sticks to the theme - a true rarity these days for a "Euro" style game. And no "intermediate scoring" round either! My only concern is the relative power of the cards and whether you can get stitched up with a bad hand (e.g. 4 plough cards or all your minor improvements needing 3-4 training etc.). Hand drafting may solve this. It might also be worth exploring making sure everyone sees the cards to be used in the game at the start before having them dealt out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
L'Europe Centrale des années 1670. La peste qui sévissait depuis 1348 a finalement été vaincue. le monde civilisé est en reconstruction. Les hommes aménagent leurs chaumières et les rénovent. Les champs doivent être labourés, cultivés et finalement, moissonnés. Le souvenir de la famine des années noires a conduit l'humanité à manger plus de viande (une habitude toujours en vigueur dans notre monde moderne).

À partir d'un lopin de terre et d'une modeste cabane en bois, les joueurs jouent le rôle d'une famille de paysans qui vont tenter de prospérer afin d'avoir, à la fin de la partie, la plus belle ferme.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After few plays I think this game deserves the score of 9. The game is simple and complex, and if you do something wrong, you can't blame your bad luck, it's all your fault. Easy to learn, hard to master.

Also the solo play is interesting.

The game to show to someone who is tired of Settlers but love the eurogames.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
New in collection jan. 08. First german edition.
Initial feeling after first two, much anticipated, plays: again, again!

Game grabs you rightaway. Combine that with the enormous amount of different setups (1-5 players, 3 different decks of cards for both occupations & attributes, each with lots of different possible starts & strategies, and a "family version" without the cards, and I can see myself playing this for years to come. It already has all the "expansions" right there in the box! Rating will probably only go up. 

Update, after 10+ games I think it's a brilliant game that I can keep playing throughout the years to come with various players. It keeps you on your toes without giving you too much headache.

Update after 30+ games: Still enjoy playing this, but it's gradually losing it's charm. Downgraded half a point.

Update after 5 years: Downgraded to a 6, because I don't enjoy it that much anymore and I probably won't suggest playing this in a while.

NL: Een van de favoriete spellen van mijn medespelers. Iedereen die Puerto Rico leuk vind zou dit moeten proberen. Goed spel voor 1 tot 5 spelers, met "instelbare" moeilijkheidsgraad.

RATING: 5
When I first got this game, it seemed like I would really like it.  During the first few games I played, I believed that once I got better at it, it would become my favorite game.  But every play since then has made me like it less and less.  I'm not sure what it is exactly that disturbs me.  I love the idea of forcing the players to diversify their farms, and I feel that every aspect of the game fits really well with the theme.  The cards add a huge amount of variability and force the players to develop new strategies each time the game is played.  Yet something about it just doesn't click with me, and I simply don't enjoy playing it any more.  I know there's a good game in there somewhere, but at this point, I'm not sure I'll ever end up finding it.

RATING: 8
I was very eager to try this highly rated game and after several plays I'm generally not impressed.  It's definitely a heavier game in that there is quite a bit to pay attention to and plan for at any given time.  That being the case, this game tends to be mentally exhausting for me, but doesn't feel adequately rewarding.  In most games where there are multiple point tactics, I can chose a few to really capitalize on.  Here, I feel like I'm punished if I don't try to do everything which ends up feeling more stressful than fun.  I will say that it is very engaging and does require good planning and decision making, but plowing through this for 3+ hours is just not enjoyable.

Update: I came back to this game after not playing it for about 2 years and really enjoyed it.  Looking for cool card combos and the timing of when to perform certain tasks was tricky, but it was nice to see plans come to fruition.  Maybe exposure to more worker placement games has made me appreciate this one more?  Still don't think it's my favorite, but apparently I like it more than I used to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game, although I can't quite put my finger on why.  I think it might be because it's so tough, because there's never enough time to do what you want, so you have to make the best choices you can.  And everyone's in the same boat.  A real brain-burner.

*Edit:  I think the reason why I enjoy this game so much, despite the brain hurt, is that it so SIMPLE.  Each action you can take is really easy to understand.  The game feels like it plays really quickly, and yet at the end you really feel like you have WORKED for your little farm.

RATING: 4
This felt very much like Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small on steroids, which I guess is exactly what it is. Very tight - you need to do everything but don't have the actions, every inefficiency taunts you and the whole thing ends just when you start to get thing rolling.

I can see the appeal, though it isn't exactly what I'm after in a game - the interaction is chunky, the play is chunky and sequential, your goals are clearly delineated as is your paths to them - however you all end up nudging each other out of sync forcing them to do inefficient detours. I like things more opaque I guess, and with further reaching butterfly-effects. Of course, some of these may reveal themselves with more play but bah. I'll gladly play this, but it's my definition of a 7.

Also, the cards, I like the cards - and they add important variability, but you'd need to draft them for them to make sense.

A good game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
An interesting worker placement game about farming.
The game is very enjoyable. You develop your farm, expand your family, get food, etc. You have to remember to develop in all areas to avoid negative points in the end of game scoring.

There is a mechanism where you have to feed your family or get negative points. This is disliked by some people, but I think it makes the game more realistic and tense. I heard Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small doesn't have that mechanism if it bothers someone a lot.

There is a beginners' variant where you play without cards. I would recommend playing with the cards from the beginning, because they add a lot of variety and not that much more complexity.

While I enjoyed it I wouldn't go out of my way to play it again.

1 October 2008 Update: Plays nicely across the board, even for one. I'm still keeping it a 9.5 but expect to lower it to a 9 after 30+ plays. Great game fo sho!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Game in a Nutshell: Using a family of workers, build a home, plow and plant fields, raise animals and have children (to help do more work). Score points in all categories listed. 

Played as: 2,3,5 player

Played with: Vanilla, Farmers of the Moor + Through the Seasons

Pros: Ambitiously implemented theme. So many minor variables from game to game it'd be virtually impossible to find one way of playing that will work every time. Has a great pace with lots of different things to build up on your farm and it only seems to come together right as the game is ending. Any game where you get to build and admire an end product adds points.

Cons: If there is such a thing as an elegant game design, this is surely the opposite. The shear amount of cards (and often poorly written ones) leaves room for lots of questions and clarifications on any given game. No solid player interaction that I noticed outside of what actions someone else might take and if I should choose it first. The interactive deck didn't do a whole lot to add much eather, and what it did, certainly was not 'interestingly' interaction. Scoring is somewhat excessive. The worker placement mechanic is really the core of the gameplay and not all that original (not bad, but Caylus did it better). The cards and everything else that fleshed it out felt like tack-ons to add longevity to an otherwise good, but not great game. 

Other: This is a game that's all about the "strategy" while having basically nothing of lasting interest tactically. I think a big part of this game is what cards you start out with. Depending on how cards are distributed to ensure a fair balance among all players is the difference between a game worth playing to the end and one where the winner is evident before even the halfway point. I suggest using any method other then the deal and play style.  

Best Use: A gamers game for those who like a lot of strategic depth.

RATING: 7
I was taught this game by friends who love this game and the enthusiasm rubbed off on me. 

I'm not sure what I like about it. Certainly I enjoy the theme and the light-heartedness of the game. I appreciate the many possible paths to victory and being able to build up your own farm.

Perhaps I find some perverse pleasure in the brutality of the game. There never seems to be enough turns, or enough food, and as soon as (or before) you start getting your farm working the game is over!

I'm not sure why, but it's a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dec 2014 update - after 368 games on iPad:

Game is still fresh and engaging.

Jan 2014 -after 10 solo games and 30 MP games on my iPad.

One of the best games I ever played.

Reading so many good, raving reviews about this game, I bought this game for my iPad and wow, it is a real gem. 

Agricola is a such deep game despite the simple interface. Farming is never so brutal and tough. I was hugely attracted to Agricola and simply can't have it enough. I play solo as well as have usually 40-50 online games with 2-5 players running at the same time.

At first I try several family games as instructed, then try the cards. Game with the cards change some of strategies and ways of doings things in a game, which I feel overwhelmed sometimes. With E,I, and K decks I have almost infinite replayability which I really appreciate.

Pros: 
- It is a surprisingly deep strategic game, just like chess. With cards, it resembles Chess960, which have no fixed opening moves.
- Sense of urgency and quiet, fierce competition
- It is very thematic experience, you really like your farm.
- Multiplayer is very well implemented
- Although players take different routes to achieve things for their own farm, in the end all the farms look quite the same anyway. The joy lays in how you develop such a farm while trying to block others do the same thing.


Cons:
- You have to make difficult decisions all the time. Some less analytical people just don't like that.
- iPad version animates a bit too much.
- iPhone version is too small to enjoy, try it only when you are familiar with all cards
- The AI players are quite weak.
- The farm will look almost the same each time despite different ways of playing Agricola. Maybe one day I will eventually be tired of playing this game, but now I am definitely hypnotized.

Overall, a 10 for such well designed game with excellent theme, a game so versatile in strategies to win, with so high replayability.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Agrícola dispone de 2 modalidades: la familiar y la avanzada. Muchos jugones advierten que el juego es algo complejo y largo (30 minutos aproximadamente por jugador).
Es de los pocos juegos en los que la temática está muy bien reflejada en el sistema en muchos aspectos. Cada jugador representa una pareja de campesinos (marido y mujer se entiende) que intentan sacar el máximo partido de sus tierras, arándolas y sembrando en ellas, cuidando los pastos de ovejas, vacas y cerdos, haciendo reformas en casa o ampliando la familia (eso es tener hijos, no comprar más vacas). Al final del juego, se suman puntos de victoria por logros conseguidos y se restan puntos por cosas que no hemos conseguido hacer o por aquellos momentos en los que, después de una cosecha, no hemos podido alimentar a algún miembro de la familia.
Cada turno, empezando por el jugador inicial, decide que acción de las disponibles quiere realizar. Las acciones disponibles pueden ser las fijas durante toda la partida, junto con las que se van revelando turno tras turno, dependiendo de la ronda en la que se esté. Cuando un jugador decide hacer una acción determinada, coloca uno de sus fichas que representa a uno de los miembros de la familia disponibles y lo pone en la casilla (o carta) correspondiente a esa acción. Nadie más podrá hacer en esa ronda la misma acción (es el único factor puteo del juego en el modo familiar).
Esta mecánica recuerda muy mucho al Puerto Rico, mezclada con algunas otras como el Ciudadelas y el Pilares de la Tierra. El juego tiene 16 turnos, divididas en 9 rondas si no recuerdo mal, y la velocidad de juego va avanzando mucho conforme se va llegando a las rondas finales.
Tiene momentos divertidos cuando alguno de los jugadores ha calculado mal y no tiene fichas de comida para su familia después de la cosecha (carta de mendicidad por ficha que falte, que son 3 puntacos menos al final de la partida).
Mi valoración personal del juego es buena. Aunque este tipo de juegos me acaban aburriendo tras un par de partidas seguidas porque odio los sistemas en los que los jugadores juegan cada uno a su bola sin interaccionar directamente con el resto. Al final todo se basa en un sistema de planificación, cálculos y estrategias para sacarle el máximo partido a tus acciones por turno, que se trastocan continuamente cuando el resto de jugadores se adelantan en quitarte esa acción que tanto necesitabas. Aún así he de admitir que el juego tiene su gracia y su despliegue en la mesa es sorprendente.
El aspecto gráfico del juego no es una maravilla, pero es agradable y se lee con claridad qué es cada cosa.
La gran ventaja del juego, de ahí su popularidad, es que en su versión avanzada es muy difícil de quemar por repetitividad de las partidas, como le pasa al Puerto Rico. Y es que en el modo avanzado, aparte de haber unos pequeños cambios en las reglas, se pueden añadir hasta 5 mazos de cartas que en total suman más de 300: oficios, pertenencias, catástrofes... y que le dan ese puntito al juego que lo hace menos predecible y más variado.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 10
This has been a 10 for me for a couple of years and it hasn't fallen.  Worker placement is one of my favorite genres and I love that there are so many paths to victory if you are able to adapt.  I like that if you have a rigid path in your mind you are going to fail.  Each turn the optimal move has to be reassessed as each person takes the tiles but I have never felt like there isn't something worth doing on the table.  As close as there is to a perfect worker placement game for me.

RATING: 9.5
Don't own but enjoy playing it. Takes a long time to explain, learn rules, etc. Very heavy on resource management and very little interaction in terms of trading and negotiating with other players. However, lots of decision making in terms of deciding what you will do with the cards you are dealt and how you will place your "people" on each round. One of the most complex games I've ever played and really liked. Takes 2-3 hours to play with an extra 30 minutes to explain the rules to new players. After playing this one at a games night, I like to decompress by playing party type games.

RATING: 5.5
Well, didn't set the house on fire.  The game was well-done but just seems too 'gamey'.  If my neighbor decides to plow his field, why can't I?  Do the seasons become shorter and shorter in 17th C Germany?  Why else do the number of rounds decrease?  Why does nothing bad happen- wars, taxes, illness?  I feel I've experienced most of the mechanisms before.  I can appreciate all the work on the artwork, but I'm not so fond of the style (on the cards, anyway).  I like Caylus better, but perhaps this beats out Puerto Rico.  Anyway, I can safely steer away from a purchase, but glad to have had a chance to try it.  There just is nothing new here: I hear all about how it includes 300 cards of which only a small subset are used: heck, Sierra Madre has been doing that for years.

There's a fair bit of explanation required for a first time player to learn it, so you don't want to drag someone in who's half-hearted.  But once you get past that (and the long play time) it's a very enjoyable game.

RATING: 9.5
This was my favorite game until we got the expansion.  I didn't think this game could be improved upon, but after playing the expansion I would say that it is slightly too important in this game to quickly expand your family, and that it is really hard to do well otherwise.  But I wouldn't have even noticed this without the expansion, and this is still a great game.  The additional action spaces keep the game balanced for scarcity of resources whether you play with 2, 3 or 4.  I like the family game, as it allowed us to teach this to my parents to get them comfortable with the mechanics of the game before moving on to the full game.  Scores ranged from 23 to 62, but everyone had fun because they were all building there own farms, and lower scorers were excited the first time they had no unused spaces. Once you become familiar with the basics, the cards add infinite variety.  This game is so tightly constructed, and everything you do makes sense intuitively.  A great theme that was incorporated perfectly.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[microbadge=1714]

[u]04-Jan-2013[/u]: This has probably been the most played game I've owned within a short period of time - I'll have 30 plays within 3 months.  This is an excellent, heavier game.  However, I've mainly only played it solo and therefore the rating is probably a notch below what it would be if this was played more often with additional players.

The challenge and complexity seems like it would increase with the number of players.  I have played with my daughter, K, a few times and once with the whole family.  Hopefully, I'll be able to get it to the table with more people this year.

So, based on mostly solo plays, I think this is still a very good game in my collection.  It can be on the fiddly side with so many resources / little pieces to keep track of and add/remove from the game board every turn, but it's worth it.

After playing the family rules early on, I've found that adding in the cards actually make it easier to build up a nice farm.  The additional actions and bonuses they provide really help to guide you along a successful path.  So far, I've only played with the E Deck and I'm looking forward to trying out the others this year, both for the challenge and the added variety.

I have not found the common complaint about the stress to feed your workers every harvest as, to me, that is the goal of the game.  It's not to build the biggest and best farm.  It's to build an efficient, productive farm that provides for your family.

It has a long, slow burn over those first 10 rounds or so.  But the action really ramps up in the last fourth of the game.

[u]24-Jan-2014[/u]: This is a great game for solo or multiplayer.  However, the solo campaign rules didn't thrill me.  Playing a single solo session seems more enjoyable to me.  Great, tough worker placement game.

RATING: 9.5
Can't wait to break this one out. Looks like it lives up to the hype and has everything I felt was lacking from the great ACBaS

*edit Nov 7, 2012* Ok, wow. Amazing game. Probably the most fiddly setup/cleanup I've yet encountered. I think I may take a page out of my own book with Homesteaders and leave everything in its own plastic bag

Having said that, this game is what I hoped. It is ACBaS but with more to keep track of. Played the family variant and I really am looking forward to bumping up to the cards. I'd also like to play it with more than two, though two players was a really good time. So after 1 play, I say the hype is well earned

*edit Dec 2012* Played full version with wife. She didn't like it! Found it too stressful. Meanwhile, I thought it was fantastic and totally transforms the game into a true strategic resource manager. Also brings engine building into it much more. I can never go back. 

So now this game may not be played as much as it was. I still want to get her to try Through the Ages but that'll come later. Right now, probably Castles of Burgundy. 

I do want to get this game played one more time and see how she feels about it. I think she was just overwhelmed (maybe convincing myself that this is so!)

RATING: 6.75
based on three plays so far.   I really enjoyed this.   I think it is less fiddly than Caylus, but with more going on in the game.   the theme seems to really fit this game as well.

*** Update May 2009 ***

i loathe the 5 player version and would avoid it at all costs.  i think the sweet spot might be 3 or 4 players, but the 4 player game seems a bit long for what it is.

really bizarre, but i have enjoyed my recent agricola plays less.  could simply be that in the Nov 2007 - Apr 2008 time period i played 25+ games of this and maybe i am a little burned out.  i find myself wanting to draft the occupations/minor improvements MTG style which adds a bit of length and can cause even more AP to break out.  

i expected that this would be a highly likely lifetime top 10 for me, but i do not think that is the case.  however, i really disliked Le Havre at first glance, but i find myself more intrigued.  

it is unlikely that i would ever turn down a game of this (except 5 player), but do not find myself looking for opportunities to play.
