=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's good. But not as good as [gameid=3076], or [gameid=28143], or even [gameid=13]. It's just a good worker placement game with a strong theme, that plays well for 2 through 5.

I get that it has like, infinite replayability due to zillions of cards. But [i]Race[/i] does zillions of cards better, because you actually get to see them, and the luck of the draw has a chance to balance out. (You know what, give me just a minute while I go change my rating on that to 10.) My desire to get better at [i]Agricola[/i] extends as far as learning to work the family game more efficiently; leet card comboz aren't going to take it any further for me. And without the leeching dimension of [i]PR[/i] and [i]Race[/i], there's just less here to learn.

The solo game rates an 'eh' - being able to let building materials pile up before you grab them just doesn't feel the same as the real game.

The farming - it's just a metaphor, right? This game could easily be about building spaceships. As one of the strengths of the game is that it requires tough choices, I believe that it is a good metaphor. But, is it the right one? Or, is the scoring system the right system to match this metaphor? In particular, I feel like food is a means to an end (not starving) and if I [i]don't[/i] starve, what does it matter how much, and what kinds of food I have remaining that I [i]didn't[/i] eat?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I believe that one of the main reason that this game is valued to high is the following: During the game you always want to have that extra action. There is never only one good option. So when the game is over, you want to try a total different strategy.

But the problem with the game is. In the end you always come to the same conclusion. The only good strategy is to spread the focus and try to score the least negative points.

Plenty of "action" cards are added just to make one game different from the other although it never feels very different.

Enough negativity. I like playing this game! It certainly deserves to be in the top 100 of games. But I don't like to start playing it, especially with new players. It takes like forever to set up everything in a manner that feels handy to every player.
You need to make good arrangements about who will add which goods at the start of the game so you don't get all confused during every refill phase.

Putting everything in the box is easy... but it takes some time to do that in an ordered fashion. So you hopefully spend less time setting up the next game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The only thing is that every game seems a bit too short. But maybe that's good as there is just so many things I want to do and end up not being able to. Also scales down to 2 players very well

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After one play, seems like just a very solid Euro. I think it will have some depth of strategy, many paths to victory with none dominating completely, and therefore good replay value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was interested to play this, simply as everyone else was. The game exceeded my expectations. Whilst it is glaringly apparent that you are involved in yet another efficiency exercise, it is actually a pretty solid, light / medium weight game. It strictly follows the Euro blueprint, but there is some fun to be had here. I could not put my finger upon why though. I would consider Agricola to be the ultimate honing of the Euro genre. It is all aspects of that style fine tuned and perfected. Almost as if the designers looked at the top 10 games on BGG, and went through each and picked out the systems that made them popular to incorporate them into their new game. The game is varied and the decisions are not restricted to a choice between sensible and stupid. I found though that I was playing against the game rather than my opponents for the most part, it seemed that the only thing they did that affected me was choose an action, thus rendering it unavailable.  Certainly not the kind of game I would like to play all that often, but every now and again with the right crowd is not too much of a stretch.

RATING: 9
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* One of the best worker placement/resource management games out there at the moment
* Learning curve is steeper than some games, but rewards those who persevere
* Family game is a nice introduction, but the genius of the game lies in the card synergies
* Prototypical Rosenberg, as no one has enough time to do everything they want/need to do
* Good as a Rosenberg primer and for any fan on the mechanics listed above 
* Initial rating: [b]9/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]b{Further Thoughts}b (after 25 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Game has become my go to solo game, as the series style is addictive and engaging
* Not much experience playing with more than 2, but does seem to bog down with 4+
* Card synergies are alluring, but game is won and lost in the care of one's farmyard
* Further rating: [b]9/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]g{Advanced Thoughts}g (after 50 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* No signs of being usurped as my solo game of choice, but cards can get repetitious
* "Collect 'em all" aspect of the myriad expansions is making this feel like a CCG
* Advanced rating: [b]9/10[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I like to think of this as Oregon Trail v2.0: what happens once you get there (albeit a bit earlier in time; people are living in clay, wood, or stone huts).  In this game you start out with a small wooden hut and two people, and over the course of 14 rounds try to build up your homestead.  To generate food players must sow wheat/vegetables in fields or build pastures to house animals, which is then consumed by people in "harvest" rounds.  The game consists primary of choosing actions from a central board; each action can only be taken once a round, so there's a tremendous amount of fighting over the actions.  There are far too many actions that appear desirable each turn, so choosing the right actions is difficult (and a key part of the game's beautiful mix of tactics and strategy).  Players are dealt 14 cards at the start of the game that give rule-breaking abilities when played; some of them are very powerful (possibly unbalancing the game), and using them effectively is key to success in the game, yet very difficult (some have clear minor uses and are easy to use; many seem to not be worth the actions to play; some are game-winners, but only if used properly).  

Overall this is a very enjoyable brain-burning game.  The game takes a long time to play (all our games have been at least 2 hours), but when I'm playing the game I don't notice how long it's taking; I'm always busy thinking about my next move in the game or analyzing what other people are doing.  I played this game five times in the first week my friends got it; I'd say it's a keeper.

One problem that I've seen in the games I've played so far is that it's easy for players to slip into a subsistence mode, wherein all their actions are spent getting food to feed their people.  People in this mode barely scape by, meaning that no growth or point-generating actions occur.  This seems to happen a lot with a bread-baking strategy (as this strategy requires an extra action to get food from a harvest), and can be very frustrating for the players (as it's often unclear what they're doing wrong, but it's clear to them by halfway through the game that they're losing).

[Update: After 9 plays, I'm realizing that the cards that are dealt to each player at the start of the game are a major unbalancing force.  Regardless of whether the cards are drafted or randomly dealt, a single player can end up with a combination of cards that is powerful enough to severely unbalance the game (and, assuming they play the cards well, this unbalanced nature can positively amplify on itself).  In a game this long, and with this much strategy, it's frustrating to end up with a start condition that can potentially be so unbalanced.  Because of this I've dropped my rating from 9 to 6.5.  If there's a good way to equalize the cards at the start of the game this would easily go back to a 9 or 9.5.]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Pick actions to improve your farm for most points.

Plays: 2.
Type: VP engine = a game where you build an engine to collect victory points most efficiently.
Complexity: Medium.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: See BGG.
Player interaction: Competition for scarce resources - actions.
Randomness: None (Base game).

Replayability: None, I don't enjoy efficiency engines.
Fun: None.  This isn't a game, it's a math problem. You have a number of actions that you are to order in the optimal sequence to maximise output. Your opponents are trying to do the same and to block your optimal actions, so the optimal sequence is constantly changing. All information is available, so you can always (in theory) solve the equation. Math problems do not make me smile.
Memorability: None, I can't get excited about building a farm. "Yay. My sheep produced offspring. And the grain is coming along fine from the fields. I think I'll go bake some bread." And if you strip away the theme, what am I supposed to remember? That player C's engine made 3 more points than mine?

Thematic integration: Strained.
Components: Functional.

Who will like this: Number crunchers.

RATING: 3
I mostly don't like Euros but tried Agricola for the first time. Wasn't too painful as other Euros I've played but it was too long. Theme works for the most part but so what? Fairly dry (farming isn't a fun topic for a game let's face it) and would have been worse but I have a fun gaming group who keep me going. Too many choices though which has you playing the system rather than having fun. Very little player interaction, a common problem with many Euros.

Typical of so many Euros where the process is the thing. The more complicated the better. Designer's of Euro's like this just don't seem to understand that games should be fun. Not work.

Games like this are not accessible to a broader audience and in fact will put most people off gaming.

RATING: 10
By virtue of my 2015 10x10, I've been able to play Agricola several times recently. It's been great to really explore the game not only with my gamer friends but also playing in family mode with my daughter (who now declares it her favorite game). I've enjoyed the solo mode quite a bit as well.

With more experience, the game has ceased to be stressful and has instead turned into a tense challenge with new twists each play. I've especially been enjoying what the Farmers of the Moor expansion brings to the game.

I've also come to realize that Uwe Rosenberg is probably my favorite of the big Euro designers, and (for the moment, anyway), this is my favorite of his games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Our favorite game. I got it a few months after becoming a board game geek, my wife and I fell in love with it quickly. I love the blend of tactics and strategy, the crucial decisions that need to be made and the variety that the cards add.

I've since pimped my Agricola like crazy: animeeples, veggimeeples, the X-deck, L-deck, O-deck, Through the Seasons, stickers for my family members, player boards with new artwork, and finally Farmers of the Moor. I even bought dice and made my own copy of Agricola Express.

This is one of very few games I feel I could play competitively (the 2-player game at least.) 

2015 update: we don't play this much anymore, but it will always be very special. When we were new to the hobby, there was a long time where, every time we sat down to play something, it was "Okay, are we playing Agricola? Or something else?".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love it. After my first two games, I decided to wait for the English edition (it wasn't even announced back then), then decided I can't wait: I must get this now. So I bought the German edition, made some Finnish paste-ups... It's just that good.

I've played mostly the family game so far. That's good - you don't necessarily need the cards. It's good with my wife as a two-player game, lovely with gamers as a five-player game (though a tad long that way)... Like W. Eric Martin said, Agricola combines an experience game and an engine game, that's most likely what makes it so sweet.

The game's a tad too long with five. I'm reluctant to play it with four newbies, two hours is just too much. I prefer the game with less: a three-player family game goes easily in an hour or less.

Enthusiastic (with two players, no cards and maybe Farmers of the Moor).

RATING: 5
The widespread adoration of this game borders on madness. There is nothing about it that draws me back. The best part of the design lies in the varied and copious Occupation and Minor Improvement cards, which fortunately keep the beginning of the game—and the rest of it too for that matter—from becoming formulaic.

Not an easy game to learn: even in the family version a new player still needs to know the Major Improvement cards well. Other significant quibbles: the less-than-good rules set, the sprawling, cumbersome layout, the okay but could have been better art design, and the constant, increasingly fiddly upkeep. [10 plays and done?]

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Playing Agricola only once in a while, I had come to find plays felt overly similar, and this rating might have gone down to a 6 briefly. As others have noted, successful farms are all going to look pretty similar in the end, so it's hard to feel like you've pursued a new path strategy at the end of any game. [i]Once again, I'm expanding my home, growing my family, and getting at least one of everything. Yay.[/i] The game severely punishes any attempt to stray too far from this formula, as I can attest from my many, many losses.

For another game, that might have been the end of the road, but Agricola has at least one saving grace. First, it's got the cards, which give widely ranging incentives to shift how you achieve your goals (even if those goals are ultimately the same in every game). In addition to the variety inherent in any game that's got hundreds of cards, there are also varying degrees to which you can incorporate the cards into the game, ranging from the family game (no cards) to using a "power deck" (all the most powerful cards). Much to my surprise, I enjoyed the former quite a bit and found the latter [i]still[/i] punished you for playing too many cards. There's the free Through the Seasons expansion here on BGG, other decks available (WC and G are reportedly the best), and of course the Farmers of the Moor expansion, though that severely lengthens the game.

Speaking of game length, that is probably the main limiting factor for Agricola. I have found 3-player games test my patience for the exercise of cube conversion, no matter how many fun cards you have, and I am therefore very hesitant to try it with 4. At two players, the game is just an hour, which is perfect, but both players are obligated to go for livestock, which does narrow the strategic variety in the game. Nonetheless, I haven't tired of it at that count, and I remain interested in seeing how the many variations in cards and incentives play out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
As venerable as this game is, and as devoted its following, I just don't care for it.  It suffers from the "dead man walking" flaw that plagues many a Eurogame, wherein a failure to perfectly execute a strategy early on dooms a player to failure without realizing it.

(I know some Eurogamers probably consider this a feature, not a bug, but I try to avoid those people at parties.  :D )

I will say that the artwork and components do a very nice job of giving the game a solid setting - you actually feel like you're farming, ranching, building, etc., instead of just shuffling tokens around the board.

I will probably give this one another chance or two, given how much people love it - it might be that I've undervalued it.  But for the moment, it's middle of my pack at best.

I love worker placements and all, but something about Agricola rubs me wrong, I just dislike it oddly enough

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Old collection

This is a rather complex worker placement game in which the theme really fits the game. You really feel like being a farmer trying to harvest his crops, nourishing his family, improving his house... at the end of the game we're always left with the feeling: I still wanted to do this and I wanted to finish that, and if only I would have... It always seems like you need a couple of more rounds to finish your work completely making you want to play the game again and again if only it didn't last that long.

It plays well with 2 players too and the game doesn't last that long then. We also bought the 2-player edition of Agricola but it doesn't give us the same 'wow' feeling that we have when playing the original. Maybe that changes with the 2-player expansion.

It's not cheap but you get a box fully packed with nicely crafted playing pieces! I didn't like the follow-up Caverna as much as it is not as tight as the original Agricola game in my opinion. For years, this was our favorite game but it doesn't get played as often anymore.

RATING: 5
I played "Agricola" with my brother and my buddy. I want to try it again because now I have a little feel for it. At first glance, I really dislike the complexity of the game. There is a terribly steep learning curve, which is usually an indication of a bad game for me. It lacks elegance because of all the obtrusive text on every single card (and there are tons of cards) and all the minutely detailed rules. There are also too many components and too much book-keeping. Nevertheless, buried beneath all of the clutter and confusion, there seems to be a very fun game hiding.

RATING: 8.5
Great game.  I feel like it does lead a little bit to analysis paralysis, but in a sort of fun way.  If you end up getting to slow a game it's no fun, but show me a game where that's not true.  The beginning really captures the stress of trying to do a million things at once.  There's food to get, babies to have, houses to build, and cards to play.  A lot of the game is making early sacrifices to supplement a powerful end game.  It's not a play every-day sort of game for me, but most of the good ones aren't.  Very fun to watch as different players branch out on different strategies.

RATING: 10
Okay, I'm on the Agricola bandwagon.  I'm not sure I can say much that hasn't been said, but this is a very fun game, even without animeeples.

Update- Keeps getting better with each play; I've upgraded my rating to a 10.

Another update (1/2015):  Don't have time to play with gamers much anymore, so I bought the iOS app - awesomeness!  Also tried playing with the family rules and my pre-teen kids; works for them, too.  Good family game, as everyone pretty much does their own thing, so not a lot of hurt feelings- maybe just a little annoyance if someone grabbed an action you wanted.  And the family game is a gateway to the real game.  I think this has moved into being my favorite game ever, partly because of the variety provided by two sets of rules and different decks of cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Mikor tudomást szereztem a boardgamegeek-ről, azt tettem amit gondolom mindenki más: megnéztem a top játékokat. Az Agricolát itt szemeltem ki magamnak, hazudnék ha azt mondanám a kis állatok nem játszottak szerepet.
Viszont azt kell, hogy mondjam, túl nagyot ugrottam (első 5 társasom között van talán). Nekem még ugyan nem jelentett nagy gondot, de a családnak úgy tűnt, túl nehezen emészthető, pedig csak a családi verzióval játszottunk. Ezért félretettem, hogy később majd előveszem. Lassan lehet megérett a dolog?
Addig is 7 pontot ér nálam de kap +1-et a sok mütyür miatt. Bár itt most meg kell jegyeznem, hogy nekem hiányzott 3 fa korong és az egyik bárány mozgássérült volt (nem volt lába, majd töltök fel fotót). A Szellemlovas kérdés nélkül pótolta illetve cserélte! Csak bosszantó, hogy egy ilyen drága játéknál (vagy úgy egyáltalán) előfordul.

Társasjáték világnap alkalmából előkerült egyik jó barátom kérésére. 4-en játszottunk, rajtam kívül mindenki újonc, és én is csak családival játszottam 2-szer, 2 fővel, most viszont durr bele minden! Hát azt kell mondanom WOW!! 4-en, kártyákkal, barátokkal, mekkora különbség!!! Viszont legközelebb draftoljuk a kártyákat (a győztes keze nagyon tápos volt), bár már így is 3 órán át játszottunk.. :P

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
At the time of this writing, Agricola is the new #1 on BGG.  Does it deserve it?  Well, that is for each of you to decide.  For me, Puerto Rico is a better game overall and deserves the #1 spot.  Aricola is a great game, however, it just not better than PR.  Let's get the little stuff out of the way--the components are fine (I don't need animeeples and cubes work just fine) but not outstanding.  For example, the cards could be of thicker and better stock.  Also, the rules are not as clear as they could be.  These are minor points.  The real test is gameplay--and Aricola, again, measures up great--just not better than PR.   I will say that after several plays, I much prefer Agricola over Le Harve.  Although both are frustrating with their "if I just had one more action"--Agricola is a much better game IMHO.  Awards: Meeples' Choice (2007); International Gamers Award-General Strategy (2007); Spiel des Jahres Winner, Special Prize for Complex Game (2008); Deutscher Spielepreis (2008); Austria Hall of Games; BGG Golden Geek Winner-Game of the Year (2008); BGG Golden Geek Winner-Gamers Game (2008); Tric Trac d'Or (Gold) 2008; Hra roku (Czech Republic) 2008; Jogo do Ano 2008 Spiel Portugal (Portugal); Jda "Juego del Año en España" (Spain) 2008; Gra Roku Game of the Year (Poland) 2009; Gra Roku - Gamers' Choice (Poland) 2009; Ludoteca Ideale (2009).

RATING: 9
A brilliant game from start to finish.
Build the best farm to win the game but make sure you feed your family, otherwise you're going to lose a lot of points.
Great level of depth, but rules are straightforward, so it's very accessible.
Highly recommended.

RATING: 10
What could be better than building your own farm? The basic rules are grasped fairly easily, but the tactics for winning can take a long time to learn. New players will be destroyed by more experienced players, but they can also mess up more experienced players plans by making sub-optimal moves.

RATING: N/A
Standard worker placement
Light strategy, the gist of it is to build an engine that is capable of feeding your own people (self-sufficient) and focus on producing a type of good that allows you to score high at the end of the game

Scoring criteria forces all players to almost play the same way. Penalty is very harsh and the lack of proper planning in the 1st few rounds can really cripple the player.

Replaced by Caverna

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.75
I absolutely respect the design of the game.  The theme integrates well with the mechanics; after all, you get to see how your farm evolves throughout the game!  In addition, I like the fact that the many different cards bring a lot of variety to the game.

On the other hand, I don't like the scoring system.  You're almost forced to have a very balanced farm at the end of the game; I feel like there would be more variety if one could successfully specialize in some areas and ignore others.

But the biggest negative for me: like a lot of others, I don't like feeling like I'm always struggling to feed my family.  There's just too much tension in there for my tastes.

RATING: 7
A pretty pure Eurogame about raising a peasant family. With almost everything being worth points, there's no single path to victory, and proper utilization of professions and implements is the main differentiating factor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Agricola has good mechanics, interesting use of the occupation and round cards and isn't as fiddly as some here on BGG have said. It has low downtime (assuming low analysis paralysis) and plays inside 90 minutes. The production values are good. The theme is meh but not fatal. I usually like worker placement games.

So why don't I like the 'gric? 

In summary, it feels like being a contestant in Iron Chef but the contestants need to continually reconsider their menu because all their required ingredients are scarced and randaom and could be snatched away by the opposition and their team. Agricola's scoring system requires that, like Iron Chef, you need to serve a 3 course meal around and unreliable supply of ingredients that may never be available to you. Add in that in Iron Chef that you're team of cooks may spit in the food if they're not paid every 10 minutes they are working and there you have Agricola - a headache more than a fun game. 

I'd definitely play Agricola if someone badly wants to play, and I think any dedicated gamer should try it at least once, but I wouldn't push it on the table myself.

>>Updated to a 7.5 after playing the iOS version over the holiday season and with some friends. Although there are lots of occupation and improvement cards that are said to make the game a unique experience, that is only partly true. There are some cards that are vastly more powerful than others while there are some cards that will never get played due to their insane resource requirements (improvements) or high level of dependency on events occuring in the game (occupations). The one aspect that does make the game interesting is the random emergence of the action space cards each turn, which does keep the players guessing and struggling to position themselves for the most useful actions at just the right time. Overall, though, the game is largely about getting in earliest on the house building and family growth without starving while other players do the same within the scarce actions available. This part of the Agricola definitely isn't new. Newbies who aren't familiar with the timing of when grain, vegetables and livestock naturally grow and become available before and after harvest, as well as how to time their actions around those factors will get trashed by the more experienced players. Agricola also seems very prone to analysis paralysis, so don't expect a short game with inexperienced or anxious players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
Was it all hype over substance? Not altogether! It is a godd game but you need to be careful when selecting which card decks to play with, as mixing them together can unbalance the game.

After playing with 5 players and the Farmers on the Moor expansion, my fears have been realised that this game is way too long. I feel that game is really a group of people sharing a board but playing their own games with minimal interaction, and for such a long game, it doesn't work for me.

RATING: 8
I quite enjoyed Agricola without loving it. I can get into the development of my farm and I really like all the decisions, even if they can get a bit overwhelming at times. 

What I dislike though are the bland look of the game and the fiddly nature of all the bits and the micromanagement that is required. I think this game would drive me nuts if I owned it...hence I don't.

I don't buy the animeeple argument as a cure for the blandness either. It won't change those bland boards and wooden animals...really...don't go bagging miniature painters now you Euro folk. :P

RATING: 10
I find seeing my farm grow in front of me rewarding and that's almost enough in itself to make me love the game, but added on top of that you have the difficult decisions weighing up which way to push your farm, the tense moments where you struggle to scoop up that final food for the harvest and the subtle but pivotal player interaction.

And that's just the family version. The full version makes the game even better, with so many more choices and so much harder choices.. The only thing I don't like is that seating order can have quite an impact on the outcome in some groups (some people are more bothered about taking the starting player token than others), but a house rule quickly fixes that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An exciting thought provoking game. Agricola ensures that none of the games you play are the same as variations of the round cards are revealed differently in different games played. What I enjoyed about this game is the micro-managing aspect of your farm, and the constantly changing tactics that you must employ to ensure that you use up for farm space whilst simultaneously not accumulate negative points by allowing your family to starve. 
I love every single thing about this game from the occupation and lesson cards all the way down to the adorable sheep, pig and cattle meeples.
This game however is not for someone who is looking for a quick game, just like real farming this game requires a lot of thought, planning and strategy to ensure the most effective yield for your evening.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've also played a couple dozen games solo, though I haven't logged them as plays.

The core gameplay seems, in many ways, to be a distilled version of the resource manipulation and worker placement that I enjoy in Puerto Rico and Caylus (also Homesteaders), with a dash of the action crunch from Princes of Florence.

The solitaire game is a fascinating operations research puzzle.  The two-player game, at least the family version, is not quite as tactile as I had feared it might be, but perhaps that will emerge after a few plays with the same opponent.  Multiplayer, at the level I am at, seems to be won by whoever is best able to execute the plan that they've come up with despite the interference (deliberate or otherwise) of the other players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Played 6th time.  This game is challenging but what it is missing for me is called 'Fun Factor', which rates around 2 on a scale of 1-10.  It's just a game that doesn't click with me.
I can't seem to put together a hand of cards (even with drafting) that give me an advantage.  That aside, I can still get a decent score.  But I do find the game tedious rather than fun.

------------

Agricola is an OK game, NOT a great game.  Granted I've only played it 5 times, but I don't see what all the hype is about.  My opinion of it may go up with more game plays.

It has the worker placement mechanic of Caylus, but with less workers to be placed, and with many more options.  And you thought Caylus caused AP.

Even though I'm not crazy about the 'farming' theme, it is well integrated.

There is the In the Year of the Dragon feel to it of, don't starve your family.

And there is the Race for the Galaxy similarity of, I have all these cards and don't necessarily know if they can benefit me at all.  As well as minimal player interaction.

The game forces you to be constantly thinking about your available optimal choices and strategies, and readjusting them constantly as your preferred choices are snatched up by other players.  This is GOOD!

However, I do feel that given equally skilled players the one with the better cards will win.  Unless the card distribution is evenly weighted amongst the players.  And I can say that in the 5 games I have played, this is a 50/50 chance.

RATING: 8
I can't really say how much I like this game. It's heavily themed, and the mechanics are many and pretty involved, and yet it plays in a very simple and intuitive way. You can play in a lot of different ways and it rarely feels samey even after a lot of plays, expecially if you change the number of players from one play to the other. And it is a blast to play no matter how many people are sitting at the gaming table. A masterpiece, one of the onlw few games that I could play twice (or even more!) in a row, and probably the best (non-war) boardgame I've ever played. Fantastic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game requires some long term strategy and short term tactics to succeed. Everything is rolled up in an immersive and captivating theme sprinkled with just enough luck and randomness in the cards to help this one stand out among the rest. 

The game takes several plays to understand how to play effectively which may turn it off for some. For those patient enough to stick with it, the game gets better with every subsequent session.

RATING: 10
My favourite game. I love the fact that there is randomness in the set-up (both on the board and with player card hands), but almost no randomness in the actual play. This is a skill game with alot of room for improving your game, which I also like. Downside is playing time (if you teach it to a new group, a 4-player game might take 3+ hours) and also the set-up and tear-down takes some time. But the playing experience, with the food tension etc, is fabulous.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First review: only played 3 times so far. 2 solos, and 1 4-player. All vey interesting, first two (solo) plays were with errors. First multi-player game was, I think, all okay. I'm loving it right now, like my first game of settlers.
So many options - seems like endless possibilities at this early stage -I look foward to the next game.
Second review: have now played a handful of solo games and similar number of multiplayer games (2, 4, and 5 players). The game still seems excellent at each level. I'm particularly impressed with the solo player, since I've never played a game with such interest in solo play. Even without the cards its quite a head-scratcher, i.e. playing the basic game.
Our game group is loving this at the moment - the theme, the INTERACTION, and the tough decision making is all really fun, fun, fun. I hope it stays this way, or matures well at least...
Third review: A few more solo and multiplayer games under my belt and I'm thinking about this game all the time!
I just want to keep playing this game, but my lifestyle wont allow it. I have responsibilities. Damn!
Fourth review: Still the main game, rarely do we play anything else, and we're all still learning about how to get better. No-one in our group has yet scored above 50 in a multiplayer game, but we're edging closer.
Summary: This game is FUN. It has replayability in spades, is for 10+ I would say, as it requires some considered thought for decisions on actions. If you collect games, then you should own this. If you enjoy many Euro's you will most likely love this. If you are more into killing things, well you might find you still like this one - you can slaughter your animals for food! Ignore the multiplayer-solitaire fuss, and the one-v-multiple strategies. Find out what you think for yourself. You can play on-line as a try-before-you-buy. 
For me, this is a clear 10 right now, and I think will remain so for a long time to come - we haven't moved off the Easy deck yet!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 6
I respect Agricola's design and understand its popularity. The different actions have a concrete meaning and are part of a natural flow. (To harvest you need to sow and to sow you need seeds etc.) However, the game feels overloaded by special cards that risk "playing the players" and since it's a point salad where everything scores in the end, it's difficult to assess the many actions.

RATING: 8
Purchased June 2009.  Previously played a friend's copy.  Played (various players, locations, copies of the game) on:  2008-09-19;  2009-01-02;  2012-10-06;  2012-11-23
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
主題:1
再也找不到比農家樂更切合遊戲規則及主題的桌遊了，本遊戲由我最欽佩的桌遊設計師烏玫瑰山所設計，遊戲中玩家扮演一戶農家，透過各種農耕方式、交易買賣、增加人手，來讓自己的農場五穀豐收、六畜興旺。每一個環節都讓你體會到當農夫的辛苦(這就有點誇張)。

美術:1
有個人風格的美術我覺得才是最好的美術，一些只依實物的繪製卡片，反倒會讓遊戲失去風格而流至平庸。農家樂就是一款又強烈個人美術風格的桌遊，讓我非常欣賞。另外各式各樣的動物米寶，讓遊戲配件更增CP值；此外風趣又幽默的卡片內容，配合卡牌能力文字描述，常常讓人發出會心一笑。

規則:1
再也找不到此絲絲相扣的遊戲規則，雖然步驟繁多，但規則只要教過一遍，配合遊戲過程，我的桌遊咖都能馬上融入遊戲中，比較麻煩的地方，大概就是職業卡及設備卡的選取，但職業卡及設備卡的加入，正是讓遊戲規則更完美的地方，讓遊戲更加多元及耐玩。

設置:0.5
本項目是一些深度遊戲的痛楚，眾多的卡片及各式各樣米寶，外加圖版及小配件，都讓本遊戲要花一些時間完成前置作業，對於時間寶貴的人來說有點小麻煩，但有愛玩久了，一切都不是問題。

路線:1
路線超多元，這也是一款成功遊戲必備的條件，此外配合眾多的卡片，都能讓本遊戲每一局都能玩出不同的策略。

互動:1
本遊戲互動超強烈，正是標準的你卡我我卡你的遊戲，每一個步驟都考驗上下家的決定，可以說是從玩家的第一步計算到最後一步，常常第一步的後續效果，都在影響著全部玩家，就是像是"蝴蝶效應"一樣，遊戲的最終結果，端看大家的第一步決定，這個遊戲讓玩家間的互動激盪出很多火花，表現真的太棒了!
 
個人:1
這款遊戲不管是多人玩還是一個人玩，都有著很多的樂趣，我個人非常喜歡。

朋友:0.9
玩過的都深深著迷，不過有人覺得太複雜，有點難以適應。

想玩:1
遊戲變化度十足，讓人欲罷不能，只是桌遊咖要有一點實力(對現在決策影響未來成果的敏銳度)，這樣玩起來才會感受到互相牽制卡位的痛苦感。

收藏:1
十大必收遊戲之一

總分:9.4
講評:擴充多，單人至多人遊戲都有不同的樂趣及玩法，本遊戲我單人玩的次數超過多人玩的次數，因為咖不好湊。在挑戰單人遊戲過程中，看著自己每場的分數持續衝高，真的很有成就感，也挑戰自己運用職業卡及次要發展卡的決策力，是訓練邏輯思考，未來決策的好遊戲。

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Sure, the card drafting is the main attraction of the game: you'll never play the same setup twice. But forcing the winning path of "doing a bit of everything" is one of the laziest self-balancing measures I've ever seen in a eurogame. You've found a great niche? It's irrelevant because of highly diminishing returns. Something sucks? Get some anyway or your score will suffer. On top of that, Agricola's neurotic approach to strategical freedom jumps right into the pitfall breeding of new workers as the obvious best move, giving the fortunate player who does it first an edge that's hard to catch up with.

Scoring is a headache, only happens at the very end and often needs a calculator, which means that at any point of the game it takes a ridiculous amount of time to determine who's ahead and what one should do. The micromanagement of fences and fiddliness of animal/vegetal reproduction don't really help with lowering the amount of mental entry barriers to what so many people who aren't me seem to find a lot of fun.

And that's before I start what I think of worker placement as the central mechanic of a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
It's the best game I've ever played, I think. A truly impeccable design, and it's surprisingly easy to teach for how much depth it has. I normally play the "family game" variant, but don't be fooled by the name. It's a tough challenge for anyone to make sure they can feed their family while scoring as many points as possible.

The best part is how many options are available to you each turn. It's one of those games that make you feel like you just never have enough time to do what you want to do. And I love games like that.

Also gets bonus points for scaling really well with different numbers of players and it can even be played solo (!). I would recommend this for any group, even non-gamers, as long as they enjoy a challenge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This game will especially appeal to those who like the idea of building a little farm that produces things, but though it's more detailed than Puerto Rico, it's more complicated and less simplistically "elegant" (lots of arbitrary rules, exceptions, compared to Puerto Rico and Le Havre). Not a good introductory game. Can take a while to figure out if none of the players know the rules, even if players are semi-hardcore gamers. There is a simplified "family" rules variation though which does significantly simplify the game.

RATING: 4.25
"[COLOR=#003300]Agricola is more like a grueling obstacle course [...] The end-game scoring conditions make every game feel much the same. It's a matter of getting a stone house "just in time." One of every animal "just in time." Covering your last empty fields "just in time"[/color]." [JohnRayJr]

"[COLOR=#003300]Feels a bit too much like an optimization puzzle rather than a game and way too long.[/color]" [mkgray]

"[COLOR=#003300]While the game has various subsystems, the all-consuming need for food bends most of them to a common goal. Due to the scoring, one can't push to far out one system to the exclusion of others forcing a balanced growth in many areas. A game that will take a few plays to wrap one's head around as the choices from the cards aren't always obvious without having a feel for the full arc of the game.[/color]"  [RPardoe]

"[COLOR=#003300]One play was not enough to understand the hype [...] Four plays is enough to know that this is a really annoying game.[/color]" [kevinwho]

"[COLOR=#003300]I strongly dislike the tension as you wait for your friend to finish so you can finally plan your turn out with whatever spaces are reamining. This game is one of the most prone to Analysis Paralysis.[/color]" [Boots01]

"[COLOR=#003300]Too long to set up, too long to break down, too many pieces, too many things to do, too much of everything.[/color]" [Pintsizepete]





=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Had it not been for the overdriven hype machine, I probably wouldn't feel the need to rip on a game I've rated an 8. The replayability provided by the card decks is a huge plus and how this game scales with # of players is amazing. But while there are some great episodes of decision making here, I get that same feeling from Stone Age (which is shorter, less prone to AP, and involves rolling dice from a leather cup. :P). I like this game a lot, but it's not the be-all-end-all of boardgaming it was made out to be, and I can't see this ever reaching my top 10.

UPDATE: Too many other games (worker placement or otherwise) are becoming more interesting for me than this one for the time needed. So much so that I don't know if I'll ever even suggest playing this one again. Rating down a point and traded away.

RATING: 9.5
An extremely solid game. Every games will be different because of the various cards you draw, making the game one of the most replayable games ever. You can play the game both strategically and tactically, the rules are easy intrinsically, game play is smooth and scales well from 1 to 5 players. The only point to nitpick (a small one) is how it encourages you to diversify your farms for points scoring, and I prefer Le Havre for its wide range of creative scoring possibility, but nonetheless Agricola is more playable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This farming game is right in my sweet spot and it is a solid version of raising a family on a farm starting in a wooden hut then going out and expanding from there.   

I've learned that the game is actually plenty good in the "family version" with no cards and food on the start player building up...plenty of game there and I will never teach the game to new players any other way as 14 cards overwhelm new players that are trying to learn the basics of the game and the "major improvements" get overlooked when you learn from the family game that they are central to the "engine" of the game, particularly food generation.....card play is too tempting to steer your entire game that way and score lower....only supplement basic game play with a few cards from the hand for the highest scores.  Only experience will give you any clue about which cards those might be...lowered this from a 10 to an 8 due to the launch of Caverna which is so much more fun.

Family members should only be worth 1 or 2 points each otherwise the game is nearly "broken"

RATING: 10
I've only had this game for a few weeks and I simply cannot keep it in the box. This is pure addiction. I have no trouble getting friends and family to play it with me, and even when no one's around, I end up playing it solo. My only issue is that is takes a long time to set up / put away and it's a bit of a pain to restock all the resources every turn on the board.

UPDATE: I hate to join the bandwagon, but this game is the nectar of the gods. My friends and I can't get enough of it. It has moved to my only number 10, replacing A Game of Thrones as my current fav.

UPDATE: Hmm... back down to a 9. For some reason, it stopped feeling as replayable. Maybe I just need to let it simmer for a while, but the cards have stopped adding enough variety to keep it feeling truly fresh. Don't get me wrong, it's still awesome though. Oh, and another thing, almost everyone I try to teach this game cannot grasp the baking bread concept, and it's getting really frustrating to have to keep repeating myself.

UPDATE: I can't decide if I like Le Havre or Agricola better. Oh what the heck, they're both 10s. Uwe Rosenberg, you are a god.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this worker placement game, with a theme based on farming, each player also has a unique set of cards. The scoring rewards being balanced, as you lose points for not having a particular animal or plant. 

What makes this game unique are the cards that you are dealt, and trying to form a strategy with what you have. There are a large number of cards, making for countless combinations. 

This is a very good game, and plays differently each time. 

It does get a bit long with 5 players, and probably a disadvantage for the person going last, so I would avoid it with 5 players. It's best with 3 or 4 players. 

I had never been motivated to play a solitaire board game of any kind before, but the solitaire version of this game is quite good.

RATING: 9
I prefer Feast for Odin most days but the more limiting nature of Agricola is still quite compelling. A common criticism of this game is that you are forced to do everything but that is key to the keeping the game competitive and interesting. Unlike most games where each player specializes and we simply see who can do their thing best, Agricola forces players to be competing for the same action spaces throughout.

RATING: 6.5
I relatively enjoy the game. I like the theme of farming and growing your family and how that comes through in the gameplay. It makes sense, most of the actions. I am not crazy about the cards - its half because I'm kind of bad with them and half because when I played with my friends, it took a bit longer than I liked. I think 14 is just too much for me to mentally wrap my mind around, and I've only gotten off a good combo about one or twice in 10 ish full game plays. I've played the Family Variant a lot too with friends and enjoyed it though (my friends aren't really hardcore gamers and it was still a bit difficult to track, so I avoided using the full game). The FV is cookie cutter, but I still liked building up my farm, even if it didn't have as much variety as the cards.

Some minor improvements I would've liked are: vegimeeples (it only had animeeples), carved pieces to differentiate the stone and clay and wood and such, an effective storage for the decks, altenative scorings (everyone's farms always look samey and some difference would've been nice - perhaps a variant with scoring the same as Caverna's?), and first time preset hands like Season's has (there's currently a variant on the Agricola forums with this).

Full review where I wrote quite at length about this:
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1332964/having-played-fair-bit-i-wanted-clarify-my-thought

Plays: 25+

Oh and I dislike how much reading there is in the game. I am reminded of tcgs with cards with long effects and text, and I feel it is usually inelegant and not fun to be reading that many. At least in something like Dominion, its just ten you go over and arent usually a paragraph of abilities

RATING: 3
Update: After 3 plays, I feel I am done with the game. I lowered the rating from 4 to 3.
----------------------------------------
Update: I like the family version of the game better. Why bother putting 300+ cards?? rating of 5 is for family version and 4 for non-family version.
----------------------------------------
Unlike other Rosenberg's games, there is nothing interesting about cardplay in this game. The only way that I see this is from Rosenberg is some of the tiles depict his own games. Look at his other beautiful games like Bohnanza, Mamma Mia, Klunker and Babel (and space beans?). They all had some very inovative rules on cards. This game just has mega-sized deck with special powers. Very disappointing to see that Rosenberg got his design depends on special power texts.Ugly-cola!!

Also the rule is very unclean and way too many data. I need my excel sheet to keep track on what is what. The game has very little player interaction too. It is not a bad game but certainly doesn't deserve the #1 place in BGG. (I think #200 is about right for this)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Well, well, well, what to say...This is the kind of game I would like to dislike: Over-hyped, loads of bits, pieces and cards and totally f*cked-up theme -I was half-dreading a game about Mikael Agricloa, pushing the player into the role of a boring theologian with a mission to put together a written language with as many phonetically incongruent bits as possible- turns out its about raising wild boars and making babies in the German schwartzwalds. But then you press "play" and it's pretty damn awesome a game. 

How good exactly is too early to determine, but it is probably an improvement over both Caylus and Puerto Rico, the two games of which it borrows its main genes (Caylus; varied strategies, worker placement; Puerto Rico; role selection, depth and reasonable playing time). But the question becomes is it better a game? Agricola feels a bit like the 5th generation Ford Mustang; faster, stronger, slicker, more clever than its predecessor - but is it REALLY better? Only time will tell, my rating could fall to an 8 or rise to a 10. But for now I'll just enjoy the awesome ride given by a game of Agricola. Definitely this is the best game experience of 2008 for me insofar. Update: Yes, it's a great game, the King of Worker Placement Games - and better than aforementioned Caylus and Puerto Rico. 

Update: The K and I decks makes the game both better and more fiddly, so I'll push the rating up to 9,5 - just short of a 10. But the game is extremely engrossing, and I'm always thinking what I should have done differently afterwards, which for me is a sign of a great game.

RATING: 9
Very hard to leave a comment here given all the hype, but I guess I can say it's currently a 9 for me - always wanting to play it. A worker-placement, resource management game with really tough choices. The main complexity lies in the occupation/improvement cards and how you use them, which can put off some casual gamers, but it's nowhere near impossible to manage. The solitaire game works well too, which is a big plus. In fact, so far I've played more solitaire games than multi-player....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A highly addictive mix of limited action placement and an almost collectible card game method of customisation, if occasionally tilted in favour of the player with the best cards, assuming all players are otherwise equal. It seems easy to get into despite the reliance on making sure you approach it with right eye for what actions are needed and when, and the variety in the cards that are drawn each game mean that I doubt I will get tired of either the multi-player or the solo games any time soon.

The theme is also curiously appealing, and adds to the gentle and accessable feel of a game that would otherwise appear quite cutthroat, which has put me off some similar titles. Maybe it's because I've been recruited to help down at my local allotments from time to time, but it makes a nice change from angry space colonists and anti-social mages!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I just can't understand why so many people love this game. Now, I understand why certain people think this is the next great thing, but there are so many others that absolutely love it that normally hate games like this that it boggles my mind. Let's see... it's a long game, taking some 2 to 3 hours depending on the speed and number of players. It's a complicated game with an enormous decision tree every turn that is further expanded by the cards. It's very fiddly. It's slow moving (i.e. the engine you are building takes a long time to get going unless you get lucky...). It's heavily influenced by the luck of the cards - some draws work very well together and others are near-useless. And finally, the theme should be a problem (farm work? Yuch) but for whatever reason, it draws people in. Baffling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I have enjoyed this thus far.  It scales very well from 1 to 5 players, and is the only game I've played solo that I've actually enjoyed, although I'm not sure I've enjoyed it enough to justify the setup time.

I like the competition for resources.  I like the cards and how they impact the game (I've only used the E deck).  I like watching my farm grow and succeed (or wallow in mediocrity).

What I don't like:  the game seems to be over sooner than it should be.  Just when you're clicking, it's all over.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Length: 4/5[/b]: AP players will probably push this game to a slightly longer length than some would like, but the game does a pretty successful job of maintaining game length because there are 14 and only 14 rounds in the game. Again, this can be lengthy with AP players, especially in higher player counts, but because there are base actions, and then additional actions are added once every round, the analysis paralysis is limited.

[b]Strategy: 4/5[/b]: The different improvements and occupations allow players to strategize around what they have from the very beginning of the game. You have to determine when a good time to bring additional family members will be, you have to determine how big to make pastures because bigger pastures will allow larger amounts of the same animal. You have to determine what resources to grab, because if you grab wood you'll be able to build additional rooms and fences, but you'll potentially be giving up the opportunity to get clay to upgrade buildings, or food for the harvest season, or sheep to place in your pastures. 

The first player marker is not passed back and forth between rounds, it's actually an action, which is really important because there will probably be constant fighting over it.

The issue with the strategy, is that this scoring for everything does have a cap, so you can't go crazy and collect a bunch of sheep or a bunch of veggies and ignore all else. Basically, everyone will be playing a similar game. Maybe one person will upgrade buildings early, but the other players will probably be doing that eventually. Admittedly, this actually showcases something nice, in that whoever wins did the job the best at the game, as opposed to other games where one path just gives more victory points for arbitrary reasons.

[b]Theme: 4/5[/b]: The theme isn't original. Farming. Riveting. 

Though I think this game does a good job of representing a family of medieval farmers. Often times, it's difficult to make ends meet. There's a lot you want to do and you can rarely do everything you want in a given turn. You are constantly doing actions that contribute to your family being fed as opposed to things that would otherwise give you victory points. I think it's interesting that the game motivates you to work in this way.

Also, on your personal board, you are legitimately building the fences and rooms that make up your estate. You are getting animals that have babies, plowing and sowing fields. It really does look and feel like a farm that you've built from the ground up.

[b]Longevity: 5/5[/b]: I don't think it can be argued that this game has a lot of replay value. You will constantly see fans of this game mention playing this game hundreds of times. This is because the game maintains the same actions, but the come out at different periods. This allows you to conjure up strategies that will work in future plays, but since the actions pop up at different times you can't necessarily be certain of the exact order you'll be able to do them in.

The replay value is also helped by the improvement and occupation cards, of which each player will get a total of 14, but there are so many of these cards in the base game, and then constant expansion decks being created (some even by fans), that you'll constantly be seeing new combinations and ways to play.

[b]Scoring: 2/5[/b] As mentioned above this is the only thing I really don't like. Caps on specific animals make it so that focusing on one thing isn't smart, and that the end game is pretty much always people taking one of each of things they didn't focus on in the game, or upgrading their buildings, or filling the rest of their unused fields. It's often times pretty samey, and turn order really matters in these situations almost more than anything else, because if 3 players in a four player game need a vegetable to avoid the negative point, it's likely one of them won't get it because everybody will be scrounging for it at the same time. Is that really a problem?... Eh... hard to say.

Someone posted a good point that if, instead of being a -1 point for not doing anything in a specific category, not having anything netted you 0 points, and then getting the lowest requirement netted you 2 points instead of 1, people would be a bit happier with that. Because negative points have negative connotations, but 0 points are basically just neutral, which makes sense when you're not doing anything in those categories. But, that cap is still annoying. You can achieve the cap somewhat easily if you kinda focus on it, and you are given very little incentive to go above and beyond.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After all the hype, I played... and I liked it, but I was not enthusiastic... then I played again, then I played again, then... I am hooked... What a beautiful game! You can adopt a strategy and see how your strategy develop... and each time new ideas, for new strategies... Also, thinking of the strategy, often it is easier to think more on the things you can do as a farmer (e.g. maybe I should cultivate more before acquiring sheep) and not in terms of points... Very very very recommended (in spite of the hype). 

UPDATE March 2013
I still consider it a wonderful game, but I moved down the rating to 9 because I like more "Ora et labora" that gives a similar experience, but which I like more.

UPDATE October 2015
Rating lowered to 8. I prefer Fields of Arle, and also Ora et Labora and Caverna. This should be reflected in my ratings.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One play, and I have some concerns.  I worry that a lot of the high praise may be purely from the experience of wrestling with a very unwieldy system.  What will be left once that system has been tamed?  Further, there is some concern that the cards you are dealt can seal your fate before the game even begins - though that will bother some more than others (I'm the latter).  This one clearly needs more plays before a firm rating can be established.  You simply can't get a handle on Agricola after just one game.

--update--
Two further plays with a fresh perspective and Agricola has redeemed itself in my eyes.  In many ways I actually like the Sim-Farm aspect of the game more than resolving the actual competitive outcome.  Agricola gets bonus points for reeling my wife in as well.

---update---
Agricola rocks my socks off.  It is the only game that has a solo-mode, official or variant, that I actually find engaging.  So good!

RATING: 7
For the longest time I ignored this game until I watched a video review with a lengthy explanation of how everything worked.  I was hooked.

Very, very good and fun game.  Great for players who like to set up their game plan turns ahead. So many choices, so few turns to bring them to fruition.

This is a harsh game for first-timers indeed.

UPDATE (2/18/14)
Unfortunately, this game takes too long to be regularly included in my sporadic gaming sessions.  Also, the unfriendliness to new players means that the beginning draft is not played to its best.

Considering playtime, harshness, aesthetics and a draft that includes a minuscule amount of available cards, I think I'm better off enjoying other games in my collection.

Still, I recognize its gaming value, and if you have time to devote to this beast, then you should at the very least play it to find out what the hell all the hype is (was?) about.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is probably my favourite game.  It's a challenge to decide how to best use your workers, there's a good level of competition between players for the resources, and the theme works well and is very cute.

It doesn't quite deserve a rating of ten as there are a few things that might be better.  One is that the initial allocation of occupation and improvement cards can perhaps make too much of a difference to the game -- sometimes you'll get a good combination that suggest an obvious strategy, other times you'll get  mixed bag that's harder to work with.  Also I'd think that an improvement might be to have the whole turn order vary, not just the starting player; this is because you can be at a disadvantage if the player to your immediate right is playing a similar strategy to yourself.  Finally it's a fairly expensive game and I think that it should come with animeeples and vegimeeples as standard instead of putting them in an expensive expansion.  They make the game much more fun.

But these are minor quibbles.  It's a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Agricola is worker placement game of limited choices.  Each player has two family members with which to choose a task.  That task is then blocked from other players.  Each player must make the best choices possible to help build their farm and feed their family, producing grain, vegetables, and livestock.  There are a large number of options to choose from on each turn, but with only two choices to make, it can be difficult to find the right path to a good score.  Many times I've felt that I was futilely selecting a bad option among many terrible options.  However, I always find myself thinking about the game long after we are finished.  This, to me, tells me it was a *great* game.  I highly recommend Agricola!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I love, love, love the challenge and tightness of this game. Daunting at first glance, but really not so difficult to teach.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Update: Played again but this time with people who know how to play. It is a tough game, but still fun.

RATING: 3

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Agricola is a worker placement game where you are a farmer with a family which you use to take actions.  3 family members, you get 3 actions, however you must feed the family every harvest as well.

The scoring system is very interesting because there are various groups where you will score in and depending on how many, sheep lets say, you have, you get points for that.  0 sheep = -1 point, 4 sheep = 2 points for example.

Once starting this game the world ceases to matter while you strive to get everything you want to get done.  This game really sucks you in, after you look at the time and say, wow, that was two hours?  Bought the game within a week of playing it for the first time and can't wait to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

After one play without the card deck I love it. Another game of needing more actions and you get to build with so many options.

However, the game is unforgiving and tense, and it doesn't get enough play because some of my gaming group are turned off due to that factor.

RATING: 10
I've only played a couple of times, so these are newbie impressions. For a game that only lasts 14 rounds, it packs a punch. I'm sure it gets easier over time but there was more brainhurt here than in Ora & Labora. It mires even fast players in AP. Yet it's so much fun -- so many ways to go, different decisions to make -- it feels like there is so much you can do (even though you don't end up doing even half of it), and then very abruptly, the game's over.
----
My newbie impressions have held up :-)
The almost infinite number of permutations of starting cards, which really guide one's strategy, means it'll be a while before replayability is a problem. There is a balance problem in that an unfortunate set of starting cards can seal your fate, but it's still fun to explore the possibilities even if a win is out of reach. AP is exacerbated in this game, so try to play with fast players.

[color=#117bc0][b]Probably rather play:[/b][/color] not many. Possibly Tichu, possibly Scrabble.
----
recent self-discovery: I only want to play Agricola with people who love it with a comparable level of child-like abandon

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Agricola is pretty easy to learn. The strategy, however, was at first pretty overwhelming. The occupation and minor improvement cards give you so many potential decisions. Once I got the hang of it, though, the strategy became super fun. There are some interesting combinations and synergies with the occupation/minor improvement cards and I like having so many options per turn. The rules are really elegant and the game just works super well; I can't really find any flaws. Some people hate the fact that gathering the food to feed your family each harvest gets in the way of developing your farm, but I love how tightly you have to play in regards to this. If you play too greedily and develop your farm to the exclusion of coming up with a food production engine, you'll get DESTROYED when harvest comes and you'll have to take beggar tokens. The game really encourages diversification by design. Overall, I highly recommend to anyone looking for a board game with a ton of depth and replay value.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
pros: theme, scoring system, some good tension, variety,

cons: anal. paral., the sheer number of different cards make you keep looking at your cards - would require so many plays to learn the cards it is simply not worth the effort, - it also makes it difficult to concentrate on what others are doing, random card combos' unbalancing effect; pick of starting player action by other players can have a strong impact on the outcome.

overall, the advanced game is a little too long for what it is and for the luck factor the card draw brings (a 5p game took almost 4 hours, with 4 it is more managable, can click under 3). I am surprised by the high ratings, I like balanced games and prefer the family version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a really smooth economic engine and reminds me of Puerto Rico (PR).  However, having played PR a few times, I believe that A[gricola] is and will be the better game for me.  The reason?  Theme.  In PR, there is a certain abstract nature to the play.  In A, you're building a farm, from start to finish.  In PR, one has to hope for 4 things to happen in the correct order just to get money to buy a building that you think will help you in 3 more turns.  In A, I find myself busy with survival at the moment - if I need clay, I move that way.  Of course, I expect to be confounded (and do some of my own :-) in a multiplayer game.

I used the SoloPlay rules and highly recommend them for solitaire play.

Why this is not a 10:
-> I can see myself not wanting to play most of the time, but not all of the time.

RATING: 6.5

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Somewhat complicated. The different improvements make the game difficult until you've learned how they work together. You need to know what paths you have before you, but it looks like a good starting position can be play a fairly major role.

After playing a few times, I realize that depending on the number of players, different approaches are needed. With five, wood is much harder to come by, plus with more players, baking bread is stronger, but not as available. With fewer, you have the chance of building up your infrastructure much more quickly.

Although it feels that the game is dependent on the initial card draw, I don't think it is that much of a hindrance. It really comes down to taking advantage of your cards, and paying attention to how your opponents are playing. Like Puerto Rico, you don't necessarily always want to take the 'optimum' option, since you might prefer to throw a monkey wrench into the other players plans.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7

Only 2 negative points:
-> Sometimes, an innocent worker placement of one of your rivals can ruin your entire throughly planned strategy.
-> The scoring mechanism, even if fair, is far from elegant.

Otherwise, it's a great worker placement game, probably superseded by Caverna.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've played several family and "advanced" games. Even a basic family game version feels very good and as such is a great game. The cards add more AP to the game and especially the start of the game goes slowly as everyone is checking their cards. But I like to play with them as then you must react to the cards and adapt your play. It's also much more fun with cards!

Theme fits mechanics very well and I like how there are many small subgoals (get food to your family, building enclosure to animals, breeding, etc.) that keep you busy while playing. Actually the scoring feels almost unnecessary in the end as playing itself is so fun. There seems to be a enough freedom in strategies and chances for being creative with your moves even thought scoring forces you to keep everything rather balanced. Simply an awesome game.

Update (13.7.2008): After another game (this time Z-man english edition) I decided to increase my rating from 8 to 9. And this is only after playing second "family game".

Update (17.8.2008): After few games with cards (basic and complex decks) Agricola really feels a superb game. The cards add variety and you must adapt your play a bit depending on what combos you'll be able to do. Cards don't change too much the gameplay but give just the right amount of more to think about. The game is simply more fun with the cards. They actually do add element of luck into the game but this shouldn't affect games too often and in any case it isn't a negative thing to me.

Update (3.9.2008): Ten games and game just seems to get better and better each time. I'll rise my rating for Agricola to a full 10 as it is very fun to play but a brain burner at the same time and simply very, very good game. When played with cards it gives me the same feeling as playing a CCG games. There is no deck building but there is thinking the playing order of cards and combos the cards can give. I didn't realize I was missing it and now playing Agricola (along with Jambo) fills this small niche for me as I don't usually play CCG's at all. This is probably the reason why I'm rating the game so high.

Update (23.9.2009): There is definitely luck involved in how occupation / minor improvement cards are distributed. Tried yesterday with drafting and although that probably is one of the best alternatives it is quite taxing to read 3-5 times 14 cards and more so to try to remember what good combos you might be giving to others... To me good things in drafting aren't big enough to really use it.

RATING: 9
Yet another efficiency exercise, and although its not the best or most elegant game in it's field, this one does it with some charm.  This game's major boon, apart from the pretty components, is the cards. The wealth of options that come from the plethora of cards gives players a sense of exploring the game and I expect will keep the game fresh over a fair number of plays. The cards also provide chrome that is usually only present in bigger, dare I say it "Ameritrash" titles and there is definitely a sense that you're building up a farm. It's not as free flowing as I would like from a game and it certainly lacks interaction - though shouts of multiplayer solitaire are perhaps a step too far. Extra interaction would be nice, certainly nothing as crass as burning each others crops and livestock, but perhaps a trading mechanism. This game is better with animeeples.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Complex worker placement game where the most valuable farm needs to be built over 14 rounds, including houses as firm as possible, cattle, cereal, veg, and other assets. Each of these items means one more layer in the game (there are different aspects to sowing, farming, building huts or fences and feeding), which involves a little bit of spatial reasoning (how to build the farm), the separate management of all the aforementioned resources plus cooking utilities, timing not just for choosing actions but to sow the right amount at the right time, and of course clever hand management.

As ambitious as it is, Agricola offers some discussion points: 
(a) The actions in a turn are not carried out for example in straight-and-then-reverse order like in Die Siedler, and picking the starting action means losing costly choices... so the player just behind gets a relative benefit when many players are on the table. Still, even though there are more refined ways to "bid for first player" (Caylus comes to mind), spending an action to gain the first move in the following round grants an extra improvement as well so it can be a useful tactical weapon.
(b) The card sets dealt to the players at the start are random so that some "synergetic combination" may occasionally bias a player, and it can't be balanced by more interaction than blocking other player's choice of actions. Nevertheless this is perfectly possible (blocking a resource, for instance), and managing the player's hand incorporates a strategic element absent from most games driven by worker placement.
(c) The games are quite tightly scripted, all phases containing similar events. This might look at first to stiffen the play, but as it happens with the previous issue, it turns out to favour the development of strategies rather than tactical manoeuvring.

Agricola might be so varied thanks to the huge amount of material rather than due a truly refined system, but the bottom line is that it shines with its love to detail and that in the end the game is insanely replayable anyway. A deserved classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
Un capolavoro. La versione avanzata è molto dipendente dalla lingua per via delle carte; la comprensione dei benefit delle carte è fondamentale. La parte iniziale del gioco: distribuzione carte (fortuna) e pausa di lettura per valutare eventuali combo e strategie (tempi morti) sono gli unici difetti del gioco. Agricola offre tante strategie; l'obiettivo è quello di far fruttare il proprio appezzamento di terreno, si può scegliere di ingrandire la propria casa e famiglia, allevare del bestiame o coltivare la terra. A fine partita conteranno solo i punti vittoria quindi potrebbe aver senso specilizzarsi, ma attenzione, rimanere a zero in qualche settore porterà dei punti negativi. Come se non bastasse durante le varie fasi di gioco bisognerà essere in grado di sfamare i membri della propria famiglia per non avere penalizzazioni carestia. Insomma un gioco complesso, dove ognuno sceglierà la propria strada ma l'interazione potrebbe costringere a cambi di programma. Spesso a fine partita si ha la sensazione di non esser riusciti a far tutto ciò che ci si era prefissati.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yup...just about worthy of all the hype. A fascinating strategy set and flawless integration between theme and mechanics. Insane variety of cards designed to appeal to the CCGers. Possibly one of the best games for long-term strategy: if you find yourself with an action to spare, you know you haven't played it right.

There's a lot to be said for 'going back to basics' and playing the Family Game a few times every now and then. The purists might sneer, but - by God - it doesn't half focus your attention. I defy anyone with fewer than one hundred plays to drop the cards from time to time and see what an intense, tight game it makes.

Further Thoughts - some of the occupations are starting to become slightly old-hat and seeing a pet card appear in front of an opponent is very demoralising. Plus it's frustrating when you get dealt a hand full of mediocre improvements which you can't justify using. And as for the game-end scoring? Sheesh! Talk about overblown.

Further, Further Thoughts - at the risk of this game getting Boydelled to death, it really does make for a good dynamic evening in without too much brainburn. Contemplating a personal Top 10 re-entry...

Further, Further, Extra Thoughts: 300 games down the line and a continuing enthusiasm to play more doesn't justify leaving this at a 9.5 rating. Up we go!

[i]Logging Plays - I am playing on boiteajeux quite a lot at the minute, but NOT logging online games. If I did, add about two thousand games to my tally![/i]

RATING: 10
Wow. I never thought I'd see a better Euro-game than Caylus, and then along comes Agricola! It's got Caylus worker-placement fun, only now you have to house AND feed the the workers you have. No more slave wages of 1 denier. Ingenious. And the cards make it a new game everytime you play. "What card is that?!"

Encountering new and powerful combinations of cards and getting into play means this game continues to be fresh every time.

RATING: N/A

It's a well made game, overall. I'm just unimpressed with it personally.

RATING: 7
Very good game. Cards give a lot of variaty, which is missing in Puerto Rico and which is not so strong in Caylus. However, they also introduce luck and the horrible "Agricola effect": when players are more than 3, you completely lose track of which cards they have played and of what they are currently doing, therefore playing basically on your own.
Moreover, experienced players overkill opponents who do not know the exact value of every card in the initial draft.
I appreciate the possibility to play solo games.

RATING: 8
Agricola manages to be far too short, but also way too long at the same time. I always end the game feeling as though I have left things unfinished. It tends to be a game of regrets, frustrations, and envy. 

That being said, Agricola is also a good bit of fun. It is visually great, especially with hand-made clay replacements for all the game pieces. It is rewarding to grow a little farm throughout the game, fun to have pastures full of animals and such. The amazing variety of cards even in the base game keeps it feeling different every playthrough. It is a game that I will never tire of playing. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
