RATING: 8.3
Amazing game, great mechanics, incredibly well designed and a "must" have for all euro games fans. Only reason I'm not giving it a 10 is because as in the expert mode the occupation cards are drawn randomly, a player can get shitty cards while another gets really good ones. This cards are very balanced, overall, but some combinations of them are too overpowered, like for example getting those that give you food for every time you get wood and then extra points for building things with that wood, so you keep stacking all the wood in the game, and as anyone else has wood, you get most of the animals too and bla bla, and that is almost certain victory for experienced players. It's my only criticism and is really rare, but it can happen. Still recommend it 100% though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2016: My favorite game of all time. Perfect as it is. Punishing and satisfying. I've never had so many arguments with my wife over anything else. So good. 

EDIT: 2018. After having owned about 200 games and played even more, it is still the best game I've ever played, and we still play it! Pure genius. It is mind boggling that, for instance, Scythe is rated higher - while being an OK game, it is nowhere near as good or thought out as Agricola. Terraforming Mars does not deserve to be in the top 10, either, it's super boring.  Heck, Viticulture is almost there and it's still a luck fest after the expansion. I don't know why someone would settle for less, in my opinion, no game has dethroned Agricola yet.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Really really not my game. 

It took me a while to understand why. It's the lack of direct interaction for sure, at least partly - but that's not the main issue in my judgement: The THEME and its IMPLEMENTATION are the problem! It's as simple as that. 1.) Farming is lame and 2.) its implementation is thematically unsound.  

There certainly are games in which worker placement is a logical choice theme wise (like Alien Frontiers or maybe Manhattan Project or Dungeon Lords), but worker placement as the driving mechanic is totally unsuitable for that particular theme. It just doesn't make any sense! The idea behind worker placement is to exclude others from a specific scarce resource, right? Resources at those times, however, were practically NEVER limited to just one farmer in a villages, on the contrary. Everyone had access to wood, for example, because forests belonged to the community. Bread was made in a public baking house and so on... I mean, even TODAY, farmers still share equipment like harvesters. Also, family farming was a mandatory all round job. The farmer didn't just chose one action, he had to do all jobs over and over again... And finally: Why can't we trade!? The theme makes it the most obvious thematic option!

These objections may seem rediculous, yet they make me not enjoy the game. The whole game design is an underestimation of the value of a well presented theme. 

Special note: I sincerely appreciate this fully developped product. There are hundreds of cards, everything is so well tested, so clever and neat - now that's value for money! Take a closer look at this and shame on you, FFG et al.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Śmiało można powiedzieć, że to już klasyka nowoczesnych gier planszowych. 
Specyficzna, mocno optymalizacyjna gra planszowa w klimacie, który niejednego odstraszył hehe.
Esencja euro.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]Agricola[/b] was received in a trade (7/17/14).

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]Agricola has become one of my all time favorite games (it is in my top 10). It is a game that I have come to appreciate much more as I have continued to play it, in fact I enjoyed my initial plays of Le Havre more than Agricola. However; the more I played Agricola the more I came to appreciate how tense the game is, I love the beginning of each game when you look at your cards and have to try and make a long term plan. At this point Agricola and Glass Road are my favorite Uwe games (I just layed my first game of Arle and I'm not sure what to think yet).

At this point I know that my kids likes/dislikes are not a good indication for other kids, but they love Agricola (my son is 12, my daughter is 10) so I always have willing opponents to play with so Agricola will continue to hit the table in my house. We also just got Agricola: Farmers of the Moor, I can't wait to play with the expansion and see how it changes the game play. I'm glad that it seems like growing your family quickly isn't necessarily going to be quite as necessary with the expansion.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8.5):[/COLOR]

[i]- I really enjoy balancing the feeding of your people with managing the rest of your farm.
- Theme: I really enjoy building a farm and seeing how everything looks at the end of the game. 
- Beautiful artwork and amazing bits (if you upgrade them, which I did directly through Lookout Games).
- Card play: They can really push you to try a different strategy in the game, since they give you a small advantage in one part of the game.
- High replay value: There are a lot of cards and different decks of cards to explore in this game.

I finally got to play this when Joel brought it to the meet up, and I definitely like it better than Caverna. 
The main reason is that I really like the card play over the buildings, much more variability. Second I really did not like the adventuring system in Caverna.[/i]

1 play -> Revised edition
5 plays -> E deck
5 plays -> G deck
3 plays -> I deck
3 plays -> K deck
2 plays -> France deck
2 plays -> FotM E deck
2 plays -> FotM E + I decks
3 plays -> FotM F + K decks
2 plays -> FotM F + I decks
1 play -> FotM F deck
1 play -> FotM F + France decks
1 play -> FotM E + France decks

RATING: 4.5
Only played 2-player and solo:

The gameplay is good and challenging. I can definitely see why the game is popular. It just doesn't make me want to play it again. The biggest factor is the amount of upkeep on the main player board is needed every round. Plus the setup and tear-down time compared to how long the game actually is at one and two players. You will spend just as much time moving components to and from the box as you will playing the actual game.

While there are certainly ways around these problems. The game just didn't do it for me.

If I got it to the table with more players these things probably wouldn't be such an issue as the game would be longer.

Compared to Dungeon Petz, which is more fiddly and has more bookkeeping. But is also longer, and has more humor and theme. Agricola just didn't make me want to play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.15
This is one very interesting game! The huge variety of card choices possible in this game, make it strategically re playable. It is intense and you cannot afford to make a mistake. In the end game point scoring I always regret any tiny mistake I made in wasting a turn earlier in the game! The need to keep variety in your farm and your choices of occupation and improvement cards really make every game unique!

So far, in 2 and 5 player games we are seeing a struggle for the wood resource, but in 4-player games there seems to be more of a wood freedom. This isn't a flaw in the game...just creates an interesting intensity of game play, with different numbers of players!

The solitaire game is really enjoyable! You play a series of 8 games, keeping one occupation from each of your games! You start each game with no food and you must feed your family 3 food per turn! Also there is a goal score which you are trying to beat...and if you beat it you may start each subsequent game with some food based on your score! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It has enough interaction through action choices to make it not too solitarish, but there are enough choices that you are seldom placed in an untenable position by the other players. The sheer amount of options seems to offer great replayability.

RATING: 6.5
A two-player learning game, and a 3-player all learning game five years later. 

I can see some of the appeal and how different cards will affect your strategy, but it right now seems TOO restricting.  It's not interesting tension between good actions, but rather boring artificial restrictions that prevent you from building much of anything.  It really ramps up the last few turns, so maybe it's just designed to have a slow curve leading to a manic finish.  But that little bit of excitement doesn't really satisfy right now.  I'm willing to try it a couple more times and see if it improves through familiarity.  

I usually like "boring" themes, so I have no problem with that aspect.

RATING: 6

And this was after I had been so pumped at the idea of buying it (it IS #1 after all) that I began pimping it out before I ever played it; got the animeeples, downloaded and printed (and stuck on) the resource stickers; the whole nine yards.  And then it just sucked as a game.

Lame theme and boring goals.  I find the whole "harvests come every few turns in the beginning but then without reason come every couple and then every one turn at the end" mechanic contrived and inelegant.  Definitely does NOT deserve to be in the #1 spot by any stretch of the imagination.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The theme carries through very well, making the rules much easier to understand than they would normally be for a game this complex. Most of the complexity is depth thanks to the conversions and all the choices from the cards. The family game wouldn't be that much easier to understand, but would be easier to figure out a strategy.

As a vegetarian, I am disappointed that it's far easier to figure out a meat-eating strategy. In my second game I came in 2nd with a fish-only strategy. Meat is SO much easier, because you can't bake on demand, AND there is only ONE "bake bread" action anywhere.

The BGG weight of 3.6 seems a bit high to me...I'll go 3.2. Still heavy, and I wouldn't want to throw even the family game at casual gamers, but better than I expected.

Somehow I managed to avoid all penalties on my first game ever, winning with 34. Wow. Second game, each player only had a penalty in one category. I came in 2nd with 30.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After playing it again with a new group (full table of 5) I was amazed at just how visually confusing this game is! The big cards representing the different actions players can do are so bright and colorful and there are so many of the... WOW! It's still an awesome game but there's so much visual noise there! It clearly lacks the simplicity and elegance I so much enjoy in Caylus.

Still love the game though! Great mechanics (though not original) and the possibility to adapt it to any configuration of players! Family, advanced, with cards, no cards, different decks for different playing styles, etc! Very complete!

- The rules are well written, a bit of a small font, but well structured. Players used to play heavy euro games will have no problem in understanding these, but the game will have to be played two or three times before players can grasp its full potential.

[b]Game for pros![/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First game bought on hype. Big mistake. The playdoh rush on this should have told me something. I can't think of another game that turned me off from playing it even once, but this game's dense, confusing, and bland rulebook, ridiculous '...meat eating habits we continue to this day' intro (shame on you Uwe Rosenberg for not adding 'bad' in front of habits and insinuating this is a game focused on meat farming.), and reviews of 'solitaire' sure don't make we want to slog through learning it or teaching it to others. The endless rules questions on BGG is another warning sign. Do you really want to bother with figuring out 360 cards and their combos? Sorry, but I had enough of that crap with MTG. Lesson learned: ignore hype and 'appreciating' a game just because it knocked another sucky game like Puerto Rico out of the number one spot. I've began to realize the majority of the entire top ten on this site is a joke and doesn't belong there. 

This is one case of too many cards. Really ads AP downtime to the game, as everyone struggles to find out what their cards mean and how they interact with each other. By the final third of the game, there are at least 25 actions you can choose from! Seriously, this is deranged. I understand that this game will take ten plays to become clearer, but I doubt most people will have the patience to reach that number. 7 hours for our first 3 player game, with ONE person in AP mode. This puts Agricola in the same category as 'Advanced civ' as far as game length, and 5 plus hours is not going to get this on the table very often, especially not when this is a clear homage to 'Caylus', a much more elegant game that does not rely on luck of card draws.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first introduction to worker placement threw me into the deep end, to say the least. It was quite an early addition to my collection and while it didn't see the table for several years it is now back in the rotation and is played on a regular basis.
I love how this game allows you to tweak your engine using your hand of cards but restricts you from the overwhelming choice presented in some of Uwe's more recent designs (Caverna and Fields of Arle specifically). The much maligned "necessity to feed" is key to my enjoyment of the game and gives you direction and tension.
I want to update it to the new, revamped and rebalanced edition but am finding it hard to justify the expense.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Owned with animeeples and vegemeeples.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ideal worker placement game. You always feel like you were one or two steps away from playing well, even if you win. The timing and pace of the game really makes it work, because you always feel like you have three more things you need to do but you only have the time for one, and then the game ends.

As opposed to Le Havre, where options open up as the game progresses, I prefer the "shutting down" of options in Agricola. As the turns progress and players get mroe and more family members, I like the fact that options in the end of each round are limited.

The expansion, "Farmers of the Moor", is pretty much a requirement, however. I haven't played the base game in a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Box 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It's sort of amazing how tense, fun, frustrating, and wonderful this game is. When things come together, assuming they do, it feels so marvelous. So many last rounds find multiple players suddenly raking up points by solidifying their farms, which is a remarkable part of this game. With many viable strategies and the influx of multiple card combinations, you can feel like you're having somewhat of a new experience with each successive game yet still feel like it's enough of the familiar experience to make you feel truly at home with the family farmers serving as your proxy in this strange, occupation-filled world. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great game and one that my wife and I really enjoy so far. Every mechanic and the overall frantic feeling of not being able to quite do everything, really matches up well with the overall theme of being a farmer in the Middle Ages. It can be very challenging and can sometimes beat you down but when you find the right combinations of occupations and minor improvements, it is a thing of beauty.

RATING: 6
I tried and tried to love Agricola 'cause everyone else seems to, but I just can't make it happen.  I should play it more often, but it is a very unforgiving game in which one or two poor moves early can doom a player to defeat.  It is of course possible to learn to avoid these, but this is only possible through repeated plays.  Learning the strengths and weaknesses of the myriad cards is essential as well, and this also takes practice.  I admire Agricola and it excites me in theory, but in practice, it takes too much effort to get to the point of enjoyment for me.

3/18/12 - This game is so random, I am surprised so many euro fans like it. I never get anything helpful in the occupations or minor improvements. I like randomness but it just doesn't fit in this game. I really need to stop playing this game.

9/17/11 - I finally got to sit down and play Agricola. My teacher was Ken and he had a nice set with some custom pieces. We flew through this two player game as the decisions got tougher. I did feel behind most of the game but for my first time through the game, my goal was to manage my empty spaces. I ended up with 20 points and lost to a more seasoned player. 

With these style of games, the multiple options always overwhelm me in my initial play. I am sure once the familiarity of cards and choices become more second hand, I would probably do better. My rating may change if I play more but for now its a 6.

RATING: 8
I'm not crazy about an excess of components to be constantly tracked and refreshed and corralled loosely on the table. And cross mingling between player boards and central play area just doesn't usually excite me.  Also, games with a large footprint on table I'm just not a fan of.

Despite this, I like it and it has grown on me.

Pluses- I like how everything kind of comes together and how you never have enough time or actions to get what you want.

Nov 08-Played solo (42). I missed the rule of less wood and feeding more(solo rule)-that would make it tighter. Need to remember this

June3 09 - Solo (48). Remembered feeding more, but forgot less wood rule. I'll get it right someday!

June4 09 - Solo (61) Maid, Forester & Fence Overseer. Got wood & feeding rules right.

10/2012- Update-the girlfriend like it! A decent length journey down the gaming highway for her, I have taken her from Stone Age, to Lord of Waterdeep and now to Agricola. And after her first play, she wanted to go again right away! 

Also, this seems to be a go-to solitaire game for me. These two factors have kicked it up to a 8.5 & a solid keeper.

RATING: 10
Warum ich diesem Spiel eine 10 gebe?!

Agricola gehört zu den Spielen für die man mich jederzeit begeistern kann. Bei jedem Spieleabend, bei dem es vorgeschlagen wurde, hatte ich auch Lust es mitzuspielen.

Ich mag die jedesmal unterschiedliche Verteilung der Ausbildungen und kleinen Anschaffungen, da somit jedes Spiel etwas anders verläuft.
Sicher sind einige Karten von großem Vorteil, aber ich brauche keine gleichen Ausgangschancen. Ich freue mich um so mehr, wenn ich trotz mäßiger Karten gewinne.

Was mir besonders gefällt, ist die Atmosphäre des Spiels.
Man ist hier wirklich ein ökonomisch arbeitender Landwirt. Meine besten Ergebnisse erziele ich, wenn mein Bauernhof Tiere, Getreide und Gemüse produziert.
Das Thema Bauernhof kann ich im Spielverlauf spüren.

Deshalb ist für mich Agricola eine 10.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Bought this at Essen without testing it, just because of the Fairplay scouts! 
1. Gaming time: This game has no hidden information so it is destined to become the worst game for players with analisis paralisis (Playing solo took me not 30 minutes but 2 hours this might become better with additional gameplay)
2. Interaction: Very limited. You can "steal" actions, but somehow it feels that it just makes no sense to see what the others do, as everybody has to check his own farm. This changes in the last round. (see point 3)
3. Turn order: Just the last two rounds it can become extremely frustrating to get actions taking that are crucial to its own farm. So having build for 12 round well enough can be undone by another player. (this seems to be contradictory to point 2)
4. Solo gaming: It may become redundant as the actions to do are very similar, even if different cards. Still it is great, that the designer has thought about it.
5. It may be too peacefull for warmongering gaminggroups, but a fun game for wives and girlfriends.

So, even though I have listed various nitpicking points, the game is still very good and fun to play. I will have to play it more often before the vote is going to rise or fall.
Update: Raised my vote to 9!
Update: After one year and playing it over 40 times I can seriously say. This is a 10 for me.

RATING: 7
So many things to do and a lot of paths to victory. The options are endless and the game is very nice looking. After a few plays it seems that you are playing alone and blocking happens only by accident since it is too costly to waste an action as a block. A good game for sure, but not as fun as I had hoped. I would also say that it is best at 2 or 3 (but even at three I hesitate to play), due to the lag between plays and the over thinking needed once you hit 4 players, which really makes the game lag. But with the right group, it can be great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I spent way too much time umming and arring about picking up Agricola, mainly because I thought that the theme wouldn't appeal to my group. How wrong I was! It is an amazing game that I keep coming back to (It is my most played game and I've almost played it twice as many times as my second most played). The cards really make the game and are often the deciding factor in who wins. By that I mean the person who utilised their cards the best. To mitigate a bad starting hand I always deal 10 and discard down to 7. I've played this the most two player with my wife and she loves the game. Our two player games take about an hour, which is great for a game of this weight. Adding players does increase the play time and I think it is usually around 30 mins per player.

Since the game can be so punishing, it has been really fun to see our scores get progressively better the more we play. In our first few games we were winning with scores around 20, now 20 is a really poor score and you need to be in the 40s to guarantee a win. Once in a while one of us hits 50 something, which just seemed impossible when we first started playing.

I also like the fact that the base game comes with three decks, which adds longevity to an already deep game. After 30 or so plays we've started to add the complex deck into the easy deck to mix things up a little.

If you like Euros at all, you've got to try this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In my opinion, Agricola did not dethrone Caylus as the king of worker placement games.  Caylus is a much more elegant game, though Agricola is more thematic.  Caylus is also much more interactive.  The set up and constant restocking of the supply spaces in Agricola is fiddly to the extreme and detracts from any enjoyment of the game. A mere two actions per round for about half the game seems more of a frustration than a challenge. I respect the design, but I just do not look forward to playing it.

RATING: 5
I have played this 5 or so times. I want to like it, and I don't know why, but I just can't. The constant pressure of not being able to do everything you want, or even need to, is just not quite for me I guess. I get enough stress at work, When I play this game, I just heave a sigh of relief when the game is done thinking, "man.. it's finally over..."
I am hoping to play Caverna, which I have heard is a couple degrees chiller, to see if that is more enjoyable for me.
Despite how stressful the game is, the pieces are great and the rules are solid. If you like a high pressure game where you can just never feel like you're getting ahead, definitely check it out.

RATING: 7
I really don't know what to say about this game, I've enjoyed playing this, but every time with a diminishing amount of enjoyment.

I think the problem is that as it's a very popular game some people have understandably played the game many times, and when you get involved in a game with one of those, your chances of playing the game succesfully are greatly diminished. I know this can be said of a lot of games, but I think because this is the No. 1 game, that situation is heightened with Agricola.

Having said all the above I still enjoyed playing the game. I might buy it one day and just play it with my wife, maybe that will be better as we'll both be at the same level.

RATING: 9

This game has me thinking about all the possibilities when I'm not playing, and I just want to keep coming back for more.  While some people complain about not having multiple paths to victory, I strenuously disagree: it's not about what your farm looks like at the end, it's about how you get there.

RATING: 10
An excellent game that is always just a little bit different. The hype is well deserved. However, I am not sure it has infinite "replayability", despite all the cards, as only a select few are really useful.  That said one must be flexible with one's strategy. Definitely not for AP prone people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
First play on 8/20/08, 3-player "family" game, plus 3-player "occupation/minor improvement deck" game. I was thrilled after the first game, and immediate felt the influence of Princes of Florence, Caylus, and Puerto Rico, as well as a little Age of Empires. Had the same desire for replay as I did after my first game of AoE, with no negatives like I felt with Caylus (length, dry). Playing my second game with the first deck was quite as impressive as I hoped, it made the game somewhat more "solitaire" than it felt in the family version, as each of us chose our own path and I can only remember one move in the entire game that one player could dramatically affect another (and he ended up choosing a different space anyway). But I rate the game an "8" immediately, and suspect it could climb to a "10" and take out Puerto Rico (or at least tie it) for me. 12-25-08, played again - 5player, and 2player. Raising rating to 8.5. June, 2013: 5 years later, Agricola has kept my interest, perhaps to a large degree due to new cards released frequently. The expansion doesnt seem necessary, and no one I play with seems to have much interest in it with all the different decks available. The game sometimes feels same-y to me, so I dont see this ever becoming a 10. Still, one of my top 5 desert island games. [iOS app has given me opportunity to play many more games in 2013. After about 25 using the E-deck, I've raised this game to a "10", but only if card-drafting rules are used.] About every third game I've played without drafting, I either get totally hosed by the card draw, or my opponent gets a killer combination. While it is theoretically possible to slow down an opponent with great cards, it requires a level of play that is beyond my capability, even with probably close to 100  games under my belt (including solitaire, which I do not log). I have not enjoyed playing multiplayer when hamstrung with a lack of card combinations or synergy, and the game drops to a "5" without 10-3 or complete drafting. Some might find it entertaining to "build a farm" while their opponents outscore them by 50%, but I would rather play a more interactive title if I know that a random draw could make any hope of competing impossible for me. As a solitaire game, I rate this a 10 for about the first 30 games with the base decks, as the combo problem is eliminated over multiple games. It's lower for me now, but stays a 10 overall due to the impact this game has had on me, my friends, the quality of components, and the value it has provided for the investment in time and money.

9-23-16: I'm rating this personally, using BGG rating criteria. Moving to an 8. My number one opponent moved away, and I've just not been inclined to teach this to new people now. Moving to shorter playing titles also.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
PO
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[color=red]Soloable Game[/color]
Playtime: 45-120 minutes

Comment: This game has gone on such a swing for me. It used to be a favorite, but that is waning just simply because it's so hard to get to the table. I absolutely adore this game. The only thing that really knocks it down a peg or two is the setup as well as the copious amounts of reading of occupation/improvement cards. If you play it like it should be played (with drafting), you're spending an extra 10-15 minutes reading and figuring out strategies.

[b]Update:[/b] Still unsure of how I feel about this game. I finally got it to the table recently and I had forgotten how mean/tight this game is. I still enjoy it and I feel like you have a lot more tense decisions than Caverna, but the Minor Improvements/Occupations partially kill this game for me. While a major bump to keeping this game interesting and fresh, it's a lot of work to plot out your cards and actually read them. Yes, with repeat plays it becomes easier, but it's such a hurdle.

I will say however that the game is excellent solo. A few years ago I was not fond of playing to beat the highest score, but that style of game has grown on me. You can learn and play with the different cards and see how they interact with each other.

Expansions:
:Wii+: Farmers of the Moor
:Wii+: Goodies Expansion
:Wii-: France Deck
:Wii-: Bliefeld Deck
:Wii-: Belgium Deck
:Wii-: NL Deck
:Wii-: World Champion Deck 2k11
:Wii-: Gamers Deck
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Personally I like to have a bit of light hearted fun or something complex with an engaging concept. This was neither of those things.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The one, the only.  Perfect balance with enough randomization and choices to ensure that you play every game differently.

This game has stood the test of time with my group, propelling itself to the to the top of our board game stack.  The consensus is that this is the best German-style board game we've played, and possibly our favorite game in the collection.

I don't know what else I can say about Agricola.  Do yourself a favor and give this game a try.

RATING: 8
Great game. Although the theme, farming in 17th century Germany, may not sound very exciting, it is very well expressed in the game; you really feel like it's a farm you're building. It is fun to see your farm grow, even if you're not winning. While the family game (without the cards) is also goos, the cards add a lot to the game, if you let them choose which one of the various paths to victory you'll to take.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great game! It's like a mixture of a worker placement game like "Stone Age" with the farming part of "Harvest Moon". But because of the abundance of cards and possibilities it's much better than similar games. I've played "Agricola" with two, three and four players and it was always a great fun.

It's quite easy to learn the game mechanics. Beginners and younger players can also start with the simplified family version without the occupation and minor improvement cards.

Even the solo version of "Agricola" is interesting. Of course it's quite different from the multiplayer versions, because you can plan all of your actions till the game's end. But it's also an appealing task to get as many points as possible with cards you have.

RATING: 9

Then, everything clicked in the 3rd game, and this is our favorite game by far.  It's totally engrossing, the 2P game goes by quite quickly now, and it's one of those games that we'll sit around for awhile afterwards talking about all the "If I'd have done/played/chosen this, it would have...", and there's very few games that do that to us.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the top worker placement games.  This game provides many hard choices vs other worker placement games, as it's very difficult to do a lot of what you want to do.  The needs far outweigh your workers.

The job cards provide an extra layer of depth to the game, however aren't really needed.  I've played without with newer or younger players, and the game still plays very well and a lot quicker.

The neg is that this game is pricier and seems to take longer than it should, due to analysis paralysis. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
+ World Championship Deck
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Too long to set up, too long to break down, too many pieces, too many things to do, too much of everything. If this game was reimplimented as a video game, it would be 10 times better. Not having to manage replenishing, harvesting, setup, and breakdown would actually put this into the 'worth the time it takes to play' category.

Update: it has now been reimplemented into a video game (iPad) so I've gotten to dig a little deeper, and... It's about the same. I traded one set of problems for another. The sheer amount of table busyness and upkeep shrouded the fact that this game is almost exactly the same every time you play it. I see now why Rosenburg put in the ridiculous amount of occupations and minor improvements he did - to trick people into thinking they weren't mimicking themselves (and everyone else).

RATING: 10
Build your farm in the most efficient way you can. Actions are very scarce so it's important to maximize their effects. Timing is very important. The tension to get food for your family is enough to always keep you on your feet and to distract you from your main goals. 

The cards twist things around just enough to make every game feeel very different. 

A true classic and one of the major achievements in gaming.

RATING: 9

RATING: N/A
Play It Forward 2014
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is my first non-traditional board game besides Risk. I've only ever played games like Monopoly or Scrabble, which I've only really liked for the companionship of playing with friends and family. Risk was my favorite board game up until I received Agricola as a gift. Now I think Agricola is my new favorite. 

My one wish, after a few games, is that it came with more occupation and minor improvement cards, because the version I have doesn't seem to have many. I like a lot of variety. Make that two wishes- I wish the pigs were pink because they look identical to the stone unless they're right in front of you. The stone could have been gray, too, because it looks more like coal or obsidian. But these are tiny complaints, and really I could just paint the pigs myself eventually.

I've played it two player so far, but it feels like the options on your turn are very limited. With 3 or 4 players, I think that would really intensify. I don't mind competition and it has taught me to try to have alternate plans ready. The shorter (1.5ish) game length is nice too. You won't stay up way too late trying to finish a 4 hour game. 

Besides some of the colors, the wooden pieces are awesome. The cards and board pieces are colorful and feel nice. 

This is a fun game that I plan to hold onto for a long time, because it's complex enough to be interesting, but not so complex that it turns people off. However, I will try to get some card expansions to keep things fresh.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played only with family version, which by the way is plenty enough at least in the beginning when learning the game. There's a lot to do even without the extra cards. Then when adding the cards I can see that you get a lot of play time out of this game.
I liked this a lot. Gave me a headache with all the planning though (not necessarily a bad thing).
Tough game. It's not the small-talk kind of game. You sit there and plan your moves and calculate how to get together enough food all the time. Good game anyway. Better than Puerto Rico? No way. PR is more interactive with the role selections and the screwing with shipments.

Still only played without the cards. Might be that the game gets even better when adding those. Possibly a 9 rating then as well.

RATING: 9
$33 ($30 Game +$3 Plano box)

I own this on IOS and so glad I did pick it up when it was on sale for $4. The app packs a long 90min game into a 15min experience and it is so much fun none the less. Of course I got my butt kicked by the AI because I was very inefficient with my actions but I will be better! I can see why people complain this game forces you to build everything and be jack of all trades in the game. There is no strategy sets like other games where you can go all out in live stock or crops. You have to do everything. This is where the worker placement mechanic comes in. You WILL want to block your opponent in this game.

---- Update ----
Bought this from Amazon when it was on sale.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My God what a slog. You have to do everything so you can't focus on building a unique strategy, so games get very samey. By that I mean that you score for doing specific things like getting one of the several types of animals, and you are penalized for not doing specific things like not getting a specific type of animal. The penalties are so severe that you have to do a little of everything or you lose on penalty points. Hence - it doesn't seem like there are multiple ways to win.

Finally, JUST as you start to finally build an engine with some momentum, the game ends. Why on earth is this game so highly rated? 

A friend who loves this game convinced me to refrain from selling it until I'd played it half a dozen more times. He insists that once I figure out how to build an engine early, that the later game will become fun, and that it is common for new players to feel "mired" throughout the game because they never build a sufficient engine to get their heads above water. I'll take that on faith for now. Ultimate assessment pending more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is about as deep as I'm willing to go in terms of complex games. Three different building materials, upgradable buildings, fences, 3 different animals, 2 types of crops, more than a dozen cards per player of occupations and improvements - it's a lot to handle. The problem is that it's so critical that you know the game inside and out to be competitive, you need to own a copy if you intend to learn all of the game's nuances. The fact that there is so much to the game is as much of a selling point as it is a reason not to buy. A 4 player game runs at a 2 hour minimum, and there's perhaps even more of a seating arrangement luck factor in this than there is in Puerto Rico. Having newbies mixed with advanced players spikes the game a lot more than fans would admit, and new players can feel disenchanted after realizing that a mistake they made in the first 4 rounds will make such a huge difference by the end. I prefer games where you can actually recover from mistakes. 

That being said, it's a great brain-burner of a solitaire game, and that's generally what I've done most of since I've owned it. Due to its complexity, I think it has more longevity as a solo game than Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Very German game: linear, few upsets, logical and very close scoring at end game. Adults can play it for the analysis required and kids for the theme. Very well designed and although it completely lacks adrenaline rushes. I heard that Agricola's instruction manual won an award - for the life of me, I will never understand why, I found it badly divided and horrible. Very static game with little variation other than 3 or two cards that are randomized each round and the choices of other players. Le Havre seems to be the exact same game except it has more variation with the availability of supplies and has a more Puerto Rico feel as to the different roads to victory. Warning: your first games will be very boring due to rule checking and not having a clue what you are doing and which combinations give you more points. Unless you are playing with gamers that want to learn and perfect themselves, don't waste a casual board game evening playing this with one timers who expect an immediate reward on their first play. Expensive game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very little to say that many people have already reiterated. I really like this game because the rules and gameplay are rather simple, but the long term winning requires careful consideration. The game also puts me in a good similar level as the rest of my family, so I can play with them as really dangerous opponents. We gave thought to "prettying" the game up with custom wood pieces from Mayday, but decided to spend our money somewhere else, as we agreed this probably would not enhance the experience that much for us. Maybe if I get some extra money I would go for that, but I think we would be more likely to buy a expansion instead.

RATING: 8.7
A lovely domestic farming game.  The animeeples and veggiemeeples are a wonderful touch, and unlike most worker-placement games, one is always bombarded by the sense that there are too many options.  One can't possibly do everything one wants, and the options only expand as the game continues.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Very clever and enjoyable game that's obviously had a great deal of thought and work put into developing, testing and balancing it.  Over-hyped, unfortunately; yes, it's good - but does it quite deserve the enormous reputation that's build up around it?

The enormous number of permutations of occupation and improvement cards make for a very re-playable and varying game, but at the same time they're the Achilles heel of the game.  If a player receives a set of cards that integrate well he/she has a *massive* advantage compared to a player that has cards that don't support each other.  This seems more of a problem in 2-player games.  Various "drafting" options mitigate this somewhat, so finding out you like to use is important.

Although all that reads rather negatively, it's a very good game and one that I certainly enjoy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
More plays diminishes the ratings...  there's other worker placement games that outshine this (Mecanisburgo, Bus, Age of Empires III).... mostly because they don't make me feel like a turn is broken into 4 or 8 micro turns and it feels like you have opponents rather than a race to complete a puzzle.  

I need to plant trees, to get wood ten years from now, to build a sawmill, to cut more wood, to build a room on my house so I can raise more kids that will cut me more wood... but wait? I built a room when I needed food... damn, I need a stove or more fences, that way I can have more food for my yet to be conceived woodcutting kids... fuck it all to hell. I need wood to build fences and that new stove too... I have an empty room and no stove!!! OH SHIT, how will I make beef jerky!!! AAHHH WE ARE ALL GONNA STARVE!!! That's an exciting game right there. I was on the seat of my pants since that first turn when I did not get the reeds and clay that I wanted.  And why can't I burn my neighbors fences or steal their daughter?

Do not touch this game !!

RATING: 10
Received from my 2009 Secret Santa!  Having the game in hand now I am very excited to jump in. Looks like I won't be able to play until after Xmas, but I think that's just about right given who it was that sent it.

Wow. Just...wow. After only a handful of plays I'm going to rate this a 10 because I have rarely been so quickly enamored of any game I've played. The beautiful interplay of mechanics combined with a theme that actually feels integral to the entire experience make this one of the finest games I have ever played. I will revisit these comments after I've put in at least 10-20 games to see if my feelings have shifted with more plays.

Wow....

Update: 20 plays in now and the game is more compelling than ever. We've only scratched the surface, really, as we've only played yet with the E-Deck. It has become our family game of choice and we all can't get enough of it...it's games like this that make me wish I had more time for games.

RATING: 7
neat game, although I haven't played Le Harve which is the next installment of this kind of game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A top-notch game of role selection.  There are never enough workers to do everything you want to do, and others are trying to block you from important actions.  A lot like Citadels with second-guessing of opponent's intentions while trying to still gain the best possible actions for yourself.  The sheer volume of cards available makes each game unique, forcing players to think on their feet (something I appreciate very much).  This game reminds me a lot of others such as Puerto Rico and Princes of Florence in that you have your own playing board, but all the action really occurs through the acquisition of things to put on your player board.  With the cards adjusting people's strategies each game, anticipation and calculated risks are important.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Basically another worker-placement & resource collection game, although it does have a number of features that in some ways increase the appeal above e.g. Caylus & Puerto Rico: the theme, the variety of cards, the way everything is tailored to the number of players.

The huge number of cards will certainly keep the game fresh, and whilst there are bound to be some unbalanced combinations, this unpredictability will make sure that your goals are slightly different in every game.

The game plays quite quickly, especially with fewer players. However, the last few rounds can bog down as there are increasingly important decisions to make.

Components are decent, although there are insufficient pieces supplied, esp. for 3+ players (doesn't seem to be an issue for 2 players) and the multiplier tokens are a pain to use.

WARNING: Could future editions have more/better pieces & corrected cards etc.?

OWN: PRE-ORDERED ENGLISH EDITION FROM JKLM (with bonus cards, without animeeples)

-------------------

NOTE: Animeeples are now available (July 2008) in a German-only upgrade kit, with German language Z-Deck & errata cards. Only available to owners of original German version, although 2nd editions in non-English languages apparently include animeeples as standard.

NOTE: Lookout Games may be selling Animeeples from Dec. 2008?

NOTE: Other animal figures available here:
http://quickreactionforce.co.uk/catalog/product_info.php/pro... (pewter, decent replacements)
http://www.hattons.co.uk/ProductList/category_list.asp?c=58 (scale? too big/small?)

RATING: 9.5
Infinitely re-playable. I have over 30 plays and have only used the E deck. When cards get used, it provides a unique way to build your farm over others.

Many don't like the tension the game creates, that tension is what makes this game great. Since all the resources are scarce, you have to plan each round according to what you need and if you don't get it, you need to have the fall back plan.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
I'm going to go against the vast majority of fellow geeks here and give this game a more average rating.

Let me start by saying I like the base game of Agricola a lot.  It is extremely well designed and balanced and on its own would merit a 9 or a 10 score.  

However, the game loses score for me on 3 fronts:

1) Fiddly - Having to reload the actions after every round is just too fiddly for me.  I think Uwe has even acknowledged this with some design choices he's made in his latest game (Ora et Labora).

2) Fixed end game scoring - The end game set goals just seem a bit boring - I can't really put my finger on why.  Everything you do which can be quite wild and diverse (which is good) all have to converge to the same score card every time.  It's only a minor thing really and it's probably just me.

3) Overpowered card combinations - This is the biggest issue I have with the game.  The fact that there are now hundreds of Minor improvement and Occupation cards leads to a big problem - Overpowered combinations just ruin the original, beautiful mechanics of the underlying base game.  Some combinations can quickly and easily negate the need to do certain things or boost their productivity in some way.  This smashes the original balance and struggle you have with the base game and makes it too easy to build a powerhouse and win.  

So how do you overcome this?  Well, you could just deal out random cards.  That wouldn't work because 1 player may randomly receive a power combo.  Instead you could do an organised card drafting - but this is more likely to generate power combos.  Whilst being fare (since all players will benefit), they are ruining the underlying base mechanics and making the game to easy still.

Now don't get me wrong, to play a power combo or even see its potential does require skill and clever timing - but it is completely unfair to players who have not got one of these combos or are less experienced perhaps.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Este juego esta muy padre, a mi me encanto, esta en español por la editorial devir.

Me gusta este juego por que colocas granjeros ( yo compre meeples de madera para substituir las fichas redondas ) y los pones a hacer actividades, solamente que lo he jugado en version familiar.

Actualizacion:

Wow! Este juego en su version avanzada es un mundo de diferencia a la familiar, los oficios y las adquicisiones menores le dan un aire totalmente nuevo.

Act#2

Les aconsejó que consigan un organizador ya sea a medida ( yo lo conseguí en mercado libre) porque es una molestia la organización en cada bolsita ziploc, también me compre los vegimeeples, los resource meeples y los comida meeples, le da un toque muy bonito al juego.

Act#3

El mazo difícil es muy complicado de usar, lo odio.

Act#4: 

Si por alguna desgracia, desastre natural o que se yo, me obligasen a escojer solamente un juego, este sería mi elección, este juego es mi favorito con mucha diferencia.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Update: I'm no longer enjoying this, in fact I find it infuriating. However,this is probably due to playing this when tired because this game pressures you to assess food (which doubles as money) and the competition for resources. So not only do you have to grit your teeth but a hand of cards then makes you consider charting alternate ways through this tough environment. The variety of cards is the appealing aspect of the game as each game will be refreshing, but unless you can build a room and start having offspring the process of building an efficient and high scoring farm is plodding and the feeling is compounded by reseeding the board every round. By then towards the end I feel I wringing my forehead to squeeze out where I can gain 1 point without losing out a point somewhere else. So feels like hard labour for little gain, much like running a medieval farm.

RATING: 10
If flavor matters to you, and you think farming in 14th century Europe sounds boring, you have yet to sharpen your wits on this brain grind stone of a game.
This is probably one of the best games for a serious gamer. A little more playable than Power Grid due maybe to slightly less complex mechanics and mechanical functions to track than PG demands.  It's only flaw for us is that a high bad/good luck on the initial hand deal can have a bit of impact. To that end we over deal and discard down to the appropriate hand size. This has significantly helped make this a very low luck factor game, that is highly player choice weighted for outcome. Unforgiving, lengthy and fairly complex, this game can become a mainstay at any game table that enjoys that, I surly could have done better next time feel. You'll be Kevin Bacon pleading, thank you sir may I have another. But next week, it is a bit lengthy to fit two plays into one game night.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[floatleft][ImageID=559964][/floatleft][floatright][ImageID=262888][/floatright]Its easy to see why so many people love Agricola. Most people get drawn in by the enticing theme and then stay for the game under the hood. I like Agricola quite a bit but after awhile each game starts to feel the same. The scoring requirements impose significant limitations on the game play options. I always feel pigeonholed at the end of each game to diversify my farm. People claim that the different occupation and minor improvements fluctuate the game enough to increase replay-ability but I disagree, the cards just feel like polished chrome that does nothing to change the overall game underneath. Argicola is the illusion of openness. Despite my qualms, Agricola is still a great game and I would happily play it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After 1 play of the family game...

Very good game, but there is a lot happening, even in the 'family' game. Not the easiest game to explain, but by the end of the first game, everyone was in the grove.  1st game including explanation took 2 1/2 hours, but there were no complaints. This is with a group that considers a 1 hour game to be 'long'.

Definitely NOT a gateway game. 

Can't wait to try the advanced version. 

Update:
Played the advanced version with 5 players. There was so much going on, my brain started slowly leaking out of my nose. Not for the faint of heart. If I wasn't so busy at work, I'd call in sick so I could play some more.  The downside is the game really CAN be determined by the opening deal. Next time we'll try the drafting variant.

RATING: 4
Too much fiddling and overcomplication. A big game with lots of bits. Decision making paralysis. Need to plan several turns ahead, impossible for new players learning the rules. Expect to be confused on how to proceed your first couple plays

-Heavy, complex rules, Worker placement, Minimal interaction

--Update: willing to give it another try
--Update 2: After 8 years between playing it the first time and now, we've grown as gamers, realized our introduction was from a scatterbrained and confusing teacher, and accepted that Agricola is a gold standard game that belongs in the pantheon of modern board games. 
Result: Now own the revised edition, but I want to let my old review and rating remain.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've played the hell out of this now, I can't remember how many games. 

We had a group of 5 of us playing it very often, we called ourselves the Farmville Five, and we we're catching up almost weekly to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There was a time when I was obsessed with Agricola. The trouble I wound up in was this repetitive feeling I got when forced to expand my worker pool. The dance to see who got to use the family growth action first, and who got to use the family growth without room spot got tiresome. I tried solving this apparent issue by over-expanding the game. I bought every card deck, and the Farmers of the Moore expansion. The problem wasn't solved, but the game did get unwieldy. I had to use white cardboxes to old the overflow. I liked the extra action cards you could select with the Moore expansion, but it always frustrated me that the card backs were different, and so it couldn't be smoothly integrated into the game. I sold the lot some time ago when Caverna came out, as Caverna has a many-workers strategy and a few-workers strategy.

Well, some time went by and I played someone else's copy of Agricola again, and it went more or less how I remembered. It did feel good to get back into it even if the experience itself hadn't changed remarkably. That's when I got curious about the revised edition. The revised edition rebalances the cards, and cuts the player count down to 4. Perhaps this helps to lessen some of the issues I had? I'm not sure yet. For now the revised version sits on the shelf waiting for me to get the itch again. I'm hoping it re-lights the fire in my heart for Agricola.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Had it since the holidays, and thought it looked too complicated to goof with...man, was I wrong.  The basic game is very, very simple to understand, and although I played it solo, I can see the deep potential.  Wonderful sense of satisfaction when you survive without a beggar card.  Simply cannot recommend this game enough.  So good.  So very, very good.

RATING: 3
It's not that the game is bad - it's that I thoroughly don't enjoy it. The scoring system (a mix of nonlinear 'buckets' and negative points) makes the game more about not scoring negative points than it is about scoring positive points. I cannot emphasize enough how much I dislike this mindset. The straw that breaks the camel's back is that if you mess up badly, you might as well forfeit, because you will never recover. The best you can do at that point is try to bring someone else down.

With some tweaks and house rules, I'd probably give this a 6 or 7. The game is *close* to being my kind of game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Acceptable -- box has some whitening from use and extensive color loss on the top from exposure to sunlight (was received that way).

 Purple player is missing two family member discs and one fence. Everything else is accounted for.

 Fifth edition has Animeeples and I & K decks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
:thumbsup: Wonderful worker placement that scales well, offers plenty of tough, interesting decisions and a high degree of tension as you struggle to do as much as possible when you simply cannot do everything. I've enjoyed mainly solo games in which I find it quite enjoyable to sit for an hour or so playing with my animeeples and vegimeeples. That type of play offers more of a sense of powering up your farm if you play the series and keep an Occupation each time. Very different from the multi-player games which really shine with the incredible tension, sweet spot being 2-4 players. While it's true that player interaction is somewhat limited to mostly blocking other players, that in itself can be quite brutal. I love the cards and agree with others who recommend a draft as the best way of mitigating random hands of junk. The fun is ALL in the cards. The family version must be dull as all hell. In the end, it's one of the more agreeable resource management games I've played, not being a fan of the genre. At least with Gric, the narrative supports the resource optimization and makes all the difference, as compared to say Le Havre, which falls flat for me.    

:thumbsdown: The game can feel quite fiddly. It's the only factor that requires me to be in the mood to play this. Sometimes I just find re-filling the board with bits every turn to be quite tedious. And of course, the rule book is awful--completely sleep-inducing. Took me over a year to get this to the table because I'd look at that rule book and it all seemed so much more complicated than it is. Thank goodness for video reviews. 

:star::nostar::nostar:Player interaction
:star::star::star:High tension
:star::star::star:Interesting decisions
:star::nostar::nostar:Dynamic game play*
:star::star::star:Strong narrative
:star::star::nostar:Desire to replay/enjoyment
:star::star::star:Re-playability

[size=7][i]*see profile note[/i][/size]

RATING: 7
Have played a 5 player game and a 3 player game. Lower my rating to a 5 if playing with 5 players. The game is fun with 3, but too little choices left with 5 players. Also, with 5 players the game takes too long. I do have a few issues with the game though. 

For one, so many minor and profession cards is overkill. It takes you 2 or 3 turns just to read them all, or you can wait 20 minutes to start the game while you read them.

Two, the game is basically multi-player solitaire. The most that you can do to someone is take an action away from them. There isn't any backstabbing or interaction here.

Finally, the end game is very anti-climatic and seems to happen right when you get your farm going. There is no tense feeling at the end of this game.

For what it is, it is still a fun game. Doesn't deserve the #1 BGG rating though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The definitive worker placement game, take it as you may. I like the random useful/lessness of the occupation cards and minor improvements, but for playing with others I think drafting is probably a better way to distribute them. 

Solo play is difficult to beat the target scores, multiplayer favors people with experience, as you might expect from a Eurogame. Have fun being 17th century farmers!

Played with drafting hands and an experienced player. With drafting, the game becomes an engine builder as much as a worker placement, a perfectly assembled hand of minor improvements and workers leads to amazing farms with tons of resources, but makes it a very different game. Not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
The very language dependent game pieces - for me unfortunately in German - without the owner taking the time to create and sleeve the English paste ups the game would have been unplayable. 
However, I much prefer language on the cards to obtuse icons where I'm constantly flipping though the rule book, I'll just have to wait until the English version comes out. 
Edit:
With the English version now out this is not an issue - except to complement the designer on using words rather than icons.

Theme farming? growing a family in the late middle ages? Wow! be still my heart. However, the play reflects the theme, including the victory where you have to be reasonably self sufficient. Just wish there was some trading element. The game play also revolves around the turn order to get a useful role. A redeeming grace is the use of cards to drive what you are able to do. 

A solid worker placement games, which ultimately is not one of my favorite genres.

I would like to see the Antebellum South version - you know with improvements to the big house, growing cash crops, and instead of begging if you don't grow enough food - family members get sold...

RATING: 10
Want to play Agricola?  I'll play anytime, anywhere, no questions asked.  In my humble and sincere opinion, Agricola is the pinacle of board game evolution.  It's feverishly fast beginning leads into a tense mid-game as you hone your farming machine.  Just as you get it up and running, the game twists a corner and you're already at the end... leaving you wanting that extra turn or two so you could just do those last couple of actions that would have made your poor dirt farm into a massive family ranching corporation.  If I owned this game, I would probably hardly ever play any other games... that's just how good I think it is.  A++!

RATING: 10
Simply the best. A masterpiece.
Over 200 plays and still can't get enough of it. "What is your second best game?" could be a hard question and my answer could vary from time to time, but number one is no contest.
Agricola is unique, feels different from the rest. I don't know if it's because of the theme, the mechanics, the variety of cards, actions, choices...
But for some reason, performing the simple duties in the farm when playing (not necessarily winning) Agricola provides us with a kind of satisfaction that we get with no other game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the best authors game out there with Twilight Struggle and 1960 MotP. The game material is superb specily if you have the animeeples. The rules are clear and the rulebook is effective in delivering the information. The mecanic of the game is not that hard to explain and to play but there is a lot of possibilities that are not obvious specialy for a beginner. The knowledge of the cards make the game a little bit less accessible because a player that have already played the game is more inclined to make the right combo of cards and be advantage compared with a new player even if both players are of the same caliber. The scoring is a little bit odd where an empty field is worth the same value has a field containing animals (shouldn't it worth more?).
I have bought the game in the frenzy of Agricola and to familiarised myself with the cards. But it's not the kind of game that I rate has one of my top.
Update july 1st 09: I increased the rating from 7.5 to 8 after playing a few game without the cards. I prefere this way of playing because it's not a card optimisation game. It becomes a management game where every player start on an even basis. You are not stuck in a situation where an experienced player, who knows the right card combos, will take an uncatchable lead, while a less experienced player will suffer trying to optimize a hand of cards that may not be good at the start. It's better this way because you do not feel like you start the game with two strikes du to a bad initial card distribution. 

Un des meilleur jeu d'auteur sur le marché avec twilight struggle et 1960 MotP. Le matériel de jeu est superbe, spécialement si vous avez les animeeples. Les règles sont claires et le livre des règlements est bien fait et livre bien l'information. La mécanique de jeu est simple et facile à expliquer, par contre elle offre plusieures possibilités ce qui n'est pas très évident pour un débutant. La connaissance des cartes rend le jeu moins accèssible car un joueur ayant joué peut plus facilement effectuer les bons combos de cartes comparativement à un joueur qui en est à sa première partie, même si celui-ci est du même calibre que les autres joueurs. Le décompte final est un peu bizarre ou un paturage vide vaut les même points qu'un paturage avec des animaux (ne devrait-il pas valoir plus?).
Je l'ai acheté dans la folie Agricola et surtout afin de pouvoir me familiariser avec les cartes, car ce n'est pas un jeu qui révolutionne le monde du jeu. Ce n'est toutefois pas un jeu que je considère être dans mes meilleurs.
Mise à jour: J'augmente la note de ce jeu de 7.5 à 8 après avoir joué quelques parties sans les cartes. Je préfère cette façon de jouer car ce n'est plus un jeu de gestion et d'optimisation d'une main de cartes. Le jeu devient un jeu de gestion et d'optimisation ou chaque joueur débute la partie sur un pied d'égalité. Vous n'êtes pas pris dans une situation ou un joueur d'expérience pourra optimiser son combo de cartes et prendre une avance insurmontable alors qu'un joueur moins expérimenté aura toutes les misères du monde à optimiser sa main de carte, alors qu'elle n'est peut être pas bonne dès le départ. Ainsi, c'est nettement meilleur de cette façon car vous n'avez pas l'impression de débuter la partie avec deux prises à votre actif car vous n'avez pas une bonne main de cartes. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

fun, thinky and interesting but needs more table time

For once, I used the suggested rating scale on BGG and rated the game based on my desire to bring it out and it gets a 4.  If I ever do play it, I will rate it on the official Randy Scale.

This is a game worthy of the 10 rating for me, and so now it is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I call this my favorite anti-game, and explaining why is going to highlight a lot about what I like and dislike about "these kinds of games" in general. 

A lot of its characteristics are things I don't care for in other games. Worker placement? Not my favorite way to select actions. Cascading turn order, where you disproportionately benefit through no skill of your own if you sit to the left of the guy who keeps taking Start Player? Again, not my favorite. Low direct interaction? Special power cards? Lots of bits requiring upkeep and seeding and (re)arranging? Individual player boards? In isolation, these things don't really do it for me, and that means most of the modern Eurocraze is lost on me. 

I'm a gardener, though, and so the harvest aspect of Agricola appeals to me. I don't ordinarily rely on theme in a game, but in this case, it's a draw. Growing your own food is engaging to me, and growing your own food without industrial intervention is also important to me. 

Agricola also captures the general angsty, anxious feel of being a subsistence farmer. I enjoy the dread, and the desperation, and the stress that comes from the accelerating schedule. Yes, it's a "pay the game back" gimmick, but again, thematically, it works in Agricola. What do you do with food? You grow it and eat it. If you don't eat, there are consequences. This all makes sense to me. 

But Agricola is a dead-end to me in Eurogaming. It is the only game I need that features an individual player board, or worker placement, or resource conversion. Certainly the only one I'd ever play against other people. I do occasionally play this solo (gate-to-gate in 30 minutes), and while I don't do it often, I do enjoy it -- I don't always need to have other people around if all I feel like doing is sequencing and optimizing.

RATING: 5
02/02/2013: Was interested in the game for the theme. Bought it and tried out for two solo plays to understand the rules and gameplay. As much as I wanted to get into the game, it became more dull as I played through. The game only started to come alive once  my food supply was secure, but it was already too late in the game to improve my farm/hut to up my score. The game felt very fiddly too, and managing all the bits (e.g placing resources in their respective spaces on the board at the start of every turn) undoubtably took some attention away from the gameplay which didn't help to improve the gaming experience. It is difficult to keep track of the score (and who is winning in a multi-player game), though I appreciated the reasoning behind the way the scoring was designed. 

All in all, a disappointing experience with a game that I really wanted to like but couldn't.

RATING: 4.25
I am not a big fan, in fact I do not like "efficiency engine" games. Slowly build up a proficient farm and so forth is just not my cup of tea. I prefer limited options (not due the lack of family counters but lack of options in general) and more luck, luck, luck. Random events, dice, and so forth. Without random elements, it is not a game, it is a puzzle, a calculation exercise, pure stress, no fun. If I want to do something that requires a lot of energy and results in something very efficient, I go to work or take a math exam. So, Agricola is not my type of game. No surprise there, seeing that I do not like Dungeon Lords, Dominion and RFTG for the same reason. I have not played with the interactive deck, so I cannot comment on that but Agricola felt like a multi-solitaire game to me, everybody is building his own little farm and there is some interaction (choice of action) but that is it. Not my cuppa.HX

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
CAVEAT: I don't particularly like worker placement/role selection games.

Why I think his game took the #1 spot formerly occupied by Puerto Rico:

[1] Greatly appeals to Magic: The Gathering fans and ex-fans (which I believe make up the vast majority of BGG users) with that huge deck of special power cards, from which players get only 14 cards for the entire game, which ensures that each player is confronted with the puzzle creating some uber-powerful combo.

[2] Hardly confrontational, like typical worker placement games. The only confrontation is selecting a role that one of your opponents badly needs -- and you'll only do that if picking that role rewards you; there is no gain by simply hurting an opponent in the lead. This caters to the Euro game fan who really can't handle direct confrontation or even prolonged player interaction, despite what they say. I blame this on their undeveloped social skills.

In the case of Agricola, the little player interaction there is simplistic when compared to Puerto Rico, which has much more varied player interaction.

[3] Simplistic strategies. Euro gamers (again, despite what they say) prefer tactical games over strategic ones. Euro gamers think that strategic games are those that have multiple paths to victory, but each of those paths don't have much variety. It's actually a bit worse in Agricola; there is really only one way to win -- simply get everything.

[4] Hardly elegant. I prefer games that achieve great depth with a minimal rule set. The "depth" from Agricola is derived from all those individual special rules for each role and playing card. (This is closely related to point [1].)

I simply do not enjoy games with these four qualities. However, Agricola has several redeeming features:

(a) Different variants of play depending on the skill levels of the players. I prefer the family version in which players do not receive any special cards. In this version, players are more focused on what their opponents are doing.

(b) Very good theme integration.

(c) Relatively quick play (for the family version).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros:
1. Stressful, but in a good way. Difficult to balance accomplishing things that will give you points and feeding your family.
2. Tough decision points. At no point during this game is it clear what you should be doing. In the sense, that there's so much that needs to be done, it's difficult to determine what's most important.
3. Variability. The minor improvements and professions can really change how you attack each games.
4. Thematic. You are physically building a farm on your tableau. The point scoring is definitely arbitrary, but to see the physical manifestation of your progress is very nice.
5. Forced to diversify - Focusing only on one strategy will almost guarantee a loss. You have to focus on multiple things to grow a diverse farm.

Cons:
1. Long game play. This game takes a bit to play. I expect at least 2 hours when I put this game to the table.
2. Analysis Paralysis. This is the reason for number 1. You will have players who will just freeze up and take a long time to make their decision.
3. While there are multiple roads to victory there is one thing you must focus on. You MUST grow your family. It scores too many points and allows you more actions. Early in the game this can cause a bit of a bottle neck if you are continually blocked from that spot.

Summary: This is one of the best worker placement euros out there. Lots of hard decisions to make. It's actually rather forgiving, a "bad move" at the start of the game can very likely help you a little later. You might say "UGH, why did I take this wood now" then a few turns later you're saying "Thank god I took that wood a few turns ago." 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

What a great game!  And it's managed to survive my ridiculously short attention span.

The downside:
- The cards dealt at the beginning can set players at different "distances" to victory.
- Table space needed is something to take into account.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
There's a lot of good in this game, but it has the flaw that the cards you're dealt dictate what you can and can't do for the first few turns, and ultimately what you should and shouldn't do for the entire game.  I love games where you collect resources and use them to build things to improve your abilities to collect more resources, and so on.  I've played probably 20 games like that, including this one, and liked them all.  But this one suffers from a feeling that I had almost no control, since the only two sensible actions to take (given the cards I had been dealt) were almost always taken by the time it was my turn, leaving me to choose among actions that made no sense to take (given the cards I had been dealt).  I've also played a lot of games where players interfere with each others' plans, and liked them all, so it isn't just that.  It's the combination of the two: a starting setup that dictates a particular plan, that then becomes impossible due to the actions of other players. It's also penalized by some scoring mechanics that create utterly illogical actions: I scored a lot of points just by plowing 6 fields, even though I NEVER planted anything in them.  That was ridiculous. (Guess what: it was because of a card I was dealt.)  I might rate this higher or lower with more plays, but for right now the best I can give it is a 7.6, and I think I'm being generous with that. (Second play: dropped the rating slightly, same reasons as before: the cards dictated what I could do, and I ended up dead last. If I ever won, it would feel like it was merely because of getting good cards. It isn't a bad game as it stands, but I would make a house rule: placing on the occupation space would let you pick from 7 face-up occupation cards laying beside the board, and placing on minor improvement would act similarly.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Im probably two years behind everybody else but Im looking forward to getting this. In fact im buzzing. I cant believe a game about farming would have me this excited. Not even a farm under attack by zombies or a farmer with chainsaw, not even aliens in the stable scaring the horses. Just farms, harvests, cycle of life stuff, critters and vegetables.Bring it on..
UPDATE. This is my favourite game at the moment, I completely ignored this game for ages reckoning that any game about farming and pushing bits of wood about must be boring, not so.
I love this game for several reasons...
- It has a great theme which it carries very well (1700s substinence farming!!).The harvest mechanic is a real tension point of the game which I love. This is about survival really, oh and getting loads of points.
- The quality of the art and components, and the tactile nature of the pieces.
- the cards, apart from the fact there are so many of them and they scale with the number of players involved.
They also mean you have get a different game everytime and have to adopt different strategies in play. Brilliant clever well designed and beautifully themed game, although im not sure about the Farmers expansion though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
"Agricola" is worker placement in its finest. It's tight on resources and there's a lot of action denying. As if that was not enough, you often feel like you're on the verge of starving, and because of that, it's a very brutal game.

Not everyone enjoys the tension of feeding in "Agricola" and that's understandable. It's not uncommon to be dependant on a single action and sometimes your opponent will take advantage of that, making you cry a little bit inside. To really enjoy the game, you have to be prepared for that. But at the same time, it's very rewarding. Watching your farm grow is amazing and when your little precious engine starts working, you do feel proud of your achievements.

There's also a lot, and I mean, A LOT of replayability even in the base box, and with all the expansions it's almost infinite. Each game plays differently and figuring out the best combination of cards is a satisfying experience. One of the best, a game that will never leave my collection.
