RATING: 6
[b]RO[/b]: [i]07/05/2015[/i]

Despite my play count on this one, Agricola has never failed to... underwhelm. Still popular today eight years after it's release, though perhaps overshadowed by Caverna, Agricola was a force to be reckoned with in it's day (vying with Twilight Struggle for the coveted #1 spot for quite some time). This fascination and love of Agricola I have never fully understood. It is entertaining, yes, but I have always felt extremely anxious while playing it. One may say this is a triumph as anxiety and uncertainty fit in superbly with the theme, but these are not emotions I want to feel while playing any game, even a euro (games prone to exacerbate anxiety in both my wife and I) like Agricola. This is due to the "can't do everything, gotta be as efficient as possible" style of the game play. A modern classic to be sure, just not for me.

RATING: 9.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Agricola takes a fair bit of time to learn, but once you get it, it can be a very rewarding game.

This game has just the right amount of randomness: the random cards won't make or break your game, but they do change things up enough that you can't play the same strategy every time. You'll have to play to the odds and have a contingency plan if things don't go your way.

Play can be a bit slow, but the pacing is quite consistent. Turns don't tend to take longer as the game progresses, as happens in many other games. Your choices are limited enough that you rarely get stuck trying to make a decision, but each one is important to the end game.

The state of the game is also very clear. You can tell without too much trouble who is winning and who isn't, who has or needs what, and get an idea of what your opponents might be doing. I don't find myself wishing I had better insight into what is happening in this game, whereas I do in many others.

The biggest downside is the amount of work that needs to be done every turn to move and stock pieces. It really slows down the game to spend 25% of your time moving wooden discs. I think this could be alleviated somewhat if the pieces were in a tray rather than in bags, or if rotating counters were used instead of tokens.

Overall, this is one of the best strategy games I have ever played. It's interactive without being aggravatingly competitive, it's long but not too long, and it's just random enough to keep things different without making strategy building impossible.

There's a reason this is still one of the highest rated board games on BGG!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Right now, I do not understand Agricola.  I mean, I can play it all right, and if I am playing with another first time player, I have a chance to win, but there are a lot of different variables.  That does not mean, however, that I do not like Agricola.  I really enjoy building my farm, making sure I have enough animals left that they can breed and planting crops.  I love placing my family members--and heck, I like building my family.  But this game is a lot of work.  It's not one that I would say, "let's play again."  I am exhausted after Agricola.  I might say, "Let's play again tomorrow."

***Update(12-26-09)***

After ten plus plays, I finally think I've got a handle on the sorts of strategies that I might employ.  I've even done some experimenting with different strategies to see what works.  I've come to the conclusion that it is very bad to pay too much attention to the cards.  Focus on family improvement and build up the house.  I think my brother (the only person who will play Agricola with me) has won once or maybe twice out of our 11 games so far, so there must be something about the strategy that I've figured out that he hasn't.  It's strange because he usually has a much higher win percentage than I do in most other games.

RATING: N/A
•Family variant of the game (see rule book) is less complex and perfect for introducing the game. (removes extra cards like improvements and occupations)

•Takes a while to learn the game (usually half way through for new players)
•Games can take a LONG time (up to 5hrs, often only get one game in). New players often want to play again, but there's no time.

"King of resource management games" - Highly rated!

Cool features:
Interactive cards
cards that get passed
multiple ways to win
everyone stays in the game

RATING: 5.75
You may like the many cards, but to me they feel as to hide the weakness of the game. The uneven rounds with harvesting show that the designer saw a problem of players getting too many stuff, so he decides to give the world a bit of a spin - towardst the end rounds/seasons get shorter. If offered to a large publisher, they would reject it as too unbalanced, too many bits, still too much a prototype. And that's how it feels to me: a prototype.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a solid and enjoyable game in the family of Caylus. I find it more enjoyable than Caylus because the theme is more personal: the struggle to feed your family feels real.  However the expansion cards seem to weaken the theme, especially the occupation cards, as suddenly your poor old husband and wife are holding down four jobs between them as well as running the farm! Player interaction is present, as trying to guess which action you can leave for the next round of picking is critical and the openly displayed resources help with this. However it doesn't usually seem to have a lot of tension or excitement.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very pure and excellent worker placement game. Agricola  has certainly one of the best (or the best) theme-mechanic-integration of all Euro-games. However, the game can be very cut-throat if the someone takes the worker spots you need and you fail to gather enough food for your family. 

The different occupation and improvement cards give  a lot of variety, but many of them are clearly inferior to others, such that there is some luck of which cards you are dealt in the beginning. I think fewer, more balanced cards in the game and being dealt fewer cards (maybe 3 instead of 7) would improve the game.  

I personally do not like how advantageous it is to increase your family, which pretty much makes the game be a race of which player gets additional family members first (which is certainly not a trivial task).

Initial rating 7.5

[i]Update: Rating increased from 7.5 to 8.5 after 5th play[/i]
With additional plays you get more skilled in using the cards you are dealt effectively. There are better cards than others, but you can "work" with most hands. If you already plan in the beginning rounds to increase your room number, you also do not fall behind much in the race for  the first additional family members. 

I am still not really impressed by the scoring, which turns the last two rounds in getting certain animals or grains which you actually really do not "need" for your farm business. But this is only a minor point and does spoil the fun you have had when building up your farm during the previous 13 rounds. 

As I now have also played more modern worker placement games, I am impressed how good Agricola (and Caylus) is in comparison to those.

[i]Update2: Rating decreased to 8[/i]
I do not like that the game very often results in a race for who gets the family growth first, which can easily result in rich-get-richer. Besides that, an excellent game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I really suck at this game. My wife regularly cleans my clock. She says it's because i over-think it. All i know is i want to keep playing it and try to dethrone her.

RATING: 9.5
Always a desperate time, even when you think it is going OK. Playing with drafting seems to be most balanced. Drafting does take some time, though. First few plays can be rough as you fight off a sense of panic. After that you can calm down and concentrate on building the farm and learning the patterns needed for each improvement. Then you can start using card interactions to make you more efficient. Then you can advance to trying to slow the other players by varying your actions to hinder theirs.

RATING: 7
Dec 2015 update: I've now been convinced that my previous analysis/issues with the game are incorrect - there is a lot more depth to this game, and a much higher skill curve, than I gave it credit for.

June 2011, Previous review: A fine game, but I feel like most games play very similar. Family growth is by far the most important action, and so a lot of your early game is setting up to take family growth. When the family growth card actually flips has a huge impact on the game - if you've prepared for it on turn 5, it's painful if it doesn't flip until turn 7. I've heard the "Farmers of the Moor" expansion fixes a lot of my issues with the game

RATING: N/A
After ten lovely years of Aggy games the time has come to move what has evolved into a massive, comprehensive collection on.  I picked up every deck along the way.  I brought in the fine E-Raptor player templates that the boards slide into. Not every board, however.  I bought a German copy of the game which had player boards that happened to fit or match up with the templates.

We even kept the game in a Pelicase, with wheels even, to move the thing around and keep it tight.  Every card is premium sleeved and there are a ton.  I bought wooden bits for all the pieces including food in half a dozen different forms.  Fish, chops, veggies.  There are even a bunch of fine looking chicken that we tried to work into the game, without great success.

The German stone house tiles have roofs, some even with storks, the ultimate touch to the game.  Inquire for pics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.38
I stuggle to understand this games ranking. Okay, I've only played it once and came in second 5 points behind (which is, I think, a massive gap in this game) but even so. The game is quite heavy, like Le Havre it overwhelms players with options. You start with 10-16 different things you can do and a new one appears each turn. This is basically quite a clever mechanism but the way it is presented leaves a player having to peer at a dozen or so cards every turn. You then use these options to build up your farm which ultimately scores you victory points.
Unlike Le Havre there is no hierarchy where you turn things into other things which turn into other things to turn into VPs. Even so there are a lot of fiddly little bits to keep an eye on and track.
Also unlike Le Havre it seems to hinge much more on opening strategy and the end-game has the same accelerated feeling I dislike in many much simpler Euro games. 
I resent a learning curve I would normally associate with light wargames in something that does essentially the same thing as medium Euros. If I put that level of time in I want to get a corresponding return. I need to give this and Le Havre a few more games to see what the return is like but my suspicion is they don't represent a good investment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.94
Bought this having read all the positive reviews.  Not sure if its the complex rules or having recently played Stone Age which was simple to explain and fun to play, but in comparison (which may be unfair), I just can't see the appeal currently.  Hoping to change my mind...

20.11.2011 - Quick update, having ditched the family game version and had 5 games last weekend, this game is a blast.

20.01.2012 - changing rating from 9 to 8 as a group we've not gone back to it for a while and played the expansion only once.  In comparison to other games played, this is a good game but for some reason not one anyone else suggests playing...

:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Easy to learn
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Fun factor
:star::star::star::star::star:   Replay-ability


Why this game stays in my collection?
This has not hit the table for sometime, but i've never considered getting rid of it, even with caverna out (which i've yet to play), perhaps due to its lengthy play time in comparison to other games now in my collection.
Would it be a desert island game, certainly.
Oh and a special thanks to The Secret Cabal for this forever being known as Misery Farm in our gaming group.

RATING: 7
D版
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Agricola fully deserves its status as one of the classics, and I'd almost always be delighted to play it - despite really not being very good at it. The constant tension of trying to scrape together enough food to survive, while building a large and diverse enough farm to score a respectable amount of victory points - and of course never having anywhere near enough actions to do everything you want, or knowing which of several crucial actions is the most important to prioritise right now - really makes Agricola what it is. And the occupation and minor improvement cards give the game near-infinite replayability, as you have to consider which cards to play and when (and how best to utilise the advantages they give you), and which ones are just traps to be avoided.

I still don't rate Agricola higher than 8, though, as these days it's almost never one of my first choices. Partly that's because of Caverna - which is missing a lot of the knife-edge tension, but adds such a wealth of new strategies and options that I'd almost always choose it over Agricola (although I do think there is certainly room for both in a reasonably large collection like ours). But more importantly, for some reason I have rarely find myself in the mood for Agricola over the past year or more (which is also true, to a lesser extent, of Caverna). It's still a great game though, hence my rating remains high.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
+ More thematic than Lords of Waterdeep
+ Family friendly
+ Get the sense of building an actual farm
+ Animeeples are great

- A bit longer than the average family game, I would recommend Stone Age over this as a family gateway worker placement game
- No resourcemeeples/veggiemeeples (breaks the theme a bit having actual animals and then circular wooden tokens for produce)
- A lot of maintenance/upkeep, updating action spaces with components
- Forces you to do everything and make a balanced farm

(Still needs more plays with the cards to see how that affects the dynamic of the game)

RATING: 9
I recently got this after hearing all the rave reviews on BGG. I was not disappointed. This is one of the most beautifully produced games I've ever played, with fantastic components consisting of thick-stock cards, quality game boards, and wooden bits. Has several different decks for every mode of play, to support any group of gamers and non-gamers alike, and even comes ready with a solo-variation. A must-play game.

RATING: 9
Pretty good. I've played two solo games (1 with family rules), several two player family games and several two player E-deck games. Amazing amount of choices. Two of my  concerns are "analysis paralysis" and playing time. The box says 30 min per player but the Geek consensus seems to be more like 45 min to an hour per player. I've found it a little more as we learn. Still a good game probably worthy of the praises. I just don't know how often it will hit our table. For us it sometimes can feel more like work than play.

Update: Taking it up a notch. The family game can be really enjoyable. The full game, even at two-players is too long for us. Maybe more plays will cut down on time.

Update: o.k. it's got me. Long but sooo intriguing.

RATING: 8
I like worker placement style games and really appreciate how well this game scales with a different numbers of players. 

While I do not feel like the "full" is difficult to learn, the simpler family mode is a great way to introduce Agricola to new players. In many ways, I like the family game over the full game because there isn't the randomness with the cards.

I am also a sucker for lots of wooden components and this game does not disappoint!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I suppose you could call this game processional, or even the dreaded "multi-player solitaire," but I still find this much-hyped game a highly enjoyable mental workout. I had an abysmal first experience (due to a poor hand of cards, a sloppy paste-up job, and an inadequate rules explanation), but recent plays with the new English edition are a completely different story. The 400 cards (including the bonus deck)give nearly endless replay value, and the animeeples have a genuine psychological effect on the game: you now think twice about barbecuing that cute sheep.

RATING: 7
To succeed, players must develop synergies between his/her occupations, improvements, and worker placements. 

I prefer this to Caverna, which is odd, considering I tend to prefer perfect-information games. 

However, what occupations and improvements a player drafts or with which they randomly starts creates a puzzle: how does the player optimally coordinate these cards with his or her worker placements? This puzzle varies from game to game, and increases Agricola's appeal.

RATING: 10
It's games like this that keep me buying new ones. An endless quest for a repeat of that sensation experienced during the exciting discovery of a new elegant game that I want to play over and over. After my first play, I chalked this one up as a nicely designed worker placement. But after a few more games I found that the variability in card driven strategy begs for more plays and attempts at improved optimization. That said, I find that games with 4 or more players can drag esp with those prone to AP. I like it best with two or three. All in all a fantastic game that has broad appeal for a relatively deep game. The hype is justified.

RATING: 6
This game basically ticks all my boxes:
Sexy theme (farming in 19th century Germany)
Exciting things to do (fishing, plowing fields, tending cattle, building a stove, baking bread)
Great mechanics (that have you scrambling to build an engine just to have the game end right when the mad hustle is slowing down and you finally feel a shred of control.)
The single most amazing thing about this game though, is that your meeples can BREED. I've always felt there is way too little sexual content in your average worker placement game. After all, what could be more natural than a little wood on wood action?

This is very far off track. Sorry.

Agricola is a fine game. Well loved. Not a perfect fit for me but I'm usually happy to play it. (If I have too.)

RATING: 9
http://ronkkonen.com/boardgames.html#Agricola
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It has a similar feeling to age of steam, the feeling of almost drowning in debt for the first 3/4 of the game, and then, once you manage to get a sustainable food source, you can focus on the luxury of expanding your farm.  Lots to do, quite evocative, a lot to admire.  More special power cards than I generally like, but I like the way your options slowly expand over the course of a game, allowing you time to get used to all the possibilities.  I feel like I'm bargain hunting, coupon-clipping.  My girlfriend played it and liked it.  She says, "I didn't know guys play games about shopping!"

UPDATE: After 10 or so plays, the game is still holding my interest.  In the general sense, this isn't my type of game.  There's too much text, too many bits.  The game requires not a jot of creative play (only efficient play), and there's very little interaction between players.  But what Agricola does it does really well.  Its appeal is broad, even to non-gamers, making it easy to get on the table.  I'm always happy to play, and I'm always proud to see what gets accomplished on my little piece of land.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Agricola is a lot of fun, till it comes time to scoring.

I'm not usually too focused on winning (save for in "take that" games where it's funny to throw hurdles at others), but I feel extra detached from winning playing Agricola -- the scoring feels arbitrary. (I like how I built my farm, where do you get off saying it sucks, game designer?)

The process of designing and expanding my farm while keeping my family fed is enough for me to have fun, though.

RATING: 8
update after 50+ plays - i still really enjoy it but the start player thing is becoming more and more annoying esp with 4/5 ppl - the person 2 the left of the most keen just benefits too much

also a self-congratulatory wank-fest ala race for the galaxy

rating after 8plays (3/4pls) - 7/8 

k so i like the constant tension of wanting to do so many things BUT i still think the end scoring is fiddly and inelegant and u can still get screwed by your start hand. 

i think itd be a better game with less random and more communal cards...oh hold on ...that LE HAVRE :) (shame that one takes a fair bit longer)

rating after 11 plays - 8 - i like it more the more i play it

rating after 20 plays - 8 - a good solid 8 and prob won't change

rating after 50 plays - 9 - lots to like about it tho can get screwed by ur cards, also i no longer recommend it with 5 - start player becomes too crucial and u can be stiched up big time but other player's sub-optimal play

RECC - le havre

rules - 2/3 - is fiddly but the tight theming helps - tho forget the cards for noobies
play - 3 - 
master - 3/4 - hard to master but random cards add to this

RATING: 4.5
There is a lot of people out there that love this game. Of all the "worker placement" games I own, this one is the least fun. The pieces are annoying, the boards are annoying and clunky at best. They may have worked better as one big board. There are so many pieces that need sub-divided based on the number of people playing. As a two player game, I find it weak and boring. I just don't understand all the hubbub over this game. Not to mention, it leaves the feeling that you want to do more and you can't. Lame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
While I bought this game to play with my gamer friends, I knew it had elements my wife would enjoy- namely efficiently building and planning a farm. She enjoys games like Vegas Showdown and Princes of Florence where you have a plot of land and buy elements to build on that plot. Knowing her aversion to complex games, I thought I'd introduce her to the Family game version and see what happened. Immediately afterwords, she demanded to play the full version. After a full game of Agricola she demanded a rematch and now wants to play again. This game is a winner.

The game starts off slowly, but starts to fly by. For a longer game, it seems like it just isn't long enough to do what you want. Very low downtime, constant agonizing decisions, and huge replay value. Every game seems to have a panic zone of seeing the game barreling to the end with a lot of empty farm spaces not enough actions to do what you want.

RATING: 6
While the game has various subsystems, the all-consuming need for food bends most of them to a common goal.  Due to the scoring, one can't push to far out one system to the exclusion of others forcing a balanced growth in many areas. 

A game that will take a few plays to wrap one's head around as the choices from the cards aren't always obvious without having a feel for the full arc of the game.

Definitely need to be the right mood to play this one, not one I am rushing to suggest all the time nor seeking to play more than a few times a year.  Rating lowered as a result, especially after playing Caverna and wondering if I slight prefer Caverna just a tad more.

RATING: 9
Does a good job of handling the "worker" placement genre--giving tough choices to every player through out the game.  Scales well for differing numbers of players through use of the different action cards.  A wide variety of minor improvements and occupations keeps the game from becoming stale.

A well done game on all levels.  The only negative is the possibility that a killer combo of minor improvements/occupations could lead to victory over skillful play.

RATING: 7
Rating will probably go up with more play.  Very multi-player solitaire.  Many, MANY options to consider on each turn.  Very, VERY few actions each turn.  Strategies seemed to take a fair amount of time to develop and seemed fairly fragile, i.e. one missed action (another player semi-randomly chose what you happened to need) could be VERY damaging.  Might have a few too many moving parts...or might be a tremendous game for years to come.  Want to try again, especially with fewer players, which I think might work better.

UPDATE: I'm definitely keen to try with fewer players, which should help a bit with the fragility mentioned above.  Rating up a bit.

UPDATE: Rating bumped up for the two-player game, which I found easier to manage and more fun.

RATING: 3
I figured it out what I don't like about this game: The goal is too dispersed for me; no empty spots and as much variance as possible with the few resources you have. I need to work towards some kind of goal; like a defendable dungeon in Dungeon Lords or (I hope) the best beers in Brew crafters. Some games I play are a bit scattered goalwise speaking, like Pillars of the Earth and Dungeon Petz, but at least in those games you can choose your own goals or ways to go forward. In Agricola not so much; Agricola crossed the fine line of not enough focus combined with too many must-do's and too little resources

RATING: 9
I predicted this would become my family's favorite game, surpassing "Settlers of Catan."  I was wrong.  The family enjoys it, but not as much as SoC, for a few reasons:
(1) At 1.5 hours, it's a half-hour longer.
(2) It is less social.  The only possible interaction is one that "hurts" another player.
(3) It makes us think more.
None of these are bad; they're just different.  For a family that enjoys "Harvest Moon," it's a terrific theme.

RATING: 10
Addictive as either a solitaire puzzle or multiplayer game.  I *really* like building games, in general, so not much surprise I liked this one.

Solitaire Series
1. E-deck: Plow Maker(63)-Baker(56)-Merchant(60)-Mendicant(71)-Carpenter(65)-Woodcutter(74)-Conservator(75)  *This series was played before I realised you got carry-over food based on points from  previous game*  
2. K-deck: Wet Nurse(59)-Forester(71)-Animal Tamer(68)-Wood Deliveryman(67)-Traveling Salesman(73)-Frame Builder(75)-Wood Carver(79)
3. I-deck: Field Watchman(64)-Bricklayer(72)-Fence Builder(63)-Clay Hut Builder(66)-Wood Collector(74)-Net Fisherman(72)-Church Warden(75)
4. E/I/K/Z-deck: Chief(58)-Carpenter(65)-Master Brewer(67)-Merchant(70)-Schnaps Distiller(67)-Fence Overseer(77)-Sower(77)
5. E/I/K/Z-deck: Woodcutter(55)-Forester(64)-Clay Mixer(65)-Animal Tamer(66)-Plow Maker(72)-Chief(74)-Pieceworker(75)
6. E/K-deck: Merchant(52)-Adoptive Parents(72)-Master Brewer(60)-Lord of the Manor(64)-Carpenter(69)-Baker(76)-Market Woman(72)
7. Gamer's-deck: Family Counselor(56)-Seed Master(60)-Food Critic(69)-Architect(66)-Inventor(72)-Grafter(75)-Grain Farmer(73)
8. Belgium-deck: Surrealist(50)-Rainmaker(66)-Anatomist(68)-Soda Producer(71)-Small Scale Farmer(73)-Elder(80)-Seed Scatterer(80)

Quarry is *very* powerful in later rounds of series...
Gamer's deck doesn't have many ways to get extra resources (at least, not in a solo game).  I think the Inventor was therefore the most powerful of the occupations.

RATING: 7.5
06-09-2014. Rated after 1 play. I refrained playing Agricola after seeing all the components and the -to me- unclear reading of the rules. I had it taught to me by an experienced Agricola player (Thanks Flashly).

In the end, I think the game is quite easy to comprehend. Basically it's a worker placement game with actions that come available during play in a semi-random order. The theme, farming I couldn't care less about, but the theme is  well executed and cards/actions make sense both gameplay wise and thematically. A well executed game and a fun challenge to play. Way better than I expected beforehand, being more thematically game minded.

The only thing that is very un-thematic is the scoring. You can not develop paths in the way you want, but are steered by the scoring (you get punished if you fail to do something), and are not allowed to focus on something you like to do or your cards suggest.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Get ready to compete for resources! Should you send your family members out to gather wood, clay, reeds or stone? Should you add people or improvements to your farm who give you a bonus whenever you or another player perform an action? Don't forget the animals. You have to get some sheep, wild boar and cattle and fence them in as soon as possible so you have something to feed those babies! The number of players (1-5) will dictate which resources and how many of each resource are available in the game. Couple that with a new combination of 14 cards per player each game and you will have a different experience each time you take it out of the box. Lots of choices and lots of paths to victory will keep you coming back for more, This game has been at the top of BGG for a long time for a reason.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
----------

Disclaimer:  I've only ever played Agricola as a 2 player game, so this is where my opinion is coming from.  With that being said, I could easily see how more players could change some of my gripes (such as the wood/family expansion unbalance).

At first, I loved Agricola... I had never played a game with so many options.  I also loved the replayability given by the cards.

But now that I've played over 30 games, I can say that I'm put-off by the food engine.  Even though the some of the occupation/improvement cards add SOME replayability to the game (not much replayability because most cards are useless due to their low ROI), I feel the food engine can only be set up a few different ways... and I don't like repetition or strategic constraints.  I also don't like how I am forced to spend 80% of the game setting up a food engine so I can spend the last 20% focusing on building my farm; I'd say about 70% of your total VP come in the last 3 rounds... and this backloading makes the first 11 rounds feel like a chore.  It's frustrating that you spend most of the game taking care of the food requirements rather than actually playing the game to gain victory points.  

And like I said, while the cards add SOME replayability, the food engines are pretty much always the same:  are you going to be a baker, a gardener, a slaughterer, will you frequent the fishing/day laborer spots, or will you use a hybird approach with some card bonuses and one of the above mentioned techniques?  Not much going on there.. and since the food engine is the core of the game, the replayability takes a major hit.

And finally, the most overpowered and obvious path to victory is to hog the wood space and increase your family as quickly as possible.  This sucks the fun out of the game because the person controlling the wood can limit the other's growth, thus securing a strong foothold on the lead.  I could see this changing in a game of more than 2 players, though.

----------
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is one of my favorite so far. It is a heavy duty thinker. The only element of luck in this game are the cards you draw which introduces a slight element of luck but not enough to change the game drastically.  Unfortunately I always lose this game but I still love it. It might be seeing my farm develop and strategically building your farm better than everyone else's farm. Some people hate the feeding people requirment aspect of this game but to me I like the challenge it gives to the game.

Pros: Very Strategic game, a lot of player options, competitive game, Extremely thematic, Changing game play every game, Variety of options, Challenging

Cons: Long playing time, difficult to teach, Long set up time, Prone to stalls with indecisive players. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent euro that is deserving of all the accolades it receives. Le Havre may be deeper, but Agricola is more enjoyable, most likely because it's missing that "digging yourself out of a hole" feeling and less resources to keep track of.

I see a lot of replay value here, and there seem to be plenty of paths to victory. The starting hand available to each player will suggest certain strategies, but there are a variety of ways to maximize VPs in any way a player chooses.

Another thing I like about this game is the artwork and resource meeples. With the goodies expansion it becomes incredibly immersive. Much like Le Havre the print on the cards is small, but unlike Le Havre you don't have to squint across the table at other player's play areas to read them.

The learning curve is steep, but I haven't played a Rosenberg game where that isn't the case. I'm disappointed I listened to the naysayers for so long, and I'm glad I finally discovered for myself how great Agricola truly is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
With the "choose a role" dynamic, it's like Puerto Rico, but with more of a story arc. Though by the end of the game you're choosing between roughly 25 different actions, it somehow doesn't feel overwhelming. More so than any other game I've played, a good performance requires balanced strategy. The crux of the game is more about planning the fastest and most efficient path towards the (relatively) same endgame that your opponents are aiming for.

Though it is difficult for new players to correctly value the improvements and occupations, but that just adds depth for the advanced player. Overwhelming for euro game newbies, but straightforward rules for those comfortable simultaneously keeping an eye on a handful of success metrics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game looks fairly simple from the outset, but there is a lot of strategy involved here.  Even in the base game you have to really plan ahead if you want to win.  Adding in the cards gives the game a lot more variety and replayability, and complexity as well.  I haven't even used the intermediate and advanced cards yet...  Easy game to play without having to understand a ton of rules.  I usually advise new players to have fun with it and build whatever farm they like!  After playing it once it becomes apparent to all players how you should 'best' play.  Recommended for board game groups who don't want to play anything crazy complex, but more in depth than Catan.

RATING: 7
This is quite the game.  I'm not surprised it's gotten all the hype.   As for my personal take;

I enjoy the combination of Economics / Worker placement that Agricola has to offer, and I really look forward to digging deeper into the game to really try on more informed strategies.  I don't however think this is the best game of 2008.  

Gamers that love games where you can exert a massive amount of control over outcomes will enjoy playing this if they get a good mix of cards in their hand.  I found this to be the one major weakness with the one game I played.  While I admit that I misplayed many of the cards I had (chalk that up to fist time played) I was able to look back and see I did indeed have one of the least powerful hands.  With the fluctuation of the cards, I feel like you should have to draft for at least half the cards in your starting hand....   not only would that make the game more interesting (you'd know who picked up that hamper...) it would also make bad hands not amount to a crap game for one or two players.

RATING: 9
One of my favourite games.  Lots of hard decisions to make, and tense throughout.  Do I take that huge pile of resources, or stick with my plan to do something else?  Will that action come back round to me or not?  It also scales brilliantly from 2 to 5, which is a big reason it's been so easy to table.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Előre le kell szögeznem, hogy alapvetően a játék helyezése és elismertsége miatt szereztem be alapvetően. A téma különösebben nem vonz, ennek ellenére sokat vártam a játéktól.
Értem és megértem a körülötte levő nagy hype-ot, de mindent összevetve nem tudom maradéktalanul elfogadni az igen előkelő 2. helyezését.
Lehetne benne talán valamivel több konfrontációs lehetőség. Kissé talán a játékidő is hosszú, bár némi rutinnal azért ez a tűrhetőn belül marad. (Meg mondjuk előnye az is, hogy jól lehet mellette dumálni, nem kell végig koncentráltan figyelni.) A szabályfüzet az maga a borzalom! Szokásos módon autodidakta módon tanultam a játékmenetet, de jó pár munkaórát igénybe vett mindez + a netes videók segítségét is igénybe kellett vennem. A szabály kuszasága azért is problémás, mert később is nehezen kereshető a válasz 1-1 felmerült kérdésre...
Fura volt pl. a Caylus-szal szemben, hogy nincs az az eszeveszett nagy erőforrás hiány, ami miatt "beszorul" az ember. Egyszerűen olyan sok a lehetőség, a választható akciók annyi esélyt kínálnak, hogy a bőség zavarával küzd az ember. (Különösen problémás ez, ha egy kezdő ül le játszani).
Ugyanakkor igazán jó és üdvözlendő döntés, hogy magyarul is megjelent. Még egyszer: teljesen érthető a játék népszerűsége (amit elsősorban a témájának tudok be).
Nekem gémer játéknak nem volt igazán mély/átélhető, családi játéknak meg éppen, hogy túl bonyolultnak ill. túl hosszúnak érzem. Valamint a mellett se mennék el említés nélkül, hogy "mechanikailag" semmi újat nem mutat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I have a love/hate relationship with this game.  I know the idea is for resources to be scarce, but I find them TOO scarce for me to have fun.  I enjoy playing it setup for n+1 players (n = number of actual players).  I feel it allows us to feel like we did something instead of just barely surviving for another season.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
You play a mid-century rancher, running your own farm by sowing, ranching and family growth. It's a perfect Deutsch Boardgame, offering many paths for each player to choose, although family growth is the key of all, you should still make your own plan about feeding, buying and point-scoring. Hundreds of Minor Developments and Occupations make the game different every time you play it. Considering that some cards are enormously more powerful than others, the card-drafting may become a drawback against the game balance. But you can still remove some of the Breaking ones. I like this game very much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[color=#CC0000]

The peak of the strongly-controlled, highly-quantified, carefully-channeled breed of board games.  I'll be surprised to see one go significantly bigger or more complex than this.

This is a game where much of your destiny is kept under the thumbs of other players, while your thumb is firmly placed on top of theirs.  In Agricola there are a broad enough array of options that you don't feel as claustrophobic as you do in others of this genre, and I give it credit for that, at least on the easier decks.

Fundamentally though, Worker Placement titles such as this are disempowering and don't appeal to me because I feel that I'm taking actions to knock others, largely because there's nowhere left that would be beneficial for myself.  Positive options not available, I finish my move getting in someone else's way and have to take contentment in the concept of slowing others down as a form of advancing myself.

That's just not satisfying gaming for me.  I won't turn down the game if it's offered, but I would much prefer other games when craving a similar level of complexity.  Even something as esoteric as WoW: DoWWII with the full altitude rules is more satisfying.  It's as complex and intense as Agricola, but your decisions are fundamentally your own to do with as you please.  You're not stuck in a "choose the best of the junk that's left" situation.  Dozens of other examples to choose from.

That's likely not going to be a well-respected opinion here on BGG, but that's the heart of my concept of interesting game play.  A game where the majority of your time is spent blocking others is not compelling for me.  Alas, it's currently the darling of the industry, so I'm largely left playing older titles.

[/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like the fact that there are different levels of complexity. I have introduced both my mother and girlfriend to the family version, and both got into it. I am already getting a little tired of the simpler game, but I like the fact that it is possible to introduce a new player with the slimmed down rules to make entry into the full game easier. The theme might seem a bit surreal at first for a wargamer like me (build up a farm? I'd rather storm through Eastern Europe thank you very much!), but the actions and the cards really did remind me of what I had read about the development of farming when I had to study Social and Economic History at BA level; therefore, I did feel it was a genuine kind of historical simulation. Moreover, I felt the mechanics fit the theme well. A further plus point is the fact that you can play solo.

RATING: 8
I really do enjoy this game. It scaffolds perfectly, allowing a relatively new group of people to board gaming to come in at a level that isn't intimidating, and builds up rule by rule until you have mastery. I play this regularly with my family (non-gamers) at our local Starbucks and happily field questions from passerby. It looks gorgeous, and plays great.

I would suggest working through the deck though. Some card combinations are downright too good, and a handful of the occupations are particularly strong. I would suggest removing them from the deck (like we did) or drafting hands (like we do).

RATING: 1
I've never been waterboarded but I imagine the experience is comparable to Agricola.

The process of partaking in this game was so prolonged I was convinced the clock was going backwards.

It later turned out that due to daylight savings the clock had gone backwards, but the point still stands due to my growing fear that I was stuck in a sort of time loop of which I couldn't escape, and I would be stuck in a purgatory in which I would be forever damned to play Agricola.

I think the earliest clue that the game was not for me was whilst reading the instructions I got a call from family informing me that my Grandparents had died in some freak accident on their farm in the valley.

I bring this review to you from the funeral service. I actually thing I'm having more fun here.

RATING: 10
I've played this so much, it's insane. Juicy decisions, solid setting, and a look that I like. The cards are one of the best design elements ever made in a game of this type. It ensures that the game will be different every time. There is an absurd sense of satisfaction at the end of the game when you look at your farm, even if you lost badly. 

I'm somewhere about 50 plays, and the decisions are still challenging for me, the gameplay is still rewarding, and the card combos are still fun to find. It's never gotten obvious, and I think it'll stay with me for years to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game may feel cruel to newcomers, and still feels like a "serious" euro game to the experienced.  It's very satisfying once you get things up and running; I love the spatial element in which you actually lay out your farm on your board, rather than having it all abstracted.

I have mixed feelings about being dealt the cards at the start of the game and having to build your strategy around them (I haven't yet tried drafting the cards), but they definitely add a lot of replayability.

It's hard to say whether I prefer this over Caverna.  Caverna feels much more open, while the cards in Agricola make it seem deeper.  Both have their strengths, and I think they are just different enough not to step on each other's toes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I bought it when it came out, based on the hype, and was sadly disappointed. 

My biggest issue is that it feels like you're constantly losing and fighting the game itself every step of the way. You never have enough time to do anywhere near everything you want, and the clock keeps getting more and more aggressive. The winner is the person who manages to lose the least, and it really sucks all the fun out of the exercise.

Furthermore, I think it takes way too long for the sort of game it is.  If I'm going to spend over three hours on a game, I want to have conquered some empires or raised a civilization or something meaningful, as opposed to barely avoiding starvation while scratching a living out of the dirt. In that respect, I guess, it's actually a pretty good simulation of the soul-crushing daily grind of being a peasant during the dark ages.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
An advanced worker placement game with a lot going on...

Every player gets his personal board to build a farm on. To take actions you have to place your workers on a free common space in the middle. Take Ressources, take actions to build houses, stables, ovens, grow food, get new workers...

Although many people consider this a great game, I am not one of them. I payed it several times but just do not enjoy it. One reason is the lack of player interaction which is non-existing (you can as well play this solo without losing anything...).
The other factor is the limited options on how to play the game - I have to explain this, right? Although you get a ton of options (often to much to get moving) and each player gets 14 different cards each game (the best part of it all) you will always have the same story told. This is partially due to the scoring mechanisms at the end which forces you to do everything to be effective -> the result: your options and strategies do not matter and every farm looks alike at the end. This sounds a bit harsh but it really kills the game for me.
My summary: Other games do it better; this is NOT for me but many do enjoy it...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun game with a real sense of satisfaction at the end as you look down at your (hopefully) thriving farm. The game-play is really enjoyable, and I will agree the game deserves a high ranking, but, I can see a few things I don't like about it. 

Played competitively some cards (or, more often, combos of cards) basically gift a player a victory, and it's difficult to block cards from being played as you've no idea what's out there. The game is unforgiving, too, with players who fall behind unable to catch up (especially in the family-growth stakes) as actions allow further actions and the game's ever increasing pace means if you've not got a food engine up by the mid-game you're probably in trouble, and then have to sit through half-a-game struggling whilst others get their stone houses and nice tools. 

Hence, the game suffers when you play it with inexperienced or unskilled players as you're romping home to victory, whilst they can't see how to get things sorted. 

Physically, the game's beyond reproach: The components are both of sufficient quality and (very) plentiful, and the art is nice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Tremendous game. A lot of Euros do not have much theme. But by the end of this game you will feel you have built a farm. Excellent replay value with the many different cards offering lots of various strategies. Very little luck and requires a lot of critical thinking, tactics, and strategy. It has a permanent spot in my collection and I evaluate all new purchases of similar games by this one to see if they are worth getting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
 

The classic! When I first bought it I was excited enough that I played 15 solo games, in preparation for playing with other people. It took me a long time before I matched that total in multiplayer games.

Love the crushing despair, that's what I'm here for. Well, that and the card combo-ing.

I never liked the individual hand of cards, though. Too long, too solitary, too much being able to crush with lucky card combos. My current preference is to lay out a 14 card communal hand of 7 occupations and 7 minor improvements. All are played as if they were in hand, replaced at end of turn...with this option, Caverna becomes redundant. This has the advantage also of being easier to teach, as all cards are visible to be talked about.

It has a whole lot more messing with other people, though, which is hard for some. I think more interaction is almost always good, myself. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played three times with the basic card set.
Similar to Caylus in that the possibilities of what to do can be overwhelming for the first game.

Will want to try again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
One of the most overrated games in the whole BGG, in my opinion: once you have the rules down, and some plays under your belt, it appears clear how there's only one strategy to win: the more your family grows, the more actions you have, the easier is to score a victory. Hence, games are developed in the very same way, doing more or less the same actions over and over and over. Additionally, there's a huge load of cards, but they actually enter play very rarely and very few at a time, giving the idea of a huge potential completely wasted.

Fortunately some of this is fixed by Farmers of the Moor, but really, not a game we play that much any longer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My favorite worker placement game and one the first difficult games I played. It sometimes feels like Uwe Rosenberg is chasing the success of Agricola and his successive worker placement games (such as Caverna and Feast for Odin) feel messier and not quite as fun or satisfying to do well at. There's something to say for a game that challenges the player and lets them fail. Caverna and Odin are friendlier games, and in my opinion are worse for it.

RATING: 8
Hat jedes Quäntchen Hype verdient. Obwohl Thema und Mechanik zunächst nach wenig anmuten, macht Agricola jedes Mal einen Heidenspaß. Das liegt einerseits daran, dass das Prinzip "Viele Möglichkeit, nur wenige Aktionen" zu sehr schwierigen Entscheidungen führt – "Nehme ich mir schonmal das Schilf oder pflüge ich doch erst mal den dringend notwendigen Acker?" –, andererseits auch an den in enormer Zahl vorhandenen Beschäftigungs- und Anschaffungskarten, die für viel Abwechslung sorgen.

Punktabzug gibt es allerdings für das Punktezählsystem, dessen Sinn sich mir noch immer nicht erschließt. Jede Farm verkommt in den letzten Spielrunden zum Einheitsbrei, weil ja alles zumindest in geringer Anzahl vorhanden sein muss.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Discovered it very late, as I was sure I would not like it because of the theme and supposedly little interaction. Little did I expect that it would become one of the games I hold in highest esteem. It's intense, requires both careful planning of your own actions and foretelling what other players are likely to do, and the results are usually - between people with similar skill - very close and reapetable. The only things I don't like about it is lack of Caylus-style order and a small luck factor of good card draw, but at least the latter can be mitigated by a draft.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I never really get why so many people are down on farming as a theme - did they not have toy tractors and an assortment of plastic animals in different scales as a kid? Playing with little wooden sheep and cows appeals to something on a very fundamental level. With the different modes of play (which can cover the range from light, family fun to an intense strategic & tactical challenge) and the vast number of optional decks of cards, there is a ridiculous amount of game in this box. 

At somewhere over a hundred plays, I'm not by any means burned out on the game, but enjoy it as an occasional indulgence rather than a weekly entertainment. That's a decent amount of play for one game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An amazing design -- taking the best of Caylus & Puerto Rico, plus an enormous selection of cards that ensures no single set of tactics will "solve" the game.

Much better than both mentioned games -- if that means it is ranked #1, so be it.  

Scales great, but seems to require a trial game for newbies to really get the hang of it.

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
Good options. All players are encouraged through the scoring to compete for all types of goods and actions. This means there's much more player interaction than I thought there would be. It seems the trick is to not compete at the same stage of the game - difficult as cards only come out at set stages. Fantastic replay value with the cards, but scoring goals are always the same and let it down slightly.

RATING: 7
It is not a bad worker placement type of game, but not as good to justify the hype around it.  I can't imagine who could prefer this game over [i][url=http://www.juegosdemesacr.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=142&Itemid=1]Caylus[/url][/i], that uses the same concept in a more strategical and tense way, in part because the improvements are determined by the players and not preset by the game.  The scoring system is complicated and unintuitive, not like in [i]Caylus[/i], and the luck of the draw could be a factor that brings unbalance to the game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
When first read, the game appears to be a Caylus knock-off, particuarly given the worker placement.  After playing, however, the game feels quite different.  The Occupation & Improvement cards change strategy from game to game as players customize their farm to maximize their card utilization.  Whereas Caylus relies more on variablity in player strategy, this game relies on card management.  The balance of farm growth versus using the farm to feed your family is what creates the most tension, and this mechanic is a welcome addition to any game.

The solo version is also excellent, and bests Arkham Horror in terms of truly feeling like a puzzle, rather than an excercise in dice rolling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A full review is coming, but I really like the game and the way it plays differently, with different decisions, based on the number of players.  

Is it a 10?  I'm not too sure anything is, but it's pretty close.

2/17 - Seems to have settled on a solid 9.25.  And beats out Caverna after all.

RATING: 9
Nos, nagy remenyekkel indultam neki a jateknak. Elore leszogezem, hogy az elso jatek elmenyet nagyban gyengitette a nemet szovegu kartyak, annak ellenere, hogy a tulajdonos keszult es a magyar nyelvu generalo programmal kinyomtatott mindenkinek egy szettet, de ugye a kartyakon ennek ellenere nemet nyelvu szovegek voltak, egyszer sikeresen mast kartyat fejlesztettem ki (ugye aki jatszott mar vele, tudja mennyire atfontoltan kell kivalasztani a cselekedetet, mert egy rossz dontes komoly kovetkezmenyekkel jarhat azaz egy kicsit stresszes jatek) mint amit szerettem volna. A szabalymagyarazat alatt jelentosen elvesztem, egy kicsit a "Houston baj van" effektus hatalmasodott el rajtam es ez a jatek kozepeig meg is maradt. Egyszeruen atlathatatlan volt szamomra az egesz, a felenel abszolut minuszban ereztem magam es kezdett elmenni a kedvem a jatektol. Ezutan azonban megvaltozott valami, feny gyult a fejemben (vagy csak siman az segitett, hogy levettem a napszemuvegem) es kezdtem megtalalni az osszefuggeseket. Egy nagyon jo lepesnek koszonhetoen (jatek kozepen kb) meg is nyertem az elso jatekomat, de ez egyben el is bizonytalanitott. Ennyi eleg is a gyozelemhez, ennyire nem szabad hibazni, ezt csak a kovetkezo partik tudjak megvalaszolni de ezeket csak es kizarolag angol nyelvu kartyakkal vagyok hajlando lejatszani, mert ezt az "ez mi iiiiis?" kerdesekkel teli partit mar kezdtem egy kicsit unni ilyen szempontbol. Ennek koszonhetoen a parti 5 szemellyel kozel 4 orasra sikeredett, ami tulajdonkeppen nem zavar hiszen jol ereztem magam kozben. Erdekel az 1 szemelyes jatekmod, hogy mukodhet. Meglatjuk mit hozo a jovo a kapcsolatunkban.
Update1: A jatek angolul beszelve mar egesz jatszhato volt, a pontszam kuszott felfele.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is the LAST time I cave in to BGG hype!  My rating might go up over time after I "get it" but after a number of plays I'm not impressed.  I'm really starting to hate this trend of games with little to no direct player interaction.  After playing this, I crave games like Age of Steam or Steam with auctioning so I can feel like I earned a hard fought win.  I could care less if I win this game.  I need a tornado card to take out one of your pig pens.  I need to be worried that you might get a thief occupation card that allows you to steal some of my stuff.  How about an earthquake card the levels part of everybody's houses?  What I get here is a cute, little, pastel play mat, to build my farm on, and if I'm lucky my opponents will take an action I need.  On the other hand, this feels like a nice activity to kill some time with my wife while building a point generating engine with vegetables and animals.

RATING: 8
A really solid resource management/building game. Excellent "starvation to riches" feel and good pacing, with an equally tasty early game, mid game and late game. A lot of fretting about how best to place your guys to get ahead or block your opponents. Among players of equal skill, the winner is usually whoever gets the luckiest hand of professions and small improvements.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ok it is worth noting that my play time with this game is very LIGHT (all using E deck) but I am totally addicted to it already!!!  The first game was 5 player and 4 of us were new... it is a very complex game so it was slow going at first.  We have since played several games using two players each (for a 4 player game)and I can say that each game has been unique.  With 3 more decks we haven't even tried there are lots of things to learn.  The strengths are that it is a very beautiful game with many different decks to use...I did however find the bits  complicated at first and kept confussing them because there are just so many of them and so many details to the game!  As you play it a few times you begin to recognize the cards and can put things together easier....BUT if you are the type of person who likes to get everything done this is not the game for you because you will want/need to do 10 things each turn but are either blocked by another player's choices...or run out of turns in that round before you get it all done. It will leave you wanting to come back again and again...

RATING: 8
I enjoy this game and the art of make the best choice with what you have available.  I have mixed feelings about the cards that add variety while sometimes upsetting the balance of the game.  There are times where the right combination of them heavily skews the victory of a game that can be long.  The card translations leave a lot of gray areas especially when they interact with each other.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Never played. Can't seem to absorb the rulebook. Could it be written more confusingly?

UPDATE: Played half a game, not quite enough for it to sink in but enough to play it solitaire until it sinks in. Having an explainer is the only way to learn this game -- well, unless someone has written a better set of rules.

UPDATE May-16-2011: Played a full five player game. It's okay. There's a lot you want to do and little you get to do. I think the game could be laid out better. There are too many words all over the place and they're not the best chosen. For five players, somebody is going to have a hard time seeing the major improvements (that person was me). I wish the little rules appeared on a help card, like one type of animal per pen, one offspring per animal pair, the steps of harvest are ..., etc. There are a lot of things to juggle in this game, and you can only begin to strategize after you grok all the rules and the scoring. This game is stressful. OTOH, I can see why some people love it.

UPDATE Jun-12-2011: Got rid of my copy. This isn't to say I won't play again, but if I'm going to play it's probably going to be with friends who have their own copies with all the special meeples and containers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There is almost no luck in this entire game.  Whoever comes up with the best strategy and flexes with the circumstances created by the other players will win.

This is a deep thoughtful game.  It is very rewarding.  

The theme (farming) did not excite me, but I do have to say that it is extremely well done.  The components are great.

Tons of replayability, but its one that i only play once in a while because it is a mental challenge.  This is not a game that you start setting up for a replay as soon as you finish.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played A LOT of games and I can tell you that I have never encountered a game that gives me as much enjoyment (and drives me as crazy) as AGRICOLA. I think it is the fact that this is a "building" game and not a "building and running" game that does it for me. If this game had two more rounds, I wouldn't enjoy it nearly as much. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a tough call.  It's a very good game indeed, but perhaps a little too long for what it is - ironically, the very unstructured nature of the game means that it is unlikely to speed up to a great extent.  And yet, even with the ridiculous multiplicity of pieces and cards, it all works.

edit: no, it hasn't got any faster.  And it's still far too fiddly.  And the repetitiveness is starting to show through.  But none of that is a deal-breaker.

edit2: it is a deal-breaker now.  I wouldn't turn the game down if offered the chance to play, but I won't actively nominate it now.  And weirdly, playing it with fast players makes it worse, not better.  (Hmmm.  There must be a geeklist about that.)

edit3: rare example of my rerating a game based on another game!  I have now played Le Havre enough to see that this is the superior game, despite all the flaws I see with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
While Agricola has some good ideas, there are a few things that really hold it back for me, and prevent me from liking the game.

1: There aren't enough good action spaces. Of all of the action spaces I want to go to, I will get to go to at most 1 of them.

2: It takes too much effort to generate food. You should be able to eat animals without building a special card for it.

3: The scoring forces you to get a little bit of everything, and gives you very little for specializing.

4: Workers are too valuable because they are the most efficient way to get points, and the action advantage you get is too important.

5: Many of the cards feel weak.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
FUN ★★★★✰
Very good first impression. It looks there are many choices of actions. Moving fields,goods and cattle around is fun. Quite a good interaction with other players as well. Setup takes some time though. Interaction with the other players is quite limited though.

RULES ★★✰✰✰
I've never seen so poorly written rules (as I remember). Concepts are used in the rulebook without having been explained. Very messy way of presenting how to play.

IMMERSION ★★★✰✰
Feed the family and keep resources to invest for the future. It gives a feeling of how it is/was hard for farmers to manage their business. It's sort of family game, therefore don't expect to remember events during the play as it can be the case with some geek games. 

DEPTH ★★★✰✰
There is not a huge depth in this game, but I can imagine that I won't refuse a quick play from time to time (around 30' per player).

RATING: 8
There's simply no way to sum up my experience with this game in short order. It's complicated. I love this game and I hate this game. It's a blast - a brutal, brutal blast.

I will say one specific thing about the Occupations in this game - they vary too much in power level. Most suck. I hate drafting a bunch of duds. And it feels no better to play a game-warping occupation that hands you the game. (Improvements, on the other hand, are fantastic - they usually don't alter the whole game, but just help you optimize.)

RATING: 9

Oh, and science MUST be able to provide us with a good solution to setup/teardown with this game.  Get on it, scientists.  I'll see how well this ages with time, of course, but in general I'm quite fond of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Action Choice Drafting with many action choices, complex scoring and great scalability with number of players. 

Solid game, but nothing "wow" in design. Seems like the only big defining thing of the game is that there are a lot of things you need to do, and lots of text-heavy cards, and you don't have enough actions to do everything, so you have to choose and balance trade-offs. Other games have this too, just not taken to such an extreme. But I'd want to have this game if stranded on a desert island with 3-4 other gamers, since the cards give unlimited, if contrived, replay value. Solid and infinitely replayable but nothing particularly special.

I don't understand wtf is so awesome about the cards. They infuse a huge dose of luck into the game, especially since you can't deduce what other people have due to the sheer volume of cards. This game's use of cards is the exact way I hate cards are used for board games (for unnecessary complexity, increasing luck and rewarding experience, and allowing for cheap, no-effort expansions). 

Perfect the Family Game (without the cards), which stands up to less than 10 plays (exposing the shallowness of this game), instead of including a ton of cards in the base game and passing it off as an essential part of the game when it really is 3 expansions already packaged in.

I would have preferred it if the design was such that 14 random cards were laid out every game in some common pool, and you could use the Occupation or Minor Improvement action space to draft one of the cards from the pool and play it, after paying its costs. I prefer this pseudo-Family Game version, because the hidden information with the cards just disrupts the well-themed elegance of this game.

Drafting the cards isn't bad either though. It's a good excuse to read cards before the game so I don't have to keep referring back to them during the game.

2+4

RATING: 8
I've found that I really enjoy this game and continue to want to play, actually seeking out additional opportunities to play, which is not a particularly common occurence anymore.  I'm still undecided on the cards, though I do think they add a lot to the game--good or bad is the question.  I imagine that it will be a while before that is firmly decided in my mind.  The animeeples are neat and add more to the game than I would have expected, though not enough for me to deck out my own copy with them.  Overall, the design makes me think that it is something that Knizia would come up with--way too much that you want to do and not nearly enough actions to get it all done.  I suppose that could be pretty high praise depending on your point of view.  The choices are deliciously agonizing.  As an added benefit, I can play this with my kids as well as gamers.  An excellent product. [10/29/2008]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun game with lots of options and micromanagement. Multiple paths to victory which is excellent. Love seeing my farm expand throughout the game.

Unfortunately the random draw for minor improvements and occupations pretty much decides who will win the game based on who gets the best cards and whether they combo well together. We have somewhat 'fixed' this by playing a variant where they are chosen in a take one and pass manner (similar to 7 wonders) so everyone has a more even hand.

RATING: 8
There's  a lot of good things that can be said about this game. This is a thematic Euro that eases you well into the life of a farmer. Lots to do, but thanks to the game's superb interface, it's very easy to teach and play. Cards add a lot to the game, theme, and replayability. It scales perfectly due to the game "changing" for different number of players.

There is truly a lot of game out of the box. Any aspiring Eurogamer can't go wrong by this game.

Received April 2013.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Now having played this game numerous times, I find it a bit odd that it's #1 on the Geek.  I really really like this game, but it's fiddly and sometimes frustrating.  I wouldn't expect it to be so popular.  But it's wonderfully challenging, scales amazingly well from 1-5 players (although the 5 player game does take a while), and the variety of paths to victory is fantastic.  Each game will be different due to the order of "actions" that come up, and the vast array of cards (occupations and small improvements) included.  As you play it, you marvel at the design:  so much game in this box!  It's too early for me to tell whether Agricola will endure as a personal favorite, but right now I find myself thinking about it more than I care to admit.

Downgrading this to an 8 (from 8.5) solely because I NEVER get it to the table.  Just a bit too heavy to teach to newcomers.  I really like it and hope I can train a group up on it one day to get the most out of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fine game that is surprisingly hard to play well. I didn't like how that diversity in the different ways to earn points leads to only a couple of valid strategies, leading to there always being competition in a 3 player game for one field, meaning that the third player who did another strategy can just take the game. The cards add variation but also imbalance. I wish they could seed this game like dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The strength difference of the initial cards each player starts with can make it impossible for some players to win in a competitive game.  The other big issue I have with this game is the way turn order does not change unless someone takes the action to change it.  Still a great game but a few small rules changes would have made this nearly perfect.

For me, Caverna pretty much fires Agricola.  I do like the randomization that Agricola has due to the card drafting, but I prefer playing Caverna far more.

RATING: 3

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Hard one to rate. So let's try. 

Backstory 1: Had a copy of this one borrowed for years (3, 4? lost count) as original owner found it too complicated and gave up. After playing Le Havre (rating 3) I wasn't very enthusiastic about it either. But playing a couple of "boring euros" for informative reasons I finally caved in. It was a promise of 3 player game of starting to casual skill that convinced me. 

And I was actually pleasantly surprised. Compared to Le Havre I enjoy this game much more: 1) It's shorter. 2) It's much more thematic. This is the main strength I see in it. It's the joy of running an engine and see your farm literally grow. It has a narrative I can embrace. 3) It has more focus - some say it's more confined than Le Havre, but this is a plus - I don't have to think about all the actions each and every turn as some actions I just have to make based on previous decision. Agricola actually gives me a better focus and easier to make lists of priorities whereas in Le Havre all options are equal, bland and boring. 

Problems of the game are threat of over thinking and optimisation. The fact that the game has limited number of turns has it's good sides (doesn't take that long to play) and serious down side: it's potentially calculable and prone to optimisation exercises. And that's why I can't give it a higher rating - I will definitely avoid playing it with certain players who analysed it to death. It's just not an aspect of gaming I care about - I will play this one for the story not for trying to win, the same as I play RFTG.

Backstory 2: Played it with GF and she hated it. One reason is that it's still too much thinking. For me I guess I do these processes so fast I have free space in my mind for narrative building. So I can optimise and calculate as long as it's not an end in its own, but serves a different goal (narrative building). But the most important reason she disliked the game is theme and harvest: [i]"we just paid the bills and you think I want to play a game where I worry like in real life if I can make it through the month?!"[/i] Yes, she likes fantasy themes, unrelated to real life much better. So I have to find other people interested in this, but not already too interested.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Una pasada el juego. Al primero que le doy un 10, Mejor en el modo avanzado.
Sin duda es al mejor juego que he jugado nunca.
Aunque la perfección no existe, este se acerca bastante.
Es como un Caylus o Pilares de la tierra, pero mucho mas divertido, mas intuitivo y con mas opciones... que se merienda a los otros dos, con todas las de la ley.
Y cuando te aburres de la versión familiar (que de por si, esta muy bien), tienes tropecientas cartas para jugar. Va a ser dificil aburrirse de este juego.
Encima hay variantes muy jugables (sobre todo la del Draft) y modo solitario que aún no me ha dado tiempo a probarlo.
Está en perfecto Español.
¿QUe mas se le puede pedir a un juego?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played two 4P and two 5P games. Agricola is a surprisingly thematic worker placement game, but its strength does not lie in its worker placement mechanism. The various occupations and minor improvements that players receive at the start are really what makes Agricola unique. I also enjoy the gradual opening of slots as well. 

The main thing that I don't enjoy about Agricola is that you're basically doomed if you can't recognise the synergy of your cards early on. The game is not particularly forgiving if you realise that a combo doesn't work as planned, or if you try to change plans halfway through.

RATING: 7.5

The only reason I don't give it a higher mark is because it just doesn't make it to the table that often - perhaps because it feels a bit 'dry' compared to many, and we like to play a couple of games if we can rather than one long one. EDIT Now I've played Caverna I prefer the newer game. The stress of feeding in Agricola is much lighter in Caverna and as a result the game feels less dry, more fun, but still with the tension of someone beating you to your ideal spot...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[36 plays]  I've played 2 player, 3 player, and 5 player games all with the "E" decks. I've played one 4 player game with the "I" deck.

The first game seemed hard to learn from reading the rules, but was actually fairly easy once we got going.

This is a game that seems overwhelming in its options after the first game, almost as though it is simply offering too much. For me, that disappeared almost immediately in my second game. Now, although there are delightful moments of indecision and calculation, I don't find it complicated or overreaching at all.

This is a superb game. It seems like it will have endless variety and challenges and will scale very well from solitaire play on up to 5 players. I love the art. I like the card combinations, the tough choices, the jockeying for valuable actions, and the feeling of never being able to do as much as you can envision. I also agree with the reviewers that have commented on how much pride you take in the growth of your little farm.

Then 6/4/11 with Corey, John S, and Michael. I was reminded in this play how solid the base game is, and while I like the idea of the Moor expansion, I'm not sure it really added anything that wasn't taken away by the length of the added time in that previous play. I just love the base game, but I'll probably still give the Moor expansion some more chances.

Most recent plays Dec '15.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
#16 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2017)
#12 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2016)
#10 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

The 'Gric! Also dubbed Misery Farm by the haters- a term I have adopted using but in a loving fashion! This game offers tough decisions and great replayability due to the occupation and minor improvement cards. I don't ever feel like I've fully accomplished what I want to do before the game is suddenly over. And there is the constant struggle to feed your people. Yet this game makes all of those things work in a satisfying way that always makes me want to play again. I really enjoyed playing through the solo series on the app. Until recently, I had not played this game in some time. I could sense it starting to lose some of my favor. But then I played again with a group of strangers at a board game meetup and was reminded that I freaking love this amazing game.

Acquired: November 2011 - Amazon

Competitive

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Got this pretty much only because it is near the top of my geekbuddy ratings as well as this other correlation tool (can't remember the url at the moment). Anyway, I asked Michelle what she thought, and she said, "Frustrating." As a fan of "all creatures," I have to say that it doesn't really feel much like the smaller game. 

This incites an astounding amount of AP in Michelle, so there is a lot of downtime for me. She also doesn't like that "too much to do, and not enough time" feeling that Agricola seems to inspire in everyone that plays it. Both of these factors, along with a sense that she doesn't understand how to optimize anything, add up to an experience that is more like (very frustrating) work rather than play. 

I can see why people like it, but it's definitely not for me. And even if it were, we'd need to get the downtime much lower for it to be enjoyable. We can't do that without rushing Michelle, which I don't want to do. We even tried the family game, and it didn't go any better. She didn't really play any faster, and it has the bonus of having almost zero variation play to play. While I doubt we are playing well (or even decently) yet, I don't see how there is enough in the family game to support more than 1 or 2 viable strategies. At least in the full games, the cards open up a lot of possibilities. 

Before I forget, I found out (a few months ago) that this is considered a highly thematic euro. I don't see it. Mechanically, it doesn't seem any more thematic than Stone Age. To me, the gold standard in thematic euros is Dungeon Petz, which is not only way (way) more thematic, but also more fun. Maybe that's what I always found snore-inducing about Agricola back when I first got into boardgames: so many fiddly psuedo-thematic rules for no payoff. 

Now that we've finished our 10 plays for the 10x10 challenge, I really don't see us ever playing it again. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2

RATING: 5.5
