RATING: 9.5
Well let's start with what we always hear about Agricola. "It's so punishing" "It makes you do everything I just wanna herd sheep" "You're basically just busting your ass to feed your family." All good points, but Agricola is not about WHAT you have to do, but HOW you do it. That's where the game takes shape and it's the occupations and minor improvements that help you dictate HOW you are going to build that complete farm. Yes the game is punishing, but that is not a flaw it is part of the genius of its design. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An extremely enjoyable and well designed "worker placement" optimization game with a variety of ways to win. The theme is surprisingly interesting and, unlike Puerto Rico, I never forget what it is. The cards add another layer of depth and variety, as well as some randomness. Yes, some of the cards are better than others, but there are several optional rules which will minimize the luck of the draw.

RATING: 9.8
A brilliant competitive foraging game. The scoring structure makes for a well defined end game goal space. Variability comes from two sources: 1) The timing of when certain resources & opportunities gets introduced into the game differs from game to game, but in a very constrained manner. 2) The hand of cards provides each player some foraging advantages - but only in subtle ways.

RATING: 9
I tried to ignore the hype, but this game honestly looked like a lot of fun.  Once Pozy had this available, I had to bite.

It has the worker placement mechanic of some of my other favorite games, but the cards make me rethink strategy every game, which is a fresh change.  A few misprints on the rules and cards make me want to "dock a few points" but this game is just too good to care.

...and count me in as a person who could care less about animeeples.  That the cubes match the pictures on the cards helps with identification and learning.

Final Update: okay, it's a solid 9, no more, no less. Haven't played it in a while and need to.

RATING: 10
3,4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.08236
Overrated.

It reminds me of Stone Age without the dice with a bit of something like Pillars of Earth thrown in.  I've only played the most basic of game versions so far.  

The Good: Lots of decisions.  I didn't exactly have a BAD time playing the game.

The Bad: All the decisions could lead to some analysis paralysis for some players.  However, there really didn't seem to be very many "interesting" decisions in the introductory game.  What type of fireplace do you want to build?  Boring...  The game has developed a craze, and I just don't usually like to play Eurogames that have that much mania behind them.  Like Stone Age, I didn't see any raiding party variant, so in many ways it's just another version of multi-player solitaire with no confrontation.  This is what everyone has been waiting a year to play?!  I don't see the hype, yet... 

The Ugly: God, what a depressing theme!  Farming and feeding people.  The plague rats from Notre Dame were more exciting and fun...  The production artwork looked good, but the wooden pieces of slightly different colors and threat of needing to replace the possible inferior animal tokens was LAME...  

UPDATE:  I guess it's not as lame as I thought, but it can quite tough for new players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Agricola is an amazing game. It was the first Euro game that was ever presented to me and since then I have played better, but this is still one of the best. I love everything about it, but it can take quite some time to play with several people and putting resources on the board in bigger games can be a pain. Other than that though Agricola is one of those great Euro games that will hold a special place in my heart forever.

RATING: 8.31
Can only speak to two-player experience. Heavier and thinkier than my wife and I often want (so many contingencies and permutations to calculate). That said, we love the long-term strategic planning based on the initial selection of occupation and improvement cards. Game play mechanisms seem complex at first (lots of bits), but operate smoothly. Mental processing power is really the only stumbling block here. Overall, an excellent game that I'm not always capable of playing.

RATING: 9
Anna
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tema interesante con un desarrollo desafiante. Juego casi sin azar con mecánicas enrevesadas aunque bien ajustadas. Muchos detalles importantes y muchos objetivos a lograr, improbables de conseguir todos. Por ello transmite cierta sensación de suspense o de agobio según el parecer del jugador. Proclive al parálisis, especialmente con muchos jugadores.
Por todo ello prefiero la versión de reglas "familiar" con menos elementos. 

Las numerosas expansiones en mi opinión lo enredan todavía más.

Interesting argument with a challenging development. Almost no random and convoluted mechanics although well-adjusted. Many important details and many goals to achieve, unlikely to get all. Therefore conveys a sense of suspense or overwhelmed according to the opinion of the player. Prone to paralysis, especially with many players.
Therefore I prefer the "family" version of the rules with fewer elements.

The numerous expansions in my opinion even more entangled.

There's a sense of accomplishment when you're able to pull off a big combo that gets you a ton of food or points.  I often feel that I can step back and be proud of what I've built even when I haven't won.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[2010-09-06]
Építsd meg saját farmod. Vess, arass, nevelj különböző állatokat és bővítsd a dolgozó családodat. A téma és a jól kidolgozott játékmenet miatt nem lep meg a játék népszerűsége, de az első-második helyen való szereplése azért mindenképp kicsit túlzás szerintem. A családi változattal játszottam csak még, így nálam 7-est érdemel, de természetesen adok neki még esélyt a több pont elérésére.

[2011-06-06]
Megkapta a második esélyt. Igaz még mindig családi változat, de most sem érzem azt az átütő érzést, ami miatt a játék ott van a toplistán ahol. Egy jó játékról van szó, ami talán még azért kedvelhetnek mert egyáltalán nem lehet a másiknak keresztbe tenni. Mert még ha a legjobb lehetőséget el is happolják előled a sok másik közül biztos van még jó. 5 játékossal talán hosszúra nyúlhat egy-egy játék, hárman tökéletesen működött és időben is megfelelő volt. Egy jó játék az Agricola egy kellemes témával, de én egyáltalán nem érzem átütőnek, de a végső értékelést a profi változat után fogom levonni, addig is marad a pontszám.

[2011-09-26]
Megtörtént a profi változat kipróbálása. Nem emelek a pontszámon. Meglepő, de nagy változást reméltem, de igazából csak pár lap a különbség, ami persze még megnehezíti a játékot, mert a rengeteg lehetőség és a szűkös körszám miatt nagyon nehéz dönteni mit végezzenek az embereink. Jó játék az Agricola, de számomra nagyon frusztráló. Szívesen játszom még vele, aztán meglátjuk a pontszámot.

[2012-05-02]
A frusztráció megvan, de mégis emelnem kell a pontszámon, mert a második profi játék vele már nagyobb élményt adott. Tényleg sokat javítanak a kártyák a játékon. Nagyobb a variancia és fontos, hogy próbáljuk a stratégiánkat a lapokra kihegyezni, ezzel tudjuk ugyanis a legtöbb pontot szerezni a végén. Sokat jelent az is, hogy eddig minden társaságban működött és mindig mindenki élvezi a játékot vele.

RATING: 8
Worker placement games have been done to death in recent years. I'm sick of them. Agricola is one of the few in my opinion that are worth playing.

Wrapped in the seemingly innocuous theme of farming in medieval Europe, Agricola is a tense and exciting game. Beware of cheap imitations (including the [thing=102794]designer's own[/thing]!).

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[i]Building Your Farm and Competing Over Resources is Fun! Better with Fewer Players (faster + more competitive)[/i]

Will only play with 2-3 players.
 
this game still has something most similar games lack: real tension because the game is demanding and other players actions can truly screw you. The farming theme is cool and makes you feel like you're really doing something. It's fun to see the result of your labor at end of game.

and there's a lot more interaction in 2 or 3 player, because blocking becomes much more powerful. That combined with the shorter length makes 2 and 3 player my favorite ways to play. Why clog up the game with more players just to make the game worse and drag it out longer?

(4 Design + 3 Enjoyment)

Why Design Isn't Maxed Out: Mostly because of the cards, which probably aren't very balanced, are pretty fiddly in an otherwise elegant game, etc. Would probably fit better if they were publically drafted. 

Why Enjoyment Isn't Maxed Out: Usually I'd rather play something more exciting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A classic game that is absolutely worth playing, even if not among my very favorite euros.

RATING: 9
If there ever was a shining example of theme present in a Eurogame, this is it.  This is the best game representing animal husbandry out there.

Certainly, this is a great "too many things to do, not enough turns to do them" kind of game.  It has you in engaged.  

There is so much information to try to take in with this, though, that you may feel a little shell shocked.  

The starting hands can be a little unbalanced.  I would like to be able to trade in some of your cards, so that you could try to form a hand that might actually work with itself.

Something I'll be playing years from now.

RATING: 5
Why can't I win being a successful cattle rancher?  Why do I have to wait until later turns for different animals and advances in 16th century farming techniques?  

The game may offer you a lot of choices and it may seem to fit the theme, but the victory point spread, exclusivity of nearly all the actions, and penalties for non optimal play make me feel the game railroads me into building the exact same farm every damn game.

Bought the iPad version just to see if I'd like it more without having to juggle all the games bits and bobs, but it turns out I still don't care for it.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game is great.  There are many paths to victory, and the theme is fun.  It even works as a gateway game. Not in terms of being easy or light, but in terms of drawing people in to board gaming in general.

It loses points for the fact that you have little or no control over the fact that other players can totally ruin your day. And not necessarily on purpose, but because they also need the same thing you need, and turn order made all the difference.  So you lost because of turn order.

What I mean is, it is really hard to adopt a new strategy on the fly, to match the situation, because when other players block you, it hurts. Bad.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Agricola is a very complex game. The first time you play it, don't expect to get a high score. In my opinion Agricola never get's old. The game doesn't rely on luck, but on strategically choosing your angle on how to earn points. We've been playing it in my gaming group for a while, and have found it very fun to start each new game with an occupation played in our earlier game, so that each player starts out with a sort of strategy that they can either build on or ignore.

The base game is perfectly fine in it self and different every time, but if you really crave for a change in the game, I would recommend getting the "farmers of the moor" expansion before investing in additional card decks.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ahh yes, Agricola. . .easily as much buzz as Puerto Rico received when it was first released. I liked this game almost immediately. Spent a lot of initial time with it solo, which is good practice for when you get to multi-player with local group. Have yet to attain the first game solitaire goal of 50 points, though I'm making steady progress. Much easier to teach (and be taught) this game than to read rules to decipher. This game would get a higher rating if it got to the table a few more times, but generally speaking, people tend to roll their eyes when it's suggested. Everybody agrees that mechanically, artistically and replayably, that it's a great game, but it seems that the investment of time and energy to actually get it out onto a table and play the damn thing is too much to bear sometimes. Extrapolating from the WBC event report from 2008, about 30 people signed on for the tournament last year, and I'm guessing that once your head gets wrapped around the idea that you're actually going to sit down to play it, the enthusiasm and fun inherent in what it has to offer emerges. The problem (with local groups and family gatherings) seems to be that initial decision to select it. Too many games that don't burn as many brain cells to select from. It's just more of a grind than a lot of people choose to deal with at a game gathering.
Still like it, though, and continuing to want to improve at it enough to keep it in the forefront of games that I'd generally like to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Much better and infinitely more charming than its current competition for the "greatest of all Euros" title (Puerto Rico). Would really benefit from a meeple dispenser--all that wrangling of "3 wood here, 2 reeds there" gets on my nerves a bit. Some people hate the "feed your family" mechanic, but I really like it--it helps to narrow the range of possible strategies in a game that would otherwise be truly overwhelming.

RATING: 6
I think the "tremendous variability" touted by Agricolytes is overstated - everybody still scores victory points for the same things, and your cards dictate the order in which you hit those marks. It also seems like you whether you get a fistful of synergy or complete shit in your opening hand kinda determines how much fun you're going to have for the rest of the game. Either things'll play out smoothly or you're going to bust your ass making the best of a bad draw and lose anyway.

I still wouldn't turn down a game, but if we're set on a Euro, I wouldn't play it over Puerto Rico either.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played 5 players with the E deck last night and thought it was just excellent. Sooooooo much going on that its going to take a bunch of plays to wrap my head around. But this might be the ultimate engine builder that actually has an integrated theme! Who would have thought? Hats off to Mr. Rosenberg for presenting us with a winner.Yummy wooden bits, tons of cards with great artwork. Major Improvements, Minor Improvements, Occupations, Action cards, Beggars, Phase cards, the list goes on. Do you use a plough and sow strategy? Raise livestock? Grow your family quickly or over time? When do you upgrade to stone? The questions go on with no wrong answers.I know that the wealth of Occupation and Minor Improvement cards is frustrating for some, but I think it makes you have to adapt and change your strategy. Its a very maleable approach to gaming that had me at draft. All in all, its a gigantic effort and it just works.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An easy 10.  tight, several ways to win, phenominal replayability due to the obscene amount of cards - looks great, cool bits, highly pimpable (easy to upgrade the bits), and one of my favorite two player, as well as solo games. It has blown me away, and will for a long time. 

I'm struggling to find anything on the downside to say, but ill try: it is very puzzle-ish once you have it down. This means you will be analizing your board and thinking stuff like: "wait, now if i get three more wood, I can hold one more sheep and feed one more person, so I wont have to use my grain to bake bread, so I can plant it in my field instead, but ill need to get another field, which I can do if I play this card, but this card requires three more wood...wait." All part of the fun though! 

My other gripe depends completely on the gaming group. With my group, the game is amazing, but it can be played much more cut-throat than we do. For example, if someone is obviously getting ready to take some boar because they have made a sweet fenced pasture for them, someone else can just swoop in and take them, even if they have room for none of them - the boar can be taken and then set free. To me, mechanics like this just seem malicious, and change the game quite a bit, but as I said, if your group is not like this, it shouldn't be a problem. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game with constant pressure, both from the game design itself with a plethora of scoring criteria, and from the other players. I particularly like you have to immediatly perform the chosen action, instead of after all placements have been made like most other worker placement games. You are very limited in your number of actions and there really is a lot to do. There are a ton of different resources and a lot of planning is involved when managing these resources and actions. The hand management keeps this game replayable. Everybody basically needs the exact same things; the cards make sure everybody takes a different route to get to meet the scoring criteria.
It's a very complete game, with a family and an advanced game. Also, there are three different decks of cards making sure this game is even more replayable.
It's not all perfect though, set up and take down takes quite a while and the game lacks a proper storage tray. I had to buy some plastic boxes myself.
I've only played this as a 2-player game. I would love to play with more players, even if it just introduces some new occupations for 3+ games.

I've pimped my game with the wooden building resources and the wooden vegetables and grain resources from Lookout Games and the wooden food tokens from Boardgame Extras.

Owned expansion: Through the Seasons

A gift from my parents-in-law.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Better than Puerto Rico? Yes.  Worthy of the hype? Not quite.  It's a quality game, and I understand why so many people like it: the cards provide for great replayability plus they also inspire goals that you really desire to work toward.  There are many paths to victory, and the game is really tight, forcing you to choose from among many actions.  I do believe it has a bunch of depth and it's a quality release.  Still, it does lack quite a bit in player interaction and it is so tight through the first few rounds that it's pretty frustrating.  Also, there are so many choices that turns can drag on a while.  Bottom line is that this a deeper game that I enjoy playing, but it's not my favorite.  I am glad it knocked off Puerto Rico, though.

UPDATE: I'd say that there is a decent amount of player action, as there is contention in the actions you are able to take, but the lack of available actions and general tightness in the game adds just a little too much frustration to make for a delightfully fun game.  Nevertheless, it's an enjoyable challenge.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.1
The game is undoubtedly very pretty and very playable alas it simply does not provide the level of player interaction or strategy that many of its bedfellows do. It falls well short of both Caylus and Puerto Rico in terms of intensity - there are simply far too many roles available and you rarely feel as if your options are limited. Furthermore the random deal of character cards  is imbalanced, in the last game I played My wife was dealt a hand of characters that were considerably less useful than her opponents and as a result she struggled to get a foothold. I guess my primary complaint is that it feels as if you are playing solo throughout, you would be as well setting up five tables with five different players, the involvement of others really had little bearing on my game. Its nice but could/should be a whole lot better.

RATING: 9
Just beginning to scratch the surface of the cards. Card drafting reduces the luck factor, as certain card combos can be too powerful to be simply handed to a player by chance. The scarcity of resources seems perfectly appropriate to the theme, and a source of great tension. You cannot play this game on auto pilot and expect to do well. But most important of all, it's just real FUN to play, quirks and all.

RATING: 4
Wow, what an overrated game. I won't say I'll never play this again, but I find playing it to be a poor use of my time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Agricola is a good game with lots of tension, and it feels satisfying in the end, win or lose. Initially players barely eek out subsistence food production, but eventually farms generate surpluses, and just as things begin to come together, the game ends. It feels like a farming game in the best possible way. 

This is my favourite worker placement game because unlike so many others, every player's actions deeply impact everyone else. Other players' choices matter, and that's because everyone needs to do more or less the same thing. Shrewd tactical moves can and do win the game. I rarely find myself requesting to play Agricola, but I always enjoy myself when I do. I only wish setup and upkeep weren't so daunting. I'd play it much more often but for all the overhead.

So that's my defence of the game.  I could also say that Agricola has many things I don't like in games.  Worker placement, individual player boards, and scripted strategies are all here and they are all negatives.  Yet Agricola stubbornly remains a game I enjoy playing.  In an alternate universe it would be one of only a handful of games of its type.  In that world, I might not be so hostile to the genre Agricola represents.  I would simply play Agricola and I would be happy.  Alas, I do not live in that world.  But when I play Agricola, I imagine that I do, and I'm happy. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great game. Not the brain-burner Le Havre is, but definitely a modern classic in its own right. Extremely tense, satisfying experience with tons of cards and excellent components. Very replayable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We have the Z-man edition with animeeples and Z-deck! - We both like the replayability and variety given by the many cards. The main strategy appears to be making best use of the cards to maximise downstream generation of resources while minimising their cost. The interaction is great without being nasty in that you can easily adapt a strategy when a favoured action is taken by someone else. Good fun & that's the whole point.

RATING: 10
Despite a lot of opinion to the contrary I think Agricola is a fairly simple game.  The huge numbers of occupation and improvement cards can make things look much more complicated than they really are.

The game itself is a pretty straightforward worker placement game and the cards mentioned above really just add some spice and freshenss to what could become a repetitive format otherwise.  They do, however, ensure that the game changes enough with each play to remain enticing.

When I first got Agricola I played it so often that I got a bit sick of it.  But after a break of a year or so I have come back to it and enjoy it as much as ever.

RATING: 7
After second game:

Played with Doron, Guy, Nir and Hila.
I won with 40 pts with the Well, Water Fetcher, 4 people and stone house.
Nir got to 2nd place of 38 with his huge grain farms... Guy blasted with the BusinessMan that gives a free occupation and improvement, but did not score as well. Doron did not succeed this game at all.

Hard and smart game, need to play by the cards you are dealt with.

Very surprising that we played for 6 hours straight and it was tense and focused the whole time. You are very engaged when its not your turn because you need to see which actions other players are taking. When not, you are thinking hard about how to achieve your next goal in the strategy.

Its massively repayable as each game everyone have completely different set of 14 unique cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Right... so Agricola really should have been two separate releases: the family game, and the expansion.  I'd probably rate the former a 6 or a 7, and the latter an 8.5

As it stands, this is NOT a gateway game as so many seem to say.  It's too big, too unwieldly, too costly, and too varied.  The rulebook is pretty crap, with no pictures of how to actually lay out the board and get ready to play, something that non-euro-afficianados would find very offputting to say the least.

Having said all this... excellent, excellent game with tons of replayability.  It oozes theme, is a blast to play, and is a satisfying solitaire experience to boot.  Can't say it's my favourite game at this point, but it's in my top ten for now.

Edit:  Revised down to a solid 8.  Look, it's a good game, a fun game, well designed with a lot going on.  But it's definitely not a 10 or even a 9 for me.  Too much setup for too little pay off.  I guess maybe if I felt inclined to play it 4 or 5 times back to back, or had the space to leave it set up, maybe I'd feel a bit differently.  I doubt it.

Edit2 June 30th, 2009:  Revised down to a 6.  I am just not inclined to play Agricola anymore.  Again, too much setup for too little payoff, that holds true for sure.  But the gameplay itself is just lacking... the game gets interesting just as it ends, and there's a chance -- a good one in fact -- that the card draws can make for a tedious game for one player or, worse yet, many players.  At this point I feel quite strongly that Agricola is very overrated.  It is a grab bag of ideas that don't quite mesh together.

Edit3 Jan 26th, 2009:  I had upped it to a stable 6.5 months and months ago, forgot to make note of it here.  Can't see the 6.5 changing.  I enjoy it well enough, and it's the favourite games of one of my favourite gamers, so it hits the table more of often than *I* would choose, but meh, that's fine by me.  And I'm not sure where I got "oozes theme" from -- maybe it was the catchphrase of the day.  Really, the theme is there, but not particularly strong or anything, especially many of the cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Still fun to play, but I have a couple issues with the game.  Most importantly, amongst experienced players, it seems to boil down to who draws the most powerful improvement and occupation cards.  Also, less importantly, the scoring seems tacked on, where you are penalized if you don't have at least one of eveything on your farm.  Perhaps that's a nod to diversification, but really why does it matter if you specialize in herding sheep and don't have any wild boar?  I still enjoy playing it occasionally but I won't request it either.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I LOVE THIS GAME!  The only thing I'm worried about is my game group being a little off-put by the number of rules and amount of strategy involved with this game that they won't want to always play it like I do.

The best part is the randomization of the action order, occupations, and minor improvements and the amount to choose from.  This keeps the game from getting stale like many other worker placement games without as dynamic a setup.  The ever-changing combinations give this game an insane amount of replay value.

It is designed to scale from 2-5 players which keeps the game balanced and just as fun no matter the number of people playing.  And if you ever do manage to get bored with the base game there are several inexpensive expansion card decks (and a full-fledged expansion) to give it a shot in the arm.

The only criticism I would give it is that with the number of different moves and paths to victory across 14 rounds and variability of the games even experienced players can find themselves taking an overlong time planning out their strategy on their turn which can introduce quite a bit of down time and long games.  This comes hand in hand with any game with this much variety though and I'll always side with variety and replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
12/07/08
Played with 3 players, family version. I liked the game but I didn't find it superb or even more than just good +.

It didn't grab me that much but I do have to play the expanded version. Or maybe that's what I don't like the game - the millions of possibilities.

18/07/08
Played again with 4 players and the Minor and Occupation cards were used. This is one of those cases where I will have to learn so much more about the game before actually like it. It's not intuitive at all for me because it has no rules at all. Everything is a tweak in this game. Instead of the game having a tweak it is the tweak itself that has a game on it. Cards and more cards make it different everytime, and that's a bless for card lovers but not for me. It is a good game though and I would like it more in the future I'm sure of that.

19/07/08
Tried the solo variant. It's not very difficult to get the 50 points. It's challenging enough but not that difficult. I've rather found it a good way to start dealing with the cards and the best way to learn how to maximize your production. I think I can play this game 20 times before opening another deck!

19/07/08
Played with 3 players.
I know the game better and it makes me like it more because of that. I still think that Agricola needs lots of experience to be enjoyed properly. One of the great things about it is that it goes very well with the 3 fromats I've tried so far: 4, 3 and 1 player.

21/07/08
Played another solo game and changing my opinion about not being hard. The first time I played it alone I made a big mistake by feeding the family with only 2 food instead of three and that makes total difference between an easier game and a much more difficult and challenging one.

Been playing many games so far with 4 and especially 3 players. I think that one of the good things this game has is how to maximize your production with your cards. It's great to watch a bad hand turn into something good or acceptable. I don't think I will ever raise the rate of this game not because I don't like enough for that but because sometimes your cards are so bad that the most you can achieve comparing to others is a family style of game, without anything really helpful to do with them. This wasn't that bad if the other players had exactly the same amount of luck but if they don't it's very hard for me to compete with such a difference between hands.

Sumarizing I don't like the gap of luck that often occurs between players. It would be chalenging enough if playing the solo version but very frustrating when having to compete with others with plenty of luck and everything simplified or actually useful.

After more than 30 plays I still like to play it. I think it's very unbalanced but since it only takes about 70/90 minutes to play it's a good option.

RATING: 8
I have three copies.  What is wrong with me?  First copy is my German copy, slaved over with love.  The second copy is the mandatory English copy to help Zev out.  The third copy was an impulse Tanga purchase.  Planning on giving it away at a game con in March 2009.


After three plays with English text:  I love this game!  It seems like you could play this game the rest of your life and never play the same exact game twice.  Each decision is important.  

Lots of German text on card.  It's difficult to play if you don't speak German.  I had the English/German glossary and it doesn't really help you with all the words on there and some of the intricacies on the cards (like it can only be used once or twice or when someone else plays a card, etc.)

[update April '11] - At Edinburgh League of Gamers recently, I had a 5 player game of this with the Interactive deck - IT WAS BRILLIANT! RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My review

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/330615

Amazing - theme, tremendous depth and breadth, scalable by complexity and number of players, and Mrs Sorp likes it (family game). My only (minor) niggle is that the component quality (yes there are lots of them!)is not reflected in the price - after 6 plays 1 tile and 1 card showing wear and tear. The theme validates the complex options, encourages me to think about how i can make my family survive and prosper - the necessity to feed your family and expand your farm is compelling and something that everyone can relate to. 6 games in and i have only scraped the surface of Agricola. Uprated  after 5 player game at Swiggers - game just gets better and better. The best board game game i have played. The translations of the occupations is a second minor niggle.

I now have a major niggle - the game is so good i have less desire to play the rest of my collection.

I love the fact that it never seems to play the same way twice, that focusing too much on card synergies can result in ignoring the table and your opponents. 

49th and 50th games in quick succession after a 3 month Le Havre induced hiatus. Just as great as i remembered - seeing new things. Looking forward to my 100th play

80th play -seeing this as a path game with very minor diversions that get you one more, or one earlier. But in  Not sure if this is genius or I should find it monotonous. It still creates a fear of feeding and failure.

RATING: 10
Rosenberg takes a giant leap in game design, congratulations!  Excellent building game with just the right amount of interaction.  The building is satisfying, the choices are good, you'll never be able to do all you want but it's okay.  A few of the cards seem a little unbalanced, but that's very minor.  It feels in spirit closer to Roads & Boats than to anything else I know, but the mechanics are nothing like Roads & Boats.  Very engrossing game.

RATING: 4
I have just played this twice with two players, but so far I'm underwhelmed. First play was family version, and the second was the normal game but with only basic cards.

I know I focused way too much on Occupations and Minor Improvements in the second game, and I realise that those can be really powerful if played at a better chosen time, instead of just "as many as possible", but I still had the feeling that they didn't add that much to the game.

The game actually feels very light to me, which was surprising, given people's general flaunting of it as a "heavy euro". It feels to me like I can get the same amount, or more, of strategic thinking with a lot less setup time from other games, and with the same amount of setup, Trickerion will give me way more strategy…

Privé (D)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
This is kinda cute, and somewhat interesting. But number 1? It's a math game...about farming. Very odd.

Family game works fine, I have no problem with it compared to the card driven normal game. When you know everyones options it actually becomes more cut-throat, so it feels like the family game opens for more screwage than otherwise!

The rule book is horrible for learning the game. Ugh! Bad bad designers. Where is the layout explained? Anyway, after getting through the first game you find that this actually plays quickly, but is prone to AP. So if you have an AP-prone player, don't play this with them.

I don't think this is solitaire. I plan all my moves depending on what the others will and want to do. It might become more like solitaire with the cards, as more options are viable to more people, but I have to play more to judge this properly.

I will probably never suggest this with my regular gaming group, there just are better games that interest us more. I will play this with my SO, and try to sell it to a few other non-regular gamers that we meet up with.

UPDATE:

8 games played. Rating lowered from 6 to 5. Nothing has changed, it's a math game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm a bit conflicted on this one. On the one hand, I really enjoy playing this and look forward to explore all the different decks (I've only played with the E-deck yet). But apart from the replayability because of the sheer number of cards, Agricola can hardly be called spectacular. Strip them away, and it's just a decent, probably even good worker placement tile. 
In the end, what saves Agricola is the experience it offers. You can get a lot of enjoyment from this game just trying to achieve your own goals, without worrying too much about your final score.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Nice storytelling, great game-concepts and a high replay-value. The huge number of cards to start with (you are randomly dealt 14 out of a few hundred unique cards) makes every game unique. It's rather difficult to keep an eye on your contrahent's plans and ressources, but that's not a flaw at all.

Very flexible - the game plays different with 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 players and works wonderful in every constellation. Even more - you can easily adjust the level of complexity and thus play the game with casual gamers. 

Definitely one of the best games I've ever played.

RATING: 8
Wow!  This is a very fulfilling game.  There is persistent turn angst throughout, as you want to either perform more actions than is possible, or your actions of choice are taken by your opponents.  You've got to constantly work out plans B and C throughout the game.  I feel pretty good when I finally accomplish the task of getting certain occupation cards onto the table, but you cannot make this your sole focus else you will most likely miss scoring points in several areas.  This game is all about the journey; enjoy the ride!

RATING: 7.5
Fantastically fiddly farming fun. Agricola overwhelms players who worry too much about considering every angle. It delights in spoiling plans and forcing unexpected choices. It is filled with more options than you could ever hope to sample. The sheer number of choices and components might cause some to shy away but if you play through to the end you can look back and realize there was some decided strategy and certain choices that defined your outcome. And it's fun to make a little farm out of all those pieces.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's one of my favorites, and the replay-ability is very high due to the random occupations and minor improvements you get each game.  Since occupations and minor improvements are so important, we just started using the mulligan rule where before we start you can trade your 7 starting cards in for 6 new ones, and then if you want trade those 6 in for 5 new ones, etc - this has worked out very well and keeps the game from sucking if someone gets cards that they dont think they can use.
I'd say the game is mildly interactive, the main interaction being the shared resources in the middle, but usually everyone can get what they want so it plays very socially.  I like this game best with 3 players.  We played with 5 once and it was awfully slow.  Playing with 4 is neat to see the 4-player occupations though.
This game has been getting less play time lately I think due to the amount of pieces we have to deal with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
At first play, I was underwhelmed by this game. After seeing numerous board game reviewers tout this game as a top worker placement, I was excited to give it a try.  However, I felt like there were a lot of options for development that were out of reach because I was constantly under threat of not having enough food for the harvest.  As a result, gathering enough food for my workers was always more of a priority over expanding or developing the farmhouse, adding to the family, or using the hand of 14 cards (only two of which actually ended up being used).  Not sure if it was due to inexperience resulting in not optimizing resources, but I expected my farm to become an engine to help me get further in the game, but never felt like it did.  I won 25-17, but not sure I would come back to this game.  I guess my problem with this game is that unlike other worker-placement games, it never felt like I had interesting placement choices to make; there was always something that I absolutely had to accomplish each turn, so placement was a foregone conclusion, as long as I wasn't blocked by the other players.

RATING: 9

2-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a relatively fun game hampered by an all-too frequent break by the cards.  If you have experienced players, it often happens that one player out 4 or 5 will get a poor draw for occupations and minor improvements.  This will not guarantee a loss because you can always alter your strategy, but you cannot win--at that point you're playing to not be last.  Similarly all too often one player will get a couple stellar combos in the occ/impr cards which, if played well is nearly impossible to beat.

A big part of this problem lies in the fact that the game has only a little direct player-interaction--almost always unintentional.  Intentionally trying to foil another's plans will typically hurt both players--because playing to slow another's progress means you're usually wasting an opportunity to pursue your own most advantageous route.

The game only truly shines when you get the rare situation when no single person is overly hurt nor helped by their cards, but rather everyone must work to find their winning strategy.

The game also has a fairly significant set up time (or take down time) to get all the cards and bits sorted out prior to play--a particular problem if you play with many different numbers of people since you use different card sets depending on how many people are playing.

All that said, though, it is a reasonably entertaining game due to the number of cards, and the fact that you see so few during any one game.  It also plays pretty quickly which is neat considering how much can be going on.

Truly I cannot believe how many people swoon over this one, but hey, as long as their enjoying it (and not making me play every week!).  Wanting to play it all the time, naah, personally I even took it off my want in trade list.

Lowering to a 6.  This is nothing more than a VERY simplistic game of engine-optimization with (thankfully) widely varied starting conditions.  Want to see how poor a game this is?  Play with the same cards for 3 games...yuck.  The cards keep it interesting enough that I will play with 4.  But I won't play with 2 or 3, and have to be convinced with 5.  I'm blown away with the fact that this remains at number 1.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rated as a solo and 2-player game.

There's just something very satisfying about creating your own self-sustaining farm, even if the animals do look suspiciously like cubes.

Tense decision-making, tight resource management, and multiple strategies, combined with the replayability inherent in the card decks make this a solid 9 for me. The only thing that keeps it from being a 10 is the lack of true win/loss conditions for the solo game. Counting up points at the end is a bit anticlimactic compared to, say, saving the world from disease. Still, it's the kind of game that makes me wake up in the middle of the night thinking, "THAT'S what I should have done!"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Very good game, playable in different levels...so eben with family its super!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like Agricola ok, but it feels like you are just filling in a spreadsheet for the most part. The special cards in your hand may help your decisions, but there really is only one ideal way to play them to score your highest. In other words there are two paths to victory, the one that nets you the most points, or the one that screws your neighbor out of points. I don't like games where your best option is to play sub-optimally in order to win. The game and components are also way too fiddly for what you get out of it. I'd rank it lower but during play it does allow you enough thought to keep it interesting, but it's not nearly as interesting as the BGG rating implies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Well look at that, I actually played the #1 game of all time (having never played "Puerto Rico")!  But I've only played it once (with the basic set of cards) so BE FOREWARNED: this is a "first impressions" rating.  "Agricola" very much falls within the "Euro-style" camp of board games, and at first glance doesn't seem to bring anything particularly revolutionary to the genre.  I do like that game play seems fairly open-ended with multiple paths that can be taken, yet the game doesn't allow you to pursue only one or two paths exclusively, and you definitely need to do a few things early in the game in order to make sure your family doesn't starve later (an aspect that reminded me of "In the Shadow of the Emperor", a game I didn't particularly enjoy).  So while the options SEEM to be plentiful, the optimal strategy (at least with the simple version of the game) might perhaps be more scripted than it first appears.  The game components are fairly nice, although the poor graphic design on some of the cards diminishes the ease with which information can be gathered at a glance, and those generic wooden cubes are fairly uninspiring (it's all about the animeeples baby!).  But all in all, I did enjoy playing this and would definitely try it again.  However, I'm realizing more and more that these "meatier" Euro-style games aren't really my cup of tea.  And one thing seems clear from all those Fimo farmers and animeeples: fans of Euro-style games secretly DO love chrome and want to be immersed in theme too!  Game design: 3/5  Personal enjoyment: 2.5/5  Total: 5.5/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have to rate this game a 10, simply for the many hours of quality gaming that it has offered me and for the potential to offer me loads more.

For me the main advantages are: 1) The subtle but very rich player interaction: the game will not actively push you towards this direction, but you cannot win without studying what your opponents are doing. Plus, whether you understand it or not, most of your moves will affect most of the other players as well. 2) The balance between the strategic and tactical elements: it is equally important to have a plan for the whole game and to make on-the-fly/opportunistic decisions that might not be serving your general plan. Be too heavy on the strategy OR on the tactics and you will lose. 3) Replayability: The set of cards that you are dealt/you draft, as well as the orientation of your opponents make each game different.

It is certainly not a game to socialize over, or to bond with friends through playing. Play Agricola if board gaming is the reason you met with your friends, not as a light "background enrichment" to your socializing. Most of the critique about this game comes from this fact - and it is reasonable if you are tricked into thinking that Agricola is something that it's not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've played it a 5-6 times, and always wish I was playing something else half way through.  The more I play it, the less I want to ever again.

RATING: 8.5
Played it twice so far, and I'm loving it.  For a game that is slightly longer than the average Euro, it sure flies by faster than any game I can think of.  It's the impending harvests and the fact that it is hard to get done even close to everything you want to do.  The game mechanics are far superior to any worker placement game I've played (Caylus, Pillars, Stone Age, AoE3, Tribune, etc.)  I really like that the game asks you to be good at everything, considering most other games seems to be about specializing.

And the cards!  Every game seems like it will be solidly different, giving this game much more replay value than most games of it's kind.  I'm really looking forward to many more plays, hence the current 10.

Down to 9.5 due to length.

RATING: 7.5
Generally play solo, or with 2. The solitaire game is great for determining the best way to use the cards available to you, but is overly predictable. Still a good min/maxing exercise if I'm looking for a brain exercise.

2 player is subject to a little bit of take-that to block the moves of the opponent if blocking their move yields a bigger differential than a move that's beneficial for you. Additionally, randomness of the improvements/occupations, and the balance of power between cards adds some luck to the game. May try to do drafting to make the game feel more controlled.

Have only played 1 game with 4, two of the players were new. One player had many cards which made fishing a very strong spot, but due to inexperience couldn't fully utilize it. The game seems to shine at 3+, and I look forward to playing more at those counts.

RATING: 7
I tend to miss the boat on the hot new games when they first come out, mostly because my game-playing opportunities are pretty sporadic, and I don't have a dedicated group of well-heeled people who buy everything as it comes out! So I tend to get exposed to the really popular games long after most other people. Thus, May 2010 was my first exposure to Agricola.

A few of the other players were experienced with the game, but there were a couple others will only a game or two under their belt, so I felt I wasn't at too much of a deficit.

I followed the rule explanation well enough, and was able to play along without making a complete fool of myself (I lost, of course).

Honestly, this game didn't do a whole lot for me. I'd love to articulate exactly what I disliked about Agricola. I played this the same day I played Airships (see above), and while that game stuck with me, my memory of Agricola has faded over time - a good sign of a "meh" reaction. I would probably play it again if an opportunity arose, but I doubt I would ever suggest getting it out myself.

NOTE: I realized later that my first play was a "family" game. My second play was the full game (quite a while later) and I enjoyed it a lot more. Now I am much more interested in playing again.

RATING: 8
[several plays] I think I have always played with all cards. I also GM'ed this game one time at a CON.  It is a good solid game, but it has not replaced my all-time favorites yet. RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[Z-man 08 edition w/ Z-deck, animeeples, resourcemeeples and vegimeeples] {Agriculture; action-drafting, variable-player-order, action-point, development, resources management; solo, scalable} {Family version 6.5; E-deck 7.5; I-Deck 7.5} Agricola is a decent Euro game.  It's thematic and highly replayable.  It's highly interactive and players have to strongly compete for resources; esp. with K-deck.  It's multifaceted: there are multiple paths to get victory points.  However, a strategy is highly dominated by the initial hand and players don't have much flexibility to adjust their strategy in the game.  The decisions are meaty yet not taxing.  It's fun to play Agricola because it's tense and engaging.  And, it's fun to see how your farmyard is developed at the end of the game.

The normal version is more suitable for experienced players.  It needs some time to teach the rule in detail.  For beginners, the family version would be better, though less fun.  It is easier to learn the game through family version.

The game experience is highly influenced by the card deck.  I select card decks depending on the players.  For general players, I would select E deck.  For most gamers, I would select I deck.  For very experienced players, I would select either I / K deck.  Z-deck could be occasionally used but X-deck and L-deck are only for fun.

The components are great, esp. with Animeeples and Vegimeeples.  The card illustration is colorful and cute.  However, non-English speaking players have a hard time to understand the cards.

[Animeeples] The animals are cute.  I esp. like the sheep.  They add much to game experiences.
[Vegimeeples] They add much to game experiences.  I like the large grains.
[Resourceemples] They increase game experiences, but not as much as Animeepls and Vegimeeples (personal taste).  I wish there were more tokens in the bag.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
OMG, I love it.  First, it is a snowball or engine building game and that is my favorite kind.  Second, I was able to play through a 2-player game in an hour.  (More players might add about 15 minutes per player).  Third, the game offers a ton of variability.  For a more family friendly game, there are rules that do not use any of the extra cards, just the actions that get revealed each round.  Then, if you do play with the cards they are split into three decks that offer different levels of interaction, conflict, and difficulty.  Finally, there is enough of each kind of card that we were able to play two full games and not reuse any of the cards that we had seen in the first game.  This game has replay value out the whazoo (in other words, a lot).  Now I just have to beg that please, please, please there needs to be an English edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Why is this so enjoyable?  No idea.  But it -is-.  At its base, its mechanics are similar to Caylus (send your workers to certain squares to get certain resources to earn points at the end of the game), but it avoids many of the things about Caylus that I find unenjoyable.

The card decks and semi-random distribution of when actions will be available give a nice sense of randomness without making the game entirely luck-based; basically, you will have a random hand at the beginning that will help guide your strategy, and you will know when most actions will be available, give or take a round or two (but, oh, that give or take can cause so much trouble!). 

The scoring rewards having some amount of balance and not totally over-specializing in one section of the game; you need to get at least one of most things to score competitively.

Somehow, despite the many decisions to be made, Agricola doesn't inspire the stiflingly bad analysis paralysis that Caylus seems to carry like a virus.  This is probably because you get the resources for a worker as soon as that worker is played, so you don't have to keep reviewing what you WILL be getting and WHEN to make sure you can do action X at the right time.

I haven't played it enough to decide whether its rating will bump up, but right now it's very enjoyable and something I am looking forward to playing again. 

COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: While a couple of the resources are close in color, it's one of those games where this isn't a terribly big deal, and everything's always in the open, so you can just ask other people around the table which is which if needbe.  All resource symbols on hidden cards also have a drawing of the resource so being able to distinguish the color is unnecessary.

RATING: N/A
I giocatori iniziano con una coppia di contadini in una capanna di legno di due stanza. Ogni turno, ogni membro di questa famiglia può compiere un'azione. Se raccolgono legno e canne, potranno allargare la propria capanna e poi far crescere la propria famiglia. La crescita della Famiglia dà  la possibilità  di scegliere più azioni, ma ha lo svantaggio che richiede più cibo per il suo mantenimento. Per ottenere cibo, i giocatori arano i campi e seminano. Il grano e gli ortaggi seminati vengono raccolti durante il Raccolto, quando anche gli animali si riproducono. Per far allevare gli animali, bisogna recintare dei pascoli per contenere le pecore, i cinghiali e il bestiame. Occupazioni e miglioramenti assicurano il mantenimento della famiglia. Ognuna di queste carte dà  un piccolo vantaggio nel gioco.

Per guadagnare altri Punti Vittoria, i giocatori possono trasformare le proprie capanne di legno in Argilla, e in seguito persino in Pietra. Ma tutto ciò che ha a che fare con bilanciare le necessità  di cibo, o che può rendere la vita di tutti i giorni più confortevole può far guadagnare Punti Vittoria, soprattutto la Crescita della Famiglia. Userete ogni volta una diversa selezione delle 166 carte Occupazione o dei Miglioramenti, quindi ogni partita sarà  diversa. Regole aggiuntive per il gioco in solitario e una versione accorciata per famiglie fanno in modo da fornire una sfida di livello adeguato per ogni tipo di giocatore.

Contiene:
9 Plance a doppio lato
135 Segnalini Risorsa
36 Segnalini Cibo
54 Cubi Animale
25 Segnalini Persona
75 Steccati
20 Stalle
18 Tessere Campo
24 Tessere Capanna
15 Tessere Casa di Pietra
3 Segnalini Ospite/Controllo
9 Segnalini Moltiplicazione
1 Segnapunti 1 Regolamento
1 Segnalino Primo Giocatore
360 Carte
166 Occupazioni
146 Miglioramenti
16 Carte Turno
16 Carte Azione
8 Carte Elemosinare
6 Carte Riassuntive

Good: 1-5

RATING: 8.3
Magic the Gathering meets Puerto Rico. I like to draft the Ausbildungen and Anschaffungen at the start of the game: you get dealt 7 Ausbildungen, pick one of them and pass the remaining 6 players to the player to your left. Repeat this until all cards have been chosen. This helps to assure that every players gets something playable for the crucial early turns. Highly recommended.

A modern classic.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Agricola takes a rather heavy-handed approach at replayability. You start with a standard action-selection game and then you're buried beneath a huge pile of cards from which you're randomly given 14. From these you attempt to carve a successful path. But the replayability is not inherent. In fact, it's forced upon you in a manner that is not entirely satisfying to me. For the replayability to really matter, the underlying game has to be phenomenal. As stated above, it's nothing more than standard. This is opposed to a game like Euphrat & Tigris where the replayability comes from the system itself. Agricola is certainly a solid Euro that I'll happily play, but it seems to have appeared at a time when throngs of geeks are desparate for a new messiah. If this game takes the #1 spot away from Puerto Rico (a game with a *truly* revolutionary idea), it will be a crime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Agricola works as a geme it just that for me it suffers the same problem that Calyus does. I do not like the mechanic of worker placement that blocks other players for using a building then you have to readjust a plan in the middle of a half round, that kind of tactile stratedgy is very unenjoyable for me (is that a word?!?).  I am a long term planning and enactement kind of guy with the need to adjust your plan when others intervene, not make the best with what you got, kidna guy.

The game requires a very tight mix of strategy and tactics almost like walking a tightrope, or what I imagine it would be like to walk a tightrope at least.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating after 12 multi player and 21 single player games.

The single player sequence of 8 games of increasing difficulty is pretty addictive. It's a great way of discovering the various two-player occupations and the minor improvements.

Though it doesn't detract too much from the enjoyment, some of the occupations are clearly overpowered. For instance, having the Lord of the Manor in play every game is an automatic 7 or 8 point bonus without even needing a single action action.

The Quarry minor improvement offers 3 stone with every 'Day Labourer' and by game 4, it can be played immediately in round 1. 

Not for purists (or so I thought) but great fun nevertheless.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
>15 plays (family: 2/3/4/5 player; E-deck: 4 player; E/I/K-deck: 4/5 player, E/I/K/Z-deck: 5 player).

If you twisted my arm, I'd say its a mixture of the best bits of Caylus & Antiquity, but the story arc is better defined and on a more human scale: for an hour or two you really feel like a farmer struggling to feed his family and develop his farm.

The one thing I'm not sure about is the cards. Without them (the "family game"), everyone is on a level playing field, I can predict people's actions, and turns move along swiftly. With the cards, asymetries are introduced; player's valuations of good changes. I can't remember all the cards that have been played, so it feels as if there are elements of the game that I'm not factoring in. Downtime is also increased as players read and re-read their cards. On balance, I think I prefer playing without the cards.

RATING: 7
The best thing about Agricola are the components. It does also play well, but I have some problems with it, namely that chance is too big a factor. Sometimes you get cards too good to be true, other times your cards offer no synergies at all, leaving you better off ignoring them.

And while I enjoy complex games Agricola often gives you the feeling that all the time you spent with the setup (which takes forever) and the thinking hard could have been spent much better with a less over the top game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
(2010-01-21) It's a good, solid Euro with worker placement and resource management. Being as playable for 5 players as for solo makes it handy to have around. Unlike most Euros, it has a solid grasp of its theme and has a good amount of replayability since it has a bunch of variable power cards (occupations and equipment). However the downside there is that those variable cards aren't really balanced so well. You also end up playing the same few strategies each game - it's far from easily solved, but can feel too same-y. It's still probably one of the best engine games around. 

(2016-02-09) So about that replayability. The problem with the occupation and equipment cards is that one player can get a hand with really good synergies and effectively win the game before it starts. So now you spend an extra 20 minutes before the start of the game to draft cards, so now it will invariably be the better card players who get the really good synergies and effectively they win the game before it starts. I guess I don't really want to play a 3h game of Agricola if the meat of the contest occurs during the card draft at the start - I'll just stick to the family game, or better yet just go with Caverna. Sold and rating down to 6. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very fiddly, with lots of components going all over the place and cards that are often too complicated.  However, the game play is excellent; there are tons of choices, lots of things to try, and so very few actions to do it all with!  Its an exciting balancing act that moves very fast and taxes the brain quite a bit.  One complaint is that the cards can seem imbalanced.  Really happy to have the English version; its much easier to manage all the cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[u]Key Words:[/u] Farming - Worker Placement - 2-5 players - Action Optimisation - Optional Hand Management/Card Drafting - 2-3h

[u]Summarized Opinion:[/u] Great game that appeals to (almost) all, made even greater by the addition of the cards.

[u]My Rating Explained:[/u] Outstanding. This game has given me countless hours of fun.

[u]Verbose Assessment:[/u]

Agricola is a game that seems to appeal to so many people, it's no coincidence that the game has been #1 on BGG for so long. 

It appeals to people who like the theme, which is almost everybody I know. Something about building up your own farm from scratch is just fun. You can't help but feel pride at your nice house and large family, your fields full of grain and veggies, your fenced in live-stock. For some people, customising their copy is half the fun. And even if you did not actually win the game, you may end up feeling satisfaction at what you accomplished.

But what really makes this game such a winner is 2 things: there's a solid gamer's game underneath the cute theme, and the cards are the cherry on top, making it very replayable, while not upping the luck factor - that is, if you go for the card drafting variant.

One point of criticism: the game is not short and takes a long time to set up and pack away. Using the cards and using the draft variant makes the game better, but also lengthens the game still.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a perfect example of a worker-placement game.  Everything here works perfectly and the game is incredibly tight.  They could realistically change the name of the game to Food because that's what it's all about for the first several rounds.

I think the family game is hardest because you don't get the cards to help you out.

I had this rated a 10 for quite a while.  I do love it, but not quite that much anymore.  Down to a 9 which is still quite awesome.

Purchased 8/12/08

RATING: 5
While somewhat good, I cannot rate it very high because without the expansion, it feels like I'm replaying the same game, even with all the variability and cards, the feeling of the game is too similar from game to game.  I do not like is being forced to build a little of everything to avoid negative points, sometimes I just want to farm and not be a rancher.  As good as this game is, I can only play it once a month or so, sometimes I just want more open choice in a game.

EDIT:  The more I play, the more I hate it.  It ends just as you start to feel you can breath.  I would much rather play a longer game like The Colonists where you really get to build something up instead of trying to cram it all into an hour's worth of play.  It just isn't fun for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Others disput this but it is more of a puzzle than a game. A puzzle with ever changing conditions.
It is a heluva brain ache playing, sometimes fun, sometimes not.
I say it is a puzzle since when you play the one player game it can be more stressful than playing with other people, since every move that is wrong is you own fault.
The game is a farm simulator where you have to get the resources to feed and house your expanding family and farm. Thought the resources are very limited and each player has turn order access to these resources and if what you thought you needed goes elsewhere you than have to change your statergy to maximise your points value.
Deciding on when you take available resources before or after an opponent has a go is the main interaction with other players.
Making a go that penalises another player without it benefitting you in your points hunt is a no-no, since every move must count otherwise you will fall behind.
Some love it. but I will only play it if others ask for it, I never volunteer it as an option to play.
Dont get me wrong it is a brilliant game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Super tight farming worker placement game that catapulted Uwe Rosenberg into recognition. A great puzzle based around how to build a farm while not starving to death. The occupation and minor improvements make every game unique. Fantastic game, a must play/have for any board game fan.

RATING: 9
Farming themed worker placement Euro. Lots of depth to the gameplay, which provides plenty of replay value thanks to the numerous minor improvement and occupation cards. Found the rulebook very difficult to follow at first (poorly written I felt as it tried to explain the basic and advanced game rules simultaneously). Despite this, it's actually a very simple game to play once you've got the instructions sussed. Virtually every decision you make throughout the game seems to have an affect on the final outcome. Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Agricola is simply awesome.  I really enjoy the experience.  You have somewhere between 28 and 52 actions (if you some how have three rooms and select family growth in rounds 5, 6 and 7). As a result of the scoring system, you want to do everything but you don't have time.  Plus there's all the tension in the worker placement mechanism that messes with your plans.  It scales well from 1 to 4 and 5 is a little crowded but can be fun too.  The cards add a bunch more actions that you want to do but don't have time for.  I find that the limited actions forces people to generally diverge in strategies (how to gather food and grow family) in the first half of the game and then try to pick up a little bit of the stuff they're missing in the last couple turns to make points.  As a result most farms end up looking similar but arriving there from different paths.  Lots of fun and looking forward to my next game. 
**UPDATE** Appears to scale quite well across the various number of players, each number feeling slightly different.  5 player seems to be pretty tight on actions and a bit more tactical than with less players; 2 player probably being the most strategic.
**UPDATE** Digging deeper into the decks has been fun.  I could see burning out on the single player game; It's fun but pretty dry and a little too easy.  I have called a couple series in the middle when I got a bad hand of minors, didn't play any of them and still busted the 68 point total.  (ie, I could pretty much play each game the same way ignoring the dealt minors and new occupations and still win)  Raising the bar might not work though because it would start to come down to if you drew good occupations and minors or not. Here to stay in my top ten though :) 2009/05/01 
Expansions owned:
Z-deck
X-deck

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Working on a farm for minimum wage is more enjoyable than playing this game.

-ve
1.Worker placement is illogical in a game about running your own farm
2.Everything here is an arbitrary micro-action
3.The scoring system rewards mediocrity
4.Feeding people is tiresome
5.It's fiddly
6.It's overly long
7.There's no positive player interaction.

Honestly the first issue is enough to make me never play this game again but I did play it 4 times because it's well rated. The second also bugs me hugely. 

I could overlook the rest in a good game. This game epitomizes the euro designer disconnect between mechanisms and theme. Normally they have the good grace to abstract things enough that their mechanism choices become irrelevant but not here. No, here the designer randomly abstracts some things and goes into great detail in others. Absolutely bizarre.

Frankly the positives of the game (which are numerous and well covered by others) just don't matter when the core of the game isn't enjoyable.

*I also tried the app on iPhone. Worst experience ever. Don't bother unless you have an iPad.
--
I've come around on this game as a 2 player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
So far the best worker-placement exam I have played.  There are numerous options each turn, and there are plenty of ways to attack your opponent(s) by taking them first.  As many have stated, once you finally feel like things are coming together, the game ends.  

The solo version is quite a fun puzzle.  It is very rewarding when you outdo your previous score.  This boosted my rating from 9.0 to 9.5 originally.

However the set up especially between rounds is a cumbersome pain.  Also, the cards add too much randomness to the game, and if I don't have good cards, I have no hope.  Having now played Caylus, I've dropped this back to 9.0 for those reasons.

Still, I'd play this any time someone suggests it, and I typically lose every game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is like being a farmer getting up before dawn, doing lots of preset chores and working hard, yet still struggling to feed my family and worrying if I am doing enough to expand my farm.  Is this process challenging?  Sure.  Is it FUN??  For me, not so much.  It just feels like so much WORK.  The game also feels too tight and limiting.  Though I do love complex, "thinky" games (which this game is), I prefer them to be more of a sandbox, where I have more creative freedom to evolve my strategy as the game progresses and changes rather than feeling like I'm on a preset path doing X, Y, Z (which is heavily influenced by the cards I receive at the beginning).  The constant pressure of feeding your family (or suffer severe consequences if you fall short) also creates a somewhat annoying tension that adds to this restrictive feeling, like another "to-do" on my list of chores.  Other negatives are the high setup and breakdown time, the many pieces, and the lack of real player interaction beyond the simple blocking/denial of actions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Fun game to play solitaire. One of the best games to play with your spouse (trust me, little sheeps and building a new room for family expansion somehows triggers something). But at the same time, pretty harsh on your choices so don't mistake it for a 'light' game.

The cards (that come equipped WITH the game) make for nearly endless replayability, and that makes this game a must-have in any collection.

[Edit] Is collecting dust right now because of a) Pandemic has trumped it as 'spouse-game' and b) not playing much solitaire because of so many new games to digest after last year's Essen (+regular buys). Also, Arkham Horror is the solo-choice if enough time. So niche is getting small. Still good game though.

[EDIT AUG 2016] Rediscovered this game after AH turned out to be too big to take on vacation. Still strong after so much time, got a few vacation plays out of it and even managed to play it with my son, who really enjoyed it. Rating revised upwards by 0.5 point.

RATING: 3
CONCEPT: Medieval village farming does not say anything to me. 
MECHANICS.not bad a far as card passing and the like. I cant help but think there are too many decisions in each turn, or else break it up somehow. There is just too many mechanics going on. 
ERGONOMICS. I found the table rather cluttered and it was hard to read the explanation for all those worker placement sites on the board. I would think this would throw off newcomers.
STRATEGIES. There must be some if you know the deck. Not knowing the deck is just stupid.
NARRATIVE. Your pens get bigger and grow carrots there. And a pack of animals only has one baby so...?
DRAMA. It's a point counting exercise so I didnt see any. 
BRAIN ENGAGE. It's interesting I get the feeling women will like this more than men. Perhaps it taps into certain types of thinking like pattern recognition that appeal more.

RATING: 8.5
The rules take a bit of reading and re-reading.  Then you have to play the family version to get the basic mechanics, then read the rules again to ensure you played properly.  Then you can introduce the cards.

I played the game a little wrong the 1st time, not doing the "Start Player" spot correctly, and not adding materials to each spot each turn.

But, once you get the hang of it, it's a good game that adjusts itself nicely from 2 to 5 players.

The only drawback is the large board space needed.

I reviewed a few different strategies, and can agree that this game can be played so many different ways that nobody really can take an advantage playing one way than another.

Very good.  Just can't wait to play with a few friends.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very intense resource management game, with lots of flexibility when the Occupations and Minor Improvements are used.   Lots of fun and endless replayability.  You can get carried away with all the options available to you but ultimately you do not want to lose sight of your goal, which is to increase your action limits by adding Family Members.  The Occupations and Minor Improvements will usually factor into that by doing things to help you decrease the amount of time spent on resource management.  It does take a large amount of time to set up (usually 5-10 minutes), however, and a fair amount of time to take down (usually 5 minutes).  We almost always without exception use the Drafting optional rule, so that increases set up time by about another 10 minutes or more but we feel its "oh, so worth it!".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

After a few more plays, maybe it'll be a 10? Regardless, as a two player game, it works really well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Having come from having played Caverna first, Misery Farm feels a lot more cobbled together. I'm not sure if it was because of expansions or not, but having two rounds of drafting felt a little excessive. I can see wanting to diversify the players with all the jobs and minor upgrades, but why have to go through all that drafting? If someone at the table suffers from AP the game drags on before it even starts.

I'm also not a fan of how the game forces you to develop in certain ways. You can't specialize your plant and animal production. When you do so you effectively lose points for everything you don't have. Also there's a cap on points for everything. You have more than five corn? Too bad, you get max points. At the other end of the spectrum there's begging. If you have to take even one begging card then you're probably not going to win.

For this alone I'd much rather play Caverna, which does give you the ability to specialize and multiple ways to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Nice worker placement game combining strategic complexity, easy rules and thematic environment.

The family mode, while easy to play, gets too repetitive after three or four games. I don't really like the non-specialization scoring system of the game; it seems there is only one winning path. That mode is ideal to learn the game or play with children, that's all.

Occupations and minor improvements add tones of strategy and replayability, without adding much more rule complexity. Non-specialization is still an issue, but it has cut down. Still, some options don't pay off (like reforming your house before expanding it), which unfortunately limits the available options every turn.

The game can clearly be played with up to 5 players without problems. While the time length increases with the number of players, downtime is not a problem here. Interestingly, the number of players dramatically changes the game options: for instance, with two players you can cook your animals as part of a winning strategy; that's hardly the case with 4 or 5 players. In this way, you have to "learn" the game with the different number of players. That's really nice.

Apart from the already commented non-specialization issue, the game also have a tedious mechanism for increasing the available resources every turn (greatly corrected in Ora et labora). Overall, an excellent game to be played both for hardcore europlayers and casuals.

A nice thing in this game is that even if a player is going to lose, he can still "do things". You're working to get the best farm; even when you're clearly not going to win, you can try to improve yours and have a good time. That means that players with really different skill levels and experience can play and have a good time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
