RATING: 10
10 x family version (3x solo)

36 x E Deck (14x solo)

I Deck (15x solo)


The family version is too shematic. Ok with cards someone could have a better draw, but usually better players win, regardless what cards they have. And with cards the game is very interesting. You could play in the same way, but the cards give you a feeling that you play in a diferent way.

The feeding is nice. When you have more family members you have more actions and more points, but more problems at the harvest.

All what you do gives you points, but you must have everything. But when you have everything only at minimum, you want win. You must have something at a big level. And you should try to spare actions (use double action fields). 

The problem is you must make family growth. With only 2 family members you will lose. And wood is a very important resource.

When you pimped your Agricola the game looks very nice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A pretty good game, but not one that I relish nor look forward to pulling out any time soon---partially because of how little it fires my imagination, and also because so much of it is simply pulling little bits out of bags and moving little bits from one pile of little bits to another pile of little bits.  The rulebook is poorly written---it misses the big pictures while focusing on details in a haphazard order without ever giving a clear view of game play in words or images: I understood how to play only through inference and extrapolations.  Not a lot of personality here, but the sheeples are cute, and it functions well as a component puzzle.
Stalin can borrow my copy while I play Cave Evil, Ambush!, and Mage Knight.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
15 June 2009: So after receiving Agricola in the Math Trade, I finally play it over the weekend with Cynthia. Turns out that we love it, and have played 3 games in the space of 2 days.

I like its simplicity in the general gameplay (ie. Take actions/stuff, Replenish, Harvest when required), and the complexity that comes from the cards. I think it's a winning mix of mechanics. The Replenishment reminds me a lot of Puerto Rico when you get a lot of coins on a Role and are torn between what you want to do versus picking up all that juicy loot.

The only gripes I have about it: I think it'll suck with 4+ players. I mean, the downtime must be horrendous, and it'll probably be an extremely frustrating game if you're going last or second-last. And I can't figure out why aren't the Occupation and Minor Improvement cards available in a common area like the Major Improvements. I understand the "play optimally with what cards you've got" idea, but that introduces a fair amount of luck in the game when one player gets brilliant cards/card combos and another doesn't. I don't mind it if this was a short card game, but this is a heavy 1+ hour game, and it is frustrating after 1 hour of playing to realise that you didn't have much of a chance of winning because your opponent had super cards that "Plowed 3 fields at once" and "Built 3 additional fences". I'm beginning to lean towards some Card Drafting mechanics as suggested in the BGG forums.

But anyway, as a 2-player game, it's an enjoyable game, and I think we'll get loads of play out of this. Rated 8 with 2-3, rated 6 with 4+.

22 June 09: Played another 2 games with Cynthia over the weekend, and lost both times :-p Looks like its one of those games where I get progressively worse the more I play! Anyway, tried the drafting variant, and found it too tedious. In the end, Cynthia and I preferred to play it with random starting hands. Definitely love the Komplex Deck - such interesting cards!

16 Feb 11: Upgraded from 8->9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A very luck decided game: a good synergistic draw can make the game easy; a poor draw, and you're stuggling just to feed your people. Since the draw is all at the beginning of the game, risk management is not possible. While this amount of luck can be acceptable in a short game, I do not find it so in a long game.

Overly complex, with too many things going on and too many rule exceptions. Sometimes thematic, sometimes not. Changes too much for my taste by number of players. Too staged: these things happen in this era of the game. It would be an improvement to place the stage cards in the same places every game, the harvest happening when all stage cards have been placed--as is, one has something of a search for desired cards for large number of players. Too start-player dependent, ensuring rotation of start player or simultaneous action would have been better solutions.

In Puerto Rico, one builds, so even in last place, I feel like the least *successful* player. Agricola is about fighting the game and often destroying what you've built before (crops, herds), so even if I were to win, I think I'd feel like the least *failing* player.

I feel I have a handle on the game: and the handle should have been treated with disinfectant and antibiotics. Agricola has complexity, but not the elegance that great games have. To be sure, PR has its inelegant clunky parts, but at least one does not feel as if they are constantly fighting the game.

Plays around 1/2 hour per player, which is better than I expected.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
can't really put it into words ... I just don't feel it

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Agricola used to be on my top 3 or so games of all time but it has fallen considerably.  While I still love this game with its animeeples, farm theme, and worker placement mechanics, I often dislike the length of this game, the setup time, and the amount of cards/options you need to pay attention to.  

In my opinion this game is on the verge between a mid-level game and an advanced heavy game and it puts it in an awkward place where I would rather play a heavier game with an amazing theme like Rebellion or a lighter game with a more neutral theme like Splendor.

Still despite the longer than expected length and heavier than expected options/choices, the game remains a very solid good game.  I would never say no to this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1-5 Players
120 Minutes
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
There is no disputing that many are left cold by Agricola’s obscure whimsical setting. Yawn, there are no explosions.  Yawn, no space-ninja-zombies.  There is no recapitulation of some grand(iose) colonial era.  Instead of summoning demons to do your bidding, you will summon carrots.  In Agricola, the goal is quite humbly to improve your lot.

And yet there are a million interesting decisions to be made in this context, what and when to plant, whether to breed or slaughter. There are seemingly endless paths to victory, but there is also a delicious tension in never knowing how deeply one should commit to any single path. The game forces you to strategize in layers of contingency. You will devise plan A, but be prepared to rally behind plan B (or C or D), and all the while work to shunt your fellow players away from their plans, denying them precious resources even as you work to collect your own.

Lastly, it is the sense of accomplishment at the end of a game, looking down at a physical model of your decisions, regardless of the final score, that makes 'Agricola' uniquely satisfying to me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The only downside is the game can run long and can get AP-prone depending on the player (sometimes it's me!). But love it overall!

RATING: 6
Not sure why the designer made a game that was so confined in play (too many things to do and not enough actions to do it) and then threw in random dealings of cards that can give a random boost to a player. That is begging for house rules where you get dealt 4 or 5 more cards and then discard.

Also, the family expansion not coming in for a while really bugs me along with the fact that there's one card that allows one person per turn until even later in the game when another card comes up just before the game ends. For the first card there's a mad dash for who can get to it first. How does that even make sense? How can only one family procreate in this town at a time? I much prefer something like Roads & Boats where anyone can increase their actions right from the start, they pick the best time for them and they can't be blocked by other players.

RATING: 9
Good: A euro with a strong theme! Equal amounts of maximising your own gain while minimising that of others. Lots of tension is brought about by having to feed your family. Really deep strategy and a ton of variety with the improvement/occupation cards.

Bad: The rulebook makes the game seem quite complex, when it is very simple in reality. It would be nice to have multiple avenues of victory instead of being harshly penalised for not having at least one of everything.

My missed opportunities makes me want to play it again to improve.

RATING: 8
If you're able to get things going relatively early, this game can be pretty enjoyable, but if you fail to get traction early on, it feels like you're constantly treading water and the game feels more like a chore.

The spatial element of the player boards is almost completely non-existent, so my board looks almost the same every single game.  It's annoying.

The interesting part of the game for me is trying to get a combo worked out with the cards you get at the start of the game, and trying to get that combo out on the table while still keeping your family fed.

Sold my first copy, but my gf wanted to get a copy so it's back in the collection.  Sadly, I think I dislike the 2p version more than 3-4p due to the scarcity of action spaces to get goods.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This will appeal to the PR-euro crowd a lot. It itches nearly the same spot PR does, but with the huge number of cards, makes this game much more replayable. After playing a draft once, I'm positive that you need to play with a variant that allows you to discard and replace cards, or just draft cards - its just too easy to get screwed otherwise. Anyone that says a draft makes the game to long? You don't want to play with them anyway - THEY will make the game too long.

This isn't bad two players - other numbers make it too long and for that I'd much rather play Ora et Labora or Cavern than Agricola. I'd probably rank this higher as a concept, but as a ranking of desire to play, my rating is much lower.

RATING: 10
This is one of those game that you are almost required to play a few times before it all starts to sink-in.  And one of the few games where I find myself thinking about afterwards ("should I have taken the wood offer, or extended my house").

It amazing how much the card expansions add to the re-playability to this game.  I own the Farmers of the Moor expansion, but have yet to play it, since I'm having so much fun with the base game, and finding the strengths of the cards from the E,I, and K decks.

This game is definitely deserving of it's lofty boardgame status.

RATING: 7.5
Cada miembro de tu familia, que al principio vive en una cabaña de madera, puede realizar una acción por ronda. Si coges maderas y juncos puedes construir nuevas habitaciones, ampliando tu familia, y realizando así más acciones por ronda. Pero tienes que alimentar a la familia arando los campos y sembrando los recursos necesarios. Se pueden criar animales de granja, ovejas, cerdos y vacas, para lo que necesitas vallar tus parcelas. Los oficios y las adquisiciones te darán ventajas.

RATING: 7.3
Hard to know what to say about this. I don't dislike this game, but I don't share the love for it that most people seem to have.

Edit: After a recent game of this, my first in some time, I enjoyed it a bit more than I remembered. Part of my dislike of it may have come down to the fact we overplayed it, and I got rather tired of it. I still find the game unnecessarily fiddly in places, and I think that the initial card deal can give players a rather unfair advantage. We're hoping to get around the latter problem by instigating some sort of card-drafting system in our next game, which should be interesting.

RATING: 8
When I bought this game, it was the most complex board game I had ever played.  We've long since run out of score sheets, we played so much.  Looking back, though, the lack of interaction with other players, the long game times (including setup and cleanup), the tedium of re-stocking resources every turn, and the difficulty to teach to new players make me like this game less.  It's not a game I really seek to play anymore, and I would be hard pressed to give an expansion a try.

RATING: 5
One of the clear hits of BGG.CON 2007, I was lucky to grab it for one play.  It was very impressive, but when you really dissect it, it's pretty much all stuff we've seen hundreds of times before.  Nothing truly new here at all, but still it was oddly compelling.  To me, it felt most like a light version of Roads & Boats (which still makes it a pretty heavy game).  We made a mistake in shuffling all of the occupation decks (and the minor improvement decks) together into one, and we were wondering why some of the cards seemed so much better than others, so we were glad to find out that if you played it correctly, it wouldn't have been as unbalanced as we thought it was.

RATING: 8
Probably the best game out there.It has everything you dream of.So there is no need to stress the positive aspects once again.Let's go to the negative ones...
-You must have a company of 'hardcore' players.
-You must have plenty of time(we are supposed to play a bit carefully)
-It is not actually a game but a small essay.After a lesson of quantum physics in the university for example  you cannot play Agricola.
-All players must know the rules(or you need 45 minutes to fully explain the rules and some strategies concerning the cards)

Nice game actually my favorite but i play Agricola only in summer and big university breaks. 10/10 as a game 6/10 cause it is not actually a 'game'.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simply outstanding. The best game of 2007, hands-down. This game somehow creates and builds tension like few others, making the many decision points for players wonderfully angst-filled! I've played more than 100 games, with varying numbers of players, and each has its own unique character ... replayability for Agricola is phenomenal. Experience and skill tend to win out ... but not always, and I consider that uncertain element part of the charm. I do recommend drafting with the occupations and improvements to smooth out the luck. Simply deal 7 of each to all players, who select one of each and pass the rest to the left. Lather, rinse, repeat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After about 15 plays I'm really gripped by this game. Any opportunity there is to play some games, this is the game I want to play more than any other!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A good solid game with lots of stuff to keep in mind.  First time I played I didn't really "get" the scoring and - not surprisingly - ended up in last place at the end.

After that I figured out that knowing the scoring rules makes it a lot easier to do better, and each time I've played I seem to "get" the whole game more than the last.

My son's reaction was that it was a bit tedious - which isn't completely inaccurate - but overall it's a good game even if there are one or two new players.  As long as everyone is willing to think; this is NOT a "beer and pretzles" game by any means.

RATING: 9.5
2 solitaire games so far. First - 28 pts, second, 54 pts. 
A great, great game with many agonizing decisions to take in the early stages. Remember to use the early stages to assure you have a proper food supply so you can concentrate on the real improvements later on!
Much more involving than Puerto Rico.
However, whereas after finishing PR I'd have another go, with Agricola I get the feeling of fullness after just one game. Hence the score.

Update: this game shines when played with 2-3 other people. Whereas solo play is all headology and predictive math, other players add a much needed element of chaos and interaction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Plays faster than I expected. Plays very nicely as 2p. Great game despite the ho-hum theme. It's funny to find myself saying "Woo Hoo, I got a plow!!"

Cons: Not the best "wife game" - causes annoyance at gaming partners when they take the resources you want. Game feels like it ends a little too soon. House improvement strategy isn't interesting to me. Not the most elegant design - feels like lots of elements conglomerated to make a game. Seems easy to run out of resource bits.

[Update] My rating drops from 8 to 7. After about 5 plays I got kinda bored with this game. Maybe it's largely the farming theme. The goals in the game aren't too motivating to me - I don't care if I get a stone house or more cows. I will probably pull it out again something soon and see if I like it better now that some time has passed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
One play only, but this was the most balanced game that I have ever played. I love games with a random component that doesn't interfere with the strategy like the cards in this game. The cards can set your macro-strategy, but turn by turn there are plenty of strategic decisions to make.

Overall, an excellent game.

RATING: 6

All of the intricate scoring happens at the end of the game, so the competition is limited to snagging worker placement spots.  A wild variety of cards add fizz to the leaden economic engine, but they introduce too much luck for such a large investment of time.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the more influential games in recent years.  Although it didn't invent the worker placement mechanic, it certainly popularized it.  

Player interaction is a minor, almost non-existent element.  This would normally be a big turn-off, but building a well-balanced (and 3-D) farm with what scant resources are left available is challenging and engaging.

I appreciate how difficult it is to juggle short-term needs (food, resources) with long-term goals (expansion, diversification).  There's no narrative to the game, but the theme of having to scrape by to keep the family fed with a hopeful eye towards the future frames the mechanics well enough.

UPDATE: I'd like to get back into this game but, man, do I ever hate the rulebook.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wonderful development game with sheer endless replayability, due to the constellation of minor purchases and apprenticeships. If there is a superlative to the term "tons of interesting options while only having limited actions", Agricola would surely deserve it. I doubt you will find that "one winning strategy". Even if you do, you will not be likely to repeat it, as you are dealt a different starting situation in each and every game, which'll force you to adapt to the new situation instead of always going to pull for the the same strategy over and over. It's hard to speak of great balancing after just one game, but finals scores were all within one point to the next player, with everyone coming from a different strategical approach. Great theme! You really feel like you are building up a farm in the late 17th century. The artwork was made with much love for the details. I don't want to rate it a 10 after one game, but I am sure this game will see more table time. And when it does, rating is likely to go up.  

Update: back down to an 8. I don't know why but I enjoy Le Havre more than this one.         
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's classic for a reason. Incredible game with tons of replayability. It wins the Caverna fight pretty handily.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Extremely fun worker placement, with a surprisingly non-gamer friendly theme (farming). The game can be tense in the early rounds, but a properly expanded farm can carry its own weight. The occupation and improvement cards can be a strategic trap; don't try to play too many.

Significantly altered and improved by Farmers of the Moor expansion, which adds a variety of new options and strategies without altering the most significant parts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
More information to follow, but after first play of the strict family game (no Minor Improvements or Occupation cards) I can safely say that I think this game will last.  The theme is rather harmless, but I do think the game will stand the test of time.

UPDATE:  Playing this (or any game) multiple times in a short time span can quickly lead to burn out.  While my opinion of the solidity of design remains unchanged, I just am not real interested in playing it over and over and over.  The cards are supposed to help replayability, and to give the game some depth, but the core system remains unchanged.  The game is very very good, I will just have to wait for a bit to play some more.

RATING: 10
Agricola deserves its spot up at the top.  Every play of it has been more thrilling than a game about medieval farming has any right to be.  I am 100 percent serious --  this is one of the most tense games I have ever played.  In each of my plays, I've generally been convinced by the second or third harvest that I'm completely doomed, and then by the end of the game it's all come together.  With so many strategies made possible by the hundreds of occupations and improvements, I can see this one getting lots and lots of table time.

RATING: 9.2
Worker placement game. Send your family members to work on the different action spaces to build a bigger & better farm and feed your family. You'll need to plow & harvest your fields, raise livestock, make babies and much more... A balanced farm will win the day. 2 decks of Occupation & Minor Improvement cards add variety.
Uwe Rosenberg 
1-5 players

RATING: 9
I really like this game. But for some reason, my family is very intimidated by it. So I don't get as many plays in as I'd like. I'll post more comments as my play count increases.

UPDATE, 3/29/12 - I've been getting this to the table more in the last year. My family is growing more fond of the challenge--especially my in-laws. In fact, my father-in-law got it for Christmas! So we'll be playing more of it in future visits I'm sure.

I'm ready to delve into the more advanced card decks to make it more interesting. I also own Farmers of the Moor, which I'm excited to crack as well. There is a lot of game with Agricola, and the expansion decks just seem to keep coming.

UPDATE: 12/3/2012 - After a few plays in the last week with my wife, Nora, and Aimee (and one game solo), I'm bumping it up to a 9 for its outstanding replayability and continuing depth. It keeps delivering. I have enjoyed exploring the Gamers' Deck (G Deck). I've found some very fun combos there.

I'm discovering more and more that I personally enjoy great combos in a game. This game has proven to be one of the best for that, making it one of my all-time favorites.

--

I bought the Spanish edition to practice my Spanish while I play! Should be good to use and play with other while I'm here in Guatemala too. I'll probably sell it or give it away before I leave. I think it would be good for Ash too, but she doesn't want anything to do with it since she doesn't want to have any part in being a [i]reason[/i] for buying a new game. I sincerely did buy it partly (probably mostly) for her and her Spanish. I thought she'd be happier about it. I was wrong. I guess I'll just practice my Spanish with it. There were several words I learned tonight in my first game with it. The cards are challenging because they use several new words, and they make me critically think in the language. I find it good practice.

[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: euro, worker placement, solo, 1-5 players, resource management, food, medium-heavy, individual player boards, favorites, rectangle box[/COLOR]

RATING: 8
[b]Farmers of the Moor[/b]
[b]The Goodies Expansion[/b]

2014-09. Agricola as a 2-player experience is starting to lose it's shine. The early game feels scripted with excessive competition over wood as you race once another to grow your family first. The experience starts to diverge at the mid-point, where only then can you start to make some strategic choices that can differ from game to game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Initial rating of 7 given after a single play of the family game. I expect this is unfair and the rating will rise with subsequent plays. However, I can't help thinking it is substantially inferior to Caylus as a worker placement game.

OK,OK - now that I've played it 4 more times using the occupation and minor improvement cards, I've seen the error of my ways and realise that this is a great game, even if a bit fiddly. Rating upgraded to 9.

10 plays: I've changed my rating back down again. It is a good game but two things, one major, one minor, count against it. Firstly, I find the game stressful to play. I'm racing against the clock (with other player's interfering) and there's just enough time to get everything done before the time runs out provided it all goes to plan. When the game ends, it's more a sense of relief than enjoyment. Secondly, the game is fiddly. It takes time to set up and tear down which, while not a showstopper, means it sometimes doesn't get to the table if I'm not in the right mood. Rating downgraded to 7.

RATING: 9.75
Absolutely fantastic gaming system.  Plays well with 2-5 players, and is a tense and tight game even without the cards.  The board cards alone add flexibility in the game play so that every game feels unique, but the minor improvement and occupation cards are what really make the game shine.  New synergies emerge every time the game is played, whether we use a card draft or just deal them straight out.  The cards allow for myriad tweaks of the game, making me feel that I will never tire of playing Agricola.

UPDATE: 3 years on and 200 face to face plays later and Agricola is still going strong.  The new decks add some spice, but I still enjoy the base game.  I'm always happy to play.  I've only played a handful with 5 players or with Farmers of the Moor, so there's still a vast amount of play left in this.

RATING: 6.4
I finally got to play this and I did enjoy it.  I was honestly VERY overwhelmed by the number of choices available in this game.  I never quite figured out a good strategy nor do I feel like I ever fully understood the interaction between many of the roles/resources/etc.

Still, it's a fun game with a lot of great depth.  It's a bit complex for my average gaming group.

It also gives me the same sort of angst that Puerto Rico and other games of this style give me...that just as I feel like I'm finally getting into the grove, the game ends.  It feels like the game is all build up, without significant time to enjoy the efforts made.

RATING: 8.5
1-5 players.

Build up a farm and hope to god your family doesn't starve to death. Balance Sheep, Pigs, Cattle, growing your family, expanding and renovating the house, and growing vegetables and grains. Serious brain burner but one of the best games ever.

RATING: 10

RATING: 8
An excellent worker placement. In classic Euro style, this is not an aggressive game so it suits players who don't like 'hostility' in games. Nice relaxing theme, with decent replayability due to the shear number of included cards.

That said, it isn't actually one that everyone likes as it can get a little 'mathy' if people stress too much about score optimization towards end game.

RATING: 6
I think the ratio of "amount of time owned versus number of times played" is worse for this game than nearly any other game in my collection.  For what it is, the game just feels 'clunky' - too much moving cards and wooden cubes in between turns, let alone on them.  Add to that the "first turn analysis dump" of having a huge hand of cards dealt out on turn 1 to define your strategy and I just haven't felt much impetus to get this to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Mechanics wise, this is a diamond game because it has:
- Tough choices 
- Multiple rewarding mini-goals
- A plethora of available strategies
- High Replayability both due to different start-up (cards)and player interaction
- An accurate and fair victory point system.

But the magic in this euro game is that despite it's great design, it's also thematic. You actually feel like a struggling farmer trying to improve your welfare. You constantly try to balance your needs with improving your prosperity and you are rewarded for your efforts accordingly. 

Although the theme integration is high, the theme is a bit uninspiring, although I admit that the experience is still better than games with a more "catchy" theme disconnected from the mechanics. Another minor flow, the game is prone to analysis paralysis, and therefore it's usually rather long to finish with 4-5 players.


If you ever wanted to be a farmer struggling to make a living this is your boardgame-dream come true. Otherwise, this is the game that will make you want to be one!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Medieval farming combined with weird pop culture references all realised in a gigantic box full of wood. Baffling, thoughtful, satisfying and probably completely broken.

Excellent Game. Highly Recommend.

RATING: 9.89
I was concerned that this game was going to be hyped when i first picked it up. I wasn't playing alot of board games beyond your classics and this was one of the first "euro" games for me to pick up. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Worker placement, building an economic engine, cards that let give you all kinds of special powers to break rules.  None of these mechanisms is unique, but here they are well implemented, fit together nicely, and work very well with the unique (although not that exciting) theme.  The multitude of cards keeps the game fresh to an extent, but I still have a few concerns.  Chief among them is the big differences in the power of cards, both alone and as part of combinations.  This is solvable by drafting, but at the price of increased play time.  I find that Agricola is interesting in a puzzle-solving kind of way, and I want to play it more, but it ultimately falls just short of being one of a 10 for me.

Rating by number of players:
1-player: 6 (interesting, but without staying power)
2-player: 7 (OK, but too little competition)
3-player: 9
4-player: 9
5-player: 8 (gets a bit long with this many)

RATING: 10
What I like:

-So many interesting choices and different strategies every single round! The replay value is huge with all these choice and different cards.
-Very thematic! The mechanics and the look of the game really support the feel of trying to run a succesful farm back in the day.
-Well made components - The animals are so cute and it really helps these are included with the game nowadays.
-A great brain teaser
 

What I do not like: 
(Actually this time it's more what others might dislike) 

-Well, mostly that the harshness is not for everyone but it personally doesn't borther me.
-A bit long and some of the rules are not intuitive to teach.
-Some people say you don't get to specialise but I personally would disagree with that. Yeah, you gotta get different things at the very end to get the points, but until the very very end you've had your very Unique strategy helping you get there and provide for your family. 

All in all my personal favorite classic eurogame

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
OK I broke my Agricola cherry last night and it is a great game. Does it deserve to be a 10? I'm not sure, it took Puerto Rico a long time to get there and I never award a 10 right away and certainly not after 1 game so we'll see where this one goes. Tough, very tough decisions to be made in this game from start to finish.

One thing I will strongly say about this game is that they did something very different than a lot of other games. Most games would come out and shortly thereafter release expansions fairly quickly. I feel like the various decks ARE the expansions and it's nice to have bought a game and feel like I've already been given the expansions and can look forward to many many months of game play. 

UPDATE:
After 36 plays in a relatively short amount of time I find myself wanting to play Agricola more and more. This game kicks ass all over the place. Hype is one thing but this game lives up to it.

UPDATE:
I play this game all the time and well didn't even  start recording plays until about 40 had gone by...still not getting old. This is certainly a sign that this is a truly GREAT game.  

UPDATE:
Well over 100 plays now and I still love this game. That's the mark of a truly great game if you ask me. I teach this game to new players using standard (non-family) rules and using all 4 decks...yes even Z. New players get the full load when I teach and as a result I can count 2 who have literally purchased the game the day after I taught it. (Certainly more bought it after learning but those took longer than 1 day!)

This game's ability to scale with number of players means it's great at any number. People will have their favorite sweet spots but the board and cards both scale so well it shines no matter what and always feels like you are playing Agricola not matter what. 

[ImageID=554376]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
UPDATE: Raised my rating from a 7 to an 8 after my seventh play.  I've tried it now with one-player, two-players, three-players, and four-players.  It scales very well (in the league with Goa and Tigris in terms of scaling) and very few games scale to accommodate a variety of player counts.  I have also tried the I and K deck now, and the sheer plethora and diversity of cards is indeed impressive.  However, while my rating has risen steadily with more plays, I don't expect the rating to go above an 8.  It's a very good game, but I can easily think of 20 games I'd rather play, so while it's very good, it's not quite great in my mind ---- UPDATE: Raised my rating from 6 to 7 after my fourth play and the first time using the drafting variant, which is a variant that I don't anticipate ever playing without in the future, may go to an 8 with further plays of the I and K decks ----- ORIGINAL COMMENT: I'm very perplexed by the people who call this "multi-player solitaire."  This game is extremely interactive, such that when we played back-to-back, I think changing the seating order definitely affected the game.  Players are choosing actions just like in Caylus, so each action can only be taken once, which clearly forces you to think about what your opponents are doing so you can plan and prioritize accordingly.  Anyway, I just had to get that out of the way first.  On to explaining my rating.  I really wanted to like this game.  Everything I had read going in sounded so good, but after three plays I think a 6 is about right unfortunately.  I'm still willing to play a few more times with someone else's copy if the opportunity arises, but don't feel the need to.  The game itself was all well and good, but the initial deal of the cards is what bothered me the most.  The cards and card combinations are clearly not balanced, which is fine (and I love Twilight Struggle despite the cards obviously being unbalanced), but unlike Twilight Struggle where you are dealt many different hands of cards, you are stuck with your one hand of cards for the entire game of Agricola, essentially sealing your fate for the next 2 hours in the first 2 minutes of playing.  That's an overstatement since a bad player can of course screw up a great hand and a good player can do something with poor cards, but among players of approximate equal skill and with the rules as written, it seems silly to play for 2 hours when some players have great cards and card combinations, and others do not.  I should note that I'm not bothered by this because I did especially poorly or especially great, but rather because I did both.  In my two games, I scored something like 19 and 49, due primarily to the cards I was dealt, and I saw my opponents' scores vary wildly depending on their hand of cards.  That being said, I love the angst in this game of wanting to do 5 actions and having to pick just 1, and I do like the integration of theme with the mechanics, as well as the likely high degree of replayability due to the vast number of cards.  So the only thing I can think to try the next time I play is to do a draft where each player is dealt 7 occupation and 7 minor improvement cards, keeps 1 of each, and passes the remaining 12 clockwise, and so on.  The problem is that this will likely add at least 20 minutes to the game, which may make it not worth it.  I don't think I really like the game with the rules as written, and I'm not sure this variant will be worth the increased game length, which leaves me uncertain as to whether this merits many more plays.  Lastly, regardless of  interest in this game, I highly recommend checking out this GeekList - http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/27177 - because it provides some great insights into the mind of a game designer.

Pre-ordered: June 16, 2008.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Easily my favorite game.  

Great engine building, lots of strategy, and plenty of opportunities to disrupt other players.  There's a massive diversity of strategies that a player can employ, and replay-ability is great thanks to 14 cards (Professions, minor improvements) that are different each game.  While some strategies work well regardless of your cards, players are forced to adapt to find an ideal strategy working with the cards they've been dealt.

The game requires a lot of forethought - Sometimes a card in your hand will be great halfway through the game, but in order to utilize it properly you'll need to start planning on it from the first turn.  This is great for players who love planning ahead, but can be a serious struggle for players who are newer to tabletop strategy games.

While I love the game, it is not without flaws.  The random professions and improvement cards add an aspect of luck, which in some cases can provide a major unfair advantage to some players.  The large number of components, resources, and rules can also feel a bit overwhelming for new players.  

Overall still one of my favorite games, after many, many plays.  Definitely worth a try if you're into deep strategy, engine building and planning games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Bleah what do I think about this. I see it has two unpleasant aspects that no doubt are what make it rank very highly on BGG: Tons of special cards to study (even a few, if you play the family version) and tons of things that affect your score. So you can really develop expertise with this game, but on one's first play you probably don't know what you should be doing.

I only played the family game (and probably only will play that). I like worker placement and I like the threat of losing points if you can't feed your people. (I finally tried Agricola thinking it might be similar to In the Year of the Dragon.) The point salad feel combined with a seemingly large number of placement options (and thus less feeling of blocking others) made my first game less tense than I expected.

But for various reasons, final scores were not close. That suggests to me that learning some basic strategy would increase competition for specific actions and improvements.

The game doesn't take very long to play, which I appreciated.

I played "All Creatures Big and Small" before this, and my respect for that effort increases. It is much less of a point salad game and doesn't have the inelegance of using cards as additional places to put workers. (Unfortunately perhaps, I don't find it strictly better, as it only plays two, has no variability, and nothing corresponding to needing to feed workers.)

RATING: 9.5
About 15 games in Boiteajeux. I find growing fast too important whatever strategy you take. Family game is ellegant and useful to learn basics. Advanced game with occupation/minors cards adds a lot of replayability, but not sure if more strategy paths. Strategy paths are based on the feeding mechanich you choose, mainly baking bread or slaughtering animals. It plays good with 2P but really shines with 3-4 players. Downs: it is a very expensive game, maybe it isn´t worthy if you play only 2P because lots of cards are out of play, and it demands a huge table to play. My rating at the moment is 8.

7.01.13 UPDATED: Bought and played 10 games in 3 weeks with my partner! and 10 more in Boiteajeaux (2,3 and 4er). Well, I was wrong, this game is amazing even with just 2 players. 2 player is a very cutthroat game, where blocking your opponent is the way to take. Cooking animals is a dominant strategy and baking is pretty harder/risky but still interesting to support animals in some games. With 4 players the game is more open, and feeding systems feels more balanced. It's a lot less about blocking and more about 'take your way' game. 4er the deserves more variety and more strategies for the players. 3 player feels in the midlle ground between 2 and 4, but seems that third player in the turn order feels too weak. I think the game is best with 4, next with 2, and then 3 (Not played with 1 or 5). Replayability feels outstanding (even with just 2 player cards). Down side is the huge amount of bits, cards, pieces...You need a big table to play this and setup&cleaning time is not less than 20 min.

RATING: 7

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
A great exercise in planning and prioritising that is very hard to crack and still challenges experinenced players in a way that many lighter games can not. Unfortunately there are problems with the base game that prevent it from living up to its potential. Many of these are corrected by the 'Farmers of the Moor' expansion (the combo gets a 9).

The main issue is just that there are too few paths to victory. Some elements of the game are underused, like renovation and the improvements. It's not worth having too many of any type of animal, so, ideally, you would end up with the same farm every time. Also, some elements of the game are too crude, like the cards can be too decisive or access to spaces can be too cutthroat. As I said, the expansion irons out many of these issues.

Some people complain that it has too much complexity, but since the gameplay is so tricky, the game will appeal to heavy gamers who will also appreciate its complexity and the number of modifying cards (to add replay value).

RATING: 9

I've done a few solo plays, and they're alright, but they take away the best part of the game - the competition and uncertainty of getting the actions you want. This game encapsulates the inability to do everything you want as well as getting your plans ruined and needing to resort to a backup.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm actually surprised that I like this game as much as I do.  Perhaps it is because of the strong theme, perhaps it is because the worker placement mechanics work very well, or perhaps it's because of the sheer enormity of the game.  If you're looking for a game that truly makes you feel like a struggling farmer, this game is about as close as you could possibly get.  It's got that worker placement tension that creates agonizing decisions every turn, and the variety that comes from the occupation and minor improvement decks is truly impressive.  The cards add a lot of depth and variety, but they do bog the game down because there is a lot to read and comprehend.  However, the family version doesn't use the decks at all, it is a great way to introduce non-gamers to the game, and I was pleasantly surprised at how well the game works under those circumstances.  Overall, it's a long and harsh battle for victory points at heart, with a solid and unique theme backing it up. I didn't think a game about farming could be that fun, but apparently I was wrong.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
UPC Code: 681706070261

RATING: 9
This is any strategy lover's dream. I avoided it like the plague when my husband bought it, having nightmares about anything even tangentially related to farming after Farmville ruined the universe. What a pity. 

This game takes a while to learn, but your patience will be rewarded greatly. We prefer not to complicate it with the largely fussy and unnecessary 'minor improvements' card deck and keep things simple. Game play is fast, and involves choices to be made at every turn, which soon snowball into your success/failure as a farmer. Agriculture at its most frustrating & exhilarating! Play with a competitive group to really put you in agony ;)

---------------
June 2012 update - demoted from 7 to 6.  Agricola is nice, but feels like work.  My tastes seem to be moving towards "fun" in games.  Agricola is not fun, really.  Its interesting, i guess.  If i have a hankering for a complex, engine-building game that frightens newbies, i will go to Puerto Rico.  New players are always keen on the complexity of PR - with Agricola, they are overwhelmed by the options and the race for food.  It can be a brutal, unfun game at times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ein absoluter Strategieüberhammer. Position 1 in der BGG halte ich für überbewertet. Aber es ist auf jeden Fall ein klarer Top 10 Kanditat. Im Prinzip ist das Spiel auch sehr simpel und schnell erklärt: Es gibt zahlreiche Aktionsfelder (Holz nehmen, Äcker pflügen, Ställe bauen, Schweine züchten) und man hat pro Familienmitglied eine Aktion also am Anfang zwei pro Runde, bis man die Familie erweitert. So besteht eine Runde im Prinzip lediglich daraus, seine zwei Familiensteine auf Aktionsfelder zu setzen und dann die Aktion auszuführen. Sehr, sehr simpel. Allerdings gibt es halt sehr viele Aktionsfelder und sobald eines von einem Familiemitglied eines Spielers besetzt ist, kann kein anderer Spieler mehr diese Aktion machen. So gibt es immer viel zu tun, auf einem Bauernhof fällt schließlich jede Menge Arbeit an, bevor die Ernte ansteht, und viel zu wenige Aktionen. Ein typisches Mangel-Optimierungsspiel. 
Für mich persönlich ist es nicht so der Überhit, mich nervt einfach der Zwang die Familie versorgen zu müssen, und auch die Tatsache dass Aktionen weg sind, wenn jemand sie benutzt hat. Wieso kann mein Bauer nicht mehr fischen gehen, wenn Bauer Robert schon fischen war. 
Das Aufbauen ist ebenfalls eine Qual, die man allerdings gerne in Kauf nimmt, die zahlreichen Tüten sind echt mehr als hilfreich. Die Spieldauer ist ein weiteres großes Manko, pro Spieler ca. 30 - 45 Minuten, gerade gegen Ende dauern die Überlegungen deutlich länger.
Aber alles in allem ein sehr schönes Spiel, dass es auf jeden Fall wert ist gespielt zu werden.

PPP = 7,40€
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Owned. With Z-deck and animeeples. :)

RATING: 8

It's relatively easy to learn as far as the worker placement goes, but the order of operations is tricky.  The steps necessary to go from planting a field to baking bread for example are pretty involved.  So I don't get to play it very much but when I do I always enjoy it quite a bit.

RATING: 7
Not my favorite Rosenberg but a wonderful thematic game.  I like hard games.  The puzzle of drafting the best cards and figuring out how to utilize them is challening and rewarding.

Doing one thing per turn should be dull but it's precisely the point of the game and captures the theme of "labor is difficult you had better be smart".  It makes every choice agonizing.

Survived my "euro cleansing".

RATING: 3
An almost endless selection of decisions.  A descendant of Goa and Puerto Rico, but with much more variety: because the players hold their own cards to use (or not), the communal board actually looks different to each of them, as it has to be weighed against their hands.  Still, more fiddly than the gaming payoff is worth.

Not sure I'd want to play it very often.

RATING: 8.5
Ok... read to the end!

So frustrating.  the only player interaction is watching the person before you take the action spot you wanted.

It's like a sailing race with no wind - too much effort to go nowhere.

Definitely a sound game, but feels too long, too much like hard work and not one to make me come back often.  Annoyingly, I will want to come back to it.

My "6" is harsh and just post-game, but right now I'd sooner beat myself over the back with a knotted rope whilst having my nipples wired to the mains.  

Very overrated with all the hype... solid game, but no better than the others in the top 10 list.

And it's not as nice as Puerto Rico or Settlers.  So there!


After 5 plays... yes, I'm learning to love it, so score adjjusted accordingly.  It's still a big learning curve, and a lot does seem to depend on the hand of cards you're dealt, but the variety is great and it is a very clever game!

Ok, I kept coming back (which says something about the game) and after several games, yes, its lovely.  So good i bought the expansion, which is nearly as lovely.  A cracking game, but a shame it's so hard to get into at the beginning of playing it...

RATING: 9
Not too keen at the start.. I misunderstood the rules, there as no example of play... lots of cards...family (ie simple) and advance (normal game) but as we played it got better. Playing with more people helped too.

Now... well it seems pretty good and we always seem to run out of time.. a funny game that seems to not be complete? 

Whoever wins seems to be the person who lost by the least?

Long term we'll see....

Another 6 months later. Two of my friends who play have bought their own sets to play as well. Now include all the cards and complex cards. The cards can make things quite random and unfair if not handled properly. The 10 and keep 7 rule works pretty well.

Six months later... Great game! Good complexity, lots of variety, reasonably quick play, all good!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My rating is for 2 players, specifically.  I believe having 3 or 4 players, and using all occupations, would make this game a 10.

Pros:
+Deep strategy game
+Enjoy seeing farm get built
+Enjoy art style
+Good variety of occupations/minor improvements

Cons:
-No box insert
-Takes a few places before you realize the amount of potential approaches to victory.  At first, it may seem like it's scripted -- after many more plays I now believe it's just a matter of better learning the cards.

Other things to consider:
:Very cutthroat; many opportunities to block and hurt someone, badly
:Very minimal luck component
:Epitome of "not enough time to do everything you want to do"

RATING: 7
The cards make, and break this game.  They are what makes this a different game every time.  They also make it possible for someone to basically win the game before it starts.  I would think that would be extremely rare, but possible that someone gets a great set of cards that all feed off each other and everyone else will be playing for second.  That's a tough pill to swallow for such a long game, but it is still fun to play and if you can deal with that one flaw it is an excellent game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I wasn't sure I would like Agricola, given the seemingly mundane theme (I mean, farming in the Middle Ages?). Also, it seemed rather bizarre to only allow one action to be used at a time, so only one person could build a minor improvement or collect wood (why would I not be allowed to do what my neighbor farmer is doing?). But for some reason, and obviously I am not alone in this, given the ranking of this game, it works. The first time I played I was immersed in my little medieval world (it didn't hurt that we have the custom animeeples for this game), building up my little farm and growing my family. It sometimes felt like all I was doing was worrying about feeding my family, but that'll probably go away with more plays. It's a game that I wan o play more often, and hopefully I'll get to soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played with 2, 3, 4 and 5 players and absolutely love this game. Maybe a bit more with 2 or 3 players. I can imagine that de order of seating or the hand of cards you are dealt can play a role in determining your chance to win, but so far this has not bothered me.
For now, I feel that Agricola plays like "Pillars Of The Earth" advanced. POTE is definitely more suitable for casual gamers, while Agricola might be more interesting for the more dedicated crowd. It also reminds me of Caylus, but I like it a lot better as it has more variety and is easier to explain.
I did not have high expectations for this game (it looked a little boring at Essen, which may be due to the unoriginal components), but it turned out to be a real surprise. There are just so many ways to win! Next time, I will try a different strategy.
UPDATE: I know more and more people who really don't like this game (too involved, too long, too much like work), and who prefer more accessible games like Stone Age. So it's hard to bring it to the table nowadays. Lowered rating to 8.

RATING: 7
03/2012: 8
Having just played once with 5-players as a newbie, these are my initial thoughts. I enjoyed the game but not starry-eyed. I understand the hype and all but this game, at first glance, is fiddly. I think this has to do with the huge amount of card text and the sheer number of pieces in the game. The game is well-designed but I feel it is out of reach for casual gamers. I have not yet tried the family version, perhaps it is more approachable. While I do like this game, it really does not feel original. Most of the mechanics were borrowed from other games. While is not possible to expect something fresh each time, I just didn't feel as amazed by the game. However, the theme is incredible. This game's theme is very very well integrated and very engaging. When all is said and done, I will still end up owning this game.

edit: Having played this game a couple more times, each time with a 5, 2 and solo player settings, I think this game is a very well-designed game. It also scales pretty well, including, surprisingly, the solo game. While the decisions are numerous, I feel like there is a distinct path to optimization. I must admit that without the cards in the family game, the game will get stale rather quickly. With the cards, the dynamics of the game changes quite bit. Thumbs up. The game is good, but falls short of the hype that it has received thus far. Pimping the game really does make the game play a little more aesthetically pleasing. 

7/11: Really did not like 5-player game at all. I think card draw is unbalanced. I actually enjoyed the family version much more right now. 
090211: Another 5 player game. This time, three players were tied! Without a tie breaker, it was rather frustrating.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I played the family version of this game 7 times before I moved onto Farmers of the Moor. I still haven't touched the occupations yet! 

This game is fantastic! It is definitely punishing when you first start playing. Once you're familiar with the tempo of the game, it has a wonderful puzzle like feature in trying to squeeze the most out of your limited actions.

I don't mind at all that the game seems to end just as you get your engine started, it just spurs me on to complete my engine before the final round!

My only regret with regards to this game is that I wish I didn't wait so long to try this game out. I didn't believe the hype, but boy oh boy, was I wrong. 

I don't think I could play another family game with just the base game. It's still Agricola but far and away a shadow of the great game it is.

Update: I've been wondering if without the expansion, this game isn't very good. The constant rush for wood and family growth are issues, and the fact that more workers equal more actions and even more points compounds the snowball effect. Without expansions, 3 player is a lot better than 4 player, though less tight. With 4, initial starting position is huge and the food difference is too small to mitigate.

I always play with the variant where the player who is coming second in turn order isn't allowed to take starting player. This variant removes the bickering over turn order between two players and prevents the person who had previously claimed first player to then suddenly find themselves in last position. Admittedly this is an issue in the 4+ player game but I've kept it when playing 3 player as well.

Expansions:
Farmers of the Moor
Gamer's Deck
World Championship Deck
Bielefeld Deck
France Deck

RATING: 7.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This really is an excellent game, for a lot of reasons. It scales from 1 to 5. It's got different potential complexity levels depending on whether or not you use the cards and which ones you use. It's got a good mix of long-term strategy (choosing occupations, planting fields early, picking complementary improvements) and tactical thinking (grabbing a fat resource pile, trying to figure out what your opponents' next actions are). It has enormous replay value with all the cards included. It has a reasonable playing time. It has cuddly animeeples.

But I think the biggest reason Agricola makes such a good impression on me is the relevance of the theme. I'm no farming enthusiast or anything, but I do find games a lot more fun when I can imagine a narrative going along with them, and Agricola is good for that. It also helps a lot with teaching the game and bringing in casual/non-gamers. Most of the rules make sense if you think about what's happening on the farm. And I must say that the various happenings in the game produce a lot of lively farm-related trash talk. Mechanically, Agricola is an excellent game, but for me it's the combination of those mechanics and the theme that make it really fun.

This is easily my favorite Euro that I've played. And, unlike some of the other "heavy" Euros I like, I've found it to be approachable enough to play with casual gamers, at least in 2-3 player games. Thus, I'll get to play this more often than something like T&E. 

Great game all around, highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I thoroughly enjoyed this game on iOS with over 100 plays.

My first few plays fell really flat. The game was dry and difficult. I stuck with it and started using the cards, which added variety and excitement to the game. Balancing feeding, growing, and upgrading is so rewarding.

I loved the game so much that I preordered Caverna, which is also a great game. But there is still something great about Agricola, so I ended up with a second hand copy, just in case ;)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I could blather a lot about how brilliant of a game Agricola is, but you've likely heard it all before.  I believe it takes the "worker placement" mechanic to the highest level of any game I've yet played.

This game also gets a big nod because of an eminently playable solo version.  In fact, some argue that the solo version is as enjoyable as playing against others.

The interaction with other players is largely limited to the worker placement mechanic - blocking their desired move.  There's also a bit of a "pass card to left" mechanic, but it's very minor and does not occur in every game - or even every other game.  I do like a bit more player interaction than Agricola provides.

The biggest challenge with us in terms of Agricola is total time - the time to set up, the time to play, and the time to put away.  With two young children at home, it's fairly rare for us to find time to do this, so instead we often save Agricola for game nights with friends.

I always like it when I play, and my brain feels tired afterward.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Clever interaction of time and resource management that makes running a preindustrial farm fun rather than tedious. As usual you have too much to do and not enough workers to do it - unless they build a spare room to house the kiddy and take a day off to... well, you know. It's a very different game from Uwe Rosenberg which, none the less, has the virtues of his designs - clever idea at the core (the expanding list of actions and the choice of expanding your family to take full advantage of them at the risk of having the one action you need stolen by another player), fairly quick player turns (play a worker, take the action), victory conditions that force diversification of strategy and intricate interactions between the action cards.

RATING: 9.5
the cards don't add replayability as much as they add randomness (not overpowering randomness, but they do cripple a lot of the "figure out what the other people need" part of the game- which is the primary form of interaction.  any time you could be blocked, you can almost always fix your bad play with the cards).  my rating drops 2 points when playing with the cards. the "family game" is the better way to play for gamers.  

and when playing it without cards, this is one of my favorites.  Pushes the boundaries of what you can reasonably parse while still keeping track of your opponents (sitting it right along the edge of challenge:skill for me, making it highly enjoyable), with heavy interaction if you actually understand the game.

RATING: 8
Most of my plays of this game have been two-player games.  With two players, I always feel like our games devolve into a battle for wood.  Because wood is so scarce, it's possible to get frozen out completely, in which case the game is really not very enjoyable.  Of course, a solid strategy is to deny your opponent access to the wood, but doing so makes things quite contentious.  It's still fun, but the angst caused by this kind of game really detracts from my opinion of Agricola as a two-player game.

RATING: 3
I am a bit puzzled about all the good ratings this game has received on boardgamegeek.
Granted:The game comes with a lot of nice components, but game play is actually quite boring, since there is almost no inter-action between the players. You are more or less exclusively concerned with your own board, there is almost no communication or even 'conflict' in the game.
The cards that you are dealt with at the beginning, more or less determine what you can do.
The theme is just not my cup of tea.
My rating is a 3.

RATING: 7.25

The biggest knock so far is that I'm having a hard time gauging how successful I'm being (mid-game) because of the non-intuitive scoring. 

Tried a couple more 2p games with my wife both family games....I won the first, but my wife creamed me the second.  

Tried the cards out, the first non-family version of the game.  I tried to formulate a strategy around my cards and it just tanked the rest of my game.  I'm overthinking this game...with too many plans and not enough family members to carry them out.  I need to find an efficient gameplan and how best to maximize my plays.  I think I could play this 100 times and still be striving to improve.  A really good game.

RATING: 6
Provisional rating, after just one play of the 'family' game. I'm not a great fan of the action-selection mechanism at the heart of Agricola (and recently Caylus and Pillars of the Earth, to name but two).  First, it's unthematic (if you choose to bake bread in your oven, why can't I do so too?) and more seriously second, for each moment of pleasure when I take a thing I need, there are several of frustration and dismay when you take the thing I needed also.  Still, I liked Agricola better than either Caylus or Pillars, and look forward to playing the Full version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It's certainly personal preference, but I enjoy the paired down All Creatures Big and Small much more, and Tzolk'in overall if I want a meatier experience.

RATING: 8.5

Be aware not to rely too much on your cards and fall short of actions to improve elsewhere.

What I also like is, how differently it plays with changing player numbers.

This one is a highly tactical, optimize your points game- So far: brilliant game.

Update: After some more plays and some time, there are other games which interests me more nowadays. Agricola tends to value wood too high, while other ressources are less valuable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Agricola is amazing. We have played it with a wide range of people. People who aren't that into board games have enjoyed it. People who love board games adore it.  In our opinion it is not that complicated - we play it with the 2 sets of cards right away with new players and they get it.  If they don't you can always go to the family version.  

Don't use the rules to explain it show them with a couple of farms as demos. Once you play a few times it becomes second nature. It's a pretty basic concept after all: build your farm and feed your family. Just get the rules down and you will want to play again and again and again. 

The more you play the more things suggest themselves to you and you wind up trying out all kinds of different things.  Thinking about what to do, being thwarted, switching plans mid-gear, experimenting all add to the fun.   I think the timing might be slightly off at 30 minutes per person it seems it takes a bit longer especially in 2 player version - but on the other hand that doesn't matter because time flies when you're playing it.  In fact it seems the final round is always there before you know it.  Highly recommended.

RATING: 7.5
After first inspection, the game seems great, but you will eventually discover that the game has a fatal flaw.  Sometimes just dealing out the minor improvements and occupations will win the game for someone, as there are combinations that are just too powerful.

One solution to this is to draft occupations.  Another is play with the Farmers of the Moor expansion.

Personally, I prefer to play Le Havre (which I've rated 9.5) or Ora Et Labora (I've rated 9.8) instead.   In my opinion, those are superior games.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was hard to rate because I enjoyed "learning" the game a lot (the first couple of plays), as well as the solo play (initially), but I feel it gets VERY repetitive VERY fast.
The major fail for me is the scoring system and the fact that while there are multiple paths to "sustainance" (vegetables/bread/animals...), in the end there are not really different paths to victory: everyone must do a bit of everything; I much prefer a game where there are very "distinct" yet balanced paths to victory (shipping vs building in Puerto Rico would be the poster-child).
it's a long game and when I'm done playing I always feel like I had to make more actions due to the game constraints (be it for feeding, or needing resources for house/famillly growth, or to comply with scoring) than startegy-oriented and stratgey-rewarding choices.

[+] a lot to do but everything makes sense, good mechanics, art, components (theme is rather boring to me but I can understand many people like it), I like the tension around food
[-] very fiddly between rounds (have to add 1/2 resources on each card... that's why I'll play exclusively on iOS), very strange scoring, takes multiple plays to get to know the cards that will come up (it's important) and understand the "value" of each resource/spot and "timing"/flow of the game; I always feel the endgame is boring, not much to do in the last round(s) except getting stuff to comply with the scoring... plus counting up points just at the end (fiddly in itself) is pretty anti-climactic as well.
the more players there are, the more it feels that everyone is just playing sub-optimally, because everyone will have to do a bit of everything (due to the scoring system), and not everyone can do everything at the best moment, so in the end everyone scores "low" and the winner is the one that scored the less low (instead of the highest)

Solo play: I enjoyed playing a couple of solo series (when you have to reach 50, 55, 60...pts and keep 1 permanent card after each win); unfortunately just like the game itself, the best part of playing the solo serie are the early choices you make (what card to save in the 1st 3 solo games), after that the games start to feel very same-y, repetitive, tension-lacking and pretty random when you have to score 65+/70+ pts, having a couple minor improvements that score points is a huge help (but randommely drawn so...)

play on iOS, enjoyed for a bit, but became repetitive fast. I suspect additional decks are the answer but I'm not convinced.

RATING: 5
I have gotten less enthused with this game with every play.  I find it to be an exercise in frustration every time.  I feel severely hindered by the other players in a way which really leaves a bad taste in my mouth.  Usually, I like player interaction, but in this game it really bothers me.  Perhaps it's the theme?  It doesn't make much sense that only one player can plow a field, or have kids.  God forbid two women in this imaginary civilization get pregnant at the same time, [i]because clearly the entire world will implode[/i].  Feeding my family isn't fun, it's annoying.  The points system is an arbitrary endgame falsehood.  The cards are annoying.  Everything about this production is what's wrong with Euros.  This game is not worth the hype.  Sigh.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
One of the reasons I play board games, is to escape life. Agricola is too much like life for me to enjoy. You look around and see all the cool actions that you could do, but most of your actions will be focused on just keeping your family fed. With Agricola, like life, you scratch out a meager existence on your farmyard until that final harvest. I really like the components and the idea of the game, but man, is it frustrating. Maybe I'm just terrible at it. And now that I have Caverna, I see no need to ever play this again.

If you're wondering, I have played this game more times than I can remember.

RATING: 2
You're building the same farm every game folks! Braindead scoring system forces most games to end up looking nearly identical, everyone gets some of everything, cows, sheep, wood, veggies, pastures, stables... Cards provide illusion of depth, but just changes what your workers provide vs cards. IE, one card gives you stone, so your worker goes on cows. Next game a card helps with cows, so your worker goes on stone, etc.

The game is tolerable with house rules that fix the silly scoring system, but still too samey to play more than once a year.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I generally like worker placement and economic games.  I also like the fact that there are so many things to do. I think that the cards are interesting, but it can be frustrating that you really can't play very many of your occupations if you want to do well. 

The game is attractive, and I like the overall flavor and farming theme.  

There can be a little too much detailed calculation.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
LOVE agricola, but it is very hard for new players to get into, even with "family" variant. Scoring is not apparent until you play the game at least once. It's confusing to have references to actions that aren't on the field yet - I have to constantly explain to puzzled looks of newbies "that will be available later".

Basically it's a great game if you manage to get into it, but it's very easy to get bored over the introductory playthrough.

Bonus for wooden animal meeples, those things are adorable.

RATING: 9

Agricola has the strongest theme I have ever seen in a game: every thing you do makes sense. Mechanics are fun and never annoying, and present you plenty of meaningful choices.

Games with >3 people tend to be a bit too long for me though. When playing boardgames 2h are enough for me.

RATING: 8
Rated after four games. After the first every-deck-and-rule-in-the-box game I was "Awwwhhh", after the second family-game-with-nothing-extra I was "Yeaah" and then the third and fourth game with four players and some cards I was still "Yeah". I think that it is good to play the first couple of games with family game and simpler rules and then use the advanced things step by step. This seems to be a good game, I'd like to play this more, once I played the basic game. After couple of games (with good experience), this could even be 9.

I really like the intuitive game mechanics - the things you think would be good to do on a farm bring you points and so on. The game mechanics is good, after that it is a matter if you like to game or not.

The latest game was a two player game with E- and I-decks and my feeling is still "Yeah", very clever game.
The latest latest game was with two players with all the decks, still yeah. Once you get the basic mechanics and learn to use cards after couple of games, then it doesn't really matter how many decks or cards are included.
The latest play at the moment was four player family game, still yeah!

Add six two player plays with family rules during one weekend and you can still hear me yeah! So many plays with family rules make me want to play with cards, the options and tactics are quite limited with family rules especially with two players.

Four more family plays with two players, getting tougher, waiting for the cards. Also, we have played the starting player square a little bit wrong, need to be careful in the future.

One four player play with family rules. I was too tired to enjoy or focus, but still a good game.

RATING: 7
** Rating decreased to 6 after playing ACBAS and Caverna. I prefer games where I can plot my moves without thinking 'how do I feed, how do I feed' every single turn.

***

Rating increased from 7 to 9.5 after further plays with the Minor/Major improvement cards. I generally hate procedural economic euros, but this one is so thematically consistent, cheery and charming (especially with my custom Fimo meeples) that I can't help loving it.

***

A thematically-strong farming simulation. If you enjoy Farmville or Nintendo's Harvest Moon series of computer games, you'll enjoy this.

Agricola falls over itself to be welcoming to a variety of player groups with, for example, rules for a simpler family variant included in the box.

The game is easy to learn because the theme is consistent with the mechanics. The rule book is colourful and easy to understand. 

Despite the lack of combat, Agricola is surprisingly interactive. You can stop other players getting the resources they need because only one player can take the same action each turn. What's more, you can physically see their farm and family growing five-strong in a stone mansion while you struggle to feed two wooden discs in a straw house.

The cards and bits are attractive with appealing cartoony graphics. The card stock is thick and rugged. My only question is why they provided unshaped wooden cubes/discs for the sheep, farmers, etc. Surely the budget could have stretched to shaping the meeples. I'm going to make some pieces from Fimo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Enjoyable worker placement game.  Occupations and Minor Improvements give enough variability that different strategies are required for each game.
