=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As an 'antidote' to the plethora of UK Expo play-test games, I was invited to try a this board game about farm and homesteading in central Europe in the late seventeenth century and has nothing to do with the Roman general. Not versed in Latin, it was explained to me that the Roman general's family were farmers -
hence the game title - so I considered myself thankful for having learned another piece of information in one game session. The rules were well-explained, but not overdone, so that enabled the three of us who had not played before to pick up the mechanics fairly easily.  

Making farming exciting was always going to be a tough ask, as it is not a theme that I'd rave about, but I was prepared to try it and it does have multiple strategy options which is good from the perspective of long-term playbility. Each player (farmer)  begins with a wooden shack with your spouse (no partnerships back then) and little else. There are two actions allowable to each farmer - one for each of his own piece and that of his spouse - although the patter of tiny feet is never far away as this procreation was certainly the winning strategy of our game. these can include collecting clay, wood, or stone; building fences; and so on. 

Rolling around in muck and worrying about starvation are clearly fun things from that era....Before children can be provided for, each farmer needs to extend his house to allow one room for each person, although interestingly the mechanics encourage sharing rooms with an assortment of available farm animals. I did not think it was that kind of game until the context of homes of multiple occupancy is taken on board.....Make no mistake, kids are only born out of love and affection, not for use as slave labour to toil on your farm, because that would be entirely inappropriate, and those cold nights leave you with idle hands otherwise....

No children were overworked during the course of our game as only one player maximised his family with  three children but let's not read too much into that cold nights thing. The range of game options cover a whole host of other things like going to market, building hovel improvements and taking up new occupations, which in my case were as a consultant and yokel priest, both of which distracted me from my duties of farming, muck-raking and procreation, but not necessarily in that order! A facet of the game I do like, in spite of the theme, is that it does make you think about trying differing combinations of activity selections next time.

So, I would try this game again, for sure. It would not be one where I would claim, "That was Agricola. Let us never speak of it again". Honest. Two features that are very important to the game are both the  minor Improvements, and as already mentioned, occupations, where each farmer starts with six each of these. There is a degree of randomness as to their comparative uses, although in fairness, that is part of discovering the range of cards and combining them with the strategies suggested by the occupations available. to you. Agricola is a turn-based game spread over fourteen turns so it is a finite time and each farmer will take x number of actions according to the number of family members they have in their family hovel. 

Harvests occur during the course of the game, and this is when you pray to heaven that there is enough food to go round, so as a first time player, I made sure i had enough to the detriment of other strategies but a beggar I was not. Glad I spelled that word correctly.....These occur on the fourth, seventh, ninth, eleventh, thirteenth and fourteenth turn ends. One key aspect of the game is that each action can be taken by only one player each round, so it's important to do some things with high preference, and taking the first player option is one tactic to ensure this as it means the greatest choice. There are countless strategies, some depending on your card hand, and others on your experience playing the game. 

Certainly a game with layer upon layer of strategies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
OK, so is this game all that, or is it just hype?  The way folks are going on and on about it, you'd think this was Jesus in boardgame format, and that this was his second coming.  Make it a little scarce, give it some exclusivity with some pre-release bonuses, etc., and you've created the perfect storm for a bunch of boardgaming geeks.  But how is it, REALLY?

Truth be told, it's not bad.  It has an interesting system, which reminds me a bit of Puerto Rico with its role selection, a bit of Pillars of the Earth with its placement system, and a bit of Age of Steam with the angst that comes about from timing when to pick the best role, based on the timing of the game and what others can do before it gets back to your turn.  It's tight and squeezy, which are two things that I like in my games.  If the game is punishing you and you're still struggling to stay afloat, then it's a good game.

Another good thing going for this game is its replayability.  At most, you're only ever going to see 70 cards per game, and there are 372 cards between the decks.  That the selections change slightly with different numbers of players gives the game that much more of a lifetime, and I can see this game being fresh and enjoyable for many, many plays.

I'm not keen on it as a 2-player game, just because the choices are so limited.  You have to understand how weird it is for me to say that; usually, I don't like games as they creep up toward the upper end of the player limit, because the added players tend to add a lot of chaos.  With Agricola, though, the added choices for the additional players make a big difference in what you can plan to do.  With only one space to collect wood, clay, and reed, respectively, it makes your choices only that much more critical, and it sometimes leaves you with some very suboptimal choices to make.  That being said, the game is balanced well with 2 players, so it's hard to criticize that version of the game, since clearly a lot of thought was put into its development.  It's just not much to my tastes.

I have a minor gripe with the primary strategy of the game changing each game, due to the random card draw.  It's easy to see one player get the cards needed to get some tremendous engine going, while someone else in the game gets a handful of random cards that don't meld together as easily.  It might throw the balance of the game off, but time will tell.

It ain't Jesus, but it's at least the Pope.

6 plays: 1 player
1 play: 2 players
3 plays: 3 players
6 plays: 4 players
2 plays: 5 players

-----

Base game
Farmers of the Moor
Gamers' Deck
Legen*dairy Forest Deck
Through the Seasons
CZ-Deck
L-Deck
Ö-Deck
X-Deck
Z-Deck

RATING: 10
A brain burner for sure.. just the way I like them. It seems though that the drunker I am when I play it, the more I own people :)

As I have been gaining experience with a number of board games, I've come to realise one of the greatest strengths of this game - sustained suspense, the quality that makes a 2+ hour session go by in a flash, simply due to the fact that it's so exciting from the word go.

Other games have clever systems, yes, but their suspense factor fails. Take Power Grid, for example (a past favourite of mine). Unless there is a slave driver relentlessly announcing each step in each turn or unless the players are remarkably disciplined, the game breaks down into a cacophony of non-game related chatter. Now, I know some people don't mind this, but I personally prefer to focus on the game itself and chat later, when it's over.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In Agricola, you're a farmer in a wooden shack with your spouse and little else. On a turn, you get to take only two actions, one for you and one for the spouse, from all the possibilities you'll find on a farm: collecting clay, wood, or stone; building fences; and so on. You might think about having kids in order to get more work accomplished, but first you need to expand your house. And what are you going to feed all the little rugrats?
\13\\13\
Agricola is a turn-based game. There are 14 game turns plus 6 harvest phases (after turn 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, and 14).
Each player starts with two playing tokens (farmer and wife) and thus can take two actions per turn. There are multiple options, and while the game progresses, you'll have more and more: first thing in a turn, a new action card is flipped over.
\13\\13\
Problem: Each action can be taken just once per turn, so it's important to do some things with high preference.
Each player also starts with a hand of 7 job cards (of more than 160 total) and 7 item cards (of more than 140 total) that he/she may use during the game if they fit in his/her strategy. Speaking of which, there are countless strategies, some depending on your card hand. Sometimes it's a good choice to stay on course, and sometimes it is better to react to your opponents' actions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The best part about it is that unlike chess, my family is actually willing to play it with me!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Agricola is a strange beast. The theme is, at first glance, far from exciting. The mechanics are pretty dry (fill up the board with cubes, take turns removing them) and the game's scoring can be brutally unforgiving. It's been tossed around here on the geek (Originally by Tom Vasel, I believe...) that a game of Agricola isn't a competition to take the best action available but instead revolves around a race to make the selection that will hurt you the least. That has certainly been the case in my experience, as there are just too many things that need your attention and not enough time to get them done. That does add plenty of tension, but not everyone enjoys it when the tension crosses over into stress. Agricola comes close to doing that at times. As a result, some people are less than enthusiastic to see it on games day, because to them, it feels too much like work.

The strangest part about Agricola is that despite all these intense and punishing moments, the game can still appeal to one's sense of make-believe. Even considering all of the unrealistic game mechanics (Seriously? Only one person in the whole village gets to chop wood at a time?), it still FEELS like you're running a farm...and for some reason, that's a lot of fun.

The cards are the game's most interesting feature. There are hundreds and you only get to use a small fraction of them in any particular game. This let's you approach each play with a slightly different set of tools to use in conquering the game's challenges. I think this is the reason Agricola has enjoyed such a meteoric rise up the BGG ranks. The cards are an extremely clever way to add almost infinite variety to what would have been a very simple and one-dimensional experience without them. I expect more games to follow suit, as the concept is a good one.

RATING: 9
Who would've thought a game about farming could be this much fun? The resources are somehow at the perfect balance; they're tight enough that you can never really do everything you want, but loose enough that I've never seen anyone involuntarily take a begging card. The metagame about getting in opponents' heads is great fun, and the cards take a game that probably would've gotten stale and give it a huge amount of replayability. It's deep enough to satisfy gamers, but intuitive enough that I've been able to play it with non-gamers and have them enjoy it. About the only downside to it is that it's very fiddly, easy to make mistakes during setup and between rounds, and difficult to have more than one person laying things out, so that downtime is a little higher than would be ideal.

RATING: 10
I think this is the finest game ever designed.  It's all about the cards, and the endless deployability they provide.  You should always do some sort of draft to take advantage of them.

I do very much dislike how important the race for the first family growth is.  I mean, I really, really dislike it and applaud Caverna's way of ameliorating it.

I also dislike how the end game scoring discourages specialization.  The result is that everyone's farm ends up looking roughly the same.

Despite those flaws, my brain is on fire the whole time I play Agricola.  I love the tension it provides and how strategic it is.

----------------------
So far so good.  Wish there was a bit more uncertainty/variety in the basic actions (and speak of the devil, the seasons expansion helps a bit with this), but I understand the choice.  The huge variety of cards and potential combos is just fantastic; more euros need this kind of expansiveness.  More strategic variation would improve the game, as there's a bit too much clustering to achieve a balanced approach.

I don't ever see this being a 10 for me, but it's very good, very tight, just a few personal nits here and there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After reading the hype on this game for over a year on BGG, my first play left me extremely disappointed.  I expected something mind-blowingly original, something that felt unlike anything I'd ever played before.  Instead, it felt like just another worker placement game.

Once I got past that initial disappointment, however, I realized that, mind-blowing though it may not be, it is a very good worker placement game.

The game has a nice complexity.  It's complex enough to feel deep and mechanically interesting while simple enough to teach new players without making their heads explode.  I think this is largely thanks to the good integration of theme--aside from the worker placement aspect (which is easy to explain on its own), most of the way the game works can be easily hung on thematic hooks.  This is how theme should work in Eurogames.

Overall, a very good game that I'm still enjoying immensely, and one that should keep hitting the table for quite a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Phenomenal game, just brilliant. I still think that Agricola is Uwe Rosenberg's magnum opus. And it just keeps getting better with each subsequent play (especially with the Farmers of the Moor and Gamers' Deck expansions added). I love the tightness of this design and the interrelation between the theme and the mechanics - everything is intuitive and makes perfect sense. The best thing about this game is the challenge of managing scarce resources and figuring out the most effective ways of using the cards in your hand. This puzzle is just a fascinating, brain-burning delight. But keep in mind that this is a "I wonder if I can do this better, quicker and more efficiently next time" type of game. Optimization is the heart of Agricola, so if you don't like designs like that, you probably won't enjoy this one. 

By the way, Agricola works exceptionally well as a solo game! It's a really challenging puzzle.

The only drawback I can think of is the constant need for repleneshing goods - this gets a bit too fiddly, especially late game.

[i]I own the following expansions: Farmers of the Moor, Gamers' Deck.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very good game, scales very well, good with or without cards.

RATING: 8
On Preorder from Zman - and it sounds like there's a good chance that it'll be with Animeeples!  What about Veggimeeples ;) Agricolated,  and made up my mind to buy it.  Solid game - it's no RftG,  but I guess not everything can have an awesome Sci-Fi Theme...Family game was interesting enough,  looks like it can only get better with the cards.  Hard to say whether the family game can be "solved" though.  

A little bit later,  now with my own copy - game is growing on me (started off pretty good above), gripes mostly limited to the "why wasn't the super starter deck labeled as such" and the post-Stone Age "resources can be different, intuitive shapes!"

Or maybe they should have included a sticker pack...

A bunch of plays later:  A very good game,  the cards keep the mechanisms fresh.  A lot of the cards feel broken,  although the actual benefit of cards is often much less than they appear.  Undoubtedly will swing the game between equally skilled players,  but the experience of building the farm is an interesting exercise in and of itself,  and getting a "broken combo" is just a bit of a bonus.  Active denial of good actions is probably necessary to keep other players in check,  but that starts getting away from the actual fun bit of building your farm...

RATING: N/A
Filter
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like many people I suspect, I initially avoided this game because it's about 18th century farming which, sorry, sounds really boring.  I let my friend in my weekly game night group go ahead and get this one so I could save my money for the likes of Terra Mystica or 7 Wonders.  However, this game is anything but boring.  It includes all of the elements I look for in games: multiple ways to win, the ability to mess with other players, relatively low luck involved to win (with the exception of the Minor Improvement and Occupation cards), and, most importantly, you don't really know who won until the end of the game, so you don't spend the whole game feeling frustrated rather than having fun.  Right after playing this game I ran out and got Caverna (which I prefer slightly, I know I'm in the minority here).  You can't go wrong with either one. Play this game!

I have only two small complaints about this game.  First and most importantly, players' turns can take a while.  There are so many choices, and every choice means you don't make the other choices; it can result in over thinking.  In a 4-5 player game, I usually see people get distracted when it's not their turn.  
My second complaint is with the game's double-edged sword, the aspect that in the minds of most players puts this game above Caverna.  The random distribution of the Minor Improvement cards and the Occupation cards are usually fun and make the game feel different every time.  But every now and then, one player gets a really killer combo of cards (or I get complete crap!) and it makes the game unfair.  Not terribly unfair, but in a group of skilled gamers, it can decide the winner.  Not always, but I've had it happen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Nog niet doorgrond spel,  dus heel goed !!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Agricola is a game I really want to love.  We played it so many times in our game group.  There are a few that do actually love it.  There are others, like me, that really like the ideas and concepts that the game has, but find the game painful more often than not to play.  There are almost always very reasonable ways to make food and get points a variety of different ways so what the game ends up boiling down to most often is who can get the family growth first.  The first two players to get it are highly favored to win in most of the games we have played.  So the first few rounds of the game are people positioning to build the house expansion followed by positioning to family growth.  Once you are behind in this game in workers, it is nearly impossible to come back.  You don't always need to have the most workers to win, but the person that gets the first extra worker often has a very significant advantage.  

Playing with the cards can help, but it can also make the game even more lopsided.  At a 2 hour play time, if you are one of the people behind, you have 1.5 more hours of losing before you get to start another game.  For those in the race for the win, it can be fun.  I'd almost appreciate a player elimination rather than having to play a game for 2 hours that I know is improbable for me to win at that point.  I'm just messing up other peoples chances of winning through what I take rather than actually being able to appreciably increase the chance of me winning.  And yet I still want to like this game...

Luckily there is Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small and Caverna.  I think both are a better than Agricola and scratch the same itch.  Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small is great for when you have a shorter time period.  I also love that you have a fixed number of workers so there isn't this "action economy" imbalance you have to worry about.  Caverna does better at scratching the same itch as Agricola when you want to play a heavier game.  It plays 2 hours or so, but fixes the issues I have with Agricola.  There are so many options each round, there often isn't a key spot that everyone is fighting for all the time (reed then family growth).  Instead there are lots of routes and timings you can take and still be reasonably in the game without having to a certain thing at a certain time.  I do wish that Caverna had a bit of a randomization more than just the harvest schedule so that each play was a bit more unique and interesting, but I would still play Caverna over Agricola any day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In my opinion this games biggest success is also it's biggest failing. The huge assortment of cards make for an interesting and new experience every time but it also brings up balance questions as some cards combo to be nearly unstoppable and some cards are just flat better in every way than other cards.

Sadly I don't believe this game could ever be a 9 or 10 to me due to my frustrations over the imbalance of the cards.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Building a farm...nah...it's all about making the most POINTS! You have a farm in front of you and you will make your points through building a type of farm. It uses worker placement and has wood.

The real mettle of this game though, for me, is the cards. The cards that you get at the beginning of the game, the ones that will be a different bunch each time you play. Finding a workable, good combination of the cards is half of the real fun of Agricola...building your farm to get points is the other half.

Together this has truly earned its high status among the BGG crowd. 

More good news...it can be played in an easy, accessible family mode, or in the full throttle mode. It can be enjoyed solo, or with 4-5 more! I have to admit that playing solo is do-able, but not as fun. I suppose one could make that call for any solo-able game though.

In short, it's a good game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Probably my second favourite board game. Family appears to love it, which is good as there are a lot of non-gamers in it. Would easily recommend this as a gateway game because of the easier to understand family game variant. I very much respect the amount of time and effort gone into playtesting this game.

Main gripe I have is the quality of components. I really don't think It would have been that hard to provide more(especially wood) or to make them look like the intended objects. The fact that people "pimp" their Agricola or make a fuss about getting animeeples says it all.

RATING: 9.1
Fun Factor: 22/25
Replay Value: 25/25
Strategy: 19/20
Component Quality: 9/10
Rules: 9/10
Theme: 3/5
Originality: 4/5

Total Score: 91/100

Comments: I love this game. For me, this is the bench mark for all other resource management euro games. The added variety of occupation cards and minor improvements is staggering. The solo player is good, but playing against others is where it's at! I am hard pressed to find fault with this gem. The theme doesn't quite do it for me, but it does make it more approachable for non-gamers like my wife. Hands down, the most well rounded, challenging, fulfilling and enjoyable game I own!

RATING: 7
From my Bokkenrijder 19 Juli 2012

Agricola was my first foray into gaming. I now have an account on BoardGameGeek and a smaller bank account due to all the games I have now purchased, so they must have done something right in Agricola development.

The game has seamless rule construction, and I like that you can still win by using your head, rather than by decimating your opponent. 
 
It is aesthetically lacking, as the plane colored blocks make me feel like I am back in preschool.

RATING: 4

In short: The life of a farmer, even with card-driven replayability and a fifth of bathtub hooch, is still the life of a farmer. Seriously, the highlight of my Agricola experience was when I upgraded my fireplace to a kettle.

The copy I played didn't come with crack.  Did everyone else's?

RATING: 7
Lots going on here. To much for me. House, plowed fields, fenced fields, grain and vegetables, number of family members, occupations, minor and major improvements, 3 types of livestock, stables and maybe some other stuff. You have to maximize your farm to the best of your ability. I found it frustrating and I really slow the game down. The learning curve on how to fit everything together will be there. I started seeing how things fit together after about the 6th round of the first family game but still cannot see how all the occupations and improvements work together. Rating after 8 plays over 9 years.

RATING: 7.5
Played a few times (with 3 to 5 players - as well as a few solo plays). A very interesting game, with many choices, lots of things to do, and an impressive apparent replayability due to the number of different cards. Scalability seems good as well, and the components are very nice. However, the scoring system introduces constraints which I don't like (the penalties for not having a bit of everything are too harsh to ignore), and familty growth is probably too important, both in the game itself and in scoring. There might be concerns with the balance of cards, too, but I haven't played enough to really judge about it.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game can seem very overwhelming at first, but after you get a few rounds into it things start to flow very smoothly.

Once you get the hang of it, this becomes an excellent game.   Lots of strategy and tons of replay value.  There are thousands of possible card combinations, and because of how the board is set up it becomes a very different game depending on how many players you have - it scales really well from five players all the way  down to just one.

The initial card draws can sometimes be a little unbalancing, so if you don't like that you could do a draft for the cards instead, or forget the cards entirely and stick with the "family game" version of the rules which still provides a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Family game:  Played a 2p with my 8-year-old; he loved it.  Played a 2p with wife; she liked it a lot (and she doesn't play many games).  My initial rating is 8; it has room to go up or down.

I've now played it 6 times (in the first 5 days that I owned it).  My family loves it, and I'm enjoying it too.  The three-player game is noticeably different from the two-player game, and each time we've played the game has proceeded differently.  It remains interesting.  I'm looking forward to playing with some of the decks soon.

Full game:  Played 2 games with the E Deck, one 3p and one 2p.  Definitely more brutal than the family game, but opens up even more possibilities for play.

What has impressed me so far about both the family and full games is that, every time you play, the game feels different.  That the game pulls this off with such a clean rule set is amazing.  Rating up to 9.

10/29/10:  Started to run out of steam with repeated play.  Still a very good game, but not quite a 9.

RATING: 10
A very complex game -- not for the weak of heart.

A game of "So much to do, so little time."  Since you can't do everything, you have to pick your battles.  And when people pick what you wanted to do, the tension really builds.

This game gets more intense (read: better) the more people are playing.  Also, playing with the cards is better than the family version.  The cards are what really make the game different from one game to the next.  Also, the more players the better occupations become available.

This game in a word?  Awesometacular.

RATING: 7
I really like how this captures the tightness of competitive min maxing, *BUT* defers the scoring and the turgid part of min maxing until the end. Lesson to be learned here in fun...

Also for the economists in the crowd the fact that only one worker can work a role effectively creates a nice model for barrier of entry economics (compared to the terrain competition of roads and boats barrier model which feels like too easy a path of entry to me)

RATING: 9
Game play weight of 'Medium Heavy' for the full game. 'Medium weight' is more appropriate for the family game variant.

The full game demonstrates exactly what type of gameplay elements I love in games. I like games where planning is useful, where you try to be extremely efficient. I like games where you build something from scratch (I like looking at the farms people built at the end of the game). I like where prople can develop different strategies, based on the card they got at the start of the game.

I like the family version less then the full version, not because its bad or less fun to play, but because it makes me want to play the full game continuously. And it keeps reminding me that playing one of my favorites games is sometimes just too taxing for my fellow players :(

RATING: 9
Not as complex as it seems, but very thought-heavy. Well designed worker placement with excellent replay value in the cards. Very tight, competitive gameplay. The cards work well to kind of steer you towards a strategy or make certain aspects a bit easier.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great family game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is a family favorite. A lot of strategy and replayability.  The 14 random Minor Improvement and Occupation Cards (7 of each) that each player starts with forces you to adjust your strategy with each new game.  The written directions are really a challenge to make sense out of.  We had to go on YouTube and watch a video explanation to figure it out.  The game is deep but not as difficult as the manual may lead you to think at first.  The game actually sat on the shelf for 2 months before I actually forced myself to learn it.  It is a 1 to 5 person game, so you can sit and tinker with it solataire style if you like.  The games are long, but in a sneaky kind of way.  You don't realize how long you've played.  A 2-3 person game is probably doable in a 1.5 to 2 hour timeframe.  4-5 person games can go for 3 hours.  A good party game though, no one gets eliminated, so everyone is in the game the entire time.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game! Always hard to stop thinking of different strategies when we're done playing.

The big downside is that it is a little bit dry and a little on the long side which makes it less fun with people who are not enthusiastic about it.  (but with people who really enjoy the game it is a fantastic time)

RATING: 10
{ P - 2 [3] 4 5 }

Drastically improved with Farmers of the Moor. The action cards and home heating requirement help offset the strength of Family Growth and new major improvements provide more options and depth. Starting with forests and moors rather than empty farmland makes for tougher decisions about how to fill up your board. Tons of unique minor improvements and occupations offer endless replayability once you remove all the broken and/or useless ones.

RATING: 9.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A decent worker placement game with some serious shortcomings. 
The Good:
Theme
Cardplay
Theme
Decent selection of choices that diversify as the game plays on

However, the main negative of this game comes from the diversity of play and the frustration of worker amount. You can only get a realistic max of 5 workers and if you play with more than 3 it becomes nearly impossible to do this. The game also demands that you accomplish every milestone rather than focus your efforts on certain goals. This is somewhat alleviated by the ability to use cards to focus your strategy but for me the game becomes stale very fast and works infinitely better as an app than a game given the amount of pieces. Just not worth my time as a game. I'd give the app a 5

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has a steep learning curve. Have patience and try to play one or two games with the rules in hand. Or better yet, have a experienced friend to guide you along. 

Once you get the basic rules in your head, this game is bags of fun and very replayable. The replayability part comes from the different (occupation and minor improvement) cards you draw at the beginning of the game. These will help determine your strategy for the game.

My Significant Other and I have invited lots of friends over to play Agricola and not one of them have found it boring! Several of them have even gone on to purchase a copy of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Sometimes one player would get handed a solid strategy while another would get a total lack of synergy. In retrospect I would have liked to have played with card drafting at the beginning.

< August 2012 sold Jan 2014 - got Caverna instead

RATING: 6
Worker placement type game where there is always more actions that need to be done than there is selections you can make. Uses a farming theme that fits the game play very well. Each space has an obvious use and resources build up over time - making spaces more valuable. 

Easy to teach.
Rewards doing a bit of everything rather than specialising in only one or two things.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
very solid game, tight gameplay, superb bits and boards, 1 of my 3 "Bring 'em into the hobby" games as a great next step after gateway games...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
King of optimization games. Can be played just for fun too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This was a completely lukewarm experience for me. Nothing great here, nothing truly new, innovative or never-seen-before, but nothing (quite yet) overused. Suffers from Option Blur -- too many directions you can move in, and too many things that need to be accomplished by the end of the game. So even on turn one, you already need a pretty clear plan on how you're going to pursue things. Evaluating the different actions is extremely difficult - because you have no clear-cut context for what is inherently more important or valuable than something else. Competition and Screw Factor feels completely arbitrary. Early on a decision can completely derail another person. There's not necessarily any game context for it. No real reason, just arbitrary shit-disturbing. Felt like a hodge podge of things I've already seen in Caylus, Stone Age and even Age of Steam. I suppose I'd play again, but there are a LOT of other games I'd prefer to play first. I simply do not "see" what the rabid fans of this game see.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very good game; worth most of the hype. Extremely well balanced. Works well with all stated numbers of players: it's a little dry with one player, but still a good game. Very nice and involving theme for such a strategic game.

RATING: N/A
Описание: Строительство средневековой фермы
Суть: Сбор ресурсов, проработанное расширение фермы, конкуренция игроков за приказы и участки, борьба с нехваткой еды и всего остального.
Сложность: выше среднего, объясняется за 30 минут.
Игроков: 2-5, игра сильно меняется в зависимости от числа игроков, но в любом варианте она очень хороша.
Тип: стратегия 70%, тактика 15%, удача 10%, дипломатия 5%
Длительность: 1-2,5 часа в зависимости от количества игроков
Оформление: очень хорошее.

Отличная игра. Каждая партия отличается от остальных даже при том же числе игроков, а уж если число игроков меняется, то и вся тактика изменится. Каждый ход приходится принимать интересные и важные решения. Каждый раз хочется построить идеальную ферму и, естественно, не получается и хочется попытаться опять.
Играл только в «семейную/детскую версию» во «взрослую» не играл.

RATING: 7
This is probably the best Euro I have ever played.  There are a ton of options, its very tense, and there are many paths to victory.

Another really important aspect for me, is that the theme does not feel pasted on at all.  I really feel like I am a farmer barely scraping by, just trying to support my family through the next harvest.

I don't really own anything like it so it feels completely fresh to me.  

Sometimes sessions can be a little too intense, thus we don't pull this one out very often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife and I bought this game, drawn in by the agriculture theme. We played through it about 5 or 6 times without using the career cards or the minor improvements, wanting to first become comfortable with the basic game mechanics. At the end of the 6th play, we were worried we were going to be bored with the game.

Then we added in the career cards and minor improvements, and suddenly the strategic possibilities exploded. The cards really increase the game's replay value as you will likely never get the same set of cards from game to game to game.

I also really appreciate the way the game board adapts to the number of players. This makes a fantastic 2 player game (which is the main reason I bought it), but also works really well with more.

I definitely recommend it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After seeing all the 10 ratings here on BGG and the prizes this game has won, I wonder if I really played the same game. This is a monster. It's huge and there's a lot to take in on a first play. I must say I'm never a big fan of these kind of cube pushers, or resource optimization games or worker placement games, or whatever you call them. Caylus did nothing for me either and I can only stomach Cathedral and Stone Age because they are so well designed and streamlined. Streamlined is not a word that is applicable to Agricola. There's a ton of resources and then a ton of extra powers too. It's just not a lot of fun. I do stuff and I don't care. If I play a two hour+ game I want to conquer the world not plant a friggin' vegetable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I'm happy to report that Agricola is just as good as most people have claimed it to be.  Even though the game was low on interaction (since you're just building and trying to diversify your own farm, only the resources and actions are being competed with), I didn't mind it because I was too busy doing my own thing.  The 4-player session I participated went by really fast, no one took an extraordinarily long time to make their decisions, and by the time when I've finally got a workable engine going, it was already next to the last round!  The game will sneak by you if you don't pay attention and plan carefully ahead.  In retrospect I took a handful of choices that could've been better spent elsewhere.

To be sure there is a randomness factor in the kind of cards you are dealt, and while it would be great to get occupations and improvements that have synergy with each other, I think half of the fun is to do the best with the hand you are given.  Agricola did not seem particularly heavy to me, and should have a wide appeal.

Update #1: This is the second time I've witnessed people running out of useful options to do in the very last round.  So they could have taken actions that others still needed.  While that is a perfectly valid strategy, but it seems like against the spirit of the game, since defensive plays isn't really what Agricola is about.

Update #2: I commented in a thread recently that I really hate the ambiguity in the sequence of how actions and card effects are resolved.  Maybe it's the old MTG in me that's resurfacing, but when you have a game that have so many cards interacting with each other, it is all the more important to have a clear set of guidelines to determine the causes and effects so you don't end up with strange and conflicting interpretations.  Agricola is a big offender of that.  Luckily with the sheer number of the unique cards available, this problem doesn't always come up.  Still, the designer should have been aware of this and addressed it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Many actions can be chosen, and you can’t make a wrong decision. Almost everything you do, will make you gain points at the end of the game. What is the right strategy? Go for the vegies or go for your live-stock? Or upgrade your rooms, or…. Or… As said, lots of possibilities and their is almost nothing what is wrong. And that’s what makes this a fun game. You just think out a strategy for yourself, and you play for yourself.

And that’s the point, what I dislike about this game. Their is almost zero interaction between the playes. A game like Le Havre is balanced better that way. Conclusion of this one. This is a nice game, maybe ideal for families and/or non-gamers. On our shelves, it’s placed below Le Havre, and I would pick Le Havre before Agricola to play.

But on the other side. We put all of the tokens in a plain-box. We could set-up a game within 5 minutes, and I think it really has a playing time of 25-30 minutes when you’re playing with just 2. This could be an ideal game to play between soup and potatoes.

RATING: 10

RATING: 10
I broke down and got it. I even took the next step and got the little animal, resources, and farmer bits from Mayday games.

I played 4 2-player games and a couple of solo games in the first week. There is so much to love and hate about this game at the same time.

Hate: the original pieces, the 9 or so double-sided boards that are all the same color, the rules that read like they were translated with one of those really bad online translators.

Love: The game is so much fun though once you get going. The cute theme has helped me suck in players that would never play any other game of comparable weight. The nail-biting tension.
I'm ready for 7,000 expansions...

RATING: 10

Update:  Draft the cards - solves all the problems in this game.  Back up to a 9 rating for me.

2012 Update:  I officially jumped off the Puerto Rico bandwagon and back into the Agricola one.  Agricola up to a 9.5, Puerto Rico down to a 9!

Late 2012 Update:  This is the best thing to ever come out of Germany.  Aside from Chess and Go (which don't really count), a better game has never been created.

RATING: 7.8
Tried it yesterday, and while it proved to be a really massively well thought-out design, it was partly a frustrating experience. Yes, repeated plays could improve this, but the constant feeling of either "I don't have enough turns/resources/workers to do what I want" or "I don't know what I should do first/second/third" was kinda exhausting.
Also the random distribution of occupations and small improvements feels like a gamebreaker, even though it actually isn't (I could win if I hadn't made a mistake on the last turn, and I was the one with less cards played from the starting hand).

It is indeed a good game, but it is really about doing most stuff and not about doing exactly "your stuff". It is also a tad less confrontational than what I like in a game, and fairly long to setup.

All in all, Caylus still owns the top spot in my eurogames and WP list.

RATING: 7
Type: Economic
Number of Players: 2-5
Sub-Type: Worker Placement, Card Drafting, Hand Management
Game Flow: (2 / 4) 
Gameplay: (6 / 6)

Game Length: Long
Game Balance: High
Strategy: High
Luck Factor: Low (Average w/out Variant)
Replay Value: High

Suggested Variants: 
a) Occupation/Improvement Card Drafting (Core Rules Variant)
b) Starting Occupation - Each player may begin the game with one occupation in play

RATING: 8
Don't let the theme scare you off. Agricola is an excellent game and once you start using the more complicated card sets it gains a decent amount of depth and variation between plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After 5+ Plays: This one grew on me after several plays, and is now one of my very favorite games.  The variable startup offered by the cards is truly amazing.  I was, like many people, worried that this would introduce too much luck for a game of this length, but my fears were unfounded.  With 14 cards, there are very few deals that produce truly awful hands.  

After 20+ plays: I've slowed down playing this after burning out on it a bit.  Still, this has a solid spot among my favorite games.  I have begun to avoid 5-player though, partially because of the loss of control, but more because it just starts to take too long, especially if one or two players are playing slowly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Hands down the coolest Eurogame I ever tried. Love the theme, love the "interactive solitaire" mechanics, love the weird cards and even love the solitairy play! Can't get much better than that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
  I bought Agricola for two reasons : it is a high praised game here on BGG and it was on sale. I doubted I would like it because I'm not too fond of worker placement games, especially the ones that take more than 75 minutes to play. It also looked complicated (a gamers game). Well, I didn't have much expectations with Agricola (though I really like some other Uwe Rosenberg's games like Mamma Mia and Bohnanza).

  Well, I'm glad I bought it because this game is a gem! Most worker placement games I know are plain, boring and themeless (read Caylus) : collect 2 blue cubes here, trade them for 1 red cube, blabla... Not in Agricola. The mechanics fit nicely with the theme and a 2-hour game is entertaining through the end. Win or lose, there's really a sense of accomplishment at the end of the game. 

  I only played the family version so far (4 times), so I still have a lot of things to discover in Agricola.

A big 10 for me!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Only one solo play so far but this one was quite impressing. It's unbelievable how many different variants the cards offer. Will update my rating after more games!
Update after 7  plays: this game really rocks. Regardless of solo or multiplayer play - it's really one of the best out there.
Only drawback is the updating and managing of resources, but that's what you have with all complex games like Caylus, Roads & Boats... The diversity of this is incredible: I still haven't even tried all different decks.
Oh and btw: this game can feel almost a bit like role-playing when you first see your cards and try to figure out what your family members should learn first.
Man, this game really rocks...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cool theme of building your own farm. Nice bits with wooden sheeps, pigs and cows.
A significant property of the game is that only a diverse strategy scores points. When you want to specialize you'll get negative points. This results in everyone doing basically the same. There's one factor though that gives variety and that are the many cards. 
Long waiting time between turns, so needs to be played with a small group. Feeding the family pawns is a little bit of a chore gameplay wise. 
Positive things is the theme of building up a farm. It's a good competitive euro to see who gets the most done with the cards he gets.

RATING: 8
I really like this game's mechanics and style. It's visually appealing to see your farm grow out, and the worker placement is great. This game is usually very intense, and stressful, but super enjoyable. I don't enjoy everything quite as much as say Keyflower, mostly because I feel like there's some artificial stress in the game that doesn't need to be there. Great when it's on the table, however, and I won't say no to it if suggested.

RATING: 6.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent example of a worker placement style game. Fairly easy to learn. Play time is at least a couple of hours, even with just two players. Players must build up their farm using their family members to take a variety of actions, the goal being to build the most well-rounded farm. Lot of variation due to different board layouts and wide selection of extra cards to play.

Theme: Farming
Mechanic: Worker placement
Ideal players: 2-4
Length: Long
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
El juego consta de 14 rondas en las cuales cada miembro de la familia (personas) llevará a cabo una acción. Cada acción sólo podrá ser llevada a cabo por una sola persona. Cada ronda queda disponible una nueva acción. El jugador que logre tener la mejor granja (teniendo de todo un poco) será el ganador.
